title: U.S. Military and National and International Diplomacy
descrip: This seminar will review concepts of military strategy, national security policy, U.S. diplomatic relations with other global power centers, and efforts to transform international institutions to address emerging global security threats.

title: The Media and Social Issues - Reporting Inequality
reviews: If this is offered again, I'd highly recommend it. It's challenging, but it helped me to grow as a writer and in my understanding of social issues.
If you are interested in social justice, journalism, and inequality, take this class. I learned a ton about journalistic writing and inequality.
Take it.
Take this class.
This course was inspiring and interesting. It felt unstructured at times, but it was worth taking.
prereqs: Enrollment by application: http://humanities.princeton.edu.
descrip: Protesters have taken to the streets over inequality; it was an impetus for Arab Spring, and has tragic consequences in India and China. We will examine different faces of inequality: health, education, indebtedness, income inequality; media coverage of the marginalized; reporting hunger (it isn't about photographing kids with distended bellies); being citizen reporters. Students will write about inequality by capturing the processes that drive it and telling the story through the lives of ordinary people.

title: Aircraft Flight Dynamics
reviews: Ask questions!

At one point, this class made me doubt my decision to pursue aeronautical engineering as a career.  I expect MAE 332 Aircraft Design will show that it wasn't a mistake.  Here is my review, so you know what to expect.
Lectures constitute a gross abuse of PowerPoint.  It is clear the Prof. Stengel spent significant time on them, but they are ultimately not very useful.  This parallels the assignments for this class well; time consuming, but worthless.  Lectures present a lot of material, but do very little to help the students develop any sort of intuition about the subject matter. Examples in lecture present a ton of data on flight paths and the like, but are provided with little explanation of their significance.  When a student asks a question that cannot be answered directly from the slides, you can actually see the depth of the professor's knowledge, but lectures are otherwise not worthwhile.  The slides are convenient for looking up equations for the homework which is about the most mentally taxing thing you are asked to do.
The assignments are of little benefit to the students.  They do very little to teach flight dynamics and consume a ridiculous amount of time as do all reports.  Students were generally not well prepared to do the assignment, as most assignments produced a series of emails containing clarifications and hints.  Comments on written work were generally requests for "more."  It was never stated why the given explanation was insufficient or what important piece of the explanation had been left out.  Quantity not quality seemed to be goal.
Professor Stengel's book is actually more interesting than his lectures.
I never attended precept, but I hear that they were not very helpful.  Most questions were answered by the professor via email anyway, so it seemed that the preceptors had little role to play.
Change just about anything and it would probably be an improvement.  Assignments should be made more challenging but less time consuming in parti
Be prepared to ask the preceptors lots of questions and to go to the professor for clarification.
Don't take it unless you have to (if you're an MAE). The most boring lectures I've had in awhile.

Get the book for reference but use the lecture slides. Ask questions! you'll win points with Stengel and you'll get better understandings. Make sure you sit on the left side of the classroom though so he sees you!

I learned a decent amount in this course, but only through asking many email questions of professor stengel. Stengel is a brilliant man, he however does not adequately impart his wealth of knowledge in the way he teaches. If he would not read from the slides and work more closely with his AI's this course could be much better.

I would not recommend taking this class unless it is a departmental requirement. In order to do well in this class, it is extremely important to seek out extra help from either Professor Stengel or the TAs.

If you like aircraft, this class is cool. That's why I enjoyed it. But be warned, Professor Stengel is not the most gifted lecturer. He is monotone and reads equations to you, but you will be forced to go to lecture because of his participation grade, and you can't even use electronics because he will get mad at you. BUT talk to him outside of class, he's a really cool and interesting guy who will always want to give you advice on the psets, career, life, whatever. Assignments take a long time, but they're not every week. Get ready to use a lot of MATLAB. The final project is looong. It's not a particularly intellectually demanding course, but it requires a lot of work and sitting through lectures. But let's face it, airplanes are pretty chill.
Make sure you stay on top of the reading and don't hesitate to ask the professor or TA's for help.
Subject material is extremely dry.
Take it if you're interested in planes. Lectures are tough to sit through at times, but Stengel knows a lot about the subject. A decent course.

Take this if you are a senior and interested in aerospace.  Really consider taking spacecraft instead if you are a junior.  This class should have MAE 433 as a prerequisite because the second half of this course is all control theory.  If you're thinking now that you will just buckle down and learn it as you go, think again.  Half of the class is seniors who already have a very good understanding of controls.  All of the juniors really struggled through the material and came away with a disjointed understanding of controls. I don't feel like I got as much out of the course as I should have because I did not have the fundamental knowledge to understand material presented in lecture and expected for problem sets and exams.
This class is required so if you want to do aeronautics (as opposed to astronautics) you have to take it but do not take if you are not an MAE or you will be in over your head.

Unfortunately, this course is not as fun as I expected it would be. The "problem sets" are actually MAE224-style reports which was not the most fitting choice in my opinion. That being said, the material is interesting so try to make the best of it.
You might learn a lot about aircraft and their dynamics but that also comes with much pain and suffering from busy work.
prereqs: MAE 206 and MAE 222 (or MAE 224)..
descrip: Introduction to the performance, stability, and control of aircraft. Fundamentals of configuration aerodynamics. Methods for analyzing the dynamics of physical systems. Characterization of modes of motion and desirable flying qualities. Case studies in aircraft stability and control.

title: Advanced General Chemistry: Materials Chemistry
reviews: A great class that serves to provide the major concepts in introductory chemistry to BSE students. Doesn't require a ridiculous amount of work and is graded pretty fairly. The frequent demonstrations/explosions are the highlight of the class.
Always make sure to read the textbook.

Ask questions during precepts if you feel like you aren't learning anything, or else you will just end up wasting an hour. Definitely do the practice tests. Make sure you thoroughly complete and understand problem sets. Don't be afraid to work with others. For labs, remember that the labs themselves aren't worth that much, but the lab practical and written exam are worth a lot. This means that you should pay attention to the procedure and concepts, and make sure you do all of your labs properly.
Be on top of your readings and homework as easy as it is to just do problems and not read. Try to take 201 i think because the curve is probably easier even if you are an engineer.
CHM 207 is advanced gen chem. It will move faster and into difficult material so make sure you understand basic chemistry concepts.
Consistently do the readings and try and stay engaged during the lectures.
Definitely do the reading and take time to understand your mistakes on the problem sets. Also study buffers!!!(despite what the TA's say).
Definitely go to precepts, so much is taught in those.

Do not make silly mistakes when taking tests. 
Office hours really help.
Do not take it unless it is a requirement for your major. Not good for humanities students. Read the textbook too and do all of the recommended problems.

Do the readings and the Psets and don't rely on the practice exams. When taking tests look at how many points are awarded per question and use that as a time scale for what to focus on. (Way too many points are awarded for multiple choice questions)
Do your reading.
Don't be intimidated that this course looks like a more advanced version of CHM201. While it technically is, the difference is minute, unlike courses like PHY103 and PHY105.
Don't take this unless you have to.
Especially if you don't enjoy labs, consider placing out of this class. While the class was enjoyable, it's not good enough to sacrifice another class for.
Expect to dedicate a few hours per week for readings. I was unable to keep up with them and fell behind slightly, but was able to catch up later. Professor Cava is amazing. Try it.
GO TO PRECEPT!!!!!!!
Get good at reading the book efficiently! It can be really interesting if you dedicate the time to read it thoroughly, although that can become rather time consuming if you're not careful.
Go to lecture.
Go to lecture. Read the book. Go to precept. Do your homework. You'll do just fine.
Go to office hours and every precept! Don't be afraid to ask questions and seek extra help.
Go to precept
Good Class, needed for Premed
Great class, not too hard and also pretty interesting.
Great course!
I recommend taking this class if you are deciding between 207 and 201

I think this course is the better option for people with a more mathematical/logical mindset who prefers doing calculations. Most of the exams consist of calculation problems. Although more material is covered, I think the grade boundaries are more relaxed as less pre-meds take it compared to CHM201 and so I think it is less competitive. Definitely take if you are a BSE, don't let the 'advanced' bit in the name of the course scare you, it is basically the same as 201.
I would advise the student to attend precepts if anything is unclear for them, since they are an effective time for clarification.

I would definitely take it because Professor Cava is really interesting and it gives you a good chance to see the basics of Chemistry. Although I am not currently considering majoring in Chemistry, there were some points in time where I was seriously considering changing majors because of this course.
If I had to retake the course, I would read before lecturers.

If somebody told you that Chem. 207 is the same level as Chem. 201, just with a focus more pertinent for Engineers, I'm pretty sure they were lying. From what I know it was much more accelerated. If you do take this course, talk to your professors individually. Professor Bocarsly was extremely helpful and willing to give me extra attention when I needed it. Also, work problem sets with classmates, and help each other understand the material! Lastly, don't get behind, or you will be in a massive amount of emotional pain. I'm serious.

If you are a student considering General Chemistry, please take this course! Especially over CHM 201! I am an AB MOL major and took this because of a scheduling conflict, but it was definitely for the best.
If you enjoy demonstrations and chemistry, take this class.
If you find the material interesting, take it. But be willing to deal with difficult labs, difficult tests, and often unfair grading.
If you genuinely like chemistry, take this course! Dont be fooled by "advanced" marking, it is not hard at all.
If you had to choose between Chem 201 or this class, choose this one.
If you have had some basic chemistry knowledge and is considering between this and CHM201, take this course. Much more stimulating and interesting. Can be tough at times but totally worth it.

If you have to take chemistry, or have any interest in the subject, this is a great class. The professors are very engaging and approachable, and the demonstrations are fun. Lab reports are pass/fail and are mainly there to ensure you learn how to handle yourself in the lab and can pass the laboratory exam at the end of the semester. Exams are fair, and if you have an understanding of the material (even if you haven't memorized a single equation) you can do well.
If you're an engineer, take it. Even if you're not, still take it.
If you're an engineer, take this course over 201.  The problem sets aren't too hard, the exams are fair, the labs are fun.  If you just want to further your chemistry knowledge, take this course.
It is many hours of class time (3 lectures, precept, and lab) but worth it to have Cava!
It was a course worth taking for anyone interested in chemistry and the natural sciences, especially if you have not taken AP Chem.
It's more topics than 201, so if you have a heavy course load, consider 201 instead.
Lecture isn't a must but do the homework.
Make sure that you do the readings prior to lectures and go to all of the lectures. Feel free to drop into the professors' office hours and talk to them. they are amazing individuals and teachers!
Make sure to go to lecture.
Make sure to pay attention in lecture and do all the work.
Make sure you do readings before doing your problem sets.

Much recommended over 201 for BSE majors. Don't feel obligated to attend every lecture - they can be boring and are generally unhelpful for doing the problem sets/doing well on the exams. Make sure to attend all precepts and review sessions and go for extra help.
Not at all

Not easy, but it'd be hard to find someone who doesn't do well in the course if they apply themselves. By that I mean, there are many resources given to us, the teachers are always available for office hours. They aren't overly serious either, and will crack jokes or do funny demos.
Pretty interesting all and all, if you have to take it, it's not that bad. You might even like it.
Read the book and do the example problems.  This will help you more than attending lectures.
Read the material and go to lecture.
Read the text book because lectures don't give you all the material that is on exams.  Attend and prepare for precept; always work hard on homework and in lab.
Read the textbook before going to precepts and lectures.
Read the textbook. Go to precept, especially if you have Colleen. Also go to office hours.
TAKE THIS COURSE!!!!! Seriously, take it. Cava and Bocarsly are a thousand times worth it.
Take 207 (especially over 201) - it's interesting, fun, and a good introduction to chemistry.
Take it if you really like chemistry.

Take it! It is a great class and very well taught. The professors are great and make the class and lectures very interesting. The precepts are very helpful, and there are many review sessions that help students understand the course.
Take it. The lecturers are awesome, would recommend this over 201, especially for engineers. You will come out loving solid state chemistry.
Take this class if you have a strong chemistry background from high school. You will learn a lot!
Take this class! It is by far the most engaging class I have taken at Princeton, and I am not a fan of chemistry. Professor Cava is a sensei.

Take this course if you need to fill pre-med/lab reqs but still want a fast-paced, challenging course. If you have a good preceptor like I did, I highly recommend attending precept and using him/her as a resource.

Take this course instead of CHM 201 if you are an engineer! The general vibe of the class is more engineering focused and has a lot less of the premed competitiveness to it. The materials science focus is also just interesting for any engineer no matter what department you might end up choosing. I learned a lot about the materials around me.
Take this course over CHM 201!
Take your time in lab.
The class was very well taught and organized overall, and I enjoyed it a lot.  It made me want to major in chemistry (although I am still going to be an engineer...).

This course is a challenge. I'm not going to sugar-coat it in any other way - it's really one of those courses where you have to "get" the material *and* put in a significant amount of work on problem sets and concept comprehension based on textbook reading just to do passably well. If you're willing to work hard and you have a decent high school background in Chemistry, though, the course can be a real blast. It is materials chemistry, so to that extent you'll learn interesting topics about the useful chemical properties of different substances that you wouldn't learn anywhere else.

If you have a weak background in chemistry from high school, though, don't take this course without having done some supplementary work on Chemistry during the summer. Unless you do nothing but study chemistry, you will almost invariably fall behind.

And I hate to say it, but if you're pre-med and watching your GPA, this may not be the course for you either. There's a reason that pre-meds usually take 201-202 rather than 207-202, and it's consistent with what I've heard from my numerous friends in 201 - 201 grades easier, it spoon-feeds you more (thank you Alex, their system of online exercises), and prior extensive knowledge of chemistry is not assumed.

That being said, if you're a chemistry person and looking for an intellectual challenge, 207 is the way to go!
This course is fantastic if you think you can grasp basic chemistry fairly quickly and want to understand scientific and engineering applications.
This course was pretty good, I recommend taking it over CHM 201. Readings aren't really necessary as long as you understand the concepts. Tests and homework were fair. Go to precept, it helps a LOT.
This is a fun and interesting course, the material is not easy, but not super difficult, and the professors are great in lecture and as people in general.
WORK HARD. DO NOT FALL BEHIND. Do not sleep in lecture.
Well if you are an engineer and don't place out, you have to do it but its not bad- you might even have fun! Chem majors, I guess its just the start for you..
Work hard.
Would NOT recommend for  people who are just pre-med. Engineers, take this. Everyone else-- take 201.
Would recommend for other students because it is a pretty relaxed class and has interesting topics.
be excited about chemistry!
do the reading on time and utilize the resource center. check your homework with friends because points add up to help you!
go to lecture, the demonstrations are awesome
prereqs: Concurrent registration in MAT 103 or equivalent placement is required..
descrip: CHM 207 is an introductory course in chemistry with examples drawn from materials science. The basic concepts of chemistry are introduced: stoichiometry, reaction types, equilibria, thermodynamics, quantum mechanics, and chemical bonding. These concepts are applied in discussions of the structure, reactions, and properties of technologically important materials: metals, semiconductors, ceramics, and polymers. This course is designed as a one term introduction to chemistry, however it may be coupled with CHM 202 to fulfill medical school requirements in general chemistry.

title: Fundamentals of Neuroscience
reviews: !!!!!!! Definitely take this course if you have any interest. Graziano is really entertaining in a dry way, and the material you learn is more than enough to keep a conversation going at dinner.
A great introductory neuroscience class. Professor Graziano is wonderful and funny.
Absolutely take it if you have any interest in it at all and can handle Princeton science courses.
Although the tests are based entirely off of the lecture, it is useful to read the textbook also.
Always attend the lectures and take very good notes.
Attend every lecture.
Be prepared for a lot of memorizing.
Be ready for a lot of material. But in saying that the material is really interesting and will keep your attention
Curve sucks.
Decide if you want to deal with this or not. You will learn something. Is it worth the time?

Definitely take this course if you are at all interested in neuroscience! This class takes a biology approach as it looks at the systems behind how we gain, integrate,and process the information behind our senses and ability to respond to our environment. The workload is really chill but you still learn a huge amount
Does what the title says.

Don't let this class color your expectations about the neuroscience certificate. While Graziano is a decent lecturer, the rest of the course was miserable. Exams were all multiple choice and required memorization of the most specific details ever. They were really tests of minutiae rather than tests of knowledge. Just make it through this class, then you can take the neuro classes that are actually interesting and well organized.
Don't take it if you're not a science person.

Evaluations in the past will say that you don't have to read the textbook to do well in this course. Unfortunately, they're wrong. Lectures are entertaining and extremely informative, but the information presented is often scattered and difficult to connect. In order to understand how this information pieces together, it is critical to read the textbook and take notes on the material. If you pay attention in lecture and do the readings, you can almost guarantee yourself a good grade.
Everyone should take it.

GO TO LECTURE. What is in lecture is on the exam. You go to the book when you don't understand/want to clarify something he said in lecture.
What you learn is really cool.
Go to ALL the lectures and take meticulous notes.
Go to lecture! Lectures are not only interesting but you'll learn a lot there and studying is so much easier when you know the stuff from lecture. Also, Professor Graziano is just a great lecturer.
Go to lecture! You won't want to miss it (seriously you won't do well on the exam if you skip for one, and honestly i never wanted to miss! it's so interesting!)
Go to lecture.
Go to lectures - SUPER IMPORTANT. Take detailed notes. You think you'll remember what he was talking about later, but you really don't.

Graziano is a very engaging lecturer, and his lectures were always very interesting. Take very very good notes though, as the exams are almost entirely based on what he says in class, with a couple random concepts mixed in. Reading the book is totally optional when it comes to doing well on the exam. Mainly study from your notes.
I definitely would recommend it.  Go to lecture, they get a bit boring sometimes but it is worth it for the exams.  The precepts are pretty fun too, a lot of dissections.
I recommend this class to both science inclined and genuinely interested students. I would advice taking meticulous notes, recording lectures for later reference, and asking questions when necessary.
I would suggest recording the lectures so you don't miss out on any information.
I would take this course if you want a fundamental understanding of neuroscience.  Professor Graziano is the best.
I would tell students to budget a lot of study time for this course, and attend all the lectures and take good notes. If you pay attention along the way, you should do well!

If Graziano is teaching this course, YOU HAVE NO CHOICE BUT TO TAKE IT. Best lecturer I've had at Princeton. His lectures may be 80 minutes long, but he kept my interest every second. He's actually discovered and researched many of the topics that are discussed in this course, so there's no better person to learn a theory from than the person who developed it himself. He's the best.
If it's taught by Graziano, take this course! Just be careful when final time comes around because it is super detail-oriented. You need to memorize memorize memorize.

If you are interested in this subject and might major/certificate in it, take it.  If you don't like memorizing, don't take it.  Non-science majors think about doing NEU 101... that's what I should have done.

If you are not a pre-med, let alone a science major, it will be pretty tough to succeed in this class. The vast majority of the class are pre-meds who memorize everything to the last detail and excel at the multiple choice exams.
If you enjoy neuroscience, take this course.
If you like biology courses this will be very interesting for you. The material isn't too difficult to understand but there is a lot of memorization.

If you're a neuro person or are interested in taking any more advanced neuro courses, you're going to have to take this course since it's a pre-requisite. And it's not going to be a waste of your time, since Graziano gives clear explanations of the subject material and presents facts in an understandable manner. If you struggle with memorization or if acronyms and jargon are your pet peeves, though, this course (and the field of neuroscience!) may not be for you, since the field is immersed in both and much of that acronym-obsession spills over into the course. It's not a bad thing per se, it's just something of which you as a prospective student should be aware.

If you're not a neuro person and are only looking for an interesting, brain-related ST, I'd choose NEU 101 based on friends' reviews - apparently the experiments are the same as in NEU 501 (read: cutting-edge and interesting), except the professors and lab TA's set up everything in advance for you, unlike in 501 where you have to design the experiments yourself. I'll leave the specifics to reviewers of NEU 101 to confirm or deny.
If you're interested in neuroscience, or want a somewhat less boring distribution requirement, I'd take it.
If you're interested in pursuing medicine or neuroscience, take it. Graziano is a great lecturer and the course is not too much work.
Interesting but very memorization-heavy. Don't take with another course of that nature.
It's easy to just cram for the test but you should go to every lecture if you want to do well because the book readings are not enough/not clear what it is from the book that we need to know.
It's not really going to teach you a new way of thinking, but it's a good introduction to the brain.
It's worth taking if you have an interest in neuroscience. If you don't, you'll find it dreadfully boring.
It's worth taking; attend lectures and take good notes.
Lecture based, however the final is very hard and is based on terms in the textbook.
Lectures are good and basically mandatory, as all of the course material will be found in them. Go to lecture or get good notes from someone, and memorize.
Like an AP bio class. All multiple choice, all memorization.
Lots of memorization. It'd be a good idea to memorize the material over the semester instead of cramming before the midterm and final.
Make sure to go to every single lecture and take great notes.
Make sure to take very good notes during lecture.
Make sure you pay attention in lecture and take great notes because the tests are very lecture based.

NEU 258 is way more technical than NEU 101. It is very similar to the structure of mol bio classes (lots of memorization). However, it does not have a lab. You should take it to gauge your interest in the neuroscience certificate.

Only 2 things matter: the midterm and the final. Kind of intimidating since there's no way to gauge your knowledge until the midterm, so it's always better to overprepare even though memorizing all the details may take a lot of time. There are a couple precept quizzes here and there on research papers, but those grade are negligible. 

Overall, go to every lecture, take very detailed notes, and memorize your notes. Review very well before each test and you'll be fine.

Only take it if you have a strong interest in the material and are prepared to do lots of memorization for the exams.  Take detailed notes!!!  The exams are based on his lectures, including specifics you can't find in the textbook or anywhere else.

Pay attention to the outlines. 

-Make flash cards on key concepts as you go.

-THe course is broken down basically through the different cortexes you cover. Organizing the material in this way may help (i.e., cerebral, sensorimotor, visual, parietal, etc. )

Really difficult class with a lot of dense material and would only recommend if you're planning to put in a lot of time studying during the semester even though the whole grade rests on the midterm and final.
Stay on top of readings. Ask questions if you have any. And take this course with Graziano. He's great. Take this class.
TAKE GOOD NOTES.
Take it even if you are not a science person, very interesting and easy workload besides studying for exams.
Take it for the subject matter, not the professor or the method of teaching. You must be very proactive to do well in this course.
Take it if you are or might be interested in neuroscience.

Take it if you think you'll like learning a lot of facts about the subject material. It's not easy to memorize all this stuff if you aren't into the systems. Gets less cool after the beginning. Graziano is a great lecturer.
Take it iff the subject matter is interesting to you.
Take it with Graziano!
Take it! Even if you're not sure about it, you might as well. And if you end up not liking it that much, you can always PDF.
Take it, especially if you're interested in neuroscience.
Take it. It's very interesting, even for non-concentrators. Great STN.
Take the course if you are interested in neuro!
Take this course!! Funniest lectures and interesting.
Take this course.  Graziano is a really really good professor.
Take this if you want to understand the brain. Very fascinating topic and course to take.

The course material is really interesting and provides a good foundation for more complex neuroscience courses. However, the lectures are disorganized and the amount of memorization needed for the tests can be overwhelming. Make sure you go to every lecture since the readings don't cover everything and nothing is posted online. Come to precept with specific questions.

The course was interesting in general. I don't feel like I acquired a really in-depth knowledge of neuroscience, but if you think you like the subject and just want to dip your toes in, you should definitely take this class. Michael Graziano is a really interesting guy, though sometimes his lectures feel a bit rushed. The midterm is basically based completely off of his lectures, but if you want a more in-depth understanding, you should definitely keep up with the chapters in the book.

The course was interesting, and would be really exciting if I were more science/biology oriented. If you're pre-med, this is probably a good class, but it isn't the best class with which to simply fill a distribution requirement.

There aren't any problem sets or papers, just a midterm, final and a couple small precept quizzes, so it's a very manageable work load. The exams are multiple choice, too, which I personally loved. I'd definitely recommend this to anyone interested in biology and the brain who are looking for an introduction to neuroscience.
This class is very memorization-heavy. Cramming for exams is practically impossible, so I wouldn't recommend it!

This course is difficult. Probably good if you want to PDF because there aren't many assignments and the focus is on the lectures. Go to the lectures!! He draws great/useful diagrams and the exams are mostly lecture material. Lot of memorization but some really cool and interesting findings.

This course was fantastic. Prof. Graziano is a fantastic lecturer. I'm a senior and I can safely say that he is one of the best lecturers that I've had at Princeton. Exams were fair, and the text and precepts were really good.
This is NOT an easy class for a humanities major. I have no idea how this class ended up on that list.
This is a good pdf class.

This is a great general interest course. If you get the right professor, there will be almost no homework or readings, and lectures will be engaging. The material is not too difficult and it's quite interesting. Graziano is highly recommended. He truly loves the material and once you get used to him you will love him.
This is an amazing course to take with Graziano. It's a ton of material, but if you're genuinely interested in neuroscience, this is the course to take.

This is not a course to be taken too lightly. It is not easy but it is also doable if one actually goes to all of the lectures and takes good notes. Doing the readings helps to clarify information but it is also important not to get bogged down in all of the nitty gritty detail that the book goes into.
Very dry material, a lot to memorize.

Very informative and educational course. Professor G. is a brilliant (and at times funny) lecturer. What you need to do to succeed in this course is take good notes during lecture. You need, and I mean need, the lecture notes for the exams.   A good class to take overall, and managable workload. The precepts are also managable and at times fun with dissections. Good luck!
Very interesting-convinced me to pursue a neuro certificate.

You should take this course if you are at all interested in Neuroscience, Computer Science, or Psychology.  It is one of the most interesting courses I have ever taken at Princeton but be prepared for a wall of information.  There is so much information packed into each lecture that it is very different from most classes I have taken before.  That being said I loved it.
go to lecture; for the experience if nothing else
good for neuro certificate seekers
interesting lectures; doesn't require much work throughout the semester and can be crammed for
minimal workload; easy to understand... just take notes as if your life depended on it
take very good lecture notes, skim the book, and don't worry about anything else
very individual
prereqs: Introductory Psychology, Biology, and Chemistry, at least at the high school level, are recommended background for enrollment. Students who have taken PSY 208 must have instructor's permission to take NEU 258 because they cover similar materials. NEU 258 is more detailed and leads into NEU 259 as a two-term sequence. NEU 258 is required for the Neuroscience Certificate..
descrip: This is a survey course on neuroscience, focusing mainly on sensory and motor processing in the primate brain. How does information from the outside world get into the brain, what neuronal pathways does it follow, how is it processed and used to construct an internal model of three-dimensional reality, and how does the brain choose and coordinate the correct behavioral response?

title: Introduction to Urban Studies
reviews:
I took this course out of general interest--it is by far the worst course I have taken in my seven semesters at this school. Even if you are interested in the literary/aesthetic representations of urban space, take another class. Prof. Massey is checked out and canceled 4 lectures. Take it with another professor!

The readings, however, are amazing. Read them outside of this class.
Massey isn't great lecturer but material is interesting
Watch out for lack of communication.
descrip: WWS 201 is the gateway course for the undergraduate urban studies certificate. It offers an interdisciplinary survey of urban topics to prepare students for later specialization. It begins with an analysis of the origin and evolution of cities, taking students from pre-urban foraging societies through early 20th century industrialization and urbanization. It surveys reactions to industrial urbanism as expressed in art, literature, architectural design and then considers later counter-reactions in the area of design. It concludes with an analysis of post-industrial urbanism and contemporary thinking about cities in the US and around the world.

title: Readings in Japanese Religions - Medieval and Modern Perspectives
descrip: In this seminar we will do close readings of primary texts in Japanese Religions representing a range of historical periods and genres, along with relevant scholarship in Japanese and English. Readings may include doctrinal texts, ritual manuals, hagiography, vernacular sermons, commentarial literature, and essays. To some extent, readings may be chosen to accommodate student research interests. Japanese reading ability and some experience with classical Japanese and/or kanbun required.

title: Advanced Italian
reviews: Always do the homework and go to class!
Definitely take it if you're interested in the language. It's easy and lots of fun.

Go to class and do the readings. You will learn so many new words simply by doing a good job with the book. Especially since the words are repeated; it's a lot easier than trying to learn new vocab through flashcards or lists.
Great course! Very interesting and lots of fun.

I definitely recommend this class to any student interested in learning Italian from two charismatic Italian professors.  Take this course only if you are prepared to commit yourself to learning the language, because a language class is a time commitment.
I enjoyed this course, and the teachers were very enthusiastic and helpful. I learned more in this one semester of italian than i did in all four years of high school italian.

If you believe you are pretty good at Italian, take this course, you can always drop back down. You dont have to know double object pronouns or relativo stuff before hand, u lern it in class. If your good on different verb tense You should be fine.
It's a good class for improving Italian.
Italian is a fun and fantastic language, take it!
Italian is a fun language to take!
Italian is very fun, and easy to pick up if you know another Romance language or Latin!
Learning a new language can be really difficult, so just be patient with yourself! It can be a really rewarding experience.
Most people will take this course to complete the language requirement, and I will say that Italian is a very rewarding language to study at Princeton.
Show up to class and do your homework.
Take this class if you want to finish the language requirement.
prereqs: ITA 102 or Instructor's permission..
descrip: This course is designed to help the student who already has some background in Italian to develop greater facility in speaking and writing Italian on an advanced level. Principally oral approach. Classes are conducted entirely in Italian.

title: Contemporary East Asia
reviews: Do readings and watch the films, prepare some questions about them, and you will do fine.
Do the readings and don't miss class.
Get excited.
If you want to learn about East Asia in an introductory setting, definitely take this course! Great lectures and assignments are fair all-around
If you're thinking about it; take it!
It is very important to do the readings. Lectures are very interesting.
Prof. Leheny is an amazing lecturer and whatever class he teaches, you can be certain that it will be thought provoking.
Take it if you have any interest whatsoever in anything East Asian.

Take this course as an intro to East Asia, but don't expect to learn anything super-detailed. Rather, this course teaches you how to approach how East Asia is perceived with a healthy dose of skepticism.
Take this course if you want a good overview of contemporary East Asia, especially from a societal perspective. It is graded harshly though, so don't take this if you are looking for an easy grade.
Take this course if you want a well-taught class that provides an excellent overview of the issues the region currently faces.
This is a great introduction to many important issues regarding East Asia. Leheny is a hard grader, but the class is so interesting. Take it!
descrip: This course is an introduction to the societies, cultures, and politics of contemporary East Asia. The rise of East Asia has inspired Western observers to reflect on the ways in which capitalism, democracy, and modern social relationships can unfold in different ways. It has also prompted debates about the development of political systems, about the most efficient and just ways to organize economic growth, and even about what constitutes Asia. Although the course will focus especially on China, Japan, South Korea, and Vietnam, we will draw special attention to issues that cut across national boundaries.

title: Selected Topics in Solid-State Electronics - Advanced Topics in Electronic and Optoelectronci Materials and Devices
reviews: Ask questions! The professors are there to present their research. If you find something particularly exciting, schedule to meet with the respective professors!
It is a very good course, you can have a broad view in this field
It's required course. No one can escape.
descrip: Introduction to the topics and methods of research in electronic materials and devices, providing an overview of current research of the faculty in electronic materials and devices, and in optical and optoelectronic engineering.

title: Introduction to Microeconomics
reviews: A lot of people complain about Professor Farber, but I don't really see why.  Are there parts of his problem sets that are vague?  Yes.  Doesn't mean he's a bad teacher.  If you go over them enough and check your work (both of which I was, unfortunately, not in the habit of doing), you'll be fine.

A solid intro course. Professor Farber gives good perspectives on basic topics, particularly from his area of interest (labor). Material not too difficult, but more involved than some intro econ courses at other universities (in a good way).
Absolutely do not take ECO 100 with Professor Farber!  Only take it another professor is teaching it.
Attend all lectures and precepts and do all readings!
Attend precepts, they are very helpful!
Be prepared for the unexpected.
Be prepared to learn a lot of the concepts on your own time.
Be prepared to self-study and focus on practice problems.
Consider the professor before choosing the course.
Definitely take ECO100 before you graduate...it'a a basic course that is useful for anyone and teaches you how to think outside of the box.
Definitely take the class!
Definitely take this course it is an extremely interesting course.
Do all the readings, if you can't face the lectures, the slides give you enough information. Don't take this course with Farber.
Do not ever take it with Farber.
Do not take it with Professor Farber.
Do not take this course in the fall. The professor in the spring is much better. I regret taking this course. I wish I had dropped it after midterms, and taken it the following spring.
Do the problem sets
Do the problem sets with friends. It's much easier, and you're more likely to understand the concepts.
Do the readings, all of the problem sets, and go to precept. Lectures are optional.
Do your readings thoroughly and you should be fine.
Don't rely on lectures, teach yourself and go to office hours.
Don't take it unless it's not Farber or you have to.
Don't take it unless you have to as a prerequisite
Don't take it unless you really have to.
Don't take this course under Professor Farber.
Don't take this course. It's nothing that you can't teach yourself or learn from watching the news/intuition.
Don't. Take it with a different professor. It can't get much worse.
Draw lots of graphs.
ECO 100 is a good course to take of you have a general interest in economics, as it does help one to understand some of the dynamics occurring when individuals make choices.
Economics is everywhere, it would be wise to take the class even if you're not required to.
Ehhh might as well you're at Princeton so it's your destiny.
Every student should take this course as a part of their Princeton education.
Expect to put in a lot of individual work.

For many people, taking this class is a must because of departmental prerequisites. However, I would still recommend the course overall. The extremely fundamental way of economic thinking is taught. However, be prepared for a lecture/precept that can be fairly (read: very) boring, especially with Prof. Farber.

GO TO MCGRAW. So incredibly useful to have personalized attention. Study groups are also your friend. I recommend the course only because of the applicability of the concepts involved - Farber could use some work.
Get a good preceptor.
Get a tutor. It'll help.
Go to McGraw and have a study group

Go to the professor or preceptor for help.  Also go to McGraw.
Great class to take, even if just for fun.
Highly recommend. Material is covered at varying paces but if you stick with it and work hard it will be rewarding
I do not recommend Farber as a microeconomics lecturer if you haven't taken economics before.
I have found that reviewing the lectures slides can be very helpful, and perhaps, so will you.
I mean most of you have to take it. Don't go to lecture with Farber, no point.
I would reccomend they keep up with their notes and their own personal studies of the material.

I would recommend taking it with a different professor unless you already have a strong basis in micro and need to take it this semester. At least half the class had taken econ in high school and were thus less affected by the poor quality of the teaching. This was my first exposure ever to economics and it was a huge struggle trying to learn the material and keep up on my own. DEFINITELY start a study group right away with other students, preferably ones who have background in econ. Meet upperclassmen who can help you. You will need all the outside help you can get, especially google and resources online! Be prepared to put a lot of work in to understand what's going on if econ is new to you.

I would recommend this class to anybody wondering about economics as a possibility who had never tried it before. It is not fascinating but provides very basic and useful information while giving students a feel for the discipline.
I would say to make sure you take the time to read through all of the readings and take very effective notes.

I would tell other students to read the textbook before lectures and to not freak out about taking notes during lectures because material is covered too quickly and not in a way that is easy to understand.
I would tell them to go through the slides after lecture to make sure they understood everything, it will make it a lot easier when doing problem sets and studying.

I would tell them to read the lecture slides before and after the lecture to ensure that they understand the material. I would also recommend that they start the problem set as early as possible and have concrete questions ready at office hours.
I would try to take this course somewhere else during the summer, before taking it at Princeton.
I wouldn't take this class unless you already have a strong passion for economics and need it to continue on for your degree.

I wouldn't take this if you know any econ already because it is completely trivial, and if you don't then go learn it on your own cause the material is easy.  If you do take it, avoid Sungmun Choi as a preceptor.

If Farber is teaching, lectures can be skipped fairly liberally. Attend precepts to pick up on more complex concepts, read everything assigned, and provided that you have some basic common sense econ-wise, you'll be fine.

If it's not a prereq, don't take it unless you're actually interested in microeconomics. I'd never taken one economics course, but a solid number of students had taken the AP. It kind of sets up the class so you have that number of people who virtually breeze by, then the people who actually need to put in a lot of effort, and then those who need to put in effort but don't want to. If you're in the first group, take it for kicks, I suppose. If you're in the second group like me, only take it if you need to or genuinely want to.
If it's required, just get it over with. Put effort into your problem sets, and look over exams when you get them back.
If taking it with Farber the lecture is word for word from powerpoints, make sure you know how to do every single thing on the problem sets and you should be fine for exams.

If you feel like you don't have a lot of economics knowledge and want a base or if you're interested in econ this is a good course to take.
If you have the option to take the course with another professor, do it.
If you like econ, go for it!  Be warned that the curve sucks, but if you can deal with that and get a good preceptor the class is fine.  Problem sets suck though!  Always do the readings.
If you need an SA, take it. If you think you might be interesting in Economics, take it. If you are neither of those things, then don't take it.
If you never did calculus, get a tutor early in the semester and go to mcgraw before sunday night.

If you're looking for an SA and want to know something about Economics... take it, I guess. But I feel like you could learn just as much just reading books on your own. Having problem sets and exams to force you to learn was nice, though.

If you've never taken economics, don't take this class. You would understand much more just reading a textbook on your own time. If you have to take this course as a pre-requisite for economics, don't expect anything interesting.

If you've taken econ in high school, or are really interested in learning the basics, take this course. However, go into the course knowing that lectures are terrible and you'll have to do the learning on your own (with some help from precept). 

If you're just taking this for a distribution requirement, you could probably find a better one. 

Again, the primary explanation for my generally negative review is the quality of lectures and the ability of Professor F to clearly communicate organized concepts.
It helps a lot to work with a small group on problem sets.

It is a good course but the problem sets can be difficult. Take it only if you are really interested in Microeconomics and are willing to devote a considerate amount of time and effort to studying the material and preparing for the exams.
It is fairly challenging and reading the book definitely helps add to the lecture and precept because not everything can be covered in a fifty-minute lecture/precept.
It's a good introductory class. It is important to keep up with the readings, so you are not overwhelmed during finals time.

I feel that if you're more quantitative orientated, you'll have no problem with this course because the equations are very simple.  Try to get Judd Cramer as a preceptor.  Not sure if I would recommend it to people are not truly interested in economics but just want a social analysis class.

There really isn't much need to go to lecture if you are good at keeping up with the readings, and read over the powerpoints.
Think about it again: Do you want to take with Farber or other professor?
This course is a good general course in solidifying and teaching the basics of micro economics.

This course is a nice, interesting but not too hard course. You should have some interest for the subject or you might not find it very fun. The workload is not too high but you should keep up well with problem sets and understanding material or you will find yourself with a surprising amount of things to learn by the end of the semester.

Try to take it with Rosen if you can but don't freak out if you get Farber--he's manageable. Do take ECO 100 at least sometime before you graduate though. Farber gets harder towards the end so don't get complacent with your midterm grade.
Unless you need to, don't take it.
Use the resources available to you i.e. study halls at the McGraw center for problem sets.

While Professor Farber is excellent in providing general academic, career, and life advice, take the class with another professor (Professor Rosen from what I've heard) if you want to learn the basics of microeconomics well.
