wait for a different professor if you must take this class and have no econ experience
wait for another professor. i've heard others are better.
descrip: Economics is the study of how people and societies deal with scarcity. This course focuses on the consumption decisions of individuals and the production decisions of firms in the context of a market system for allocating scarce resources. The advantages and disadvantages of market systems and the role of government in resource allocation are also discussed.

title: Population Genetics (Half-Term)
descrip: This is an introductory course on empirical and theoretical population genetics. The first half of the course covers the primary population level processes (mutation, drift, selection, migration, recombination, mating patterns, population size and subdivision) and the second half focuses on methods of measuring genetic variation and testing population genetic models. The course will also cover some advanced topics such as coalescent theory, models of the evolution of sexual reproduction, genetic hitchhiking, speciation models. A working knowledge of basic molecular genetics, algebra and statistics is assumed.

title: Readings in Modern Korean l
reviews: Great course. It's a really a great look into the  modern classics in Korean literature.

I think that as long as you find the readings and the history engaging, the writing assignments - though they are very frequent - are not bothersome at all. Because there is a lot of discussion about pretty complex things it would be good if you are able to discuss your thoughts freely in Korean. If not, this class still provides a great opportunity to learn to express yourself in Korean.
Take it if you are a native speaker who'd like to improve your Korean!

Take this course if you want to improve your Korean writing abilities. Unless you are PDFing, do NOT expect this to be an easy class. The class requires more time than you would think, but it's totally worth the work because everything you do in the class is relevant. You also get a great sense of contemporary Korean history.

Taking KOR405 did more to improve my Korean than both KOR401 and KOR402 combined. I came into the class not very confident in my writing abilities, but I now feel that I can write roughly at the level of a high school senior or college freshman.

The workload is not light. You learn a lot if you didn't know much about Korean history and politics. You also write, read, and speak more in Korean, so definitely helpful if you want to improve in that area! Class is small, so I recommend taking the course with people who seem to be about your level in terms of fluency in Korean.
You must take this class! Not too many people, chill environment, fun readings and movies, awesome professor.
prereqs: KOR 402 or instructor's permission..
descrip: The 5th-year Korean course is designed to advance students' reading and writing skills to the superior level and to promote a deeper understanding of the Korean language, culture, society, and history. Readings cover various types of authentic materials (e.g., newspaper articles, editorials, think pieces, essays, and literary short stories). Discussion and presentation skills in formal settings (e.g., academic, professional) are also emphasized. Class discussions are conducted in Korean.

title: Neuroscience of Being Human, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Survey of Selected Greek Literature - Survey of Greek Literature
descrip: A survey of major literary forms and works from the Archaic to the Greco-Roman period.

title: Self Interest and Other Regardingness
descrip: This course draws on research in political science, psychology, economics, and sociology to explore the role of self-interest, group-interest, and other-regardingness in the formation of mass political preferences. Our focus will be the distinctions and commonalities within the diverse scholarship on social norms, psychological traits, moral reasoning, communalism and civic virtue, duty and obligation, altruistic punishment, and sociotropic evaluations. Outcomes of interest include political participation, policy preferences, vote choice, inter-group attitudes and behavior, and citizens' broader understandings of the political sphere.

title: Early China - The Qinghua University Bamboo Manuscripts
descrip: We will survey the recently published first volume of the manuscripts acquired by Qinghua University, analyze and translate selected chapters, and reflect upon their relationship to received texts. By reviewing current text-critical scholarship, we introduce the various methodological and technical issues in reading early Chinese manuscripts. We draw comparisons to the manuscripts in the Guodian and Shanghai Museum corpus and consider the implications of manuscript studies for the study of early intellectual history.

title: Planets in the Universe
reviews: A fun and engaging course for a science major that wouldn't overwhelm a non-science major.

As the description says, this course presumes very little knowledge of astrophysics. Math is kept to simple algebra and trigonometry (but there's lots of trig.) Homework was simple, midterm was pretty easy, too. It's not too hard to get an A on the tests. There's also a non-optional observing portion of the course, which was very interesting but a little tedious.

Bakos is great and the lectures are interesting. However, be warned that you are left on your own to do astrophysics in the problem sets. If you don't have a science background and can't find time to attend weekly office hours, the homework may be difficult. On the bright side, observing planets is sick
Be ready for the problem sets.  They are by far the most difficult part of the class.
Best professor ever, very interesting subject area, and definitely "do-able"
Do not fall behind with the work and take notes during class, even though he puts all of his slides online.  This will help you to process and encode the information in a more organized fashion.
Do the readings and go to lecture, and it'll be fine. The TAs and Professor were great.
Don't confuse this with Stars for Stoners because it's not that easy. It's very interesting though and if you can commit time to it, I feel getting a good grade would be very possible.
For anyone interested in astronomy or who wants fulfill a science requirement, it is a great class.
Get the observations done as early as you can.
Go to all the review or office hour sessions you can. It is definitely worth it, especially if you don't quite understand something.
Great course. Learned a lot about the universe, it's formation, and current research. Bakos is the man.
I hope you really, really, really like physics.
I would definitely take this course again.  Professor Bakos is awesome and makes the lectures interesting.  He is a very approachable and funny guy.  Take this class.
I would strongly recommend this class. I had no interest or knowledge before taking the class but the professor was so passionate that I got to really enjoy it.
I would tell them that unless they are extremely interested in astronomy, they should opt against taking this class.
If you are interested in astronomy, take this course.

If you are interested in the subject, I advise you to take the class. It is entertaining, and you also get to collaborate with your peers a lot. You will have star parties, observations and astrophotography projects that might sound difficult in the beginning, but once you do them, you will find them very rewarding.
If you are into space, and good with numbers and physics this is an awesome and interesting course.
If you like the subject matter
If you're taking this as a distribution requirement, be warned-- a surprising amount of math for a STN.
Lectures are great; take if it sounds interesting and you don't mind taking a couple nights for observations.

Make time to attend the star parties! This is where some of the best learning takes place. Also, the lectures are very good and you should make a sincere effort to attend all of them and to listen respectfully to the professor. Start the problem sets ahead of time so you're not overwhelmed at the last minute; the same goes for observing with your small groups. Last but not least, enjoy every minute of this course, and start looking at the stars when you go outside at night! It's always good to look up: the intense pace of University life is very conducive to forgetting to seriously think about the bigger picture of our lives and existence.  It is good to appreciate the beauty of our world (and universe) and to approach the other questions that arise from this contemplation.
Not a bad STN
Not a difficult course, and you will learn a lot about a truly interesting subject.

Observation nights were great, and exoplanets are interesting, but most of the course ended up being random information about our own solar system (think elementary school science) and basic physics, which I did not expect and did not appreciate. Take only if the brief (2 weeks our year) unit on exoplanets and Prof. Bakos's enthusiasm makes up for that
Only take if you are very interested, or at least wait for the professor and TAs to get the curriculum together.

Really focus on understanding the concepts behind the formulas and equations. Unfortunately, the professor and assistants often fail to make this clear, leading to unnecessarily confusing math. Also, BE SURE to go to the Star Party's. These are incredible, by far the best aspect of the course. I truly feel sorry for the students who did not go to any star parties.

Stellar. Out of this world, if you will. Professor is truly fantastic. If I had to recommend one astro course for a student's undergraduate career at Princeton, this is the one. Everyone needs a cosmic perspective, and to go through Princeton without having got a taste of astronomy, the oldest of the sciences, would be a tremendous loss.
There is a lot more math/ physics than it seems from the course description.
This course covers a lot of ground. Don't take it if you're looking for an easy grade, but if you're genuinely interested in Astronomy then Professor Bakos is a fantastic and very engaging.
Work hard.
interesting class, not too much work
it is an easy course especially if you are a science or engineering major.
make sure its the same class u think u are signing up for
start problem sets early
yes
prereqs: This course is intended for non-science majors; however, familiarity with high school algebra and geometry will be assumed. An introductory high school physics course will also be useful..
descrip: This is an introductory course in astronomy focusing on planets in our Solar System, and around other stars (exoplanets). The course starts with reviewing the formation, evolution and characterization of the Solar system. Following an introduction to stars, the course will then discuss the exciting new field of exoplanets; discovery methods, basic properties, earth-like planets, and extraterrestrial life. Core values of the course are quantitative analysis and hands-on experience, including telescopic observations. This STN course is designed for the non-science major and has no prerequisites past high school algebra and geometry.

title: Physics of Gases
descrip: Physical and chemical topics of basic importance in modern fluid mechanics, plasma dynamics, and combustion science: statistical calculations of thermodynamic properties of gases; physical equilibria; quantum mechanical analysis of atomic and molecular structure including rotational and vibrational transitions; atomic-scale collision phenomena and excitation and ionization; emission, absorption, and propagation of radiation. Analyses of major greenhouse gases from point of view of molecular absorption and emission properties; discussion of effect of greenhouse gases concentration and disribution on climate equilibria.

title: Seminar in Plasma Physics
reviews: Give the student presenters a chance.
descrip: Advances in experimental and theoretical studies or laboratory and naturally-occurring high-termperature plasmas, including stability and transport, nonlinear dynamics and turbulence, magnetic reconnection, selfheating of "burning" plasmas, and innovative concepts for advanced fusion systems. Advances in plasma applications, including laser-plasma interactions, nonneutral plasmas, high-intensity accelerators, plasma propulsion, plasma processing, and coherent electromagnetic wave generation.

title: Joyce Carol Oates: Fiction and Essays
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Extramural Research Internship
descrip: Full-time research internship at a host institution, to perform scholarly research relevant to student's dissertation work. Research objectives will be determined by advisor in conjunction with outside host. A mid-semester progress review and a final paper are required. Enrollment limited to post-generals students for up to two semesters. Special rules apply to international students regarding CPT/OPT use. Students may register by application only.

title: Advanced Computer Graphics
reviews: Definitely take the course; you'll learn a heck of a lot.
Give yourself more time than you think you need for the assignments.  Know your own interests to help guide the class structure.
I would strongly recommend this course to anyone who wants to learn more about graphics.
Only take it if you're very interested in graphics and ready for rapid learning of advanced concepts

Take it if you have a serious interest in computer graphics. You'll just have to budget a lot of time for the programming assignments, especially image analogies and photon mapping. It does live up to its name of being an advanced graphics class, but if did well in 426, you can handle this, and you will feel quite accomplished for having done so!
Take this course if you want to learn tons and tons more about computer graphics but are also prepared to do the involved assignments.
This is definitely a great course for anyone looking to take the next step in computer graphics research.
Would strongly recommend fellow students with interests in graphics to take this course.
descrip: Advanced topics in computer graphics, with focus on learning recent methods in rendering, modeling, and animation. Appropriate for students who have taken COS426 (or equivalent) and who would like further exposure to computer graphics.

title: Maya Painting
prereqs: ART267 and/or ART268 recommended; ability to read Spanish recommended.
descrip: Painting was the ancient Maya expressive mode par excellence. Whether depicting mythology, history, or hieroglyphic writing, painting was for more private acts of visual consumption than architecture or sculpture. This seminar invites students into this private realm of ancient Maya scribes, nobility, and royal patronage. The course explores the 1500-year history of Maya painting, including murals, ceramics and books. We will consider techniques of production, iconography, aesthetics, and social context. Students will gain basic literacy in Maya writing and training in Maya astronomy.

title: German Literature in the 18th Century - Goethe
descrip: Goethe. Approaches. You have to read Goethe! But how is this possible, given that the "Goethe" in the Sophienausgabe is 142 volumes thick, and the literature on Goethe fills up entire libraries? The seminar departs from this problem in order to find entries into the textual cosmos called "Goethe". The selection and compilation of Goethe-texts is, following the methodical premise of the seminar, already part and parcel of the Goethe-reading.

title: Macroeconomic Theory I
reviews: Just force yourself to practice practice practice for the tests.  Success has a lot to do with being super familiar with doing a few different kind of problems
Just sit back and enjoy the wonderful lectures. And you will learn a lot!
Start the problem sets early and go to every lecture.
descrip: First term of a two-term sequence in macroeconomics. Topics include consumption, saving, and investment; real interest rates and asset prices; long-term economic growth; money and inflation; and econometric methods for macroeconomics.

title: Forms of Realism
prereqs: Reading knowledge of French or German is desirable but not required..
descrip: An investigation of how literary authors use language both to create a sense of "the real" and to question what "the real" may be. Looking closely at forms of description and narration including verbal tense, figural patterns (such as repetition, simile and metonymy), vocabulary, voice, irony, and grammatical construction and syntax, we will study some of extraordinarily complex ways fictions generically termed "realist" bring about an "effect" or apprehension of the real we could not otherwise perceive. Readings in major realist and theoretical texts (incl. Auerbach, Jakobson, Lukacs, Barthes).

title: New Media, Old Media, Dead Media
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Rome, the Eternal City
descrip: The main goal of this course is to acquaint students with the major architectural monuments of ancient and post-classical Rome, paying particular attention to creative transformations of form and meaning. The urban development of the city will be stressed and used to provide a contextual reading of individual buildings and public spaces.

title: Software Engineering for Scientific Computing
reviews: A very nice and very helpful course if your work involves heavy programming. Recommend to learn the basics of C, C   and Python before the class.

A very useful course for anyone wanting to become a better programmer, regardless of programming experience. The degree of difficulty of the assignments will most likely  be strongly dependent on the programming background of the student.
Buckle up

Do not get behind on the final project. Work ahead as much as possible because there are always design changes and last minute problems, including in parts of the code that you thought were working. Make a serious efforts to learn how to use version control properly because it is easy to break your local repository with sloppy commands.
Fantastic class if you want to learn how to write quality code. Be careful with assignments, though (especially the first), since they might require much more work than you're expecting.
Highly recommended for 1st or 2nd year grad students. If you expect to do any programming at all in your research, this is a really nice class to take.
If you already have a heavy courseload, consider just getting the notes and old assignments from someone who already took this, and reading over them on your own time.

If you already have a working knowledge of C  , this course will be excellent. If you don't, you will struggle with many of the homework assignments and miss some of the better points of the course being stuck in the implementation details.

If you are not solid in programming don't take this course!  Take another course in general programming first (I believe there is a good summer course taught by BK).  Then you will feel much more comfortable with this content later on.

Would certainly recommend in the right circumstances.

If you don't know how to program already, this course will be more difficult for you. If you know how to program in a language already, consider taking this course to gain exposure and learn new languages. 

On the downside, there is a high risk associated with taking this class since you never know how well/poor you are doing relative to anyone else, or even on an absolute scale.
If you have a computer science background, much of the material may already be familiar to you.  Still a nice course.
If you have to do some coding stuff in your work or research, you should take it and hear from professional guys about how to do it in a good way!

If you're largely a self-taught programmer and don't feel fluent in computational tools, this is an outstanding course. It requires a large time commitment, and if you're unwilling to invest the effort the group project will not be enjoyable, but the payoffs are well worth the trouble.
If you're planning on writing code, there are a lot of reasons to take this course, and few not to, besides perhaps the final project.  If that scares you, then at least audit.

If your encounters quite a bit programing exercises in your daily research (as most of the other people in science major), and know some basic programing languages, this course will be really worth taken.
It is better to have a moderate programming background to take this course
Make it known that it doesn't focus on one particular language, but offers an overview of the many tools available to create programs to scientific ends.
More useful if your research directly requires these stuff
Start the final project early and be sure to clearly define your scope. Be open to trying new tools and new languages, as that will help you learn the most.
Take it if you have some programming experience, but aren't familiar with things like version control, very many programming languages.

Take it if you want to learn a lot of different tools and languages, which you think may benefit you in the future. Topics range from C, C  , profiling, parallel programming, python, etc. It might not be very deep, but each opens the door for you to learn more about topics that you care on your own.
Take this class earlier in grad school, because it is a lot of work.  You will learn a lot of practical skills, however.
This couse is very good. You can learn the basic skills for coding, from shells to the major coding lauguages. But this couse will take you a lot of time.
Unless you are quite familiar with Linux, C  , python and stuff like that, I would not that recommend this course for a rookie.
You will learn a lot, but it is a ton of work if you are still a beginner at programming.
if you want to improve in software engineering design this is THE class to take
take this class seriously, otherwise you will fail or learn nothing.
descrip: The goal of this course is to teach basic tools and principles of writing good code, in the context of scientific computing. Specific topics include an overview of relevant compiled and interpreted languages, build tools and source managers, design patterns, design of interfaces, debugging and testing, profiling and improving performance, portability, and an introduction to parallel computing in both shared memory and distributed memory environments. The focus is on writing code that is easy to maintain and share with others. Students will develop these skills through a series of programming assignments and a group project.

title: Witnessing Disaster
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Colloidal Dispersions I
reviews: As the course stands now, if you are looking for a broad overview of colloids this will suit you well. The course felt a little more like a seminar than it did a course in that it seemed more to introduce topics than it did really help you to understand these topics. It serves well to make students aware of the various topics, methods, etc. that exist in colloids science for further investigation.
I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in learning about a variety of topics related to colloids from a professor who is a leading researcher in the field.

Interesting course, especially if you have any interest in colloids in your graduate work. There wasn't too much required work, so what you got out of the course was largely what you were willing to put in and I think for a graduate course that is appropriate.
descrip: Study of static and dynamic properties: hydrodynamics, Brownian motion, electrostatics, dispersion forces, electrokinetics, and electrostatic stabilization.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Affordable Housing (Sess 1)
descrip: This course will examine the policy and practice of developing income-restricted affordable housing in the United States (new and rehabilitated, single-family and multi-family, for sale and rental) by the public, private, and nonprofit sectors.

title: Topics in Tonal Analysis - Rhythm, Meter, and Groove
prereqs: MUS 106 or equivalent..
descrip: Through readings, direct engagement with a range of music, writings, and small composition exercises, we will endeavor to deepen our understanding of notions of rhythm, meter and groove.

title: Europe in the 20th Century
reviews: I highly recommend this course. Professor Rabinbach is a great and really interesting lecturer.
I recommend it to anyone who thinks Europe is interesting.

Learning this material is essential to understanding international politics in the current century. Reading is pretty heavy, but Rabinbach is entertaining and good at explaining the major themes. Take it!
Pay attention in lectures because that's where all the vital information comes from. I found the readings to be unnecessary.
Prepare to read a lot.
Read, read, read.  Think about the readings, too.  Study the chronology, also.
This class focuses less on the timeline of the history than it does on the social and cultural events.  I found it to be quite interesting and the work level reasonable.
You should know that this class will focus on intellectuals and intellectual trends in 20th century Europe, particularly in Germany.
descrip: The course will explore problems of modernity in European society, culture, and politics from the First World War to the fall of communism in Russia and East Central Europe. Part I will consider: the impact of the Great War, the crisis of liberal ideas and institutions, the ascent of communism and fascism. Part II deals with: post World War II justice and reconstruction, the cultural, and political divisions of the Cold War, and the Central European revolutions of 1989.

title: The Rule of Law
descrip: Considers role of law in gov't: When is a state constrained by law & when it may legitimately change/ignore the law? Use a range of materials from fiction to court cases, legal theory to political history, etc. Proceed by negative example, considering cases from the US: Lincoln's conduct during Civil War, Roosevelt's economic emergency, the Cold War, Nixonian exceptionalism, "war on terror" after 9/11. Also consider comparative examples: Russian Revolution, the collapse of the Weimar constitution, the breaks from communism in the "revolutions" of 1989 & beyond. Also Nuremberg Trials & Kosovar War.

title: Roman Elegy from Catullus to Ovid
reviews: Awesome class! Take it.
Go to office hours!

I would recommend taking this course if you know you will enjoy working through the texts and thinking about the issues on your own.  Don't expect the in class discussion to transform the way you read elegy; on the other hand, be prepared to contribute to the class discussion and make it more interesting and challenging.  It is still a great course - it's just a different style of seminar than many similar classes.

If this is offered again, do take it-- it's on an interesting subject and the professor is very good. You're essentially on your own as far as translation goes, though-- class discussion is mostly about the literary features of the text-- so I would take at least one 200-level course before taking this.
If you have a strong language background and are prepared to move beyond discussing grammar, this is a very rewarding class.
It's a lot of work, but definitely worth it.

Learn the elegiac vocabulary! You will start to notice recurring words, phrases, motifs...this is very helpful in making connections across poems. Also, I've found it helpful to develop a small study group with other students to go over translations, which we do not do in class. Finally, now is the time to learn to read poetry in meter, if you've never learned or learned improperly in high school!
Only take this if you are comfortable translating with no assistance.
Take it--Professor Feeney is amazing.
There is really no downside to this class, especially if Professor Feeney is teaching it.  Take it!
This course is a great survey of Roman elegy! The readings are not too demanding, and Professor Feeney is very engaging and a goldmine of Latin poetry of all genres.
This is a really fun course with a great professor.
descrip: Selections from Latin elegy focusing on the writings of Propertius.

title: Probability Theory
reviews: Find another textbook that you really like and learn the material by yourself. I don't think I learned anything in class. Attend class, however, as much of the problems on the homework assignments are derived from exercises in class.
Good if you want a theoretical background to probability.

I am torn between two opinions: one the one hand, this course introduces students to an interesting field and provides a gentle introduction to real analysis, which might make Integration III: Hilbert spaces a lot easier. On the other hand, more material could be covered if the class had real analysis as a pre-requisite. That way, students would have an understanding of basic measure theory and more complicated topics (filtrations, for example) could be addressed. So, if you've done real analysis, take ORF 526 which is more rigorous, if you want to take real analysis and want to ease the transition, take this class.
I didn't look at the other probability course before taking this, which may have been more appropriate for my background.
Remember to go over the entire book by Prof. Sinai before his oral examination. Also, make sure you know real analysis basics well.
prereqs: MAT203 or 218 or equivalent..
descrip: Sequence of independent trials, applications to number theory and analysis, Monte Carlo method. Markov chains, ergodic theorem for Markov chains. Entropy and McMillan theorem. Random walks, recurrence and non-recurrence; connection with the linear difference equations. Strong laws of large numbers, random series and products. Weak convergence of probability measures, weak Helly theorems, Fourier transforms of distributions. Limit theorems of probability theory.

title: Earth's Environments & Ancient Civilizations
descrip: http://www.princeton.edu/pub/frs

title: Financial Risk Management
reviews: Know what to expect from it.
Recommended.
Strongly recommended for students interested in finance but have little background in it.

This course is more mathematical than its name suggests. The way it was taught focused largely on the quantitative aspect e.g. CAPM and derivatives pricing, options theory, and does not really deal much with the "risk management" aspect.
descrip: This course covers the basic concepts of modeling, measuring and managing financial risks. Topics include mean-variance portfolio theory, fixed income securities, options pricing, Greeks, risk measures and utility functions.

title: Introduction to the Professional Study of the Near East
descrip: A departmental colloquium normally taken by all entering graduate students. It is designed to introduce students to reference and research tools, major trends in the scholarship of the field, and the faculty of the department.

title: General Computer Science
reviews: 1) Attempt assignment. 2) Fail within first 5 minutes. 3) Go to Lab TA hours and have them teach you. 4) Success!

A difficult, challenging course, especially for students without prior programming experience. Many students end up PDFing the class. A good (and necessary) class to take if you are considering COS as a major.
A good introduction to the world of programming and its possibilities.

A very well organized course. Definitely take it if you want a useful QR. For the prospective COS majors, skip it if you know java already. I wouldn't say it's a waste of time, since the assignments are rather interesting, but overall the course focuses on basic programming ideas more than specific properties of Java (for example, Inheritance and Polymorphism are not mentioned at all).

After taking this course, I am not surprised at the statistic that "around half of Princeton students in a given year take this course." Despite being a requirement for engineers and COS majors, it is still a very interesting class that makes learning computer science fun!
Apparently over 50% of Princeton takes this class. Don't be in the bottom half.
Attend all the lectures and precepts, as they help a lot.

Be fast, and careful of bugs.
Don't worry about missing lectures.
Be prepared to work.  Keep up with concepts.
Be ready for a lot of work and time committment but rewarding experience.
Be ready to do a lot of work but it is worth it in the end.
Beware of experienced coders--but definitely take it. You need to know Java.
Budget time for the assignments
COS all the way! The only danger is that it might turn you into a COS major.
COS is so important in the modern world I think everyone should take it
COS126 was fascinating and definitely worth trying, even without any experience in computer science or previous interest. It is a great class for any student that likes problem solving.
Definitely Take this course, so much practical knowledge and experience will be gained!

Definitely begin the problem sets early (before Saturday if possible) as it's difficult to predict how much time will be needed to de-bug programs. Also, always remember to format your code correctly and submit the correct readme files online, as these mistakes can cost you points. Finally, pay close attention in lecture, as the answers TEQ (typical exam question) are not posted online, and you'll have to write them down in order to benefit when studying later on.
Definitely take it!
Definitely take it! It's a great course and very well organized: you always know what to expect, which it makes it a relief to take.
Definitely take this course regardless of whether or not you have any prior compsci experience. Very well taught, great introduction to the field.
Definitely take this course.  You will really enjoy it, no matter what your major is.
Deifnitely take this if you have no background to COS. A serious yet fun introduction.
Do it.
Do it.  It's fun.  Just stay on top of your work, and you'll learn a lot.
Do it. It's overall a very fun course if you get into the material and is a great introduction to computer science.
Do not leave programs to the last minute, but otherwise, this is a good course.
Do not take this course unless you require it or are interested in majoring in computer science. It is difficult to do well if you have no prior experience.
Do sample papers. Attend precepts.
Don't be afraid of it. I had never programmed before, and I did quite well and learned a lot. COS 126 deserves its excellent reputation; take it as early in your Princeton career as possible.
Don't fall behind.
Don't get intimidated and just go for it because this material is do-able, it's just different from other stuff you've done in the past.

Don't start assignments the night before they're due (this should be obvious, though). Take advantage of your "free late points". Budget them wisely and you can turn in four of your assignments up to 24 hours late. Read the textbook. It's a little dense, but very helpful. Lectures cover little more than the content presented in the textbook.
Don't start the programs too late
Don't take it and expect to do well if you're not a math/science geared person. But overall great intro to comp sci. for a complete beginner like myself. I had NO prior experience.
Don't take it. Sorry for BSE's for which it is a requirement. Made my first semester awful.
Don't take this class if you don't have a background in COS
Dont take it if you have not taken computer science before. it is not worth your time and you wont get a good grade.
Even if the course is a little outside of your comfort zone, it seemed to be an enjoyable experience for everyone taking it. It's definitely worth a try.
Everybody should take COS 126 at some point
Everyone at Princeton should take this course.
Finding a good precept is helpful -- many of my friends gave me good advice on the assignments simply because of what they learned in precept.
Follow what instructors say to do
GO TO OFFICE HOURS. do the practice exams!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Get a head start! So many students in this class have programmed for years. There isn't a curve, so you aren't competing with the experienced programmers, but there isn't much time to adjust and learn the material. It is a tough introductory course, but then again I am a freshman from a poor southern urban high school.
Go for it.  It's a lot of fun.
Go to all the lectures and precepts, especially if you don't have experience with computers or programming. Take full advantage of the cheat-sheet opportunity for the midterm and final.
Go to precepts. Lectures are not as needed though recommended. Do lots and lots of practice exams because they do really help. Spend time doing the assignments. Enjoy the course!

Go to the lab TA hours (they're on the course site [labta.cs.princeton.edu, or see course site]. The TAs are much better at pinning down bugs in your code than you are and can save you a huge amount of time on each assignment.
Great for those with or without programming experience.
Highly recommend for students with interested in COS or any other science/math discipline

Honestly, there's probably not too many better intro CS classes in the entire country. Absolutely take it if you have any interest in programming and you'll be surprised at how much you can do and how easy it is to learn other programming languages afterwards.
I did all the practice problems, but make sure you talk to your preceptor about how to do certain problems quickly. There is a procedure and once one knows it, things get better.

I had always convinced myself after aborted attempts to teach myself programming from a book that I was "programming dyslexic"; this course quickly dispelled any such delusions. While it is not always an easy course, every effort is made to, as Robert Sedgewick repeated twice, in the first lecture and in the last, "demystify programming." Anyone without prior programming experience does not really have any reason to fear this class.
I thought this was a great course to take because, unlike most courses, the assignments were fun to complete and very rewarding.
I would advice him/her to always to the readings and come to classes. That helps a lot and will save you from spending time alone learning it. At last, it's an awesome class!
I would advise any student to make sure they firmly grasp the initial assignments and readings.
I would advise them to take the course. I think in today's world, it's essential to have a basic understanding of computer programming and theory.

I would definitely recommend taking this course. Not only was the material really engaging, but it was also incredibly useful (and not just for science, like you'd expect). The real-world applications of many of these programs made the class neat and definitely worthwhile.
I would happily suggest anyone interested in using computers take this course, even if they have done quite a bit of programming work before.
I would recommend going to all precepts because those help a lot, and don't be afraid to ask for help, because there is lots available.
I would recommend making sure you really understand all the previous assignments before starting the next ones.
I would recommend students of all majors to take this class--it really makes programming an accessible skill for everyone.
I would tell them to definitely take the course.

If you already know CS, you probably don't need to do anything. If you don't, attend every lecture and skim the slides beforehand. Read them thoroughly afterward. Don't do the assignments with partners if there's any risk your partner is doing parts of the assignment that you couldn't do, since you'll be in trouble on the tests.

If you are not a science person, expect it to take a lot of time. I'm not saying that humanities/social sciences people are not good at logical thinking, however many of my non-science struggled A LOT. Yet it is a important course in boosting logical thinking, so I would definitely encourage people to take it. Just don't assume that it won't take that long.

If you can, get in Moretti's precept.  He presents the material in a simple, easy-to- understand way that makes Computer Science approachable and fun.  This is a great course for anyone with even a slight interest in computers and wants to learn some programming skills, especially since computers are such a large part of our daily lives.

If you don't have prior programming experience, be prepared to work your butt off. Do the readings, do your best to make sure you understand them, because no one is going to ask you if you did. You can get by with finishing weekly assignments without truly understanding everything, and then come midterm time (mid october) you get killed - don't let that happen to you. Go to office hours, any preceptor, not just your own, they'll help you finish a lot faster and understand what you're doing
If you even have some experience with computer science and want to have a lot of freedom, don't take this course. If you have no experience, this would be a good class.
If you have a lot of programming experience, don't take this class, but otherwise, it's a really great and useful class.

If you haven't programmed before, make sure to read all of the material and get into a good precept. Ask students who have taken the course about preceptors; this is a must to understanding and appreciating COS 126.

If you're having any trouble, take advantage of the lectures, precepts, and textbook! Learning the material from three sources helps a lot in clearing up foggy spots. If you still have questions after that, you can always ask fellow classmates or go to office hours. Also, it's best not to leave assignments for the weekend, because you might run into a question that you'd want to ask during a precept. If you still leave the assignments for the weekend and get stuck on a bug for over an hour, you can go to labs for some help.
If you're interested in this course, take it.  I wish I had taken it in freshman fall or spring; I'm switching my major from astophysics to comp sci because of it!
If you're not naturally inclined towards computer science, you will find this subject very hard. Go to office hours, make use of the  lab TAs, and ask for help!
It is a difficult class that requires a lot of hard work, but it is also very educational.
It is an excellent course! I really recommend this class to anyone in any major; it gives you a really logical way of thinking and this class is really useful by itself and so applicable!
It is better to have some knowledge of programming before undertaking this class.
It is good to know how to program. Take it.
It's a good course to take if you want to learn programming. It's also interesting, so I would suggest it regardless.

It's a great course.  Lectures aren't great, but I feel like it's very important to have a basic understanding of computers.  The homework takes time, but it's fascinating and rewarding.  There is absolutely no busy work in this class.  Make sure to get Chris Moretti or Donna Gabai for precept.  They are both great and very claer in explanations.
It's a very useful and not very technical course.  I found it a lot of fun and should definitely be taken.

It's definitely a useful class, and it's often fun as well.  Be aware, though: they will tell you many times that you absolutely must buy the textbook.  The truth is that you could get by fine without it.
It's fun, educational and useful; what more do you need?
It's important to get a good preceptor for COS 126.  The class is not very hard if you stay on your work.  Not one of those classes where you can crank out the problem set in a hour or so.

It's just so tough for students who have no CS background to come into this course and keep up with the pace. Lectures could use some jazzing up and clarity, rather than speed, and SOME preceptors are horrible, but overall the course was well-intentioned.
It's very useful course. Take it
Its really interesting and will allow you to better understand what is going on in your computer
Its tough if you are not a quantitative sort of person but a good course.
Just follow the checklist and listen to lectures
Keep up with the readings and start early on assignments so you have plenty of time to go to office hours if you get stuck.
Keep up with the work! And start assignments early.
Learn a bit about Java before taking the course, will be useful
Make sure you ask for help! Just do it! It's a foreign subject for most people and the TAs and professors understand and WANT to help explain things.
Make sure you do the readings. They explain everything.
Make sure you have a good preceptor, I think it makes a huge difference. Other than that, I think the material is interesting enough and it helps you think differently.
Make sure you read the power point slides.
Never fall behind - if you do, you'll be completely stuck on the coding assignments. Also, don't be afraid to ask for help!
None
One should definitely take the course, and don't feel afraid to make use of the lab TA's. They are extremely helpful, and they are also willing ot help you learn when you get stuck
Only take it if you are actually interested and are willing to put in the work.  Stay up to date on the readings and get help even if you aren't sure you need it.  Programming exams are VERY hard.
Only take it if you must for a certificate or major. If you are simply interested in learning to program or learning basic computer theory, there are far better resources freely available.
Pretty good intro level course
Put in lots of time to complete each assignment properly. No shortcuts for this course.
Read readings, look at weekly assignment, go to lecture. Precepts can be helpful depending on who you have--they will provide tips and tricks for assignments. TAKE THE MIDTERM AND FINAL SERIOUSLY.
Read the book, don't procrastinate on homework.

Read the textbook! Do the extra credit on the assignments if you have time! Get started on the weekly assignments early! Go to office hours - they're incredibly helpful! Work with a partner on pair programming assignments!

Regardless of your major, if you come in with an open mind, I think you'll find this course interesting and beneficial. It's more difficult if you've never had coding experience before (so I've heard), so if that describes you, you might consider doing a little reading/practice beforehand. The first two assignments are easy, but NBody can be a surprise if you're not ready for the difficulty.
Relax. The first few weeks go by fast, but then it becomes incredibly enjoyable

Sedgewick is a boring lecturer, but if you can get past that and actually pay attention (not having a laptop might help) he's actually quite good at explaining concepts. On the other hand, if you have an amazing preceptor, your preceptor will also help explain everything. Try to get DONNA because she's amazing and I think that having a good preceptor was really helpful. Do take this class - it's not that hard, it's really fun and you're learning a useful skill.
Seek out extra help if you need it.

Someone taking this class (who is not planning to major in computer science, particularly) should just take the information that he finds to be applicable and useful and master that, rather than fret about the entire course, which contains some elements that are clearly not as important as others.
Spend more time checking over assignments
Spend time on it each day, even if it is just a little bit of reviewing.
Start assignments early and comment your work.
Start programming assignments early.
Start the assignments early.

Start your code early. Don't be afraid to ask for help. In the second half of the course, when lecture content is not directly related to your assignments, keep up weekly - it will make the final exam easier to prepare for.
TAKE COS126 I DONT CARE WHO YOU ARE YOU BETTER BE SIGNING UP FOR THIS CLASS RIGHT NOW CLOSE THIS TAB AND SIGN UP IMMEDIATELY
TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT!!!!

TAKE THIS COURSE, especially if you like computers and technology and all those goodies.  Then again this course might not arouse your interest if you're not into those sort of things.  I had never taken programming before this class and I can honestly say that I was able to keep up pretty well with everyone else.  People with prior programming experience might not have to read from the textbook as much but I suggest to read from it if you don't have any experience (although I know of some people who had no experience and didn't read the book yet were doing just fine in the course).  The readings however can sometimes get a tad long for some chapters but overall they teach you what you need to know.  It takes a little time to get used to but after a few weeks, you will be up to the level of the people who do have prior programming experience.  BTW Donna Gabai, my preceptor, was really kind and helpful.
Take advantage of the availability and knowledge of your preceptors.
Take another COS class before this one.
Take during sophomore year because then you can ask your friends who took it during freshman year any questions you have!

Take into account that regardless of whether you take this course for a grade or p/d/f, it constitutes a huge time commitment to factor into your schedule. It really does help to start problem sets early, but a lot of times it's more effective to just go to Lab TAs or office hours so you don't stuck at the very beginning.
Take it even if you aren't interested in COS/an engineer.  It teaches an interesting way to approach problems and requires a fun and interesting midset.
Take it if you have any interest in computer science. You don't need any background knowledge and there is a lot of help available if you ever struggle with something
Take it if you're willing to be challenged (or if you need to).  It's very hard but it's also interesting and useful.
Take it!
Take it! Great course that everyone should take, either for general knowledge, or for brushing up on previously learned material, or to just try something new.
Take it! It's a great requirement.
Take it! Programming is a basic literacy nowadays!

Take it! True, you may fall asleep during the main lectures. But the assignments are doable, challenging, and rewarding at the same time, and you will be amazed at all the applications for your new-found programming skills.

Take it! Very fun course, and programming is a skill that can be applied to any field. Even if you have prior programming experience (like me) I would recommend taking it. It will be an easy class, and I guarantee you will learn something new (especially in the second half of the course when it gets more theoretical).
Take it, even if you have no programming experience. It's really fun.
Take it, if you are even remotely interested in how programming/computer science works. After all, you can drop if it really isn't your fit.
Take it, it's actually amazingly well organized and the preceptors are more than willing to help.
Take it, it's great to learn and though time consuming, worth it.
Take it.
Take it. It is very fun and intellectually stimulating.
Take it. It's a fun course, especially for science and engineering majors. The assignments are really enjoyable and reflect what you're learning in the course.
Take it. Period.
Take it. You will want to become a COS major after taking this course, but COS 217 will quickly change your mind.

Take this class because it includes essential information about introductory programming, which is very valuable and can be fun. It can get boring at times, lectures can turn dull, and the readings may seem repetitive, but the assignments are fun and thought-provoking. However, the assignments will be even more fun if you give yourself enough time! (Though you do have late points, so take advantage of those if necessary. They are there for you to use, so use them if you think you'll get a better grade because of it. And try to do extra credit on assignments.)
Take this class. It is a good intro to COS if you haven't taken it before (something I think people should do) and not too slow even if you have.

Take this class. Work hard. Don't slack. You will do fine. One thing that you might want to know though is that unlike many other classes here 126 is not curved. You will be graded against those kids that have been doing COS since they were 10, but it is still possible to do well and a lot of fun.

Take this course if you are interested in the material. I only took this course out of interest (didn't fulfill any requirements) and I don't at all regret the decision. I had little programming experience coming into the course, but as long as you stay on top of things that shouldn't matter. Each assignment will probably take you around 8 hours, and they are due on Monday nights. I always tried to have mine done by Sunday, and I never really ran into any problems with a time crunch. I found the written exams to be a little easier than the programming exams, which was good because they are a larger portion of your overall grade. Sedgewick is not a captivating lecturer, however learning this material now can open new programming possibilities in the future for you.
Take this course if you like the sciences, math, or thinking logically (in a fun way).
Take this course only if you are very interested in computer science.  If you have not taken computer science before, this course can be very challenging and time consuming.
Take this course only if you have no background in computer science and programming; if you know some java, go to 226, else self-study java and take 226 as soon as you can.
Take this course!
Take this course.
Take this course.  And read the textbook.

Teach yourself the basic syntax of Java beforehand. It feels like at least two thirds of the class knew it beforehand.

Don't take it for general interest - do Code Academy instead.
They should be prepared to dwell into theoretical matters as well and not only programming.
Think carefully before coding, be patient while coding and debugging, seek help if needed, and it will pay off.
This class is very easy if you already have comsci experience, but can be very challenging if you don't.

This course is a lot of work.  The course is rushed, and many topics are not fully explained.  The assignments, due on Mondays, are often confusing and badly-worded.  My recommendation is that you should not take this course unless you have previous programming experience or are willing to spend a large amount of the semester teaching yourself the material.

This course is a lot of work. If you are not really interested in computer science or think it's not your strong suit, this might not be a good fit for you. If you put in the work, you will learn what you need to learn in the course, and you can get a good grade. But it's a lot of work, especially if you have no coding experience. So be cautious. That is all.

This course is hard for someone without any previous programming experience, it goes really fast. Read the textbook before the lectures and at least take a look at the assignment before the precepts so that you can ask questions. And you never know how long an assignment would take, I advise you start working on them well ahead and go to the lab TAs if you are stuck, they are a great resource.
This course takes a lot of time, and there will be a lot you still don't know, but if you want a basic introduction to programming in a structured and supportive environment, take it.
This course will help you in ways you never before imagined - take it. If you haven't learned computer science, there's a very big gap in your education.

This is a course that everyone should take. It takes up a fair amount of time if you don't have programming experience, but the amount of knowledge you gain is worth it. For precepts, Donna is amazing
This is a fun class if you like the way you have to think while programming, but it is going to be a significant amount of work with all the programming assignments every week.
This is a good class to take, even if you're not a BSE student. It's a different type of material than most students are used to that still falls under the realm of quantitative reasoning.

This is a good intro course to computer science! Some people say that you have to know a lot of cos to take it, but I strongly disagree. I did not even know what computer science was before I took this course and the great preceptors, and fun assignments taught me so so so much. Take it, or at least try it out =)
This is a great course for students in all departments and it has a wide range of applications. It's also good for learning new ways to think about problems.
This is one those courses you shouldn't leave Princeton without taking.
This is probably the most well-structured course that exists at Princeton. VERY accessible to non-comp sci majors and people who have never programmed before, and applicable to today's society.
Try to learn some Java beforehand to come in better prepared
Understand the theory or you won't be able to program well. I learned this the hard way.
Very good course. The material is interesting and engaging, but can be time consuming. Get Donna Gabai as a preceptor, she is a great teacher.
Very interesting, exciting, and satisfying course. Does, however, require commitment as there is a program due every week.

Very interesting. Drop if you genuinely aren't interested or genuinely don't get it, but neither of those should be a problem. You have to put in work but it's the most fun and most rewarding (you get to actually do things and see them happen!) work I've done here so far (sophomore fall).
Very useful course. CS is an extremely applicable topic...you should definitely take this at some point before you graduate!!

You should definitely take this course!! (You can always PDF it).  But seriously, don't bother taking it if Sedgewick is lecturing it.  Also, make sure you get Donna Gabai for your preceptor.  I really wish I had her instead of Finkelstein.
You should take this course, whatever your major.
always understand each chapter before the lecture of the next class

definitely take this class if you've ever programmed before. The assignments are really cool and fun. If you've never programmed though, I'd be a little cautious. It's not as beginner-friendly as they say, and I know a lot of people who struggled with the class.
do the work and you'll be fine.
for a general start for computer science, and anyone not CS major that want to learn a little about computer science, this is definitely the best intro CS class I've ever taken.
get a good preceptor

it's simple. if you are even slightly interested in computer science, take it. you're gonna love it! and contrary to most people say, this is NOT a difficult course...it is FUN course, and provided you work sincerely, you're gonna ace it!
take it even if your interest is totally different, this basic level of coding is just good knowledge to have
take it. even if you haven't coded before. most interesting course i've taken at princeton
very interesting class, even if you are not in engineering or science department, it is a good class to take.
work hard and attend lab ta hours because they are quite helpful
yes, but it's hard if you have no prior experience in computer science.
descrip: An introduction to computer science in the context of scientific, engineering, and commercial applications. The goal of the course is to teach basic principles and practical issues, while at the same time preparing students to use computers effectively for applications in computer science, physics, biology, chemistry, engineering, and other disciplines. Topics include: hardware and software systems; programming in Java; algorithms and data structures; fundamental principles of computation; and scientific computing, including simulation, optimization, and data analysis.

title: Algorithms and Data Structures
reviews: A great class if you're interested in learning an overview of algorithms or just improving your computer programming skills. Study lots for the exams - they are the hardest part of this class. Final course grades are typically uncurved, so ~93% = A.
Absolutely. It gives you a different perspective on software and algorithm development.
Assignments are interesting. Make sure you stay on top of the work though. It can pile up for studying and sometimes the assignments may take longer than you think.
Be prepared to spend a lot of time on the assignments, like the other COS classes.  Go to the TA lab on Saturdays (nobody is ever there) and use your TA!
Being good at COS126 doesn't mean you'll do well in this course, but it's just as interesting and just as well run.
COS 226 is a fantastic course! You won't regret taking it. Professor Wayne is one of the best professors I've ever had.
Definitely take it if you liked 126. The course is front loaded. It gets less stressful after midterms because there are fewer programs.
Definitely take this course if you have any interest in the field because it is the foundation of Computer Science.
Definitely take this course if you want to program later in life. Wayne is a baller lecturer and the data structures and algorithms are interesting for their own sake.
Definitely take.
Do not take if not comfortable with coding.

Get maia as a preceptor. Discounting the precepts, a very well-designed and useful course. Definitely one of the better ones I've taken at Princeton. I took it PDF to not have to worry about the nit-picky grading.
Go to lecture and do the weekly exercises for assignments. For exams you should go over as many past exams as possible.
Good class overall, worth the time.
Great class, well taught, well organized
I really enjoyed taking this course, the material is interesting and taught very well. Be warned though that it is a time-consuming course.

I would cautiously recommend this class to anyone interested in computer science. The material requires a bit more memorization than I expected from a computer science class, but it will absolutely make you a better programmer. Lectures can be dry, but Professor Wayne does his best with the material he has to work with and is enthusiastic and approachable. For exams, do practice tests and make sure you understand the algorithms you have to come up with! Those questions require a very thorough understanding of the algorithms we are given in class and are by far the most challenging.
I would recommend taking the course with Wayne, as I have heard that he is better than the other professors. I definitely give him high marks.
I would say, don't unless you are really ready for it

I would strongly recommend this course to any one wishing to learn more about computer science. I would also recommend planning out partners for homework assignments, so you don't have to scramble at the last minute.

I would take it, but BEWARE. If you really want to come out of this course with a deeper understanding and better problem solving ability, use all the resources you have. I wouldn't recommend this as a 5th course, but definitely take it if you had enjoyed 126 or are interested in programming in general.
If the only reason you want to take this is to ace interviews, don't. You can learn interview material in weekend.

If you had trouble in COS 126, you will have more trouble here. If you don't understand how to think like a programmer then you will not do well. On the other hand, if you like programming and figuring out how to solve problems, this is a great class and Wayne is an incredible lecturer.
If you have any interest in cos beyond cos 126, then take this class. If you're not great at programming, then this course can be a lot of work, but I would still say it's worth it
If you like COS, take this class. You will learn a lot of cool stuff that is applicable to more than just COS.

This is a good course to take but make sure you understand your study methods and try to keep notes of everything from the class- it will probably show up in the exams.

This is a great class. If you're interested in learning a lot about algorithms and fine with spending a good chunk of time a week doing programs, it is definitely worth it. It is taught extremely well!

This is a great course if you liked 126. It requires a bit more work but is quite worthwhile. You'll get to dive more in-depth into topics with many important applications. Indeed, part of the beauty of this course is how it relates to many other fields of study. In addition, it is intrinsically really interesting- getting to use logic and problem-solve is quite fun. Be aware this course is front-loaded. The first six weeks have more work than the second six weeks do, so keep that in mind as you plan out your schedule.

This is a very good class if you're at all interested in COS and enjoyed 126.  The programming assignments are really not much harder than 126 and many of them are actually more fun (and this is coming from someone who initially struggled with COS 126 as I had never taken a programming class before!).  The exams seem to be harder but the information you learn is more relevant and less memorization.

prereqs: COS 126 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course surveys the most important algorithms and data structures in use on computers today. Particular emphasis is given to algorithms for sorting, searching, and string processing. Fundamental algorithms in a number of other areas are covered as well, including geometric algorithms, graph algorithms, and some numerical algorithms. The course will concentrate on developing implementations, understanding their performance characteristics, and estimating their potential effectiveness in applications.

title: Mathematics for Political Science
descrip: Basic mathematical concepts essential for formal and quantitative analysis in political science research. Course prepares students for advanced courses offered in the Department, e.g., POL 573-576. Topics will include calculus, linear algebra, and probability theory. Some applications to political science will be introduced. The course is aimed for both students with little exposure to mathematics and those who have taken some but wish to gain a more solid foundation. No prerequisite.

title: Slavic Dissertation Colloquium
descrip: A practical course devoted to scholarly writing intended to facilitate the dissertation writing process. The seminar meets every two to three weeks. Dissertation writers circulate work in progress for feedback and meet for discussion as a group. The seminar is required of all post-generals students in Russian literature who are in residence.

title: Fundamentals of Engineering Statistics
reviews: Be prepared to put in work with the problem sets and final project.  As a non-math person, this course was not nearly as scary as I had anticipated.  It is manageable, and if you want to learn stats it's a good course, especially if you can PDF it.  I wouldn't have taken it for a grade if I didn't have to though.
Be sure to be aware of the curve before making the decision to attend.

Compared to what I've heard about other introductory statistics classes from other departments, ORF 245 offers a more general understanding of statistics and I feel would be very useful for anybody with no prior knowledge of statistics despite its faults. It certainly is not a mathematically rigorous introduction to statistics, but it provides a basic understanding that later courses can expand in a more rigorous fashion.

Course was required for me however i found it very interesting.  lectures were interesting. Precepts were not and were not important.  You could get through this class without going to lectures or precepts.  Stats isn't a very interesting topic however Rigolett did a good job trying to make it intersting
Definitely take this course if you're interested in statistics and prepared to work hard on the final project.
Do it if you're ORF, and even if you're not ORF, it'll be an interesting course.

Don't underestimate the R project. Otherwise, a pretty simple and straightforward class.
Go to precept

Test different ones out.  The class is absolutely great when taking it with ORF 309--a lot of crossover and some of its content is a nice supplement with real-world application.  And statistics is really important.  This class isn't SO terrible that you should never learn it.  It's good enough.

I think ORF 245's difficulty is overrated. It takes about an hour of reading to fully understand a whole chapter and we only cover 8 chapters through the course. Rigollet is a good lecturer but extremely rude....it did make lecture somewhat entertaining though lol
I would suggest this class to anyone interested in statistics.

I would take it if you're interested in learning about statistics from a more quantitative angle. It is really not as difficult as people make it out to be; the homeworks are very easy (1-2 hours a week), the midterm exam was pretty easy, and you don't need to go to lecture to follow what's going on.
If you need a stat class, take it. This course isn't difficult, but is rather dry.

If you've never take statistics and you're thinking about it, I say take this course. It's really not too hard and you learn statistics well. Tough curve though because most people have taken AP stats before.
Interesting course that gives a good introduction to statistical methods. Methods seem like they could be used in a lot of other environments.
It's an easy class in terms of materials. Take it but avoid the lectures.
It's basically a quantitative overview of AP Statistics for most of the semester until multiple regression at the very end. Manageable workload and very doable if you stay on top of the assignments.
It's extremely easy and fun, a great course to take especially as a freshman
It's the only really legit stats course.  If you need to learn stats take it.

Only if you are an ORFE major. Premeds, take another statistics class

Take it if you need to and if Rigollet is teaching

Take it. Super relevant, not too difficult.  PDF if you want.

Take the course if you're an ORF major or just generally interested in statistics.  It's not the most exciting course, but it's a good introduction to statistics, and you'll learn a lot if you've never taken a statistics course before.  In other words, it's a useful class.
The course is a good introduction to statistics.
The course is not too time-consuming, but just make sure that you understand the concepts well because that will bring you a long way.
The course material is straight forward, lectures and precepts are not good though.

This is a good class to take as a departmental for an engineering major. I'd be wary if I were a humanities student, though.
This is a good course! And if you want to learn statistics, take it!

This is a great statistics class.  It is not particularly difficult, and yet is far more rigorous than the other statistics classes offered. I would recommend that every student take this as their statistics class.

This is a very good course. It's not that hard, so don't worry about the time commitment, but I suppose grades might be a bit arbitrary since the assignments and midterm were pretty easy. take it. prefer it to eco 202 and that psych stats course. this course will teach you all you need to know about stats, and it is GOOD to know stats. contrary to what most people think, stats is indeed itneresting, and prof does make it even more enjoyable
prereqs: Three semesters of Calculus or its equivalent.
descrip: A first introduction to probability and statistics. This course will provide background to understand and produce rigorous statistical analysis including estimation, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing and regression. Applicability and limitations of these methods will be illustrated in the light of modern data sets and manipulation of the statistical software R. Precepts are based on real data analysis.

title: Morality and Politics
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Viruses: Strategy and Tactics
descrip: Viruses are unique parasites of living cells and may be the most abundant, highest evolved life forms on the planet. The general strategies encoded by all known viral genomes are discussed using selected viruses as examples. The first half of the course covers the molecular biology (the tactics) inherent in these strategies. The second half introduces the biology of engagement of viruses with host defenses, what happens when viral infection leads to disease, vaccines and antiviral drugs, and the evolution of infectious agents and emergence of new viruses.

title: Religion in Japanese Culture
descrip: This course will provide an introduction to major themes and issues in Japanese religions from ancient to modern times, focusing on the role of religion in culture and history. We will examine representative aspects of Buddhist, Shinto, Kirishitan (Christian) and other religious traditions, as well as such topics as shamanism, magic, healing, religion and the state, and religion and modernity.

title: Great Books of the Jewish Tradition
reviews: At first it is kinda unclear what the texts selected are actually saying, but if you stick with you can get a very good feel for the material.

I advise students to take the course with any other professor but Professor Himmelfarb. I have heard wonderful things about the course when other professors teach it, and I just wish that I had taken it with another professor.
I don't really know... take it if you like this sort of thing...
If you're not Jewish, be careful. There is an assumed background for this class, and if you do not have that background - beware.

This class is not easy and unless you are really interested in judaic studies and have a little background in the subject I would not take it. Also, if you are not Jewish, this class is twice as hard.
descrip: This course is intended to Introduce students to the classical Jewish tradition through a close reading of portions of some of its great books, including the Bible, the rabbinic midrash, the Talmud, Rashi's commentary on the Torah, Maimonides' Guide for the Perplexed, the Zohar, the prayer book, and the Haggadah. We will pay particular attention to the role of interpretation in forming Jewish tradition.

title: Darwin and His Legacy
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Ends and Means: Issues in Composition
descrip: The topic is Patterns and Partials. The seminar concentrates principally on music that makes rhythmic and pattern-based music influenced by ideas of the overtone series and other spectral processes. All students will work throughout the semester on a composition incorporating some of the ideas discussed in class. The seminar series will examine work from the early twentieth century through to the early 21st century, including music by Ravel, Janacek, Grisey, Murail, Reich, Glass, La Monte Young, Arnold Dreyblatt and Claude Vivier.

title: Special Topics in Performance History and Theory - Performing Australia
descrip: This course will investigate how, since the Second World War, Australia's sense of itself has been reflected in and shaped by theater and film, as well as by some important works of fiction and non-fiction. While they have made their names on the world stage, Mel Gibson and Cate Blanchett, Hugh Jackman and Russell Crowe, Baz Luhrmann and Dame Edna Everage have their roots in a specific cultural and performance tradition. Among our topics: Convicts and Aboriginals, the Ned Kelly Myth, Australia at War, "Cultural Cringe" in relation to England and the U.S., Transvestite Performance, and Magical Realism Down Under.

title: Life in the Universe
reviews: Do the lab version with the trip to Yellowstone, or seriously consider finding another STN course.
Do the problem sets with other people.
Drink coffee before hand, because it is an hour and a half lecture in a large, dark lecture hall where the whole time is spent with one professor talking about a slideshow.

Due to it's cross-disciplinary structure, a lot of the course was hard to follow, especially for the technical sections. Good course to take if you're into the sciences and interested in the question of extraterrestrial life.
Going to lecture isn't required, but I'd highly recommend it, as the subject matter is always interesting. The problem sets are useful for the midterm, so be sure to understand those.
I enjoyed it, but I would recommend being prepared for a fair bit of work!

If you have a background in science and an interest in the topic, this class will be easy and fascinating.  However, be careful if you haven't taken a math or science class in last few years or if you struggle with either: it might be a challenge if that's the case.
If you're interested in the subject matter, take it.

This course might be a bit challenging if one is not a science major, but it is very rewarding in the end.
Try to stay awake during the long lectures after lunch. Also, look at the problem set for the week before the optional precept days in case you may have any issues.
prereqs: At least one course (but two are recommended) in Astrophysics, Biology, Chemistry, Physics or Geology is required. In the case of freshmen, an advanced placement score of 4 or 5 in Chemistry, Biology or Physics is required..
descrip: This course introduces students to a new field, Astrobiology, where scientists trained in biology, chemistry, astronomy and geology combine their skills to discover life's origins and to seek extraterrestrial life. Topics include: the origin of life on Earth; the prospects of life beneath the surfaces of Mars and Europa, a moon of Jupiter; and extra-solar planets nearby that offer targets for NASA space telescopes searching for life.

profs.name: Jorge Alejandro Mendez Seijas, Course Head

title: Intermediate/Advanced Spanish
reviews: A good course to take. Keep up on the work though.

Although most people take this just as a requirement, I would really recommend it anyways.  Its a fun class and a nice break to just go and talk to your classmates while practicing the language.  Also, if you want to review what you have already learned in spanish a while ago, this class is great for that.
Anna was a great teacher and class was always enjoyable with her
Attend class and keep up on daily assignments. Catch up is difficult.
Attend class and practice and do the homework and workbook
Consuelo was great. The structure of 107 was not though.
Definitely take this course. By far the best introductory Spanish course, just make sure you get Javier!!
Do it to learn Spanish, but even if you're doing it just for the language requirement, you'll enjoy yourself.
Do the homework nightly!! Don't wait until workbooks are collected to do all the assignments at once.

Don't take this course unless you are ready to go to class five days a week. By the end of this class, all of the students couldn't wait to be done with the course. Only take the course if you want to learn the language, otherwise it will be very tiresome.

Embrace the class aspects of this course. Be communicative in class and get to know your peers because it makes having conversations with them in class in a different language seem more natural and easier.
GET CONSUELO!!!!!
Get ready to talk a lot more in spanish than you probably are comfortable with
Go to all the classes and stay on top of your work.
