Go to class and pay attention.
Good course for solidifying an understanding gained in previous courses.
Great course.
I do not like taking language courses, but took it because I had to. I only enjoyed the class and thought it went well due to the professor.
I highly recommend taking a class with Paloma,
I really liked it and it was well taught. There are a lot of little assignments very frequently though.
I would recommend taking Ana over other teachers

I would suggest taking this course. It is wonderful because the emphasis is on Spanish in the new online world rather than memorizing grammar rules. Paloma is awesome! The professors are all wonderful and so friendly!
I would take the course and if you can take it with Consuelo.
I wouldn't take it if it's not a language requirement.
If you can, take a class with Prof. Alsina. She's a total joy to learn from.

If you're looking to be able to speak more fluent Spanish, this is an excellent course. I always felt comfortable about speaking up in class, even if I didn't have perfect grammar or vocab. Making mistakes was natural, but it didn't stop me from being able to participate.
It is a fun course and you will learn a lot. It will also feel good coming into the class already having some previous experience. It is so rewarding to see your progress on a weekly basis.
It's a fine class, and Profesora Sabau is great.
Keep up with the workbook and practice speaking Spanish.

Make sure to actively particpate and to speak as much as possible. Also, make sure to at least glance over the assigned vocabulary and grammar for that day before class. Also, be prepared for there to be a lot of little tasks that  when combined take up a good chunk of time.
Make sure to stay on top of the many exercises and homework assignments.
Make sure you get Jorge. He made the class fun
Paloma Moscardo-Valles is a great professor!
Paloma is a wonderful teacher. Do the work. Speak with people outside of class, because you won't be forced to inside in a productive way.
Paloma was a good, fair and encouraging teacher. I would recommend her class.
Put forth as much effort as possible on the assignments they allow you to improve greatly as the semester progresses.
Select Consuelo's section of SPA 107! She is the best teacher along with Jorge.

Spanish 107 is a requirement to complete the language track but it is also a very fun class! You get to know your classmates, and the workload is not terrible. As long as you work and practice consistently, you can use this class to advance your Spanish a lot.
Strongly recommend :)
Study the vocab ahead of time and don't be afraid to talk during class
Take it for the requirement.
Take it if you have to.
Take it with Anna.
Take it with Javier if he is teaching! Such a great instructor.

Take this class with Jorge! He gives lots of personal attention and his goal is simply to make your spanish incredible.  I loved just getting lunch with him and talking.  He made me want to continue studying spanish.

This course is a fairly large commitment, especially since it's five days a week and you can't skip it.  But you won't want to--I looked forward to being there.  I also think I was able to make significant progress in the language.
You got to get lucky. Some Spanish teachers are hilarious and nice, others not so much. Try to pick classes with friends.
take it!
prereqs: SPA 102 or 103 with a passing grade or instructor's permission..
descrip: SPA 107 is an intermediate/advanced course designed for students who have successfully completed SPA 102 or SPA 103. The main goal of the course is to develop and consolidate the skills acquired at the introductory level, and to prepare students for 200-level Spanish courses. Language is presented in cultural contexts and through authentic audios, videos and texts.

title: Intensive Elementary Chinese
reviews:
At first I took this to fulfill my language requirement and take ownership of my heritage, but I'm so glad this class became so much more! The students, lecturers, and overall class dynamic is brilliant. Absolutely my favorite class this semester! 
--Instructors are very knowledgable, great at engaging students and driving the conversation, and just very sweet, fun people. 
--We discuss really pertinent topics such as being Chinese-American or college life.
Be prepared to memorize a lot of characters! Study in advance.
Be prepared. The curve is terrible. The class is somewhat difficult, but not impossible.
Do it. And make sure to be willing to remember the characters in the long term.
Do not take this course if you have never spoken standard mandarin or are not already relatively fluent
Do your homework EVERY NIGHT. If you get behind, you'll stay behind.
Go to class
Hard course... don't think it'll be a breeze but it is really worth it.

I hope you're more familiar with Chinese than I was! If you don't have a basic understanding of the language, be prepared to spend a lot of time annotating the text and making up your own sentences with the grammar patterns. Other than that, go for it in class and say what comes to mind.
I would say take the course if you have a genuine interest in the language. Otherwise, it will not be enjoyable for you.

If you speak Chinese relatively decently (Mandarin, not other dialects. Other dialects will have trouble, be warned.) you should definitely take this class. Your Chinese will improve immensely and the teachers are so adorable and wonderful, and they will definitely help you out if you are struggling!
If you want to improve your Chinese, definitely take this class. It's a lot of work, but it's worth it.
If you want to learn Chinese, take this course. It's fun and challenging.

If you want to learn Chinese, then you want to take this course. It's not an easy grade by any stretch (93 is usually a B ), but the quality of teaching is remarkable, and you will definitely learn a ridiculous amount of Chinese in a short period of time.
It takes a lot of time, and this isn't a course you take with the expectations of an A, even if you are a native speaker. The curve is awful.
Make sure that your Chinese level is sufficient enough. As a native speaker, this course still proved quite difficult in the reading and writing departments.

Only take this if you are very serious about learning Chinese. Do not think it will be an easy class even if you are already fluent. If you can speak and understand Chinese, but can't read or write it, this is the class for you!
Put in the effort and you will get what you put in.
Really put in the work everyday. If you fall behind it would be really hard to catch up.  If you spend time with it everyday, you'll be find and really enjoy the class.
Study hard!

TAKE IT. TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT. I don't know why everyone makes it out to be so tough... it's really not. Learning Chinese isn't hard, you just have to spend a lot of time working at it. If you do, you'll get that A.
Take it. It was very tough, but I believe the amount of learning you get out of it is worth it regardless of the grade you get.

Take the course, even if it can be a little bit difficult and time consuming at times. However, if you're willing to put in the work, you will learn a lot of information in a relatively short amount of time because the teachers help prepare you really well.
Take this class. It's not nearly as scary as everyone makes it out to be. In the end, you'll walk away with a much better understanding of Chinese and a much improved ability to read and write.

This course is a lot of work, and I probably put somewhere around 5-6 hours outside of class studying characters and doing the assignments. Weekly quizs are not so bad, but I tended to spend all of Friday afternoon before studying. If you speak Mandarin at home with your parents this course, 103, will most likely not have much new in terms of vocab or grammar until the final few weeks. It helps greatly if you've been to Chinese school at some point in the past, or at least have some familiarity with the written language beforehand; if not be prepared to do a lot of review as quizs will require you to have a working knowledge of the language. The teachers are amazing in the class and you'll rotate between three. All in all it was probably my favorite course this past semester because of teacher quality and classroom interaction, though the class has a bit of a negative curve. They teach simplified in class reading, but you can learn traditional and take quizs in that if you want.  Overall, if you want to learn Chinese, take it. It's worth it.
Work hard, but also don't be afraid to approach the teachers. They are very helpful.
descrip: Designed for students who already have some familiarity with spoken Mandarin. The course will emphasize reading and writing skills, and how to analyze grammar. Students who speak Mandarin with non-standard accents will be trained in standard pronunciation.

title: Beginning Workshop in Musical Composition
reviews: A fun class, and not much work.
Do it!  It's fun, and not all that much work.
Even if you don't have much music theory experience, take it! It's good to workshop your pieces early on so you get classmate's and prof's remarks--they give great feedback.
Have fun! This is a great course and take it.

I loved the course as it allowed me to sit down and focus my energy on composing a complete piece and to get to know a lot of other musicians, but your experience may vary depending on how the people in your class is (lots of group projects).

I would tell other students to have fun with this course. Professor Lansky and Elliot created a very low-pressure and welcoming environment. It's probably the most relaxed and comfortable place to experiment with new ideas, so go for it!

If you play a musical instrument, you HAVE to take this course! MUS210 is very free-form, flexible, and allows you to really explore your own style of composition. You will have so much fun in this class. This is hands-down one of my favorite classes at Princeton.
Super laid back but a bit unorganized. Take it if you're motivated to work on your own.
TAKE THIS COURSE. It will be one of the best courses you take.
Take it if you're interested in composition.
Take it!!
Take this class. Stress-free and you learn so much and meet great people!

This is a great, non-intimidating introduction into composition. There were students of all levels of musicianship in my class and I would say that we all got something good out of it. It is also very low-stress and not a lot of work at all, and the classes are very relaxing.

Very good, fun course to do musical improv and composition; however, don't expect to be taught directly very much. The structure of the class is more around getting feedback on pieces, rather than teaching how to compose.
so, so much fun. and very relaxing
prereqs: Some musical background..
descrip: A continuous cycle of creation, discussion, and response based on the creative activity of the students. Students will be encouraged to explore varied styles and techniques (for example, notated composition, multimedia music, and improvisation) and to perform their own works.

title: The Cognitive Neuroscience of Selective Attention
reviews: Awesome course in attention research covering a wide gamut of fields in Neuro. Relaxed environment, but with students that actually care about what they're learning. Prof. Kastner also brings in guest lecturers from her lab that talk about their work. Overall really informative class with the added benefit of showing what first couple years in grad school in (Cog) Neuro will be like.
Definitely a good course if you're interested, and relatively advanced in cognitive neuroscience and attention.

If you are at all interested in attention or cognition, this is a great class.  Professor Kastner is very accessible, and will work with you a lot individually to prepare your final paper (which makes Dean's Date much easier and more pleasant for you).  Be aware that most of the class is student presentations.  I definitely recommend this course.

If you are interested in attention, this is a great course to take.  The workload is small.  We read 2-3 articles a week, and each person gives 1 or 2 presentations.  We have no written assignment except the final research proposal, which the Professor walks you through during the second half of the semester.
Know your cognitive neuroscience and brain structures thoroughly!
Take it if you're interested in neuroscience. The topic may seem very specific but we ended up talking about many universal themes in cognition.
Take this class if you are interested in how cognitive neuroscience is really done (as opposed to what is usually written in textbooks).

Take this course!  Professor Kastner is a fantastic teacher, researchers, and mentor.  She has an incredible amount of knowledge about selective attention, and has published many well-known papers on the subject.  She really cares about her students and ensures that each student understands the material.  Great course.
prereqs: An introductory neuroscience course, such as NEU/PSY 258, or NEU/PSY 259, or equivalent..
descrip: Attention is a fundamental cognitive process that enables us to select info that is relevant for ongoing behavior. Course reviews the cognitive neuroscience of selective attention starting from theoretical foundations provided by cognitive psychology to the neural underpinnings identified by systems neuroscience, and also includes an intro to the pathology of attention disorders. It presents a hands-on science experience by drawing on current lab research, focusing on the design and analyses of 'real' experiments, with opportunities to attend ongoing behavioral, physiology, and functional imaging studies.

title: Transformations of the Self
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Wordplay: A wry plod from Babel to Scrabble
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Future Physics
reviews: Come to lecture.

Do not take this course to fulfill your STL or STN - take something else.  This is harder than it should be for a class for non-science majors, and it is not nearly as relevant to every day life as some of the other non-science major courses are.

Do the homework, communicate with the professors--they WILL acknowledge things like last-minute technological difficulties--pay attention, and try to prepare yourself for the mind-bending concepts covered when discussing relativity. I would personally recommend reading a work of H.P. Lovecraft; after that, the universe will seem logical and instinctive through comparison.

Do you hate class participation? Do you hate having to sit in the first five rows near the professor and attend every lecture? Do you hate having to do classwork in lecture? If you answered yes to any of these questions, DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE. If those things sound okay to you, and you want to learn more about basic physics, go ahead. Knock yourself out.
Not too stressful of a class at all.
Take this course. Prof. Meyers is really awesome and devoted to help. Good way to meet the distribution requirement esp if you had high-school physics.

This is a great way to learn some physics without the time commitment of a lab course. If you've never taken physics before, I'd highly recommend it; it'll help you gain a new perspective on the world around you.
Unless you have no idea how gravity works, you're going to get bored and lose your motivation
prereqs: Math skills at the level of high school algebra are assumed. No prior classes in physics or astronomy are necessary..
descrip: What do future leaders of our society need to know about physics and technology? The course is designed for non-scientists who will someday become our influential citizens and decision-makers. Whatever the field of endeavor, they will be faced with important decisions in which physics and technology play an important role. The purpose of this course is to present the key principles and the basic physical reasoning needed to interpret scientific and technical information and to make the best decisions. Topics include energy and power, atomic and subatomic matter, wave-like phenomena and light, and Einstein's theory of relativity.

title: High Tech Entrepreneurship
reviews: Definitely take the course - it's a lot of work to prepare each week, but definitely worth it.
take it, it is fun and worth the learning.
descrip: This "hands-on" practical course introduces students to the analysis and actions required to launch a successful high tech company. Using several conceptual frameworks and analytical techniques, it addresses the challenges of evaluating technologies for commercial feasibility, determining how best to launch a new venture, attracting the resources needed to start a company (e.g. people, corporate partners, and venture capital), preparing comprehensive business plans, structuring business relationships, and managing early stage companies toward "launch velocity" and sustainable growth.

title: Seminar in Research Methods
reviews: I don't see why anyone would take this without having it forced upon them... so just get through it.
I wouldn't recommend non-majors take it, but if its your thing, go ahead
If you have to take it then don't worry its pretty good. I would not take it if you don't have to
If you're NES, you're going to have take it. If not, take it for the readings and the professor if the topic interests you.
N/A (required for NES majors).
You can't avoid it if you are NES, but if you take it take it for the Professor. Not super useful in the end, although it did help me to get a solid head start on my JP.
descrip: Introduces advanced undergraduates to the basic methods of research and analysis in history and the social sciences as well as to fundamental debates in the field of Near Eastern Studies. Topics addressed include causality, research design, case studies, selection bias, historicism, Orientalism, ethnography, textual analysis, and the ethics of research.

title: Shakespeare I
reviews: A good way to fulfill a departmental or not.  Still a great course.  Shakespeare, you sometimes forget is a genius, but then you start reading and then you remember.  You'll like this course if you appreciate literature.
Attend the lectures -- they're amazing, and will be really helpful on the final!

Definitely take this course, even if you don't think you're interested in Shakespeare particularly.  Professor Leo is amazing, and his love for his subject is infectious.  He's also very willing to work with students to take the class in whatever direction their interests lie.
Do it.

I would advise another student considering taking this course to do so, but to take his/her time dealing with each text.  He/she should understand that he/she cannot breeze through a Shakespeare play, but instead must take time engaging closely with the language.
I would strongly recommend this course if you have an interest in Shakespeare.

If you are interested in Shakespeare at all, this class is wonderful. It is a lot of readings, but the lectures are exciting and enjoyable and the writing assignments allow for individual freedom and creativity.
If you have any interest in Shakespeare and Professor Leo is teaching it, take it! Take anything with Professor Leo!
If you like studying literature, gotta take it.
If you're interested in Shakespeare, take it!
It's worth it if you love Shakespeare.
Read all of the works, and attend all of the lectures. You don't want to miss anything.

Take it if it's Professor Leo, but you should probably take it anyway.  Prof. Leo is an incredible lecturer and an extremely nice guy.  He's always willing to help with anything or even just talk for a while.  My favorite class and my favorite professor, and I'm a science major.
Take it with Dolven, not Leo.

Take this course with Professor Leo!  He is great!  He gives extremely interesting and enlightening lectures.  He is also a very fair grader if you have him as a preceptor.  The course also is not very much work.
Take this course! It is so amazing.
Taking the blackboard posts seriously is a really good way to get ideas for papers--that's where both of my papers came from.
This class was great!  There was a lot of reading, so take it if you enjoy Shakespeare, but it is fantastic.
Try to go to the acting sessions, if they're available. And certainly go to office hours both before and after to discuss your papers!
descrip: The first half of Shakespeare's career, from the uproarious antics of the early comedies to the fathomless mystery of Hamlet.

title: Topics in Combinatorial Optimization
prereqs: Undergraduates must obtain permission of Instructor..
descrip: The lp duality theorem applies to a general real matrix; but the matrices that arise in discrete math, particularly in graph theory, are nicer than general matrices, and various strengthenings of the lp duality theorem hold for them. This course is, for the most part, a survey of the min-max theorems in graph theory, viewed from the point of linear programming.

title: Web-Based Social Research (Half-Term)
descrip: Half-semester seminar on introduction into web-based social research. Topics include experiments, digital traces data, crowdsourcing, and ethics. Techniques and approaches will be illustrated with examples from the literature. No previous knowledge of computer programming is required, and graduate students from other disciplines are welcome.

title: Climate of the Earth: Present, Past and Future
reviews: Do finish all the reading, and you can survive if you persist, regardless your background.

Good class to get a strong overall picture of the climate system...great background for understanding random seminars and getting ideas for research topics. Problem sets are not hard, but research paper at the end of the class and final exam take a while to prepare.
Great broad overview course to take if you want to learn more about the climate system.
If you haven't seen the material covered in the course before, it's reasonably interesting.  But if you like physical understanding, you may be disappointed and/or annoyed by the way it's taught.
Need some basic math and physics background. For example basic ideas of calculus

Read the textbook in order to get a fuller understanding of the material in class. Some of the information is skimmed over and some knowledge is assumed. Ask questions if you don't understand something.
Review the slides and notes after each lecture
Take it.
The course did a good job of introducing the students to climate phenomenon. This course can be taken by students not having a substantial physics or mathematics background.

This class provides a very comprehensive and useful review of key aspects in today's climate science. As such I would only recommend taking this course once you have completed the more rigorous fundamental courses covered in this sweeping review.
This course is super helpful as a start point of research on climate.
You should be familiar with the principles of atmospheric science before taking this course. Otherwise, you may spend too much time playing catch-up.
descrip: The goal of the course is to provide students with an introductory overview of the broad factors that determine our current climate, as well as past and future climates. We first build a foundation for understanding the principal features of today's climate. This includes examining the Earth's energy and water cycles, the processes determining the principal atmospheric and ocean circulation features, climate feedback processes, and dominant modes of variability. We then use this framework to interpret observational records of past climates, including ice age cycles, and to examine projections of future climate change.

title: Psychology of Face Perception
reviews: However, I would not recommend the course to someone who was not a psych major, as I feel that it would have been difficult for them to understand much of what was discussed.
Prof. Todorov is an easygoing professor and an expert in this field. I wished the seminars were less like lectures and had more discussion, but overall this was an interesting and enjoyable class.
READ the articles.
Take it if you have a head for statistics. Otherwise, be prepared to re-read everything.
Take it!
Take this course!! Do all the readings, not because you have to but because they're so interesting!

This class was not a lot of work (a few written assignments, a short multiple choice midterm and final, a 4 page paper).  The material covered in the first and second half are quite different, and I didn't find the second half (on social perception of faces) to be quite as interesting.  I was one of the few non-majors in the class, and learned a lot about how psychology research works.  I felt that I really got a good sense of this sub-field.  There was not a whole lot of discussion in class, mostly he asked questions which had clear answers from the reading.

This is definitely an upper level psych class and some background in social psych and/or neuro is helpful. Nevertheless, the subject is super interesting and applies to so many aspects of daily life. Todorov is a leader in this field and is great about sharing the interesting aspects - plus, he's super helpful. If you're a psych major, I definitely recommend this class!
good class! hard final, but interesting and relevant material
prereqs: Students should have some background in cognitive psychology, cognitive-neuroscience, or equivalent background in related fields relevant to face perception..
descrip: This course will be an upper level seminar that will attempt to synthesize research from multiple disciplines on how faces are represented in cognitive, computational, and neural systems. The material covered will include work on the role played by face perception in social cognition. The methods used in the research to be discussed include cognitive-behavioral measures, functional brain imaging, electro- and magnetoencephalography, single cell recording, lesion studies, and computer vision. The reading will include review articles and research reports.

title: Engineering Design for Sustainable Development
reviews: Although this class does sound very interesting and you explore interesting areas, I wouldn't take this class unless it was required.
Be sure to stay on top of your group's progress, even when you are not a group leader. Review their work always and be sure that you are collectively meeting the objectives.
DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS.
Definitely.
Great class if you're interested in sustainable design.
I would recommend this course to other students who are interested in sustainable design -- but beware of disorganized, frustrating projects!
Put a lot of effort into the reports.
Take this course.
This course has lots of projects that take forever. I have not learnt anything but have spent a considerable amount of time working on the projects. Don't take this.

This is good course to take if you're looking to get exposure to what engineering in the real world is like. However the work load is pretty heavy, so be prepared to put a good number of hours into it.
prereqs: CEE 303 or equivalent with instructor's permission. Open to Seniors and Graduate students only..
descrip: Students will design several features of a LEED-certified building project. Features that will be considered include ground source heat pumps; ventilation; photovoltaics (PV); insulation; glazing; green materials; and storm water management systems, including a green roof, and rainwater harvesting. Ventilation will be designed considering the potential for vapor emissions from building materials. Energy software will be used to determine the carbon footprint and energy costs of alternative designs.

title: U.S. Military and National and International Diplomacy
reviews: A must take. The course would have  been amazing even without such an incredible instructor, but having someone who lived and recently worked on some of the most pressing foreign policy issues in the world was a once in a lifetime opportunity - seize it if possible.
Absolutely take this course.
Do whatever you can to get in the class if it's here again with Admiral Mullen. He even signs his emails "Mike"

If you ever have the chance to take a class with ADM Mullen, and in our case, meet SEC Kissinger, just do it. The class is a fantastic experience that few Princetonians will ever get the chance to enjoy.
Once in a lifetime opportunity.
TAKE IT.
Take it.
You should take this course if you want to learn more about how the military fits into foreign policy making and implementing.
You'll have to make a significant effort beyond the scope of just preparing for class to stand out in any significant way. Always always always be prepared with lots of questions.
descrip: This seminar will review concepts of military strategy, national security policy, U.S. diplomatic relations with other global power centers, and efforts to transform international institutions to address emerging global security threats.

title: Chinese Martial Arts Classics: Fiction, Film, Fact
reviews: A great course that covers a wide variety of martial arts material. The timeline was very well structured as well, starting from Sima Qian and ending with Kung Fu Panda; the course came together nicely. I enjoyed Professor Keulesmans as a professor very much and plan to take his course next semester as well.
A very interesting course, especially for someone with no prior study in the field.
Awesome class.
Even if you don't know anything about martial arts, a great class to take!
If they were into EAS and didn't mind reading boring Chinese novels, it's a fun class to learn a little about East Asian fiction.
If you like chinese culture, take it
Put effort into your responses and papers. Don't just read the readings - think about them. Play with them in your head, make connections, explore themes. That's really the beauty of this course.
Relatively easy LA that promises to be a lot of fun. Keulemans is one of the best lectures I've had at Princeton.
Students should do all of the readings before the week starts because it is very difficult to read all of them the night before.
Take it - you won't regret it. You learn so much and it's so interesting you'll look forward to every lecture and do all the reading and more (honestly).
Take it! It was extremely enlightening and I came out of the course a new person more interested in Chinese culture. I motivated me to continue learning more on my own time!
Take it. It's not much of a time commitment, you get to watch movies you may or may not have seen before, and it's a good way to learn about East Asian culture without having to speak the language.
The movies are good enough that you can watch them as a relief from studying for other classes. It's multi-tasking.
This is a fun course about a really fun subject, and there's not too much work. I recommend it highly.
This is a really fun course to take.  Readings are quite interesting.
you get to learn about martial arts and watch famous kung fu movies, both good and bad. what could be better than that?
descrip: This course provides an overview of Chinese martial arts fiction and film from earliest times to the present day. The focus will be on the close-reading of literary, art-historical, and cinematic texts, but will also include discussion of the significance of these works against their broader historical and social background. Topics to be discussed: the literary/cinematic pleasure of watching violence, the relationship between violence and the law, gender ambiguity and the woman warrior, the imperial and (trans)national order of martial arts cinema, and the moral and physical economy of vengeance.

title: Music in the Middle Ages
reviews: Take it, Anna is great!
Take this course if you like music, music theory, and cool music.
descrip: This course is a survey of Western musical practices from the earliest notations to c.1400. Topics include Gregorian chant and the development of musical notation, the courtly love songs of troubadours and trouveres, polyphonic practices in 13th-century Paris, and the new genres which emerged in the later Middle Ages: motet, chanson, and mass. The focus throughout will be on the productive tension between sacred and secular and on examples of transformative musical borrowing.

title: Advanced Physical Chemistry: Quantum Mechanics
reviews: I would definitely recommend taking this course! It was really neat to gain a better understanding of the mathematical basis behind atoms, molecules, bonding, and spectroscopy. While there is a considerable amount of work and math involved, you will most likely find this course very rewarding.

I would recommend taking this course if you're prepared for a challenge and if you want to begin to understand the world on the atomic scale. It has definitely enriched my understanding of chemistry and was quite interesting. Definitely give it a try and worse case scenario you can drop to CHM 305.

If you are comfortable with math, DEFINITELY take this over 305. If Prof. Rabitz is teaching, you're in for a treat, though Prof. Selloni is good as well. The textbook is wonderful, exams are fair, and the material is presented in a very engaging way.
It is a lot of work, but worthwhile if you feel comfortable in your mathematical abilities.
It's a decent overview of quantum mechanics. Don't let the 400 level intimidate you.
Read the textbook. Keep up with the course by reading the textbook. Read ahead if you can. Be able to not only understand the lectures, but predict where they might be going.
Take this class if you want a good introduction to Quantum Chemistry, with a decent amount of math involved. Consider taking linear algebra before/concurrently.
Take this class if you're interested in quantum at all.

This is a really interesting course. If you enjoy using math to understand chemistry, it will likely be a good fit. Be prepared for some things to seem not immediately intuitive: quantum requires a new way of thinking. If you are considering computational chemistry, you should definitely take this to see how you like it. Even if you aren't, if you want a thorough understanding of concepts such as molecular orbital theory, you should seriously consider this course.
prereqs: CHM 202 or CHM 204 or CHM 215; MAT 201 or MAT 203 (multivariable calculus); MAT 202 or MAT 204 (linear algebra) is very helpful, but not required; PHY 101. First semester of a two-semester physical chemistry sequence intended primarily for chemistry majors. Students may take CHM 306 or 406 to complete the sequence..
descrip: First principles development of quantum theory, with applications to atoms, molecules, and their spectroscopy. This course will emphasize developing basic principles and focus on illustrative examples.

title: Major Filmmakers
reviews: I highly recommend this course. However, it is a time commitment due to the amount of reading required and the long film sessions prior to class.

I would advise students interested in taking the course to take in out of interest in the professor and the films.

Students should also be comfortable with large doses of Monica Vitti.
If you haven't seen these movies, take this class.
Make sure you are willing to sit through long screenings. But the films are great so it's worth it.
Make sure you really take note of what Prof. Sitney has taught you and take the time to meet with him about papers!
Sitney is fantastic! You watch many fantastic movies in this course and learn so much about what makes them work.
Take it.
descrip: A seminar on the major films of Alfred Hitchcock, Ingmar Bergman, and Michelangelo Antonioni. There will be an emphasis on psychoanalytical themes in the discussion of such films as Spellbound, Rear Window, Psycho, The Birds, The Silence, Persona, Fanny and Alexander, L'avventura, La notte, and Blow Up.

title: Sound Design
prereqs: Please contact Professor Tim Vasen (tvasen@princeton.edu) for enrollment permission..
descrip: An opportunity to explore what theatrical sound design is, how to look at a text from the point of view of sound, how to launch your creative process, and how to take the ideas based on that creative process and turn them into sounds to be used in a show. Students will also learn how to communicate their ideas, palate, and the arc of their design in a way that demonstrates to directors how they will fulfull the director's vision while embracing their own artistry and response to the text.

title: Law, Social Policy, and African American Women
reviews: Course is worth taking for any student. Great readings and lectures and very manageable work load
Definitely take this course!
Don't.

If you are low on time, do not do the readings. She will summarize ALL of them in class.  The books, however, are fascinating.  Go to office hours ALL THE TIME and she will love you. Do not go into this class expecting miracles, but if you have an interest in the subject matter and want to put in minimal effort, take it.
It is a good course but a lot of reading that is not so interesting.

Prof. Perry is obviously very smart and charismatic and offers some very interesting insight, but she speaks WAY too quickly in lecture making it hard to take notes.  You don't have to read any of the material or go to lectures to do well, but they are both pretty interesting. If Clifton is precepting, he is AMAZING, get him.   Easy, pretty interesting class with a minimum workload.
Take the course but be self motivated and organized. She doesn't hold your hand.

Take this course! Imani Perry is one of the best professors at Princeton and if you haven't taken AAS classes, it will definitely open your eyes to injustice in the United States. And the workload is very manageable if you are able to keep up with your readings.

This is a great course, but not quite mindblowing. Be prepared to answer questions and ask some of your own in LECTURE, not just precept. Professor Perry is really open to meeting with students, and you should definitely take her up on that. She's brilliant.
http://24.media.tumblr.com/tumblr_mb7y6rUIkm1ql5yr7o1_400.gif
descrip: Journeying from enslavement and Jim Crow to the post-civil rights era, this course will learn how law and social policy have shaped, constrained, and been resisted by black women's experience and thought. Using a wide breadth of materials including legal scholarship, social science research, visual arts, and literature, we will also develop an understanding of how property, the body, and the structure and interpretation of domestic relations have been frameworks through which black female subjectivity in the United States was and is mediated.

title: Policy Workshop - US/China Nuclear Weapons Relationship
descrip: US and Chinese nuclear-weapon policy communities find it difficult to understand each other. In the US, some see China as content with the current situation in which China's small non-alert strategic nuclear force is seen as sufficient to prevent nuclear threats by the US nuclear superpower. Others fear that China could decide to "race to nuclear parity." The purpose of this workshop is to better understand the influences of the US and Chinese strategic offensive and defensive programs on each other. The final report will make recommendations to both sides to prevent the US fears of a Chinese nuclear buildup from becoming self-fulfilling.

title: Seminar in International Relations - International Organization
reviews: Great course, great professor.
Overall this is an enjoyable course. Professor Davis has high but reasonable expectations for class discussions and participation
Standard high level politics seminar.  Take it if you are interested in the material.

Take this course if you're at all interested in the material!  Skim the readings for key concepts  before every class and participate in seminar discussions-- you'll be fine.  Professor Davis really helps to cement your understanding of the theory during the first half of the course in order to give a deeper and more substantive understanding of the institutions studied during the second part.
prereqs: POL 240 or POL 381.
descrip: From peacekeeping operations, development assistance, to rules for free trade, the mandate for international organizations continues to expand. Why do states delegate authority, and what accounts for the change over time and issue in the role of international organizations to promote cooperation? The course will examine theories about the design and effectiveness of formal institutions and assess the record of specific organizations including the United Nations, World Trade Organization, and World Bank. This is an advanced seminar, and students should have completed POL 240 or POL 381 prior to enrollment.

title: Political Thought in South Asia
descrip: This seminar will engage the key political ideas that preoccupied South Asia's modern thinkers. We will read primary texts by thinkers like Mohandas Gandhi, Jawaharlal Nehru, and Mohammad Ali Jinnah, along with secondary historical writing to foreground how they grappled with questions of political modernity through ideas such as freedom, colonialism, rights, religious faith, and revolution. What sorts of utopias continue to be imagined from these engagements? How can these ideas open up historical connections between world regions beyond Europe and offer new narratives of the past?

title: Intermediate Studies in Acting: Creating Character and Text
prereqs: Program Director's permission. Please contact Professor Tim Vasen (tvasen@princeton.edu) for enrollment permission..
descrip: The group will theatricalize narratives of Burmese Refugees regarding women's survival in a war-torn country, the indoctrination of boys in to the Burmese Military or Orders of Monks, the Saffron Revolution, Aung San Suu Kyi, etc. Students will work as actors , writers and directors in an ensemble setting.

title: Modeling and Observing the Universe: Research Methods in Astrophysics
reviews: An excellent, enriching course, that anyone interested in science should take! Covers many topics, from telescope design to important mathematical/statistical techniques for experiment, and an applications based outlet for computer programming.

Definitely take this course if you're interested in pursuing astrophysics. It is an upper-level course so it may be conceptually difficult if you have never thought about astro before, but it's not very demanding in terms of workload.
Interesting and very useful course for Astrophysics majors. Don't take it particularly for the math or the programming part (which are both easy), but for the astro content.
Practice Python beforehand, start the problem sets early, and don't be afraid to ask for help. You'll enjoy it!

Super interesting class! psets can get tricky so give them plenty of time. Even if you're not an astro major, definitely take it if you have a solid physics background and are at all interested in the topic.
prereqs: PHY103/104 OR PHY 105/106, and MAT 103/104, or consent of instructor. Background in computer programming is helpful, but not required..
descrip: How do we observe and model the universe? We discuss the wide range of observational tools available to the modern astronomer: from space-based gamma ray telescopes, to globe-spanning radio interferometry, to optical telescopes and particle detectors. We review basic statistics and introduce students to techniques used in analysis and interpretation of modern data sets containing millions of galaxies, quasars and stars, as well as the numerical methods used by theoretical astrophysicists to model these data. The course is problem-set-based and aims to provide students with tools needed for independent research in astrophysics.

title: Intermediate Turkish I
reviews: If you want to take Turkish, Erika Gilson is the individual to study it with.
Take it! It is very well-taught.
prereqs: TUR 102 or permission of instructor..
descrip: Extensive exposure to current news, authentic multimedia sources; in-depth review of grammar. Introduction to modern Turkish literature, with close reading of selected prose and poetry. Development of all language skills and cultural understanding is emphasized.

title: Seminar in Roman Art - The Augustian Provinces
descrip: The seminar will address the provincial developments in art and architecture across the empire during the Augustan period (Hispania, Gaul, Mauretania, Africa, Greece, Asia, etc).

title: Dissertation Writers' Seminar
prereqs: This course is open only to post-generals students. Each student will give one fifty-minute presentation of work in progress..
descrip: A practical introduction to scholarly writing at the dissertation level and beyond, providing guidance on planning and completing the dissertation and on other aspects of becoming a professional scholar and teacher, such as mastering the craft of the journal article (conceiving, writing and submitting), writing effective syllabi for different kinds of courses, and turning the dissertation into a book (with visits by editors from leading presses). The seminar meets every two weeks and is required of all post-generals students in residence, who will have the opportunity to present and discuss their work in progress.

title: Political Economy Workshop
descrip: Seminar led by different guest professors each week to discuss their current research in the field of Political Economy. Third and fourth year graduate students are expected to attend; first and second year graduate students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: The Diversity of Brains
reviews: A wonderful, cool class that doesn't waste your time with busy work but teaches you how to think.
An interesting class with not too much work. I would recommend it.
Great course. Fun topics to talk about, and manageable work load.

I love this class. Really interesting material, extremely manageable workload, low stress (just weekly readings and a small final project). Also, Asif is the best. He is a great professor - really nice, understanding with grading, and super funny. A little nervous about the curve because it seems everyone always gets very good grades. Aside from that, highly recommend!

I loved taking Ghazanfar's course. He's a really nice guy, and he will get on your level to talk to you. He doesn't patronize you as a student at all. He loves engaging you in intellectual conversation. Take it, dude. It wasn't even that much work.
I would highly recommend this course for any student looking for a neuro certificate elective. It's interesting and not too much work. Also, the final paper is very short and there is no midterm.
I would recommend this class.
Take it if it sounds at all interesting to you.
Take this course! Professor Ghazanfar is awesome!
The presentation is a big part of the grade and it can be a lot of fun to be an "expert" on one of the articles, so I would encourage spending a lot of time on that.

This is a good class to take for anyone. It's actually a good mix of EEB and neuro, and I was surprised at how much I actually learned. The topics covered are very interesting, and Asif does a good job of providing background information for the following week. The class revolves around student presentations, which were very chill and low stress. Asif is very fair, funny, and kept things interesting.
This is a great neuroscience course! You don't need a ton of neuroscience experience to enjoy it.
prereqs: NEU/PSY 258 or NEU/PSY 259A,B.
descrip: The premise of this seminar is that an understanding of the neural basis of behavior can be gained by examining species-typical behaviors. Each animal species has evolved neural solutions to specific problems posed to them by their environment. The course will focus primarily on forebrain mechanisms in mammals, highlighting the unique environmental problems that a species must solve and the ways in which the brains of these animals implement their solutions. Some example model systems include prey capture by bats, monogamy and aggression in voles, and eye gaze processing by primates.

title: The Ethnographer's Craft
reviews: Do not take it unless you have to, and try to prevent taking it with Professor Rouse
Don't take it. even though you have to dont do it
Don't take this course unless you have to.

Good luck. Do the readings because they will help you. Go to office hours because those students are her favorites. Try and participate when you can and ask Bridget for her help. 
If you play a sport don't let it be known- she has obvious dislike towards athletes.

I don't think anybody would ever take this class except for the requirement, so I think the only thing you can say is you just have to grunt through it. its not a fun class, especially not with rouse, but its necessary.

If you are Anthropology major, you have to take this course. Unfortunately, it is not a good course, and it is a shame. Grading and assignments are vague, and though some of the readings are interesting, they do not get discussed.
If you must, you must. If you are taking this for interest, take any other anthropology course instead.
It's a requirement for anthro.
Just hang in there.
No
Only take this class if you have to.
Only take this if you are an ANT concentrator.
Required for Anthro Majors--take it from Rouse.
Start the assignments early because they are time consuming.

This class certainly meanders; just go with it, and you'll learn a lot.  It's good for us not to always have all the details printed out anyway ;)  You need to be engaged with this class to learn, so don't check out.
This course is miserable, use the TA not the teacher if you have questions.

This is a pretty annoying class. It's a departmental so you have to take it, but it probably won't be your favorite class. The assignments are so much fun and worth really investing in, but it's hard because you have to write exactly as Professor Rouse wants. I'd try to get to know what she's looking for - she leaves most assignments open-ended but then surprises you in her grading with very specific things she was looking for.
Would not recommend to non-Anthropology concentrators.
You have to take it if you're anthro... don't even consider it otherwise.
You have to take this, and don't feel compelled to do the readings if you're not tested on them. Also, take another class with Rouse because she is better teaching on a subject/body of knowledge.
You probably shouldn't take this unless you're trying to be an anthro major.
prereqs: Open to all students interested in learning more about qualitative methods..
descrip: What are social and cultural facts? And how do we identify these facts using anthropological research methods? This field methods course is for students interested in learning how to work with complex and often contradictory qualitative data. Students will examine how biases and beliefs affect the questions we ask, the data we collect, and our interpretations. Key topics include objectivism, interpretation, reflexivity, participant-observation, translation, and comparison. In addition to reading ethnographies, this class will use ethnographic films as a lens through which to explore the extraordinary power and limits of qualitative research.

title: Advanced Korean I
reviews: Take it if you're interested in Korean.
This class is more geared toward transitioning a student towards more formal learning.
prereqs: KOR 107 or placement test..
descrip: Advanced Korean is designed to develop fluency in both oral and literary skills. Expansion of vocabulary, practice in reading comprehension as well as active skills of conversation and writing are stressed through short readings and class discussion. Readings include different styles of writings on various topics including Korean culture, society, and history. 100 characters of Hanjas are introduced.

title: Economic Development I
reviews: Great class!
Take it even if this isn't your field.
Take this course if you want to know about what is going on in the third countries
descrip: An examination of those areas in the economic analysis of development where there have been recent analytical or empirical advances. Emphasis is given to the formulation of theoretical models and econometric analysis and testing. Topics covered include models of household/farm behavior, savings behavior, equity and efficiency in pricing policy, project evaluation, measurement of poverty and inequality, and the analysis of commodity prices.

title: Organic Chemistry I: Biological Emphasis
reviews: Actually do the problem sets. They're very useful. Also, be very good at the formalisms- they're important.

Although getting up at 8:30 is rough, and some of the material is difficult to go through, I really liked the course by the end of the semester. Some of the trickier exam questions were like putting a soduku puzzle together.
Always attend lectures and do a lot of practice problems. Always ask questions if you don't understand something.
Always go to lecture!! Don't cram! It's definitely a worthwhile class.
Ask questions before you get behind.
Attend all review sessions and find others in the class to work with.
Be a morning person. I feel I would have took a lot more out of the class if it were just at a later time.
Be prepared to do a lot of individual work and reading.
Be prepared to work hard! Do every single practice exam in preparation for examinations. Readings were helpful!
Be prepared to work really hard! This course is a giant puzzle- you need to keep up with each of the little pieces for it to fit together!

Be prepared to work very hard, especially if you do not have an immediate interest in organic chemistry! It really is a very cumulative course, so be sure to keep up and understanding everything the moment classes start.
Be smart and spend a lot of time studying.
Beware of the premeds!

Challenging intellectual experience; can exercise brain. Usually won't understand everything in lecture but will understand in precept. Do past exams fiercely. Need to be very familiar with the materials in order to be fast enough. Takes much time to prepare for exams. Don't hesitate to shoot preceptor emails to interrogate whenever have questions. Don't spend too much time on lab.
Choose a schedule that gives you time to commit to this class.
DO THE READINGS. Don't take it unless you have to and/or want to get a C. Honestly it's not a lot of work outside the tests so it might be a good p/d/f option
DOn't take it unless you have to. If you are premed or Chemistry major (or even Chemical Engineering) and have to, then it is irrelevant.
Definitely form study groups. Your understanding of the material will improve from discussion with others, and problem sets will be much easier to do in groups.

Definitely review your lecture notes after lecture, see what you're confused about, attend office hours, and get help when needed! Do as many practice exams as you can before exams in order to gain confidence and familiarity with the types of problems. It's a lot of work, but with lots of practice, you will be alright. Never forget that there are a ton of resources for you-- seeking help when needed will make all the difference. Professor Semmelhack and the TAs are all very approachable, so don't be intimidated!
Do LOTS of practice exams. The questions are HARD.
Do all of the practice exams
Do all the practice tests!
Do it. It's not as bad as everyone says it is. Go on! Don't be a pussy! Why are you still reading this? Have you signed up yet? YOUR LAB NEEDS YOU!
Do not take.
Do practice exams!

Do practice exams. Do problems everyday. Go to McGraw. Go to the resource center. Go to office hours. Stay on top of things or they will catch up to you, I promise you. And you won't follow my advice, because I didn't follow my advice, but you'll still make it through.
Do problems on your own!!!
Do the practice exams. They save your life. Do all of them. The only way you're gonna get better is by practicing, and you'll get used to the patterns once you do it more.
Don't be scared! Just do the problem sets, use your preceptor, and when you study, do old exams.
Don't do this class for fun like I did
Don't fall behind, read the book when you are unclear about something, do as many practice tests as you can. Good course--I enjoyed it.
Don't let the course material intimidate you; make an effort to understand all the material and do as many practice tests as possible.
Don't memorize.
Don't miss lecture and try to get a good preceptor. Do the readings if you can, and definitely do the problem sets (and understand them!)
Don't take it unless it's required. Do lots of practice problems throughout the year.
Don't take it unless you have to.
Don't take it unless you have to. If you have to, do all the exams.
Get a different book.
Get help as often as possible. Many exam questions are "exceptions." And it helps to know tricks in order to pass.
Go to Professor Semmelhack's office hours and attend the weekly McGraw Review sessions. I went to almost each one and they always helped me make sure I understood the material and.
Go to lecture and do not fall asleep. Go to office hours. Read the textbook. Don't throw out something during lab without making absolute sure you don't need it anymore. Do practice tests.

Go to resource hours, especially if you've missed a lecture. Be brazen and just ask all the questions you have. DO ALL THE PRACTICE EXAMS. Don't take this class if you plan to be lazy and be prepared to skip fun nights out studying for orgo. In the end, the course is super rewarding and it really is like doing puzzles--just progressively harder ones.
Go to the resource center!
Grade deflation is a bummer.
Great class just stay on top the of material and do ALL of the practice tests and problem sets.
Great class!
Hard, but once you move past being angry at how hard it is the material itself is interesting.
I assume most people don't take this course on a whim. Certainly, it is not something to be afraid of, though if you are looking for an easy, low work course, this is not it.

I do not recommend this course to Freshman at all. I really regretted putting myself through this first semester. A caveat: I was enrolled in probably the HARDEST freshman seminar which accompanied with this class made it hard to find time to do the practice tests.

You're probably going to have to take this course because you have to. I wouldn't take it if you don't have to.
I felt that this was a good course even for people who do not plan on majoring in chemistry.
I took orgo because I had to and probably wouldn't have otherwise. However, I thought the course good considering it was in a subject I wasn't incredibly interested in.
I would not recommend this class unless you have to take it.
I would say that Orgo, though known to be hard, is actually a fantastic course and that if you put in the effort, there are so many people there to help you.

I would say the most important thing is to keep up with the material as you learn it. It is very hard to learn four weeks of material the weekend before a midterm. If you keep up with the readings and the problem sets, you will find the course manageable
I would tell students to only take this course if it is a requirement.

If you can, take this course at another university. It's very disorganized. If you can't, it's definitely something you can survive, but expect to spend a lot of time learning independently because Semmelhack isn't the greatest lecturer. Become best friends with the T.A.'s -- they will save your life. ALWAYS do the problem sets.

If you need to take it, do that, otherwise the class isn't particularly exciting or interesting. Do not feel compelled to go to lecture and/or precept if it does not help you; however, the most important thing is just to do as much practice as you can. The class really isn't as hard as it's been built up to be, but you shouldn't really be trying to "study" orgo so much as just doing it. Studying for tests is best accomplished by looking over all the previous practice tests, and as well as the respective answer keys (published online)
If you work hard enough, you can come out with a good grade.

If you're looking at this class, you're most likely either pre-med or a chemistry major in which case you have to take it anyway so just keep on pushing through it. If you're looking at this course just for the heck of it, reconsider your options. If you really think this is the class you want to take for fun, then you really have no one to blame for the consequences.

If you're taking it, it's a requirement. Not nearly as scary as everyone makes it sound. Class is very well organized, especially with mind-bogglingly quick exam grading times (24 hrs to grade all the finals... O_O )
If you're taking orgo, there's usually a requirement for it. Get a good preceptor, go to as many lectures as possible, work really hard for the exams.
If you're taking this course, make sure you do as many practice exams as possible.
If you're taking this, you probably have to. If you really like chemistry though, I'd recommend it as well.
It goes without saying that this course is tough.  Be prepared to work a lot and not necessarily see great results.  Seek out resources early and often.

It is definitely a course you can take even if you're just interested in the material. I would highly recommend it. It's not hard to stay on top of the material, though it might required more time to get the most practice.
It's a lot better than people say it is. As long as you put the time in, it'll be okay!
It's fun if you're curious about the magic source of life.

It's not a class that I'd say is one you have to take before you graduate and it's not even one I say you should take for fun. If you have to take it though, it's taught very well and the material is presented interestingly.

It's not as awful as people say. It certainly is very difficult, but if you are prepared to dedicate yourself to learning the material, you will do well. There are also plenty of help resources. Note: Do not take this course just out of a light interest, etc...
It's orgo.  Only do it if you have to or you honest to God love chemistry.
It's time-consuming.
It's very competitive grade-wise.  Pretty hard

Its orgo. do all the practice exams and as you are doing them and checking your answers, write down the concepts that you miss in each question you got wrong so you can intentionally clarify that later.
Keep up on the material and ask for help if you need it.
Keep up with the lectures and ask questions if you fall behind.
Keep up with the material! It builds up, and it is a good idea to review a little bit each day!
Keep up with the material...
Make sure you do as many practice tests as you can to prepare for exams and you should be ok. Also, go to office hours!

Most of you will be taking this course as a requirement, but it's really not that bad, and some of the material is actually really interesting. But big word of advice: Go to Semmelhack's office hours starting Week 1! Only a few students ever go, so you get LOADS of individual attention. It's really worth it!
No one take's this course without being forced to anyway, so I don't have any advice.  Everyone already knows that it is horrible
Obviously only take this course if you're CHM/CHE/premed. Otherwise you're insane.
Only if you need to.
Only take it if you need to/ have an actual interest.
Only take it if you're really interested or have to.
Only take this course if you are willing to put in the work, but it is extremely interesting.

Organic Chemistry I  is a course you should seriously consider, whether or not it is required for your major.  The lectures, despite the large number of students, are taught in an engaging manner, the professors, preceptors, and lab TA's are genuinely helpful, and the course is really designed to help you learn instead of "parroting" back information.  The homeworks are graded on completion and the formal labs are submitted in a draft/final version process, so you can use the written as a tool to help you understand the material rather than worrying about points.  The lowest score of the three class exams is also thrown out when grading, and all the exams and the final are open notes and book, so the exam pressure is also fairly low.  Overall, the class does a wonderful job of being very informative without being overwhelming.

Organic chemistry is time consuming, it may take up your entire weekend before the three midterms, so time management is key. Semelhack and the team make the class easy  to gain information if you are willing to take advantage of all the resources available.
Orgo is a really interesting class, both for majors and non-majors. The teachers are very helpful and are willing to help you do well rather than trying to trip you up all the time.

Orgo is definitely a difficult course, however it is probably not the worst you'll take at Princeton.  It helps to pay attention to everything he mentions in lecture, especially towards the end of the semester, and do not fall behind because everything builds upon itself.  In the end, it is much more about understanding why things happen/are the way they are than memorizing all the different reactions and chemical properties.

Don't be scared away from this class--it is entirely doable and it actually turned out to be one of my favorite classes of the semester.  Semmelhack is a great lecturer, the problem sets are not stressful as they are graded only for completion, and all the professors/TAs are very good at answering any questions you might have.
Orgo is not as bad as everyone makes it to be. It just takes
Orgo is really not as bad as it's made out to be- it is a LOT of work, but it's really interesting. Make sure you do all the practice tests, or as many as you can!
Orgo really isn't all that hard. If you want to take it, take it.

Orgo's not nearly as bad as it's cracked up to be. If you make the time to study for the midterms and the final, you'll do really well. GO TO LECTURE, and don't really bother about the readings. Study with other people, and ask questions.
Perfect for anyone with a strong interest in chemistry or biology, and one that is able to apply a variety of basic concepts to a plethora of novel situations.

Please, do all the reading. Pay attention in class and take great notes. Start the problem sets early in the week, then compare answers with other students. Don't wait until the last minute. Study in groups. Never be afraid to ask questions in precept, especially early on. My problem was that I got so far behind that I felt stupid asking such easy questions in review sessions; at least I thought they would be perceived as stupid questions. Review a little bit each week so review for the midterms and final exam isn't so stressful. Honestly, do these things. They sound basic but I didn't do them and I regret this. I found out a lot about myself; that I wasn't as disciplined and mentally tough as I thought I was.
Pre-meds.

Pretty much everyone is taking this class because they have to, but don't think that means you can't enjoy it.  Forget about orgo's reputation and everyone else stressing and put in the effort all the way through.  It's far more qualitative than most sciences I've encountered (the debatability of the first few sections is a weird adjustment off the bat).  My best advice is to focus on doing the practice tests, not reading the book.  The class is very fair in grading, so don't be hesitant to ask for regrades.  I also enjoyed the labs more than in gen chem.

Probably don't take for a grade unless you need it.
Good class in that as long as you can grasp key concepts, you should be fine. Still pretty difficult though.
Read the appropriate sections in the book before coming to class. Also, get a good night's sleep beforehand. It's important that you pay attention in class as well as stay awake in it, too.
Read the textbook before going to lecture, otherwise you will be lost. Do a lot of practice exams.

Reading the book is not as necessary as doing practice problems.  Also, make sure to study for all three exams even if you do well on the first two.  I didn't do this and it really hurt my preparedness or the final.

Really try to understand the material, don't just try to get the right answer. It's not worth doing 10 practice tests: doing and redoing the same 5 making sure you understand every problem (i.e. the majority of the material) can get you an A
Recommend if you like puzzles and don't mind putting in the extra work.
STUDY HARD AND GOOD LUCK :D

Speaking from experience, I think they should work on organic chemistry regularly. It is a class where the staff is really dense, and needs constant work. So be aware and be wise! But the material is interesting if you put in enough work.

Stay ahead, make sure you understand everything fully. Everything's somewhere online. Khanacademy, handouts from other courses, they're all golden. Take the course and get it over with and do as much practice as you can.
Stay on top of everything.  It is tempting because you can drop an exam, but at least do a few practice tests even if you plan on dropping.

Stay on top of notes daily, do not let yourself fall behind for a second, but you will get blown away by the pace and difficulty of the course. No room for slacking. Do lots of practice problems from the book and old tests.

Stay on top of the material. Take as many practice tests as you can. If you don't go to lecture, read the completed lecture notes on blackboard, they cover the material pretty thoroughly. That said, Professor Semmelhack is a good lecturer, so go to lecture.
Stay on top of the work and always ask questions. Go to McGraw.
Stick through it and work hard. Orgo is fair.
Study a lot.
Study early for exams and do the psets.
Study hard and make sure to understand the material.
Study! Take the time to read and actually understand, not just scan through the concepts and try and memorize them.

Study, study, study. The professors are great and willing to help you, but it's up to you to hold yourself accountable for understanding the material fully. Always do your problem sets even though they're "optional." And don't get behind on your work or you'll seriously regret it come exam time. It's rough, but you can get through it. Grading is very fair.
Study. Don't get behind in the material.

Take advantage of all the resources, and not just before you fall behind. Start studying for the tests about a week before them. Do as many practice exams as you can, but don't be intimidated if other students complete over twice as many as you.
Take advantage of the numerous resources offered for the course.  I found Henry Gingrich and the various McGraw tutors to be the most helpful in clarifying the material.
Take it if you have to.
Take it if you have to. Not something I would imagine most people taking for kicks and giggles, but as far as orgo goes, well taught
Take it if you need to.  It's very hard but interesting.  Keep up with the readings and practice early!
Take it!  Even if I didn't need to, I would not have regretted taking orgo!
Take it. The subject material is interesting, and the grading isn't too harsh.

Take organic chemistry if you are a person who loves chemistry, or if you need to take it as a requirement. It is a good idea to take the practice exams, and perhaps time yourself. I was always poor on time, but I did practice alot.
Take practice exams like there's no tomorrow.
Take the practice exams.

The course is certainly challenging. If you are interested in the subject, by all means please take it. However, the course requires a lot of studying on your own and you should prepared to spend time everyday learning.

This class is a killer. You need to study way harder than you think you do and need to stay on top of work every week as it will soon pile up with the midterms. But, if you do well on the final you do well in the class. Just work up to it and do well on it and nothing else matters.
This class is a requirement for many students, but I would still recommend it as it is a very useful and interesting class.
This class is very difficult, so you'll probably only be taking it if you need to anyway. But if you do, you'll learn something.

This course is not bad. First tip: Read Organic Chemistry as a Second language (First semester topics) by David Klein INSIDE OUT until you can quote the book. Second tip: Read the lectures over and over until you can quote them. Third tip: Find a study buddy.

This course is really interesting and can be an incredible demand on your time. I would not recommend taking it as a senior unless you can make sure the rest of your classes will be lighter. 

Do the reading. At times it more clearly explains something than lectures. There is little emphasis on memorization in the course, but having as full a command of "facts" as possible will help you in exams so long as you are not stuck with a fact you can not explain. Meaning - if you memorize something, understand what chemically makes sense about the given arrangement, molecule, atomic orbital, etc. 

While you read, I recommend that you make outlines of chapters so that you can have something of your own to study prior to practice exams. Practice exams? Yes, do them, and do them after studying as if you would study for an exam. Which means you may need to start working to an "exam-ready" state days before the actual exam. Doing practice exams without studying may help familiarize you with problems, but it may just lead to a perpetual sense of "oh, how was I supposed to know that?". 

The course emphasizes problem solving but at times does not offer a clear, explicit way into this way of thinking. It can be helpful to identify for yourself a methodological approach to the problems, maybe a series of questions or a schema, that can help you organize your thoughts when you see a new, seemingly undo-able situation. There are so many "exceptions" to "rules" that the instructors are wary of setting up students for future setbacks by asking them to remember a set of rules - but students may be more successful if they attempt to consciously reflect on the more schematic side of things. The students who do this really well are often unaware of what it is they are doing well -- which often creates an image of "innate" ability with orgo, but is not so much the material as an approach that they take to well. This certainly can be learned; do not be intimidated by people who may be

This is a very challenging, but rewarding course. Organic is very interesting and much more free-form than general chemistry. I thought the course was hard, but very worthwhile. However, a lot of time and effort needs to be put into this course. Study groups are absolutely essential and so are office hours. Chemistry actually becomes quite fun once you understand the  concepts.
This is a very rigorous course. Please be sure you are willing to work very hard and dedicate an incredible amount of your time towards practice, studying, and other review avenues.
This is actually a very good course. I thought it was tremendously difficult, but the material was interesting and extremely well taught.
This is definitely a work-intensive class, but in the end you may find that it is also a fascinating field of study.

To do well in this class, you really need to put in a lot of time. The more time you spend doing practice exams and asking questions at office hours, the better you will do. Do not miss lectures at all!
Try to do the readings on the topics you're shakier on. They're super dry, but they explain the material a little differently which can be helpful.

Unless you really like memorizing reaction types and being finicky over nitrogen versus phosphorus in structures, I do not recommend this course. If you need to take orgo as a pre-med or for a certain concentration, buckle down.
Very hard class.

WORK HARD.  This class requires a lot of time, and there's no two ways about it.  But you can do fine.  Make sure you do, and redo, as many practice problems as possible in preparation for exams.  Don't get behind, read the book if it helps you, but most of all, get the "feel" of orgo.  The advice everyone else gives (don't memorize, etc.) is spot on.  Also, you NEED to read / buy / learn Organic Chemistry as a Second Language by Klein.  Really.
You probably have to take it anyway. If you get it, great. If it doesn't come easy to you, GET HELP. You have no other choice.
You're probably taking this class because you have to. It's pretty hard, but can be fun!
difficult. but if you're taking it. well.. you're probably stuck doing it anyway. no need for advice.
do not do not do not do not EVER take it unless you have to.  i highly suggest taking it somewhere else if you don't want to suffer from depression after taking this class.
don't fall behind. Do the practice tests, problem sets, and the readings. Most importantly, go to lectures and review them daily.
if you get Kevin Wu, switch labs
it's difficult. spend a lot of time doing practice tests. a lot of work but you get a lot back if you put a lot into the work
keep up
only take it if you have a genuine interest
only take this course if you either LOVE it or it's a requirement because if you're just in the middle, it will be difficult to get motivated to work hard and do well in the class
take advantage of outside help like the mcgraw review sessions, they are more helpful than lecture
take it if you are premed, dont take if you arent
prereqs: CHM 201 and 202, or CHM 203 (or CHM 207) and 204, or CHM 215. Please contact Patrick Andrae (pandrae@princeton.edu) for all changes in lab and class sections after the completion of registration {OR} to add CHM 303 {OR} to be added to the waiting list for closed lab or class sections..
descrip: This course is designed as the first part of a three-semester sequence, CHM 303/304B and MOL 345 (biochemistry). CHM 303 will introduce the principles of organic chemistry, including the structures, properties, and reactivity of simpler organic compounds. The emphasis will be on the mechanisms of organic reactions, with examples taken from biology when appropriate to illustrate the principles. For a complete presentation of the subject, the course should be followed by CHM 304B in the spring.

title: Topics in Economics - Energy Economics
descrip: Examines the economics behind many issues related to energy use, including the investment and use of renewable and non-renewable resources, energy conservation, deregulation of energy markets, transportation, and energy independence. Current policy options will be discussed.

title: Introduction to Islam
descrip: This introductory course provides a thematic overview of Islamic beliefs, rituals and practices. The course will highlight commonalities among Muslims but will also focus on historical, geographical and cultural diversity. Course materials include primary sources in translation, academic articles and books, feature and documentary films, fiction and poetry in translation and images.

title: Music in the United States
descrip: Introduction to American music from its beginnings to today, tracing influences from Europe, Africa, India, Asia and considering classical music, jazz, popular, sacred and film music.
