Includes listening to, reading about and discussing a variety of compositions, reflecting composer's biographies, their socio-historical context, their musical language and investigating how much they have sought and succeeded to create an American musical idiom.

title: Special Topics in Entrepreneurship - The Lean LaunchPad
reviews: Apply if you're even considering entrepreneurship.

I think EGR 495 changes from semester to semester, but I took it when it was the Lean LaunchPad taught by visiting professor Jim Hornthal. It was a great experience to be able to try and launch a startup while being provided resources and guidance through this class. However, do not blow this class off or make it a low priority -- you'll get nothing out of it. Take this class if you're passionate about it.
If this class is ever offered again and you have any interest in entrepreneurship, it is definitely a must.
If you are interested in entrepreneurship, and want to get your hands dirty, this is a good class.

If you have a group, AND a clear idea, AND the desire to interview customers, AND you don't expect to get useful guidance from the instructors, this class is a great way to start a business for credit. But if you actually want to learn something in the classroom, or aren't 100% passionate, don't take it.
If you're lucky enough, TAKE THIS COURSE.

Make sure you have enough time for it! It will be one of, if not THE most memorable, fun, and rewarding things you ever do at Princeton, but it definitely takes a lot of time (think around 20hrs/week)

Take it, especially if it's taught in the same format next year with Profs Hornthall and Simmons showing up every wednesday. This is the best class I took at Princeton and was a potentially career changing experience

Take this course if you get the chance. Hopefully it will be offered in some form in the future. You will learn a ton - about business models, interviewing customers, your strengths and weaknesses, what you are interested in, how to evaluate ideas, etc.

This is by far the most interesting and the most useful course I have taken on entrepreneurship. It is great to experience the process of creating a business in a safe environment. If you have any interest in entrepreneurship, this is the course you should take before graduation.
prereqs: Enrollment for the course is by written application. Applications are available at the Keller Center (ACE-21 in the E-Quad) or http://commons.princeton.edu/kellercenter/2012/03/egr-495-the-lean-launch-pad.html. All applications must be completed and returned by April 20..
descrip: This course provides real world, hands-on learning on what it's like to actually start a high-tech company. This class is not about how to write a business plan. Instead you will be getting your hands dirty talking to customers, partners, competitors, as you encounter the chaos and uncertainty of how a start-up actually works. You'll work in teams learning how to turn a great idea into a great company. You'll learn how to use a business model to brainstorm each part of a company. Each week will be new adventure as you test each part of your business model and then share the hard earned knowledge with the rest of the class.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - GIS for Public Policy
descrip: This course is designed as a practical introduction to the use of computer mapping (Geographic Information systems) for policy analysis and decision-making. Students learn ArcGIS through examples of map applications. Students are expected to complete exercises and a final project applying GIS to a policy issue.

title: Dance Performance Workshop: Advanced Repertory and Choreography
reviews: Take if you love dance and want to learn how to look at dance in new ways!
Take it
prereqs: DAN 319 or equivalent experience. Interview with faculty for placement in composition section April 9th to April 20th, 2012. Interview times: Rebecca Lazier (rlazier@) T/TH 1pm-2pm; Tina Fehlandt (fehlandt@) M/W 1pm-2pm. To arrange interview, email Professor Lazier or Professor Fehlandt and send a list of any previous composition experience at Princeton. NOTE: Placement for Technique/Repertory component of class will be held Thursday, September 13th from 4:20-6:20 at Hagan Dance Studio at 185 Nassau..
descrip: In this course students will learn and perform repertory from a New York City-based choreographer and master teacher. This course will focus on a mastering movement that requires fluidity, lyricism, and musicality. Additional emphasis will be placed on performing dance movements with attention to alignment, detail, spatial clarity, and an awareness of other dancers. In choreography, students will work together on group objectives in movement-based laboratories focusing on collaboration and choreographic choice-making skills. Readings and viewings inform the studio work and place it in a relationship to current artistic movements.

title: Political Philosophy
reviews: Appiah is a good professor and very laid back, but I would take a lecture with him instead if you can.

As a politics student, I would strongly recommend this course to other politics students looking for a stronger command of the democratic theory which necessarily informs any wider study of politics in a modern democracy.
Drink a coffee before
Gives a broad and interesting overview to the various democratic theorists and critics.
I definitely recommend taking a class with Professor Appiah and taking advantage of his office hours.
I would take this course if you are interested in democratic theory, and would like to get a solid grip on some of the basic schools of thought.

If you have any interest at all in philosophy or democracy, this class will give you a new perspective on both. Professor Appiah is full of insights and the discussions are always productive, if slightly meandering.
If you like politics and philosophy take this course.
Professor Appiah is wonderful and you will enjoy this course!

This is a very interesting class if your passion is democracy, but if you are looking for other political theories, go elsewhere. This class is a great basis for becoming an expert in democratic theory and Professor Appiah is phenomenal, but my qualm with the course is that it didn't compare enough democracy to other forms of government, in which I am more interested. As a philosophy major, I was able to decide through this class that I did not want to pursue political philosophy as a sub-field.
descrip: Many people think they can recognize democracy when they see it and that democracy is uncontroversially good. Even if they are right, it is worth trying to give a theoretical account of what makes a practice, institution or state democratic; and to consider and evaluate arguments for and against democracy. So we will begin with a brisk survey of some traditional analyses and defenses of democracy and we will then spend the rest of our time (a) discussing a few more recent attempts to say what the core elements of democracy are and to defend it, and (b) evaluating some recent challenges to democratic ideals.

title: Introduction to Portuguese I
prereqs: No credit is given for POR 101 unless POR 102 is taken..
descrip: Students will be taught the fundamental skills of oral comprehension, speaking, reading and writing, while gaining exposure to the Portuguese-speaking world through the media, literature, film and the music of Brazil, Portugal and Lusophone Africa.

title: Economics of the Labor Market
reviews: Easily one of the best Economics courses I have taken at Princeton
Good course, taught by master of the field.  Very laid back and low stress, but still interesting and educational.
It's an interesting course.
Office hours can be very helpful when doing the final paper.
The professor is kind and knowledgeable, but it isn't the most engaging course I have ever taken.
prof. ashenfelter is a really entertaining guy with a lot of great stories to tell. this is a great class to take as an elective.
read the assigned paper carefully in order to get used to structure of the paper you are expected to write
take it
prereqs: ECO 100 and ECO 302 and MAT 102 or MAT 103..
descrip: To provide a general overview of labor markets. Covering labor force participation, the allocation of time to market work, migration, labor demand, investment in human capital (education, on-the-job training, man-power training), discrimination, unions and unemployment. The course will also examine the impact of government programs (such as unemployment insurance, minimum wages, or a negative income tax) on the labor market.

title: Numerical Prediction of the Atmosphere and Ocean
descrip: A practical introduction to the numerical approaches that are used to simulate the evolution of the ocean and atmosphere. This course covers the forms of the equations of motion that are most appropriate for numerically studying various atmospheric and oceanic phenomena, and the numerical techniques that are used for their spatial and temporal discretization. The conservation properties of the continuous equations of motion and the numerical approaches for reproducing them are covered, as are the parameterization of unresolved phenomena, and specific considerations for accurate simulation of tracers.

title: Basic Principles of Quantum Mechanics
reviews: Attend class and do the readings.
Good class worth taking for chemists.

If you are interested in studying Quantum Mechanics at an advanced level, then this course is for you.  But be prepared for a lot of homework to do each week, and a lot of dense reading to get through.  If you are persistent and actively engage the course, you will learn some pretty cool things about Quantum Mechanics.
It's basically linear algebra in a strange format.  Once that's understood, it's not very complicated.
prereqs: Successful completion of a quantum mechanics course (at the level of CHM 405) and one semester of linear algebra.
descrip: Basic QM concepts at a rigorous level appropriate for graduate students in experimental and theoretical physical chemistry, applied physics and engineering. Topics include (i) mathematical formalism of Hilbert spaces and operators in time-independent quantum theory (ii) single-particle QM for bound and unbound states (iii) basic angular momentum theory (iv) exactly soluble systems: harmonic oscillator and hydrogen atom (v) indistinguishable particles (vi) variational theorem (vii) time-independent perturbation theory (viii) time-dependent theory and Fermi?s golden rule, and (ix) applications to chemical problems.

title: Microeconomics for Public Policy
reviews: Be prepared to put a lot of time into it if Rosen is teaching it, but it's worth it.
Be prepared to work hard.
Don't freak out after the first p set destroys you. They get easier.
Get ready to work your tail off.
Go to class.
Go to lectures. That's where you will learn the most. Textbook is useless. This class is P-set based.
I would take this because of Professor Rosen, and, otherwise, I may have taken ECO 300 instead because I think the curve was easier.
If Harvey's teaching it, you gotta take it. If you don't get it just reach out to him--he loves his students.
If you're deciding between ECO 300 and WWS 300, take WWS 300.
It's difficult but Harvey's worth it.
Professor Rosen is one of the best professors Princeton has to offer.

Take it if you love Professor Rosen, since he is basically awesome. It's not too mathematically intensive, and there's a lot of very interesting concepts you get to learn. Just keep in mind that the primary purpose of this course is not to teach you policy, it's more to teach you the economic tools you need to keep in mind while making policy.
Take it!

Take this course with Harvey Rosen! Rosen is the most amazing professor, and this course is extremely interesting and engaging. I am not an econ person, but Rosen was a phenomenal professor and completely changed my mind about the importance of econ in public policy. It's great that this is now a WWS requirement- everybody should take this.

Take this course with Rosen!! It's not easy, but you will get so much out of it and learn to think about econ in a much more intuitive way. Lectures keep you on your toes -- Rosen cold calls, so you have to keep up. Overall this was a wonderful course and made me want to take more econ in the future.
Take this over the Econ 300 course.
This course is extremely difficult, but the material is useful and Professor Rosen in a spectacular professor.
rosen is amazing, and so is yan lau. take this class even if you're just a little interested in economics and public policy!
take it!!!
prereqs: Prerequisite: ECO 100. This course is not open to students who have taken ECO 300 or ECO 310..
descrip: Microeconomics is the study of how people and societies confront scarcity. This course, taught at the intermediate level, focuses on markets as a mechanism for dealing with scarcity, and uses examples that cast light on public policy issues.

title: Policy Workshop - Innovations in Urban Economics Development (Cleveland's Coop Model)
descrip: Many US cities are in economic decline as jobs evaporate, poverty deepens and populations shrink. In response, several cities and organizations are partnering with anchor institutions, universities/hospitals that are deeply rooted and committed to community development. These institutions are spurring job creation by investing in and utilizing worker-owned cooperative businesses, such as the Evergreen Cooperatives in Cleveland. This workshop examines the feasibility and potential of worker cooperatives to help rejuvenate inner-city economies and will produce a report for a government agency/leading organization engaged in these issues.

title: Witnessing Disaster
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Race and the City
descrip: Race and the City examines how the politics of race and racialization shaped the development of American cities over the course of the 20th century. The course cover a diverse array of topics including: ghettoization, urban renewal, the creation of public housing, popular music (Jazz, Motown, Hip Hop), public art and graffiti, literature of urbanity, the fair housing movement, deindustrialization and gentrification. We will have particular foci on the following cities: Chicago, Detroit, Atlanta, Los Angeles and Philadelphia.

title: Senior Independent Work
prereqs: For each project the requirements are set in consultation with the faculty advisor, and depend somewhat on the nature of the project. An oral presentation during Reading Period (as per departmental schedule) and a written final report is required. A written report is required by the Department, even if ELE 497 is taken as a part of a two-term sequence with ELE 498. An unbound copy of the report must be turned in to the ELE Undergrad Office by Dean's Date. Details of requirements are available from the ELE Undergraduate office. Senior standing is required..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a "state-of-the-art" project in electrical engineering. A student may propose a topic and find a faculty member willing to supervise the work. Or the student may select a topic from lists of projects obtained from faculty and off-campus industrial researchers, subject to the consent of a project advisor. There is no formal reading list for the course; however, a literature search is a normal part of most projects.

title: Israeli Media: Barometer and Engine of Sociopolitical and Cultural Change
reviews: I loved it, and if you need to fulfill some requirements, this is a great course to take.
This is a great course to take if you want to keep updated with what is going on in the Middle East while keeping up your Hebrew speaking.
descrip: This course uses various forms of Israeli media, including television shows, web sites, blogs, and newspapers, to explore the ethical and moral dimensions of contemporary debates on cultural pluralism in Israel and tensions in Israeli society. Topics include relations between Jews and Arabs, rifts between Orthodox and secular Jews, and the challenges of accommodating and integrating into a single society immigrants who come from diverse backgrounds and lack a common immigrant experience. The course is intended for advanced speakers of Hebrew.

title: Introductory Physics I
reviews: A lot of out of class work is required for success in this course.
A well taught and straight forward physics class. If you took the AP Physics in high school, this will be a review.
Absolutely miserable - don't take it if you don't have to. If you have to - make sure you get into a precept/class with a good teacher.
Avoid Kirk McDonald like the Black Plague. Avoid Kirk McDonald like you avoid murderers. Avoid Kirk McDonald.
Be sure to attend the lectures. Professor Austin is excellent and his demonstrations really help in clarifying the concepts.
Do the problem sets and go to office hours with questions! They will prepare you well for the quizzes and this kind of course is one you don't want to slack off on.

Do the weekly problem sets, and be prepared to give up your Thursday nights to study for the weekly Friday quizzes (find a study group and go over lecture demos).  Overall a reasonable class... Just don't schedule anything right after lab, which frequently runs an hour (or longer) over.
Do well on the quizzes. Pay attention during demos and take advantage of the STUDY GUIDES  on Wiley Plus.
Don't be fooled by the fact that this is Physics 101, this is a hard class that requires a lot of work and good time management.
Don't take it unless you have to
Don't take it unless you have to.
Don't take unless you must.
Even though this class is 101, it is difficult and requires dedication. I would only take it if necessary.
Get Giombi as a preceptor!

Hire a tutor if you need to be taught this material. Don't get McDonald as a preceptor. Go somewhere else. I legitimately had to self-teach this entire course, which is hard because it's physics. Do the homework, then do it again. Just keep doing problems. Use McGraw as a resource too, those guys are key.
I learned a lot, and unless you're a physics genius, there are a lot cool things that you didn't know before!!
I think this was a great course and I would recommend it to all those who are interested in physics.

I took this because I need physics for pre-med and did not want to be challenged as much as I would in 103.  It was a review of high school physics, but the pace is quite fast with weekly quizzes to make sure we're staying on top of things.  While sometimes interesting, Professor Austin's lectures are often difficult to follow, and labs are long and not engaging.
I would recommend that you only take this course if you really have to for Pre-Med.
I would say do the problem sets and go to precept.
I would suggest not waiting until junior year to take this class.
I would take it!
I wouldn't take it if I didn't have to.
I'm not very good at physics to begin with, but I wouldn't take this unless you have to.
I'm sorry

If this class is taught by Austin, please avoid at all cost. If you have no other choice, make sure you get Uson as your preceptor, even if it means going to class at 9am. Trust me, losing that nappy time will be worth it because he may as well be the lecturer.
If you are taking physics with no background, it is very challenging. However, the professors are very kind and always willing to help. They genuinely want to see you succeed.
If you like science this is a great course. I really enjoyed it and learned a lot of useful things.
If you're premed, it's probably better than PHY 103 so you don't have much choice. For those looking for an ST, there are better classes out there.

If you're taking this course, you're probably premed, or it's a prerequisite for your concentration. Don't take this course if you think you're interested in physics and just want to fulfill an STL - it really isn't worth it. Robert Austin was really confusing, so if you don't understand demos during lecture, make sure to stay after and ask him more questions - he's usually much more helpful then. Weekly quizzes are really unpleasant, but doable if you understood all of the homework and made sure you understood all of the demos from lecture.
It's fine. Austin is a great lecturer, but many aspects of the course are simply annoying.

It's not a bad course, but be prepared to work to get a good grade as it is fast paced and frequently full of premeds. Lecture was fun and a good precept can make it an all-around fun course. Lab is the worst part easily.
Just do all the homework and go to class and you should do fine.
Labs suck. Overall not a bad course. If Simone is one of your preceptors, make sure to be in his class!
Make sure you're committed if you take this class.
Maybe try not to take it with Prof Austin.....
No, don't take it. Realistically think about doing physics over the summer at a school near you.
Only really take it if you  need to. There's no point to taking this out of a "general interest" especially because the class is 90% med school applicants and/or mol bio and eeb majors.
Only take if you must.
Only take this course if you have to. If you are simply curious about physics, this course will be a great disappointment.
Only take this if you have to.
Preceptors are key to have in this course. Get a good one no matter what.
Prepare as much as possible for the midterm and final.
Read the textbook. Read it before Monday precepts so that you are on top of the material.

Solidly understand how to do a variety of problems before each quiz. Sometimes you may really understand the concepts of a chapter, but if you don't know how to do the 2 or 3 questions that are on the quiz, you're screwed. Also, prepare well for the midterm. It's killer.
Some precepts took home quizes and other precepts had to do them on Fridays.  Not very fair, but this wasn't addressed until the semester was halfway over.

Study for the quizzes and keep up with the work throughout the week. The midterm is much more difficult than the quizes. Attend lectures because it's just once a week, Professor Austin often gives hints about the quizzes, and they are actually very entertaining.
Take it if you have to -- workload is relatively easy but not the most enlightening class
Take it if you have to. Study for the weekly quizzes and get a tutor if you need it!
Take it if you need it. If you take physics classes for fun then you're insane.

Take some sort of physics before this class. You'll be thoroughly lost if you have no background of physics

The lab will take three hours, at least. Resign yourself to that fact.

Your experience with the class will definitely be shaped by who you have as your preceptor, so try to get someone who does a good job.  If you have to take it, just be sure to put in a fair amount of work and you'll be okay.
This is a good course to take if you need to take physics or get a science/STL out of the way. Not entirely easy but also doable.
Try to understand lectures
Use this to get rid of pre-med requirements. It's awful, but easy.

You're most likely taking this class because it's some sort of requirement. If it's not, don't take it. Even on the off-chance that it's taught well when you take it, you'll be competing with a million pre-meds who will all kill for an A.
don't take it if you aren't premed

take it if you're pre-med. there are many other science classes to take if you need a STL.
you have to take it.
prereqs: Completion of laboratory experiments is mandatory..
descrip: The course is concerned with an introduction to the fundamental laws underlying physics and having general application in other areas of science. The treatment is complete and detailed, however, less mathematical preparation is assumed than for PHY 103-104. Mechanics and thermodynamics are treated quantitatively with a special emphasis on problem solving. In the spring semester PHY 102 covers electricity and magnetism, optics and relativity using the topics treated in PHY 101.

title: Beginner's Russian I
reviews: As long as you are willing to put in the time to learning the class material and doing the homework then this class is wonderful.
I highly recommend this course.
If you need to satisfy your language requirement and want to do something cool and different, TAKE THIS CLASS.
Only take this class if you have a genuine interest in Russian. Do not just take it if you need a random language to fulfull your distribution requirement.
Seriously, take this class.  Stas is great, and the classes in Russian are so small, its basically seminar style.
Take this course if you want to learn Russian, because you will.
This is a course needs daily work.
You should really be motivated to learn the language.
descrip: The objective of RUS101 is to give a basic knowledge of Russian. All aspects of introductory grammar are thoroughly presented in this course, with emphasis on conversation throughout the term. All additional materials are available on the web.

title: Religions of Late Antiquity Workshop
descrip: A weekly, year-long workshop providing students in the Religions of Late Antiquity with the opportunity to present their current research for discussion.

title: Environmental Decision Making
reviews: Be prepared for a course that's challenging in the amount of thinking that goes into the assignments.

Excellent professor! Great class to help you seriously think about not just environmental decision-making, but general decision-making that can be applied to any field and any career. Great holistic personal development class.
I would highly recommend the course.

It's time consuming, but really interesting. Even if you don't plan to pursue geoscience, the sets of skills and knowledge you gain from this course is useful and interesting. You will definitely gain a new perspective about environmental efforts,

Just take it. The professor is amazing. He will make you think about environmental issues in ways you might have never thought before. Being taught by someone as great and as captivating as he is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity, so just take it.
TAKE IT. It will change the way you think and act forever. Professor van der Vink is AMAZING.
Take it!
Take it. The work load is manageable, the professor is fun and brilliant, and it is not too hard to do well.

Take this class. This course is challenging in that it throws you into "real world" situations. As GVDV explains during the first lesson, there will not always be an answer in the back of the textbook for the questions asked in this class. I acquired so many life skills in Environmental Decision making and learned a lot about the Environment during the process. The professor is amazing, so accessible (he gives you his cell number and expects you call him with questions), and very well versed in the topics he covers. Certainly a challenge but YOU MUST TAKE THIS CORUSE.
Take this course! GvdV is brilliant and you gain so much knowledge from him about life and environmental decision making. He has honestly made me a better thinker in one semester.
Take this course. It may be the hardest course I've taken at Princeton, but it's also the most rewarding. GvDV is the best.

This is not a light course load. Assignments take a lot longer than expected, and at the end of the semester there's an incredibly time consuming paper (a legitimate business proposal) as well as a final exam. van der Vink does everything orally - there are no written notes, syllabus, or assignment descriptions, so you're in trouble if you miss class. And be sure to take good notes because you'll need them for the final exam as well as for assignments. Listening in class/paying attention is vital. If you're quick to fall asleep in class, or you tend to miss class for whatever reason, this is not the class for you. Nor is it the class for you if you don't like giving oral reports or speaking up about your opinion. But if you're interested in environmental entrepreneurship, you will really like this class. van der Vink is an unbelievable guy who really cares about his students - he even gives students his cell phone number and encourages them to call him should any questions arise. Not to mention, he's one of the funniest professors I've ever had.

This is perhaps the best way to fulfill a QR at Princeton. Van der Vink is entertaining, engaging, and passionate, and will change the way you think of the environment and everything that has to do with it. I highly recommend this for all students, freshmen-seniors.
descrip: Use of scientific data and arguments in formulating environmental policies, international development, poverty reduction, economic growth, conflict, and risk assessment.

title: Theory and Methods of Comparative Literature: Critical and Literary Theory
descrip: A course in the foundational texts of contemporary critical theory. The relationships among literature, philosophy, aesthetics, and linguistics will be investigated as they come to the fore in the intellectual development of the following, among others: modern philology, New Criticism, hermeneutics, structuralism, speech act theory, Marxist and cultural criticism, historical-epistemological aesthetics, rhetorical criticism, and poststructuralism.

title: Italian Civilization Through the Centuries
reviews: It's a good class - an overview of Italian history through primary source texts, only once a week and not too much work. Some of the earlier texts are more difficult due to archaic language, but they get easier. We only read a few short excerpts per week an had weekly 1-page response papers. Not a lot of speaking practice - mostly the professors lecturing and reading/writing. Take it if you're interested in Italian literature and history.
Take it! Fiorenza and Weinapple are the best, and it is such a low-stress, enjoyable class.
Take it! It's a great way to gain a broader perspective of Italian lit and to get exposed to some of its most influential authors.
never pass up an opportunity to take a course with profs. weinapple or frassica.
prereqs: Italian 107 or Instructor's permission..
descrip: This course is designed to give an overview of pivotal moments in Italian culture, such as the relationship between Church and Empire in the Middle Ages, Machiavelli's political theory during the Renaissance, and the rise and fall of Fascism in the 20th century. Through the examination of the most relevant intellectual, historic, and artistic movements and their main geographical venues, students will be able to acquire a comprehensive understanding of the development of Italian history and civilization.

title: Ethics in Context: Uses and Abuses of Deception and Disclosure
reviews: Although I sometimes felt like I wasn't receiving the grades I would like and didn't know how to improve, I enjoyed the discussions an thought it was a worthwhile class as a whole.
Come prepared to participate in every seminar so make sure you do the readings - it makes the 3 hours go by a lot easier!

If you are interested in really taking apart the "common sense" of the world we live in, and if you are ready for a new way of seeing ethics in context, then I highly recommend this class. Be prepared for quite a bit of commitment and in depth reading if you really want to get something out of this class, though.
Stay up on your readings and use the journal entries to tie the readings to the larger class themes

TAKE THIS CLASS! It was one my favorites at Princeton. The material itself is incredibly interesting - you think about terms of "lying," "deception," and "secrecy" in different contexts. Technically fiction is a form of lying, right? Yet people read a fiction novel knowing they are being "deceived" and enjoy it. It brings in medical ethics, so anyone who's pre-med would appreciate it, but also talks about reality tv shows, magic shows, etc. so it's so much fun. Lecture is only once a week, and it's a relaxing yet engaging setting to talk about whatever issues the readings brought up. Definitely do the readings, and have fun with your journals. She prepares you well for your final papers. The assignments are completely fair and so much fun to write. Great class.
make sure to do the readings--it helps a lot with class participation!
use the journal entries to develop your ideas.
prereqs: This seminar approaches ethics anthropologically: as culturally-meaningful social practice. Participants must have at least one prior course in anthropology or instructor's permission. Students with prior training in ethnographic methods (or other relevant experience) are welcome to design field research projects..
descrip: Stage magic delights us with expert illusions; biomedicine and other fields use deception as a research tool (e.g., placeboes); and everyday politeness may obscure painful truths. With deception and disclosure as springboards, this course explores the contextual complexity of personal and professional ethical judgment, with special but not exclusive attention to knowledge circulation. Topics include: social fictions in daily life across cultures; the tangled histories of science and stage magic; ethically controversial cases from popular culture ("reality" TV, journalism), the arts (fictive memoirs), academia (sharing/plagiarizing), and more.

title: Ethics in Financial Market
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Music and Power
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Quantum Field Theory
reviews: A good introduction to field theory, Feynman diagrams and path integrals
Be ready to invest a lot of time in the course.
Don't read Peskin's book, read David Tong's note and Srednicki's book.
Fully involved, lots of reading
Good course overall. Take it
I think it's very important for the furture research.
Make sure you have ample time for the problem sets. They are a doozy.

This course will take a lot of time to do properly. I would be a bit cautious in loading too many courses along with prelims, but you will learn a lot in this course, and delaying it will end up delaying a lot of other courses. If you are thinking of doing theory (and have not already taken QFT), you really ought to take this course.

This is a great introduction to QFT, and is open to suitably prepared undergraduates.  One should of course have a good background in quantum, plus have familiarity with tensor manipulations.  Besides that, any math can be picked up as you go along.  Lectures were good at filling in the conceptual gaps of Peskin and Schroeder, giving a good feel for what QFT really "means".  Strongly recommended.
you have to do a lot of readings.
descrip: Canonical and path integral quantization of quantum fields, Feynman diagrams, gauge symmetry, elementary processes in quantum electro dynamics.

title: Readings in Japanese Academic Style
descrip: The two-semester course is designed for students in Chinese studies, who already possess reading fluency in Chinese. Its goal is to train these students in reading the particular style of Japanese academic writing; at the end of the year, students will be able to independently read modern Japanese scholarship on China. Students take this course after at least one year of modern Japanese (JPN 101/102). The course does not train all four skills of reading, writing, speaking, and listening; instead it is devoted entirely to rapidly develop the necessary reading skills in Japanese academic style. The course is conducted in English.

title: Intermediate Spanish
reviews: Always do the work, and supplement the grammatical training if you really want to get a lot out of it!
Attend to every class, if possible, do the work,  it's all worth it!
Be engaged in the course!
Be prepared to do lots of writing!
Be prepared to participate a lot because that is a large portion of the grade.
Definitely try and go the 105/108 path if you can. The classes are so much better
Do a little bit of Spanish every night, ask the teacher for extra instruction if you need it, and practice!

Do the homework assignments for each class. It may seem slow and unnecessary, but you will definitely see improvement. Don't be afraid to speak up in class because that's the only way you'll get better at conversing in another language.
Do the readings and try to speak in spanish as mucha as you can and you'll be good for the rest of the class without studying much.
Do the readings, and participate a lot to really learn how to speak the language
Do your homework.
Don't be afraid to ask questions, and always practice talking in spanish, becasue thats how you imporve.
Don't doubt the placement exam, and try to engage yourself and others around you during in-class discussion.
Don't slack. She gives you freedom but you shouldn't take advantage of that.

Go to class because the class size is very small. Do well on the grammar exercises, oral exams and written exams. Participate a lot in class. The nightly homework doesn't matter that much as long as you participate and pretend like you did the work.
Go to class everyday so that you don't fail the class.
Go to class, do the readings, participate as much as possible.
I highly recommend this course, especially with Marta as an instructor.
I learned more in this one semester course than I did throughout 4 years of high school. I would definitely recommend it.
I recommend noting all the dates that assignments are due onto a calendar. This will make it easier to keep up with the lectures and assignments that are frequently due.
I would recommend taking the class as long as Marta was the professor
I would suggest this course to a student who enjoys learning languages in general.
If it seems at first that you might be in a bit over your head, relax. I'm glad I didn't drop down a level. This will help you grow.
If you are considering this class, I would recommend that you take it.  It is fun, helpful, and manageable.
It reminds me thoroughly of language classes at other colleges and in high school -- take it to continue to develop Spanish skills.

It seems that no matter how much effort is put in everyone gets an A- or a B . Some of the readings for class are a little long and boring, but with a good teacher the subject material can be fun and interesting.

It'll be a good course! If you are placed into it right from the start, don't worry. It's all right if your Spanish is rusty or if you think this is higher than you should have been placed, like I did. I think the toughest part is getting used to understanding the professor during the first weeks, but once you've adjusted, it gets better.
It's a requirement but it was a manageable course.
It's not super hard, but it's kind of tedious.
Keep up with the homework.
LOVE IT. TAKE IT. LOVE IT.
Listen to Marta!
Luis is great!  Don't spend too much time on grammar exercises.
Make sure you participate and take your time on all the assignments. Grammar mistakes are graded harshly.
Meh...  You have to take it.  Marta's not a bad teacher, and she is definitely a nice person.
Participate in class! Also, don't be afraid to ask the professor questions because she's really helpful.

Participate in discussions and get to know your teachers. Especially Maria because she is always there for you and extremely understanding as a teacher. I loved our in-class discussions and definitely got the most of the language class by participating.

Pay attention, sleep well the night before class, try to avoid early classes, practice outside of class, do your homework before class, and use the dictionary you are provided online. It can be a life saver in many ways.
Plan ahead bc assignments can sometimes come out of nowhere but overall good things!
Profesora Bores is very nice and helpful :)

Profesora Souto is a fantastic professor! She is patient in class and is really encouraging too. I haven't had other professors for Spanish, so I can't speak for them, but for an intermediate Spanish class, you can't go wrong with Profesora Souto.
Professor Martinez was good if you have to take Spanish.
Professor Monserrat Bores is excellent! She is so nice and helpful. The workload in this course is very reasonable.
REQUEST SRA. SOUTO!
Relax, talk in class it's the best way to become fluent. Engage in the material to stay interested.
Study independently and use office hours to ask questions.
Take 105. Take it with Marta. Enjoy it.
Take it and request Monserrat!
Take it! great teacher and a good class!
Take this course with Monserrat Bores Martinez!
The optional work from the textbook is very useful in helping you understand what is being taught in class.
The small class size is an awesome opportunity to get better at speaking Spanish.
You probably have to take it, but it is mostly busy work.

You probably have to take this course, but don't worry it's awesome. Try to get Marta as your instructor because she is the best! I hated language in high school (which is why I did not take AP Spanish and had to take this course in the first place). So, I was very afraid of having to take Spanish at Princeton. How wrong I was! Here the classes are very small (~10 people on average), so you are really exposed to the language since everyone has to participate. This might seem intimidating at first, but don't worry, no one is going to judge you. Also, instead of having to sit through lectures on grammar like in high school, we were expected to learn those on our own. This was pretty easy, since most of the concepts at the beginning were just review. As a result we got to spend class time discussing various readings (like fairy tales or articles on environmentalism) and films (Motorcycles Diaries!). I feel so much more confident in my ability to read/write/speak Spanish now after taking it, and I can almost guarantee you will too.
You should take this course.
You should try to get Maria for this class she is the best teacher for it.
excellent teacher, very approachable and encouraging.
prereqs: A satisfactory score on the Language Placement Test..
descrip: SPA 105 is an intermediate language course that focuses on oral and written communication and the consolidation of the skills acquired at the introductory level. It prepares students to move on to Advanced Spanish 108.

title: Literary and Cultural Theory - Performance and Performativity
descrip: This course investigates "performance" and "performativity" as both curricular objects and modes of inquiry. As the field of performance studies begins to take root in many contemporary locations, the seminar will re-ignite a spirit of radicality to theories of performativity and engage critical and creative works that challenge the field's dominant paradigms of embodiment, liveness, and official theatrical stages. Through close attention to critical experiments in sound, visual arts, and literature, the seminar will explore how performance and performativity enliven scholarly methodologies and aesthetic forms.

title: Contemporary Facade Design, Procurement and Execution
reviews: If it's required for you, take it soon because Bruce is a very good professor and you never know if he'll be back next year.
Not unless you want to work at Front should you take this course with Bruce.
descrip: The course will introduce students to the current state of facade design and engineering as an emerging integrated discipline and for students to develop an understanding of the global facade industry. Discussion will focus on the multi-faceted and changing role of the architect in enabling and leading the necessary collaborative process that is required to collectively achieve common goals in a discipline that is both essential to the artistic expression of building and which is highly technical in every regard.

title: Topics in International Relations - Defense Policy Analysis
descrip: Covers types of analytical frameworks for evaluating military issues. Methodologies range from simple quantitative methods for understanding combat to structured use of military history to defense budget calculations to simple assessments of military tech. Address 7 topics: terrorism, modern air-ground warfare; infantry combat including guerrilla war, peace enforcement, urban warfare, mountain & jungle warfare; missile battle/missile defense; military transport, supply, logistics; effects & implications of weapons of mass destruction; budgetary & econ. issues in defense planning; military tech., future of warfare.

title: Advanced Graphic Design
reviews: David is great to work with, and this is a fun class especially because it is so intimate. Our class had only five students.

If you took VIS 215 and enjoyed it, I definitely recommend taking this course. It's different, but it will (hopefully) develop your designing skills and you'll come out of it with some interesting work.
Take this class if you have a strong interest in graphic design.
prereqs: VIS 215 Graphic Design.
descrip: This studio course builds on the skills and concepts of VIS 215 Graphic Design. Advanced Graphic Design is structured around three studio assignments that connect graphic design to other bodies of scientific knowledge, aesthetic experience, and scholarship. Studio work is supplemented by critiques, readings and lectures. Motivated students will refine their approaches to information design and visual problem solving, as well as develop the critical acumen for decoding and producing graphic design in a variety of traditional and electronic media.

title: Horace
prereqs: LAT 203 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: Close reading of selected Satires of Horace, considering his poetic program and techniques, together with the contemporary Augustan context.

title: Fundamentals of Environmental Studies: Population, Land Use, Biodiversity, and Energy
reviews: Although this is an easy course, it takes up a lot of time -- especially if you are doing the lab.  Only take this if you are pursuing the certificate in ENV.
Do not take this course unless you need it for the ENV certificate. It is dry, uninteresting, and contains an unreasonable amount of busy work. Taking this course is my biggest regret of Princeton.

Don't take it. If you're an ENV certificate student, beg Angela or Lars to let you take another one as a substitute for your core class. It's not worth it. It will make you hate your certificate program, and it is not at all representative of the incredible array of courses that the certificate has to offer. I know dozens of people who feel the same, and hope that they took the time to answer this survey like I did.

Don't take this class if you just want to fulfill dis req. 
201B is NOT a good STL. Lab reports were very time consuming. 
201A is also NOT a good STN. Too much written work.
Don't take this class.
For an STL, this course is easy but also gives a lot of work. You end up doing two courses in one: everything for ENV201A and then all the things for the lab.
For the love of whatever it is you believe in, do not take this class.

Frankly, I would recommend a student not take this course. There are many superior STL courses for people not in the sciences. If you're pursuing the environmental certificate, I'd take another ENV class first to avoid turning yourself off from the certificate.
I do recommend this course but be prepared to put in a lot of time, even if considering PDFing!
I would recommend attending lectures and precepts as those are the most valuable ways to gain information relevant to the midterm and the final.
I would tell them that it is stimulating and educational but they should be aware of what a huge workload it turned out to be, a lot of reading and writing on top of exams.

If you are taking this with a lab it will be way more work than you think. There were field trips, lab assignments, a final project, and precept assignments that all seemed to happen at the same time. The work in labs seemed pointless at times with lots of time spent copying and pasting numbers in excel. If you are looking for an stl for distribution requirements, look elsewhere. That being said, lecture was interesting and environmental science and issues are only going to become more relevant and pressing in the future.
If you're interested in environmental issues but not terribly informed about them, this is a good survey course.
If you're looking for a solid basic understanding of the wide range of environmental challenges facing modern society, take this.

Somewhat difficult as a lab WITH precept, would've been a joke if just precept. Regardless, the precept is annoying in that it's 0 work up until the final project at the end, which they don't really prepare you for at all. So yeah. Aside from that, it's a good course (interesting topics, good lectures, interesting lab, readings are eh, but whatever).
Take it without the lab. Attend lecture, it's a good lecture

The course is way more work than it's worth, especially if you're PDFing. It's 6 hours a week--2 lectures, a precept, and a three-hour lab. Precepts and labs are a waste of time, and often involve busy work that I'd rather do on my own time than have to carve a block out of my schedule to sit in a room with other people also doing the same busy work. 

If you do take it...beware of how annoying Wilcove's voice is. Seems trivial, but it's such a struggle...
The lectures are pretty nice, but the disorganization of the course (mostly evident in the precept assignments and especially the lab) made the course not very enjoyable as a whole.
The material is interesting, but be prepared for a lot of work. There are precepts, and papers for the precepts, labs, and reports for the labs, and attendance at lectures is heavily encouraged.
This class wasn't done well this semester.  But they will be changing it in the future so don't worry too much.

This is NOT an "easy" STL -- the material itself is simple enough, but you may be loaded down with a lot of hidden work that isn't listed in the syllabus. Take this class if you are genuinely interested in environmental studies, or it won't be worth it.

You have precept AND lab. this is a horrible lab because so much of your grade is showing up and doing time intensive things.  i just wanted to take 2 tests and call it a day.  on the other hand, the lab field trips were cool
you will probably be disappointed
prereqs: P/D/Fail option is available, but precludes qualifying for the Certificate of Proficiency in Environmental Studies..
descrip: An expanding human population and the desire of all people for a more prosperous life have placed tremendous demands on the environment. We will explore how human activities have affected land use, agriculture, fisheries, biodiversity, and the use of energy. Our focus is both global and local, highlighting not only fundamental changes in the biosphere, but also the ways in which individual decisions lead to major environmental changes. We explore the fundamental principles underlying contemporary environmental issues, and we use case studies to illustrate the scientific, political, economic, and social dimensions of environmental problems.

title: Quantitative Analysis for Public Policy
descrip: The course is designed for students preparing to incorporate statistical analysis in their policy research. In the context of case studies, it will cover the principal methods of data analysis and applied statistics in social science and policy research, including multiple regression, analysis of variance and nonparametric methods. Students are expected to have some knowledge of basic probability and statistical concepts.

title: Information Technology and Public Policy
reviews: A very interesting and engaging course.
Definitely take it! The professors are great, and the topic is relevant, topical, and important in the present.

Definitely take this class.  The format needs to be worked a little bit because there is more content than could ever fit into 2-3 classes but this was my favorite class of the semester.  No matter what your background there will be people in the class who compliment you and make the discussions really interesting.
Go to every seminar. They are really helpful and are really what the class is all about.
Good course, helps if you are proficient in either internet/computer technology or public policy but don't need to be an expert in either/both to get a lot out of the class
Great if you want to learn about complications of IT policies
If you're at all curious about the subject of the course, then I would recommend taking this class.
It's a great choice for a computer science departmental and it is fun. However, be aware that there is a lot of reading and try to keep up as much as you can.
Only take it if you are willing to really put some time into it. There are a lot of readings. It is definitely worth your time if you have any time to spare.
Take it if you are interested in technology policy. This course offers a very comprehensive look into relevant issues in the field.
Take it if you're genuinely interested in the subject matter. Big reading load (but you'll learn how to manage it). Pretty cool discussions with relevant players in the field.

Take it if you're interested in the topic! It's a good mix of technical and policy-based, and does interdisciplinary very well. Be sure you can handle the reading load, though - and realize that its awkward size halfway between seminar and lecture may lead to an uncertain amount of attention, since it's a bit too big for personal attention from the professors, but too small to have precepts.
Take this, but beware of the amount of reading!

The professors are both great lecturers, thoughtful questioners, and allow for a lot of discussion in class (they're not there to spout, but to think). Do be aware, though, that the class seems to focus more on sociology than public policy during the second semester. It's not a bad thing, but not something I had expected.

Regardless, though, you'll learn a lot. A lot of people know about computer science. A lot of people know about public policy. Very few know about both. This class changed my views on a lot of tech policy issues around the world.
This class would be better in a seminar format, but the material is still fascinating and the lectures are fun.

This course will likely change year to year based on enrollment and feedback.
This is a fascinating and deep tech policy class taught by two experts with very differing academic foci.
However, this is not an easy 4th or 5th class.  There is a LOT of reading.  This is a great class for the ITS certificate, but it is as much work as a departmental.  The readings and ideas are generally pretty fascinating, so it is well worth it, but be aware of the workload.
This is a great class on IT policy, but there are copious amounts of reading. Also, the take-home final was a 15-20 page paper to be written in 48 hours, which seemed quite demanding though doable.
Would definitely recommend taking it. You get exposed to a wide range of technical and policy issues and it is a unique course. However, readings take a fair bit of time.
interesting, but the larger class setting sort of prevents the kinds of interesting discussions that could have happened. This kind of class definitely needs a precept.
very interesting concepts in this course. some of the weeks were a little slower than others and you have to be willing to read a ton and to do blackboard posts (which I hate with a flaming passion)
prereqs: Students should have some background in either technology (computer science, engineering) or the social sciences (especially economics, politcs, and sociology..
descrip: New technologies have changed the way we communicate with each other and learn about our world. They have also raised public policy dilemmas in every area they touch: communications, regulation, privacy, national security, intellectual property and many others. This course is predicated on the belief that we can only productively address the social and policy dimensions of the Internet if we understand the technology behind the Internet; the social-science concepts and research that illuminate the likely effects of policy options; and tradeoffs among fundamental values that different policy options imply.

title: Science in the Modern World
prereqs: P/D/F option not available to History concentrators..
descrip: This course covers the history of science and its interactions with broader society and culture from the death of Isaac Newton (1727) to the end of the Cold War. We trace developments in various sciences, with a heavy emphasis on the physical and life sciences, to explore the ways in which science and public life have become increasingly separated. Emphasis on the spaces and technologies of science, genres of scientific communication, the place of science in the emerging nation-state, and contrasting themes of backwardness and modernity in several national contexts.

title: Introduction to the Mechanics and Dynamics of Soft Living Matter
reviews: Although this is a biophysics class, you need very little bio background and a lot of physics background. Be prepared to need to know things that you should have learned but didn't in freshman physics.
Do it!

I think you should take it if you have an interest in bioengineering and are not sure about what topics/ research areas you might be interested in. For me taking this class helped me realize that biophysics and soft matter were not really a research field I would be interested in pursuing.
If you're interested in equations describing biology, take it!
It's an okay class, I guess. Nothing more.
descrip: This course introduces the concepts of soft condensed matter and their use in understanding the mechanical properties, dynamic behavior, and self-assembly of living biological materials. We will take an engineering approach that emphasizes the application of fundamental physical concepts to a diverse set of problems taken from the literature, including mechanical properties of biopolymers and the cytoskeleton, directed and random molecular motion within cells, aggregation and collective movement of cells, and phase transitions and critical behavior in the self-assembly of lipid membranes and intracellular structures.

title: The Literature of Fact - Writing about the World
reviews: How often do you get the chance to work with award winning journalists on pieces over 800 words long? Take the course.
Journalism courses at Princeton are fantastic. You cannot graduate without taking one of them.
Take it but don't expect it to be easy
Take this course!
Take this course.
You'll learn important skills for writing, interviewing, and reporting, but you will be bullied, mocked, and condescended to for an entire semester by a brilliant writer but terrible teacher.
pick your jrn classes based on the professor. that's what I did and it worked out well
take it, this woman is a total genius who actually cares about her students.
prereqs: Applications at http://humanities.princeton.edu..
descrip: This seminar is designed to improve participants' reading, writing and reporting skills. How can we can train ourselves to see better and learn more about our surroundings? How do our origins and upbringing influence what we see? How do we choose subject matter? We will experiment writing about subjects from different points of view and then consider the implications of these shifts.

title: Computer Architecture and Organization
reviews: Any CS or ELE student who doesn't take this class is a fool.
Any student interested in hardware should take this course.
Good professor, interesting subject. Not too much work. The book is only okay (although it is the standard).

I loved this class, and would absolutely recommend it to anyone.  I didn't find it to be too much work, and though I thought I wouldn't have much interest in the material covered, found that couldn't have been further from the truth.
If you're looking for an interesting departmental and don't mind discussions, then I strongly recommend taking the course
Take it! The material is very interesting. The classes are discussion-based and extremely engaging, and you don't have to do very much work outside of class.
Take it! You'll learn a lot and Prof Clark is awesome, and it's a regular amount of light work, so you never feel in over your head.
Take the course if you want to know about computer architecture and its real world applications. It's hard work, but it is very rewarding in the end.
The final exam is really harder than the materials that you have in your class

This course is extremely interesting. I would highly recommend it to anyone who is interested in the intersection of hardware and software. The course also goes hand in hand with Operating Systems - each helps to clarify concepts in the other
prereqs: COS 217 and COS 306/ELE 206.
descrip: An introduction to computer architecture and organization. Instruction set design; basic processor implementation techniques; performance measurement; caches and virtual memory; pipelined processor design; design trade-offs among cost, performance, and complexity.

title: Independent Research Project
descrip: Independent research or investigation resulting in a substantial formal report in the student's area of interest under the supervision of a faculty member.

title: Special Topics in Chinese History - Classical Historiography
descrip: Selected problems on the historiography of the early, medieval, or late empires, with a focus on literati thought, religion, or literature in the historical and comparative context. A working knowledge of classical Chinese or kanbun is strongly recommended.

title: Francophone Literature and Culture Outside of France - Mediterranean Wonders and Wanderings
descrip: Through a chorus of major works in French from around the Mediterranean, will emerge questions of identity and estrangement, hybridity and hospitality, crossings and metamorphoses. The polyphony of fiction, the dialogues between the main texts, along with other readings from scholars and poets (from Homer to Derrida), will suggest how France and the Mediterranean have relentlessly influenced each other's images. Further, these readings will guide us toward another definition of the Mediterranean, stranger than the Mare Nostrum, a space of wonders, perpetually transformed.

title: Topics in Social Anthropology - States in Crisis
descrip: This seminar will explore states in various kinds of crisis: their "weakness" and "failure," their borders and margins, their porosity and dysfunction, their proxies and pawning, their disasters and debts, their violence, their corruption - as well as opposition and threats to state power: dissidence, social movements, paramilitary organizations, communal and corporate sovereignty. Readings will tack between theories of what the state is and is not, and recent ethnographies that propose critiques, re-imaginations, and oblique visions of the state - opening new avenues to examine agency, justice, economy, and social ties.

title: Science Journalism
reviews: A great course.
Absolutely enjoyed this course. Excellent readings, fun assignments, great professor. Take it!

Definitely worth taking if you're interesting in journalism. Science knowledge is not necessary, as it's more about how to write  a story, particularly when people aren't all that familiar with the topic.
Even if you've never had any experience with journalism before, you should consider this course.

Fun course for science concentrators and journalists, and a must-take for aspiring science journalists of course. Mike is a fun teacher to have - he has a lot of interesting experiences to share and he is a really nice guy.
Great if you enjoy science journalism and want to really dig into what makes it work

I would definitely recommend this course. It's not too challenging, but it's very rewarding. Professor Lemonick is a wonderful teacher and an even more wonderful individual, and his willingness to be a resource even beyond the course is much appreciated.
I would recommend taking it if you are interested in science journalism. Professor Lemonick is very experienced and knows what he is talking about, and he is very insightful in critiquing your work.
If the topic interests you then go ahead and take it.  Be aware that how useful or constructive the class discussions are will depend on the group of students.
Lemonick is a great professor, and this is a fun and interesting course if you have any interest writing about science.
Take it!! This is an amazing and fun environment to combine two different areas of important knowledge
Take this! It's the most useful course I've taken at Princeton.

This course is a relaxed introduction to science journalism, but it's important to remember that the only way to really improve the skills addressed in this class is to practice them, so you have to expect to write frequently and often - the amount that you get out of the class is directly proportional to the amount that you put into the assignments.
This is a great course to take if you have any interest in the subject matter.  Michael Lemonick is a great resource and a great teacher to learn from!!

This is a wonderful, really interesting class, packed with fun readings. Mike is a great guy, not too demanding, and brings snacks to class! He's a great resource for advice about many areas of journalism, and always very kind about getting together to talk. You can tell he really cares about being a good teacher. I learned a lot about science writing and had a great time doing it.
prereqs: Must have fulfilled writing requirement.
descrip: Albert Einstein has been quoted as saying "You do not really understand something unless you can explain it to your grandmother." This workshop-style course will show students (science majors and non-majors alike) how to explain science and technology to non-technical audiences in a clear and compelling way. Through discussion, analysis of published writing, visits with professional journalists, and extensive and closely critiqued writing exercises, participants will learn how to turn scientific research -- their own, or that of others -- into stories that will hold the attention of readers who didn't realize they were interested in science.

title: The Ordinary
reviews: Definitely worth considering for both undergrads and graduate students.  It covers a great base of written work produced by prominent architects working within modern and contemporary times.

I would definitly recommend this course and my advice would be for them to read some of the reading material before the semester to decrease the amount of work during each week whick can sometimes be very busy.
It's a course that urge you to establish your own thinking and critiques.
They might suggest to have more structure during the class.
Very Good, excellent discussion.
take it
descrip: This course examines the notion of the "ordinary," and the ways in which it has been exploited as a site of inquiry in the architectural debate, particularly from the mid-1950s to the present. Structured upon a series of projects dealing with the scrutiny of so-called existing conditions--from Alison and Peter Smithson to Aldo van Eyck, Reyner Banham to Robert Venturi and Denise Scott Brown, Rem Koolhaas to Atelier Bow-Wow--we will interrogate the ways in which architecture has dealt with emergent and seemingly irreducible urban phenomena, as well as has by the same token constructed a peculiar practice of architectural theory.

title: Sociology of Culture (Half-Term)
descrip: This mini-seminar surveys the field, exposing you to major research traditions, themes, and specific areas of study. The course will evolve around several debates in the sociological study of culture: relative autonomy vs. dependence, structure vs. agency, instrumentalism vs. expressionism, part vs. whole, synchronic vs. diachronic analysis. These debates will be explored against the theoretical and methodological developments of the field.

title: Introduction to Anthropology
reviews: A decent survey course to take, great lecturer, minimal coursework but sometimes lots of reading
Although this course is organized well and provides a good background for concentrators, it might not be the best class for someone trying to test out an anthropology class.
Always do the reading and attend the lectures - you won't regret it.

Anthropology is a very interesting subject, and this class may give you an enlightening new perspective on some aspects of our culture. It doesn't require a big work commitment, so it's a good way to explore different perspectives about the world at little risk.
Do the readings before the paper is due.
Don't just read the assigned readings; try to draw larger generalizations and concepts from them, and align them with the concepts introduced in lecture.

Don't take this course unless you have previously taken another Anthropology course. The course isn't demanding, but the subject material is very general and having deeper knowledge would allow you to draw more conclusions about the reading through yourself.
Easily one of the most interesting classes I have taken at Princeton
Go to lecture and take good notes.
Great class. Not too difficult, so it is a great one to take to learn more about a subject and not stress out about your grade.

Honestly, only take this course if you want to major in Anthropology.  If you're just trying to get a taste of Anthro, take a more specific class that delves directly into something that interests you.
I would advise doing the readings definitely, as they are interesting and useful!
I would recommend that they keep of with the readings...it helps not only for precept discussion, but also for knowing which documents to draw inspiration from during the exams!
I would take this if you like the natural and social sciences

If you are interested in anthropology as a major, definitely talk to anthropology majors about their experience with the discipline instead of just relying on this class. Keep in mind that anthropology isn't really something you study, but something you use to study other things.
It's interesting, and if you're at all interested in anthropology, I would take it.
It's not a lot of work and really interesting, but the lectures are hard to get up for.
It's not bad, but most anthro courses are way better.
Make sure you're willing to do a ton of reading every two days.  I might suggest you take a more specialized anthropology course first to see if you like the discipline.
Only take this if you are interested in anthropology.
Pay attention/go to lecture!
Probably should not take this class if you are actually interested in anthropology.  Probably the least work I've put into a class at princeton.

Professor Rosen is an amazing lecturer - not too fast, easy to understand, always has something interesting to say. He doesn't usually use any slides, and those that he does use are for images only. Go to class, take notes, and enjoy!
Professor Rosen's lectures are excellent, and the material is interesting. However, the midterm exam was the first graded assignment, and that made things a bit difficult.
Put the time in, and you will get a lot out of this course!
Take it
Take it with Prof. Rosen!
Take the course.

Take this class! Make sure to do the readings so that the midterm and final are easy to right. But it's all very interesting if you are into learning about the development of the human society. Every minute of it was worth it, and the amount of work was quite doable.

The class is interesting, but not fascinating. Rosen is an engaging lecturer. Your notes from lecture will look like gibberish after the fact, but don't stress about that as long as you were paying attention. He cares about the big ideas and their application, not about inconsequential details.
The material is very interesting but the reading takes a really long time if you want to do all of it well. There were some nights when I read anthropology for 4 hours
There are a lot of topics covered and some are more interesting than others.  Professor Rosen is great in lecture.
There is a decent amount of reading, but it is all really interesting.

This course is ok, but if you are looking to try out anthropology I would suggest taking a smaller more focused class if possible. This class gives a good introduction and basis for anthropological study, but wasn't always particularly interesting. Professor Rosen is, however, fabulous and a great lecturer!
This was a very interesting course for someone who really wanted to take an intro ANT class.
Though a good course, I think that taking another anthropology course will help you gain an understanding of whether you want to pursue this discipline as a major or not.
Will definitely take another ANT course in the future and will consider it as a major. Professor Rosen did a great job.
YA!
definitely take this course, even if youre not an ANT major.
do the shorter readings
make an effort to go to every lecture - you learn a lot from the professor.
take it!
take this class
descrip: An introduction to the comparative study of human societies. The focus will be on the ways in which different communities organize their beliefs and relationships. Issues will include the role of culture in the development of our species, the relation of religion to economics, the cultural embeddedness of sexuality, and the ways in which native peoples are represented in Western thought.

title: The Making of the Modern Middle East
descrip: An introduction to the political, social, intellectual, and cultural history of the Middle East from the late eighteenth century to the present, with particular focus on the Arab world, Iran, Israel, and Turkey. Emphasis is on reading and interpreting primary sources in English translation, including literature, film and other visual culture.

title: International Trade I
descrip: The determinants of foreign trade: (1) inter-country differences of factor endowments and technologies and (2) scale economics and imperfect competition are studied. Dynamic comparative advantage; innovation and growth; factor movements and multinational corporations; gains from trade; tariffs and quantitative restrictions on trade and their role in dealing with market failures and oligopolies; the political economy of trade policy; international negotiations on trade policy; and economic integration are studied as well.

title: Selected Architects of the 20th Century: Louis I. Kahn: The Tectonics of Ideology
descrip: A review of the development of Kahn's conceptual framework, works, pedagogical standing, and contemporary critical reviews against the parallel development of the ideology and compositional modes of architecture and urbanism from before World War II to the early seventies. Course also reviews the characteristic line of progress in Kahn's office work discipline, and examines the philosophical position that set him apart from the dominant development of the 'late' moderns.

title: Ancient Judaism and the Dead Sea Scrolls
descrip: This course studies the history of Judaism in ancient Palestine from the emergence of the Torah as an authoritative document under Persian rule in the middle of the fifth century BCE through the destruction of the Second Temple in 70 CE, with an emphasis on the critical reading of primary sources. Much of the second half of the course is devoted to the Dead Sea Scrolls and their implications for our understanding of ancient Judaism.

title: Studies in Greco-Roman Religions - Canon Formation and the Sociology of Reading in Late Antiquity
descrip: This course examines the notion of sacred scriptures and the formation of authoritative bodies of scripture from a socio-historical and material culture perspective. The seminar will engage broader questions regarding the social life of religious texts, such as: How and where were these texts produced and re-produced, and by whom? What do ancient manuscripts reveal about reading practices? In what social settings were texts read and studied? What roles do orality and literacy play? How do these canons relate to larger issues of identity formation and community boundaries?

title: Solid-State Devices
reviews: Basically a tougher version of 208, minus the lab. A very good class if you want to learn about devices.
If you liked ELE 208, this is more of the same but it more detail. You can definitely handle the workload and the seminar is pretty fun!

Overall, this is a good course.  The material is useful and interesting and Professor Kahn is a good lecturer.  However the problem sets too often involved scrounging for constants on the web and the material overlapped too much with ELE 208.
The course is hard. The material however is vey interesting and much better presented than 208. Pay attention in class, Professor Kahn is a very good lecturer.
prereqs: ELE 203 and 208.
descrip: The physics and technology of solid state devices. Review of electronic structure of semiconductors, energy bands, doping. Detailed analysis of p-n junctions, bipolar transistors and field effect transistors. Survey of a wide range of devices, including photodetectors, solar cells, light-emitting diodes and semiconductor lasers, tunnelling devices and single-electron transistors, power transistors, photoconductors, electro-optic devices, piezoelectric and micro-electromechancial devices, sensors for chemicals, and devices for magnetic and optical recording.

title: Early Christian Biblical Interpretation
prereqs: No prerequisites, or restrictions. Primary sources will be read in English translation..
descrip: In this seminar, we shall study the ways in which the Christian Bible, comprising the Old and the New Testament, was interpreted in the early Church. After a broad survey of the history of Biblical interpretation to the end of the sixth century, we shall focus on the exegesis of specific Biblical themes (The Creation Narrative; the Story of Cain and Abel; the Sacrifice of Isaac; themes from the Book of Daniel; the Adoration of the Magi; Christ's Entry into Jerusalem; Lazarus and the Rich Man). Primary sources will be read in English translation.

title: Global Environmental Issues
reviews: Don't even try to do all of the readings; just read the summaries / skim. Try to say everything you can on the subject for the homeworks because you never know what points are going to be taken off for.
Great for science majors to get a policy perspective on important scientific issues. Mauzerall is very helpful and approachable! Take the course!

I would tell them to take it, but be careful because there is no way they will be able to do all the readings, and to make sure to allow enough time to do the problem sets because sometimes they take a lot longer than one would expect.
Take it if you are interested in the subject. Its not too much work, and you learn a lot about environmental issues and the policy that goes with them.
Take this class - though be expected for a greater workload than most other seminars, with long papers, weekly problem sets, and blackboard posts.
Talk, listen, get engaged, and always keep the big picture in mind.

The professor may rely heavily on slides, but the class is generally great to take if you are looking for a refresher of all things environment. Also, the professor is the nicest woman in the world. She believes you can succeed, so don't let her down.

This class offers a pretty vague understanding of important and interesting environmental issues.
