Use the assigned readings (which aren't always relevant to class discussions) as a jumping-off point for delving deeper into the scientific literature in the topics you are most interested in. Most of the really engaging thinking and learning ultimately happens in the midterm and final papers.
prereqs: AP Chemistry, CHM 201, or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course examines a set of global environmental issues including population growth, ozone layer depletion, climate change, air pollution, the environmental consequences of energy supply and demand decisions and sustainable development. It provides an overview of the scientific basis for these problems and examines past, present and possible future policy responses. Individual projects, presentations, and problem sets are included.

title: Writing About Art (Rilke, Freud, Benjamin)
reviews: Definitely, definitely, definitely take this class.  The subject matter is so interesting, and Professor Doherty deals with it so well.  The readings were beautiful.  The reading responses were helpful, and Professor Doherty always gave constructive feedback. Seminars were engaging, and our class would often have "real" discussions about the material, as opposed to the fake sort of discussion that curses many a classroom of uninterested students.  Take it!
If you are interested in aesthetics and modernity, TAKE THIS COURSE.
If you're interested in the material, great course!
Take it!
Take it.
Take this course if you're willing to commit to it. It's only worth it if you care!
This course is aimed at a lot of details and subtleties in writing, so if you're interested in that go for it.
descrip: Seminar addresses significance of works of art, and of practices of writing about visual art, in the work of three great writers of German in the early 20th-century: poet Rainer Maria Rilke; founder of psychoanalysis, Sigmund Freud; and philosopher and critic Walter Benjamin. Emphasis on close reading and critical analysis. Readings drawn from variety of fields and genres, including: lyric poetry, experimental prose, psychoanalytic theory, cultural analysis, aesthetic theory, criticism. Topics include: situation of work of art in modernity; art and the unconscious; the work of art and the historical transmission of culture in modern Europe.

title: Sex, Gender and Sexuality from the Enlightenment to Today
descrip: At the eve of the French Revolution, debates concerning sex and gender, identity and equality erupt and announce the stakes of the democracy to come. This course will ask how representations of femininity and masculinity are established in literature, politics and aesthetic discourses from the Enlightenment to today. Inversely, what are the strategies of resistance and transgression through which individuals can, in turn, define themselves? Topics will include writing the self, pleasure, gender as heuristic tool, and the intersection of sex, race and class, in texts ranging from travel narratives to memoirs, as well as in contemporary film.

title: Seminar in Medieval History - Thirteenth-Century France
descrip: Reading and research seminar on thirteenth-century France.

title: Program and Policy Evaluation
prereqs: WWS 507B/507C or instructor's permission.
descrip: This course introduces students to evaluation. It explores ways: to develop and implement research-based program improvement strategies and program accountability systems; to judge the effects of policies and programs; and to assess the benefits and costs of policy or program changes. Students study a wide range of evaluation tools; read and discuss both domestic and international evaluation examples and apply this knowledge by designing several different types of evaluations on programs of their choosing.

title: Mathematics for Economists
reviews: Don't worry about it.  It's just something you have to do.
Go to the lectures and at least attempt the problem sets.
Good course to review the Math topics that show up repeatedly in first year classes.
Read the lectures very well, do the problem sets and everything will go fine.
You don't get very much out of the course.
descrip: An exposition of those parts of mathematics necessary to equip the graduate student in economics with modern techniques of analysis and empirical investigation. Service course.

title: Ethical and Scientific Issues in Environmental Policy
reviews: Definitely take this course! Make sure to do all the readings because they make the class more interesting and give you more to talk about in class.
I would recommend this course to everyone!
If it's ever offered again, I recommend taking the course. It was very interesting, and not a terrible amount of work.
If you want to take a course with two great professors, this is definitely what you should sign up for.
If you're interested in thinking about the best way to help the environment, this is a good course!
It's a seminar, so make sure you do all the readings. Pay attention, because it's a very good class.
Maybe, if you are interested in ENV, and would prefer it for an EM.

Overall, this was a really great course.  I enjoyed all of the readings and all of the class discussions.  Time flew by in seminar.  If you choose to take the course, don't be afraid to ask the professors questions, they are very approachable.  Review practical ethics on your own or you may have some difficulty on the final paper.  Be sure to participate in class.
Straightforward course, will be better with the suggestions we made in class. Professors are great.
TAKE IT OR PREISH. BEST CLASS EVER TAUGHT.
Take it! Especially if you're interested in environmental ethics and policy. Singer and Wilcove are great professors.
Take it!!!!
Take it.

This course was fantastic overall. Professor Singer could sometimes be frustrating, as he would often respond to students' claims and arguments with something akin to "hmm, yes, that's an argument you could make" and not much more feedback than that. Both he and Professor Wilcove were, however, fantastic, and I would strongly recommend this course to people if they want to become interested in one of the most pressing issues of our time.
prereqs: Open to juniors and seniors only, by application. To apply, submit a one-page statement indicating why you want to take the class and what you believe you could contribute to it by April 16, 2012. Your statement should be a Word attachment to an email sent to either Professor Wilcove (dwilcove@princeton.edu) or Professor Singer (psinger@princeton.edu)..
descrip: This course will discuss policy issues relating to the environment, using several case studies to provide a deeper understanding of the science and values involved.

title: Strategy and Information
prereqs: MAT 200 or MAT 201 or EQV..
descrip: Explores basic themes in modern game theory and information economics. Non cooperative solution concepts for games will be developed and applied to the study of repeated games and dynamic interaction in oligopolistic industries, reputation formation, auctions, and bargaining.

title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Geosciences
reviews: I thought the class was reasonably interesting and enjoyable.  I generally tried to do the readings in advance, although I'm not sure that's absolutely critical.
It's a good refresher on some practical issues relating to a career in science. Providing food was a big plus.

While this course is a requirement for geoscience and AOS graduate students, I ask that those who are taking the course come prepared to act as mature Princeton graduate students, not immature teenagers.
You have to take it, or else. So take it.
more engaged in discussions
none
descrip: Course educates Geosciences and AOS students in the responsible conduct of research using case studies appropriate to these disciplines. This discussion-based course focuses on issues related to the use of scientific data, publication practices and responsible authorship, peer review, research misconduct, conflicts of interest, the role of mentors & mentees, issues encountered in collaborative research and the role of scientists in society. Successful completion is based on attendance, reading, and active participation in class discussions. Course satisfies University requirement for RCR training.

title: Language of Love, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Political Philosophy - Political Ontology
descrip: This seminar will cover some basic concepts deployed in political thought and practice, looking at the various ways in which they may be institutionally implemented. The concepts discussed will include those of the state, the constitution and the people as well as some more regular social concepts like that of agency, corporation, freedom and power.

title: Making American Theater: The History and Challenges of Creating Theater on Broadway and in New York
descrip: The most vital theater is in direct conversation with the world in which it's created and performed. This class explores the American theater over the course of the last 100 years, surveying how some of its most vital plays, artists and theaters were engaged in ambitious attempts to reclaim or reinvent the American stage, while tackling some of the biggest issues in the American Century. Additionally, the class will explore challenges faced by producers and artists currently working on Broadway and in New York. The class aims to inspire those who might wish to make theater or performance in any context.

title: Directed Research
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out research and presents the results. Directed research is normally taken during the first year of study. The total grading of the course will be 25% poster presentation and 75% submitted work.

title: Responsible Conduct in Research: A Course on Ethics in Engineering (Half-term)
prereqs: This course is required for graduate students in engineering who participate in federally funded research; the course is highly recommended and/or required for undergraduate students as well as post-doctoral researchers in engineering who participate in federally funded research. There are no prerequisites for attending the course..
descrip: This course educates the graduate student of engineering in the responsible conduct of research. The lectures provide theoretical background information as well as case studies about ethics in day-to-day research situations, in publishing and peer-review, in student-advisor relationships, in collaborative research, as well as in the big picture and considerations of long-term impact. The students are provided with resources to consult in ethical questions. In small-group discussions in research field-specific precepts, the theoretical concepts are made relevant to the individual students situations.

title: Introduction to Finite-element Methods
reviews: Begin your work sooner rather then later.
Don't unless you have to or you know for sure that you are going to need it later.
Find a suitable textbook to go along with the class
For civil engineer it seems quite obvious to take this class.
GO TO PRECEPT
Make sure you attend both lectures and precepts.
Only take it if it is a requirement- quite useless, did not get anything out of it.

You can learn a lot (and there really isn't another course where you can learn this at Princeton as far as I know), but you really need to put in the time to read the notes and the codes outside of class.
descrip: Basic concepts of matrix structural analysis. Direct stiffness method. Axial force member. Beam bending member. Formation of element stiffness matrix. Assembling of global stiffness matrix. Introduction of boundary conditions. Solution of linear algebraic equations. Special analysis procedures. The finite-element method. Introduction. Basic formulation. Plane stress and plane strain problems. Plate bending problems. The use of structural analysis and finite-element computer codes is emphasized throughout the course.

title: Sociology of Migration, Development and Ethnicity
descrip: This course will be taught as a hands-on practicum on research on immigration and development, especially the former. It will supplement the Center for Migration and Development's (CMD) symposium talk during the 2012-13 academic year, which meets approximately every other week from 12-1:30 on Thursdays. We will discuss the ongoing work of CMD speakers, students, post-docs and other members of the university community that work on migration or development. We expect that participants will attend the CMD symposium talks, read the paper associated with each week's discussion and be active participants in the discussion.

title: Macroeconomics/International Finance Workshop
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Advanced Design Studio
reviews: Be prepared to do a lot of work and to push yourself - but the results are worth it.
Be very diligent and always have work to show during desk crits.
Work a little (or a lot) every day on your project.
take it
prereqs: This course is open to senior Architecture concentrators ONLY..
descrip: The Advanced Design Studio examines architecture as cultural production, taking into account its capacity to structure both physical environments and social organizations. A specific problem or topic area will be set by each studio critic, and may include a broad range of building types, urban districts or regional landscapes, questions of sustainability, building materials or building performance. Studio work will include research and data gathering, analysis and program definition. Students are expected to master a full range of design media, including drawing, model-making and computer-aided design.

title: Work
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Statistical Theory and Methods
reviews: Buy course books from the start and study from these books.
Don't take it!
I recommend this course to every student who is interested in mathematical statistics. You can learn a lot of things from this lecture!
I would absolutely recommend it if you are looking for the mathematical foundations of statistics. If you are not interested in mathematical details, then this is not a good course for you.
It is a useful course. But one needs to have a good statistical background in order to fully understand it.
Take if interested in statistics.
They should get a good book in Statistics because the lecture notes and notes are too abstract without examples and quite confusing. I would personally recommend Jun Shao's Mathematical Statistics
dont take this class
descrip: A graduate-level introduction to statistical theory and methods and some of the most important and commonly-used principles of statistical inference. Covers the statistical theory and methods for point estimation, confidence intervals, and hypothesis testing, and the applications of the fundamental theory to generalized linear models.

title: Neuroscience: from molecules to systems to behavior
reviews: Like every lab this course takes a lot of your time, but you learn a lot, and it is well worth the time.
descrip: This lab course complements NEU 501A and introduces students to the variety of techniques and concepts used in modern neuroscience, from the point of view of experimental and computational/quantitative approaches. Topics will include synaptic transmission, fluorescent and viral tracers, patch clamp recording in brain slices, optogenetic methods to control neural activity, and computational modeling approaches. In-lab lectures give students the background necessary to understand the scientific content of the labs, but the emphasis is on the labs themselves. Second half of a double-credit core course required of all NEU Ph.D. students.

title: Research Ethics & Scientific Integrity (Half-Term)
descrip: This course is concerned with the professional obligations of social science researchers. Topics covered include teaching and mentoring relationships, human subjects protections, professional codes of ethics, data management, peer review, collaboration, scientific misconduct (fraud, fabrication and plagiarism), conflicts of interest, and scientific agenda-setting. The course is intended for graduate students in Sociology and the Office of Population Research.

title: Topics in Development - New Media & Social Movements: New Tools for an Old Game
descrip: Movements ranging from the Arab uprisings to ?Occupy? protestors in the US have been using new media technologies to coordinate, organize, intervene in the public sphere as well as to document, share, and shape their own narratives. The objective of this course will be to enhance our conceptual and empirical understanding of the interaction between this emergent new media ecology and social and political change. We will explore various conceptual approaches to studying social movements and social change, and then consider specific cases to evaluate these conceptual methods in light of empirical findings.

title: Earth Materials
reviews: Blair is a great professor and you will learn more about geology on the fieldtrip than you can in any class room
Don't take it unless you're very interested in the subject matter. The class is very disorganized and poorly run.
If you're a GEO major, take this course for sure.
prereqs: GEO 203 or Freshman Seminar "Earth's Changing Surface and Climate".
descrip: This course serves as an introduction to the processes that govern the distribution of different rocks and minerals in the Earth. We learn to make observations from the microscopic to continental scale and relate these to theoretical and empirical thermodynamics. The goal is to understand the chemical, structural, and thermal influences on rock and mineral formation and how this in turn influences the plate tectonic evolution of our plant.

title: Problems in Ancient History - Ethnicity in the Ancient Mediterranean
descrip: This is an interdisciplinary seminar on the problem of ethnicity and cultural identity in the ancient Mediterranean. Both the chronological and the geographical sweep is broad, including cases from the earliest phases of the Greek city-states to the post-Roman states in the West. Although Greek and Roman problems are at the core of the seminar, other ethnic identities in the period will be investigated. Central to the project is the consideration of a broad range of modern theoretical literature on the subject.

title: The Social Organization of Secrecy and Deception
descrip: A course on the organizational foundations and consequences of long-term deceptions and secrets, beginning with conventional accounts of social order, involving legitimacy, self-interest, and coercion, and then turning to the challenges of organizations founded on lies and secrets, focusing on the interplay of dramaturgy, self-interest, and trust in social networks. Extended case studies will include the Mafia, the Church of Scientology, the Bernard Madoff Ponzi scheme, the secret program to break the German cipher during WWII, the market for stolen art, big tobacco's cover-up of the health consequences of smoking, and Iran's nuclear program.

title: Modern Regression and Time Series
reviews: "Always check for stationarity".
As long as you go to lectures and save plenty of time to do the HW, you will learn some interesting material.
Avoid if possible if you already have a bit knowledge on timeseries/ monte carlo.

Basic programming background and experience with R program would be advantageous, though not necessary. The course focuses a lot on applications, methods and techniques in regression and time series analysis, rather than the theory.
Be prepared and go to lectures.
Go to Polytechnique and get some math skills, because they won't teach any of the math required in this course!
Good course, mainly applied, good introduction to R.
Good for programming skills, take as requirement only.
Great class. You will learn very useful skills.
Highly recommend. Very practical content.

I would recommend it to a student with a light background in statistics/probability for the content. It can also be interesting for any student wanting to learn R, discover many tools, but the theory will not be very challenging.

I would recommend to devote time and do some independent reading as well as test problems. Its also recommended to do a different set of computational problems apart from those given in the class to get a complete picture.
If you want to have a taste of time series, regressions, copulas and heavy tails. This is a very good course. But for more in-depth knowledge you should probably take another course
Programming in R is difficult for beginners.
Recommended.
Strongly recommended for students who are interested in learning finance from an engineering approach.
Take this course as a way to change your thinking!
Take this course under Carmona.

The course in required, so you don't have much of a choice. The work is reasonable, but make sure to really understand the material for the two midterms, as partial credit isn't given. The final exam/project is also reasonable, though a wrench that was thrown in made it seem more difficult than it actually was.
Try to familiarize yourself with R beforehand
You should take it.
the problem sets are sometimes quite long but they are a very preparation for the exams and midterms
this course is a very good foundation
prereqs: ORF 245 and MAT 202.
descrip: Heavy tailed distributions and copulas. Simple and multiple linear regressions. Nonlinear regression. Nonparametricegression and classification. Time series analysis: stationarity and classical linear models (AR, MA, ARMA, ..). Nonlinear and nonstationary time series models. State space systems, hidden Markov models and filtering.

title: Playwriting II: Intermediate Playwriting
prereqs: THR 205 and Program Director's permission (interview is not required). Please contact Professor Tim Vasen (tvasen@princeton.edu) for enrollment permission..
descrip: A workshop devoted to translation and adaptation for the stage, with the goal of creating a new adaptation of foreign language or non-dramatic source material into a new full-length play by the end of the semester. Knowledge of a second language is not required.

title: Philosophy of Physics
prereqs: A high level of mathematical maturity, equivalent to an A grade in one or more upper-level mathematics or physics courses..
descrip: This will be an intensive introduction to issues in the philosophy of physics that have both technical and nontechnical components. Topics may include: foundations of spacetime theories, substantivalism and relationism, symmetry arguments (parity and handedness, time reversibility), the anthropic principle.This will be taught in an advanced seminar format that will require active student participation in each class.

title: Institutional Finance, Trading, and Markets
reviews: Great class to PDF.
Take it, but be prepared to PDF.

The trading simulations are fun and the curve is very generous, but the lectures are really unstructured and there's no accompanying textbook/problem sets. While this means that the workload is low over the course of the semester, it means you have to scramble to prepare for the exams.
Very difficult, but worthwhile.
prereqs: ECO 300 or ECO 310 (preferred).
descrip: Financial institutions play an increasingly dominant role in modern finance. This course studies financial institutions and focuses on the stability of the financial system. It covers important theoretical concepts and recent developments in financial intermediation, asset pricing under asymmetric information, behavioral finance, and market microstructure. Topics include market efficiency, asset price bubbles, herding, liquidity crisis, credit crunch, risk management, market design, and financial regulation.

title: Classical Mechanics B
reviews: Do problem sets early and with other people, study them for the tests.
Even though it is difficult, I don't think "Death Mech" lived entirely up to it's name.  I would recommend taking it if you took the 105/106 sequence as a freshman.
Fair amount of work, but worth it.
Great class! Physics major? Take!
If you enjoyed 105/106, you'll enjoy this. The class is definitely challenging, so I wouldn't recommend taking other serious courses along with it.

It's a very interesting course and quite well taught. It definitely will take a lot of your time, but it's much more manageable than the legends say. The one thing is Professor Jones will almost never answer your e-mails.

Know what you're getting yourself into. This class will take a huge amount of time, and plan for that. Be careful doing five classes with this or you'll suddenly find yourself with no time whatsoever. On the other hand, it is a fantastic class, and if I had to redo the semester, I would take it again in a heartbeat.

Many will take this class as a right of passage. If your interests lie more in mathematics, you will probably not be satisfied, and you will be better off taking another math or COS course. If you like physics, you'll probably enjoy this class.

Please remember: Do practice questions on your own. Don't expect the professor to teach you how to solve problems. My experience is that Death Mech is all about doing practice questions before the exam.
THIS CLASS IS TOUGH! 105 was a step up from most high school physics, 205 is far above that.  Expect to spend at least 10 hours on the weekly problem sets, and sometimes quite a bit more.
Take it if you have the time to put in; it seems to be a better class overall than 207 at the moment.
Take it if you're a physics major.  Dont mess around in 207.

This course will introduce much of the mathematical formalism in physics.  There is not much use of physical intuition, but rather much of the course uses and derives common mathematical tools used in solving physical problems.  Also, it is very helpful to have basic programming knowledge going into this course.

This is a difficult, but extremely rewarding class. If you enjoyed mechanics and would like to learn more advanced tools, take this course. The problem sets can be challenging, but if you go to the problem sessions, they are definitely doable.

Yes, this really is "death mech." Take it if you really love physics and are willing to work every day and put in up to 20 hours a week on it. You will need to prioritize this class over anything else and probably shouldn't take this in a 5-class semester. Also, you will not survive unless you find a study group early in the semester.

You have two choices for your physics class sophomore year: 205 and 207.  Nobody will give you a straight answer about which is best for you.  The truth is, both have flaws.  Many of my friends who took 207 found it very easy and are worried that they won?t be prepared for quantum.  205 can consume your life, though; also, be aware that it assumes familiarity with differential equations.  If you do decide on 205, make sure to work on problem sets with friends.
prereqs: (PHY 103 and 104) or (PHY 105 and 106); one 200-level math course; or instructor's permission..
descrip: Classical Mechanics with emphasis on the Lagrangian method. The underlying physics is Newtonian, but with more sophisticated mathematics introduced as needed to understand more complex phenomena. Topics include the formalism of Lagrangian mechanics, central force motion and scattering, rigid body motion and non-inertial forces, small and coupled oscillations and Hamiltonian chaos. The course is intensive but rewarding.

title: Linguistics and Language Acquisition
reviews: Even if you're interested in languages in general and not necessarily language acquisition, this is a great course to take. You don't need any previous psychology or linguistics classes to understand the material and develop an interest in the subject.
Go to lecture! Lectures are great, if you pay attention during lecture you'll do well in the course.
I would recommend that students take good notes.
If you are at all interested in linguistics/how children learn languages, absolutely take this course!

If you are reading this evaluation, TAKE THIS CLASS. Prof. Goldberg is WONDERFUL - approachable, dynamic, flexible with class time, interested in her students. She gives you everything that you need to know, so that you are completely prepared. But the class is not a joke. It is a real, serious Princeton class. You will learn, and it will be AWESOME.
It's good, but be ready to work hard on understanding if you don't know anything about linguistics.
Strongly recommend. Very fun and interesting.
Take this, regardless of your experience in linguistics. It's interesting, not too much work, and Prof Goldberg is an interesting professor.
The course may seem easy at times, but you do need to know the material well in order to be successful.
Yes
descrip: We investigate the development of language from infancy to adulthood. The class examines naturalistic and experimental data concerning the acquisition of phonology, syntax semantics in light of current debates in linguistics and psycholinguistics.

title: Advanced Econometrics: Time Series Models
descrip: Concepts and methods of time series analysis and their applications to economics. Time series models to be studied include simultaneous stochastic equations, VAR, ARIMA, and state-space models. Methods to analyze trends, second-moment properties via the auto covariance function and the spectral density function, methods of estimation and hypothesis testing and of model selection will be presented. Kalman filter and applications as well as unit roots, cointegration, ARCH, and structural breaks models are also studied.

title: Studies in Spanish Language and Style
reviews: An excellent course to someone who has a notion os Spanish, but need to improve it.
Beware of grammar exercises.
Definitely take it, and if you do, simply keep up with the readings and you will succeed in it.

Definitely take this course with Profesora Dominguez. Your grammar and vocabulary will both improve dramatically. Profesora Dominguez really understands the needs of her students and will work to accommodate them.
Do the grammar assignments even if they aren't checked; it's almost impossible to keep up by only reviewing during class.
Enjoy interacting with students; don't be shy. Also ask for help if needed.

Essentially a review of advanced high school Spanish, this course can be very fun when taken with a good instructor ( I had Gorka Bilbao Torreros) and is a good introduction to the structure of Spanish courses here. That said, if you're VERY comfortable with your knowledge of grammar or are fluent, I'd suggest taking a higher level with a more specific focus.

Great course if you have a decent handle on your Spanish skills. Definitely the right option if you want to continue Spanish after having fulfilled the language requirement. You'll still learn grammar, but at a higher level than what's covered in 100-level courses, so it's not completely repetitive in that respect. You'll also have the chance to watch some Spanish movies, read stories, and speak a lot because of the small class sizes. Grading is very fair.
Hopefully you get Daylet because she is a great instructor who really cares about her students.

I would absolutely recommend a student to take a course with Gorka. The course load (SPA 207) in itself was also very good, and I'd recommend the course for anyone looking for additional practice past the language requirement, but primarily I would recommend trying to get him as an instructor.

I would definitely recommend taking this course. Even if you you place out of the foreign language requirement (as I did), you should take this class because it's more of a "chill" class than others. The workload is not bad at all, and you will have fun with the discussions.
If it is a requirement, this is a good class to take.

If you need this class, or really want to take it, do it. But if you are just looking for a Spanish class for a language requirement, this one might not be what you are looking for unless you really want to improve upon your grammar.
It's a fun class! Have fun learning Spanish.
It's a nice course, and I recommend it.
Make sure to do all of the work and fully understand the grammatical concepts on time.
Pay attention to the nit picky grades stuff or you will get a bad grade in this class.
Practice the grammar and ask questions!
Prepare and you'll be rewarded.
Put in the time necessary (duh) to do well.
Read the grammar book because she doesn't go over every topic in class.
Take it, with Daylet if you can
Take this class.  The small environment is great and it's just fun.  Your professor can definitely affect your experience, so try to shop around if you don't like your original professor.
Take this course!
The course was great if you're interested in continuing to develop language skills. Get Gorka Bilbao if you can.
This class is kind of hard.
This class is very similar to a high school AP Spanish class, but will develop other important skills, such as conversation and more detailed grammar, as well.

This course is a lot of work, and it's very hard to get a decent grade even with all the effort. And after taking this course, I have not noticed a significant improvement in my language abilities. Prof. Bono, however, is very nice, approachable, and accommodating.
This is a good spanish course to take if you need help with your speaking skills not for grammar
Try to learn vocabulary on your own too, because we don't have like a "to memorize" vocabulary list every week
tough course. very grammar heavy
prereqs: SPA 107 or 108 or permission of instructor. Also open to students that placed out of the Spanish language requirement..
descrip: SPA 207 is an advanced course in Spanish reading, writing and conversation. Its main purpose is to increase the student's fluency and accuracy in spoken and written Spanish. Importance is also given to understanding elements of Hispanic literature and culture through literary texts, Hispanic periodicals, and films.

title: Intermediate Persian I
reviews: Definitely take the course if you want to learn Persian!  It is, however, a decent time commitment and Prof. Mahallati both invests highly in the course, and has high expectations from her students.
I think that more people should consider taking Farsi because Prof. Amineh is the best.
It's a great course! Take it! Amineh is amazing!
prereqs: PER 102 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: PER 105 is designed to introduce students to intermediate level Persian. It stresses oral fluency, written expression, and reading comprehension. It will help the students to read texts of intermediate level difficulty communicate and converse in Persian in everyday situations write intermediate narrative style paragraphs coherently with reasonable accuracy.

title: Topics in Contemporary Architectural Theory - Kissing Architecture
reviews: Course requires a degree of maturity on the side of the student, which I appreciate. The seminars are based on open discussion and the professor does care for student's takes--as opposed to be merely checking students read the stuff.
Don't take the course if you do not intend on being an active participant. The quality of the course depends highly on the level of commitment and curiosity of the students.
Follow a hunch and amass an interesting archive.
Have spoken with professor, course will be droped

I would adamantly suggest that all students enrolled in the seminar properly prepare to engage in discourse, inquiry and debate by reading all of the assigned readings, being prepared with their own lines of inquiry and investigation. Students would also be well served to directly contact the professor in order to establish greater clarity and to share and test ideas beyond scheduled class sessions.
descrip: The seminar will argue that architecture has consistently propelled itself through its embrace of other cultural forms and that most key moments in the advancement of 20th century architecture are related to the conceptual and material friction generated by contact between architecture and other mediums. The seminar will construct a genealogy for contemporary architecture by examining the history and theory of medium specificity, tracing the dissolution of material specificity into notions of discipline, and speculating on current expansions and retractions at the limits of the field.

title: Policy Seminars
prereqs: Enrollment is limited to WWS concentrators and certificate students. The course is required for concentrators, for whom it is considered Junior Independent Work. Junior concentrators are automatically signed up for the policy task force as Junior Independent Work, not as WWS 401. WWS juniors who are certificate students must enroll. Seniors serving as commissioners and graduate students serving as consultants may enroll with permission of the instructor..
descrip: In policy task forces, students work in groups of 8 to 10, first formulating the general problem, then engaging in individual research on subtopics, and finally presenting their inferences for discussion and debate and producing a collective policy report.

title: From Negro to Black: African Americans and the 1970s
descrip: Using film, primary documents, literature, art, and secondary sources, this course explores the ten-year period between the assassination of Martin Luther King in 1968 and the 1978 Supreme Court case, Regents of the University of California v. Bakke,which upheld the constitutionality of affirmative action. This decade marks one of the most turbulent periods in American history -- one marked by radical changes impacting the political, religious, artistic, legal and educational cultures of Black people.

title: Introduction to Biomedical Innovation and Global Health
descrip: This course focuses on introductory biomedical innovation and global health in four specific areas: biomedical implants, nanotechnology and bioMEMS for cancer detection and treatment, the impact of select diseases and treatments on global health, and the use of ceramic filters for water purification. Lecture topics include basic concepts in cell and molecular biology as well as fundamentals of materials science and bioengineering. The course will demonstrate how biomedical innovation has impacted global health and enterprise in the developed and the developing world.

title: Traditional Chinese Architecture
reviews: Definitely take it if you have a strong interest in the subject; otherwise, since there aren't tests or a lot of papers, you might end up not learning anything if you don't do the readings.
Do the reading. Think hard and write creatively. Do not be daunted by Chinese names and terms which are foreign to you.
I would recommend the course for someone interested in architecture or Chinese culture or history.
I would would highly recommend taking this course, if you have any interest in the topic, or architecture at all. It's taught very well, and you're sure to get something out of it.
Professor Silbergeld is a great lecturer! The only written work is a short paper and term paper, which is stressful but not a lot of work compared to other courses.
This is a course that can be your start for Chinese architecture, and of course, you can also get deeper understanding and do deeper research on the subject through the course.
You're not expected to be interested in every topic since the professor just wants you to gain insight on what you're interested in.
good class
descrip: Thematic introduction to traditional Chinese architecture, urban design and garden building, with attention to principles and symbolism of siting and design; building techniques; modularity of structures and interchangeability of palace, temple, tomb, and domestic design; regional variation.

title: Main Currents of Spanish Thought, 1848 to the Present - Spanish Literature Between Empires
descrip: We will explore how the establishment, consolidation, decline and loss of Empire is represented in a series of works from the XVIII - XX centuries in Spain. Working in reverse chronological order, major topics will include: Francoist visions of empire and Spain's manifest destiny; representations of the rise of the US as empire in early twentieth century Spanish literature; links between Spain and Latin America around 1898; Spanish romanticism as the performed authenticity of a colonized nation; Enlightenment and Empire.

title: Fundamentals of Environmental Studies: Population, Land Use, Biodiversity, and Energy
reviews: Attend lectures, but readings aren't important.
Avoid taking this class unless you need it to satisfy the ENV certificate requirement. This course covers material that you can research on your own.
Definitely take it
Definitely!  It is eye-opening and stimulating, no matter what you want to study.
Don't take this course unless you have to for the requirements.
Fill out the exit tickets!
I enjoyed the course -- if you're interested, do the readings. I PDF'ed it too.
I highly recommend this course. The workload is not heavy, and the time commitment is low. It is basically just great all around.
I would definitely recommend this course to anybody who is interested in nature and the environment!
IT"S NOT EASY
If you are EEB or ENV, take it because you will already know everything going into it. I PDFed it, and it is not much work for a PDF course.
If you are interested in environmental issues, you probably know quite a bit of the course material already.  Only take this class if you need it.  If not, take higher level ENV.
If you're interested at all, you might as well give it a shot.
If you're interested in the environment, it is a good place to start.
It is helpful to have somewhat of math background for the work in the course. It is a good to course to learn what environmental  problems the world is dealing with.
It's not a hard class, some of the information is pretty interesting. Will inform you more about the environment.
Its a really interesting course and makes you believe we need to be doing more to lessen our environmental impact.
Nice, interesting intro course on major environmental issues.  If not taking for certificate program, would be a good class to PDF. Be sure to catch up on all the readings by exam time.
Only take it if you have to
Only take this class if you have to.  The lectures are interesting but never really go in depth enough.  It is incredibly hard to get an A and the curve/exam grading is really tough.
Overall it's an easy course that presents a lot of material that everyone should know. There are a lot of readings and assignments that take up some time, but are doable.

Overall, the material is interesting, but the course lacks focus and organization. It's a pretty easy ST, with very little actual science. If you have a science background, you will be bored. If you're more interested in policy, you might like it more.
Please do not judge the ENV department based on this course.  If you are in the certificate, try and use one of the other low level courses to replace this because it is not worth your time.
Survey class
Take it -- really easy and you learn a lot about some interesting topics in environmental studies.
Take it for an easy STN. Prepare for stupid (yet still easy) precept assignments.
Take it if you have to.  This course did not make me excited about the ENV program and I even considered dropping the certificate.
Take it! It's interesting and not too much work, and Caylor and Wilcove are great professors.
The lectures are a good introduction to environmental science, but the grading and structure of the class are illogical. I would recommend auditing the lectures instead of taking it for a grade.

There seems to be a lot of readings; however, not only are they very interesting, but if time is limited, a lot of them can be skimmed. I would recommend doing the readings purely for personal knowledge.
This course is great for providing a broad look at environmental issues and how earth systems work. Great background for any other ENV class.

This is a fun class for anyone interested in becoming more informed about the evolving debates in energy and climate change.  It is not too difficult and the lectures are definitely worth going to because the profs are very knowledgeable.
You should take this class if you're interested in environmental material.
do the readings--you'll learn a lot!
go to lecture
none
prereqs: P/D/Fail option is available, but precludes qualifying for the Certificate of Proficiency in Environmental Studies..
descrip: An expanding human population and the desire of all people for a more prosperous life have placed tremendous demands on the environment. We will explore how human activities have affected land use, agriculture, fisheries, biodiversity, and the use of energy. Our focus is both global and local, highlighting not only fundamental changes in the biosphere, but also the ways in which individual decisions lead to major environmental changes. We explore the fundamental principles underlying contemporary environmental issues, and we use case studies to illustrate the scientific, political, economic, and social dimensions of environmental problems.

title: Reading & Writing About the Scientific Literature in English (Half Term): Science and Engineering
prereqs: Course open to international graduate students in their second semester of study or beyond in any field related to science and engineering. Non-Credit. Enrollment by application..
descrip: Introduction for non-native speakers of English to reading and writing about the scientific literature in science and engineering. Topics include how scientists work with the research literature as both readers and writers, how scientific articles are constructed and interpreted, how research findings are presented, and how scientific arguments are developed. Two 80-minute seminars. To apply, visit http://www.princeton.edu/writing/wse

title: Introduction to the Evolution of Jazz Styles
reviews: A great course whether you are a music major or far from it. You need to be interested in Jazz or you probably won't like it.
I would definitely recommend the course as a fundamental overview of the jazz paradigm. However, some basic musical background in jazz might be useful.
If you are interested in music, yes.
If you don't know jazz, take this -- it will open your eyes so much. But don't expect it to be an easy class at all.
If you're into jazz, you have to take this
If you're not really interested in jazz, you'll probably get bored, but if you come in with a little bit of background or a lot of motivation, you'll probably enjoy it.
Read the textbook, and keep up with the listening!
Take this if you want a low-stress interesting survey course about jazz music.
The material gets boring in some places but it is not an overly challenging course. If you are looking for a course with less homework and a teacher who absolutely loves what he does then take it.
This class is great for people who want to learn more about jazz, regardless of whether you have a background in music or not.

This is a fun, relaxed class, although you'll need to put time in to memorize everything you need for the midterm. As a non-music major, I was still able to keep up and found everything interesting. Prof. DeMotta is really nice...his lectures weren't perfectly composed, but he always got out whatever he needed to.
Will expand your knowledge of jazz and widen your exposure to songs, styles, and musicians, regardless of whether you are a seasoned jazz listener or new to jazz.
descrip: An introductory survey examining the historical development of jazz from its African origins through the present. The course will place an emphasis on the acquisition of listening skills and will explore related musical and social issues.

title: Intermediate Chinese I
reviews: A very positive experience- I am going to continue with my Chinese courses here! A supportive environment.
Chinese is a really intensive program. While I really enjoyed it, it is much more intensive than other languages.

DEFINITELY! While the setup of the course is not what I expected for Princeton University, I have heard that the upper-level courses are much better and in all, I did improve my Chinese somewhat. I hope. 
Besides, learning Chinese, even poorly, is a good idea given the path of the world currently.

Definitely take it if you have the time and ability to do so - especially if Jia Laoshi is in charge again! It is a significant time commitment though, and you will not be able to slack off and get away with it - keep that in mind!
Do it, it's a great language, very easily picked up and worth the work.

Go to class every day, and make sure you don't sell yourself short in the writing aspect of this class - you have to do a little work on your own memorizing how to write characters, but it will benefit you greatly throughout the year.
I think this is an interesting course, but would definitely tell them that inorder to do well, they must keep on top of their work becuase it is very easy to fall behind.

I thoroughly enjoyed the course and would strongly recommend it to others. A lot of students will tell you that it's a ton of work, and not fun at all, but it's really not that time-consuming if you put in a small amount of work every night. Just don't try to cram the night before tests. Also, the teachers are absolutely amazing.
I would say try and get an individual session with Professor Jia. I didn't, and I wish I had, because he is really good at Chinese and also really hot.
If you're looking to learn Chinese, then this is a great course to take.
Keep up with the readings and vocab; listen to the recordings; keep practicing in your own time, and you should be fine!
Make sure you have time to stay on top of your work, and to get to class every day!
Prepare for class every morning - it helps a lot
Rigorously do the homework.
Stay on top of the material. The class moves quickly and it can be easy to fall behind.
Take it. A welcome break from stressful classes!
Take the class if you have the time, as it is very time consuming depending on your chinese background
The workload is tough, but Chinese is a great language to learn and this class is a great way to do it!
They should be well-prepared before classes.

You should only take this if you're serious about learning Chinese and not to fill the language distribution requirement, but if you are serious, it will be extremely satisfying and is very well taught.
prereqs: CHI 101 and CHI 102 or equivalent..
descrip: While reinforcing the knowledge students have acquired thus far, this course will further develop the students' audio-lingual proficiency as well as bring their reading and writing ability to a higher level.

title: Quantitative Analysis III
prereqs: Prerequisite: POL 572..
descrip: Second course in applied statistical methods for social scientists, building on the materials covered in POL 572 or its equivalent. Course covers a variety of statistical methods including models for longitudinal data and survival data. Material covered corresponds to the quantitative part of the General Exam in Formal and Quantitative Analysis at Level II.

title: Fixed Income: Models and Applications
reviews: Be prepared to commit a lot of time to the class. You'll learn a lot if you really put in effort to the class.
Be prepared to work a lot, but learn a lot!
Be prepared to work hard and know your math, primarily stochastic calculus and multi-variable calculus.
Do the readings.
Don't be cowards. TAKE IT!
Fast paced course, good lecturer - clear and can put all material in practical context.
Huge time commitment for the course.
If you have the background in mathematics/economics, I strongly recommend this course for anyone with an interest in financial markets,  the game is worth the candle
Only take this course if you have a decent amount of previous exposure to finance, espeically fixed income. Even then, be prepared to work very hard and mentally prepare yourself for low grades.
The course is made out to be much more difficult then it really is. The material is really quite simple, but the instructor makes it seem impossible, for no apparent reason.

This course is excellent if you want to learn more about the fixed income markets. Professor Jurek is very ambitious so it is very demanding and solid grounds in mathematics ( notably Stochastic calculus are required). It is worthwile taking it. It is really a great subject which is very well taught .
Very challenging course if lacking the basic foundation.

You must do this if you want to be a quant or want to learn about various pricing models and techniques for fixed income instruments. The course is very quantitative so knowledge of basic stochastic calculus, programming and being comfortable with mathematics (some linear algebra, differential equations) is advisable.
don't hesitate
if you have taken a derivative pricing class and a stochastic calculus class, take it; else refrain
just take the class but you have to know that there is a lot of work.
only take 1 "Jurek" course.
prereqs: FIN 501, MAT 201-202 and recommend MAT 203-204..
descrip: Course covers no-arbitrage models of contracts based on interest rates including bonds, forward and future contracts, swaps, options, and other derivatives, and develops the theory of arbitrage-free pricing of financial assets in discrete and continuous time, as well as many special models that can be used to price and hedge fixed income securities.

title: Modern Physics II: Nuclear and Elementary Particle Physics
prereqs: PHY 304 and 305.
descrip: Introduction to the Standard Model of particle physics describing elementary particles and their interactions. Specific topics include symmetries and conservation laws; electromagnetic, weak, and strong interactions between quarks, leptons, and gauge bosons; and experimental methods in particle physics. Selected topics covering current research in high energy physics will also be discussed.

title: Health Economics I
descrip: Examines health issues in the developed world. Specific topics include the evolution of health over the life course; the fetal origins hypothesis; the two-way links between socioeconomic status and health; the impact of social safety nets on health outcomes; environmental threats to children's health and development; health insurance and its effects on health; the industrial organization of health care delivery. Prerequisites: PhD-level microeconomics and econometrics.

title: Regression and Applied Time Series
reviews: An excellent course on statistics that touches on a good variety of topics.
Anyone interested in statistics should take.

Don't take it unless you have to.  Heard that Carmona is really good but he usually teaches the grad student version.  Be prepared to basically self-teach yourself the material and learn a lot of R on the fly.
Don't take this course unless you're in ORFE. If you're in ORFE it's required. It's poorly taught and organized terribly. I barely learned anything during the semester. It's not a good class.
Don't take this course unless you're required to.
Grit your teeth and bare it, poor souls.
Han Liu is not teaching this class any more so no recommendations.
Han Liu obviously cares a lot about the class and his students, and he puts a lot of effort into teaching the course well. The material, though, just isn't that interesting.

I personally enjoyed this course. A lot of students complained about Professor Liu, but if you look past the sloppy handwriting, I thought that the lectures were quite informative and helpful. He also follows the book pretty closely, and he posts lecture notes online. A little bit slow at the beginning and rushed towards the end, but not too difficult, given adequate background.
If Prof. Liu is teaching any course I would definitely take it as he is a brilliant kind man from whom I was able to learn a great deal.
Not very well-taught or structured, but that's because it's Han Liu's first year of teaching this. Maybe next year it'll be better.
Take if required. Otherwise don't take.
Take it if you must
Take it. It's a fairly easy class (and very easy compared to other 400-level classes in ORF/ECO)
Take the course only if you have to
This is a good course to take, to become familiar with R coding and time series data analysis.
You can actually learn something in this class if you attend the lectures. Professor Liu is down to earth and cares about teaching. Ask questions to get as much as you can out of the course.
You have to take it anyways, but you actually learn a lot of statistics.
study a lot for the midterm
prereqs: ORF 245 and MAT 202.
descrip: Statistical Analysis of financial data: Density estimation, heavy tail distributions and dependence. Regression: linear, nonlinear, nonparametric. Time series analysis: classical models (AR, MA, ARMA, ..), state space systems and filtering, and stochastic volatility models (ARCH, GARCH, ....).

title: When Music Is Made
reviews:
- Have some background in music and get ready to sing a lot. 
- Don't worry if you can't sing, they teach you, more or less.

A solid introduction to song writing for people not familiar with composition theory. The class eases you into writing music, and then picks up quite a bit towards the end, by which you'll be composing, performing, and recording your own song. I recommend taking this class if you want to start learning how to compose.
Definitely take it! It's fun and not stressful.

Great class to take as an LA requirement. And Paul Lansky is awesome... a good enough reason to take the class by itself. Only complaint is that lectures sometimes felt like a waste of time and we get almost absolutely no grading feedback until after the final assignment.
Great course. If you take it for a grade, talk to your preceptor a lot about how to make it better. If you're PDFing, have fun. The projects take some time but are well worth it. I learned a lot
I would definitely take it! It was so much fun, and a good creative outlet/break from pset heavy classes. It definitely helps to how to play piano, or even read music before hand.
I wouldn't recommend this if you have no experience with music, but if you have at least some knowledge, it is great. It is a great survey of composition.

I'd recommend this course to those with an interest in music.  Those who are musical experts may find the course a bit slow, but otherwise everything works well.  Professor Lansky's use of songs in lecture make at-times slow sections seem fun.  Precepts are almost familial, relaxing, and interesting at the same time.  And if you have a knack for creativity, the midterm and final assignments are great.  Plus, the material isn't that hard or too long, so even those in difficult majors should be able to find time to enjoy the course's material.
If you already know music theory this course might bore you. If not, go for it.
If you have an interest in music, take this course!
If you love music and especially if you play an instrument, then this course is one you should take.
If you play an instrument and want to improve your ear and your knowledge of how music "works," it's an awesome class.
If you're interested in learning more about composition without being too challenged, this is a good option for you.
If you're interested in music theory, or music in general, but not in a music major or certificate, this course is the one for you.
It is a great course to take, especially if you have some background experience with music.
It's a fun way to fulfill an LA, but also might be more work than expected.
It's a good, fun and easy course.
Make sure you have a good music background.
Take it if you want a laid-back introduction to music theory. You still learn a lot, but it's not very intense.
Take it! It's a lot of fun, and you get much better in everything: music sight-reading, composing, pitch recognizing, etc.
Take it, especially if you love music or write music.
Take this course if you want an easy LA and if don't care about learning anything of actual substance about music theory.
Take this course. You will love the assignments. Would rather not take it with lansky tho

This is a great class for someone who knows a little bit about music to gain a very good understanding of the basics of music theory. I don't have a desire to go on and learn a lot more about music theory, in large part because this class taught me everything I wanted to know, plus a little extra. It also helped me become a much better songwriter.

This is a great course to take if you want to learn about basic theory, chord progressions, composition, etc without too much work. BEWARE however: the lectures are really hard to follow and are almost entirely unhelpful. PRECEPTS and ASSIGNMENTS are where the learning happens, and the learning IS substantial--just not where you'd expected it to be.

This is an easy course if you have had some musical background. The assignments can be time consuming at times, but this will mainly depend on you musical backgound. The assigments are pretty fun though. There are few concepts that have to be learned. The course is mainly in their application. The lectures mainly play musical examples of these concepts.
Yeah, you should take it! It's not demanding, but very cool and you learn a lot!
You might wanna come in with some knowledge in music.
did not really learn much and was lot more work than it was worth
good class, enjoyed it
if you like music you should take it probly
super easy if you have a background in music
descrip: An introduction to the fundamentals of music theory through exercises in songwriting, harmony, notation, ear-training, transcription, composition and analysis. A variety of musics will be studied. Students should have some knowledge of notation. The main emphasis in the course will be on song-writing as a means to master rudiments.

title: Asset Pricing
reviews: Do problem sets and study hard for the exams
If you want to build some muscles for  asset pricing and interested in bubbles, take the course.
Learn some stochastic calculus before this class.
Take it.
descrip: Introduction to asset pricing covering theory in both continuous and discrete time to study dynamic portfolio choice; derivative pricing; the term structure of interest rates; and intertemporal asset-pricing and consumption-based models. Pre-requisites: All required courses in micro, macro and econometrics at the first-year PhD level.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Advanced Topics in Financial Inclusion
prereqs: The course assumes familiarity with basic financial concepts..
descrip: Access to finance has been the most prominent development intervention of the last 20 years. Yet half the world's population remains unbanked, and the evidence of microfinance's impact is limited at best. This seminar will explore obstacles and policy solutions to providing the world's poor with appropriate financial services. Focus will be on current and policy-relevant topics, with guest presenters from the microfinance industry.

title: Theory of Groundwater Flow
descrip: Fundamental physics of fluid flow and contaminant transport in porous media; derivation of governing equations; analytical solution of simplified equations, with application to well hydraulics; and parameter estimation and analysis of field problems. The course examines the application of numerical models and gives an introduction to multiphase flow systems and advanced methods for equation development.

title: History and Theories of Architecture: 20th Century
reviews: Excellent and deep overview of 20th Century theories and histories.
I would recommend to other students to ask what the overall theme of the class was.

I would suggest that every student embarking on this seminar ensure that they have ample time in their schedules to complete all the assigned readings, in order to fully grasp the range of information presented in the seminar presentations by the professor. Having completed the readings would also ensure greater discourse from students in the seminar.
If you want to take a challenging course that will stimulate a lot of thinking esp. when writing your final paper, take this class.
Recommend taking it.
Skip the session on Corb.

The prof has a very unique approach to the study of architectural historiography. Though it is highly idiosyncratic, his method becomes more apparent across multiple class sessions and offers an alternative mode of analysis that will appeal to a range of students.
The subject matter of this course is really interesting. However, it is hard having only one paper to base your grade off of.
This class is a broad history, but which provides a lot of specific information.
take it if you are looking for a good history overview class
descrip: An overview of the major themes running through the various strands of modern architecture in the twentieth century. While overarching in scope, the seminar is based on a close reading of selected buildings and texts by prominent figures of the modern movement and its aftermath. Special emphasis is given to the historiography and history of reception of modern architecture, as well as the cultural, aesthetic and scientific theories that have informed contemporary architectural debates, including organicism, vitalism, functionalism, historicism and their opposites.

title: Beginner's Greek: Greek Grammar
reviews: Absolutely go for it.

If anyone is even remotely interested in studying Greek, I would recommend the course, especially if Professor Flower is teaching it. While I do not know how the other professors approach the material, I felt very happy with him as the instructor.
If you're looking to start Ancient Greek, Flower is a good choice. He teaches fairly well, and he's very helpful. He's always willing to meet.

It would be very helpful to have a good grasp of grammar in general before taking this course; a lot of time was spent explaining the actual Greek but not a lot of time explaining the actual function of each piece of grammar!  A little knowledge of Latin is also pretty useful, though not necessary.

Put in the time and effort and you will be rewarded - Greek is not a course that you can merely learn the concepts, grammar, and vocabulary and be fine. It takes a thorough amount of time and practice to hone your skills but it is beyond worth it in the end as you truly earn the grade you deserve and develop a command in the language that you might not in other 101 language courses.
Take it!
Use the book a lot!  It's very helpful.  Also learn the vocab and paradigms super well, because the class is mostly translation.

You really should put in half an hour at least a day with Hanson & Quinn: it is easier to forget paradigms than you might think, and if you fall behind, the confusion builds up and you may get overwhelmed. Get off to a very strong start, and focus 100% of your energy on learning Greek when you're studying it, even if you only have fifteen minutes.
prereqs: Greek 101-102 are a unit. Greek 102 must be taken to receive credit for 101. Greek 101 must be passed to qualify for 102..
descrip: Designed to enable the student to read classical Attic Greek with facility; at the end of the year a short Platonic dialogue or comparable text will be read. Equal emphasis on acquiring a vocabulary and an understanding of the structure of the language.

title: What is Modern?
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Research Methods in Political Science
reviews: At least you don't have to use R.
Fine for the departmental requirement.
If you have to, you have to! The precepts were fun :)
Study harder for the midterm
This class is exactly what it sounds like: research methods in political science.  No more, no less.  It is very dry.  Very useful, but very dry.
Yes, absolutely!
descrip: This is the introductory undergraduate course in research methods for Politics majors, designed to help prepare students for junior papers and the senior thesis. The material is chosen to convey an understanding of research design, choice of methods, and analysis. Both qualitative and quantitative methods will be taught. However, this is not a statistics course, and the material is different from what a statistics class or qualitative research class would teach. Rather, it is an introduction to a range of research methodologies as they are applied to political science topics.

title: Contexts of Composition
descrip: "Righting Wrong Notes": Course focuses on music that both establishes or assumes a normative syntactical context then stretches that context to achieve extreme expressive ends. Emphasis will be on unexpected, blue, pointed or flat out "wrong" notes used dramatically "right" effect/affect. The interplay between syntax and expression will be a recurring general theme as is the function of rhythm, meter, texture and orchestration in contextualizing surprises. The course will focus primarily on analytical discovery with some compositional exercises.

title: Modern China
reviews: Don't be daunted by the enormous readings. Write the review report carefully and most importantly review and contextualise each book and each author.

I don't think that you'll be able to take this course in future (at least in its current form), on account of Prof. Naquin's requirement. However, it stands as a fitting testament to her requirements for scholarly rigour and never letting yourself lose sight of the most basic, and most difficult, questions.
If interested in Qing period China, should take the course.
descrip: This seminar will examine the major historiographical and methodological issues in Chinese history for the modern period. We will read and evaluate the most important historians and consider the issues that seem especially provocative or interesting.

title: Origins of Language
descrip: An examination of explicit and implicit accounts of the origin of language and the necessity of these to the larger literary and theoretical practices and projects they inform.

title: Problems in Byzantine History - Rethinking the 11th Century in Byzantium
reviews: Exciting topic and well worth taking
It's a stimulating and challenging course in an interesting (not to mention important) subject.  Just watch out for the hefty workload.
Take it.
descrip: The eleventh century is now generally seen as a period of economic expansion in the Byzantine and east Mediterranean world, on the one hand, but of military and political collapse on the other, chiefly as a result of the defeat at the battle of Manzikert in 1071 at the hands of the Selcuk Turks. Is this picture justified? How do contemporary sources view the empire and its politics at this time? What is the nature of the evidence for both the economic and social and political history of the empire? This course will re-examine key sources for the period to see how far the currently-accepted view is justified.

title: An Integrated Introduction to Engineering, Mathematics, Physics
reviews: Course is taught fairly well, and lab component is extraordinary.
Definitely take EMP rather than physics and math separately because the rocket lab is amazing (much better than regular physics lab). Had so much fun in lab.
Definitely take it if you are interested in applying physics and math to the engineering field.
Don't expect a super cool rocket lab. It was pretty cool when we launched the rocket, but that took around 15 minutes.
Don't worry too much about every derivation on the board.  They are helpful for understanding the material, but the resulting equations are more important.
EMP is worth taking for the rocket lab.

I believe that although there are a lot of problems that still needed to be sorted out with the EMP program, it was still beneficial to have a smaller class size and more relaxed class environment.  Additionally the rocket lab was much more interesting than traditional physics labs.

I think that the laboratory experience is what makes this course worth taking. The course itself is in a bit of a state of flux and modification, and the lecturers seem to be finding their footing a bit, but the lab is certainly very interesting and seems to provide an interesting alternative to the basics physics class.
I thought the professor was more engaging than the normal 103 class and the lab really makes the class.

I would say to take it! The lab component is a lot of fun. The physics is hard, but you can do it if you put in the time. Vikram is a great lecturer, and it was definitely worthwhile taking this course. I really learned the material and I am excited to keep taking physics at higher levels.

If you are a hands-on learner and need to play with pulleys to fully understand how they work, or need to feel the effects of friction by sliding blocks up and down ramps, this is not the physics course for you. I would recommend this class to students with previous physics experience (not necessarily AP; I didn't) and who can understand concepts only through lecture and precept. The rocket lab was really cool.
If you decide to take this take advantage of the office hours and extra help because they are very available and useful.
If you have any interest in how mechanics truly work and seeing the world from the viewpoint of mechanics, TAKE THIS COURSE
If you love physics, take this course. If you're not sure if you're that into it, stick with 103.

It's certainly an interesting course, and I can't do a direct comparison against 103. We did learn Thermo and Fluids, which they didn't. I think the course heavily depends on the professor, which our year was Vikram Duvvuri. He was a great preceptor, but sometimes jumped around in lecture to cover stuff--if you went to him outside of class, he'd clear everything up for you. The lab is basicaly some soldering, rocket building, and a launch, then 3-4 weeks of MATLAB data processing. It does introduce you to data analysis done by engineers, but I personally didn't find it interesting, since it was just following directions and troubleshooting, basically. Something else to think about--only around 40 people take EMP, so you do miss out on meeting more engineers who would have taken 103/201 due to the small class size. Many people also didn't work on psets together, so it was a little hard making friends in the course, though we did have a few EMP-exclusive pregames through the semester!

It's the best substitute for 103. Guaranteed good precepts, thoughtful written work, an amazing and useful series of labs, along with more useful topics covered than in 103. Take it if you need physics.
Much more interesting than the normal engineering route and not much harder so i recommend it.
Only take this course if you've taken AP Physics C.  Even if you have taken AP Physics, and are thinking about taking this course, seriously reconsider.
Physics is tough, but the rocket lab and the instructors are great. It is nice to be in a smaller class setting where you know most of the students and the teachers know your name.

Remember that EGR 192 (math) is part of the package, too, when you take this course. I definitely liked this course, but EGR 192 was almost a deal-breaker.

Instruction quality varies greatly by professor, so take past years' comments on this course with a grain of salt.

Also, don't pick this class if you don't like small class sizes and labs where you "have fun" more so than doing physics.

Stay on top of things from day one. As in pay attention during lectures/precepts, do your assignments diligently (you may not get all the answers but at least try as hard as you can until you hit the wall), go to office hours to review things you got wrong. You should be fine.
Take it for the lab, but the classes will be either very good or very terrible depending on the professor.

Take this course if you are doing MAT 201 and PHY 103. The lab component is worth it, and because the class is small, it is a tighter-knit group of students. It is thus easier to get help and ask questions.
Take this course if you need to take PHY103 for engineering requirement anyways.
The biggest drawback is having very little material to study off of. If you aren't the kind of person who keeps up with the material consistently all year, it will be difficult.
The lab is enjoyable.
The physics is hard.
The physics portion of EGR was really pretty cool, the lab is much better than regular physics labs, but over all I don't think I would recommend this course over regular physics 103.

This course certainly achieves its goal of teaching students general mechanical physics and multivariable calculus. While it did not completely feel integrated in terms of strong connections between the math and physics aspects of the course, it was still a very sufficient presentation of the material. The problem sets and quizzes were very manageable, and the professors are reasonable about extensions and questions. In addition, the lab did not take up much time and was not stressful, unlike the labs in Physics 104. Overall, I would say this course is a lighter workload than taking its parts separately.

This course does not introduce very much material specifically related to engineering, but it seemed like we had a much easier time than our counterparts in PHY 103. The course does teach you a new approach to physics without being overly stressful. If you need help, definitely take a peek at a friend's PHY 103 textbook rather looking to Simple Nature for guidance.
This is NOT an introductory physics course.

Vikram is a great guy and makes class interesting. He doesn't always explain very well *why* you need to solve a problem a particular way, which can make the problems tricky. Overall, the class content wasn't my favorite (I just don't really like physics) but Vikram made the class much better than I was expecting. (If he's not teaching it, then I don't know - I guess just take EMP if you want the rocket lab, which was fun, or a smaller class size.)
have some background in physics
make sure you do the practice problems
prereqs: All first-year engineering students who have placement into multivariable calculus on the basis of a score of 5 on the BC calculus exam (or equivalent) are eligible to enroll..
descrip: Taken concurrently with EGR/MAT/PHY 192, this course offers an integrated presentation of the material from PHY 103 (General Physics: Mechanics and Thermodynamics) and MAT 201 (Multivariable Calculus) with an emphasis on applications to engineering. Physics topics include: mechanics with applications to fluid mechanics; wave phenomena; and thermodynamics.

title: Issues in Environmental and Natural Resource Economics
prereqs: A working knowledge of multivariate calculus and intermediate microeconomics is assumed. Consult the instructor if you have not taken MAT 200 or equivalent and ECO 300 or equivalent..
