descrip: Course introduces use of economics in understanding both the sources of and the remedies to environmental and resources allocation problems. It emphasizes the reoccurence of economic phenomena like public goods, externalities, market failure and imperfect information. Students learn about the design and evaluation of environmental policy instruments, the political economy of environmental policy, and the valuation of environmental and natural resource services. These concepts are illustrated in a variety of applications from domestic pollution of air, water and land to internatinal issues such as global warming and sustainable develoment.

title: Russian Language Pedagogy
prereqs: Open to Graduate Students Only.
descrip: A practical course required of graduate students who are teaching beginning Russian. The course will cover all issues relevant to the teaching of the language: phonetics, grammar presentation, efficient use of class time, class and syllabus planning, writing quizzes and tests. In addition to weekly meetings with the instructors, students will be expected to meet as a group to develop best practices for covering each week's material. An important part of the course will be instructor supervision of teaching.

title: Intensive Beginner's and Intermediate Spanish
reviews: Come to class every day and stay up-to-date with the readings and workbook assignments. It's not that difficult, and it really helps!!
Do all the work and you will be successful.
Do the online activities that accompany the textbook, and take this class because it is fun and you learn a lot.
Do the workbook exercises everyday and try to practice vocabulary everyday so you don't cram for the exams. Be sure to review the cultural facts before every exam as well.

Don't leave all of the work until the last minute. Because this class is everyday there is daily work and it is very easy to get behind. This class has a lot of busy work but I would highly recommend Professor Olander.
Don't take a course with this professor!
Go to class and participate everyday.
I definitely recommend taking this course if you can get Lisa as your professor.
I highly recommend Professor Baranski.  If you enjoy Spanish she will give you a cultural and love for the language, and if you really don't like languages she will make you a better Spanish student.
I hope you like Spanish and speaking in Spanish!
I would definitely take this course. Learn how to speak Spanish!

I would say that it really is dismal if you get sick during the semester because it puts you behind.  Also, attend class everyday because repitition and exposure are the keys to improving your linguistic ability.
I would tell the student to stay ahead of the course because it is hard to catch up, especially nearing the end, when all the assignments are due.

If you can, definitely take SPA 103 if you want to learn more spanish in a short amount of time. Also Profesora Rina Ramos Lopez is a fantastic teacher and person, so if you can try to get her as your teacher! She helped me alot with grammar and made me feel more confident speaking spanish.
If you do your homework in advance, and re-read your notes regularly you will make great progress.
Keep an organized notebook.

Keep in mind the weighting distribution for exams, assignments, participation, etc. The latter mentioned components actually have a lot of weight. Put in an effort everyday so that you won't regret it later.
Keep up with the work. It's easy to not do work until the week before the test.
Profesora Baranski was fantastic. You should take the class and read the textbook pretty much every day if you want to speak Spanish.
Stay on top of your workbook assignments and proofread your writing assignments before you turn them in. Ask the professor for help anytime you feel lost in class!
Study as you go along.  Thats the only way to learn spanish.
Study nightly so that you don't fall behind.
Study your vocabulary and make sure to practice your speaking skill.

Take homework assignments seriously, as they constitute a significant portion of your grade and help you solidify your understanding of the language. Also, listen to other Spanish media as it will help you contextualize the language and solidify  and expand on what you've learned.

Take it with Baranski, she's a good teacher. The readings and language skills are fairly basic. The organization of the course is not clear however, and I would recommend you double check with the professor in regards to things just because it is hard to follow the syllabus.
Take it with Olander - she makes going to class 5 days a week do-able

Take it! I grew a lot - it really challenged me in ways that my Spanish courses in high school never did. If you're used to this level of work in Spanish class/are proficient already, then this class will be pretty low stress and engaging at the same time.
Take this class it is very good as a starter class if you want to study Spanish.
Take this course if you have an interest in spanish.
Take this course.

The SPA 103 course did a great job filling in holes in my grammar, that I had allowed to emerge at high school. Even though it's also supposed to be for beginners, I feel that the course is more suited to those that have done the language before to some level as the pace would be a little too fast for beginners, at least in my opinion.

Recommended with Marcia Olander, great professor.
They should take it
This course is fast paced, so having taken multiple years of spanish in high school is essential
This course will take a lot of study time. You are covering 101 and 102 in one semester, so it moves quite fast.
This is a challenging yet fair spanish course that will help you with your speaking ability.
Tough to get a good grade in, but worthwhile.
Watch the movie even though it's not very good, and don't procrastinate the homework just because it's not due every day.

You are probably taking this course because the language placement test placed you into it, which is fine. At first I wondered whether or not I should have been placed into 105 following my 3 years of High School Spanish, but this course definitely moved quickly enough for me after the first few weeks. The textbook used, Sol y Viento, is very good in teaching you a lot about the language and culture and even has a video story that goes a long with it making things more interesting. Seeing the other people in this class every day will definitely leave you wishing you could stay with the same class dynamic in 107, you grow fond of some of the others, but I guess it's just time to move on and meet new people. You will definitely learn a lot of Spanish if you take this course.
You definitely get out what you put into a language course.
You probably only want to take this class if you need to fulfill your language requirement. The 5 days a week can become tedious.
Your Spanish will improve. Lisa is great.
get this teacher
good course.
put more work than you think you need and you just might succeed.
take it.
prereqs: Prerequisites include a satisfactory score on the Language Placement Test and permission of instructor..
descrip: SPA 103 is an intensive course that covers SPA 101 and SPA 102 in one semester. Designed for students who have previously studied Spanish at elementary levels. Language is presented in a cultural context in order to develop the skills of listening, speaking, reading and writing.

title: Classical Mythology
reviews: Be prepared for a decent amount of reading, but the workload is not very high otherwise.
Don't let it go on the backburner, or else all those missed readings and lack of effort in the class will come back to bite you
GO TO LECTURE. Completely worth it.
Go to lecture - it's fun and informative.
Great class! Read ALL of the plays; the secondary source readings are more optional but they will really deepen to your precept discussion if you have time to get to them!
Great class. Loved it. Take it.
Great course, very interesting and not a bad setup with work. Precepts are enjoyable and you get to go into a lot of detail with the characters of these great ancient plays, which is fun.
Great course. Well worth taking!

I think mythology is something every educated person should know. This course teaches you the basics. You should read and understand the material before the lectures/precepts to get the most out of them.

I would definitely encourage students to stay up to date with the reading. As long as you don't fall behind, lectures will be interesting and you'll be well prepared for the tests and term paper. In addition, I found that posting discussion posts early and reading other students' posts prior to precept helped me get more from the discussion.
I would recommend this course to anyone interested at all in Classics

I would recommend this course to anyone interested in the subject matter, anyone in the department, or anyone looking for a distribution requirement who may be unsure of which course to take. This seemed like it would be enjoyable and manageable for a student in any discipline while offering those more familiar with the material or the department the opportunity to delve into the texts more deeply.
I would strongly recommend this course to anyone with interest in mythology. However, some people with little background in ancient literature seemed a bit lost in precepts.
I would take it- the topic is interesting, and it is taught well.
If it's with Feeney take it.
If you are interested in mythology this is a very interesting course. The readings are engaging and I feel like I learned a lot. The weekly ID quizzes are a bit tedious to study for though.
If you like mythology, you should take this class. It's really really fun to have reading myth be your homework. If Feeney's teaching it, he's amazing, he has this wonderful British wit.
If you're hesitating about whether or not to take this class, take it. This was the best surprise I had in my academic year.
Interesting class to take as an introduction to classics.
It is well worth it if you enjoy mythology.
It's an interesting course, but make sure that you are familiar with the IDs on Blackboard to do well.
Keep up with the readings.

Please take this class; you will not regret it at all! Prof. Feeney is an amazing lecturer and the readings are not overwhelming and the whole class is so engaging that you don't even realize you're doing work!
Take if you like mythology and don't mind reading a couple plays a week.  The weekly quizzes are easy as pie and Feeney is an incredible lecturer.  Ginny Clark as preceptor is amazing.
Take it with an open mind, not just to fulfill a distribution requirement. Do all the readings.
Take only if you have a strong interest.
Take this course even if you have no previous knowledge. It provides a wonderful background to common-known myths that you think you already know.
Take this course!

Take this course. It was wonderful and a great opportunity to learn about the ancient world through mythology and literature. It is surprising how much of the information is relevant to every day life and Feeney is an excellent professor.
Take this course. It's an easy LA for engineers and it's actually incredibly interesting.
Take this if you want to learn the wonders of Heracles and cool things like that!
The course was overall pretty good but more work than I was expecting.

The readings can sometimes be hard to initially engage in (because of antiquity), but they are enjoyable if you are curious about the material. While there is a lot of reading, the lack of writing evened it out. Come to precepts prepared with a point of view to help discussion.

This class is amazing. You learn so much about mythology, and its role in culture, history, and communication. The class load is not overwhelming and will not interfere with any of your other classes.
This class was awesome. The amount of reading was cumbersome, but the material was very interesting, lectures and precepts were great. Take it!

This is an excellent course especially to fulfill a distribution requirement. The material is interesting, and there is not a lot of class time. However, there is a lot of reading that you have to keep up with. Professor Feeney is extremely knowledgeable, and I was lucky to have him as my preceptor.
When reading the materials, always try to identify the themes and significance.
descrip: An introduction to the classical myths in their cultural context and in their wider application to human concerns (such as creation, sex and gender, identity, transformation, and death). The course will offer a who's who of the ancient imaginative world, study the main ancient sources of well known stories, and introduce approaches to analyzing modern myths.

title: Introduction to Early Sufism (ca. AD 800-AD 1200)
reviews: Awesome class.
Definitely take it.

Do not hesitate to take this course! One gains so much from it if one puts in the work. Professor Barry is a phenomenal lecturer, seamlessly connecting his ideas but effectively emphasizing the main points that you need to know. It's definitely one of the best classes I've taken at Princeton.
Everyone who wishes to better understand universal fundamentals, Oriental cultures, or the development of modern religion should take the course.
Meet Professor Barry outside of class! He is great to talk to.
STRONGLY recommend this course, if only to sit in the Professor's seminars.
Take it!
Take it! Unless you need a strict, planned out syllabus.
Take this and engage it.
This course is ideal if you know next to nothing about Sufism and want to learn more.
This is a course unlike anything else you will take at Princeton. Please be sure to take this course, and if you do not, you MUST take a course with Professor Barry.
prepare to be mind blown
take it
descrip: Popularized through translations of world-famous poets like the 13th-century Rumi, the Sufi mystical strain pervaded Islamic culture for a thousand years and played a major historic role in furthering friendly relations between Muslims and other religious communities through endorsement of spiritual tolerance. This two-term course examines Sufism's origins, growth, social role, guiding ideas, impact on Islamic literature, and even on medieval European thought as filtered through Spain, and the profound but controversial influence of the Spanish-Muslim Ibn `Arabi (1165-1240) as far as India.

title: Society and the Witch
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Beginning Studies in Acting: Scene Study
reviews: Absolutely take it! Especially with Tracy.

Don't take this course in order to get "an easy A". For one thing that is not necessarily the case. Take this course because you want to be there. You will not get very much out of it if you take it for any reason other than that.
Good class! I would recommend it for anyone who wants to take a unique class.
Have an open mind, and be willing to take risks, and you'll get a lot out of this class.

I definitely enjoyed taking it, but make sure you don't approach it as less important than other classes. It may have had less work than my other courses, but the assignments do take a good deal of time and thought to prepare properly.
I loved it. It was always a nice break from the rest of my schedule, and definitely worked well as a fifth class, although the five hours in studio is a lot.
It is a fun course and a chance to channel your creative side, but if you're not that interested in theater or have no experience it may not be for you.
It's a fun course. But I don't think it provides a solid enough foundation for acting in the future
Really listen!

Take it with Tracy Bersley and never regret it. It's not an academic class in any traditional sense of the world, but it's probably more rewarding than any traditional course. The first few class sessions might scare you, but DO NOT DROP IT. Again, make sure you take it with Tracy. I've heard very sketchy things about the other professor (Suzie) and from more than one person.
Take it! It's a lot of fun and you will improve as an actor remarkably.
Take the course, just not with Suzy. She'sa nice enough person, I just didn't like her teaching style (not even talking about her acting technique here).
Take this course! It's a great class, Tracy is great, and it's a great break from everything else that's stressful in your life.

This class is literally AMAZING. Tracy was so fabulous. And please, don't feel like you have to have any acting experience when you come into the class. It is a really welcoming environment, and everybody has something to contribute. Take it!

This class will boost your acting skills, provide you with a new perspective on theater, and will generally be a fun experience. However, be prepared to receive subjective criticism and arbitrary grades.

This course is absolutely fantastic, and truly excels in helping novice students make the leap from demonstrative acting to emotionally genuine character portrayal. Tracy Bersley is a  fantastic teacher and a wonderful person who makes every class a   joy. If she is still around, take it with her.
This was my favorite class this semester, I would strongly recommend taking it.

Tracy Bersley is an amazing teacher.  If you have any spark of interest in acting, take this course!  I had done a fair amount of acting before, and after the first class, I was on the fence about whether to stay in the course, but I'm so glad I did.
You get out what you put in.
prereqs: Open Enrollment during April & May 2012 student course enrollment dates. Then for September 2012: Enrollment by permission of instructors during the first two weeks of classes..
descrip: An introduction to the craft of acting through scene study monologues and, finally, a longer scene drawn from a play, to develop a method of working on a script. Emphasis will be placed on honesty, spontaneity, and establishing a personal connection with the scene's substance.

title: The Energy Water Nexus
reviews: Definitely worth taking.
Get your flowsheet done early and start the project early. Homework is not bad at all.  If you know Aspen, you are well ahead of the curve.

If you have interest in the subjects of energy and climate, you should take this course. It is well taught, and its themes are very relavent to the fields of energy and water management in the years to come.
Take it. It's not a bad class, and it will only get better as it's offered more.
Take this course!
This is a great course if you are interested in energy and environmental issues. The final project is a lot of work, but you design a power plant so end up with a very satisfying end product.
prereqs: Prior completion of a course in thermodynamics is required. It is also desirable for students to have taken CBE 245 (An Introduction to Chemical Engineering Principles), CBE 250 (Separations), CEE 303 (Introduction to Environmental Engineering), and/or MAE 427 (Energy Conversion and the Environment). This course is designed primarily for CBE or MAE majors but open to all majors..
descrip: Students will gain an awareness of challenges to sustainable water and energy and inter-linkages between these. Energy-water design trade-offs will be investigated for various energy and water processing facilities, e.g., electric power or desalination plants. Students will participate in a design and simulation project to analyze water and energy balances for selected processes. Lectures will include review of relevant unit operations, tools/methods for lifecycle environmental and economic analysis, and discussion of contemporary issues where the energy-water nexus plays a critical role.

title: Selected Topics in Solid-State Electronics - Physics & Technology of Low-Dimensional Semiconductors
descrip: A broad overview of materials science and physics of low-dimensional semiconductor structures will be presented. Emphasis will be on the fabrication and physics of high-mobility carrier systems in modulation-doped structures. Examples include two-dimensional, one-dimensional (quantum wire), and zero-dimensional (quantum dot) systems.

title: Intermediate Hebrew I
prereqs: HEB 102 or Placement Test..
descrip: Reinforcement and expansion of reading, oral, aural, and writing skills through maximum student participation, exclusive use of Hebrew in the classroom, and coverage of remainder of basic grammar. Readings of graded selections from prose, poetry, and newspapers, and viewing and discussion of Israeli films and television programs open a window on Israel and its culture.

title: Mechanics and Waves
reviews: Even if you didn't like 103/105, take this to learn a different, fascinating approach to mechanics!
Hopefully, Bialek is not teaching this course again. After the reviews, he better not be. Take 205 for a more enriching experience.
I would recommend this course; the subject matter is interesting, and if Professor Bialek is teaching his lectures are very good.
It was the first time Bialek took this course, so it was fairly disorganized. If he continues teaching it, it will probably be more organized from the future, and he is a great teacher.
Its an interesting course. I'm not sure how well I'll be prepared though.
Only take this class if you really like physics. It is much more fundamental that 103-106, and requires a much greater time commitment.
Professor Bialek is a boss.
Sorry, unless it's a departmental or you have a strong interest in the material, I wouldn't recommend it.

Take death mech. Better yet, switch out of PHY (into MAT or CHM.. or COS ....anything fun). Random variable grading. No unified goal of the course (seems like filler). One of the TAs was never around, getting in touch with the professor was tough sometimes too.
Take time on the problem sets.  Ask a lot of questions.
This course is easier than 205, but you definitely don't get as good of an understanding of classical mechanics.
This is a challenging course, but if you are very careful and devote a lot of time to the problem sets, you will succeed! Lagrangians and Hamiltonians are very helpful in your future work in physics!
This is a course on "Things Bialek Finds Interesting", which may make it easier than Death Mech, but also much more infuriating. Beware.
This is probably not a class for people not already interested in physics and going into something in the sciences. But for people who are, I would recommend this class
Try to learn the material for the gain in understanding of the world rather than for the grade. It's theoretically interesting stuff.

Was excited by the prospect of Bialek teaching, but did not enjoy his teaching style. Too abstract, literally did no concrete problems. Lecturing was discursive and it was easy to get lost just before an important idea. Wait for someone else to teach it.
take it
try another professor
prereqs: PHY103 and PHY104 or PHY105 and PHY106; one 200-level math course; or instructor's permission..
descrip: This course covers wave phenomena, both classical and quantum, and it also includes an account of special relativity and introductory aspects of statistical physics. Topics include: special relativity, Lagrangians, small oscillations, coupled oscillations and waves, wave-packets and the Schrodinger equations, and elements of statistical mechanics. Mathematical methods will be developed as appropriate, in parallel to physical concepts.

title: Microsociology: Social Interaction
descrip: Social Interaction, particularly when conducted face-to-face, is highly complex and lends itself to competing methodological approaches. This course will review research on informal and institutional talk; non-verbal behavior including gesture and facial expression; emotion displays; task groups and decision-making; social network effects on interaction; proximity and co-presence; and computer-mediated interaction. Throughout we will consider the insights provided by assorted quantitative and qualitative approaches, including conversation analysis and ethnomethodology, ethnography, and the statistical analysis of coded data.

title: Musical Modernism 1890-1945
reviews: ABSOLUTELY TAKE IT! Even if you don't like modern music!
Attend all the lectures because they are all amazing!
I think it's a lot of fun.
I would highly recommend this course to another student. It's great!
If you are interested in the subject you will like it.
If you are interested in this period of music, and can tolerate sometimes highfalutin music philosophies, this is a class for you.
If you have any interest at all in music, you must take this course.
If you have interest in any music from this time period you should take this course.
Interesting material, but it's a good thing I PDFed this class...
Really interesting!
Take this even if you can't read music! But you should probably really like classical music.
Takes quite a bit of time, but if you're at all interested in music or the philosophy of modernism, take it!!! Very interesting course.
The music is incredible and Simon Morrison is the man. A basic theory background is helpful.
This course is fantastic for those with some interest in the period. Morrison is an absolutely wonderful and knowledgable lecturer, and really makes the material come alive.
This is a great course. Morrison is a great lecturer. Take it if you have interest in the era (which is fascinating, incidentally).
This is an excellent course.  There is a bit of reading, but you can get by if you have to just skim a few of them, and there's a lot of deep material that make you really think about music!
This was my first music history course, and it was amazing. Simon Morrison is an awesome professor - take anything with him. Take this course!!
Yeah... if you don't care about music, probably a bad idea :)
realize that music from this class is (mostly) not to be enjoyed...but understood and put into context.
descrip: This course is an overview of modernism in European and Euro-American art music, including movements such as symbolism, expressionism, and neoclassicism. We will listen to music of-among others-Bartok, Berg, Copland, Debussy, Ives, Mahler, Milhaud, Satie, Schoenberg, Scriabin, Stravinsky, and Varese. Topics will include introduction to a wide variety of musical languages and forms, as well as different cultural contexts for music making (music and ethnicity, music's relation to other art forms such as dance and visual art, music and politics).

profs.name: Esther Roseli da Costa Azevedo Meyer

title: French Theories of Space, 1920s-1970s
descrip: Drawing heavily on the work of Henri Lefebvre, this seminar focuses on French architects, thinkers, and groups who engaged with representations of space and challenged the institution of architecture. Whether they framed their views in terms of utopia, dystopia, interpellated geographies of empire or the colonization of everyday life, Le Corbusier, Bataille, Debord, Foucault, Perec, and others spearheaded a revolution in our ways of conceptualizing space.

title: Theory of Computation
reviews: A very interesting subject for those who like a little more math and theory.

Good course to take if you're interested in or think you may be interested in theoretical computer science. If you already have a strong proof-based background, then the class will be fairly easy compared to other math classes and not much work. Otherwise, you may find the class to be more of a struggle since everybody in the class is pretty good and does well on their homeworks

If you like theory, take this -- the topics covered are fun, and you get to write about whatever you want (almost) for the final paper. Problem sets are not overly difficult, but require some careful thought. Make sure to word your solutions VERY precisely (as should be the case for all theory courses).

If you're interested in the material, this is a great course. (i.e. If you liked the week on Turing Machines in 340.) The lectures aren't always super engaging, but are generally good. The problems sets can be tricky, but are still interesting to think about.
Read the book. You should not take the course if you do not like proving things.
Read the material, start working on the problem sets early.

The lectures for this class were not amazing - they could actually be quite disorganized. However, the material in the class is fantastic - both interesting mathematically and philosophically. The problem sets and the book are great - worth taking the class just for them.

The student would have to be somewhat motivated to be able to enjoy this course. The material is challenging since it's abstract, but it's 'realistic' enough that the student must think of plausible algorithms.
prereqs: COS 340/341 or equivalent mathematical maturity..
descrip: Studies the limits of computation by identifing tasks that are either inherently impossible to compute, or impossible to compute within the resources available. Introduces students to computability and decidability, Godel's incompleteness theorem, computational complexity, NP-completeness and other notions of intractability.This course also surveys the status of the P versus NP question. Additional topics may include: interactive proofs, hardness of computing approximate solutions, cryptography, and quantum computation. Two lectures, one precept. Prerequisite: COS 340/341 or instructor's permission.

title: Transportation Systems Analysis
reviews: Definitely take this course, just keep in mind that projects always seem to take longer than you expect
I would recommend this class. Take it if you like Kornhauser.
Kornhauser is very interesting and engaging.

RUN, RUN AWAY!!!! Run as fast as you can to a computer and delete ORF 467 from your course list and from all of your friends' course lists too actually. I don't care if you've heard Kornhauser is a good teacher, this class was so poorly organized that all the programmers in class pulled several all nighters and all the "non programmers" either were very lost and tried to do something, or did barely anything. If you like to spend multiple weeks on excruciatingly tedious data analysis on data that was flawed to begin with, and throw it away because the professor changes his mind on a whim about what he wants or gives you a scathing criticism and orders you to fix it as soon as possible, then go ahead. You probably deserve this class. If you enjoy learning rather than debugging code and spending all your time in a computer cluster, run away. I understand how Professor Kornhauser may be a fun teacher in other classes, but trust me.... this class is different.

TAKE THIS COURSE.  This is the first time I actually got a chance to do "research" (in terms of a significant academic project) so if you are looking to that AS PART OF A CLASS, you should take this course.  This has really taught me how to build a framework around research problems and inspired me to pursue other projects in the future.
Take this course if you are interested in the material and are willing to spend a great deal of time on the assignments, which can be difficult and poorly explained, but still very interesting.

The course description does not say that COS is a pre-req for this course.  However, on the first day of class the professor asked each of us about our experience and said that we would be okay if we didn't really have any. This was only partially true, especially when it came to the final project.  So programming experience is useful so that you will be able to make substantial contributions.
The final project is interesting but time-consuming.

This class is extraordinarily disorganized; you will do minimal work for most of the semester and then pull all-nighters in the last few weeks. If you take it, get to know Kornhauser personally because he's brilliant and a really interesting man. Only take it if you're willing to deal with his antics, though.

take it if you like Kornhauser.  He really cares about the students (comes back at 4:30 am to check on a project's status - you won't get that dedication anywhere else).  The class is not super structured which is fine, since he's awesome.
prereqs: ORF 245 or permission of instructor..
descrip: Studied is the transportation sector of the economy from a technology and policy planning perspective. The focus is on the methodologies and analytical tools that underpin policy formulation, capital and operations planning, and real-time operational decision making within the transportation industry. Case studies of innovative concepts such as "value" pricing, real-time fleet management and control, GPS-based route guidance systems, automated transit systems and autonomous vehicles will provide a practical focus for the methodologies. Class project in lieu of final exam focused on major issue in Transportation Systems Analysis.

title: International Organization
descrip: Why do states establish institutions and what determines their design and evolution? Do these institutions merely reflect underlying power and interests? The course will introduce theories of international institutions, evaluate critical perspectives, and examine applications in security, economic, and environmental policy areas.

title: Information Security
reviews: A great general COS course. No reading, good problem sets.
A very interesting course. Professor Felton is one of the best lecturers in the school.
Absolutely take it! Ed Felten is an amazing lecturer, Josh Hug is a great preceptor/TA, and the lectures/assignments are both fantastic.
Absolutely take this course if you can. Everything is just top-notch.
Brush up on your linux skills.
Dear God, take it.  Just take this course.  Please.
Definitely recommend this course very highly, it is incredibly interesting through and through, and Prof. Felten exudes awesomeness from his ears. That is all.
Definitely take it.
Definitely take it. Ed Felten's lectures are great, the assignments are worthwhile, and get easier overall as they go.
Do it. It's really fun and not that much work, and you learn a lot.
Don't just take this course because of its famed infrequency; make sure you're really interested in the material.
Fantastic class!
Fantastic course. It's a privilege to pick Ed Felton's brain about security. Balance of practical and theoretical, entertaining, Josh Hug is the best AI ever.
Fascinating material, excellent lectures.
Felten is fantastic.  The assignments are fun.  Material is not difficult to grasp.  A must-take course.
Good course. Take it if you can.
Great course
Great course! Definitely recommend.
Great lectures, light workload, difficult to get an A
Great, interesting class! High-level approach.

I can't say enough good things about this class. It was by far the least time consuming of my COS departmentals, the material is fascinating, and the assignments are fun. If you're on the fence, definitely take it!
I would highly recommend this course. Great lecture, interesting material

If this fits your schedule, take this course, no questions about it!  Not only is it fascinating to just about everyone, but it's well taught even beyond the standards of the COS department.  And an opportunity to learn from Professor Felten shouldn't be missed.
This class had 3 programming assignments, 2 design (team) assignments, 2 design review (team) assignments, and 1 hacking assignment (also team).  The first two programming ones and the hacking one are time-consuming.

If you are a COS major (or just someone with an interest in security who can program) definitely take this course. It is extremely well taught, and (I assume) some of the kinks in the assignments will be worked out in the future.

This class is best it you sign up for it with friends you can work in a group with, since most assignments are group assignments.

If you do nothing else with your life take this class. Professor Felten is an incredible lecturer. As someone who routinely falls asleep in their classes I had no problem paying attention. The assignments are challenging but reasonable and fun.
If you have any interest at all in computer science, take this class.  It's one of the best classes I have ever taken at Princeton.  When doing

If you have any interest at all in cryptography or information security, I would strongly recommend you take this course. It is a very easy workload. The first three assignments are individual, and take several hours to complete, but all subsequent assignments are very interesting, open-ended group assignments that can take however much time your group is willing to spend on them. Not only is it a relatively easy course, but it is definitely one of the more interesting courses. I took operating systems and cos 445 concurrently with this class, and this had by far the best ratio of enjoyment/satisfaction to work put in. Take this course! :)
It's very interesting. I recommend you take it if you like computer science.
Make sure to take this class with a friend because there are lots of group assignments.
Must take it!
Not a very demanding course. You learn some very interesting things, if you're into computer science or technical policy. Felten is great.
Probably one of my favorite courses at Princeton
Really great survey of all sorts of issues in security.  Professor Felten really knows his stuff and has tons of real world stories from his work at the FTC to regale you with.
TAKE THIS CLASS. TAKE IT.
Take good notes during lecture, start early on assignments.
Take it as an applications for sure!
Take it!

Take it! Fairly light workload, interesting stuff, and good lectures. Professor Felten is great. Only issue is that it's a survey of many topics, so if you've read up on some of them independently you won't get as much out of it.
Take it! Felten is the man, and the assignments teach you a surprising amount about security
Take it! It's not too time consuming and Felten is amazing
Take it! The assignments, especially the last, are interesting and enjoyable even when frustrating
Take it, please. It is one of the best courses at Princeton.
Take it.
Take it. A lot of nonmajors take it too, and in-depth understanding of computer science concepts is not a prerequisite.
Take it. It's only taught once every two years.
Take it. The class should seriously be renamed "Ed Felten is a Boss". He's awesome.
Take this class and learn computer security from the best!
Take this class!  Well taught and well run, and a little less work than comparable classes.  Sometimes can be more about common sense than detailed computer science.
Take this class.
Take this course if Ed Felten is teaching. Even if you don't think you're interested, try it. A must for all CS majors.
Take this course if you're a COS major, COS certificate person, or think it would be interesting.
Take this course if your interested in information/cyber security.
Take this course!!! Definitely one of my favorite courses at Princeton so far.
Take this. No question. Do not hesitate. Felten is a god.
This course is a good introduction to security, so take it if you need to learn the basics. Don't expect a lot of programming...most of the assignments are written reports.

This course is great, and Ed Felten is one of the best lecturers at Princeton. Consistently interesting, clear, and relevant, and on top of that, not that much more work to add to your schedule. If you have the opportunity and background to take this course, it would be silly not to.

This is a great class to take if you're interested to learn more about information security. It won't have the same mathematical rigor as a cryptography class, and the second half feels more like a humanity class than a computer science one. If this doesn't bother you (or if, like me, it actually makes you more interested in the class), then you should consider taking it.
This is a great course. I'd recommend it if you have any interest in the subject, even if you feel like you don't know anything about it.

This is a very good course to gain general knowledge on information and computer securty; I would almost consider this a sort of survey course. However, if the other student is looking for a more detailed discusson about specific topics covered in the course such as crypto or network security, then the student is better off taking a course in that specific topic. I would also point out that the homeworks in this course aren't programming-heavy but rather focus on making the students design secure computer/information systems and evaluate other students' designs.

This was a very good course, and I would definitely recommend it to any COS major or student with a general interest in the subject matter.  The assignments are a lot of fun and are not particularly difficult or time-consuming, so it's probably on the easier side of upper-level COS courses.
Very cool, minimally time-consuming course.
Very interesting course, not such a heavy work load, just make sure you go to lecture.
You'll need to spend a lot of time looking at Information Security outside of lectures to really enjoy it.

attend every lecture. Make sure you get a full score in each assignment. Make sure you practice with practice finals enough to be in that mindset. Make sure you have a good enough team that doesn't neglect this class just because they are taking some other more intense departmental like OS, cuz then either you'll have to do or the work or you'll end up doing badly on the assignments. Overall, good applications departmental course.
meh.  sure.
prereqs: COS 217 and COS 226..
descrip: Security issues in computing, communications, and electronic commerce. Goals and vulnerabilities; legal and ethical issues; basic cryptology; private and authenticated communication; electronic commerce; software security; viruses and other malicious code; operating system protection; trusted systems design; network security; firewalls; policy, administration and procedures; auditing; physical security; disaster recovery; reliability; content protection; privacy.

title: Consequentialism
descrip: A graduate seminar on consequentialism. See the syllabus for a provisional list of topics to be discussed.

title: Intermediate German
reviews: Definitely if you are interested in German. It's work the work!
Definitely take it.
Don't read to comprehend. Try to do some critical thinking about the pieces beforehand, so that class discussions are more productive for you.
Go to office hours! Ask for help if you need it.
Take this course if you are interested in learning German. Manageable workload, useful grammar, reasonable assignments.
This class is fun! Your German definitely improves a lot, so it is well worth it!

This course is by no means a breeze unless you're a native German speaker, but is totally worth it if you're looking to expand your lingual abilities beyond the basic level. It's an easily manageable amount of work each week, but will require some thinking and effort.
prereqs: GER 102 or permission of instructor.
descrip: Develops deeper proficiency in all areas (cultural understanding, production skills, and receptive skills), using a combination of language-oriented work and cultural/historial content, including film and texts.

title: War and Politics in the Modern Middle East
reviews: Be prepared to actually do 300 pages of reading a week and to sustain a high level of discussion; most people already have a background in the subject. This is a very interesting class, though.
Expect more reading than you have ever done.
Highly recommended for any student interested in contemporary history, public policy, international relations or regional studies.
Must-take for anyone interested in the modern history of the middle east!

Probably the best course I've taken at Princeton so far.  The other students will likely be very knowledgeable and passionate about the topic, so bring your A game to the seminars.  Try to do the readings, but they are often 300  pages/week.  Extremely interesting and well-structured class about the evolution of warfare in the last 60 years or so, using case studies from the Middle East

Read all the required readings. It may seem daunting at first, but divide it over the week. There's a crucial difference that shows during class discussions between the students who have actually done the reading, and those who haven't.

This class begins with a study of the definitions of war, and then studies wars in the Middle East as case studies. The reading is very heavy, but the understanding you gain both of the theoretical aspects of warfare and of basic modern Middle-Eastern history is unbeatable. Highly Recommend.

You should definitely take this course if you're at all interested in the subject matter. Prior knowledge of the region is not necessary, but absolutely make sure you do all the reading. For one, it's all interesting, and for two you definitely need it for class.
prereqs: Although exposure to strategic thought and/or Middle Eastern history may be useful, there are no prerequisites..
descrip: Drawing on case studies of Middle Eastern wars, this course examines the changing nature of warfare from the second half of the twentieth century through the present day. The course begins with Clausewitz's theory of war and examples of conventional state warfare in the Middle East. It then moves on to cases of insurgency and so called fourth generation warfare and uses them to test Clausewitz's ideas and less state-centric alternatives. The goal of the course is to compel students to think seriously and critically about war and the ways in which it is and is not changing in the twenty-first century.

title: Introductory Logic
reviews: A solid intro to logic, although class isn't always stimulating.

An awesome class! You will learn lots and really get a nice mental workout. Both classes and precepts were interesting. Problem sets were lengthy but there are only five of them throughout the semester. The curve will be cutthroat in this class since everyone does so well, so good luck!
Do not take unless you are prepared to try with all your might to find interesting aspects of this course.
Do the ungraded p-sets if possible.
Don't take unless you're a genius
I really enjoyed the class. Doing logic is fun and the class was not overwhelming.
I'd probably recommend taking it when Dasgupta is not teaching it. Good.

Just go to lecture and work a little bit on the class each week (do the ungraded problem sets, they take like 20 minutes), and you will do great. Ignore it and you'll do terribly. Grading is kind of erratic -- you may get the same amount off for a big mistake or making a small one.
Keep up with the readings.
Only take this course if you're a huge fan of mathematical proofs. That's really all there is to say on the matter.
PSets.
Take it if you are interested in logic!
Take this course if you're looking for a chill, relatively easy fifth course.
Yeah, go for it.
descrip: Logic is the study of the principles of valid reasoning. This course provides an introduction to symbolic logic, which studies the principles of valid reasoning from an abstract point of view -- paying attention to the form of valid arguments rather than their subject matter. We will cover the basic concepts and principles of symbolic logic: validity, logical truth, truth-functional and quantificational inference, formal languages and formal systems, axiomatic and deductive proof procedures.

title: Food Matters
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: The Classical Roots of Western Literature
reviews: Allot several hours during the week specifically for reading for COM 205.

Be prepared for a lot of reading, and don't take it unless you are willing to put in some effort. However, even as a non-humanities student, I found the material really fascinating, and I am glad that I took the class. Learn how to read faster than I do.
Be prepared to do the reading and don't leave it for the last day.
Certainly take this course with Daniel Heller-Roazen. The readings are important for everyone, and he presents the material thoughtfully and helpfully.
Definitely take this if you are interested in any of the readings.

Don't take this course if you're concerned about grades. It's definitely not an easy A. The professor is brilliant, but not always engaging or approachable. If you do take the course, don't be discouraged by grades but really try to engage with the texts and learn from the experience.

I wish I would not have taken this course my freshman year except for its reassurance that I do not like English courses. If you take the course, you might want to talk to your professors more than I did.

I'd definitely recommend this course to other students, but I would warn them that there is a substantial amount of reading that the class entails, so for those who don't enjoy reading, this might not be the right class to take.
It helps to have a background in classics and translations. You should take this class only if you are really interested in the material, because the readings are challenging and long.
It's very very good. DHR is a great lecturer. The readings are hefty however, although the selections are excellent.
Keep up with the reading; while it may appear that one can skip some readings without any repercussions, doing so would result in getting much less out of the class.

One of the best classes I've taken at Princeton. A lot of reading, but incredible lectures--and take it as a senior! I think the influence of the classical works you read is much more apparent after four years of academic study.
Professor Heller-Roazen is a great lecturer (and preceptor). The reading list is great and he presents the material in such an interesting way. Take the course.
Space out your reading throughout the week -- you can't read a couple hundred pages of Herodotus or the like in one afternoon.
Take it - a liberal arts education is incomplete without it.
Take it only if you will enjoy reading the books. Don't assume that this class will be palatable to everyone just because it involves the classics.

Take it. DHR is one of the greatest lecturers you will ever meet. He's absolutely brilliant; going to class and hearing him talk is a treat. Be warned, though: you get out of this class what you put into it. The more you engage with the texts on your own and in precept, the more rewarding it will be. Otherwise, it can be painful.
Take this course if you are at all into literature.
Take this course if you need a classical background in literature or if you are interested in this area, but be warned about the volume of readings. It gets tedious.
The reading load each week is a lot, so if you have a heavy work load already take this course when you think you will have the time to do the reading each week.
descrip: An introduction to comparative literature, this course will investigate the many forms of cultural transmission: literary, historical, intellectual, political, religious. Readings of major works of the Greek, Roman, Arabic, and European traditions. From Greeks and barbarians to the Library of Alexandria, the foundation of Rome, the sacred texts of Christianity and Islam, and the traditions of learning in medieval Europe, we shall examine the different ways in which pagan, Jewish, Christian and Muslim cultures of Europe and the Near East have understood themselves as products of transmission.

title: Introductory Painting
reviews: Do it because you love it!! It does require work and time, but if you put yourself into it, it goes by really quickly! Plus, you get painting you can be proud of!
Excellent course, Eve is an excellent instructor. Class time and time spent on assignments adds up though.

I would strongly recommend this course not only to beginner painters but also rather experienced ones. The workload is not easy, but the assignments are given in quite a range of subjects so you will never be bored. Also, the final project is a very exciting opportunity to display the skills you attained in the course.
If you have the time (also to spend time in the studio beside class time), definitely take this class. It is so much worth it and you will learn to see differently!
If you take this course, be prepared to put a lot of extra time in the studio. If you do not love painting, I would not suggest taking this class.
It's a huge time commitment, but you'll be better at painting by the end.
It's definitely a LOT of work  time commitment
My advice to future students would be to make sure you have time and are willing to put in time outside of class.  If you are able to do this, the course will be very rewarding for you.
Take it! take it. It's a huge amount of work, if you really want to get all you can out of it, but it's worth it. It teaches you entirely new ways to think about problems.

The course was very good. I had a wonderful experience with the professor and really felt that I learned something about painting and art as a whole. It really depends on who your teacher is. The class takes up a lot of time, but if you put effort into it you can come out feeling accomplished.
This course is very time consuming; do not take it if you are looking for an easy grade or easy class.
Time is of the essence - but take advantage of all the wonderful materials.
don't take it if you don't know how to paint
its a lot of hours outside class but its worth it if you enjoy painting.
descrip: An introduction to the materials and methods of painting. The areas to be covered are specifically color and its interaction, the use of form and scale, painting from a model, painting objects with a concern for their mass and its interaction with light.

title: Identity Politics
descrip: Graduate seminar on identity politics within the U.S. context; primary focus is on ethnic, racial and religious identities. Course tackles questions about when, why and to what extent ethnic, racial and religious identities take on significance in American politics. In doing so course examines theories of identity development and change; considers strategies for measuring identity; and assesses the standard empirical approach to studying identity in American politics. Course also explores how context, institutions and elections work to politicize identities under some conditions.

title: Writing an Effective Scientific Research Article (Half Term): Sci & Engineering
prereqs: Course open to graduate students who have completed sufficient research to begin writing a research article in any area of science or engineering..
descrip: Writing workshop for students in any area of quantitative research, including science and engineering, who are prepared to draft a research article for publication based on their original work. Topics include getting started, presenting data, communicating visually, understanding the elements of a research article, using evidence persuasively, revising effectively, soliciting useful comments from readers, and incorporating feedback. One 2-hour, 50-minute seminar.

title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Chemistry (Half-Term)
descrip: Discussion and evaluation of the role professional researchers play in dealing with the reporting of research, responsible authorship, human and animal studies, misconduct and fraud in science, intellectual property, and professional conduct in scientific relationships. Participants are expected to read the materials and cases prior to each meeting. Successful completion is based on regular attendance and active participation in discussion. This half-term course is designed to satisfy federal funding agencies? requirements for training in the ethical practice of scientists. Required for graduate students and post-docs.

title: Problems in Literary Study - Colonialism and Theories of the Novel
descrip: This course is an exploration of competing practices of the English novel within the context of colonialism. It is also a rethinking of the theories that have been developed to explain the emergence of the genre since the Eighteenth Century. Focusing on the rewriting of canonical works by postcolonial writers, we will read signature works from Defoe to Rushdie, exploring how colonial spaces mediated the form of the novel and its social spaces. Why and how did the culture of colonialism become constitutive of the aesthetic idealogy of the novel? How was the style of canonical novels maintained by experiences located in colonial outposts?

title: Introduction to South Asian Cultures
descrip: This course introduces core themes in culture and society in South Asia, with an anthropological focus. Topics include the religious traditions of South Asia (in particular, Hinduism, Islam); varied expressions of kinship, gender, and everyday life; and the influence of global forces on local practices. Emphasis will be on the modern period, with selective historical context highlighting recent forces of nationalism, communalism, and "modernity." A variety of films will be shown throughout the course.

title: Media Arabic I
prereqs: Successful completion of ARA 107 or the equivalent..
descrip: In this course, students will develop their skills in reading and listening to Arabic news media, including newspapers, magazines, websites, radio and satellite TV broadcasts (including BBC and al-Jazeera, among others). Attention will also be given to informal discussion of these subjects. Study will be arranged by subject matter: Meetings and conferences, demonstrations, elections, etc.

title: Islamic Family Law
reviews: Although it lacks in present day examples, the class does a very good job of explaining the Quranic side to family law and gives a good understanding of how Islamic law works in general.

If you are looking for an engaging seminar class, this is not it. That being said, I have learned a lot from the readings and some from Professor Modarressi's lectures during class. He doesn't ever go over 2.5 hours, so it's not as long as other classes, but it was one of the classes that I just powered through for the week. If I had to re-do this semester, though, I would not have taken this class, and instead substituted it with a more dynamic seminar.

This class can get a little mundane initially as you spend almost half a semester talking about Islam  and the topic of Islamic family law is discussed only after the mid-term. It is more of a lecture and less of a seminar, which was one of my biggest disappointments! I learnt a lot from this class but it is definitely not the best Islam-related class offered at Princeton.
descrip: This course examines the oulines of Islamic family law in gender issues, sexual ethics, family structure, family planning, marriage and divorce, parenthood, child guardianship and custody, etc. The course starts with a general survey of Islamic legal system: its history and developments, structure and spirit, and the attempts of the Muslim jurists to come to terms with the challenge of time.

title: Junior Independent Work
descrip: Subjects chosen by the student with the approval of the faculty for independent study. A written report, examination, or other evidence of accomplishment will be required.

title: Corporate Restructuring
reviews: An all around great course. Learned a lot without having to spend an inordinate amount of time doing it.
Go for it. Especially if you have any interest in M&A
I would recommend the course to anyone who is interested in finance, econ major or not.

If you have any interest in corporate finance or plan to ever work in a corporate finance related field, you must take this class. You will learn more practical knowledge and applications than in any other finance course at Princeton. The workload is somewhat substantial, as there are alternating weekly quizzes and assignments, but these force you to remain involved in the class which ensures you will learn a lot. Professor Sexton is an engaging lecturer, combining the perfect mix of theory, anecdotes, empirical results, and applications.
Interested in advanced corporate finance?If yes, take this class.
Problem sets are technical, but the rest of the class really isn't. Really not a huge burden on your time, and you will learn some interesting things on subjects related to corporate finance.
Start studying early and find a good working partner.
Take this - though be aware it is quite rigorous and requires a lot of work outside the classroom.
This class is the one applied finance class I have been able to find in four years here. If you are interested in working in finance rather than learning about finance theory, take this class!

This was a great course - one of the best I have taken at Princeton. I definitely learned the most in this course than in any other course I have taken. If you have the chance to take this course - definitely take it.
You get what you put into it.
prereqs: ECO 300 or ECO 310.
descrip: This course applies topics from microeconomics (ECO 310) and corporate finance (ECO 363) to study corporate restructuring. Topics include mergers, acquisitions, joint ventures, divestiture and share repurchases. Each of these is discussed in the context of the relevant economic theory, institutional and regulatory environment, and with a focus on shareholder value.

title: American Cinema
reviews:
1) TAKE IT!
2) Great films. All among the list of movies you need to see before you die (IMDB top 250, AFI top 100, etc).
3) The first couple lectures were a bit irrelevant (eg the history of Thomas Edison's film company, etc), but don't be put off. Professor Fuss will really impress you with her analyses and explanations of certain films. I really enjoyed getting up and going to lecture.
4) Papers were not all that bad and were actually enjoyable to write.
5) TAKE IT!
A fairly fun, light course that lets you watch a lot of really good films!
A little interesting, somewhat strange analysis occurs though.
Absolutely take it, and don't drop it if you're not excited by the first few films. My favorite class at Princeton so far.
Absolutely take this course. But choose a better movie at the end of the semester. Good Will Hunting!!
An enjoyable and interesting course. It was rather large, but the precepts were great.
At the very least, you will have seen some of the best films ever made by the end of the course.

Awesome course for filling an LA or med school requirement. You get to watch movies for homework. There's only 3 papers and they're not very long. If you're considering taking it, do so. Totally worth it.
Cool class. Take it.
DEFINITELY TAKE THIS COURSE.

Definitely take it for a good LA.  You get to watch 2 movies every week instead of readings or problem sets.  The papers kinda suck if you don't love formal film analysis, but they aren't very long and it's a small price to pay for getting to watch movies

Definitely take it!  It's a great class for an LA and it's pretty fun too.  You can't pdf it (or you couldn't this semester) but it's definitely not too stressful and the workload is not too much.  It's a fun class.
Definitely take this class!
Definitely take this course if you like watching movies and are interested in discussing films with others.
Definitely take this course!!  Go to all the lectures because they are all so interesting and make you think in a different way about movies that you may already love!
Definitely take this course.

Do it--and take advantage of her lectures. I appreciated the movies we watched, and film in general, so much more after taking this class, and hearing everything Prof. Fuss had to say. I don't know that I would have enjoyed the class as much if I hadn't attended every single lecture anticipating what I would learn, about cultural and historical context, the film's thematic statements, and the way the selected films have impacted modern cinema.
Don't get your hopes up

English majors and non-english majors alike, I would be comfortable taking this course if I were you. It's an amazing class to take, and the workload isn't too much, so if you have a heavy course load, you should feel comfortable taking this one as well to lighten the mood.
Fun, annoying that it doesn't allow p/d/f.
Fun, not too difficult class. You watch movies and don't write that much. What's not to like?
Go for it, but don't expect it to be as awesome as it sounds.
Go to lectures and watch the movies! Also, do the extra weekly assignments if your preceptor offers them. They aren't graded, but it's helpful.
Go to office hours if you're having trouble choosing a paper topic.
Good.
Great course, that was a lot of fun to take.
Great course. Highly recommend.
Great to learn more about cinematic techniques that will help you appreciate some really great movies.

I highly recommend taking this course.  The workload is really light, just watching movies, and it's super fun.  The lectures are absolutely amazing (with Fuss), and I looked forward to going to class always.
I highly suggest taking this course.
I really liked this course. It changed the way i approached about films and gets you thinking on a deeper level. Also, watching the movies are a great study break from other work!
I really recommend taking the course for anyone with even a slight interest in film. Professor Fuss was amazing in lectures, and especially if she is teaching the course, I strongly recommend.
I think this is a very fun and relatively easy class.  Would definitely recommend for those who don't like reading or struggle in reading heavy courses.

I would definitely suggest taking this class or any with Professor Fuss. She dives deep into the subject material and often provided film clips during class to supplement her lectures. I also liked that the class was able to choose the final movie that she lectured. I will say that it is a VERY large class and you can really make it as rigorous or relaxed as you want. Take this course!
I would highly recommend this course.
I would recommend this course in a heartbeat.
I would recommend this course to anyone. It is a good amount of work. It isn't just watching movies, there is work, but it is interesting.
I would recommend this course to anyone. It is so interesting and fun. I loved it. Diana Fuss' lectures are amazing. One of the best courses i have taken at Princeton.
I would recommend watching each movie before its allotted lecture.
I would take this class over again. It was fun and you can watch the movies with your friends!

If this course is offered again, take it. It is a fantastic window into American Cinema and is effective at teaching how one should view movies. It will change how you appreciate media, and Professor Fuss is astonishingly engaging during her lectures. They are very well prepared, relevant, and thought out. Take this course!
If you are able to take this class, you definitely should.  There is not a lot of work and it is pretty interesting material especially if you like movies.
If you are at all interested in movies, take it. Go to lectures and watch all the movies!
If you are interested in cinema- take it. It is very interesting. Be prepared for a wide range of movie types however
If you enjoy movies, take this course. It really gives students an opportunity develop a different style of analysis.
If you have any interest in film, take the class.
If you haven't seen the movies and want to force yourself to, do it, but don't expect a fascinating investigation into American cinema.
If you take it, make sure you have a good preceptor, I have heard some horror stories.
If you watch the movies, you will be fine.
If you would like to better understand movies, you should take it.
It is an interesting class. Watching movies for homework is nice, but because you can't PDF it, it isn't quite as nice.
It is non PDF able so make sure you are interested in movies and putting in effort on the papers. Either than that, it is an interesting class.
It was a really fun, interesting class that changed the way I'll watch movies from now on. The assignments were very reasonable, and the lectures were great.
It's great. The movies are long, especially during the second half of the course, but it's fascinating to learn about all of this.
Keep up to date with the movies and talk to the preceptors about every paper
Lectures weren't fantastic, but watching movies and discussing them in detail for credit is pretty awesome.
Make sure to meet with your preceptor before the essays, as they provided ample instruction and guidance for the assignments, and they are very willing to meet with you.
Make sure you like the majority of films on the list.
Make sure you watch the movies ahead of the lecture
Not a lot of work relative to some other classes, and very enjoyable to take. I would seriously recommend if you need the LA, have any interest, or want a good 5th class.
Not too hard, super interseting
One of the best classes at Princeton--definitely take it!!!
One of the best courses I have taken at Princeton.

Particularly if you haven't seen them before, the films in this class are very worthwhile.  Lectures may not be as engaging as the movies themselves, but the class is worth taking for the films alone.
Professor Fuss is a great lecturer. Take the class just to hear her speak! But otherwise this is a good class if you need a fifth class to take or just have a general interest in Hollywood films.
TAKE IT!!
TAKE IT.
TAKE THIS CLASS! It was one of the most interesting classes I've taken at Princeton, and Professor Fuss is a FABULOUS lecturer. Seriously. Take it.
TAKE. THIS. COURSE. It's fantastic.  One of my favorite classes by far!
THIS COURSE IS AMAZING. TAKE IT. EVERYONE SHOULD TAKE IT.
Take it
Take it and watch movies for homework!

Take it if you like movies, but it's no joke course.  Very relevant to understanding movie/pop culture.  You won't get much out of it unless you watch most of the movies.  Take the papers seriously and get help from your preceptor if you need it!
Take it if you love movies.
Take it take it take it. It's really interesting and It's not that hard.
Take it!
Take it! A great LA for non-majors, and a fun, easier course for majors.
Take it! Especially with Professor Fuss!
Take it! It's not a ridiculous amount of work, and yet the material is incredibly engaging.
Take it! Make sure you watch the films even if you have already seen them 3 years ago etc.
Take it! Professor Fuss is so knowledgeable, and you will come out of the class understanding the history of American Cinema and how to write and speak about film studies in a more academic way.
Take it! Super interesting, and unlike any other class here
Take it! Watch the movies - don't need to read the book.
Take it!!! It's unlike anything else offered at Princeton, and will make you think about movies in a whole new way.
Take it, great class.
Take it, it's pretty good.
Take it, no PDF, but yes it's worth it.
Take it.
Take it. All of the movies are influential to American cinema today. Plus, Professor Fuss offers hilarious analyses about the films.
Take it. It's a lot of fun.
Take it. Its interesting if you like movies and I found the grading fair and there were only a few assignments.
Take it. Its relatively easy and actually fun too.
Take notes on the films while watching.

Take the class!  It's not going to be something you can just breeze through -- it's important to watch the films carefully, spend time with the essays, and go to lectures -- but it's extremely interesting and rewarding.  Plus, your homework is to watch some of the best films in American history that's simply fantastic.
Take the course.  Great way to learn about American Cinema.
Take the course. You won't regret it.

Take this class if it's every offered again! Or take any class with Professor Fuss - she is amazing and delivers spectacular lectures.  Very engaging class, and you look at American films in a new light and are able to understand how they interact with society.  And not too much work either - I was never stressed about how I was doing in this class.  The papers give you a lot of freedom.  And watching movies every week is always fun, a nice variation to add to readings and psets!
Take this class if you enjoy watching movies and learning about them.
Take this class, its fun, despite three intra semester papers, and take it with friends to watch the movies with
Take this class--good movies, interesting lectures, and pretty straight forward assignments.
Take this class.
Take this class. Professor Fuss is awesome and the films that we watch are also great. I highly recommend this class
Take this course the movies are great and the lectures are interesting.
Take this course!
Take this course! Just remember that it isn't a blow off class!
Take this course.
Take this course. It is very interesting.
Take this! You'll never look at movies the same way.
The class is graded very hard!

The course material is entertaining. I mean, you get to watch FANTASTIC movies. But Prof. Fuss is neither an engaging nor insightful lectures. Her puns and attempted witticisms are painful at times, and you will feel like you are wasting your time if you actually expect insightful commentary and learning from the lectures. I recommend it as a joke class for the material and lectures, except that the graders grade very hard. It's a great class if you just want an excuse to watch the Classics.
The movies and lectures are great, I strongly recommend it if you have an interest in film.
There is not that much work and the movies are very interesting.

This is a great course to take!  Obviously, watching movies is really easy, so the work load is low.  We watched 2-3 movies a week, and there were 3 writing assignments throughout the semester.  The first was 1-2 pages, the second 4-5 pages, the third 6-7 pages.  My only criticism is that the quality of precepts seems rather inconsistent.
This is a great last course for people who are interested in film. The lectures were not the best but the precepts were terrific and the assignments were interesting and manageable.

This is a really enjoyable course and gives you exposure to some classic American films that you might not have an excuse to watch otherwise! Additionally, it teaches you how to critically analyze films. Definitely recommend, especially for those trying to get an english requirement out of the way.
Watch all the movies and go to all the lectures!
Watch classic movies and write a few papers. formula for success
Watch the films, even if they are long because the lectures will really give you new insight.
Watch the movies before lecture (you will get so much more out of it) and enjoy thinking about the films!
Watch the movies, or else you will get nothing out of this class.
Without a doubt take it. It is a nice breather from harder classes, and aside from the papers, the homework doesn't even feel like homework.
Yes
do it
go to every lecture
great class
incredibly interesting course. opens your eyes to things which you would never notice in some classic movies.
take it
take it, highly entertaining, really learn a lot about movies and american cinema
take it, its awesome and easy
take it. If you're someone who does not enjoy english classes, there really isn't a better way to get your LA requirement out of the way.
take it. the movies are all great films.
take this course.
take this!
descrip: This new film genre course addresses the cultural heritage of our national cinema. How has cinema shaped American culture, and how has American culture shaped cinema? We will focus on iconic figures in American film: cowboys, gangsters, detectives, soldiers, aliens, machines, lovers, orphans, monsters, teenagers. Each week will pair an early film with a later one to trace a given genre's evolution; for example, the week on westerns might pair John Ford's "The Searchers" (1956) with Ang Lee's "Brokeback Mountain" (2005). The course studies not art house films but commercial Hollywood films that serve as important barometers of their times.

title: Colloquium on the Biology of Populations
reviews: Attend all the seminars and ask questions. I feel as though this is an opportunity to get an unbiased opinion on your project, so consider how each presentation might pertain to your own research.

I would advise other students to take this course because it gives people the opportunity to see what other types of research are being pursued at other universities and in different disciplines outside of just your own research field.
descrip: Discussion of the central problems of population biology and approaches that have proved fruitful. Topics ranging throughout ecology, evolution, biogeography, and population genetics are usually related to presentations by visiting speakers and students. (This is a core course.)

title: Seminar in 17th-Century French Literature - Theatrum Mundi
descrip: This course seeks to present a series of literary variations on the early modern topos of "the world as a stage," from baroque plays of illusion and truth to classical representations of court society and the spectacle of power. While particular emphasis will be placed on comic and tragic drama, readings will also include narrative and moralistic works, as well as selected critical and theoretical texts. (In French.)

title: Advanced Creative Writing (Poetry)
reviews: I had a great time, and I think my writing improved significantly, so I'd certainly recommend the course.  (Caveat: Since it's a workshop, the experience depends a lot on who else is in the class.)

Laurie is incredible.  She is so knowledgeable of other poets and really encourages you to pursue poetry.  She baked for our class and showed us fantasic poetry youtube videos.  She truly cares about learning and I felt very supported and cherished. TAKE THIS CLASS
You get out of creative writing courses what you put into them. Make the time and commitment to make it worthwhile.
prereqs: Please visit the Lewis Center Creative Writing website for application information. Please note that this course cannot be audited..
descrip: Advanced practice in the original composition of poetry for discussion in regularly scheduled workshop meetings. The curriculum allows the student to develop writing skills, provides an introduction to the possibilities of contemporary literature and offers perspective on the places of literature among the liberal arts.

title: Asian American Literature and Cultures
descrip: This course studies the relationship between law and literature by focusing on the roles that Asian Americans played in US constitutional history. We will examine cases involving Asian Americans that reflect on American policies on citizenship, immigration, civil rights, human rights, and foreign policy, and we will explore novels, plays, poems, and films that respond to these cases. We will also consider the invisible ways in which the law shapes our every day lives: how it structures our feelings, bodies, spaces, and the sense of the quotidian.

title: Organometallic Chemistry
reviews: I'd recommend reading the handouts before going to class and try thinking of all the possibilities before answering a homework question.
Take very good notes. Think carefully about assignments. Come to precept prepared. Have an alternative reference for clarification of the material presented.
Try to read the handouts given BEFORE lecture.
read the handouts before coming to lecture.
prereqs: Open to senior undergraduates only, with permission of the instructor..
descrip: To familiarize the student with basic principles of structure and reactivity of transition metal organometallic chemistry.

title: Introduction to Classical Chinese I
reviews: I highly recommend this course for any student who wants to improve his or her modern Chinese while reading some of the foundational texts of the Chinese intellectual tradition.
