It is challenging and very rewarding--you will be able to read the Analects and Mencius within the semester. And the fact that the course is taught in Chinese rather than English will allow you to learn how one of the world's most ancient languages lives on in the modern day.
If you are comfortable learning lots of abstract knowledge in Chinese, take it. It will improve your language skills, but if you really want to learn the material, you have to put the time in.

If you're interested in the material, or want to lend depth to your knowledge of modern Chinese, I would highly recommend the course. Time commitment is considerable, but fairly steady... About an hour per day of preparation, as well as assignments that take an hour or two extra per week, and a test every week.
Make sure to study for the weekly tests- it really helps! This course will also be very helpful in personal readings of Chinese classics.
prereqs: CHI 107 or CHI 108 or instructor's permission.
descrip: Introduction to the grammar of classical Chinese through study of selections from ancient texts. Readings include the Analects and the Mencius

title: The Politics of Public Policy
descrip: An analysis of the forces that shape the behavior of public organizations and individuals in organizational settings. The emphasis is on the workings of U.S. governmental agencies. Special attention is given to writing skills as they apply to the roles of advisers and decision makers in public-sector organizations.

title: Urban Sociology: The City and Social Change in the Americas
reviews: As long as you don't mind political rantings, then the course was interesting and relevant to issues prevalent in today's society.
Awesome course. Great conversation in precept and the classroom. Don't leave Princeton without taking this course.
Certainly worth taking. PFK is an eccentric lecturer and there is a fair amount of reading but it is a good experience.

DO.NOT.TAKE.THIS.CLASS

seriously....no matter what

I recommend it. The workload is manageable, the professor is engaging (although you should be prepared for her possibly calling on you in lecture), and the content really important if you want to learn more about inequality and social policy.
In terms of required reading and assessments, this is an undemanding course. Take if you're interested in the topic but the quality of the precept discussion will make or break it.
Not too demanding, but could be complex and confusing at times.
Only take it if you enjoy PFK.
PFK loves her students and takes the time to get to know them by name.

Some people might find PFK's lectures difficult to follow, but the class is worth it for the wealth of readings. They really work to change your understanding of our cities and the way they've been shaped.
Take it if you like PFK.
Take it.
Very reasonable course with lower workload.  Great course to take for the URB certificate.
do the readings and participate in precept
take it
take it! easy to keep up and do work. lots of readings but easy to get the gist and keep moving along.
descrip: By taking a comparative approach, this course examines the role of social, economic, and political factors in the emergence and transformation of modern cities in the United States and selected areas of Latin America. We consider the city in its dual image: both as a center of progress and as a redoubt of social problems, especially poverty. Special attention is given to spatial processes that have resulted in the aggregation and desegregation of populations differentiated by social class and race.

title: Fans and Consumer Culture
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: The Fall Show
reviews: DO THE FALL SHOW!!!!!
Do it!! Your Princeton experience will be enriched if you get the opportunity to work with Tim Vasen

If Tim Vasen is directing the show this year, you should definitely audition. He's an amazing director. The show will take over your life though. The official four-hour meeting period for the class is a tiny fraction of the actual rehearsal time you'll have. But it is worth it if you're passionate about theatre because you will have a lot of fun, make great connections, work with really professional people and amazing resources and get to spend time watching Tim work.
If you are interested in any aspect of theater, doing the fall show at least once is a must.  You learn so much about what it means to work professionally as an actor.
If you like acting, do it. Especially if Tim is the director.
Take it! It is a great way to get theater in your life and get course credit for it.
Take it, regardless of what aspect of theater you're interested in!  Great opportunity for actors, great opportunity for techies.
prereqs: Please contact Professor Tim Vasen (tvasen@princeton.edu) for enrollment permission/further information..
descrip: The Fall Show provides students with a rigorous and challenging experience of creating theater under near-professional circumstances. A professional director, design team, and stage manager, as well as two weeks of performances in the Berlind Theatre, are key components.The Fall Show involves an extensive rehearsal period and a concentrated tech week,often requiring more time and focus than a typical student-produced production might. For the first time, students cast in the Fall Show, or those who take on major production roles (such as Assistant Stage Manager, Assistant Designer, or Assistant Director), will receive course credit.

title: Introduction to Historiography
descrip: The literature of art, architecture and archaeology in Europe until the late eighteenth century. Some sessions to be devoted to the Islamic World and East Asia. Later intrepretations, consequences, and relevance to other cultures will be considered.

title: Advanced Macroeconomics: Domestic Policy Issues
prereqs: WWS 512C.
descrip: This course is about the economics and some of the politics of central banking, especially monetary policy. Special emphasis is given to central banks as unique policymaking institutions and, especially, to the Federal Reserve System?although other central banks are mentioned frequently. Since the focus is on monetary policy, the course presupposes a working knowledge of the relevant macroeconomics, but particular aspects thereof are taught in the course. A great deal of attention is paid to the causes, consequences, and central bank behavior during and since the recent financial crisis.

title: Advanced Dynamics
descrip: Principles and methods for formulating and analyzing mathematical models of physical systems; Newtonian, Lagrangian, and Hamiltonian formulations of particle and rigid and elastic body dynamics; canonical transformations, Hamilton-Jacobi theory; and integrable and nonintegrable systems. Additional topics are explored at the discretion of the instructor.

title: Modern Microbiology and Disease
prereqs: MOL214, MOL 215 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course examines the modern field of molecular biology through the lens of bacteria, viruses and parasites, emphasizing the impact of microbes on everyday life. Topics will include pathogenesis (evolution of communicable diseases, molecular mechanisms of virulence, antibiotic resistance), microbial biology (cell division and differentiation, quorum sensing), and how microbes interact with their habitat (microbial diversity, biofilms, bioremediation, symbiosis).

title: Advanced German
reviews: Be prepared to work hard, but be rewarded for it...
For a language course, it's not too bad
I thoroughly recommend the course.

I woudn't recommend it based on my experience with one of the professors who was often confusing to understand, never responded to emails, only cared about two students in the class whose language capability was above that of German 107... Professor seemed irresponsible.
It's a good course, and it has the potential to be very good for your fluency and vocabulary-acquisition. Put in all the work, even if its not always checked, and you'll get something out of it.
Take it!
Take it, but avoid this instructor.
The course requires a lot of time spent out of class to be useful, and this seems unnecessary. That time spent out of class should be spent, in part, in the class itself.

Unlike the previous levels, this is much more of an actual class in the German department than a language class. You will spend most of the time discussing and analyzing texts, as opposed to learning grammar or other things.
Very interesting and helpful.  You'll learn a lot of German or possibly
prereqs: GER 105 or permission of instructor..
descrip: Continues improvement of proficiency in speaking, listening, reading, and writing using texts, online media, and other sources as a basis for class discussion. Grammar review is included. Conducted in German.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS)
prereqs: Completion of EGR 350.
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Reproductive Health and Reproductive Rights
descrip: Examines selected topics in reproductive health, with primary emphasis on contemporary domestic issues in the United States--such as unintended pregnancy, and sexually transmitted infection--but within the context of the international agenda on reproductive rights established in the 1994 Cairo international Conference on Population and development.

title: Introduction to Monte Carlo Simulation
reviews: Great course.

I really enjoyed this class, but I would recommend people shop it before taking it. It's a decent amount of work, and if you don't like Massey's style of lecturing you're going to have a rough time. I recommend it highly though. I really liked the material and I thought Massey did a good job teaching it.  I would say that you should shop it first though.
If you liked ORF 309 and you like coding, you will love this course.

Take it! The exams are rather long, but they are take home so you are given enough time. Massey is an amazing professor and the material is more application based and really interesting. Really great class!
Tough course - be prepared to spend a lot of time on the exams and some problem sets. Recommended if strong coder.
very practical methods and techniques for modeling and doing simulations.
prereqs: ORF 245 and ORF 309..
descrip: An introduction to the uses of simulation and direct computation in analyzing stochastic models and interpreting real phenomena. Deals with generating discrete and continuous random variables, stochastic ordering, the statistical analysis of simulated data, variance reduction techniques, statistical validation techniques, nonstationary Markov chains, and Markov chain Monte Carlo methods. Applications are drawn from problems in finance, manufacturing, and communication networks. Students will be encouraged to program in Python. A precept will be offered to help the students unfamiliar with the language.

title: Chinese Cinema
reviews: I would definitely recommend this course to anyone who was interested in film or chinese studies at all. Its a great class and a lot of fun, but you definitely need to be dedicating time to it.
Take it - just be prepared for the length of the seminars.  If you're interested in the topic the professor literally knows all.
Take it if you like film. The assignments are not heavy at all, however there is a significant weekly time commitment in watching the movies
Take it if you want to learn more about art film.

Take the course. Think of your own ideas about the movie before you do the readings, because it can be strange when Silbergeld asks questions about what you think something means when he already offered a suggestion in the book you read that he wrote.

This course isn't for everyone.  I wouldn't suggest taking this course if you 1) don't like film, or 2) don't like art-house.  This is not blockbuster Chinese cinema, but it's good for anyone interested in foreign art films.
descrip: Thematic studies in Chinese film (Republic, People's Republic, Taiwan, Hong Kong), 1930s to the present with emphasis on recent years, viewed in relation to traditional and modern Chinese visual arts and literature, colonialism and globalism, Communist politics, gender and family values, ethnicity and regionalism, melodrama and the avant-garde, the cinematic market, artistic censorship, and other social issues.

title: Modern Microbiology and Disease
reviews: I would recommend the class but the test questions sometimes weren't clear.
If you are planning on going to med school, take it
If you're not much of a talked or bad in front of people, I wouldn't really take this course, which is a real shame because I feel like those factors have nothing to do with microbiology.
Take it!
The lectures are key.
prereqs: MOL 214, MOL 215 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course examines the modern field of molecular biology through the lens of bacteria, viruses and parasites, emphasizing the impact of microbes on everyday life. Topics will include pathogenesis (evolution of communicable diseases, molecular mechanisms of virulence, antibiotic resistance), microbial biology (cell division and differentiation, quorum sensing), and how microbes interact with their habitat (microbial diversity, biofilms, bioremediation, symbiosis).

title: Seminar in Theoretical Astrophysics
reviews: Attend every session and ask questions.
Get an early start of making your slideshow.
Give great overview of the field for people who don't work in star formation; and also provide good insight for people are familiar with this field.
Great chance to practice giving a talk, if you prepare your talk well!
Great introduction to star formation theory.
descrip: Designed to stimulate students in the pursuit of research. Participants in this seminar discuss critically papers given by seminar members. Ordinarily, several staff members also participate. Often topics are drawn from published data that present unsolved puzzles of interpretation.

title: Europe from Antiquity to 1700
reviews: Absolutely take it. If you're interested at all in the history of Europe or the West, it's a great, great class that I loved.
Absolutely take this class - Professor Grafton is fantastic and lectures are worth every moment of your time.

Be prepared to catch up with the readings every week - the pace is quite fast. Also, the precepts are based on student-discussion so be ready to contribute to the class by talking about your thoughts on the readings.
Be prepared to do a lot of reading each week.
Do the readings, go to lectures, and you will be successful and fully enjoy this course.
For a survey course, its really good.
Go to lecture - they are mindblowingly fantastic.
Go to lecture to understand the history behind your required readings. Do that, and do NOT read the textbook. Just do the primary source readings. Focus on big ideas rather than small details.
Grafton is God. Greatest lecturer to ever walk the halls of McCosh.
Great lectures, take it!
I definitely recommend this course. Professor Grafton is terrific and the readings will give you a very comprehensive view.

I would definitely recommend this course. Professor Grafton is wonderful and the lectures are incredible. There are a lot of readings but it's manageable and they are always fun to read and they give you a great feel for the time period they were written.
I would recommend it to anyone with the slightest interest in western history.
If you like history at all, take it. If you don't, Prof. Grafton is good enough to keep you engaged.
Make sure to go prepared to precept - it makes the sessions so much more fun.

One of the best classes I've taken at Princeton! The amount of reading is very manageable, and all the readings are really interesting. Prof. Grafton is also probably one of the best lecturers you'll ever have at Princeton.
Pretty good class, take it.
Professor Grafton is an amazing lecturer.
Read the primary sources and don't put them off until exams.
TAKE IT! Take any course with Professor Grafton in it! He is truly incredible - lectures are a joy to attend.

TAKE IT!!! I thought taking a survey history class with one of the world's foremost historians would  be so intimidating. However, Professor Grafton's masterful pedagody and more than evident passion completely put me at ease: he usually starts with an ice-breaking question or story, like 'do you think ancient Greek robes had pockets?', after which you'll go home with a big idea or two which characterises that particular era. His best lecture was probably the closing one, in which he asked us 'what makes Western civilisation Western civilisation? Is it the agricultural revolutions over time? Or the trading and development of technology? Or the contrarian thinkers who constantly have been rearing their heads?'  You will come away with your own interpretation of what makes our intellectual heritage what it is, guided by the great, passionate yet soft-spoken Professor Grafton himself.
Take this class.
Take this course with Grafton he is awesome.
Take this course!
Take this course. It's awesome.
Take this course. Professor Grafton is INCREDIBLE. A true genius who genuinely loves teaching and cares for his students and their learning. Get into his precept if possible.
This class covers a very broad scope but its interesting
This class was excellent. I truly enjoyed both lectures and precepts. The work load is not too overbearing and even though it was a survey course over a lot of years, I learned a lot.

This course is very big on themes. You learn to think like a historian, but I found it very hard to do. You are forced to do a lot of critical thinking and learn to identify and make relationships between themes, time periods, people, and subjects. 
Ask questions. Professor Grafton is very approachable and willing to help.
This is a great class.  Come to the lectures, since they're brilliant, and do the readings so you'll have something to say in precept.
This was a good course, and Professor Grafton is awesome.
Yes, if only to hear Anthony Grafton speak, because he is excellent.
take it if you have to
the lectures are interesting but i didn't particularly enjoy the discussion in my precept.
descrip: This course shows how Greeks and Romans, Jews and Christians, nobles and merchants built the civilization of the west.

title: Disease Ecology, Economics, and Policy
reviews: A really fun class. Definitely doable for the non-science major, so long as your math is still pretty sharp. Be warned it's more of a lecture than a seminar, but that isn't the end of the world.

A really great course if you're interested in a holistic approach to public health (economics, policy, and science). The three-hour lecture can be a little rough but it's worth it. Be sure to start your poster early so that you can ask the TAs questions - they can be really helpful.

Absolutely take it. It's not as much economics as you'd like it, so keep that in mind. Professors are great, and it's not that much work either. Final project is tough if you don't keep up with it yourself.
Definitely recommend if you're interested. Content is really cool, professor and preceptors are good. Beware of the 3 hour long lectures though - they can be difficult.
Do the readings!
Don't take this course unless it's in seminar format.  In the 70-person lecture, it's still interesting, but requires a lot of effort and work to stay engaged and keep up.

Ecology - heavily covered, especially in lecture.  very well taught.
Economics - heavily covered more in the test than in class.  not as well taught, so you should have a comfortable economic understanding already.  for the poster project, already knowing how to do regressions would have been a HUGE help.
politics - the least covered topic, but naturally discussions do come up of how decisions should be made.

Fascinating subject material but the format is a little strange at the moment. This is not a seminar- it is a power 3 hr. lecture that although the material and the professors are great, it gets a little hard to stay focused during simply because of the length. Also the work load definitely gets heavy at the end of the semester for this course - the poster project is definitely challenging, especially given that the the course never takes the time to teach you any of the skills you would need to execute the project and you essentially have to teach yourself MATlab or STATA. Then once you have suffered through the project, you have to take a final exam!
Great class! Really interesting. Make sure to start your poster project early!
Great course, final project takes a good amount of work but is also fun. It would be really helpful to be good at manipulating equations come exam time.
If you're at all interested in infectious disease, do it.
Interesting course for those interested in GHP, EEB or economics.

Keep up with the readings and take notes on the powerpoints during lectures. Anyone will have access to the lectures again on blackboard, but if you remember some supplemental notes and speaking points made in lecture, it will serve you well for the exams and essays. Also, make sure you ask questions if you do not understand how to solve different variations of the SIR model.
Take it! It's a great course!
Take this course.  It is extremely interesting and allows to undertake a very interesting project.
take it!
prereqs: Calculus is required..
descrip: The dynamics of the emergence and spread of disease arise from a complex interplay between disease ecology, economics, and human behavior. Lectures will provide an introduction to complementarities between economic and epidemiological approaches to understanding the emergence, spread, and control of infectious diseases. The course will cover topics such as drug-resistance in bacterial and parasitic infections, individual incentives to vaccinate, the role of information in the transmission of infectious diseases, and the evolution of social norms in healthcare practices.

title: Institutional Finance,Trading and Markets
reviews: Avoid if Philip Yan is still the TA. Ask proof of improvement over this year's program.
Great course, highly recommended.
Highly recommend, though need efforts to understand it well.
I would highly recommend the class.
very intense but very interesting topic
prereqs: ECO 300 Microeconomic Theory (ideally ECO 310).
descrip: Course studies financial institutions and focuses on the stability of the financial system. It covers important theoretical concepts and recent developments in financial intermediation, asset pricing under asymmetric information, behavioral finance, and market microstructure. Topics include market efficiency, asset price bubbles, herding, liquidity crisis, credit crunch, risk management, market design, and financial regulation.

title: Topics in Physical Chemistry - Dynamics in Condensed Phases
descrip: After a review of basic background (solid and liquid state physics, matter radiation-field interaction, quantum relaxation processes, linear response theory, correlation functions), the course will focus on topics of current interest, such as vibrational energy relaxation, chemical reactions in condensed phases, solvation dynamics, electron transfer processes, and molecular conduction.

title: Introduction to Biological Dynamics
prereqs: MAT 103 or equivalent.
descrip: Course focuses on the application of mathematical methods to biological problems and is intended to provide a basic grounding in mathematical modeling and data analysis for students who might not have pursued further study in mathematics. Topics include differential equations, linear algebra, difference equations, and probability. Each topic has a lecture component and computer laboratory component. Lectures are in common with MOL 410. Students work extensively with the computing package Matlab. No previous computing experience necessary. Two 90-minute lectures, one computer laboratory.

title: Neurogenetics of Behavior
prereqs: open to all graduate students in the biological or psychological sciences.
descrip: How do seemingly simple organisms generate complex behaviors? Course will explore our current understanding of the genetic and neural basis for animal behavior, with an emphasis on cutting-edge research and model systems that are amenable to genetic manipulation. Each week students will discuss a new behavior with a focus on the underlying mechanisms; students will also lead discussions of primary literature. The goal of this course is to provide required background knowledge and critical thinking skills to move beyond the published literature to proposing original experiments. This effort will culminate in a final paper from each student.

title: Electrical Engineering Master's Project
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out a master's-level project and presents their results. For M. Eng. student, 597, fall term; 598 spring term.

title: Workshop on Social Organization
descrip: A two-semester course for graduate students whose work is at the intersection of the fields of organization studies, economic sociology and social network analysis. In addition to covering foundational readings in these fields and addressing selected special topics (e.g. social organizational aspects of economic crisis), the workshop provides opportunities for students to develop research projects and presentation skills, and to read the work of and interact with scholars brought to campus by the Center for the Study of Social Organization.

title: Structural Analysis for Architecture
reviews: You have to take this class.
descrip: Elementary structural analysis for architecture students covering statics, strength of materials and approximate methods of analysis, including historical examples.

title: Intensive Fourth-Year Modern Chinese I
reviews: Be sure to study hard for the tests!

If you are serious about improving your Chinese, take this class.
For tests, study usage and sentence structures above all. Memorizing English meanings will not be enough to learn the vocabulary.
It will take up your life, but it's definitely a very rewarding course. You learn so much. Note just Chinese language, but also about China   China society. Interesting topics.
Make flashcards.
Studying for this course should be done early and consistently. Any interruption in studying should be remedied immediately.
Take it! It's fun and the work becomes routine, really

Take it! The Princeton Chinese classes are legendary for a reason! The teachers are great, the difficulty is just nice, the tests are well-planned. You will definitely be learning quite some Chinese in this class!
Work hard. Stay on top of the assignments. Always check Blackboard for homework. Talk to the teachers a lot!
prereqs: CHI 305, CHI 306 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Reading and discussion based on Chinese scholarly journals, popular essays, and newspaper articles. Students are exposed to a variety of modern Chinese literary genres, as well as some of the major substantive issues that modern Chinese intellectuals have faced.

title: Golden-Age Poetry
descrip: A close reading of selected lyric poetry of the Renaissance and Baroque periods. The course will have a workshop format: every week each student will prepare a brief analysis of a given poem in order to stimulate class discussion.

title: Advanced Creative Writing (Fiction)
reviews: A great way of honing your writing skills and getting to meet one of our most talented contemporary novelists.
Be prepared to receive legitimate feedback; JCO does not hold back (which is a good thing) so don't expect to have her hold your hand.
Come on, it's Joyce Carol Oates. You can't NOT take it.
Definitely take this if you are at all interested in creative writing.
Great professor.
I would take it if you like writing, but you really need to have thick skin.
It's a great course, take it!
It's fun, it's almost no work. Not life-changing, but fun.

It's interesting to take a course with JYO she's such a character and so fun to be around.  You'll get helpful advice from other students on your work, and you'll get out of this course what you put in.
It's worth it for the experience.
Prof. White has great stories to share and really encourages others to be open in order to improve their writing.
TAKE IT

Take it! If you're at all interested in creative writing, I highly recommend it. It's more work than an automatic pdf class might seem to be, but if you want to write, then I think it's definitely worth it.
These courses are great ways to learn about writing and reading creatively.
Try it out!
YES.
You should take it! Make sure you start your short stories early.
prereqs: CWR 203 or CWR 204 and admission by application only. Please visit the Lewis Center Creative Writing website for application information..
descrip: Advanced practice in the original composition of fiction for discussion in regularly scheduled workshop meetings. The curriculum allows the student to develop writing skills, provides an introduction to the possibilities of contemporary literature and offers perspective on the place of literature among the liberal arts. Criticism by practicing writers and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS): Non-credit
reviews: TAKE THIS!  It's not as much work (although it is significant) as the other EPICS and Prof Littman is a great prof to work with.
Take EPICS!
definately take it, even if you arent an engineer.
prereqs: Seniors only (except for juniors who have completed EGR 351)..
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: Special Topics in the History of Philosophy - Plotinus
descrip: An intensive study of selected philosophers or philosophical movements in the history of philosophy.

title: Proseminar in Anthropology
descrip: First term of a two-term survey of major anthropological writings, primarily for first-year graduate students. This seminar will focus on some major figures who have influenced anthropological theory and shaped our ideas of what anthropology is or should be. Historical formulations of some issues which are currently revisited and hotly debated such as rationalization and unreason, science and communication, subjectivity and dialogic encounters, and the status of knowledge and truth in the social sciences will be examined.

title: Advanced Econometrics: Nonlinear Models
descrip: This is half of the second-year sequence in econometrics methodology (ECO 513 is the other). The course covers nonlinear statistical models for the analysis of cross-sectional and panel data. It is intended both for students specializing in econometric theory and for students interested in applying statistical methods to statistical data. Approximately half of the course is devoted to development of the large-sample theory for nonlinear estimation procedures, while the other half concentrates on application of the methods to various econometric models.

title: Optimization under Uncertainty
reviews: An interesting and fairly easy introduction to optimization under uncertainty.
Dont take this class.
Go to precept and make sure you know how to do the questions on the practice exams. The exams are nearly identical to the practice exams.
I think the material is pretty useful. Hopefully it would be better taught and more well structured with a different professor

I took this course because the description looked great and a few older friends said it was easy to get an A in this class. Not true at all. We didn't learn anything useful throughout the semester; all we did was a bunch of busy work (modeling in various software packages). I think I will get an A but I had to work my butt off for that A. Overall, avoid this class unless if you have some compelling reason to take it.
I would take it if you like a reasonable ORF elective. Not too difficult.
Make sure you are clearn on how to use AMPL
Mulvey is a great guy, but there are definitely better ORF electives to take. Just didn't feel like I learned that much in this course.
Take it.
The topics covered in this course are very interesting. I am sure many of the topics we covered in this course will be useful for later ORF classes and my thesis.

The way this course is organized and lectured can be very confusing! Jumps around between topics a lot and sometimes repeats the same topic. Board work during lectures in particular can be very frustrating, and there isn't smooth transition from topic to topic throughout the course. That being said, it's not a difficult course, and learning simulations is pretty interesting.

There's a big emphasis on finance, so if you're really set on that field, go for it. But otherwise, I'd probably pass for another class that discusses stochastic modeling, like 411 or Intro to Monte Carlo simulation.
Try looking for something else?
You learn some fairly interesting stuff about multi-objective optimization and stochastic programming.
don't forget to show up for the discissuions!
prereqs: ORF 307 or MAT 305, and ORF 309.
descrip: A survey of quantitative approaches for making optimal decisions under uncertainty, including decision trees, Monte Carlo simulation, and stochastic programs. Forecasting and planning systems are integrated with a focus on financial applications.

title: Logic - Logical Philosophy of Science
descrip: This seminar will look at how mathematical logic has been, and can be, employed in the philosophy of science. It focuses on the work of Carnap, Reichenbach, Hempel, Putnam, and van Fraassen. (There will be enough real logic that Philosophy graduate students can earn a logic unit with this seminar.)

title: Intermediate Arabic II
reviews: A great class only because of prof. Hisham! The other Arabic professors don't even come close to him. If you're interested in Arabic definitely only take classes with prof. Hisham. Can't recommend more strongly.

Although Hisham doesn't always check the homework, it is in your best interest to complete all assignments. You are in charge of knowing all the vocabulary and grammar rules introduced over the semester.
Arabic needs a lot of time and practice, so do not take this class unless you are willing to work hard.
Because Professor Hisham is a great professor teaching great subject material. He is an expert and that really shows in class.
Do it!  Hisham will give you the tools to really succeed in Arabic in the future.  He helps you build a solid and thorough base.
I would highly recommend this class but be prepared to work hard on grammar.
prereqs: ARA 105 or permission of instructor..
descrip: A continuation of ARA 105 Intermediate Arabic I. This course continues the study of Arabic grammar, syntax, and morphology, and expands the students' mastery of the language in functional contexts. Discussions are held in Arabic to enhance the students' skills in speaking and listening.

title: Building Science and Technology: Building Systems
reviews: At this point every Architecture major must take this course to graduate, so again therein lies a problem, as any future student will just be stuck in a course that teaches nothing and is led by a professor who is clearly more interested in his own career outside of Princeton than any of the students he teaches.
Lab is fun. But that's pretty much it.
if you do go to lab--definitely worth it
it's fun building a house and bench
prereqs: The material in class requires students to have some experience and understanding of architectural design, drawings and details. It is required that undergraduate students have completed ARC203, ARC204 before embarking on this class. Engineering majors earning an architecture certificate should contact the instructor for permission to enroll in the course..
descrip: This course introduces students to the art and science of building. Emphasis will be placed gaining an understanding of construction materials, methods and the process of translating design ideas into built form. Specific topics are introduced each week during the two one-hour lectures. These topics are then further explored, and students gain hands on experience, each week during the two-hour laboratory component of the course.

title: Advanced Computer Networks
reviews: Freedman is a great teacher. He's very sharp and will get you thinking about the deeper issues. Definitely take 461 before this class, though, unless you have a background in networks.
If you are interested in networking research - take it.
If you are interested in networks, it'd be a good follow-up to 461.
If you want to learn more about networks or have to satisfy the systems requirement take this class!
It is worth taking.
It's a good course to know the state-of-the-art of networking research.
Make sure you choose a final project that you are truly interested in, because the bar of expectation is pretty high (which is understandable given the level of the course).
Take it and enjoy it.
Take this if you want to learn the current state of networks research.

The material itself is useful and well taught. Great introduction to systems research. Be careful when picking a project team. 50% of the grade is dependent on the project, and it's good if you know you can work well with the people in the team.

This course is very reading- and writing-intensive, but the writing is really helpful to understand the reading. The amount of information covered is vast, but you learn a lot about old and current research being done in the area of Networks. I would also say tell the student to make sure to allot enough time to work on the final project.
This is probably the lightest and definitely an enjoyable seminar course, you must consider it even if you are not a systems person.
You better took COS461 before this.
descrip: Survey of computer networks covering end-to-end principle, multiplexing, virtualization, packet switching vs. circuit switching, router design, network protocols, congestion control, internet routing architecture, network measurement, network management, and overlay networks. Survey of research papers from classic literature through contemporary research.

title: Socialist Experiment and Its Legacies, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Topics in Science, Technology, and Environmental Policy - Living in a Greenhouse: Technology & Policy
descrip: A focus primarily on the challenge of modifying the global energy system to reduce projected carbon dioxide emissions. Students pursue both science/technology and policy in each of five two-week units: 1)underlying carbon cycle science, ways the world has organized to learn more & to communicate results; 2) Energy efficiency, patterns of demand, lifestyles, energy & poverty; 3) Fossil fuels, abundance & depletion, energy security; 4) Carbon capture & storage, policies enabling commercialization, risk assessment; 5) Non-carbon energy in its two forms, nuclear power & renewable energy. Final two weeks are devoted to student reports.

title: Topics in American Literature - The Supernatural in American Literature
reviews: TAKE IT! Professor Rivett is amazing. So smart and a great professor who will help your writing, thinking, and introduce you to tons of new material.
Take it! This class is really interesting and while it is a bit English major-y, anyone will find something to like in this seminar.
This was a great course that had exciting discussions about truly interesting works of literature.
descrip: The 1692 Salem witch trials defied rational explanation. How does one reconcile invisible specters flitting through the night or inflicting harm on young girls with religious orthodoxy and scientific modernity? Beginning with the crisis exposed by Salem, this course charts how a supernatural domain of sleepwalking, ghosts, and gothic haunting persists throughout American literary history from the colonial period to the twentieth century. We investigate supernatural phenomena in ghost stories, gothic novels, prophecies, spirit photography, and horror film. Oscillating between spirit and matter, the supernatural resists secular history.

title: Dissertation Seminar
descrip: Open to post-generals students actively working on their dissertations. The seminar aims at assisting students in the research and writing and at developing their teaching skills by improving their ability to present advanced material to less expert audiences. Students will make presentations of work in progress, discuss each other's work, and share common pedagogical problems and solutions under the guidance of one or more faculty members. It will meet for two hours each week throughout the academic year.

title: Technology and Culture
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Policy Aspects of Federal and State Budgeting and Fiscal Decision-Making
reviews: Definitely take it--but only if you are interested in learning about a very specific policy sector.
Excellent course.  Fair grading and interesting material (assuming you are interested in budgets).

If you are interested in budget issues and federal/state debt this is a great course to take. I had no knowledge going in and feel very comfortable having a conversation about current issues in government on the subject. That was my goal for the course and it was certainly surpassed.

This course is GREAT for anyone who is interested in budget policy at the federal and/or state level. Keevey knows a ton and does a great job of clearing up misconceptions. He has a point of view (somewhat liberal but not super far left), but he's very good about being open-minded. I say that as a conservative. I highly recommend it. My favorite policy course in my four years here. Strongly recommend for those interested in budget issues.

HOWEVER, I would strongly recommend AGAINST taking this course if you have little or no interest in budget issues. This will not be the course that makes you find this stuff interesting, and when you need to sit through three hours a week of lecture on a subject you don't like, that can be torture.

One final note - this course really would be a lot better as a twice-a-week lecture rather than as a three hour seminar since Keevey doesn't really make his lectures very discussion-oriented. Three hours of lecture can get tough to sit through sometimes. I'm glad this wasn't discussion based since I doubt we'd have been capable of carrying on a three hour conversation about these issues with our limited knowledge, but just keep in mind that if the format for the course does not change, there will be some weeks when you can't concentrate anymore on the lecture by 3:30 even if you like the material.
professor is very insightful and should take course if time allows
descrip: The purpose of this course is to discuss the academic and practical aspects of state and federal finance. The course will discuss the major financial processes of governments - budgeting, taxing, raising capital, managing debt, financing pensions, and forecasting long-term trends. Although the total expenditures by state and local governments in this country approximates the amount spent by the federal government, there are vast differences in the way each level of government does its budgets, raises its revenue, issues its debt, and manages its finances; this course will analyze those differences and their impact.

title: Advanced Japanese I
reviews: A good course for anyone genuinely interested in the language and culture.  Those enrolled as freshman might want to really make sure he/she is prepared.

Absolutely continue studying Japanese!
But as students of Japanese will realize by now, in the journey from intermediate level to advanced level, progress is often slow and the path is poorly marked. Use this course as a guidepost, but don't forget to do some exploring along the way. Supplement this course with self study and enjoy the material!

Stay on top of the assignments, and practice using the vocabulary/grammar/expressions that you learn in class. Regular studying helps a lot more in the long run (or even just in the semester run) than cramming five minutes before a quiz. You might survive the quiz, but that information won't stay for long.
Take it. I feel as though one would struggle to get better Japanese instruction elsewhere.
The written work isn't too hard, but pay close attention to grammar and particles on assignments that are graded for accuracy. Also, practice speaking as much as possible, especially casual.
prereqs: JPN 107. Students should have completed Intermediate (second-year) Japanese or equivalent as a prerequisite to admission in JPN 301.
descrip: This course is designed to further students' reading ability. Students will have ample opportunity to hear and use increasingly more sophisticated vocabulary and grammatical construction through discussion and composition. Japanese video tapes will also be incorporated into the course. Reading materials include "Tobira" and selected readings from works in the original language.

title: Rationality and Human Reasoning
reviews: A reasonable EC.

DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. Prof Osherson literally speeds through the lectures and does not post the slides. The whole time you will be rushing to take notes instead of actually listening. The material is not interesting either and there are tough weekly quizzes. Just don't. Please. Do yourself a favor.
Do not take it unless you're willing to do A LOT of extra work because he doesn't provide lecture slides.
Do not take. Just don't.
Don't take this course. If looking for a psych departmental, there are other courses available. If looking for a logics course, I'm sure other departments will have better.
Don't.

Easily one of the classes I've hated most in my four years here. This is not a psychology course on human rationality and reasoning... Be prepared to spend 90% of course time on sentential logic, with minimal discussion of human behavior. Lectures are painfully boring and assignments are arbitrary.
GO TO PRECEPTS. This will help greatly. Record lectures.
Go to the friday review sessions, they're worth it.

I would not recommend this course to another student. I spoke to many other students in the class, and not a single student actually enjoyed the course. People who took Psychology of Decision Making, a similar course, conversely enjoyed it a lot.
If Osherson is teaching this course, then you will not enjoy it.
If you are not a quantitative thinker, think twice before taking this course.

If you're looking for an interesting psych class on decision-making, this is not it. If you like Logic, and are decent at math, then this is the class for you. I fall in the former category in that I enjoy real psychology courses and not logic/math classes.

In a way this class is false advertising because its not a traditional psych class.

So, take this class if you think the material will interest you because I'm sure you will really like it.  If you're not crazy about the material and are a psych major, any other class will be a better use of your time.
Probably don't take it...half the class dropped after midterm.
Stay away; basically a math course; don't be fooled by the interesting course description
Stay on top of the reading and ATTEND CLASS. If you can't, ask someone to take notes for you because quiz and exam questions often come directly from lecture details.
Stay on top of the readings and don't miss lecture. All in all it's quite manageable and the material is interesting.
Take it if you need a 300 level Psych course, but not particularly enlightening.
The class had so much potential, but the way the professor presented the material was a huge letdown.

The perfect PDF class.  I am not PDFing, but I do not recommend this since it is really hard to know how you are doing.  If you are taking it for a grade, read everything really carefully and take notes in lecture.  Professor Osherson is great, but he doesn't give out his lecture slides, and most of the quiz material comes from them.  Grade entirely based on quizzes.
This class didn't really feel like a psychology class. I personally liked that, but I can see why other psych majors might not.

This course is an interesting synthesis of economics, game theory, computer science, artificial intelligence, philosophy, and just about everything besides psychology (besides a bit of neuroscience). Take it for distribution or if you're really interested in the above fields. Professor is a smart guy.
Unless you are passionate about learning sentential logic, do not take this course.
Whatever you do, don't take this course. The professor is awful.
don't take this if you think it will be similar to cognitive psych. it's not. if you are a math major you'll love it so you should take it then.
it's more of a math class than anything else. doesn't make much sense. pick something else
descrip: Reaching belief and making decisions are two activities performed especially well by humans. Contemporary investigation distinguishes normative from descriptive questions about belief and decision. The former concern how our cognition ought to function; the latter, how it actually functions. Fundamental theories of belief and decision will be presented in the course, and discussed from both the normative and descriptive perspectives. Utility, logic, probability, and abduction will all be examined, with additional topics drawn from computability theory and from collective choice.

title: Mathematics for Economics/Life Sciences
reviews: Definitely go to office hours before a quiz!
Do NOT take this unless you have to.
Do all the weekly problem sets regularly- go to office hours for help! Attend class because the course covers a broad range of material in only 12 weeks.
Do not be afraid to ask for help outside the class. Also organize your notes very carefully.
Do the practice problems weekly.  They were what helped me the most on the exams.
Go to lectures and pay attention. Approach the professor if you have any questions.
Go to office hours, and keep on top of problem sets. I recommend using the online lecture notes to supplement your class attendance.
Great QR if you want to take a math class without any engineers or committing yourself to more than one semester. I enjoyed the material and highly reccomend this class to other students
I think you should be prepared to review things from high school on your own and perhaps learn things it is assumed you had learned.
If you need this as a requirement, take it -- otherwise, I wouldn't recommend it.  Try to get Nora as a lecturer!
It is a requirement for some but I found it to be a great class for anyone that want a basic understanding of linear and multivariable.
Keep up with readings. Read them before lectures. you won't regret it.

Make sure you like the instructor for the section you're in because that can make a huge difference in understanding the material and you will be spending much more time with them than just the time in class.
Not a bad course. Take it if you need it for your degree. It is not an unreasonable amount of work, but not a cake walk either.
Obviously only take this course if it is applicable but it's not absurd so don't worry about it if you have to.
Only take it if this Yu-Han is teaching, or req. Yu-Han's the man!
Only take it if you have to as a requirement, but it wasn't bad
Only take it if you need it, but it is one of the better math classes I have taken.
Practice problems are the key to success.  Make sure you understand the concepts.
Read the book! It is so helpful and will be a good review of in class learning. Also utilize office hours and make sure you understand how to do the hw problems yourself.
Review the problem set problems before class.
Sign up for Yu-Han's section and complete all of the additional problems on Blackboard.
Stay consistent with the work and you will gain a lot from the class.
Take 104 if you haven't taken BC in high school before this course.
Take it if you need to, all the professors are very patient.
Take it if you want to learn math.
Take it with Yu Han Liu if u you can.
Take it with Yu-Han Liu, great teacher.
Take this class only if: you want to stay far away from math, but you're either an economics major, you want/need to take higher-level economics, or you like practical/application-based math.

Take this course if you want an introduction to multivariable calculus at a level easier than MAT201. It's a good class and you can fulfill the math requirement for Econ major with this class, but if you plan on taking the more-math track, take 200 level math classes, as this is a terminal course.
The class is not terribly difficult, but the teacher does not make the class easy.  It is interesting, but relies on more independent work.
The course cover a ridiculous amount of material. Be prepared to study hard on your own.
The problems sets are pretty difficult.
This course is helpful in learning the concepts of integration, linear algebra, and multivariable calculus.  The instructors are always available for help, but the class is not easy.
Yes, but make sure that you have taken some previous calculus course before.
Yes, but make sure your teacher is the right fit for you.

definitely take this class, but preferably take it with Yu-han Liu- he is a more theoretical teacher. However all the teachers are very nice and willing to help and I felt a lot of support in this class. This is the first time I've been confident about mathematics in years and it feels great
only take it if you have to for econ
prereqs: MAT103 or equivalent..
descrip: Survey of topics in calculus and linear algebra as preparation for future course work in economics or life sciences. Topics include basic techniques of integration, average value, improper integrals and rates of growth, partial derivatives, gradient, Lagrange multipliers, linear systems, determinants, matrix inversion, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, as time permits.

title: Topics in Anthropology - Revisiting Sacrifice
prereqs: Open to juniors, seniors and graduate students in Anthropology. Other students can be accepted depending on instructor's permission..
descrip: The course brings back to discussion a concept and a set of practices central to the lives of millions of men and women across the world. While sacrifice is invoked in religious and political discourse and practice, it has been somewhat neglected by anthropologists in recent decades. Understanding sacrifice is understanding ritual and religion and their role in the globalizing world. Topics include theories of sacrifice, categories and comparison, genealogies and deconstruction, violence, power and religion, jihad, sacrifice and terror. We will study contemporary materials from public discourses and arts before going back to classical theory.

title: Physics of the Ocean and Atmosphere
reviews: Professor Philander is a great and accessible professor, and so long as you keep up with the material, you'll enjoy the class!
should take this class if you are interested in oceans and atmosphere.
prereqs: MAT 201, PHY 104 or equivalent.
descrip: The habitability of our planet depends critically on the motion of the oceans and atmosphere, which determines our weather and climate. Associated phenomena include hurricanes, tornadoes, the Jet Streams, the Gulf Stream, El Nino, La Nina, and the recurrent Ice Ages of the past million years. The course includes the use of an idealized computer model (which runs on a laptop) to study how these phenomena depend on the Earth's rotation and sphericity, and to explore the predictability of weather, and of long-term changes in climate, including future global warming.

title: Philosophy of Language
descrip: This is a joint seminar with Rutgers. It will meet on alternate weeks at Princeton and at Rutgers, taking up topics in semantics and pragmatics. There will be several outside speakers.

title: Inorganic Chemistry: Structure and Bonding
reviews: Don't fall behind in the course, especially during Group Theory and MO theory, since that is applied for pretty much the entire course.
Go to Professor VanderKam with any questions or concerns and she will do a great job to help you out.
Great introduction to inorganic chemistry
I would advise them to not take this class. I have advised them to not take this class but they will anyway and then they will understand why they should not have.
I would recommend taking this class if you need to take an inorganic class. It wasn't particularly interesting at certain times and the tests are really long.

I would recommend taking this course if you are planning on pursuing a career in chemistry, as it introduces many necessary concepts.  However, if you are just trying to fulfill the inorganic departmental requirement, I think that CHM 408 is a much more interesting (although more difficult) option.
Interesting class to get an introduction to analytical side of chemistry. But I don't think it's a good representation of inorganic chemistry as a field of research.
It might be interesting if you're a sophomore and haven't taken many higher-level classes.  It feels like AP chem.
It's a solid choice for a chemistry departmental. The material is fairly straightforward and useful.
It's challenging and covers quite a bit of material, so stay on top of it.
Keep up with the work. DON'T BE AFRAID TO MEET WITH THE PROFESSOR. She's so helpful and very approachable and understanding.
Might want to try another course.
Professor VanderKam is extremely helpful, make sure to take advantage of her office hours. The tests are very long, but the questions are at least well-written.
Reasonable course.  Not too exciting, but a good introduction to inorganic.
Take it if you're a chem major.
Take it, but demand old exams or extra difficult problems otherwise you will be totally unprepared for the exam.

Take only if chem major
VanderKam is funny and helpful, but the class is crazy hard

This class covers some interesting material, like symmetry and crystal structures, but it's not worth taking unless you have to. Professor VanderKam's lectures are pretty much reading off powerpoint slides.
This is a good class and Dr. VanderKam is a good lecturer.  It requires a good amount of work but is so much better than orgo if you are more of a math person.

You will not be able to get everything in lecture simply because she goes through so much in so little time (her powerpoints are easily 50-60 slides for a 50 minute lecture, and each slide isn't cursory). If you want to do well, you will need to go back afterwards and look through the lectures again, or read them before hand when she posts them. This is a very good class, but it isn't one where you can just go to lecture and expect to learn everything there.

You need to go to precept and do your own review of the lectures before or after you've heard them.
take it if you have to, other wise probably skip it
prereqs: CHM 301/302, or CHM 303/304, or equivalent is required..
descrip: Structural principles and bonding theories are discussed for various classes of main group inorganic and transition metal coordination compounds. Includes an introduction to the electronic structure of d-orbitals and ligand field theory.

title: History of the Life Sciences - Biomedicine
descrip: The seminar focuses on the interface between biology and medicine in the modern period, leading up and including the coinage of "biomedicine" in World War II-era U.S. We will examine how developments in biology were fundamentally related to medical education, research, or practice; how the development of laboratories recast the understanding of diseases and their etiologies; and how patients have been integrated into research regimes, both "basic" and clinical.

title: Composition
descrip: Emphasis will be placed upon the individual student's original work and upon the study and discussion of pieces pertinent to that work.

title: Topics in Differential Geometry - Kahler Geometry
prereqs: Undergraduates must request permission of instructor..
descrip: This course covers current topics in differential geometry. Specific topic information will be provided when the course is offered.

title: Studies in Ancient Judaism - Textual Exegesis in Classical Judaism
descrip: The seminar will examine the methods of exegesis developed in the Classical Jewish sources. Particular attention will be paid to explicit and implicit formal rules of deduction underlying each exegetical text. Participants with a working knowledge of Biblical or Rabbinic Hebrew will be encouraged to work with the texts in the original.

title: Intellectual History of China to the Fifth Century
reviews: Definitely take this course. The seminars are engaging, and the material is absolutely fascinating.
I would recommend this course if you have any interest in Chinese history and intellectual thinking.
Take it. You will have a good sense of Chinese intellectual history
prereqs: A prior course in EAS is desirable but not required..
descrip: Critical consideration of a selection of monumental contributions to early Chinese thought, and the uses to which they were put by later Chinese thinkers. Readings will be from English translations such as: [Analects],[ Lao-tzu], [Chuang-tzu], [Mencius],[ I-ching] and secondary works. All assignments are available on reserve.

title: Intermediate Japanese I
reviews: I would highly recommend it if you are willing to take on the relatively high work load and level of difficulty.
If you have to take it, do. If you want to become fluent, take it. If it's just a passing interest, this is a huge time investment with potentially low returns.
Japanese is the coolest language. The class can get hard at times, but it's only for improvement.
descrip: This course aims to give a thorough mastery of modern colloquial Japanese (Tokyo speech) by consistent review and reinforcement of major grammatical points and more advanced vocabulary and grammar. Students will reinforce four major skills by speaking - listening drills, readings, and written exercises.

title: Introduction to Genomics and Computational Molecular Biology
reviews: Definitely consider taking this course if you're interesting in computer science and genomics.  A background in R or Python would prove fairly helpful (in addition to a background in biology -- not necessary, but definitely very helpful as well).

If you really want to learn about genomics and basic bioinformatics, take the class. The material is interesting and useful. Just be prepared for some frustration and a good amount of work when it comes to the assignments and readings. And make sure to review the lecture material for the daily quizzes.
If you're a person really interested in bioinformatics and also not averse to studying more bio than usual, go for it
Lots of interesting material but the lectures aren't useful and you have to go for the quizzes. Probably not worth taking unless you have to.
Only take it if you need to for the QCB certificate or if you are really interested in computational biology.

This class has the potential to be very interesting, but does not always fulfill that potential. Only take this if you are really interested and have some background in both bio and cos (despite the lack of prerequisites, it is pretty difficult if you have no background in one of the disciplines)

This class is a fair amount of work, but it can be quite interesting.  If its a subject matter that you're interested in, I'd definitely recommend taking it.  However, if you're not certain that this is something that you'd like to learn about, this might not be the class for you.

This class is interesting if you're genuinely interested in learning about the material. However, I felt like I would have gotten more out of the class if I had prior experience in genomic research or if I already had a basic knowledge of the biological techniques discussed.

This course is difficult and requires a broad background. Make sure you can trust your group-project partners.

No real need to do more with the reading than skim it in my opinion (unless they change things).

This course is not a worthwhile use of your time, but you may have to take it if you are QCB. If so, your instructors are failing to provide a treatment of quantitative biology that lives up to the name of QCB, and you should go in aware of that.
Work on the group project as early as possible.
You learn a lot about methods very useful for biological research, but the course is not as exciting. The daily quizzes were painful.

You'll learn a lot from the assignments, not so much from the lectures, worth it if you think you might use any computational techniques in your bio thesis. Learning Python and RNA-seq analysis was really a huge pro, that made me get over how dreadful the lectures can be for this course.
descrip: Introduction to computational and genomic approaches used to study molecular systems. Topics include computational approaches to sequence similarity and alignment, phylogenetic inference, gene expression analysis, structure prediction, comparative genome analysis, and high-throughput technologies for mapping genetic networks.

title: Junior Seminar
reviews: Do the reading! Don't leave it all for the night before.
Do the readings, otherwise you won't get anything out of discussions.
I would recommend this course for majors, but it is already a requirement.
Keep up with the reading - it's sometimes a lot, but you'll get much more out of the class discussion.
Keep up with the readings as it will only help you in your future studies of art history.
This class is great. Make sure you give yourself enough time to complete the readings and write the papers - it takes a deceptively long time.
necessary
descrip: An introduction to a range of art-historical approaches and to the writings of key figures in the history of the discipline. Attention is also given to research and writing skills specific to the history of art.

title: Fundamentals of Solid Earth Science
reviews: I think the new GEO203 class is excellent. Would strongly recommend to all future GEO students, and also to those with a general interest in the geosciences.

If you are a CEE major debating between this course and bio for a requirement, this course is a logical choice because of its scientific base that we have been extensively exposed to, making the course much easier.
If you are interested in geology and also pretty capable in math I would definitely recommend this course.
If you like the geosciences, you will be pleasantly challenged by this course.
Keep your notes neat and study the problem sets.
Only take this course if you have to as a distribution requirement, or if you are positive you want to be a geo science concentrator and have already taken 200 level math course and chemistry.
The course is entertaining enough. The exams aren't.
Too much math, not enough geology.
take this course
prereqs: At least single-variable calculus, preferably multivariate calculus..
descrip: A quantitative introduction to Solid Earth System Science, focusing on the underlying physical processes and their geological and geophysical expression. Topics include basic physical conservation laws, examples of constitutive relationships, waves, transport phenomena, geopotential fields, geologic time, basic thermodynamics and mineralogy. Single variable calculus is a prerequisite. The course serves as a prerequisite for several upper-level GEO and CEE courses.

title: Engineering Design
reviews: A design-based course is a nice change from crunching numbers and applying formulas from a textbook.  Start on group projects early, and make sure that people understand what they are doing long before picking an idea and modeling it.
Actually lab was really fun. I just think the project and grading were just stressful
Be prepared for a huge time investment.

Design is really fun at times, and other times feels like a huge burden. In the end, it's something you just have to get through. Machine shop is great- get to know Glenn well. Beware of this class being a huge timesuck during midterms week and Reading Period, so plan accordingly.
Don't take this course unless it is required for your major. If it is required, definitely adhere to a strict design schedule, and manage your time effectively.
Enjoy it, work hard and use Glenn and Gigi who are great resources
I loved this course.  Really make an effort to get fully involved in every aspect of the design and manufacturing process for both projects.  You won't regret it.
If you don't work well with others or feel the need to micromanage, you will be miserable. Otherwise it's really fun.
It'll suck in the process, but you do learn.
MAKE SURE YOU START YOUR PROJECTS AS SOON AS HE ASSIGNS THEM. ALSO, DRAW FBDs correctly.
Make sure you and your group are organized and plan carefully for your projects. It takes MUCH longer than you would expect.

Make sure you know exactly what Gigi wants for the projects, and keep in mind it might be different from the criteria he gives you. He will get angry if you try to exploit the criteria to get points for one aspect of the project. Talk to upperclassmen who have taken the class. Use lots of rivets. Don't use screws in Delrin, they won't bite. Don't let Glenn make steel hoops for you, they won't be real circles. Get a design down and set in stone 100% before you start manufacturing, which means you have to start designing SOON. Don't get on Glenn's bad side. And hope to God your projects don't fail, because you sure as hell can't put your faith in your design and manufacturing skills, sorry.
Plan ahead with the group projects- leaving stuff too late is a good way to have issues come deadlines.
Prepare to pull all-nighters. And Gigi, Glenn, Chris, the TAs are all great resources that you should definitely take advantage of.
Start early on projects, especially since the machine shop closes for the night.
Start projects early.
Start working on the projects early.
Start your projects early!
Take it if you need to. If you don't need it, it's a lot of work. Consider that.

The class really teaches you how things are made/manufactured. The projects really challenge you to be creative and test your ability to think under little guidance. Really fun class. The two projects require a lot of time.
Too bad, you have to take it.

You have to take it.  It's quite miserable since Princeton students are difficult to work with and everything you do is group work. You are not taught anything and are expected to do a lot and find your way. Just try to start early on the designs, don't overthink stuff, and push through. I really hope you enjoy it - it was literally the class I was most excited about and thus the major disappointment.

You really only take this course because it's a requirement of MAE. Not a terrible course, but the grading is a little harsh. Get moving on design projects ASAP. There will be issues and they will take time to resolve
You'll learn a lot of useful skills... Start early on the projects and budget your time well. When you design, think SIMPLE, not super fancy and complex.
good course, design is fun
start your projects as early as possible
prereqs: MAE 206, 221 and 222, and CEE205 or MAE 223.
descrip: This course introduces the technical foundations and basic processes of Mechanical Design, which are appropriate for the design of both mechanical systems, and components. The emphasis is on innovation, and designing for the complete product life-cycle. Topics in parametric design and design optimization are also presented. Basic techniques in Computer Aided Design (CAD) and Manufacturing (CAM) are first introduced in the classroom, and then reinforced and expanded in the laboratory.

title: Holocaust Testimony
reviews: Be prepared to talk about the Holocaust for three hours every week. If you're not that interested in the subject, this class will only depress you. But if you are truly interested in learning more about this time period, Prof. Trezise is very knowledgeable and we had some very interesting discussions throughout the course.
Definitely
Do the reading!

I would advise another student taking this course to do all of the readings before the seminar and to make sure to read very thoroughly. Because the reading load is not too heavy, the seminar really went in depth into the documentaries, comics, and books that we read.
Take it!!! You have much to learn
Take this class!
prereqs: At least one 200-level literature course is strongly recommended..
descrip: This course focuses on major issues raised by but also extending beyond Holocaust survivor testimony, including the communication of trauma, genres of witnessing, the ethical implications of artistic representation, conflicts between history and memory, the fate of individuality in collective upheaval, the condition of survival itself, and the crucial role played by reception in enabling and transmitting survivors' speech.

title: Policy Workshops - External Current Account in Macroeconomic Adjustment Process in Turkey
descrip: Following a period of robust economic growth during the last decade, the Turkish economy has entered a challenging phase in the last couple of years, most notably with regard to large external current account deficits, heavy reliance on imported inputs in the production process, and volatile capital inflows. The Turkish authorities have accorded a high priority to addressing these imbalances, and have tightened fiscal and monetary policies and have allowed the lira to depreciate to bolster external competitiveness. The workshop will focus on these and other measures to contain the external imbalances.

title: Independent Study II
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out independent study. Prior to course registration, students must complete a departmental Graduate Independent Study form that describes the work being undertaken, and have the form approved by the supervising faculty member and the Director of Graduate Studies. Usually taken in the Spring semester.

title: Second Language Acquisition Research and Language Teaching Methodology
descrip: Designed to provide future teaching assistants with the knowledge and conceptual tools needed to reflect critically on pedagogical practices in the second language classroom. Examines issues related to teaching language and culture in a university setting, highlighting the relationship between theory in Second Language Acquisition and language pedagogy and helping students understand the practical implications of theoretical frameworks in the field.

title: Analysis in Several Variables
reviews: I recommend taking this course if you are a prospective math major. For whatever reason, a ton of students skip this course. Don't do that. This will prepare you well for higher courses in the department.
Take it if you like theoretical math and want to get a super deep understanding of analysis (we don't learn to integrate, we just prove general theorems).

Take it! You get to learn cool things like how Stokes' theorem is trivial. I would definitely recommend this course to anyone who struggled through 215 or 217 and would like another shot at doing math. Third time's the charm!

If the course is taught from Spivak's Calculus on Manifolds, make sure to look online for a list of errata and ask the instructor plenty of questions. Sometimes Spivak could be clearer and other times he just plainly makes mistakes.

The class is more interesting in the second half of the semester.  Sometimes I wish I had skipped the course.  Its definitely possible.  It might require a little reading on your own time.  Its not as hard as 215 or 217.

This course can be kind of frustrating because it isn't necessarily stuff that turns out to be all that useful later on. Good for delaying taking the 300 levels though if you've got a tough sophomore year.
prereqs: MAT 215 and 217.
descrip: Rigorous introduction to calculus in several variables.

title: Intermediate French
reviews: Attend all classes and do all readings.
Attend class.
Definitely worth it. Fast paced but you really learn french!

Do no underestimate the course. Just because you may have already seen the material in high school does not mean you understand it at the level that is required of you. Consider French 103 if you are not pursuing French and just want to complete your language requirement.
Do the assigned homework every day because even though we may not go over it in class, it will be to your advantage to understand it indepedently.
Do the homework; even though it's not collected, it makes sure you're ready for the tests.
Hardly used the grammar books from labyrinth, just buy the course book from princeton.

I would advise another student to stay on top of all the readings and the grammar lessons, because falling behind is disastrous and difficult to recover from. All in all, I found it an excellent class for a student with a fair quantity of high school French experience.
I would advise them to consistently keep up with their vocabulary and practice their speech as much as possible.

I would advise them to really get engaged and try to participate in class, because you get more out of the course that way. It is possible to just sit through lectures, but half of the value of the class comes through engagement.
I would definitely take this course and if possible with this teacher. Obviously you have to for requirements anyway but it's not too painful.
I would only take this if you need to fulfill your language requirement or you just love french

If you have been taking French for at least five years but are still not that advanced, this is a great class. It seems a little like review, but it is very helpful for reinforcing everything and preparing you for the advanced class. Everything is very organized and the grading is very fair. Also, if you need any help, the professors are always there for you.
If you take this course, do not take it lightly because although the workload is relatively light, the grading can be harsher than you expect!
It is a somewhat boring and tedious course; however, the work is manageable and by no means impossibly difficult.
