It is easy to blow off the mini assignments you have to prepare for grammar or questions on mini readings because they're easy to do, but do them thoroughly and make sure you understand all the grammar as you learn it throughout the course it will make studying for tests and the final much easier. Also learn the vocab lists when you get them, some of it sneaks up on you on tests
Keep up with the homework and readings and visit a language table.
Since the class is grammar-based, it may require hard work to remember all of the rules.
Take it with Sagnier
Take this course! It's very easy; just realize that it's not as hard as you expect it to be. Take it with Madame Sagnier. Seriously, she is the best professor I've ever had.
The class is more helpful if you speak up in class.  Also, going to office hours are very useful.

The class itself isn't hard- the tests are manageable and the compositions are not too long. The rest is all participation and your level of comfort speaking French. If you're not comfortable speaking French yet, maybe try a lower level class.
This course largely focuses on French media and culture. Grammar and language are the secondary focus, yet the most important aspect of the final.
Try not to take this course at 9am. It hinders everyone's ability to participate and think clearly.
Try to take Sagnier's course if you can manage. I assume the other professors are just as good, but I can assuredly vouch for her!
do the homework it helps
take it if you need a review before taking other higher level classes
prereqs: Typically two to five years of high school French. Appropriate score on the Princeton French Language Placement Test, or special permission of the Placement Officer..
descrip: The main objective of this course is to develop your listening, speaking and writing skills, while allowing you to strengthen your knowledge of contemporary French society and culture. There is a thorough review of French grammar and a wide range of communicative activities chosen to improve proficiency and give practice of newly acquired linguistic material. The course aims at building your confidence in French, while giving you a foundation for the understanding and appreciation of French-speaking cultures and exposing you to their rich literary and artistic productions. A wide range of authentic material will be offered, including films.

title: Readings in Judeo-Arabic
descrip: An introduction to the reading of Arabic texts written by medieval Jews in the Hebrew script, especially documents from the Cairo Geniza.

title: Elementary Biblical Hebrew I
descrip: Students will achieve a basic ability to read the prose sections of the Hebrew Bible in their original language. During the semester, students will learn the script and the grammar, develop a working vocabulary, and read passages from the Bible itself.

title: Language Acquisition: What Not to Say
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Combinatorial Mathematics
reviews: Combinatorics is a great course. It covers a lot of interesting topics in the field (spending about a week on each), so you end up getting a broad overview of a bunch of different areas. The problem sets can be time-consuming, so make sure to start early! It's a really fun course though and Professor Van Zwam is a great lecturer.
Get a study group and keep up with the material on a weekly basis (as opposed to cramming near a test)

Survey of many areas of combinatorics. Fairly straightforward and incredibly engaging. The special topics this year were coding theory and matroid theory. Problem sets and exams were manageable, particularly compared with other departmentals.

Take the class. It's fun! 
Be advised though that it is not an easy class, and that while no specific prior knowledge is assumed, prior mathematical experience (i.e. familiarity and comfort with proofs and mathematical problem-solving, etc.) will be very helpful.

The problem sets in this class seem really hard at first, and you might be frustrated when you can't get very far on a problem. But after you solve the problem, you look back and think "Wow, that's so obvious! How could I not have thought of that for so long?" It happens every time! Pretty amusing. (In other words, the class is great. The problem sets are hard until you solve them!)
Work with others on the problem sets!
prereqs: MAT202 or equivalent..
descrip: Introduction to combinatorics, a fundamental mathematical discipline as well as an essential component of many mathematical areas. While in the past many of the basic combinatorial results were at first obtained by ingenuity and detailed reasoning, modern theory has grown out of this early stage and often relies on deep, well-developed tools. Topics include Ramsey Theory, Turan Theorem and Extremal Graph Theory, Probabilistic Argument, Algebraic Methods and Spectral Techniques. Showcases the gems of modern combinatorics.

title: Reading Literature: Poetry
reviews: Get started on the papers ahead of time. Ask questions if you don't understand any of the material.
Make a timeline to organize the poets, as we jump between time periods rather quickly.
My biggest suggestion would be that the students mark up their books and mark the pages on which the poems are on and pick a few favorites from each of the reading sets.
Take it with Stewart- she will make you love poetry!
prof. stewart is lovely, take the course and just listen to what she has to say!
you have to really love poetry to take this class
prereqs: Prospective concentrators are required to take ENG 200 and one course from the following: ENG 205, 206, 207, 208, 209. No laptops without permission because of disability..
descrip: This course will introduce students to the art of poetry written, spoken and sung in English over the course of nearly a millennium. Surveying forms as various as ballads and meditations, and writers from anonymous to the Beats, we will consider poetry as a form of beauty and a way of knowing.

title: Strategic Asia
descrip: Analysis of the recent evolution of strategic thinking in Northeast Asia with coverage linked to Southeast Asia, Central Asia, and South Asia. Comparative responses to common challenges: division on the Korean peninsula, the rise of China, the post-Soviet space, competition over new inter-regional ties, and a search for regionalism. Scrutiny of views over the past five years. Interdisciplinary approaches: historical roots of ideas about security, cultural assumptions behind strategic views, social networks and interests, clashing perspectives in political divisions, evolving international relations.

title: Neoclassicism through Impressionism
reviews:
A joy to P/D/F
A fair amount of work, with a very rewarding subject. As someone who studies primarily technical disciplines, it was a relief to come to class and enjoy wonderful art and the voice of Prof. Alsdorf.
Will be a fair amount of work if you don't P/D/F and want to get an A, though.
Absolutely take it!  The work and reading is of moderate quantity and always relevant.  Engaging professor, great material.
Attend lectures because they're great, do you readings because you need to do well on the exam, start your papers ahead of time so that you don't have to kill yourself.
Come to lecture!

DON'T DO IT. DON'T DO IT. DON'T DO IT. This course is for art history majors. I am PDFing the course, putting in as much time as I am for my other courses, and STILL running the risk of not passing. The papers and exams are graded ridiculously harshly (it's easy to get a D or worse), so just think carefully before taking this course (especially for a grade).

Definitely take this course if this time period and subject matter interests you in the slightest bit! Prof. Alsdorf is a phenomenal presenter, who structures her lectures cohesively and is very engaging. Both big assignments involve going to the museum, which should not even be considered a chore, and precept is often in the museum and involves critiquing and examining works of art. Simply put, a great class where you'll learn a lot and be excited to do so and a great eye-opener in understanding art.
Do it if you are remotely interested in the art of the period.
Don't take it unless you're willing to spend considerable time on the assignments. And go to lecture.
Excellent material, great lectures and professor...Just make sure you do not get Erica DiBenedetto as a preceptor.
Go to the lectures. Read instead of skimming the readings because they will help with the final exam.
Great course for anyone interested in history!
I LOVE PROFESSOR ALSDORF!! She makes every class feel like storytime. Do the readings for precept
I would recommend this class to anyone. I think it is a great opportunity to learn about a fascinating and very popular period of art history.

I would strongly advise anyone to take this course.  A lot of the art covered is already familiar to most people, which probably makes it a little easier for students who have never taken an Art History course before.  It is a great course!
I would suggest the course for people who would like an introduction to art history as a possible major (especially if they would like to learn about paintings that have become popularized)
If you like art history and know about art, definitely take it. But i think the grading is too hard for a non art history student.
If you love the material, you will still like this class despite its uninspiring delivery of information and the fact that it assigns overly pedantic/time consuming readings.
Interesting material and good lectures but a little too much work to justify taking it just for fun.

It's no walk in the park, the readings are intellectually challenging but stimulating and include a wide variety of sources.  Alsdorf's lectures are structured and organized and packed full of interesting material. TAKE THIS COURSE
It's not just looking at slides.

Make sure you leave ample time to read and digest the precept reading materials. (Textbook readings are not that important in terms of exam material). Do not skip lectures because they are informative and fun!
Pay attention during lecture.
Take it!
Take this class if you're interested in the subject. Don't think it's an easy art class though.
Take this course only if you are an art major and be weary of the preceptors.
This course is really fascinating. I didn't know just how much I was underestimating 19th century European art until after I took this course. It is my favorite course taken at Princeton so far.
Very good course! A bit heavy as a intro-level art class, however. Highly recommended for any one interested in Art & Archeology as a concentration.
YES, get Alsdorf as your preceptor
amazing class. you learn a lot and the professor is fantastic
do the readings!
pdf
take notes in precept because you will want to have specific notes from the reading to refer to on the exam.
what a great course
descrip: A broad study of European painting and sculpture from the French revolution to 1900 with special attention to art's relationship to social, economic and cultural changes. Lectures will explore a range of themes including art and revolution, the rise of landscape, shifting conceptions of realism, and the birth of "modernism" and the avant-garde. Emphasis on major figures including David, Canova, Goya, Ingres, Turner, Courbet, Manet, Monet, Degas, Rodin, Van Gogh and Cezanne.

title: Ornament Past and Present
descrip: This course has three aims: close encounters with some of the world's major traditions of ornament, close examination of issues that arise in the study of ornament and its history, and the cultivation of skills for writing about ornament. One troublesome issue is simply the problem of defining "ornament" (or "decoration"): is this anything more than a catch-all category for arts traditionally excluded from "the fine arts"? Themes for discussion include plant, animal, and geometrical ornament; space constraints as a stimulus to invention; and the relations between ornament and architecture.

title: Money and Banking
reviews: Definitely great material and very interesting, not too much work, but good if you have some background in finance.
Go through homeworks and make sure you understand every detail.
If Professor Haddad is teaching it, I wouldn't recommend the class. He is completely inept as a Professor.
Not a good course...
Take it if the same two guys are teaching

Take it!!! Every economics major should know the material covered for this course, and Prof. Haddad presents it really well! The course is really well organized, both the prof and the TA are wonderful and accessible.
Take this course. It was very interesting.
take this class if you want a brief overview of the basics in finance and banking
prereqs: ECO 300 or 310; ECO 301 or 311.
descrip: This course explores the role that money, financial markets and institutions, and monetary policy play in shaping the economic environment. We investigate why these markets and institutions arise and may lubricate the resource allocation analytically (rather than descriptively), using tools of economic theory.

title: Thermal Physics
reviews: 9.5/10, would take that.
A good introduction to a fascinating topic.
Go to the lectures; they're great. Take good notes too, because the book isn't that helpful.
If Huse is teaching it, see if he posts his notes online and use those to study from.

If you want to take a physics class, this is definitely something I'd recommend. It's not easy, but it's not the most difficult thing in the world, either. It has a lot of transferrable information, about statistics and probability, so there's that too.
It is difficult, but rewarding.  May be of interest to students outside PHY department due to the statistical mechanics focus differentiating it from other thermodynamics courses.
It teaches you the why behind so many thing I had wondered about!
Just make sure to keep up with the readings and lectures, then be ready to think for a bit on the problem sets.
Lots of work, but well organized and good course.
Prof. Huse does a great job of teaching thermal physics. The problem sets were long and final exam was pretty tough, but overall this has been my favorite physics class at Princeton.
Read the book closely, and review previous sections to see how they connect
Study.
Take it if you have to. Don't expect it to be the most interesting class you've ever taken here.
The lectures are great and Prof. Huse covered most of the important material. On the other hand, some of the material is a little bit dull.
The way the material is presented makes it much more interesting than it sounds from the description, and Huse is a great professor. Take it, even if you're not a physics major.
This is a very tough class, and solutions are often non-intuitive. I do not recommend to anyone who does not have to take it as a physics major.
You probably have to take this anyway if you are a physics major or doing biophysics. However, this is important and fundamental material that needs to be learned and understood. So there ya go!
the problem sets are lengthy, start as early as possible
prereqs: PHY 104 or 106; PHY 208.
descrip: A unified introduction to thermodynamics and statistical mechanics, both classical and quantum. Topics include heat engines, kinetic theory, black-body radiation, ideal Fermi and Bose gases and phase transitions.

title: Junior Seminar: Introduction to Classics
reviews: Of course, if it is a requirement, a recommendation for it may be a bit unnecessary, but I would still say that it is a class that students should be glad to take because it will definitely help with their independent research and their writing.

This course is fascinating and challenging, and is a great way to gain a more nuanced perspective on Classics.  I would recommend taking it!  You will gain more from the course the more you engage with the earlier texts and discussions; begin thinking about the different areas of Classics in relation to one another and in relation to potential independent work.
Well you have to take it anyway so there isn't much to say. I think Professor Holmes did an admirable job in teaching a class with no basis and think it will only get better with time.
descrip: This course will introduce concentrators to the study of classical antiquity. Students will become acquainted with different fields of study within the Department, including literature, ancient history, ancient culture, linguistics, and reception studies; gain experience in the methods of their chosen area(s) of study; and acquire an understanding of the history of the discipline and its place in the twenty-first century. Sessions will involve guest visits from members of the faculty. Particular attention will be paid to acquiring the skills necessary to pursue independent research and the selection of a topic for the spring Junior Paper.

title: Introduction to Nanotechnology
reviews: If you want to know current science, Take this
Take it.
This is a great, low-stress class. You will learn a lot about nanotechnology and improve your scientific reading, writing, and presentation skills.
descrip: This course will thus cover a broad range of subjects, with particular emphasis on characterization and control of materials at the nanoscale. The focus is on both the techniques necessary for scientific investigations at small dimensions, and the very latest research developments in this rapidly evolving area. Specific topics covered will include fundamentals of nanoscience, processing of nanomaterials, self-assembled nanostructures, bionanotechnology, graphene, nanoelectronics, size-scaling of properties, and nanodevice fabrication and testing. The course will also provide critical practice in scientific writing and presentation.

title: Topics in Ecology (Half-Term) - Integrating Modern Ecology with Pastoral Knowledge in East Africa
descrip: A major challenge in resource management, especially in an African context is the linkage between indigenous and local knowledge on the one hand and scientific knowledge on the other. This course will explore how to meld the two spheres of knowledge as they apply to rangeland ecology. One avenue will be to investigate issues of range management by using scientific ecological knowledge as a yardstick and compare its recommendations with practices informed by local and indigenous knowledge of mainly East African pastoralist societies.

title: The Law of Democracy
prereqs: Admission is by application only, with preference given to students enrolled in the American Studies certificate program. NOW TAKING APPLICATIONS FOR WAIT LIST ONLY. Applications are available outside the AMS office, 42 McCosh Hall, and at the website: http://www.princeton.edu/ams/undergraduate_program/seminars_1/.
descrip: Examines the interaction of law and politics. Topics covered will include the development of the right to vote, the Voting Rights Act, redistricting, the role of political parties, ballot access, election and campaign activities, recounts (including a review of the 2000 Presidential Election recount), and the regulation of money in politics. This course focuses on federal issues, but also will examine the States, including New Jersey. Students will receive theoretical and practical knowledge of the role that government and courts play in the political process and how that interaction affects campaigns, candidates, and officeholders.

title: Advanced Thermodynamics
reviews: Be ready to participate and try to 'think' while taking the course.
Figure out early which text Thanos is following most closely, and learn from that in preference to the lectures or lecture notes, since the organization of the lectures is pretty poor.

I would say to print out the book chapters and class notes before coming to class, and to follow them during lectures.  I would read along during the class and take notes in the book to clarify what is being written.
If you need advanced thermodynamics knowledge, this is the course !
Make sure to go over your undergraduate thermodynamics notes.
Make sure to read a lot outside of class, because Thanos may assume you have more knowledge than you do.
Need a good engineering background to have the proper intuition for problems.
Prepare for class and purchase additional textbooks. Stay on top of the reading--I would say it is more important to do that than getting an early start on the HW.
Print out the online lecture notes and take them to class.
Read the chapters before lecture.
Start the problem sets early and keep up with the readings or you will fall behind very quickly.
The course is time-consuming, but very insightful. I would recommend this course.
The instructor followed his book very closely; it would be helpful to either read ahead or follow along with the book while he was lecturing.
This is a very useful and interesting course. But the homework is reasonable heavy-load.
Those who are interested in thermodynamics should take this course. However, strong understandings in fundamental concepts are required to fully appreciate what is being taught in class.
Try to solve many problems in the textbook.
descrip: Derivation of the laws of thermodynamics starting from postulates based on everyday experience. Application of thermodynamic principles to the solution of practical problems in modern chemical engineering. Microscopic and statistical basis of thermodynamics.

title: Generalized Linear Statistical Models
prereqs: The course assumes prior exposure to statistics at the level of WWS507c and familiarity with matrix algebra and calculus..
descrip: The analysis of survey data using generalized linear statistical models. The course begins with a review of linear models for continuous responses and then considers logistic regression models for binary data and log-linear models for count data, including rates and contingency tables and hazard models for duration data. Attention is given to the logical and mathematical foundations of the techniques, but the main emphasis is on the applications, including computer usage.

title: Trade Workshop
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Intermediate Korean I
reviews:
I'm not a linguist; in fact, I hate most language with a burning passion. But I've come to genuinely enjoy Korean, mainly because of the amazing faculty here at Princeton. Professor Choi is funny, entertaining, and a great guy to get to know (during our "drill sessions," we usually discuss books and trade dating tips). He often shows us Korean dramas and other video clips in the middle of class, just for fun. He's also extremely dedicated and willing to go above and beyond -- I meet with him once a week individually, outside of class, because he noticed I was struggling. Mainly because of him (and Professors Suh and Yun from 101/102), I've actually gotten to the point where I can speak to relatives and they can understand me.

The one thing I would caution: I believe I'm the only person in the class who has NOT studied in Korea for an extended period of time. Almost everyone else in the class came in fairly fluent (many speak Korean at home), or were at least fluent in a similar language (there are many Chinese speakers in this class). Luckily, this class isn't graded on a curve. Also, with the creation of the native speaker track (KOR 103 -- also taught by Professor Choi), that might be less of a problem.

It is an intro level language course so be prepared to work.
Professor Choi makes it highly enjoyable though, and that helps a lot.
YESSS! Take this course! Professor Choi is really funny, and the class is chill but you also learn a ton!
amazing course! Prof. Choi is the nicest, sweetest, most supportive teacher ever and will answer all your 3am emails.
prereqs: KOR 101 and KOR 102 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Intermediate Korean is designed for students who have learned the basics of the Korean language and want to improve their competence to a higher level. Complex sentences and grammar are covered while the basics are reviewed. Balancing four language skills -- listening, speaking, reading, and writing -- is emphasized.

title: Studies in the History of Islam - Legal Categories and Social Realities
descrip: This seminar explores the relationship (or dissonance) between legal and social categories in the context of late Medieval Muslim societies. Some of the topics that we will cover in this context will be gender, slavery, religious minorities, ethnicity and hybridity, communal violence and concepts of transgression. Readings will include scholarly literature and Medieval Arabic texts.

title: Introduction to the Professional Study of History
reviews: Be prepared to engage questions about the assumptions that undergird history as a profession.
Do all the readings
Do the readings and come prepared. Always engage.

Enjoy the chance to take a course with students who have very different interests than you; I probably won't ever sit next to a Medievalist in class again, and the chance to hear how students in other areas thought about readings outside of their expertise was very interesting.  Having the chance to do so myself was also great practice for thinking historically even when I was dropped into a foreign country or time period.
Focus on what interests you most in the course, and get what you need from it.
I think the course is most suitable for students majored in European and American history to take.
It's a requirement...not the most pleasant one.  But it does give you some basic groundwork in historiography.
Take it.
Use it as an opportunity to get to know your cohort.
Very good opportunity for first year grads to review fundamental books that one should be familiar with and to get a broad view of the profession.
descrip: A colloquium to introduce the beginning graduate student to the great traditions in historical writing, a variety of techniques and analytical tools recently developed by historians, and the nature of history as a profession.

title: Modern Latin American Fiction
prereqs: A 200-level Spanish course above SPA 209 or instructor's permission..
descrip: "Las afueras" - This course focuses on the analysis of Latin American fiction that doesn't speak about Latin America, but about other times and places. Even if we tend to think that mainstream tradition of Latin American literature always deals with the problems of Latin American identity, there has been a strong tradition of Latin American literature that tries to take distance from its boundaries and explore other realities. The course will examine how many Latin American writers of the 20th Century had reinvented European and Asian traditions, and what their narratives show us about Latin America.

title: Independent Work
prereqs: This course is restricted to MAE concentrators. Non-concentrators may seek the approval of the MAE department to enroll..
descrip: Student selects subject and advisor - defines problem to be studied and proposes work plan. A list of possible subjects of particular interest to faculty and staff members is provided. Written report and oral presentation at end of semester to faculty, staff, fellow students and guests. Independent work is intended for juniors or seniors doing only a one term project. 339 Fall Term project; 340 Spring Term project.

title: Morality and Politics
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: From Berlin to Hollywood
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Reading Images
reviews: A very very interesting course for anybody who wants to  use French to analyze images.
Do your reading!

Professor Sagnier is my favorite French professor at Princeton.  She is encouraging and does a great job of making sure everyone participates in class.  I strongly recommend this course to anyone considering French. Best French course I've taken at Princeton.
Sagnier is worth taking a class with if you're a French student. She's tops!

Take this course!! Mme Sagnier is amazing. She's a huge reason why I signed up for the course in the first place; I'd taken a class with her before, and she was wonderful. The course itself is also very interesting, as it is a departure from the traditional literature/history courses offered by the department. The images we analyzed ran the gamut, from advertisements to propaganda to paintings, so you're likely to find something you're interested in for your final project.
This course is a great way to expand your French in a new subject area. It isn't too taxing and Professor Sagnier is super friendly.
prereqs: FRE 207 or special permission of Placement Officer..
descrip: Can images be "read"? In this course, we will study the visual as a reflection of culture and will draw on methodologies from a wide range of fields to examine images that try to persuade, shock, seduce or surprise us, and will learn to identify the various elements that are combined to produce meaning. We will examine different types of images and texts stemming from French culture, ranging from advertising to propaganda, political communication, cartoons, caricatures, and artwork.

title: Lyric Poetry of the French Renaissance - Imitation and Self-Identity
descrip: Conception and artistic realization of lyric poetry in France from the late medieval to the baroque.

title: Intensive Elementary Arabic I
reviews: Enjoy.
Highly recommend for students who have a familiarity with classical or dialectal Arabic, reading or speaking.
I would recommend taking this course, but only in the case that a student either has background in Arabic or is prepared to study more than usual in language classes.
Please make sure you are ready to be challenged and move at a fast pace. It is a great course but you have to put in the time and effort to master the language.
Review the material everyday for at least five to ten minutes. Those five minutes help tremendously.
Stay ahead and get a grip on everything you learn.
Take this course. It's better than 101
he is an excellent professor and very kind and fair man. you can learn a lot from him as a teacher and as a person.
prereqs: No credit is given for ARA 103 unless it is followed by ARA 104..
descrip: Designed for students who already have some familiarity with any dialect of spoken Arabic and/or students who have had considerable previous experience in learning languages. The course will emphasize reading and writing skills, as well as how to analyze grammar. No credit is given for 103 unless followed by 104.

title: International Macroeconomics
descrip: Issues in open economy macroeconomics and international finance. Topics include an exchange rate determination and dynamics, macroeconomic policy under fixed and floating exchange rates, current account behavior, exchange rate management and international policy coordination, and the history of the international monetary system. Special attention is given to the analysis of exchange rate crises. Prerequisite: 512c.

title: Plato and His Predecessors
reviews: Do the readings--ask questions
Don't miss it if it is taught by Cooper. However, it can be intellectually demanding.
If you want to take a philosophy this strikes a good balance between material that is demanding, but is not impossible to comprehend
Plato can oftentimes be very obscure, but Prof. Cooper is quite good at presenting a coherent argument on Plato's behalf.
Take it as a departmental or if you're interested about the material. If you're looking to get excited about ancient philosophy, though, I'd take a class with Morison first.
prereqs: At least one prior Philosophy course.
descrip: We shall investigate Plato's developing views on ethics, knowledge, metaphysics, and the nature of the soul, along with his perspectives on some of his predecessors (particularly Parmenides). We will read and discuss Plato's dialogues philosophically - for their philosophical content - rather than from a literary or cultural point of view.

title: Topics in 20th-Century Italian Literature - 20th Century Italian Fiction
reviews: Classes with Professor Frassica are the best - the class sessions are entertaining and the course work is interesting. The potential workload of the class depends how seriously you take your reading assignments.
Excellent, but you have to read one book a week if you can manage.
Great course with a fantastic professor.  The books assigned and seminars do a great job of covering trends in Italian history, and the course helps a lot with your understanding of Italian.

I would highly recommend it to any students taking Italian. Students should try to take more than the required 3 semesters of the language so that they can take a class like this. It's definitely worth it.
If you speak Italian, definitely take it.
Take it!
prereqs: ITA 107, ITA 208 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: The course's goal is to analyze the Modern movement in Italian fiction from 1900 to the present, particularly as it reflects various responses to social, political and cultural problems of the period. The following topics will be examined: Fascism in literature; literature of neo-realism and its relation with films, and neo-capitalism; the protest movement of the 1960s and '70s, and the new outlook for the '80s, '90s, and beyond.

title: Mechanistic and Physical Organic Chemistry
reviews: Great course, but be aware of how much hassle going to class for 3 hours at night is going to be.
I'd recommend that future students read along in the textbook during the class to cement the knowledge covered in lecture.
Read the relavent chapters in the book before taking classes
Stay on top of the material and don't hesitate to ask questions about the assignments.
Very valuable information is taught in this class. Take it, particularly if you're an organic chemist.
start homework early and go talk to prof
descrip: This course covers the fundamentals of physical organic chemistry to provide the students with a thorough understanding of chemical reactivity. Within the framework of organic reaction mechanisms, the class will discuss a number of topics, including the essence of structure and bonding, the anture of reactive intermediates, and the use of kinetic measurements and isotopic labeling studies to decipher chemical mechanisms. Grades will be based on problem sets, a mid-term, and a final exam.

title: Topics in Romanticism - Romantic Passions
descrip: "Romantic passions" is a key term that juxtaposes the erotic and the religious, the bodily and the transcendental. To get a purchase on the full range of human passions, Romantic-era writers developed some extreme types, among them the fanatic, the convert, and the pervert. We will explore these types in works that push the envelope of form and twist the sinews of genre. Students are encouraged to consider the legacy of these types in contemporary culture. Two ninety-minute seminars.

title: Introduction to Physical Oceanography
prereqs: MAT 202.
descrip: The study of the oceans as a major influence on the atmosphere and the world environment. The contrasts between the properties of the upper and deep oceans; the effects of stratification; the effect of rotation; the wind-driven gyres; the thermohaline circulation.

title: Critical Trespasses: Theorizing Political and Intellectual Borders
descrip: This seminar structures an encounter with theoretical writings about nation, subjectivity, power and culture, which are assembled for their relevance to "East Asia." The collection is not meant to be comprehensive, but is intended to facilitate discussion of work that has shaped and revised active intellectual traditions. It starts with reflection on "area studies" as an academic discipline and move to considerations of national identity and nationalism. It proceeds to a study of power through psychoanalysis and "neo-Marxism." Finally, it turns to practices - writing, media, technology - that embody and inflect these conceptual formations.

title: Responsible Conduct of Research (Half-Term)
descrip: Examination of issues in the responsible conduct of scientific research, including the definition of scientific misconduct, mentoring, authorship, peer review, grant practices, use of humans and of animals as subjects, ownership of data, and conflict of interest. Class will consist primarily of the discussion of cases. Required of all first year graduate students in the Department of Psychology. Open to other graduate students.

title: Middle High German Literature - An Introduction
descrip: Introduction to Middle High German language and literature 1100-1300. Selections from Arthurian romance (Parzival, Tristan), epic (Nibelungenlied), lyric poetry (Minnesang), and mysticism (Meister Eckhart, Mechthild von Magdeburg). Additional readings on history and culture also examined.

title: Introduction to Differential Geometry
reviews: A very nice pace for very nice material!

I think do Carmo is easy enough that you could actually pick it up and learn it, especially with the teaching the way it is at the moment. Gang Tian's really a genius, though; it's a shame there isn't a harder course he could teach that would be accessible by undergrads.

Not recommended if the textbook stays the same (do Carmo's Diff Geo). Could be vastly improved if the textbook was changed to one without ridiculous numbers of typos (google Bjorn Poonen's list of errata for Do Carmo), and the problem sets actually tested ideas THOROUGHLY.
On the whole, an easy and relatively undemanding class, but perhaps not the most gratifying.
The class is a good introduction to geometry and has some interesting material.
prereqs: MAT218 or equivalent..
descrip: Introduction to Riemannian geometry of surfaces. Surfaces in Euclidan space, second fundamental form, minimal surfaces, geodescis, Gauss curvature, Gauss-Bonnet Theorem, uniformization of surfaces.

title: Biophysical Chemistry I
descrip: This course provides a comprehensive introduction to basic principles of macromolecular structure, stability, and interactions. Major topics include protein structure; protein thermodynamics and folding; nucleic acid structure and stability; principles of intermolecular recognition; and principles and practice of ligand binding analysis. Special emphasis is placed on understanding, in macromolecular systems, the relationships between structure and stability; the molecular origins of cooperative effects; and the relationships between covalent and non-covalent properties.

title: Integrative Dynamics of Animal Behavior
reviews: Definitely do the readings after lecture to get a sense of what is important/what isn't necessary. If you are having trouble, do reach out to Professor Couzin -- he is very open and willing to meet with students and answer any questions or mitigate any concerns you may have.

Don't even think about taking Professor Gould's class over this, you'll learn so much more with Professor Couzin. Not just about animals and their collective behavior, but about how collective patterns emerge at every level of biology. Really, it's such a fascinating course.
Fascinating subject material presented by a great and enthusiastic professor.
Great course
Great overview of current research topics in animal behavior, especially if you are interested in modeling or group behavior. Very interesting content.
I would definitely recommend this class as I found it very interesting and worthwhile.
I would suggest taking this course if you enjoy the subject matter.
If you want a really up-to-date perspective on animal behavior, take this class.

If you?re an EEB major, you definitely want to take this course to get a feel for a modern approach to animal behavior. However, I strongly recommend to non-EEB majors as well due to its large breadth and relevance to many different connected areas such as psychology and even politics. Lectures are intriguing and Prof. Couzin is a dynamic teacher.
It is a very interesting class
It's a lot of work

Professor Couzin is a very good lecturer and the subject matter is really interesting. It's not extremely well organized, but it you're good at taking notes and keeping yourself organized then you'll be completely fine.
Really great course! Takes steps beyond neuro classes and more interesting and applicable than EEB 311.  Professor Couzin is an awesome lecturer.
Take advantage of break time to bounce ideas off of Prof. Couzin!
Take it with Couzin in a heartbeat...hard to beat his style of lecturing and the topic is just great...by the way, cookie breaks every class?  Amazing.
Take it!
Take the course! It is amazying and interesting.

Take the course! You will not regret it. The subject material is fascinating and you get to learn the latest in the field. The lectures are very well explained and prepare you for the midterm and final. The readings simply complement the material so pick and choose what you read. The precepts were a ton of fun. And the final term paper was quite rewarding since we had the chance to delve into a topic of our choice. Wonderful course!
This is a very, very interesting and fun course. Couzin is an amazing lecturer. Great course, highly recommended.
Very interesting and well-taught class.
You learn a lot of things you wouldn't even think you'd want to learn or that you even knew you could learn about.  If you're in EEB take it, if you're not take it for fun anyway.
neutral
take it. very interesting material and not a lot of work.
descrip: This course will explore the fundamental principles that underline the evolution and mechanism of animal behavior. Animal behavior naturally crosses scales and disciplinary boundaries. This course will integrate our understanding of behavior with information from neuroscience, evolution, physiology, genetics, and the biology of complex systems.

title: Network Society: Global & Local
descrip: http://www.princeton.edu/pub/frs

title: Jewish Messianism from Jesus to Zionism
reviews: I strongly recommend this course.
Take it if you're at all interested in Jewish history, especially if you want a big-picture look.
descrip: Since its origins in the Hebrew Bible, messianism has motivated Jews from ancient heralds of the apocalypse to modern Zionists. It has been reinterpreted by rationalists and mystics and has spawned sects in virtually every century of the past two millennia. Intellectual and social movements as diverse as Marxism and Iranian Mahdism have roots in Jewish messianism and Christianity began as a Jewish messianic sect. With an emphasis on a close reading of primary sources we will explore the unfolding of this idea in its vastly different historical moments and social contexts, providing a window onto 3000 years of Jewish history.

title: Accounting for Taste
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Advanced Arabic I
reviews: Decent for what it is. Classes can become dull, but your Arabic will improve.
Don't take it at 8:30 am.
I would suggest that students be prepared to put in the required hours outside of class in order to benefit as much as possible from this  class.
It is necessary to work on Arabic outside of the class if you want to continue improving your language skills by third year Arabic.
Take the course, it is a great foundation for moving on to higher level fusha Arabic or study of dialects.
This course is a must for any student wishing to develop further abilities in Arabic and better confidence in using them.

Ustaadh Greg is a really great teacher. If you want a course that is less grammar and more reading/speaking, this isn't the course for you. But if you're looking to solidify and expand your formal knowledge of the language and you don't mind Al-Kitaab then take this course.
You get from this class whatever you put in.
descrip: Readings from modern Arabic works; systematic study of syntax; speaking and composition. Main text book is al-Kitaab II.

title: Environmental Chemistry
reviews: DON'T
Environmental engineers who have not taken organic or environmental chemistry before should take this course.
I fully recommend it if interest in environmental topics, but make sure to have some physico-chemistry background, otherwise it is very challenging.
This course does not really describe how to solve or remediate environmental problems but does build the framework for partitioning and other thermodynamic problems very well.
take it if you will do some research on environmental chemistry
descrip: In this course, environmental chemistry serves as a vehicle for study of chemical thermodynamics. Students will gain an understanding of Gibbs free energy, chemical potential, and fugacity, and the universal applicability of thermodynamics to environmentally relevant topics such as equilibrium phase partitioning and oxidation of organic chemicals. There will be a focus on toxic organics and their chemical properties. Assignments will be based on chemical property estimation methods and on simple mass balance models that link chemical properties with pollutant transport, fate, and reactivity in the environment.

title: Solid-State Physics I
reviews: Expect to be challenged.
Good course. Important for anyone interested in fabrication technology.
It will take some time, but it is a good course
It's an necessary course to the one who wants to work in EMD. It's a good course which I'd like to recommend to others.
Read all of Kittel's Solid State Physics at your own pace before taking the course; chances of mastering the material first time through, especially under the given time constraints, are slim.
This class is quite difficult. Think long and hard about taking it, unless of course it's a requirement or something. In that case, brace yourself.

This is probably going to be one of the hardest courses you've ever taken. Get alternate textbooks for when A&M seems too mathematical. Kittel is your friend, and Marder is a godsend if you're inclined towards the hard sciences.
This was a good course - it didn't go too fast and still covered a good amount.  Take it if you're interested in solid state physics.
Very good physical approach to solid state at the introductory level.
prereqs: ELE 342 or PHY 208 and PHY 305 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: An introduction to the properties of solids. Theory of free electrons--classical and quantum. Crystal structure and methods of determination. Electron energy levels in a crystal: weak potential and tight-binding limits. Classification of solids--metals, semiconductors and insulators. Types of bonding and cohesion in crystals. Lattice dynamics, phonon spectra and thermal properties of harmonic crystals.

title: Creative Writing (Literary Translation)
reviews: Take it! Choose challenging passages for translation
This is a fascinating course that helps you appreciate the under-appreciated art of the translator.
This is a very relaxed, enjoyable class. Professor Muldoon is wonderful, and it is a pleasure to hear and learn form others in such a small workshop setting. Definitely recommend!
prereqs: This class is open to any student with fluency in a language in addition to English, by application only. Students apply with either 3-4 pages of original literary translation, or a paragraph explaining why they would like to take the course. See the Creative Writing Program webpage for application information. Please note that this course cannot be audited..
descrip: Practice in the translation of literary works from another language into English supplemented by the reading and analysis of standard works. Criticism by professionals and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature. Students MUST be fluent in their chosen language.

title: Topics in Mineralogy and Mineral Physics - Physics and Chemistry of Earth Materials at High Pressure
descrip: Selected topics related to structure, properties, and stability of minerals and melts. Topics include mantle mineralogy, applications of synchrotron radiation to the study of earth materials, physics and chemistry of minerals at high pressure and temperature, and advanced concepts in mineral physics. The emphasis is on applications to the study of planetary interiors.

title: Independent Work with Design
prereqs: This course is restricted to MAE concentrators. Non-concentrators may seek the approval of the MAE department to enroll..
descrip: Course similar to MAE 339-340. Principal difference is that the project must incorporate aspects and principals of design for a system, product, vehicle, device, apparatus, or other design element. Written report and oral presentation at end of semester to faculty, staff, fellow students and guests. Independent work with design is intended for juniors or seniors doing only a one term project. 339D Fall Term project; 340D Spring Term project.

title: International Politics
descrip: This course introduces competing theories of international relations and evaluates their explanation of foreign policy decisions and general patterns in international relations over the last century. Broadly covering security policy and international political economy, topics include the causes of war, the role of international organizations to promote cooperation, and the interaction between domestic actors and governments in negotiations on trade and the environment.

title: War in the Modern Western World
reviews: A great history course, the readings are for the most part relevant and engaging and Bell is a good lecturer. Very little work outside of reading, and the paper and exams are not difficult; the exams will require you to write a lot in a very short amount of time, however.

Absolutely take this class. If you just need an HA, it's perfect: not a whole lot of work but really interesting material. If you're more seriously interested in history, you can also get some real knowledge out of this course. Take it, take it, take it.
Be prepared for a lot of reading and memorizing. Also, only take this course if you are interested in military history.
Be prepared for a lot of reading.
Definitely take this course. Attend every lecture.
Do the readings. They matter, and are worth reading anyway
Do your best to stay with the readings.
Good pdf, 1 paper, 1 midterm, 1 final. Final has a terms list so that shouldn't be too bad.

Great course if you're interested in learning about history of modern war since medieval ages. However, it is a lot of reading every week and sometimes felt like we were covering too much material in the allotted time. Really enjoyed the lectures and precepts though!
Highly recommend taking this course.
I would avoid this one unless you have enough time to read 250 pages a week of material (that can be quite dry at times).
I would recommend this course to anyone with an interest in the history of war.

Interesting material, good preceptors, great lecturer, and fairly easy (lots of PDFs mean that even doing 50-75% of the reading puts you way ahead), means that I would highly recommend this as a good HIS class to take for anyone with a passing interest in warfare.
Lots of work, tests are hard. Good class
Perhaps not the best PDF course because of the reading, but otherwise a fantastic course with Professor Bell. highly recommend. learning about military history is awesome.
Prepare to read. Take only if you enjoy the subject matter.
Tak it, its fun and interesting.
Take it -- it's grrrrreat!
Take it if you are interested in warfare and the military, but do not have Christina Welsch as your preceptor.
Take it if you're interested in the topic.  You won't be disappointed by Professor Bell.
Take it!
Take it!  For a 300 level history, it doesn't involve too much writing, and the readings are almost always interesting even if you don't really know any of the context.

Take it! You probably don't have to do all of the readings, as long as you go to lecture and pay attention in precept. The readings will enrich the course, but the class is interesting enough on its own. A really fascinating look at modern military history through a multifaceted lens.

Take it! You'll love it. It takes a lot of work to study for the midterm and final, but there's not a lot of work besides those. If you keep up with the readings, you'll be in good shape. Professor Bell is a great lecturer and makes you appreciate the evolution of military history.
Take it. Lots of reading, but its very cool
Take it. Professor Bell is great (and likes the material) and if you are interested at all in military history/technology, or even just general Western History, this is the class for you.
Take it. The course material is incredibly interesting

Take this class. If you're a history major, it should be a requirement. It's a huge survey of so many interesting aspects and will give you a great sense of what you would like to concentrate it. If you're not a history major, only take this course if you're willing to do the work, which is a lot, because that's how you'll get the most out of it. It's fascinating and David Bell does a great job at lecturing.

Take this course if you have some familiarity with western European history already and want to go into specifics of tactics, weaponry, etc. Otherwise, PDF it. It's a lot to cover and requires a lofty time commitment, but is certainly an interesting class.
Take this course.  Exceptional.
The readings were fascinating and should be done when time permits, but not worth stressing over, other than that they are the topic of precept discussion.
The span of the course is intimidating, but the material is very interesting and definitely worth the effort.

This course focuses on a different conflict/battle every week.  There are lot of assigned readings each week (~200 pgs) so be prepared to spend a lot of time reading for only a few take-aways.  But that's the nature of history courses, I guess...

This course gives a very thorough review of war in the "modern western world" and I would highly recommend to anyone willing to put in the time to complete all the readings and engage with the material.
This course is not an easy course. You have to pay attention in lecture (as in, go to all of them, awake, and take notes) and you have to be willing to put in the time to do the readings.
This is a really interesting course, however it is rather heavy on reading and the lectures move very quickly.

This is a very interesting course that provides a unique perspective regarding war. Not only is war seen from the perspective of a general, but the soldier's viewpoint is also addressed. Recommended if you're interested in history or think you would like to learn more about battles.
This is the class to take to get rid of the HA distribution. The subject matter is always interesting and thought-provoking, and this is a great class to take.
Worth taking if you think the subject material will be interesting.  Puts modern warfare in context within the last 500 years.
interestinb
take it but expect it to be a lot of information
yes definitely! professor bell is awesome. but lots of reading, you'll need to budget your time for.
descrip: A survey of the history of war in the Western world since the late middle ages. Will cover both "operational" military history (strategy, tactics, logistics, mobilization, etc.), and also the relationship of war to broad changes in politics, society and culture.

title: Legal and Regulatory Policy Toward Markets
descrip: This course employs the methods of microeconomics, industrial organization and law and economics to study where market failures warrant gov't intervention with policies implemented through the law or regulatory agencies. Topics include antitrust policy toward business practices and vertical and horizontal combinations; policy approaches toward R&D and intellectual property; reliance on tort law, disclosure law, and regulatory standards to mitigate information and externality problems pertaining to health, safety, and performance risks; and the implications for pricing, entry, and investment of different forms of public utility regulation.

title: The University: Patron of Architecture or Rapacious Developer
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Quantitative Analysis
descrip: Statistical analysis with applications to public policy. The course begins with an introduction to probability theory followed by discussion of statistical methods for estimating the quantitative effects of changes in policy variables. Regression methods appropriate for the analysis of observational data and data from randomized controlled experiments are stressed. The basic level (507B) assumes a fluency in high school algebra and some familiarity with calculus, while the advanced level (507C) assumes a fluency in calculus.

title: Radical Innovation in Global Markets
reviews: Absolutely take this immediately if possible.

Add this as a 4th or 5th course. If you're into technological innovations and/or public policies, this is a very good course. Not very workload heavy except for a couple of write-ups and the final pilot.
Definitely take it!

Definitely take this course if you're interested in business and public policy. The material in the class is different from other classes at Princeton, and it's definitely a refreshing change in your schedule.
Do take this class if you're interested in entrepreneurship and technology!

Drop everything else and Take It! This class will actually make you feel  (after you're done with it) that you can think logically through problems. You'll also meet some really cool people. Don't be shy to speak in class but also speak only if you have something interesting to add. Who cares if anybody thinks you're being a motormouth? The material is interesting. Go for it!
Good, straightforward, interesting class!
Grading sucks.
I would very strongly recommend against it, and advise taking GEO499 or some other related EGR 400 class instead.

If you are interested in learning about the real world decisions that corporations need to consider, take this course. You can draw decision trees all you want, but you will never know how they apply to business and innovation until you take this course.
N/A
Professor Shinn offers very valuable insight to innovations and the companies and political bodies involved. Take it.
Take it! You'll make great friends with diverse interests while also meeting those who have similar tastes as you in terms of academics and world developments.
Take this class. Professor Shinn is amazing. Best class I have taken so far in Princeton.

This is an excellent and interesting course (arguably the most interesting I have taken here). However, the class could have been better if we were given more frequent grades over the course of the semester. As of Dean's Date (there are no exams in this class), the only grades we received were assignments that as an aggregate made up 20% of our grade. Also, we weren't given a grade for our midterm paper, which seemed a little odd. Thus, final grades may come as a surprise.
This is really a great course. Professor Shinn is awesome, you learn some valuable skills, and you especially gain a lot from great conversations with the brilliant students that are in the class.
Watch out. It's more work than you think, and it's the type of busy work ( doing decision-tress) that you may not get as much out of.

You do have to put in a fair amount of time preparing the cases for this class, but I think it's worth it. The final project is to write a case of your own with your team, and it's pretty manageable. Overall, this course was really useful for me because I was exposed to a wide array of career options, and Professor Shinn gave great advice. I would highly recommend it.
need to have interest in technology
really interesting class, but it's hard to know where you stand grade-wise in the oourse
prereqs: A background in engineering, computer science, or the life sciences is helpful but certainly not required..
descrip: Radical innovation solves big problems and alters the way we live, colliding with government polices as the effects ripple across national frontiers. Where do these innovations come from, how do they work, and what policy problems do they cause? This class examines the impact of technical innovation on a global scale. Students learn how innovations in areas such as satellite imaging, global positioning, internet search engines, and pandemic vaccines have a profound impact on foreign policy. Students learn to think about innovation from the standpoint of business managers, government regulators, social entrepreneurs, in very practical terms.

title: African American History from Reconstruction to the Present
reviews: Compare readings, lectures and precepts to get a good grasp of themes, topics, categories, etc.

DEFINITELY take this. Prof Guild is awesome and funny and just such a cool guy, and the material is so important -- things that everyone in America should learn if they want to understand our country and the way it works. Cannot recommend this enough.
Definitely take this course. You learn an incredible amount of information and Professor Guild is really interesting and helpful.
Go to lectures and understand the major themes associated with each week's readings.
Great introduction to African American history. This is a survey course that goes way beyond just the surface of the material, as some survey courses do.
I would not suggest students take this course unless they are receiving an AAS certificate.

I would recommend the class if you want a general look into African American history. What this class did well was introduce us to several unknown African American trailblazers through their first hand accounts of situations. I'd say that the reading is pretty fair compared to other history classes. Professor Guild put the page count for each week in the original syllabus so you would know what weeks would require more time.
I would suggest this class, but be prepared for a lot of reading each week
If you have any interest in AAS, I strongly recommend the course. The reading is manageable and all the material is compelling.
Interesting class on the topic of African American studies. The readings were very interesting and the topics of lecture really made me think differently about American History.

Keep up with readings and you will find this course very rewarding. If you have never studied African-American History before (like me), expect to be confused at times by the large list of names and institutions, but don't let that put you off. This is a varied and exciting course.
Make time to do the most relevant readings first, then work on the rest of it.
Professor Guild is a great teacher, and its such an important subject. A morally invigorating class where you actually learn something.
Read the readings. Check Blackboard daily. Treat everything like a test
Stay on top of all the readings and blackboard postings.
TAKE THIS CLASS!!!
Take it early in your college career
Take this course!!
Take this course- you will be challenged and learn a lot.

Take time to read the introductions in Let Nobody Turn Us Around if you struggle with jumping directly into the primary sources. Always try to connect new information with the ideas you have already encountered.
Would strongly recommend, but do not take if you cannot handle diverse viewpoints
if you would like an interesting and encompassing overview of African American history, this is a great course.
descrip: This course offers an introduction to the major themes, critical questions,and pivotal moments in African American history since emancipation. It traces the social, political, cultural, intellectual, and legal contours of he black experience in the United States from Reconstruction to the rise of Jim Crow, through the World Wars, Depression, and the Great Migrations, to the long civil rights era and the contemporary period of racial politics. Using a wide variety of texts, images, and creative works, the course situates African American history within broader national and international contexts.

title: Intensive Portuguese
reviews: Absolutely take this course, if not just for Professor Cooney!
If you speak another language, take this over POR108
If you think you can handle a fast-paced course and have the Spanish to back it up, go for it by all means

TAKE THIS COURSE! THE MOST AMAZING/FUN COURSE I HAVE TAKEN IN MY FOUR YEARS AT PRINCETON. Never a dull moment. You will learn so much and you will surprise yourself with how much Portuguese you are able to speak, read, and understand by the end of the semester. Best decision I could have made for my senior fall.
Very past paced, a lot of work at home, but incredibly fun and valuable.

You should be willing to dedicate time to the learning of the language.  There is a large amount of material to cover at a fast pace.  In order to take advantage of the program of the course you should keep practicing outside of class, which is only twice a week.
descrip: An intensive course designed for students who have fulfilled the language requirement in Spanish or another Romance language. Knowledge of one of these languages provides the basis for the accelerated learning of Portuguese. This one-semester 'crash' course teaches fundamental communication skills--comprehension, speaking, reading and writing--and some exposure to cultural aspects of the Portuguese-speaking world, but does not offer an in-depth study of grammar.

title: Networks: Friends, Money and Bytes
reviews: Be sure to really read/watch the lectures before class. It really helps. Also, don't be shy to say that you do not understand a concept presented - the math can be very non-trivial and if you do not understand it, it can be difficult to understand its role in other material (for example, matrices) since the course follows a very interwoven roadmap.
Don't take.
Easy, interesting, and worthwhile. Make sure you focus on the final project.
Excellent survey course that introduces you to lots of interesting topics. I will warn you that there is a lot of math in it, but it's not difficult math. The professor is really great and engaging.

Go all out for your project because it might just develop into something you're a) really proud of, and b) probably going to be able to use for future work, e.g. theses and JPs. Take advantage of the TAs and don't be afraid to ask lots of questions.

I enjoyed the class a lot, but there was a lot of outside work. The final project was a pretty big endeavor, especially because there was a long report and a presentation about it. If you don't want to spend a lot of time outside of class, I wouldn't recommend it.

If you think it sounds interesting I would say take it. Material/homework/exams aren't too hard and the project has potential to be something really cool that you can continue working on after the class if you want to. Flipped classroom is annoying though. It doubles class time for the week, and lecture is completely useless. Also, read the book instead of watching lecture videos.
It's pretty awesome! Don't coast though, it's a waste of an awesome class if you don't take it seriously.
Take this - though be aware, the weekly problem sets are quite difficult.
The material is pretty interesting, and it's nice to know that some pretty technical concepts can be explained, at least on the surface level, using fairly basic math

This course declared itself in the first year in an "experiment" with reverse classroom, and boy did it show.  The entire curriculum was presented as a hodge-podge of trivia,  guest lectures, linear algebra,and TA demos.  My recommendation: wait until this course has figured out what it is doing before enrolling it.
This is an interesting course on applications of networks in everyday life. If this is an interest to you, take it. But know the flipped classroom will affect it.

This was the best course I've ever taken and I highly recommend it. Mung is a great lecture and the course content is remarkably intersting. What really took this course from excellent to perfect were the TA's: Chris (head TA), Michael, and Arpan. They spent SO much time on the course and actually cared about it. Don't hesitate in the slightest to take 381.
prereqs: Knowledge of calculus and linear algebra..
descrip: This course is oriented around 20 practical questions in the social, economic, and technological networks in our daily lives. How does Google sell ad spaces and rank webpages? How does Netflix recommend movies and Amazon rank products? How do I influence people on Facebook and Twitter? Why doesn't the Internet collapse under congestion, and does it have an Achilles heel? Why does each gigabyte of mobile data cost $10, but Skype is free? How come WiFi is slower at hotspots than at home, and what is inside the cloud of iCloud? In formulating and addressing these questions, we introduce the fundamental concepts behind the networking industry.

title: Civil Society and Public Policy
reviews: I feel neutral about this course.

I would strongly recommend this course. Professor Katz is very knowledgeable and you will end up learning a lot about civil society and society in general. I would recommend staying on top of readings as this will ensure that you really benefit from the course.
Professor Katz is a great professor and the material covered in this course is very interesting.
Start the term paper early and pass in several drafts.  You will get valuable feedback.
Take it.

Take this class for Prof. Katz.  I lot of Professors pay lip service to the notion of caring about their students, but it is clear from Day 1 in his course that Prof. Katz's means it.  He is tremendous resource on this subject and also about social science research more broadly.  My only regret is that I didn't take the class earlier in my Princeton career.

This is a good class if you are interested in civil society, though what you get out of it seems pretty dependent on how much of the readings you actually do. If you don't think you will be motivated enough to do the readings, then you might not get much out of the class.

This is a great course if you are willing to do a lot of independent work. Definitely meet with Professor Katz outside of class to discuss your research project, and come to class with specific topics from each week's reading that you would like to discuss so that you have valuable things to contribute.

Very interesting topic that I don't think would be covered in other classes at this school. Professor Katz has offers a wealth of information and resources and is happy to discuss any academic interest with you. Classes can be slow depending on the weekly topic, but some more topical issues  led to great discussion, led by a wonderful professor.
descrip: Civil society is the arena of voluntary organizations (churches, social welfare organizations, sporting clubs) and communal activity. Scholars now tell us that such voluntary and cooperative activities create "social capital" -- a stock of mutual trust that forms the glue that holds society together. The course will be devoted to the study of the history of these concepts, and to the analysis of their application to the United States and other societies. This will be an interdisciplinary effort, embracing history, philosophy, anthropology, sociology, and other disciplines.

title: Knowledge and Travel
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Advanced Physics (Mechanics)
reviews: 105 is for physics majors, or someone who really wants a challenge. Very satisfying as a course.
Attend the Wednesday night problem set sessions.
Be prepared to spend a very significant amount of time on problem sets.
Be prepared to tackle the problems and think a lot during lectures. But if you are someone who wants to be challenged, then take 105.

Be prepared to work hard. Though, if you attend lectures, spend time reading through the textbook over and over, and getting a fundamental understanding of the concepts in the course, you'll be sweet.

Be prepared to work very hard if you haven't had AP Physics C in high school (and even if you HAVE from what my friends say). The course is very rewarding and interesting if you like knowing how formulas come to be.

Definitely consider taking this course.  It was my second hardest class but I was able to adjust after a while.  The homework problems are quality and each one will give you a deeper understanding of what you thought you knew.  Good for physics majors and general interest students alike.

Definitely give it a try if you are deciding whether or not to major in physics. Be prepared to work very hard throughout the semester and grapple with some very challenging concepts, but once you are done, you realize you gained a lot from the experience.
Definitely work hard from the start. Do the readings in the book instead of just reading the notes from your class. Practice your problem solving skills daily.
Do the readings, go to the Wednesday problem sessions. They'll keep you from pulling allnighters on Thursday.

Don't be discouraged if you do not do well initially. There may be some students who seemed to have a stronger physics background, but this course's topic goes so deep that eventually everyone's knowledge is normalized. This course will give you a whole new perspective in physics.
Don't take this course if you are good at physics. Lobby to skip into 205

Go to the wednesday night problem sessions. Try to have looked at the problems before the session if possible, so you can spend that time figuring out how to attack the problems and not doing algebra.
I definately reccomend this course for students seriously considering physics as a major.

I loved it. I loved it, and I am not doing too well. I for my part would say, don't worry about the grade, if you really like physics, strongly consider 105. 

The problem sets are tough, but amazing. All the problems are hard, but so beautiful in themselves, you really grow on them.

Do not fall behind. Try to actually do the readings before class, it will help you a lot in understanding the material. 
Go to office hours, often and many! That's what they are there for!
Also, form a study/problem set group. For me, this was vital. Find a set a people and have regular problem set meetings, it will be helpful. And don't be afraid to ask questions, most likely, everybody else is just as confused as you are.
I recommend this only if you are truly interested in physics. Otherwise the class will be frustrating.
If you need to take it for physics.

If you really and truly enjoy physics, take it! If you think you do, take it! However, be ready to work very hard unless you have seen the material before. It was certainly the highlight of my semester.

If you're a physics major, take it.  If you're a prospective physics major, take it.  If you think you're good at physics, but not a physics major, stay away from this course.  You will most likely get destroyed.  Of course, if you truly love physics, who cares, right?

If you're really set on physics, just take it. Otherwise, you might have some hard time, but it's manageable. It wasn't my favorite, but I definitely learned new things, and I liked being challenged. Go to problem solving sessions.

In my opinion, this class is for the brave, and even above that, a class for the INTERESTED. You must wish to know the WHYs of physics to benefit from the rigor of this class and its assignments/lectures/examinations.

It's a really good course. Material is challenging, of course, but doable. Everything gets better after gyroscopes. Take it if you're interested in seeing a more conceptual presentation of the material and are appreciative of first principles.

It's easy to fall behind, because (unless you know a great deal of physics for a freshman) there is plenty of studying to be done each week. It's sometimes easy to skimp on the studying and still turn in a decently done pset. However, this will hurt you for the exam. Try to stay on top of things.
It's not too hard, really.
Only if you really like physics.
Recommend for anyone who wants to go the extra mile in physics. If you have limited background in physics, it will be a challenge, but mainly a mathematical one.
Take it if you like mechanics
Take it if you really like physics.

Take it to see if you want to major in physics. If you don't get an A, you probably don't want to. Put in work for an A. Otherwise you'll probably get a B. It's really not an incredibly difficult course.
Take it. Physics is what dictates the workings of our entire world.
Take the course. It definitely demands more of your time and effort, but is well worth it in the end.
Take this course but be ready to work hard.

The class was a really good one--intense, but very worthwhile if you want to be a physics or astro major and feel like putting the time, blood, sweat, and tears in.  I met some really cool people through it, too, and never found anyone competitive.  Frankly, the class was just too hard to do it entirely on your own.  I got a lot out of it, and sort of felt like I could tackle and intellectual bear right before the final.  (In actuality, the final tackled me.)

The course is very interesting but difficult. Be prepared to spend a lot of time in problem sets every week. You learn a lot if you like physics. Take 103 if you are not so interested in physics. But maybe if you take 105, you are going to develop strong interests in physics?

This course is challenging but very rewarding.  You walk away with a much greater understanding of all the physics concepts you learned in high school.  I believe that even with AP credit, every engineer should take this class to build a solid foundation for engineering.
This course is not as hard as it is made out to be, though you do need to put in a lot of work to understand the material and to do well. The labs are terrible--boring and unhelpful.

This course is not as tough as many people say. I would suggest going to office hours more because I regret not having taken advantage of it myself. Otherwise, it would be no different than just self-studying.
This is a difficult course that hurts your grade if you don't have much physics background.
This is a tough course, but if you pay attention and do the readings and homework, you will learn amazing amounts of physics and have a lot of fun.
This is a very challenging course. Please make your decision between 103 and 105 very very carefully.
This is a very difficult course.  Only take it if you have a decent background in physics and strong problem solving skills.  However, if you can handle the rigor, you will really enjoy it.
This is definitely a hard physics class, and a good one.

This will likely be the hardest class you take fall semester.  If you don't have two or three years of physics and higher level calculus from high school, don't take this class.  It will be a rough ride, regardless.  So study hard if you really are thinking about being a physics major.
