Very challenging course, take if you really like physics and preferably already have a good grasp over it.
Will take quite a chunk of your time per week, depending on your previous exposure to advanced physics. Take only if you really love physics, or if you're awesome at physics.
Wonderful class if you're interested in physics and love tricky problems.

You might enjoy it, if you're the kind of person who loves hands-on physics and doesn't expect a very good grade. If you're more inclined towards the theoretical and mathematical side of things, you'll be very frustrated when you do poorly on exams because you drop a constant somewhere. If you want to study physics, you have no real choice whether to take it, even if you don't plan on majoring in the subject. 103 is probably almost the same in terms of what material you learn and the tests won't make you cry as much.
prereqs: Good mathematical aptitude required - students should be taking MAT 104 or higher concurrently. Students do NOT preregister for PHY 105. Instead, sign up for PHY 103 and select C03 or C04..
descrip: PHY 105 is a first-year course in mechanics, taught at a more sophisticated level than PHY 103. The approach of PHY 105 is that of an upper-division physics course, with more emphasis on derivation and the underlying formal structure of physics than one gets in 103, and with challenging problem sets due each week. Though we get excellent physics majors from both 103 and 105, PHY 105 will give you a better sense of the flavor of the more advanced courses in the department.

title: The Female Literary Tradition
reviews: A really excellent course surveying over 200 years of literature by women writers, of all sorts of different backgrounds, nationalities, races, and classes.  All of the very different books we read were extremely thought-provoking and beautifully-written, and it was a delight to compare and contrast them all year long!
Definitely take this class if you're interested in a deeper analysis of gender and women in a field that has traditionally excluded them.

I looked forward to this course every Thursday. The usual workload was a book a week, but discussion about it was always engaging and interesting. The environment of the seminar is a very comfortable one and we felt free to engage in a wide variety of ideas and topics related to the book.
If you like reading, it is a great class.  Don't take it unless you feel up to talking about books for spans of three hours at a time.
N/A

There is a fair amount of reading and the grading is not super generous but if you're interested in the material this is a very good class. The seminars themselves were definitely a highlight of my week-- the three hours passed very quickly and Professor Nord and Arianna did an excellent job of keeping the discussions interesting and relevant.

This class was great, but challenging--try to avoid it if you're taking 5 classes because of the sheer amount of reading. PDFing is a great option if you love the reading list but are nervous about participating in class. Though it was difficult for a non-English major/non-GSS certificate student, I'm glad I took the chance of sticking with it! Professor Nord is awesome.
don't take it.
descrip: The course will survey a range of novels by women writers from the early 19th century to the present. How is the "tradition" transformed by post-WW II globalism, the geography and politics of empire, by differences in nationality, class, religion, and sexuality?

title: Media and Public Policy
descrip: Introduction to communications policy and law, covering such topics as freedom of the press and the development of journalism; intellectual property; regulation of telecommunications, broadcasting, and cable; and policy challenges raised by the Internet and the globalization of the media.

title: Education, Freedom and Equality
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Socialist Experiment and Its Legacies, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Corporate Restructuring, Mergers and Acquisitions
reviews: Do not take the course if you care about your grades or fairness. Take the course if you want to learn some tangible lessons about the real world. One lesson upfront: the world is not fair!
I strongly recommend this course to students with a deep interest in corporate finance.
descrip: This course applies topics from microeconomics (ECO 305) and corporate finance (ECO 318) to study corporate restructuring. Topics include mergers, acquisitions, joint ventures, divestiture and share repurchases. Each of these is discussed in the context of the relevant economic theory, institutional and regulatory environment, and with a focus on shareholder value. Meets concurrently with ECO464.

title: Probability Theory
reviews: A course very worth taking.
A subject that really is worth studying and putting a bit of extra time into.
Great course. Everyone who needs probability knowledge should take it.
I recommend this course to every student who is interested in stochastic model. Anyone can learn a lot of things from this coruse. I believe.
It is a good course. And you have to spend a lot of time on it if you want to learn it well.
Make sure you follow along with the material.  Review the notes after each lecture so you can ask appropriate questions at the next lecture.
Read more than required.
Revise Real Analysis and read up on Measure theory.
This is a great alternative to Sinai's probability theory class. See this page: https://blogs.princeton.edu/mathclub/guide/courses/prob-stats/ for an in-depth review of this course.
descrip: Graduate introduction to probability theory beginning with a review of measure and integration. Topics include random variables, expectation, characteristic functions, law of large numbers, central limit theorem, conditioning, martingales, Markov chains, and Poisson processes

title: Seminar in Modern Spanish Literature
descrip: This course will explore the priviledged and complex place occupied by "Spain" in the imaginary European Romantics (particularly in France and Germany), as well as the debates in Spain with regarding the reception of European Romanticism. Topics explored will include Spain and Orientalism, historicism and the emergence of national canons, Spain's Romantic reinvention of its literary traditions, particularly its Medieval and Golden Age traditions, Romanticism and gender, Romanticism and race.

title: Climate: Past, Present, and Future
reviews: It was usually interesting.
The professors are very willing to help, so make use of this resource.
This course is a great STL or STN for students not pursuing the sciences and needing to fulfill a requirement.
keep up with readings
prereqs: High School Calculus.
descrip: An introduction to the processes and conditions that control Earth's climate; an overview of past climate evolution from the time of Earth's origin to the period of human history; and an investigation of ongoing climate changes and those predicted for the future, including the capacity of human activities to alter climate and the impacts of climate change on environment and society. Intended primarily for students not concentrating in science or engineering. 102A: three lectures per week

title: Policy Workshop - Elections and Conflict in Sub-Sahara Africa
descrip: This workshop will conduct an examination of electoral conflict in Africa. Recently, electoral conflict has occurred in Zimbabwe, Uganda, DRC, Southern Sudan, and Nigeria and other locations. The PW will provide a methodology to profile electoral threats and examine steps which have been taken to reduce such conflicts. Success stories such as those of South Africa and Angola will be examined. The group will identify a couple of potentially conflict-prone elections occurring in 2013, and the students will design an electoral security plan to prevent, manage, or mediate electoral conflict in those elections.

title: The Soviet Gulag
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Electromagnetic Field Theory and Optics
prereqs: PHY 103 and PHY 104..
descrip: This course should provide the students with a broad and solid background in electromagnetics, including both statics and dynamics, as described by Maxwell's equations. Emphasis will be on basic engineering principles, and applications will be discussed throughout. Examples include cavities, waveguides, antennas, and fiber optic communications.

title: Directing Workshop
reviews: I'm not sure how much I really learned about directing. It was fun and Tim is great, but don't expect to come out with vast knowledge you didn't have before.
If you like directing you'll take this course no matter what - it's really interesting skill and worth trying if you like theater.  The class is imperfect

If you want to learn about directing, and you are willing to put in some strange hours outside of class to rehearse your projects, then take this course. If you do not want to direct or if you have trouble dealing with criticism or if you have trouble working with others or if you have a serious problem with scheduling midnight rehearsals, then this is probably not the class for you.
My previous statements should show that this class is fantastic. Whether you are a director, actor, musician, etc., this class pushes you to truly access your individual creativity.

This class requires a lot of active participation and teaches a variety of different ways of directing, ranging from adaptation to pure movement to imagining an entire production.  A good course for students who are willing to work hard and respond well to criticism.
prereqs: Prerequisites: THR 201 and by permission. Please contact Professor Tim Vasen (tvasen@princeton.edu) for enrollment permission..
descrip: Special directing assignments will be made for each student, whose work will be analyzed by the instructor and other members of the workshop. Students will be aided in their preparations by the instructor; they will also study the spectrum of responsibilities and forms of research involved in directing plays of different styles.

title: Studies in the Religions of the Americas - Religion and Church in Mexican History
descrip: This course explores important questions in the study of religion and church in Mexican history. Readings will focus on the colonial era but will also include some 19th and 20th century material and some theoretical and interdisciplinary approaches to the study of religion in Mexico. Topics will include: religious conversion; religious institutions and religious practice; clergy and laity; gender and sexuality; race and spiritual status; and local and lived religion. The course is designed to give graduate students a strong beginning foundation in Mexican religion as a primary or comparative teaching and research field.

title: Microeconomics Analysis (Accelerated)
descrip: Course covers many key concepts from microeconomic theory, including consumer and producer theory, competitive markets, market power, information and contracts. Emphasis of the course is on developing a formal, model-based treatment of these subjects and applying them to various relevant policy issues. The course is intended for those students who are already familiar with microeconomic concepts (at the level of 511c) and have an appropriate level of mathematical proficiency, including knowledge of multivariate calculus (including constrained optimization), basic probability, and some familiarity with linear algebra.

title: Muslims and the Qur'an
reviews: A very good course to take!
Absolutely take this class if it fits into your schedule
An interesting course of the sort you might take just to learn about something you've never been exposed to. Not the best course ever, but a solid one, and Professor Zaman is amazing.

Be prepared for more reading than you expect for an intro-type course: 150-200 pages a week on top of other work is a lot. If you're the type of person who never does the readings, though, you'll probably be okay just going to lecture.
Definitely take it if you have any interest in Islam, and go to lecture!
Don't overestimate your knowledge of Islam and its teachings coming into class.
Great EM. Don't be discouraged from the quizzes and responses.

I highly recommend this course no matter what your needs:  whether a departmental, a distribution requirement, or simply an interesting class, this one has it all covered.  Of course, in the latter case, it helps to have a prior interest in religion in general or Islam in particular.
I would recommend it. It gave a good overview of many aspects of Islam without getting too specific on any one topic. It was a great introductory course I thought.
If you are interested in learning more about the Qur'an, Islamic religious traditions and the different schools of thought, you should take this course.

If you are interested in religion or in learning about Islam, DEFINITELY take this course.  Professor Zaman is a very organized and great lecturer and precept for this class was my favorite here at Princeton.
If you are interested in the material to start with yes, not for a class on a whim
If you have no previous knowledge of Islam, fear not! This course gives you a fantastic introduction to the topic. Professor Zaman is FABULOUS. I really recommend this course.

If you still need the EM distribution requirement, I would recommend this course. And even if you don't, I would still recommend it. I learned a lot about an interesting (and important!) topic I wasn't familiar with and didn't have to give a Herculean effort to do so. That's more than you can say about a lot of writing classes.
It is a very good introduction course. You really need to put together what you learn from lecture and what you learn from the readings together.  Take the written assignments seriously.
It was a very good basis and introduction to Islam but to succeed one needs to stay on top of the readings which can sometimes be difficult.

It was an interesting class. I think most people have almost no knowledge of the subject matter, and a lot of us could benefit from learning more about Islam.

Go to the lectures. The readings are of an obvious level of importance, but the lectures summarize the themes and put them in a valuable perspective. If nothing else, hear what professor Zaman has to say.
It's not overly difficult. The readings can be kind of substantial. Just talk in precept.
It's not too bad.

Make sure to complete the readings, as they will greatly help you in precepts, response papers, and the midterm and final. Also, you will leave the class with a greater appreciation for the subject matter and the lectures, as they are truly informative and absorbing.

Particularly for those who don't know much about Islam, this is a great introductory course with a manageable work load (there were times when the amount of reading was excessive for me, but I am a slow reader)
Please do all the readings, this is a well-designed and informative course, and Zaman should not have to explain everything in such great detail if you do your work.
Professor Zaman is knowledgeable and kind. I would only take if you have a serious interest in the subject, otherwise I can see the  lectures and readings becoming a bit boring.
READ ALL READINGS!
Take it!
Take it! Zaman is a brilliant professor. You do not need to know anything about Islam - interest and consistent work are all that is required.
Take the course.. It's alright and you'll learn a lot about the Middle East.
Take this course if you want a good history of how Islam has been shaped by its surrounding cultures.
Take this course. Great way to get your EM requirement out of the way. Prof. Zaman is great and the work load is very manageable. A good fifth class.
Take this course. Professor Zaman is one of the best lecturers at Princeton, and the subject matter is interesting and pertinent to current events.

This class was poorly organized, should have included more introductory readings or included more primary sources and been a 300 level course, and ultimately really turned me off. This is the only class for which I have ever routinely skipped lectures, because they were not meaningful
This course is a very well taught course, and may be more worthwhile as a distribution requirement over a very large Philosophy course.
This really helps give a background for a lot of the issues that have shaped Islam into what it is today.
This would be a great class to PDF and would require little effort.  GO to the lectures, they are great.  Also, if you are willing to put in a bit of work, it's VERY easy to get a good grade.

You won't get A's on all the reading responses it seems. But thoughtful, well written essays do get rewarded i think. But the class in general is great. I was going to PDF it but then decided I was interested enough in it to not want to do that.
great EM requirement. Originally was going to PDF, but didn't have to.
descrip: A broad-ranging introduction to pre-modern, modern, and contemporary Islam in light of how Muslims have approached their foundational religious text, the Qur'an. Topics include: Muhammad and the emergence of Islam; theology, law and ethics; war and peace; mysticism; women and gender; and modern debates on Islamic reform. We shall examine the varied contexts in which Muslims have interpreted their sacred text, their agreements and disagreements on what it means and, more broadly, their often competing understandings of Islam and of what it is to be a Muslim.

title: Beginner's Latin
reviews: Definitely take it. You learn a lot in one semester.
Even if you've never taken any latin before, this is a very manageable class. Even if you've taken some latin before, this class is a great way to sharpen your grammar
I would definitely recommend this course, especially if you're interested in beginning Latin or enjoy studying ancient cultures. Make sure to get Kaster as your professor, though!
If you have any passing interest in Latin at all, take this course.
Make sure you learn the vocabulary!
Pay attention in the class, memorize the vocabulary a little bit every day, and go over the grammar in the book.
Professor Kaster is very approachable and presents the material in a clear and helpful way.  I would absolutely recommend this class to anyone who want to pursue the study of Latin.
Take it

This is a great introduction to Latin. Having a basis in ancient Greek made the grammar concepts easier to grasp, but I think the class would still have been great if I didn't have the Greek, albeit more challenging.

This is a great introductory course that covers many aspects of the language well. Do not take it if you do not plan on devoting extra time to the nuances of this ancient language, but it is an interesting class to take.
This is an effectively taught latin course

Very awesome course. Great for students looking for a foreign language requirement and for those interested in learning how to read ancient Roman texts. Professor Kaster is a phenomenal professor... you need to take a course with him while at Princeton!
You need to be sure you have the time to spend around 2 hours on it per night, since it is difficult but fun.
prereqs: No credit is given for LAT 101 unless it is followed by LAT 102..
descrip: An introduction to the basic grammar, syntax, and vocabulary of Latin designed to enable students to read and understand simple Latin prose and verse.

title: Intermediate Czech I
descrip: After a thorough review of the basics of Czech grammar, we will continue to explore more advanced topics (word formation, verb aspect, syntax, etc.) while reading challenging but rewarding works of Czech literature, both prose and poetry, and watching Czech films. Added emphasis will be placed on speaking and writing about these works (and other topics) in Czech.

title: Topics in International Relations - Terrorism, Civil Wars and Non-State Threats
descrip: This seminar is devoted to understanding (1) forms of political violence other than interstate war and (2) how policy makers can (and sometimes cannot) take action to ameliorate the threat from non-state violence. Course requires careful reading of 1-2 policy statements and 2-3 moderately technical articles each week on topics including: terrorism, the causes of civil war, the duration and cessation of civil war, the transition from violence to democracy, violence and social order, economic development and violence, the institutional structure of insurgent organizations, government violence and expropriation, revolution, and ethnic violence.

title: Advanced Macroeconomic Theory I
reviews: Read only the papers you consider relevant
Should take this course if you are interested in Macro or any ecnomics in general.
Take it.
descrip: Topics vary from year to year, reflecting current developments and the instructor's interests. Topics covered in past years have included methods of numerical analysis and econometric testing of equilibrium business cycle models, the role of monetary and fiscal policy in inflation determination, the nature of optimal monetary policy, dynamic games and time consistency in macroeconomic policy formation, central banking, and the theories of price stickiness.

title: Rebellion and Recognition
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website

title: Algebra I
reviews: Algebra is a brilliant topic to study, and I really enjoyed group theory. As always, be prepared to spend 10-15 hours on the problem sets. Also, make good use of office hours and study groups. You kind of have to take this if you're a math major, but it's a highly rewarding course.
Be prepared to spend a lot of time.
Claudiu is awesome!
Claudiu is awesome.
Definitely take it.

I really enjoyed the material and Claudiu is fantastic. However, not being a math major, it felt like quite a lot of work (10 problems/week) and I had a hard time maintaining it alongside other commitments - this might just be me.
If you are a math major I recommend this class
If you want to learn Algebra, take the course. If you're just curious or something ... you should probably take something else (try Topology or Graph Theory---though beware the curve on that one.)
If you're taking it you (probably) have to. Otherwise, think twice.
Listen to what the professor says, and try to understand it asap. Do not be afraid to ask. GO TO OFFICE HOURS.
No good reason to take it unless you're a math major. Not worth the time and effort. The class was taught extremely well, though.
Only take this course if you really need to or you know that you are really, really interested in Algebra. Otherwise, it's a lot of hard work and tears over nothing.

Since doing the problem sets requires playing around with the objects you learn about for quite a long time, it helps to get started at least thinking about them early so that they aren't foreign when it comes time to really crunch down on the homework.
Take advantage of office hours, talk with the professors, and read in advance because the lectures do not have enough time to go over everything.
Take it

Take this class only if you are interested in algebra or have to. The class moves quickly and covers a lot of material. The problem sets each week took me 15  hours. I feel like most of the students already had extensive proof-based backgrounds, experience in math contests, or background in number theory or algebra. I highly recommend reading an algebra book over the summer to prepare if you don't fall into one of the categories above like me. The course also gets significantly harder in the second-half of the semester and can be a challenge. Fortunately, you can work with other students and attend problem sessions for help
Take this class, I think it is critical as an introduction to more advanced Algebra.

Take this course if you are interested in learning group theory. I thought it was fun but it might not be very relevant to later courses and you will still have to take 346 to get into higher level classes.
There is a fair bit of work, but if you are interested in algebra this is a good choice. It is quite well-taught.
This is a very challenging course.  The problem sets take a lot of time, so plan accordingly.

This was an excellent course with a great instructor.  Abstract concepts were always illustrated with concrete examples.  The amount of work was certainly reasonable, maybe slightly on the heavy side, at least for a non math major.  I recommend this course for physics people as an introduction to algebra, which is essential for theoretical physics.
descrip: This course will cover the basics of symmetry and group theory, with applications. Topics include the fundamental theorem of finitely generated abelian groups, Sylow theorems, group actions, and the representation theory of finite groups.

title: Species Counterpoint
reviews: Be prepared to compose a lot. Ask anything.
Be prepared to spend a long time on the weekly assignments! Not for the faint of heart.
Essential for a solid understanding of counterpoint.
Find someone to check over your work because they may catch things that you may not have seen before.
I hope you can sightread...it's very specific to one style of music.  So if you're not a huge counterpoint fan, it could get pretty boring.

Professor Trueman is a wonderful professor, and you should take a class with him if you can. This class might sound dull, but you get to sing and compose a lot of great music, and it's surprisingly fun.

This class is an intense course about how to write 16th Century counterpoint, which is of course not interesting to everyone. However, to anyone interested in music theory or classical music in general, it is a really interesting and rewarding way to experience the roots of all of our music today.
You probably won't take this class unless you are a music certificate or major, but even so it's quite interesting, fun, and not too hard.
beautiful music and trueman is a boss
dont take it if you arent interested in this kind of thing- its hard, and a lot of work, but very rewarding if this is your jam.
it's difficult material but ... if you're stuck taking it for departmentals just hold your breathe and dive in.
prereqs: MUS 106 or permission of instructor.
descrip: To lay the foundations for a thorough understanding of the principles of linear structure and voice-leading through the study of species counterpoint. Twice weekly exercises will lead to a complete 4-5 voice Mass Movement as a final project.

title: Socrates
reviews: 101 and 102 suck compared to 105.  Your future is bright, Young Hellenists!

Bourbouhakis expects a lot out of you especially in the first weeks where the translation can take a great deal of time (1.5-2 hours every night) but by the time you're in the middle of the semester your Greek is much better and the preparation can take less than an hour each night. So it's a lot of work but you do learn Greek.
Definitely take!
Enroll.

I would advise getting an additional grammar reference. Smyth takes a while to navigate, and it is not a book you want to carry around in your bag all the time. Get a smaller intermediate grammar book to keep with you.
If you enjoy reading Greek, take this class. Plato and Aristotle are brilliant minds and I greatly enjoyed receiving instruction on their works.
Take the course and do independent work in the areas where you need it. Only you can make yourself learn a language.

This class can be really challenging. Having a firm basis of ancient Greek grammar is very useful as it allows for smooth translation. Without review of grammar and vocab you are likely to have good days and really bad ones.

This course is a relatively solid part of the intro Greek sequence. It is really cool to be able to read real Greek, and your translating skills will greatly improve. Do your best to keep up with assignments, though if you fall behind, it is possible to catch up. Definitely look up vocab before class.
Unless you are very secure in your high school coursework in Greek take 101.
prereqs: CLG 102 or CLG 103 or permission of instructor..
descrip: A close reading of Plato's "Lysis" ("About Friendship") intended to improve students' facility in reading Greek prose.

title: Seminar in Political Theory - Machiavelli and Modern Political Thought
descrip: The main goal of the seminar is to offer students the opportunity to explore the historical meaning of Machiavelli's thought in the context of modern political philosophy. Special attention will be dedicated to refine the interpretive skills and to learn to avoid the most common misinterpretations that have historically affected the comprehension of Machiavelli's ideas.

title: Constitutionalism 3.0
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: 20th-Century Japan
reviews: A good pick for the asian requirement in the HIS department. I would not have taken it otherwise.

A really great way to fulfill a distribution requirement, or if you're at all interested in Japan.  Professor Garon is a great lecturer, and the paper gives an opportunity to concentrate on a specific topic.
A very interesting and entertaining course for anyone interested in East Asia. Highly, highly recommended.
Awesome class, take it with Garon and pray that Reut will be your preceptor. Garon supposedly only talks about his books during his precept, and social contracts are kind of boring...
Definitely take the course, it's just great.
Do the readings and use your preceptor as a resource for the paper
Do the weekly readings.
Don't miss the lectures
Great course. Breaks down all the stereotypes one might have about Japan (especially as an American) and really dives into all aspects of society

I would highly recommend this course. Be prepared for a good amount of reading, but if you are interested in the subject matter, this class will be immensely interesting. Especially with the research paper pretty much being on anything you want, you can explore whatever aspect of modern Japan you please.
If it's offered again, definitely take it. Just be prepared to read a lot.
If you have any interest in modern Japan, take it.
If you're at all interested in Japanese history, take this course.

It's a great course. Japan's story during this time period is fascinating, and the readings are pretty good as well. I PDF'd it, and found it to be a satisfying PDF, though a ton of work if you do decide to do the readings.
It's an interesting class, but definitely the most stressful one out of my semester.
Take it!! Great way to get your non-western req out of the way if you're in history, super interesting if you want to learn more about Japan or WWII or Asia.
Take this course, especially if you know nothing about Japan.  Fascinating material, amazing lectures.
Take this course. If you need an HA or just have extra time and want to learn about Japan, this course is super. The exams and papers aren't hard if you go to class and pay attention.
Take this if you're interested in Japanese history, or Asia in general. There are a lot of surprising similarities with other Asian nations. And Japan is a fascinating place.

This is a wonderful history course. Professor Garon is very passionate and very knowledgable. This is not a "easy" course in that there is a lot of reading and thus you should, and need to be, engaged. If you are interested in history and are curious about Japan, take it.
This pairs well with interests in politics, trans-national history and History of American Capitalism.  It's very transferrable to knowledge of other areas of the world.
Very entertaining lecturer.

Very interesting course if you are interested in Japanese history. However, there is quite a bit of reading to do. Nevertheless, Professor Garon is a great lecturer. Exams are very broad based. Take this class seriously because there is a lot of work.
go to lecture
descrip: The course provides a general introduction to Japanese history from 1890 to the present, with emphasis on Japan's rise as the modern world's first non-Western power, imperialism, industrialization, social change, gender relations, democracy, World War II, the U. S. Occupation, state management of society, the postwar "economic miracle," and the preoccupation with national identity in a Western-dominated world. In the final weeks, we will think about post-1945 developments in terms of continuities with (and divergences from) the prewar and wartime history of Japan.

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - Interactive Music Systems
reviews: A great course, probably my favorite at Princeton so far. A must-take for anyone interested in computers or music.
Definitely take it. Really fun course.
Especially if your interested in that topic this is a great class. I've enjoyed every class, the students in that class were great and the instructor also did a wonderful job.
I would first describe the course and what takes place during each class. If the student decides he/she wanted a course similar to this, I would tell him/her to look no further.
If a similar course is taught again, I would definitely recommend you enroll in this course surveying computer music research, regardless if your background is more in computers or music.
If you are at all interested in learning more about digital music interfaces/instruments from a slightly more technical perspective than COS/MUS 314, then I would recommend this course.
If you're interested in computer music, take it!
If you're interested in music technology, definitely go ahead and take this!
Make sure you have time in your schedule to read and think about all of the papers (~4/week).
The reading and responses seem a lot in the beginning, but they really help you become a better reader.  The responses become quite easy by the end of the course.
descrip: Exploration of challenges in designing, deploying, and evaluating interactive human-computer systems for music composition, performance, education, entertainment, and research. The foundation of this reading- and discussion-oriented course is current academic research in computer science and computer music; course also discusses significant artistic works and relevant commercial systems. Course culminates in a research or software development project of the student's choosing.

title: Hebrew Bible and Ancient Israel
reviews: Approach the texts as a scholar, not a believer.

I wasn't particularly interested in the material to start with, but Prof. Meshel is so enthusiastic and knowledgeable that it's hard not to enjoy it. It's definitely a great way to fulfill the HA requirement as a non-humanities person.

Meshel is a really engaging professor and keeps the class interesting for sure. However know its a more literature-based type class more so than a straight up history class, so you know what you are expecting
Speak up in class, and study details for the midterm.

Take if you're interested, a lot of reading but you will learn a lot about the Hebrew bible. Given that, Professor Meshel is a very enthusiastic and approachable professor and loves what he does, which really shows in the lectures and makes a difference.
Take it if you have interest, or even if you don't. You will learn a lot about a book that obviously bears much importance in this world of ours.
Take it take it take it. Very interesting HA, professor Meshel is hands down one of my favorites.
Take it!  Professor Meshel is awesome -- one of the best teachers here in my opinion -- and the subject material is quite interesting as well.  Well worth the work you put in!

Take it! It's one of the best classes I've taken at Princeton! Prof Meshel is entertaining, funny (especially when he mumbles to himself), very good at drawing approximate maps, knowledgeable, accessible, caring, engaging, etc. He makes the subject matter incredibly interesting. That being said, if you believe in the Hebrew Bible (which I do), this class does raise quite a few difficult questions, so keep that in mind. Also keep in mind that this class primarily offers one perspective (of course more since you read from other scholars) but still. Also not too much work. Very good class, would definitely recommend it!
Take it, it is engaging. Also the class alters the way the bible is read in a very healthy and natural way.
This is an awesome course. Meshel is now one of my favorite professors.  The material is incredibly interesting, and he is always really excited about it.
descrip: A critical introduction to the Hebrew Bible in its historical, ideological and intellectual setting within the ancient Near East will be offered. Central problems in Biblical studies will be addressed, e.g., the historical value of Biblical narrative, the documentary hypothesis, and the process of canonization. A selection of texts from the Hebrew Bible will be read in class (in translation) from a broader, comparative point of view, including the narratives of the Deluge and of Samson and Delilah, the pentateuchal dietary laws, and the poetry of Song of Songs.

title: Global Exchange in Art and Architecture
descrip: Examines the global exchange in art and architecture between and among the continents of Europe, Asia, Africa, and the Americas in the period 1492-1800. The course focuses on the geographical, historical, religious, anthropological, and aesthetic aspects of issues such as cultural encounters, diffusion, transculturation, regionalism, and related topics.

title: Psychological Studies of Inequality (Half-Term)
descrip: Two major areas of psychology make important contributions to the study of social policy and inequality . The first is social psychology, which focuses on inter-group relations, interpersonal perception, stereotyping, racism, aggression, justice and fairness. These are the micro-level building blocks of structural inequalities and processes that are shaped by the larger context of race, ethnic and gender relations. The second domain involves the fields of social-cognition, judgment and decision making , areas of research that study human information processing in a way that is not about individual differences, and often not social.

title: Chemical Oceanography
reviews: Great! Don't miss it if you have a chance to take it.
I would advise other students to take this course as the content is excellent.
Make sure to stay caught up on the problem sets.

Photocopy turned in assignments, as future work will draw from previous problem-sets turned in and nor returned. Form a study group early on. Cover recommended material (optional but integral to further chapters).

Photocopy your problem sets. After you submit them, you will never see it again, and you need it in order to do the later problem sets, as much of the course material builds on prior material. Form study groups, and make friends. This course will give you plenty of opportunities to bond with your fellow students because unless you've seen the material before, you will spend a massive amount of time on this class.
Take this course! You will learn a lot
descrip: The chemical composition of the oceans and the nature of the physical and chemical processes governing this composition in the past and present. The cycles of major and minor oceanic constituents, including interactions with the biosphere and at the ocean-atmosphere and ocean-sediment interfaces.

title: Behavioral Economics Workshop
descrip: Seminar led by different guest professors each week to discuss their current research in the field of Behavioral Economics.

title: Structure and Properties of Materials
reviews: Arnold is one of the best professors you will have at Princeton. The materials is clear and interesting, and the lectures are extremely entertaining. Seriously. He's also very accessible, and often reminds the class that he's available to talk to. If you're interested and going above and beyond the course material into some really interesting stuff, Arnold offers to help with that too. Definitely take the course.
Class attendance.
Don't shy away from this course. It's definitely worth taking, and you may consider the Materials certificate as a result.
Go to Arnold's office hours. He is very helpful and good with the one-on-one. (when he has time).
Go to lectures

I wouldn't recommend taking this class unless it is required. Do not expect to do well on tests if you do well on homework assignments. The exam questions are much more difficult, and time is a huge factor.
If you go to lecture and read the textbook you'll do fine.
If you have to take a materials class for anything, take this one.
Interesting for a mechanical engineer.
Keep up with the material there's A LOT of it
Not too hard, make sure to get the book obvi. If you like materials it should be fun but if not, it'll be fairly easy to sleep your way through the class.
Professor Arnold makes materials science very interesting, and is very approachable with questions and feedback as well.
Study for the final!!
Study hard for the exams!
Take it as a sophomore.
Take it if Professor Arnold is teaching
Take it.  Gives a whole new microscopic view on everything around us and why stuff happens.

Take this course to learn cool materials science, Tests will be difficult (compared to Homework) so prepare accordingly.  I personally think Prof. Arnold needs to set up a Piazza site for this course.
Take this course with Professor Arnold! He is amazing and i actually looked forward to lecture every week. You learn a lot and the homework really prepares you for the tests.
Take this with Craig. You won't regret it.
This class is cool, I think you should all take it. Professor is great. Read the book, use the textbook's student website.
This is a great course to take in conjunction with MAE223 Solid Mechanics- they are both telling different sides of the same story.
prereqs: It is expected all students will have completed the BSE freshman requirements of chemistry, physics, and math or their equivalent. MAE 221 recommended but may be taken concurrently. Audit option available only for non-departmental students..
descrip: Relates to the structures, properties, processing and performance of different materials including metals, alloys, polymers, composites, and ceramics. This course also discusses how to select materials for engineering applications. This course satisfies the MAE departmental requirement in materials as well as the MSE certificate core requirement.

title: History of Photography
prereqs: Coursework in 19th and 20th-century history, literature, philosophy, or painting would be good preparation for this course. Studio photographers are also welcome..
descrip: A survey of photography from its multiple inventions in the early nineteenth century to its omnipresence (and possible obsolescence) in the twenty-first. Themes will include photography's power to define the "real;" its emulation and eventual transformation of the traditional fine arts; and its role in the construction of personal and collective memories. Precepts will meet in the Photographic Study Room of the Princeton Art Museum to study original images.

title: Issues in Contemporary Art
reviews: Enjoy. Ask lots of questions. Don't take the critiques too personally
I mean... you have to take it.
It's an incredibly inspiring course. You will learn so much about contemporary art.
Martha is awesome. Take it and absorb as much as you can.
Martha is cool.
Take this course!
Well if you're in a VIS program it is required, but it's good.
You need and only can take it if you're a certicate but it's super-helpful and great.
a must take
descrip: A required seminar for Art and Archaeology Program 2 majors and Program in Visual Arts certificate students emphasizing contemporary art practices and ideas. The course addresses current issues in painting, drawing, sculpture, film, video, photography, and performance installation. It includes a visiting artist lecture series, critiques of students' work, and excursions to galleries, museums and/or artists' studios.

title: Readings in Chinese Religions - Dunhuang Manuscripts
descrip: An introduction to the study of Chinese manuscripts from the medieval period unearthed in western China early in this century. We will read selected texts in classical Chinese drawn from religious texts (Buddhist sutras and ritual texts), literature, and documents related to social history. Reading knowledge of classical Chinese is required. Course introduces research tools and methods in Dunhuang studies plus some secondary studies. Students from all departments welcome.

title: Topics in German Film History and Theory - New German Cinemas
reviews: Talk a lot and don't be afraid to speak your mind.

You will never regret taking a course with Tom Levin. He's a force of nature in the classroom, but is easy to talk to outside of it. The material is also infinitely interesting and highly applicable to any major. Even if it doesn't seem like it, it is. Trust me. You're shorting your education if you don't take a class with Tom and you can.
prereqs: Seminar and all assigned texts will be in English. Reading knowledge of German, while desirable, is not required. Open to freshman with permission of the instructor..
descrip: An interdisciplinary investigation of the aesthetics and politics of post-WWII German cinema which will study both the road movies, documentaries and flamboyant melodramas of the first generation of New German filmmakers (Kluge, Fassbinder, Ottinger, Herzog and Wenders) as well as the more essayistic work of the second generation (Farocki, Bitomsky, Klier) and the "Berlin School" (Paetzold, Arslan and Schanelec). Close readings of films will be informed by historical texts, analysis of shifting institutional frameworks, and debates in film and media theory.

title: Microeconomic Theory I
reviews: Be sure to build a strong background in topology and real analysis before taking this course. If you do so, everything will be easier for you.
Don't worry about getting the problem sets completely right.  They hardly count for anything, and it's easy to get caught up in a question for hours.
Hard to follow without a background in micro.
I would not recommend undergraduate students taking this course: it is just not worth that. Reading textbooks is much more useful...
Take it if you're an undergrad considering graduate school, especially if other undergrads will be taking it.
Try to read the lecture notes before class. Make sure to take the problem sets seriously.
Very difficult course
descrip: First term of a two-term sequence in microeconomic theory. Topics include consumer and producer theory, choice under uncertainty and an introduction to game theory.

title: Laboratory Techniques in Materials Science and Engineering
reviews: Don't take if not getting MSE certificate. Otherwise, it is a cool, fun, and easy course, but grades are very arbitrary.
Fun class, and you learn about semiconductors, steel, and soft materials.
Fun class. The workload is dominated by a few large projects that take a lot of time. All three professors are good lecturers. Definitely worth taking.

Good class to learn about cool techniques in materials science - the labs are definitely the best part. Be prepared to not really have a lot of work and then have a lot at random times with lab reports and assignments. The profs also have very different lecturing and organizational styles, so be flexible and appreciate their strengths. Pay attention during lab and work thoroughly on your lab reports, because ultimately that's what will count the most.
I would not advise this class unless you're set on the MSE certificate.  In that case, you just have to tough out the work and boredom.
It is a pretty decent core lab.
It's a pretty good course based on the labs, but the lectures vary a lot in quality.
Most of the time, this class is fun and rewarding.
Prepare to do some work, but it will be worth it. You learn a lot about material science techniques, a field that I did not know much about coming into the course.
Really investigate what interests you, because there are a lot of cool things discussed in this course, and the three professors and assistants know a lot about their respective fields.
So good! Highly recommended to anyone doing a sciency major!
Take it! Lots of learning and lots of fun!
Take this course if you can, even if you don't want the certificate. It's just so fun!

This course is a good overview of multiple fields in materials science.  We covered semiconductors, especially solar cells, the mechanical properties and characterization of steel, and soft matter/emulsions.  The labs were fun and a good way to get a taste of hands on work with these concepts.  If you're interested in learning about these on a fairly-detailed-but-still-overview level, or in getting a taste of this sort of lab experience, I'd recommend this class.
This is a good core lab option for chem majors interested in materials science.  I recommend it, and it's a good idea to work in groups on all the assignments.
prereqs: MSE 301 or MAE 324 or CEE 364. Enrollment in this course is restricted with preference given to Certificate candidates. This course is required for students wishing to obtain a Materials Certificate..
descrip: A hands-on introduction to the use of laboratory techniques for processing and characterization in materials science. Structure-property relations will be explored through experiments in mechanical, optical, biological, and electronic properties of materials. The underlying theories and lab techniques will be explained in two weekly lectures covering such topics as electronic and mechanical properties, electron microscopy, electron diffraction and materials processing. The goal of this course if for the student to develop a solid understanding of materials properties and the common techniques used in research, as well as to gain valuable

title: Topics in Latin American Modernity - Autobiographies of the 20th Century
prereqs: A 200-level SPA course above SPA 209 or instructor's permission..
descrip: This course will focus on autobiographical writings of some of the most important Latin American writers of the 20th Century. It's a common place to say that Latin America doesn't have a strong autobiographical tradition, but this seminar aspires to demonstrate the falsity of this remark. From the seminal memoir of Jose Vasconcelos at the beginning of the 20th Century to the most recent autobiographical narratives of some young authors, the course will also explore the relation between literature and politics in Latin America.

title: Chinese Intellectual History
descrip: Methods, sources, and problems of research in history of Chinese thought.

title: The Political Pact
prereqs: None.
descrip: The course addresses two related issues: the nature of the political pact (aka the social contract) and its relevance for understanding the importance of such basic concepts as state, sovereignty, constitution, constituent power and rights. We examine works of Hobbes, Pufendorf, Locke, Rousseau, Paine and Hegel to illuminate the first issue. We then apply their insights to understand the constitution of political authority. The key is in two features of the political pact: it is not a historical event but a virtual act; and it aims both to establish the state on a principle of equality and to legitimate a hierarchical governing regime.

title: Phase Transformations and Evolving Microstructures in Hard and Soft Matter Systems
prereqs: Prereq: MSE 301 or MAE 324.
descrip: This course covers the fundamental principles of thermodynamics and phase transformation kinetics in hard and soft matter systems, such as metals and alloys, semiconductors, polymers, and lipid bilayer membranes. The course synthesizes descriptive observations, principles of statistical thermodynamics, and mathematical theories to address emergent physical, chemical, mechanical, and biological properties of multi-component, multiphase materials systems.

title: Cellular Biochemistry
reviews: I would suggest that if they want to gain a better understanding about mass spec, x-ray crystallography, as well as protein structure they should take this course. A variety of areas are covered thus you improve your understanding in many areas of biochemistry.

If you are interested in proteomics, this is a good core class to take, as you will gain a better understanding of the field. Other topics were also covered well, but in a more scattered manner. It would help to have a good background in cell biology as well, or at least read up on it.
It is a grade class to take. I would encourage students to take. Do not feel intimated by the mass spec portion of it, it is a great and useful topic to learn.
Participation is key!
Read a lot about Protein biochemistry in terms of stability as it relates to structure
Reread the papers a couple of times before you come to class. The more you participate in the class the more you will get out of it.
Review undergraduate level biochemistry.
Take the course!  It's structured well, and the readings are worth it.  I would definitely read all the papers carefully, because they're good for any molecular biology lab researcher to know.

The class is not actually about "Cellular Biochemistry," as practically no cellular biochemstry is discussed. Instead, the class is more on biochemical techniques, and even then was very limited to protein structure, mass spectrometry, and force transduction. No reactions and few pathways are actually discussed. Many students in the course found that it was very much NOT what they expected.
The course relies heavily on participation, however, I really recommend this course.
The exams will be challenging, and reading the papers many times may not help.  Try to understand techniques and the logic behind them.

This course might not be what you expect. It's not really a biochemistry course or a cell biology course. It addresses some areas of both, but neither completely and has a large emphasis on proteomics.

This is a great course for someone interested in biochemistry and proteomics. You will learn a lot about how modern mass spectrometry can be used as the swiss army knife of protein and proteome analysis. The instructors are engaging and the work load is reasonable.

Try to focus on learning the concepts behind the techniques and think critically of  their limitations. Try also to think of experiments you need to do for your own project and how techniques learnt in class can be applicable! While reading papers - when you go back to them, ask yourself if you can just look at the figures & interpret what they convey without the text that accompanies them. Also pay attention to the methods/material section of the papers and try to walk through them as if you were actually doing it - this will help you think of limitations. Oh, and definitely learn your amino acids really well!
descrip: This course focuses on the molecules and molecular assemblies that underlie cellular structure and function. Topics will include protein structure and folding; ligand binding and enzyme catalysis; membranes, ion channels, and translocation; intracellular trafficking; signal transduction and cell-cell communication; and cytoskeleton assembly, regulation, and function. A major goal of the course is to increase proficiency in parsing and critically discussing papers from the primary literature.

title: Thus Spoke Zarathustra: The Zoroastrian Tradition from Ancient Iran to Contemporary India
prereqs: This course assumes no prior knowledge of Iranian or Indian history. Some familiarity with the study of religion may be helpful, but is not necessary..
descrip: In this class we will survey the history of the Zoroastrian religion from its origins in ancient Iran to the present. As the state religion of the Achaemenid and Sasanian Persian empires, Zoroastrian thought had impact on the Classical, Jewish, Christian, and Islamic traditions. In later centuries, Iranian and Indian (Parsi) Zoroastrians interacted with the Islamicate and Sanskritic forms of learning around them to re-articulate new forms of religious identity. We will discuss such themes as the transmission of sacred knowledge, the nature of good and evil, the practice of ritual, the impact of colonial modernity, and the effects of diaspora.

title: Prose Writing for Composers
descrip: A seminar for pre-generals composition graduate students. Course examines and practices three forms of prose writing: analytical article, essay, and review. Seminar work includes reading and critiquing published examples, drafting and completing individual prose writings, and critiquing other students' work. The focus is on negotiating the fluid and fertile boundary beween creative activity and intellectual inquiry.

title: Drug Discovery in the Genomics Era
reviews: A very interesting class with very low work load (the midterm and final take-home exams are very time consuming though). Precepts are a joke though, you don't need to go.

Absolutely take this course. It's that sort of very relaxed learning that is both very enjoyable and very informative. Also, it's one of the coolest experience to hear from the people who actually headed drug development projects.
DEFINATELY take this best class on campus
Definitely recommend if you're interested in pharma, even if you've never taken an upper level chem course before.

Definitely take this course if you are looking for a low-key science course that requires relatively little background knowledge and shares a lot of information about the drug discovery industry. The assignments will seem impossible when given out, but as long as you are reasonably good at online searches and web research, they really are not that bad and can even be somewhat enjoyable!
Definitely take this course if you have any interest! It's not much work and it's extremely interesting.
Easy course, especially if you are interested in the drug discovery process. Attendance really not mandatory for all the lectures.
Highly recommend it!
I really recommend this class! Super low stress class.
I think this was a very good course, and would highly recommend it for students interested in learning about drug discovery and the pharmaceutical industry.
If you are interested in any health related field be it medicine, drug delivery or health policy, this class is a MUST.
Interesting information, easy course.

It's pretty interesting, but I kind of had no idea what was going on or what I was learning half of the time. Otherwise, extremely low-stress, low-work class. Basically all you have is the two take-home exams, which are very difficult and time-intensive.
Low workload and pretty interesting.
Please take this course. You will learn a lot
Prepare well for the midterm.  The average was very high with very little deviation from the mean this past semester.
Prof. Reider's stories are amazing and he has great guest lecturers throughout the semester. If you have any interest in medicine or drug discovery, I highly recommend taking this class!
Something different and interesting. Take it! Certainly don't have to be a chemistry or mol bio major to enjoy it/understand the material.
Take it! It's new material and you get exposed to aspects of chemistry/pharmaceuticals that you never would in a different class.
Take it! The lectures are interesting; there is absolutely no homework involved. Just have to spend a lot of time for the take-home research midterm and final :)
Take it, but on day one, decide what you want to get out of the course, and make every effort to achieve that goal.

Take this class! It isn't too time consuming, and it gives you a great new perspective on how drugs are made. I learned a lot about not only how drugs work in the body, but also how the industry works (and how it should work). If you take this class, make sure to meet up with Paul just to chat at some point. He's had a fascinating career and is a really nice guy. Also, don't be too worried about the organic chemistry pre-requisite. It's helpful to have that background for understanding the speakers, but you'll never be asked to draw a mechanism or push electrons!
Take this class.  It's really interesting and is not a lot of work on a week to week basis.  The professor is great and the lectures are fascinating.

This is a great class for anyone mildly interested in medicine and/or drug development. Professor Reider makes sure that this class is about learning and not too much work. The guest speakers are very interesting and come from the top pharmaceutical companies. Definitely recommend it.
Useful for aspiring pharmaceutical chemists and business people looking to understand big Pharma.
Wonderful course.

pretty chill class (workload is low)
but you really have to pull out all the stops on the take-home midterm and final!
take it!
take this class. period. do it.
prereqs: Two semesters of organic chemistry (CHM 301 & 302 OR CHM 303 & 304/304B) or the equivalent..
descrip: A detailed review of recent successes and failures in the discovery of new drugs. Therapeutic areas to be discussed include: HIV, oncology, asthma, Alzheimer's Disease, antibiotics, diabetes, and neglected diseases (malaria, TB, human African Trypaonosomiasis). Case studies presented by leading pharmaceutical scientists will complement discussions of the functional steps required to select a target, indentify a new chemical entity, and get it to patients. The course will emphasize the integration of the molecular sciences and the role of chemistry in inventing and producing important new medicines.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Leading Change
descrip: Drawing from cases all over the world, this seminar examines the dynamics of institutional change, helping students develop a wider lens and critical thinking skills as they work across cultures and borders. Topics explored include: How is change negotiated at the national, sectoral and organizational levels? What is the role of the state, citizens and foreign actors in the reform process? What obstacles should a leader anticipate and how should they be addressed? What specific dilemmas emerge when working across borders? What is the role of the individual leader in success or failure?

title: Topics in German Literature - Crime and Literature
descrip: This seminar pursues the theme of "Crime and Literature" in three aspects. First, which events and actions, which norms, which figures or catastrophes are invoked in the literary treatment of crime? Second, the seminar looks at the relationship between literature and legal systems. Third, we will focus on the interdependence of crime and literature. The seminar discusses texts from antiquity through the present, with a focus on the nineteenth and twentieth century.

title: Modernity and China (II): Medicine
descrip: This course addresses the issue of Chinese modernity through medicine and its relationship with culture, society, and state power up to the post-Mao transformation. It tackles the complexity of modernity - its unique roots, its tumultuous turns, its predicament, and its promise - in the globalized world yet the rising consciousness of its Chinese nature. In roughly three sections - traditional Chinese medicine, psychiatry, and social and cultural history of diseases and governance, this course is in an effort to deepen the link between medical anthropology and history of medicine and science.

title: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Western Culture I: History, Philosophy, and Religion
reviews: Be prepared to read tremendous amounts and be willing to put aside other courses' work in order to attempt to finish what this course calls for.
Do the reading.  Like, seriously.  The course is nowhere near as valuable if you don't actually read the incredible collection of works.

HUM is not for everyone. It's a difficult and frustrating experience, but it's fun and unique. Don't expect to be able to complete all the readings, it's just not possible. Do expect many late nights trying to complete the readings and frustrating all nighters writing the papers. If you like breadth (reading a bajillion books at the speed of light) go for it. If you'd rather focus on a handful of readings but go into detail on them, take another course.
If you do the readings, you benefit from this course. If not, don't take it.

If you take this course really commit yourself to the readings. Don't get discouraged after you get back the grade on your first essay (but don't not take this class because you're scared of hurting your GPA). Form relationships with the professors. Got so much more out of this than any of my other courses.

It is a lot of reading, but it will make you think about the world differently and turn you into a more knowledgeable person. You get out of it what you put in, but if you have any interest in the humanities, you should take it.
Only do it if you are really interested.
Read, read, read
Same answer as for HUM 216.
See HUM 216.
Stay up on all of the readings.
Take HUM if you are willing to read a lot and study hard! It is extremely rewarding to be able to have informed opinions about all this awesome lit!
Take it.
The course is a lot of work but completely worth it.
This is the one-in-a-life-time course!!!
You either love it or you hate it.

You should take it or go hide in an intellectually-cut off hole.  Like Dante's Inferno.  Unless you were in limbo, because then you get to talk to Socrates and all his bros.   Take this class if you love life.
don't take this course
stay on top of the readings. go to office hours to discuss your papers, both before and after. use the writing center.
prereqs: This course is primarily directed to exceptional freshmen, but qualified students may apply at any point in their undergraduate careers..
descrip: In combination with HUM 216, this course explores the landmark achievements of European civilization from antiquity to the middle ages. Students must enroll in both 216 and 217, which constitute a double-course. The lecture component for HUM 217 is listed as TBA because all meetings are listed under HUM 216. There are no separate meeting times for HUM 217.

title: Saints and Martyrs
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Quantitative Methods
reviews: A great statistics class if you're not into math. Pay attention every week because concepts build upon one another.
Always make sure you understand the problem sets and understand the lecture materials.
Andy is a wonderful man to interact with.  Be prepared to work outside of class to make the material stick.
Do not take this course. Take any other stats course that is offered.
Don't miss class.  Do the weekly homework and reading.  If you do that, then you're almost guaranteed an A in the course.
Don't miss lab.
Go to lecture because the slides are impossible to understand on their own.
Go to lecture. If you don't understand something, talk to Conway before it's too late. Everything is cumulative.
Good basic stats class to take.
I wouldn't really recommend taking it unless you had to.
I wouldn't take it again.
If you want a course that fills a QR with little effort and pretty much no math, then this is the course for you. I called it "Qualitative Statistics".
It's a fine statistics class but try and get to know the prof.'s they're great people, and also take a trip to the library to see if there is more helpful material on the subject.
It's a good course, a pretty good statistics class although it's really general.
Learn the material from other places online, such as Khan academy or Wikipedia, since lectures are impossible to follow.
Not a great class. I guess if you need to take it, do. It's not particularly hard.
Since it's the easiest stats class, it's the least of the evils you can choose from. But don't be prepared to enjoy it.
Take another stats course.
Take it for an easy stats class if you need. Otherwise, look to other departments for a deeper introduction to the topics.
Take it if you want to learn more about stats.
Take it if you want to specifically learn about psych stats.
Take this class if you want an easy statistics class with little to no math.
Take this course. Pretty straight forward stats course but from a nonmathematical side.

The class gave me statistical concepts that I can use in everyday life, and it is a  relatively manageable QR for students who don?t like quantitative stuff, but a lot of students were worried about the grade distributions and the fact that everyone scoring so highly all the time meant that it?d be harder to earn a better grade than everyone else.

This class is overall okay. Dr. Conway is a below average lecturer. It's often hard to understand what he's getting at, and the lectures are incredibly boring. That said, the class isn't that hard. For the quizzes, STUDY THE POWERPOINTS. the rest isn't terribly important.
This course is great with Andrew Conway and Brooke Macnamara. TAKE IT

This course is horrible, although it is not all that time-consuming or difficult.  You will not learn statistics even if you make an A, so only take it if you need it for a departmental or pre-med requirement.
This is a good intro to stats, and it's not that bad if you just study a little bit before the quizzes and tests.
This is a really easy stats class if you've taken AP Statistics in high school. However, I've seen it become very confusing for students who have never taken any stats before.
Unless you have to take Psych stats to be a Psych major, I'd not take it.
VERY Easy class; don't expect to learn much. VERY little work. Professor doesn't really care about the course and it shows.
Very easy course but pretty slow at times.
make sure you do not fall behind and that you are understanding the material

this course is not the best to take just to fulfill the distribution, Andy is not a good teacher and while there is not much math at all involved the concepts can get pretty tricky and complicated, lectures are not good and problem sets are time somewhat consuming
descrip: The purpose of the course is to introduce students to the basic techniques of statistical analysis used in psychological research. Students will learn the logic underlying the statistical techniques and learn how to perform statistical analyses and interpret the results.

title: Topics in Country and Regional Economics - Economics of the European Union and Economies in Europe
reviews: Although at an ECO 100/101 level, most students are upper level Econ majors, so the curve can be difficult. Regardless, you learn a lot and it is a very interesting and useful course, especially considering what is going on in Europe right now.
Good way to learn more about EU institutions and policies, not too many difficult economic concepts convered
Had high hopes, but extremely boring course. Far better departmental courses out there
If you're interested in finance, you HAVE to take this class. The most relevant financial subject for the next 4 years at least. And you learn SO much.

If you're someone interested mainly in European politics and looking for a good introduction to the economics, this is a great course to take. The course is presented in a sufficiently policy-friendly manner for someone not particularly into economics to still get a lot out of it.
Not as interesting as you would hope. Very dry theory class for the most part. Course has not been updated to focus on contemporary macro issues but mostly focuses on trade and micro models.

Not at all a bad course to take if you need another ECO distributional. Very similar to International Trade if you've taken that course. We did trade models for about 1/2 the semester. Nice around midterms time that there's no midterm exam .. until you have to learn everything for the final. But in general not much work at all (only 4 problem sets total) and a presentation and memo.. not bad at all in terms of ECO course work.
Take this only if you are very interested in European economics. Otherwise, it is a bit dry.
This class is actually quite a bit of work. The final is very hard to prepare for because so much material is covered.
This is a course for those willing to study extensively on their own as the lectures are not entirely engaging.
prereqs: ECO 100, ECO 101.
descrip: This course studies the economies of current and prospective European Union (EU) members and economic integration in Europe after 1945. It explores the political motivation for, and the economic implications of, the European Union's moves towards ever deeper integration and enlargement. Topics include policy-making in the EU, adoption of common policies including European Monetary Union and the Euro and their implications for fiscal and labor market policies, problems raised by an EU enlargement to the East, and economic transition in EU applicant countries. The course uses economic analysis to study policy issues.

title: French Theater Workshop
reviews: Do it. Florent is really relaxed, papers and grading are fair, and reading is never overwhelming. A great introduction to French theatre!

If you can read French but can't speak it well you'll learn a lot from this course, though you'll find it tough. If you can speak it, it won't be too hard.

And either way, if you enjoy theater you'll have a blast. In my opinion in not a Class about French theater.

This is a class about theater, which happens to be run in French.
If you like French and have any interest at all in theater (reading and/or performing), take this class! Florent Masse is a dynamic and engaging professor.
It is pretty interesting and the work load is moderate, albeit quite different from any other class one would take here.  I recommend it.
Never hesitate to take any risks; liberate yourself entirely, and have fun!
Take it! It is one of the best organized and best taught classes I've taken at Princeton.
Take it! It's not too much work, and you'll learn a lot.
Take it!!!!!! The work isn't extremely difficult and it's so much fun and you learn so much.

Take this course! Do not be afraid of participating in class discussions or putting yourself out there during improvisation exercises. The bond you will create with M. Masse and your classmates is incredible. Just dive in; you will not regret it.
prereqs: FRE 107, 108, or equivalent. FRE 207 recommended as a co-requisite. Course is conducted entirely in French. Interested students must contact the instructor: fmasse@Princeton.EDU to apply and schedule an interview. Course is open to Freshmen..
descrip: L'Avant-Scene will offer students the opportunity to put their language skills in motion by discovering French theater in general and by acting in French, in particular. The course will introduce students to acting techniques while allowing them to discover the richness of the French dramatic canon. Particular emphasis will be placed on improving students' oral skills through pronunciation and diction exercises. At the end of the semester, the course will culminate in the performance of the students' work.

title: Negotiation, Persuasion and Social Influence: Theory and Practice
descrip: Examines the principles of negotiation in organizational settings and provides firsthand experience in simulated negotiations. Theoretical and empirical research on the variables that affect success in negotiations is discussed. Students engage in a series of bargaining exercises between individuals and teams, and results are analyzed in detail by the class.

title: Linear Algebra with Applications
reviews: 204 is a confused course- take this instead, and just read about Jordan form/abstract vector spaces/inner product in your own time (or pick up the ideas as needed in the future). 217 might be a better choice if you're a physicist, or if you want to take more advanced math courses later.
A low-level math lecture, you've got your reasons for taking it.  I can only recommend Prof. Patakfalvi (if he's teaching).  He's funny and explains things pretty well.
Be prepared to do a lot of the learning on your own but don't be too scared.
Be ready and willing to spend a lot of time self teaching yourself things from videos online, etc. You won't reach a deep understanding through class alone, if at all.
Calculations are kind of heavy, but if you dislike Linear Algebra and need the requirement, this will do it.
Class was hard.  definitely wouldn't recommend for fun.  Only take if you have too
Create a chart of definitions you learn throughout the course. A lot of definitions, and if you want to get an A you must do well on the true/false

Definitely take it (well I guess a lot of you don't have much choice in that), and take it only with Zsolt. Some of my other classmates with other professors didn't enjoy the course as much as we did.
Do the problem sets.
Don't take it unless you absolutely have to.
Don't take it unless you have to. Better than 201, however.
Go to office hours and begin the practice exams as early as possible.

Going in I was scared because I was not a fan of 201. This course is a lot better than 201. Seriously. The concepts are more straightforward and here I felt that hard work really payed off more than in 201. If you find yourself struggling at any point GO TO OFFICE HOURS and/or get a Peer Tutor.
I liked linear algebra better than multivariable calculus.
I recommend the Adrian Banner videos online instead of going to class
I understand matrices now! It's like being a wizard with boxes of numbers!
I wouldn't really take it unless you have to.
If Zsolt is teaching the class, take it with him!! Very accessible, listens to all your questions, and makes sure you understand what's going on.

If you are considering taking this class for the finance program/math-track economics, you might save yourself a good amount of work by just going with MAT175. With that said, I thoroughly enjoyed this course and in hindsight do not regret taking it in spite of the extra semester of math. Mihai Fulger is an awesome dude.
If you have an interest or math or if this is a requirement, linear algebra is a good chance to expose yourself to a different kind of math.
If you're taking this class, it's probably because you have to. But if you don't, don't take this class.
If you, like me, feel obligated to do math at least through linear to be able to have some self-respect, but don't want to kill yourself in 204, then take this. If you're looking for a QR, stay away.
It's a fun, easy, and interesting. What more could you want...?

It's hard. Study a lot. I learned a couple things that I though were more useful than anything else I've learned recently in math (linear equation solving and data fitting), but a lot of the stuff is really abstract.
It's not as bad as lots of individuals say.
Lectures aren't very stimulating; but go as much as needed
Mihai is very easy to understand and works well with students. Because he doesn't use notes in class, he is more engaging than other professors who just write and write and write.
Most students will only take it because they have to, but keep an open mind--some of the material in Linear Algebra is really interesting, not to mention applicable to many real-life applications!
Not that bad, but take it only if required
Office hours were very helpful for doing homework. Also, take advantage of the fact that they let you do homework in groups, because it is very easy to make simply computational mistakes!
Ok, honestly classes aren't necessary if you learn well from the textbook. I stopped going to class halfway through and my 2nd quiz grade actually improved. It's a math class so it's hard.
Only take if it is a requirement.
