Prepare for all the tests and don't get nervous on them.
Read the book ahead of class. READ THE BOOK AHEAD OF CLASS!!!!! Do it or else if you aren't a genius, you WILL BE CONFUSED.
Read the chapter prior to attending class
Take it if you have to.
Take it if you need it for your major. It isn't too difficult. Classes are not super useful, but they are good refreshers.
Take this course if you need to or have an interest in math.
This course is about the same level of difficulty as 104 and 201.  Try to keep up with the material throughout the semester.
This is a good course to take. I wouldn't particularly recommend it outside of being a requirement for your major unless you have a genuine interest in the course material.

This is a very tough math course. There is a large discrepancy between the level of teaching and the level of the skill required for the exams. The problem sets and lectures do very little to prepare one for the very difficult exams. Your best friend in this course will be the Adrian Banner MAT 202 review session videos. They prepare one to succeed in this course.
This is much lighter than MAT 203 and 204. If you took MAT 203 and did well, definitely consider taking 204--you'll learn more!
Try to take it when they update the course (book and professors)
Typical tough math class. Study up....

You probably have to take this course, which is understandable. The MAT department here is god awful, so don't expect to actually "enjoy" this course. That being said, it is much more tolerable than the rest of the MAT classes here, and if you get a good professor can be much less stressful than you think. 202 is easier than 201 by miles.
You'll have to take it as an engineer. Take it with Prof. Zsolt Patakfalvi if you are. Don't let yourself fall behind and ask help if you need it.
Zsolt is AMAZING. take it with him.
don't unless you have to or have prior exposure to linear algebra. if you liked 201, go for it.
good luck!
practice problems.
take it with Zsolt.
take it. very nice way to study linear algebra.
the more effort you put into it the more reward you will get out.
prereqs: MAT104 equivalent..
descrip: Companion course to MAT201. Matrices, linear transformations, linear independence and dimension, bases and coordinates, determinants, orthogonal projection, least squares, eigenvectors and their applications to quadratic forms and dynamical systems.

title: Religion, Ecology, and Cosmology
descrip: This course explores religions within the horizon of interdependent life and the cosmos. It investigates the symbolic and lived expressions of this interconnection in religious texts and practices. The course draws on science for understanding the dynamic processes of the universe, Earth, life, and ecosystems. In part I, we explore ecological perspectives from Indigenous traditions, Christianity, and Confucianism. In part II we survey environmental ethics. Finally, we examine the scientific story of the unfolding universe as a cosmological narrative orienting human-Earth relations.

title: Third-Year Modern Chinese I
reviews: A lot of work.

After PiB, it's still definitely worth taking third year. You learn a lot more useful vocabulary that goes beyond daily life and get more practice, even though the number of new grammar structures decreases.

CHI 303 is insanely intense -- in order to really benefit from the class, you need to spend a lot of time outside of class learning the vocab. That said, I have learned a lot, and I feel confident that I could speak Chinese in China.
Hard, but worth it.
I would strongly recommend this course if you have an interest in continuing Chinese past the compulsory 4 semesters.
If they are willing to give it the time, I would really recommend this course! Course load in terms of homework is not much, but they must be willing to learn the material.

If you are a grad student, pressure the university to offer this course as a PDF.  The course load is extremely heavy, so do not take this unless you are prepared to invest large amounts of time (or else get a poor grade).
If you are genuinely interested in taking Chinese, you should take it. The course demands a lot of work, but I would be more worried if it was an easy course.

If you really love Chinese and learning languages, this is a great course to take. The teachers are great and the subject matter is weird but interesting. But it will keep you really busy with sort-of mindless work for every day of the week.
It is a lot of work. You must be committed to putting in the hours .There is a weekly test and quiz.
It's a good class and you'll learn a lot, and if you take the intro sequence you'll be used to class every day (except not on Friday in this course)
Ready to participate and speak a lot during class.
Take it if you want to learn Chinese.
Take it! Keep up your chinese skills.
Take this course if you want to really learn Chinese! It's hard, but it is worth it.
The course work is manageable, so take it if you are interested in maintaining Chinese studies.
Work consistently hard - don't do it all at the last minute! If you dedicate time and effort to Chinese classes, you won't regret having that test every Friday (as much).
Write out the texts - verbatim - when studying for the weekly quizzes. It helps immensely.
only take it if you're willing to put in the time. but if you are, its a lot of fun and you can actually see yourself improving.
prereqs: CHI 107 or permission of instructor.
descrip: Designed to develop further the student's overall language skills through reading and discussion of contemporary affairs published in Chinese newspapers.

title: Labor Economics/Industrial Relations Seminar
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: American Mysticism
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Understanding the "Barbarians": Discovering Ethnicity in Ancient History, Art, and Archaeology
descrip: Civilizations of ancient history, like Egypt, Greece, Rome and Mesopotamia, incorporated small ethnic groups who significantly influenced their society, history, and worldview. Yet they are often minimized in the study of the past because they had only a marginal effect on the sources that the large civilizations left behind. In this course we will examine their art, archaeology, and texts to understand the role of the peripheral "barbarians" on the past and how their ethnicity changed history. In a series of case studies we will analyze how ancient peoples created their own ethnicities and how other groups applied ethnic stereotypes to them.

title: Intensive Third-Year Modern Chinese I
reviews: Amazing Professors! Liu LaoShi and Wang LaoShi definitely made this course worthwhile. They were always incredibly sweet and helpful. Class discussions are always interesting (and sometimes even humorous!) but there is a good amount of work that must be put into this course.
As a non-native student, I found 305 to be INCREDIBLY helpful for exposing me to native speech patterns and raising my chinese level!
Be prepared to do a lot of work, but if you do the work, your efforts will pay off.
It it quite a big time commitment

It's more characters and grammars than in 103/8, but a lot of it is repeated from those classes. The topics covered are interesting, involving such things as sex, mental illness, and cheating. The midweek quizzes get more difficult as the semester goes on, where it eventually turns into you translating an English sentence into Chinese. There are assignments due during breaks, don't forget those.
Keep a regular schedule, don't fall behind and it should be fine
Keep up with the class, it's easy to fall behind if you miss a few classes. Make sure to read the text before each class, and definitely use the teacher's study guides - they are incredibly helpful.
Lots of work but worth it.
Put in effort. Its worth it
Strongly recommended!
Take it if you have already been taking Chinese and are looking to improve your skills.
Take it!  I definitely got a lot out of it.
Take it. You won't regret it.
Take this course, or any Chinese course for that matter. All the teachers are wonderful and you will learn a lot as long as you follow the curriculum.
There is a lot of work but there are no surprises each week.
This course takes some time but the knowledge you gain out of it is well worth it
This is the heritage course but that shouldn't stop you from taking it if it's at your level.
Unless you speak Chinese at home, take 303. You'll just end up overwhelmed and frustrated in 305.
a lot of work, but great professors, learnt a lot
prereqs: CHI 103, 108, or instructors' permission..
descrip: Designed for students who are interested in current political and social issues in Chinese affairs. Reading materials will be selected from newspapers of the People's Republic of China.

title: Designing Life: The Ethics of Creation
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Moby-Dick Unbound
prereqs: Applications are available outside the American Studies Program office, 42 McCosh Hall, and on the AMS website: http://www.princeton.edu/ams/undergraduate_program/seminars_1/ Preference will be for students enrolled in the American Studies certificate program, but students from all departments are welcome to apply. APPLICATION DEADLINE HAS BEEN EXTENDED TO : 12:00 NOON, FRIDAY, APRIL 27..
descrip: This seminar undertakes a close reading of Melville's major tales and Moby-Dick (1851), often acclaimed as the greatest American novel. Why was this story of a tragic sea voyage so neglected in its day, and so celebrated by later generations? To explore its twin lines of action--Ahab's drive to kill a white whale versus Ishmael's quest to know it--we use the methods of history, literature, art, religion, economics, philosophy, and ecology. We will especially note how Melville anticipates recent environmental thought, depicts a globalized culture, and dramatizes the national struggle to reconcile faith and fact, race and justice.

title: Analytic Number Theory
prereqs: MAT335 and MAT345..
descrip: An introduction to classical results in analytic number theory, presenting fundamental theorems with detailed proofs and highlighting the tight connections between them. Topics covered might include: the prime number theorem, Dirichlet L-functions, zero-free regions, sieve methods, representation by quadratic forms, and Gauss sums.

title: Instrumental Music: The Symphony from Haydn to Stravinsky
reviews: Depends what you want. If you want to listen to great music, then take it. If you want a gut music class probably take clapping for credit. If you are serious about music, then this class is probably too easy.
Do the listenings
If you have ever listened to classical music and liked it even a little bit, you should take this course. No music experience necessary.
Just enjoy it!
Keep up with the listenings, they add up.
Make sure that you don't study for the exams last minute-- listen to the music contentiously throughout the semester!

Make sure you do the listening (of the symphonies) as they are assigned! It will make it easier to identify the pieces on the exams. Come to every lecture, because you will not have a professor this good in many other classes.
Pretty good music class- doesn't require much prior knowledge of music. However, be prepared to write papers!
Prof. Burnham presents music in a way which will enchant anyone lucky enough to be a part of his class. Regardless of your musical background, take the class: you won't regret it.

SCOTT BURNHAM IS AN AMAZING PROFESSOR!!!!!  Take this class, whether you have perfect pitch and can pick out the most obscure chords in the world or you can't tell a I chord from a V chord.  There's a bit of basic musical vocabulary used (tonic, dominant), but he explains musical concepts if people don't know them.

If I had lots of money, I would pay big money to listen to symphonies with Professor Burnham to have him tell me what I'm hearing.  When we listen to things in class that I've heard before, I'm able to appreciate them so so so much more because he points out these tiny details in pieces that make them so much more poignant!
Take the course but make sure you get into Burnham's precept.

Take this course. Just do it. You won't regret it. Get scores of the music from the library, and listen to them on Youtube, because RealPlayer (the player they use to send you the music) can be shoddy. If you really engage into this course, you'll really enjoy it.
This class is full of music majors and PUO students. Almost everyone in the class has extensive experience reading music.
You must take a class w/ Prof. Burnham before you graduate!
take it if you like classical music; professor burnham is pretty awesome as well
prereqs: Required background for enrollment: any prior course in music or some ability to read music..
descrip: Consideration of the symphony from the mid-eighteenth century to the mid-twentieth century, both in terms of musical procedures & cultural significance. The course is designed primarily for non-concentrators. The focus will be on intensive listening, minimal ability to follow musical notation helpful.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Surveys, Polls and Public Policy
descrip: Course aims to improve students' abilities to understand and critically evaluate public opinion polls and surveys, particularly as they are used to influence public policy. Course begins with an overview of contrasting perspectives on the role of public opinion in politics, then examines the evolution of public opinion polling in the US and other countries. Class visits a major polling operation to get a firsthand look at procedures used for designing representative samples and conducting surveys by telephone, mail and Internet.

title: Contemporary Fiction
descrip: How do we create our artworks, and how do we create ourselves, in the contemporary world? What can each process tell us about the other? How do changing notions of subjectivity and subjecthood interact with our archive of literary and cinematic forms? In this course we'll explore the technological, geopolitical, and cultural developments of the last quarter-century through lenses provided by novels and films produced in this period. These texts will range from relatively mainstream to quite experimental; our task, in all cases, will be to embrace their challenges as well as their pleasures--and, again, to ask how these inform one another.

title: Food Matters
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: General Chemistry I
reviews: 201 is really good. The material is not too difficult and the lectures are good. Labs are great. Balasubramaniananan Harish and Max Friedman are both good for lab and precept, respectively. Study hard for everything. Lab practical and lab written exam are not difficult. The midterm and thermo test are hard. Go to lectures; precepts help in learning ways to think about and solve problems. Also, don't put off ALEKS until the night before. It can really screw up your night and next day.
A great intro to chemistry, and stay on top of your ALEKS objectives because if you do not you are at an extreme disadvantage for the rest of the course.
ALEKS might seem like a bit of a pain at the beginning of the year, but it's extremely helpful for learning the material.
Always start lab reports a few days before they are due.
Attend lectures. They're very helpful for understanding the material.
Be organized, take your time on the problem sets, and go to review sessions and precepts.

Be patient. There's a lot of new topics to learn especially if you haven't taken AP in high school. I wouldn't say topics are extremely challenging , but with ALEKS there are a lot. So be organized and persistent and you'll be fine.
Be prepared to devote A LOT of time to this class if you have never taken AP Chemistry.
Be ready to be tested on math. This is a very math intensive course.
DO THE READINGS BEFORE LECTURE AND CLASS
Definitely go to office hours and McGraw if you need help.
Definitely read the textbook, go to lectures, don't hesitate to email your professor and TAs, and be careful about having a TA who you can understand.
Depends on what you want to do!
Depends.
Do Aleks. Go to precept. Read the text.
Do it. You'll learn a lot. It's challenging but manageable, which is the best kind of class.
Do not fall behind on ALEKS assignments, and attend class as often as possible, as they are critical for understanding the material.
Do not fall behind on course work and pay attention in lecture.

Do not take this class if you have placed out with AP credit.  It's not worth your time; you'd be better off just reviewing your AP notes.  But if you haven't taken chemistry before, I would definitely recommend this course.  Professor does a great job of teaching the material and the workload is not too bad. The lab reports are a bit tedious though.
Do the problem sets and all of the Aleks questions because that will prepare you for the  tests.
Do the reading far in advance to help your understanding in lecture.
Do the readings.
Do the textbook readings regularly, and take notes. Study what happens in the demos and take advantage of the fact that demo descriptions and the slides are posted online.
Do your readings before going to class.

Don't be scared away if you need this course to satisfy requirements; it's perfectly manageable. It's safe to say, though, I think, that no one takes this course for fun and you should know that. For an interest in chemistry, you'd be better off trying to get into a higher-level course or taking "Chemistry of Magic".
Don't fall behind on the reading
Don't get behind on the reading!!
Don't take this course if it isn't a requirement or part of your serious interests. If you like chemistry, you will like this course.
Don't take this course if you're not willing to work hard, it can be very difficult at times.
Fast-paced class -- keep up with the textbook readings and don't put off getting help from instructors or tutors!

For a huge lecture class, 201 isn't too hard or overwhelming. Hecht is a very approachable and engaging professor, and the labs are super easy if you can follow directions. The only advice I would give is GO TO PRECEPT. Depending on who you have, it can make your chemistry experience much happier and easier.
Go over demos
Go to Professor Hecht's office hours! He's a nice and interesting man.
Go to all the lectures and class times, and try to keep up with this course daily.  It is a lot of work, so do not let yourself get behind.  The readings do help, so if you have time, read those.

Go to lecture, but definitely go to precept; it's precept where you learn how to approach problems on problem sets and exams. Also, reading the book helps; yes, it takes time, but lectures make a lot more sense if you've seen the material beforehand.
Go to office hours when you need help and reach out to others to do problem sets, you'll thank yourself.

Go to resource center and weekly review sessions if you want to learn more or are having trouble with problem sets! Don't be afraid to ask TA's, they are very helpful and kind! Also, Professor Hecht teaches the material in a very well organized manner and adds interesting biological contexts!
Good class
Great intro course.
Helps to have a background of chemistry

I think that this class is a good choice for science majors and non-science majors alike.  It presents the material in easily understandable way.  The preset 85=A curve is a little ridiculous because it does not always equate to the grade distribution, but this is not that difficult of a course anyways.
I would advise getting a good preceptor that can thoroughly explain any questions to you and that can better help you understand the concepts.

I would advise other students taking this course to attend precept (even more than attending lecture). I would also advise them to seek help either in the preceptors office hours or from the McGraw Tutoring Center for problem sets (take it from someone who struggled!). I would also suggest that they read the chapter before attending lecture.
I would advise students to attend office hours and review sessions because they help a lot for exams.
I would not take this course unless you have a stronger background in chemistry, or if you want to be a science student (pre-med, etc.)
I would say study hard and don't get behind.

I would strongly recommend taking this course. The professor and TAs are very knowledgable and friendly. Labs are painless.  There are so many resources available to prepare for exams that it is fairly easy to do well if you prepare.
I wouldn't take this course for fun, but I don't expect that most people would. The work is time consuming and usually not as "intuitive" as the instructor says.
If ALEKS is still a tool being used to study, take notes as you do it.  Also, go to office hours.
If this course is using the ALEKS program, I would say absolutely take chemistry at another institution.
If you haven't covered the material, you will have to invest a lot of time.
If you like chemistry, take this course. The lectures are bland unless you are really interested in learning chemistry. Labs are a lot of fun, and you learn a lot from them!
If you love chemistry then you will love the course. It is very interesting. The lectures can get hard to get through but it will all benefit you in the long run.
If you love chemistry you probably will love this class; I personally was not in love with chemistry but it is a necessary science to take if you plan on taking more science classes in the future.
It goes very quickly at the beginning, but then it slows down, so don't worry if you feel like you do not know any chemistry at first.  Just read the textbook and it will get better.
It is a good course especially considering it's required for many people.  If you can, get Brian Schaefer as your lab TA. He is wonderful.
It is a lot of work so only take it if you need to but you will learn a lot
It was a lot of unnecessary work with the ALEKS program. It was frustrating and took up entirely too much time that I was not able to use on other classes

It's a general chemistry course.  Nothing is going to be spectacular, but Professor Hecht is interesting enough to make the lectures a lot less dull than they could be.  If you like the subject matter or need it for a pre-req, take it.
It's a lot harder than you think it's going to be.
It's difficult if you have no prior exposure to advanced chemistry. Only take it if needed.
Its a gen chem course. Almost everyone takes it as a prereq so you don't have a choice. But do take good notes when Hecht introduces concepts outside of the text.
Its difficult to know how to study and prepare, go to McGraw, read the chapter, talk to TA's. It is hard and a large class but teaches you a lot!
Just stay up on the readings and go to all the classes and you'll get a good grade.
Keep up with the reading

Keep up with the readings! It moves very quickly, so try to set aside some time to just absorb the information from lecture. The book helps with this. Also do all of the problem sets and ALEKS (if you have that again) so that your grade does not solely depend on exams.
Keep up with the readings. Lectures aren't that useful. Do a lot of practice problems.
Listen to your instructors and do as they say - the readings, extra problems, etc. will all go a long way in making sure you thoroughly understand the subject.
Make sure to do the readings before lecture because it definitely helps. Also, do the challenge problems at the end of each chapter to ensure that you've mastered the concepts within each chapter.

Make sure you get Nyssa as a preceptor, and talk to her. Talk to RPL for lab help if you need anything, he's pretty cool. Read, read, read. Don't miss precept, its a saving grace. Go to the Sunday night review sessions, its pretty helpful!
Make sure you read the textbook before lecture.  Go over the lab instructions in detail before each lab.  Try to get Nyssa for your preceptor.
Make sure you take full advantage of all of the resources given to you!
Manage your time wisely

My advice to the future students is to read the textbook daily, it really reinforces your knowledge of the information and will prevent you from falling behind at any point during the course. Lectures reiterate the book, so if you are reading it constantly, lectures aren't necessarily required to go to.
N/A
Only if need to take it.
Only take this class if you are genuinely interested in Chemistry or if you want to be pre-med.

Only take this course if you have taken the AP Chemistry exam and have scored well. Well over 50% of the class has previously taken AP Chemistry and this fact will be very apparent when you take tests.
Only take this course if you have to, and expect to do a lot of work for it (especially if they still employ Aleks).
Overall, a good course.  Lecture is a little boring, but the labs are enjoyable.  Not very difficult.
Overall, the course helped learn more chem than I ever had before.
READ THE BOOK! IT HELPS A LOT!1
READ THE BOOK. Do problem sets, etc. Ask if you don't understand.
READ THE TEXTBOOK!
Read the book as much as possible and practice problems, and go over old exams.
Read the book before lectures, if at all possible. It makes everything so much clearer. Also, don't procrastinate on ALEKS.
Read the textbook before going to lecture and attend precept.
Read the textbook!
Read the textbook. Do practice problems.
Really liked it! Very similar to AP chemistry, so quite easy if you've taken that before
STUDY STUDY STUDY.
Stay on top of concepts as you learn them, especially if you don't understand specific problems from psets or other homework.
Stay on top of the reading and use all the resources you are given!
Stay on top of the readings and go get help if you don't understand anything. Be prepared to do a lot of work if they decide to keep the ALEKS program.
Stay on top of the workload and take advantage of office hours and study sessions. Do lots of practice problems!
Stay on top of your work and the topics and you will do fine.
Study groups will save your life.
Take 207 if ALEKS is still in 201.
Take Aleks seriously. Go to lectures, use the book as reference.
Take it if you have to. It won't be a wild thrill ride, but it'll be okay.
Take it! It was fun, and there are a lot of resources available to you if you struggle. And work hard!
Take it! It's solid, a little difficult, but not impossible if your are willing to do the work.

Take it. Not too much math. So much help is available from so many different sources and there are a ton of different components to the course that there are many areas to potentially do well in or to make up for deficiencies elsewhere
Take only if it is required or you are very interested because it is a lot of work.
Take this course if you have to.  There really is no other reason to do so.
Take this course if you like Chemistry.
The class is a lot of work. Also, definitely go to lecture, because it helps a lot to have Professor Hecht explain the material rather than just reading over it in the textbook.
The class wasn't bad, but I think there are better classes to take for interest.
The course if very calculations based, so students should really focus on the equations and the ability to do problems.
The material is not very hard to understand but it is important to keep up with the material. Aleks really helped with that.

This class was actually interesting. I didn't really get into chem in high school and this honestly made me consider majoring in something chem-related! (except that would also mean taking orgo... AHH we will see if I'm up for that)
This course is a good introduction to basic chemistry, but is a lot of work.  I would not recommend it unless you need it as a prerequisite because of the workload.
This course is a lot of work. With nightly homework's, problem sets, exams, and labs its a lot to get done every week with no break. You have to stay on top of the work.
This course is definitely manageable if you take the time to do well on problem sets and understand the concepts completely.  It just takes time.
This course is great.
This course is terrible. Do not take it if at all possible. Extremely frustrating and unreasonable. ALEKS was created to ruin lives and their grading policy is erroneous.

This is a good course. Prof. Hecht does a good job making the information engaging and connecting with his class. The labs are interesting and the precept was helpful when trying to understand or clarify confusing pieces of information.
Try to stick with the textbook readings and ask many questions in precept.
Well taught - hopefully they'll fix up the ALEKS thing.
Work ahead.
Work hard.
Would recommend students to have at least some chemistry background before deciding to take it though.
Yes.

You should go to lectures.  Professor Hecht is very thorough.  At the beginning of the semester I kept up with all the reading, but at the very end I was a little behind.  By attending lectures I was able to easily keep up with the problem sets even without the reading.  There are some nice demonstrations in class as well, so if you like seeing things go boom or light up you should hed to lecture.  Overall, not that hard of a STL if you want to take it.
You should take this course if you plan on majoring in a science. In fact, if you're a BSE student, this class is required unless you test out.
do not take this course unless you are pre-health or have to take it as a major requirement. it is not that inspiring and has a massive amount of work in relation to what you actually learn.

don't take this course unless you are interested in chemistry or premed.  It is one of the drier sciences in my opinion, and the workload does demand a good amount of attention, so i wouldn't necessarily suggest it for general interest.
good course but very time consuming.
its kind of unfair if you are actually taking it as an introductory class
there are a lot of Pre-med students taking this class, so the curve is always screwed.  But other than that it's a pretty cool course.

would recommend actually paying attention. it would be better to take this course with classes that are not too much load on work. sometimes felt like there were too much things for this course-- psets, aleks objectives, lectures, readings, labs, lab reports, etc... so it should take up a lot of your time and as long as you have a lot of that, you should enjoy the course. but pton students generally dont have a lot of that.
descrip: CHM 201 (Fall) and CHM 202 (Spring) comprise an overview of Chemistry. This sequence serves as the entry level course for concentrators in Chemistry, and for other sciences requiring General Chemistry as a prerequisite. This sequence is also well suited for premedical students. The goal of General Chemistry is to enhance our understanding of our surroundings through a study of matter at the molecular scale. Topics in CHM 201 include chemical reactions, equilibrium, energy and entropy, quantum theory, atomic structure, and chemical bonding. These concepts will be illustrated with real-world examples from the chemistry of biological systems.

title: Saints and Martyrs
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Sex in Ancient Judaism and Christianity
reviews: Be sure to figure out your paper topic well before the due date, so that you can ask questions prior to submitting it.
Don't take this as a 5th class! Lots of reading and you'll be disappointed if you can't finish it because it's all very interesting.
Great class for religion, classics, or anthropology majors.
If they offer it again, DO IT.
descrip: Contemporary discussions about sexuality are filled with Jewish and Christian texts from antiquity. Quotations from the Bible and its ancient interpretations are continuously used to make claims about sexual behavior and sexual desire. Yet these texts themselves come from a very different world, with values, facts and passions of its own. This course examines the classical Jewish and Christian texts on sexuality within their own ancient historical context. Throughout the course, we will emphasize the diversity of positions in antiquity and the broad cultural conversations in which these positions were staked.

title: Stochastic Analysis Seminar
descrip: Recent developments in the theory and applications of the analysis of random processes and random fields. Applications include financial engineering, transport by stochastic flows, and statistical imaging.

title: Immune Systems: From Molecules to Populations
reviews: Anyone with an interest in molecular and/or evolutionary immunology should take this course. Some background in MOL courses would be recommended, since there are a good number of specific molecular mechanisms covered in class. However, all of the graded coursework is writing, so it's much more of an EEB course in that respect. All in all, Prof. Graham is an awesome lecturer and her class is not one to be missed! One serious consideration though, is that this class is at 8:30am. If you can't wake up for lecture, you probably won't enjoy it as much.

Definitely check out this course if you're in EEB.  It's not really that MOL-oriented, much more focused on higher scales like organisms and populations.  If you're not in EEB, but generally interested in immunology, this is also a good course to take because it doesn't require you to know a lot of background knowledge on things.
Enjoy the class even though lectures are early.
Even if you're not an EEB/MOL major, this is a great class with a great professor who makes you excited to learn!
Go to lecture, for sure. All of the important concepts are best explained by Andrea rather than in the readings.
Great class. Definitely take it.

I had originally planned to drop this course because it's at 8:30, but the mechanics of the class pulled me back in.

Graham offers granola bars EVERY CLASS for the whole class. There is no textbook; reading comes from relevant scientific literature that Graham make available through E-Reserves. The material is interesting and very macro-oriented (holistic; not particularly detail oriented). 

The class helped grow a very useful type of critical thinking and gave a very clear, holistic understanding of immune function in humans and across other species and populations. 

This class is definitely worth it, especially if you're particularly fond of thinking about the "big picture."
I highly recommend this class! There are quite a few assignments, so don't expect it to be little work.
I'd take it even if you're not a science major - it's an interesting class and seems almost like a humanities or social science course

If you are at all interested in disease, take this course! Andrea is a great professor - super smart, engaging, patient, and clear. This course also does a nice job of balancing the hard core molecular details of immune system functioning with the big ideas and concepts in immunology.

If you are interested in immunology, why/how our immune system has evolved in the way it has, and why there is so much polymorphism from molecules to organisms to populations over ecological and evolutionary time, then take the course! It presents a wonderful perspective and challenges you to think critically and to be an independent thinker. Stay on top of your work and you can do well. Ask for help if you don't understand something. 8:30 AM is not the greatest time, but you can manage.
If you're interested in the immune system, take it!

It is an 8:30am class...but, Andrea is super sweet and an excellent lecturer. Definitely go to class--her slides make a lot more sense as a result. As a ton of questions--anything that peaks your interest!
It is ok but there are too many assignments.
It's a tough course. I'd only recommend it to those willing to deal with a lot of MOL.
TAKE THIS COURSE.  It will make you think about biology and the world in a whole new way.  It is so interesting that you will enjoy doing the very reasonable reading and workload.
Take it if you're at all interested!!
Take it.  It is not overly difficult, but you feel like you've really learned something by the end.
The lectures are incredibly interesting and Prof Graham is an attentive and knowledgeable professor. This is a wonderful class with a manageable reading load and much to learn.
The only downside was 8:30 morning classes. But they offer granola bars!!
The workload during the semester isn't that bad except for the two papers. Definitely an interesting course to take if you're interested at all in immunology.
This is a GREAT course.  If you think that you can get yourself to wake up in time for 8:30am lecture, TAKE IT!
This is a good introductory course to immunology. More importantly, students are expected to contribute to how the course is taught. I recommend it to all biology majors.

This is a great class; very informative, very interesting, and just the right level of rigor. Andrea is a really great lecturer (she's really clear, doesn't talk too fast, posts the slides on time), and you can tell she really cares about helping students learn about immunology. Definitely take it if you're interested in understanding how the body mounts an immune response, and how those issues scale up to impact the entire population.
definitely take this course if you are interested in immunology
do the readings, go to class..don't focus too much on specifics, think about the big picture - that's what the exams cover.
prereqs: EEB 211 and MOL 214..
descrip: How do immune systems work, and why do they work as they do? Why is there so much immunological polymorphism in animal populations? To address these questions, students will examine immunology across multiple biological scales. At the molecular and cellular scales, students will learn mechanisms by which animals recognize and kill parasites. At the population scale, students will investigate causes of the tremendous immunological heterogeneity exhibited by animals. Both the clinical relevance and the evolutionary basis of polymorphisms will be emphasized.

title: Eye of the Tiger: Reading Buildings
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: 1912 Election, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Intermediate Swahili I
prereqs: SWA 101 and 102 or instructor's permission..
descrip: This second year Swahili course focuses on enhancing the communicative skills acquired in the first year. Instruction is done through reading, writing, speaking and listening activities on cultural content that review and consolidate already acquired language skills. The course infuses cultural and socio-political aspects of life in East Africa with more complex grammatical concepts such as the subjunctive, grammar infixes, and relative clauses. Students are also introduced to intermediate-level reading and writing in Kiswahili.

title: The 18th Century - The Late 18th- and Early 19th-Century Novel
descrip: Sometimes called the pre-Victorian novel (which imposes a false teleology), sometimes called the Romantic novel (which conveys nothing), the span of novels covered here has no name--a phenomenon we shall ponder--yet it includes among some of the richest, most searching, and most influential fiction written in English. Sentimentality, national identity, canonicity, and novelistic form will be among the issues we discuss.

title: Functional Programming
reviews: Be prepared to spend time thinking about the assignments.  More time consuming than 226/217, and the final project definitely took more time than ish just because there is so much of it.  Definitely take it.  Professor Walker is excellent, and the class will only get better the more it is taught.

Extremely interesting material that you may not learn anywhere else quite as thoroughly. Assignments may take a very long time, particularly the final one and symbolic zero-finding. Knowing functional programming makes you seem 1337 h4xx0rz.
Great class, it should be a crime to graduate with a degree in Computer Science without ever having learned a functional language, so take this class.
Great course to take for learning the fundamentals of functional programming (as opposed to object-oriented as in 226, etc), save late days for the final assignment.
If you take this class, be ready to put in more work than you might think.  Some of the conceptual material is pretty difficult and different than other classes you have taken before.
It was very rough in its first year, but I learned a tremendous amount and Professor Walker is a fantastic lecturer.  I expect that it will only get better in the future.
It's not bad but there are more interesting classes in the department
Positive. Go for it!
Take it if you are a COS major or a COS certificate student. You will definitely want to learn about functional programming. It will change the way you program forever.
Take it if you enjoy learning about how functional programming works at a theoretical and application level. Be prepared that OCaml can be a strange and sometimes silly language.

Take it. It's an awesome course. The material is well-presented and the assignments are just the right degree of difficulty. If you never learn to program functionally, you will be missing out: you become a much, much better recursive thinker and your reasoning about correctness improves ten-fold.
This was a great class! Functional programming is pretty cool and felt like I learned a lot. The assignments were very interesting.
prereqs: COS 226 or with permission of the instructor..
descrip: An introduction to the principles of typed functional programming. Programming recursive functions over structured data types and informal reasoning by induction about the correctness of those functions. Functional algorithms and data structures. Principles of modular programming, type abstraction, representation invariants and representation independence. Parallel functional programming, algorithms and applications.

title: Special Topics in the Study of Religion - American Religious Utopias and Communal Experiments
descrip: This seminar will examine manifestations of the utopian impulse in American religious history with attention to such topics as theological visions of the perfect society, the lived religious worlds of intentional communities, gender, race, and sexuality in utopian communities, religious dystopia, imaginative visions of utopia/dystopia, and contemporary examples of intentional religious communities.

title: Nation of Immigrants, A
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Latin Historiography - Sallust
descrip: The course offers the chance to read the Catiline and the Jugurtha complete and in depth, as well as the major fragments of the Histories, together with an introduction to recent scholarship.

title: Intermediate/Advanced French
reviews: A good course. Make sure you do the exercises in the book, and you'll be fine.
Be ready for busywork. There was one day in particular where we got a crapton of work (like 18 pages of exercises) assigned overnight for really no good reason.
Do practice tests.
Good class, ask for Anne Ambrogelly for your prof.
I don't particularly enjoy french, but with this professor it was allot of fun
I really recommend this teacher if you are in the course.

If you end up in a class with Professor Ambrogelly, consider yourself very, very, lucky. She's great! That being said, the format of the course is a little frustrating -- it's a language class. Do with it what you can.
If you have to take 107, it's not bad at all.  Rather fun, at some times.  Try not to take it at 9am because tests at 9am are miserable and I was always pretty groggy.
If you want to round off your French education, take this class. It's not the most exciting class you'll ever take. There's a lot of grammar and busy homework, but it gets the job done.

If you're taking this class, then most likely it is for the language requirement, but that doesn't mean you can't enjoy it.  Anne Ambrogelly was a phenomenal professor and taught us a lot while making everything accessible and interesting.  If you have the ability to take any French 100-level course with her, do it!
It is about on par with most other classes.  No surprises, its rewarding if you put in a little effort.
It's French.
It's a good course to have!
It's not a joke, it's a hard class

Language departments make it very difficult to discover which classes are taught by grad students or actual professors, but if at all possible, switch into one with a professor, even if you must do so by sitting in on a full class and trying to wait for a slot to open up. It will greatly improve your experience.
Make sure you keep up with all the vocab
Make sure you take it with Ambrogelly.

Most people taking this class are simply doing it to fulfill their language requirement. If this is your goal, this is a fine class but otherwise, I might suggest a class with more committed students.
Prepare for a lot of independent work.
Professor Ambrogelly keeps the material engaging and interesting. Your french will improve.

Professor Ambrogelly said she revamped this course from previous years, and I really did enjoy it.  The structure is very similar to 102 with compositions and revues de presse.  All the grammar is a review from 101 and 102, but we learn more about French culture and society with videos and readings.  There's a little bit of work in the course packet or the grammar book each night, so it is easy to work ahead for the week if you so desire.  It's not a bad way at all to finish the language requirement.
Study a lot. Practice French everyday.
Take it and make sure to participate because that is the only way to improve!
Take it with Vincent
Take this course. It is just an advanced version of FRE 102. The grammar lessons are same so you will actually need to study less than before.
This course could be extremely interesting or painful depending on your professor. Try getting into the section with Anne Ambrogelly or Muriel Perrier, they are amazing!
To do the readings more than once to understand them as much as possible before class
You don't really have a choice if you have to take it for your language requirement.
anne ambrogelly is so great!
definitely do your homework and stay on top of everything we are learning.
prereqs: FRE 102 or FRE 103..
descrip: The main objective of this course is to develop your listening, speaking and writing skills, while giving you a foundation for understanding and appreciation of French-speaking cultures. There is a thorough review of French grammar and a selection of communicative activities chosen to improve proficiency and give practice of newly acquired linguistic material. A wide range of authentic material will be offered, including readings from the media, short stories and contemporary texts, films and songs.

title: Architecture Design Studio
reviews: I would suggest that any student in studio with Liam Young be adventurous, rigorous and daring.
When taking this studio, push yourself to think about architecture as much as you can, and I think your film will be stronger. Also consider how you might work with non-linear forms of narrative.
descrip: Vertical Design Studio

title: An Integrated Introduction to Engineering, Mathematics, Physics
reviews: As with physics, this course depends on the teacher, which for us was Kunal Chaudhury. His lectures were kinda jumbled, and the general consensus was that the class learned from our preceptor, Haoshu Tian, and the book more. It's math, so I feel like everything I learned in this class I learned during Reading Period :/
DON'T TAKE THIS COURSE!!!!!  You will regret it if you do.  I warned you!
Despite Kunal not being the best, EMP 192 is a good course- I recommend taking it.
EGR 192 is not worth it by itself. The only redeeming factor of the EMP course is the rocket lab.
I recommend the course in general but Kunal was not a very good teacher
I would advise him to not waste his time going to class and not even take the class if this same professor was teaching it.

I would highly recommend the EMP sequence if only for the physics lab component. MAT 201 may have been a superior math course to this one, but I would still recommend taking EGR 191 and EGR 192 together to complete the math and physics requirements for freshmen in the B.S.E. program. Another plus is the final is a take home, which was very helpful since we learned so much information over the course of the semester that an open note exam was appreciated.
I would not recommend taking this course, although the EMP physics version was slightly better.
I would say that the textbook is an invaluable tool in learning and understanding, and that my preceptor was a superb person when further explanation was needed.

I wouldn't recommend this course to anybody that struggles reading math textbooks and needs a teacher to clarify the material. I flew solo in this course and learned multivariable calculus by myself essentially. If you are going to take it, read the textbook before and during class to follow along on what he is saying. Don't take notes in class. Do it after. Unless you write at the speed of sound, you probably will miss something and become even more confused at the chaos. Also, take time and do the psets. They can be long, which was fine with me. The psets are helpful for making you learn the material and connect the dots.
If you are an engineering student I would definitely take this course. Otherwise, take regular multivariable.
If you are comfortable teaching yourself out of a book-- go for it! The physics half of EMP was really fun. If you need more guidance in math, then you may be out of luck...

If you are interested in learning multivariable calculus deeply, don't take this course: it gives you only the bare minimum of concepts. From what I've seen, MAT 201 is only marginally better, though. 

I feel like I learned as much multi from this class as I did learning single-variable calculus from Barron's AP study guide. Take something harder if you think math is fun (I did math contests in high school, so I do). If you want an "easy" or "trivial" math course, though, this fits the bill.
If you don't mind learning from a book, take this course so you can take EGR 191

If you're planning on engineering, and you don't want a giant lecture or a bunch of math majors in your class, I'd recommend this class. Be prepared to teach yourself/work with classmates for the content Kunal teaches; unfortunately you might not have Haoshu because I don't think TAs generally do multiple years of the same course. The assignments are generally relevant, though, and the practice exams are very useful for preparing for the actual exams. Also, despite the course description, I don't think the course focused on applications more than a regular math class would have - but it doesn't involve a ton of proofs, either.
It really depends on the professor.
It's a gamble, depending on what professor is teaching in your year. Could go very well or very badly.
Just read the textbook.
Just take 201.
Learn the material well. Use the textbook.
Material is interesting. Would have been a good course with a better lecturer.
Not as good as the analogous MAT 201. Of course, the physics complement is great, so win/lose.
Only if you really like the idea of EMP and are fine with reading the book and teaching yourself.

Take it if you want smaller class structure (for physics primarily its important) and if you want to do the rocket lab. Don't bother if you place out of physics. 
Try to go over your problem sets as you get them back, what you did wrong. Try to get Haoshu to do office hours or go to him if you have any questions. Stay on top of things.
Take multi in highschool because the teachers here don't bother to teach you.
Take notes from the book
Take this course if you already have a strong background in multivariable calculus, as the lectures will do virtually nothing to help you.

The course itself is just like MAT 201, with the addition of Ordinary Differential Equations. It is not taught in conjunction with EGR 191, which is unfortunate but fine. The instructor was not good. If he is teaching, I recommend enrolling in a different course.

This course, while not necessarily always easy, is rather low-stress alternative to MAT 201. The lectures, while dry, were straightforward, and I feel like I was able to come to a better understanding of multivariable calculus. Take it, it's not the best, but it's certainly not a bad class, and the physics counterpart is enjoyable too.
Under no circumstances should you subjugate yourself to this course. The physics portion is good, and the lab is cool, however it does NOT balance the sheer awfulness of Kunal as a professor.
Unless you're really interested in analyzing math all the way from the proof to the application, I would probably just take Math 201 instead.
need to spend a lot of time studying outside of class- if you don't have the time then don't take it
take haoshu as a preceptor
prereqs: All first-year engineering students who have placement into multivariable calculus on the basis of a score of 5 on the BC calculus exam (or equivalent) are eligible to enroll..
descrip: Taken concurrently with EGR/MAT/PHY 191, this course offers an integrated presentation of the material from PHY 103 (General Physics: Mechanics and Thermodynamics) and MAT 201 (Multivariable Calculus) with an emphasis on applications to engineering. Math topics include: vector calculus; partial derivatives and matrices; line integrals; simple differential equations; surface and volume integrals; and Green's, Stokes', and divergence theorems.

title: Geodynamics
reviews: I would cautiously encourage others to take the course but warn them to be ready for what they're getting into.
Make sure you've taken Multivariable Calculus. Extra plus if you've taken Differential Equations. A good class for people interested in geodynamics. Take it only if you enjoy the topic.
None
Read before class and come with questions.
The weekly homework takes a while to do, the lectures can be difficult to understand
prereqs: MAT 201 or 202.
descrip: An advanced introduction to setting up and solving boundary value problems relevant to the solid earth sciences. Topics include heat flow, fluid flow, elasticity and plate flexure, and rock rheology, with applications to mantle convection, magma transport, lithospheric deformation, structural geology, and fault mechanics.

title: Contemporary Logic Design
reviews: A lot of work for a pdf, but the first 2/3 of the class were fabulous. A great way to learn how computers work at the circuit level.

A time-consuming class, not worth the effort for most.  Malik is a very smart man who want to see his students do well.  However, when I took it, the lab TAs were for the most part unhelpful, which made doing most of the problem sets and lab assignments a real pain.  I would recommend only to ELEs and people really interested in computer architecture.  I took it as a COS in search of a departmental sophomore year, and think it was a mistake.
Be sure to learn the basics of Verilog first so that the labs take less time. Also be sure not to overt hink every problem.
Don't bother, unless you need it as some prerequisite.
Don't take unless you are considering being an ELE major. It's not for the rest of us, the material is interesting but you will find it tedious
Don't underestimate how bad the last lab is. Start early. Also, for exams you need to have understood the entire material very well.
Enjoy the lectures!
Go to all the lectures.  You'll gain a zoomed-out and holistic understanding of digital logic that is lost in the textbook with all its details.
Go to the undergrad TAs for help early and often
Good class for ELE and COS; don't take it otherwise.
Good.
Great course! The rumor is that its one of the easiest ELE intro courses, and that's true. It did teach me a lot about digital logic, and is a great course!

Hardly any guidance on how to program in verilog - we are basically handed some info packets and expected to go at it in lab. If you have no prior experience in programming, this will be a very difficult course. Subject is interesting though, just the exams are very difficult.

If you want to take this course to see how computers are designed from the ground up, this class is perfect, and is very well structured.  Professor Malik is a very clever teacher who is patient to a fault.  However, if you're looking for a class to learn how to program in Verilog, this class doesn't really help; you may just be better learning on your own.
Interesting for even an econ major trying to take ST! Make sure that you're ready to use up a lot of time towards the end on PUnC (the final project)
Interesting material, boring lectures.

Its a very nice course and you learn a lot from it. But the labs are just annoying. Not difficult at all but very, very, very annoying. Because most of the time in lab is spent figuring out what to do rather than how to do it.
Its not the best course ever but I think you get a new view on electronics and circuits so in that regard it is useful.
Leave a lot of time in order to learn Verilog language.
Lectures and problem sets can be a bit dull and tedious. Labs are where the class comes alive, but be prepared to put in the time as the semester closes.

Malik is a great lecturer. Sometimes a little slow paced, but outstanding clarity. Labs sucked though, the TAs were terrible for the most part and never actually taught us Verilog. Definitely take if you can handle a few hours of torture in lab every week...lecture and the subject matter make up for it.
Mixed feelings
Only take if you think you'll LOVE Logic Design and chips, or if you have to.

Only take this course if you really want to know about how computers work on a hardware level (or are an ELE and have to). I found the concepts in this course to be fascinating, and that was enough for me to see past the terrible labs and organization. If you don't love logic design, though, you're going to hate this course.
Prepare to be bored. Very, very bored. If you know any verilog that labs will be very easy. Not that hard of a class.
Read the book as you go.

Start lab assignments early, and get help early when there are TA hours available. The assignments will get longer and longer throughout the year, so be prepared to spend many hours in the lab towards the end of the semester.

Start labs early, and find a partner ahead of time for homework assignments. Also, be sure to always attend lecture. Professor Malik is an awesome lecturer, so be sure to make the most of it. This is  a really fun course!
Stay on top of the material!

Take ELE 206! If you're at all interested in how things work, take this course! If you're a COS major, you'll learn all about the digital circuit underpinnings of processors and memory and come to a whole new appreciation of hardware components. If you're ELE, well, you have to take it (but it's great, so don't worry!).
Take it if you like computer architecture and want to deal with some weird compiler error messages.
Take it with a friend in mind to be your lab partner. You may be spending a lot of time with them at the end of the semester.
This was a very interesting class. Though there is a lot of written work, the material was fun.
Very easy STL. Moved slowly, reminiscent of high school classes.
Yawn. The people who do the best are the ones who care the least.
attend lectures
if you have to take this class, start the labs early.
descrip: Introduction to the basic concepts in logic design that form the basis of computation and communication circuits. Logic gates and memeory elements. Timing methodologies. Finite state systems. Programmable logic. Basic computer organization.

title: The Arts of Japan
descrip: ART 217 surveys the arts of Japan from the pre-historic period through the present day. Painting, sculpture, and architecture form the core of study, though we will also examine the critical role of other forms, including calligraphy, lacquer, and ceramics. Throughout the course we will take close account of the broader cultural and historical contexts in which art was made. Our topics include the ongoing tension in Japanese art between the foreign and the indigenous, the role of ritual in Japan's visual arts, the re-uses of the past, the changing loci of patronage, and the formats and materials of Japanese art.

title: Quantitative Analysis in Psychological Research
descrip: An introduction to quantitative methods in psychological research appropriate for first and second year graduate students. The topics covered include experimental design, null hypothesis significance testing, power, effect size, and confidence intervals. Specific procedures covered include ANOVA, ANCOVA, multiple regression, moderation, and mediation.

title: Seminar on Education-Theory and Practice
prereqs: Prerequisites: See Teacher Preparation Program requirements. Course requires admission into the Teacher Preparation Program. Enrollment limited to students doing their practice teaching (TPP 402) except by special permission from the program director..
descrip: Seminar taken concurrently with Practice Teaching (TPP402). Students investigate the processes of curriculum development and implementation, develop learning goals and rubrics for assessment, study national and local issues in education and their impact on schools, examine current philosophies and effective practices, reflect on their work and evaluate their performance as practice teachers.

title: Introductory Video and Film Production
reviews: ABSOLUTELY RECOMMENDED! I will never watch a film the same way-- it makes you appreciate how much goes into the filmmaking process! It is such a beautiful form of art. I am so incredibly thankful that I took this class.

Assignments are not difficult but they are not particularly relevant or helpful either. The final project is nice because you can do whatever you'd like. It's worth taking the class just for the final project and so that you can take the next video class.

Be warned: this course takes up A LOT of time. Be prepared to spend a lot of time both in and outside class working on assignments. Plan your time very well; the equipment loan schedule is very rigid and you'll need to budget your time wisely and well in advance.
Make sure you really want to do this. If you do, it will be great. If you don't, don't waste your time or the professor's or your peers'.
TAKE THIS CLASS!!!!!

This course is a commitment. Make sure you have time to do the assignments and to do them well, otherwise you are squandering a great opportunity to learn a lot about film. 6 hours of class a week is a lot!
prereqs: Admission by application and interview with the instructor. Interviews will take place in April. Please visit the Lewis Center Visual Arts website for application information and interview calendar link to schedule an interview..
descrip: A film/video course introducing the techniques of shooting and editing digital video. Works of film/video art will be analyzed in class to explore the development of, and innovations in, cinematic language. Production will be oriented toward film/video as a visual art, including narrative, documentary, and experimental genres. Several short video projects will be produced during the semester.

title: Experimental Project Laboratory in Quantitative and Computational Biology
reviews: DON'T LISTEN TO TONY.  HE WILL TELL YOU THE WRONG THING.  MY LAB NOTEBOOK HAS "TONY WAS WRONG" EVERY 10 PAGES.  HE HAS VERY LIMITED KNOWLEDGE OF BIOLOGY, AND WHETHER OR NOT SOMETHING WILL WORK, AND HOW MACHINES OR MECHANISMS WORK.  That said, this is a wonderful course with more lab space and attention then you're ever going to get for the rest of your life.  Enjoy.

It's probably about what you've heard - lots of time in lab and no guarantees of success like in MOL Core Lab, but you get to work with Botstein and some awesome Lewis-Sigler fellows and pretty much do whatever project you want!  Plan your experiments ahead of time, do proper controls, be meticulous.

Take it!  Great faculty who are willing to help you do your own project, including offering some of their labs' latest results and technologies.  It is indeed time-consuming, but note that most of that will be during the second half of the semester.
prereqs: ISC/CHM/COS/MOL/PHY 231-234 and 235 -236, or by permission of the instructor. Students planning to major in Molecular Biology are encouraged to take MOL 350 in the spring of their sophomore year..
descrip: An intensive double credit course focusing on state-of-the-art experimental design and practice in quantitative biology. Emphasis is placed on functional genomics using global genome-wide measurements (e.g. microarray gene expression, sequence, phenotype) to understand physiological and evolutionary processes. Begins with a short introduction to technology and principles, followed by the design and execution of independent projects done by pairs of students in collaboration, with the continuing guidance and advice of the teaching staff.

title: Intensive Beginner's and Intermediate French
reviews: Because French 101 & 102 are combined in this accelerated course, the pace is rather difficult to adjust to and keep up with. However, the department really goes out of its way to provide additional resources and make the transition smooth. There is a large variety in assignments so they don't feel repetitive. There is homework every night but it isn't checked so it's up to you to take responsibility for learning concepts that you struggle with. Professor Hart was amazing and I wish that I could have her as my French teacher for the rest of my French classes at Princeton.
Definitely take this course.  It's a great foundation course that you can use as a stepping stone to go further on in French.
Go to class and participate often.
Good professor, didn't mind the class.
I would advise keeping up with the homework assignments and readings because they are necessary to do well in the class.

I would recommend this course to students who are confident in their ability to handle most of the entry level concepts in a language in a week or two before moving on to concepts that a high school French program will take four years to get to, and in a more thorough manner than that aforementioned high school French program.
I would say if you need to take French, Prof. Hart was a good teacher and a very nice person.
I would take any class with Rachel Hart and recommend 103 if you are interested in french
Keep up with the independent homework assignments, as that will help you pick up the language faster.
Keep up with the readings in Motifs, because it actually does really help, especially if you read the chapter before/during the lessons.
Really good. I would really recommend this class to whoever has somewhat of a background in French and wants to further develop their French skills.
Show up to class (on time!) and you'll be fine.
Solid language class with a good professor.
Study a lot of the little grammar rules and make sure you try hard.
Take it take it take it it's awesome OMG
Take it!
Take it! Be sure to keep up with the homework, as it will make studying for tests less stressful.
Take it!!

The course moves pretty fast, which can seem overwhelming at times. However, when you look back on how much you've picked up in such a short time, it's quite rewarding. It's a course you almost have to take (I would definitely prefer it to taking 101 & 102), and meeting everyday might seem like a hassle, but it's very much worth it, especially if you try and participate in the slightest bit.

The difficulty and preparedness of other students was much higher than I'd expected. Having taken multiple years of high school French (I was admittedly rusty), I thought 103 was the correct level. I believe 101 would have been more manageable for me, and also would not have skimmed over things like vocab which I was not already competent in. If you are unsure about your French abilities, I would recommend going for 101 instead of 103. Take 103 if you are already fairly confident with beginning French but want to tune up your skills.
This course is more about grammar, so thus a really easy language course.
This is a great intro to French

This is more challenging than I thought it would be. It says about 2 years of high school french required, but you should have more than that before taking this or you'll be very behind. Great class though and so much fun!

You definitely get out of the class the effort you put into it. The class was well structured for maximum development in the language, you just have to do it. Do the homework, and do the stuff in the course packet. I didn't do as well in the class as I probably could have because I skipped out on doing a lot of the course packet stuff, and it affected me in the end. You have to put in the time to learn a language. You will learn if you don't do a lot of work, but don't expect an A.
if you are looking to take a language i would recommend charlie.
repetition
prereqs: Prerequisites include approximately two years of high school French and an appropriate score on the Princeton French Language Placement Test..
descrip: FRE 103 is an intensive beginning and intermediate language course designed for students who have already studied French (typically no more than 2-3 years). Covering in one semester the material presented in FRE 101 and FRE 102, this course prepares students to take FRE 107 the following semester. Classroom activities include comprehension and grammar exercises, conversation, skits, and working with a variety of audio-visual materials.

title: America and the Melting Pot
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Dante's Inferno
reviews: If you're even remotely interested, I would take it (if Marchesi is teaching it). He's so knowledgeable and makes the material interesting.
Take this class.
This course is an absolute must. I really enjoyed it. My Italian and my appreciation of the Inferno both improved greatly.
This course is phenomenal and this Professor is phenomenal. Take the course.
descrip: Intensive study of the "Inferno", with major attention paid to poetic elements such as structure, allegory, narrative technique, and relation to earlier literature, principally the Latin classics. Course conducted in Italian with highly interactive classes and preceptorials.

title: Advanced Arabic Skills Workshop
reviews: Good class to improve your reading skills. This will make you a better reader and you will be able to understand the things you read better. It is not focused on speech or writing, but you get a lot of different texts to read and go through them thoroughly on your own and in class.
I would suggest taking this course if you plan on doing research in Arabic, but not if you've completed third year in the language and are looking for more of the same.

If you've gotten to this level of Arabic, I hope you've figured out that the way we teach Arabic in the U.S. is awful. This class is a great example of just how out-of-touch Arabic instruction can be.

There are plenty of people at Princeton who are amazingly capable and smart with a strong desire to learn Arabic. Sadly, they won't. To learn a language, you need to actually use it, but they will never get to practice. Sure, learn your case endings for MSA, but understand that they are used only in a very limited way when Arabs speak in MSA with each other.

The instructor (Hisham Mahmoud) did not speak Arabic during this class. You will not speak Arabic during this class. You will translate very old texts aloud into English. You will not learn any of the words you are looking up - you will just get faster at using a dictionary. Your time is better spent elsewhere, like finding a language exchange partner to talk to over Skype.

Unfortunately, if you're interested in actually using Arabic to talk to people, this is a class to stay as far away from as possible. Princeton's Arabic department is highly lacking at higher levels. The instructor came across as pretentious and made sure we knew he had no interest in teaching Arabic for any non-religious purpose.
It's basically like learning it on your own.

You have to take control of your own education in this course.  If you want to advance your Arabic, you will have to independently find your own homework assignments and opportunities to speak in Arabic.
prereqs: ARA 302 or the equivalent.
descrip: Advanced readings in modern Arabic literature. Major emphasis on syntax and the accurate understanding of authentic material. Also some readings for overall understanding, with discussion in Arabic.

title: Optical Electronics
reviews: A very good course, but need some background knowledge about electrodynamics, quantum mechanics, photonics, etc.
Have a good familiarity with Electricity and Magnetism and at least a moderate familiarity with Quantum Mechanics before attempting the course. Reference the lecture notes frequently.
It takes a lot of time before lasers bring everything else in the course together. Stick with the mathematical derivations and the reward will come then.

This course can be very challenging, particularly with the level of mathematics involved to justify experimental observations. Come to class early because the professor takes time to review discussions in previous lectures. These review sessions are extremely helpful if you come to class prepared having read the material from the previous lecture.
Will take a lot of work to keep up with the lecture material (which is key, because you can't learn this anywhere else). Overall interesting subject.
descrip: Fundmentals of light-matter interactions, waveguides and resonators, nonlinear optics and lasers.

title: Research Program in Development Studies
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Advanced Workshop in Musical Composition - Topics in Twenty-First Century Tonality
reviews: Absolutely take it! Multiple times if possible!

For the final piece (the one that determines practically all of your grade): probably a good idea to find your musicians BEFORE you write the piece, especially if you're using nontraditional instruments, or instruments that not a lot of people play. Preparation for the final concert is VERY time-consuming and stressful, more so if you have lots of musicians.
I would strongly recommend this course to another student. It's great!
If you have any interest in composition, take this course.
It's a great class and to get you acquainted with modern music and help with your music.
Take it if you can! I would qualify this and say that you should be a strong music academic because you will learn the most if you are.
Take this course, you won't regret it!  Lots of fun, and you'll probably learn a lot.  More than you would expect anyway.
prereqs: Some previous compositional experience. Pick up application in Woolworth Room 310..
descrip: Music 310 is a composition course for independent, self-directed composers, working in any style whatsoever. The major requirement is to compose a substantial piece, and to present it at our class concert at the end of the semester. Each week students will present drafts of their pieces to the class in workshop format. In addition, I will ask you to listen to (and think about) various provocative pieces over the course of the semester. I may also provide a few assignments to get everyone started.

title: Environmental Economics
reviews: Interesting content but Prof Brunnermeier is sometimes hard to follow during lecture because she talks quite fast - try to take extensive notes, it will help you understand the material better for when psets, midterms, and the final roll around. Study hard because everyone basically does the same.
Since readings are mostly optional, do attend all the lectures.  I think that participating actively in class will make this a much more rewarding experience!
Take it.
Take it. It has a lot of Econ juniors and seniors and you should take it only after ECO300/310. Don't be a fool like me and take it without the prerequisites.
at times, the lecture material is very boring, but overall, the course is pretty interesting and also, there are only 4 problem sets, so that's a plus
prereqs: MAT 103 or equivalent and ECO 300 OR equivalent..
descrip: Course introduces use of economics in understanding both the sources of and the remedies to environmental and resource allocation problems. It emphasizes the reoccurrence of economic phenomena like public goods, externalities, market failure and imperfect information. Students learn about the design and evaluation of environmental policy instruments, the politicaleconomy of environmental policy, and the valuation of environmental andnatural resource services. The concepts are illustrated in a variety of applications from domestic pollutin of air, water and land to international issues such as global warming and sustainable development.

title: Studies in Persian Literature 900 - 1200 A.D.
prereqs: PER 302 or permission of instructor.
descrip: This two-term exploration of Classical Persian literature in the original acquaints students with the principal authors of chronicles, epics, imaginative tales, and stories of spiritual initiation throughout the Persian-speaking world (Iran and Central Asia and also medieval India and Anatolia) from the 10th to 19th centuries. Part I, ca. AD 900 - ca. AD 1200, addresses the formation and gradual Islamization of the ancient epic tradition, the writing of "mirrors for kings" for the Ghaznavid and Seljuk sultans, and the impact of Neoplatonic mysticism.

title: Coeducation
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Modern Chinese Thought
reviews: Def. take this course
Do all of the readings every week (it'll be really evident if you don't) and get started on the term paper early!

If you are really interested in China, this is an essential. Sometimes it became an outlet for Chinese Americans to vent their frustrations about Chinese culture, but Zhou was good about keeping it academic. You don't need to have a knowledge of Chinese history, but it certainly means you will get more out of it.
