Zhou has pretty strong opinions about the subject matter, but is incredibly intelligent and knowledgeable.

TAKE THIS CLASS. I am a BaiRen and I took Chinese Levels 1-3 (Fre/PIB/Soph) @ princeton. This is a great class where you learn about why Modern China is the way it is today. Also Chou LaoShi occasionally uses simple chinese sentences to illustrate themes or points, which is great because It makes you feel like you know a lot.
Take it if you are at all interested in China.  Chou Laoshi is an expert and teaches very well.  Best seminar I've taken at Princeton.
Take it if you're interested in Chinese history and the writings of intellectuals; be prepared for a lot of readings; be ready to talk about it in seminar
descrip: A systematic study of problems and concepts connected with the development of modern Chinese thought. Such issues as antitraditionalism, the rise of communism, the emancipation of women, the promotion of Western ideologies and the process of modernization will be treated.

title: Mapping the Universe
reviews: DO IT. psets are fun and graded fairly, but always try to go to class since Gott is very interesting. There's also a lecture where students get to eat pizza!
Gott's the man. Take it for an easy and super fun STN.
If you are interested in this subject, take it. But if not, I recommend to not take it.
If you love the material, you'll love the course.

If you need a fifth course, take this one. I did at most 10 minutes of work per week (this is no exaggeration) and am getting an A. However I had a little bit of prior knowledge and a somewhat sciency background, but not too much to give me an unfair advantage.
Do not try to endure the lectures; they are actually pointless.
It's an easy STN

Little work involved. Take it if for a light work class, but be aware that you probably won't get a lot out of it. Lectures are pretty much incomprehensible, but thankfully the problem sets are easy and have nothing to do with the lecture material.

Only take it if you want to get an STN out of the way. It's easy but sometimes nervewracking because it's hard to tell what you actually need to know. A good fifth class to take. The free pizza was great.

Professor Gott is a great teacher; I highly recommend you take a course with him if you have the opportunity.  The map projections part of this course is pretty interesting, but the rest, especially the part on relativity, is incredibly interesting.  If you're interested in learning more about the universe, you should take it.
Professor Gott is a very intelligent and entertaining lecturer and makes the course a great experience.

Really don't.
Don't do this to yourself.

Since Professor Gott wrote most of the books for the course, his lectures often sound like him reading the book aloud. If you don't quite catch something in lecture, read the books and you'll get the same information there. The readings are super helpful in that respect.
TAKE THE COURSE

Take this course if you would like a relatively easy-going ST course. Assignments are sparse and easy to complete. Gott is a very interesting individual and has a lot (emphasis on a lot) of knowledge to offer.
This is a good way to fill distribution requirements.
descrip: We will begin by discussing the cartographers' problem of mapping the curved surface of the Earth onto a flat plane, and compare different map projections and their properties. We consider projections for mapping the Moon, Mars, Jupiter, and the sky. Other topics include mapping the solar system and galaxy, the Sloan Digital Sky Survey 3D map of the visible universe, the WMAP map of the cosmic microwave background, Einstein's mapping of space and time, and mapping the inside of the black hole. Finally, we explore the Gott-Juric Map of the Universe, showing everything from satellites in low Earth orbit to distant galaxies and quasars.

title: Numerical Methods
reviews: This class was a little more theoretical and more challenging than I had expected, but it was overall a pretty good class.

This is a great way to learn about numerical methods. The course provides a nice balance between learning the theory of these algorithms and actually implementing them in MATLAB. A must-take for anyone interested in applied math.
prereqs: MAT201 and 202, or MAT203 and 204, or equivalent..
descrip: Introduction to numerical methods with emphasis on algorithms, applications and computer implementation issues. Topics covered include solution of nonlinear equations; numerical differentiation, integration, and interpolation; direct and iterative methods for solving linear systems; numerical solutions of differential equations; two-point boundary value problems; and approximation theory. Lectures are supplemented with numerical examples using MATLAB.

title: An Integrated, Quantitative Introduction to the Natural Sciences III
reviews: If you love biology (like I do),  and you don't mind being challenged and struggling a bit academically, you'll like this class. Definitely take first year ISC before taking this course, though. Otherwise it's kind of a shock in terms of the pace and the way things are done.

If you've come this far, it's so worth finishing it, even if you're majoring in something that's not related to ISC. There's no lab, psets only take 2-7 hours, the lectures are understandable and epic, and the professors are still unbelievably mindblowing.
It's ISC without the lab and without physics.

Take first year ISC before doing this. 
Ask questions in lecture.
Take it if you liked first year and are considering chem/mol.
This is worth taking.  Seriously.
prereqs: Students should have completed ISC/CHM/COS/MOL/PHY 231-234, or equivalent preparation (MOL 214, COS 126, CHM 201-202 or 203-204, PHY 103-104 or 105-106), or received permission from Instructor..
descrip: An integrated, mathematically and computationally sophisticated introduction to biochemistry, molecular biology, genetics, genomics and evolution. This course is designed as a sequence: 235 in the fall and 236 in the spring. Multiple faculty will be involved over the year: D. Botstein, M. Murthy, E. Wieschaus (MOL), J. Rabinowitz (CHM), P. Andolfatto (EEB). 2 hrs and 40 min of lecture, one precept (1 hr 50 min), one evening problem session.

title: Calculus I
reviews: Always go to class! A lot of people skip this class for some reason (not sure why especially because I had an 11 o'clock section) and I really thought them to be quite silly for it, because the lectures were always great at explaining the material, and I would hate to have to read through the textbook to understand everything.
Always stay engaged in class and keep up with the material.
Attend all of the lectures so you don't get lost.
Attend all the lectures
Attend as many office hours as possible!
Be ready to do a lot of studying on your own. The class is good and has a great atmosphere though.
Be ready to reteach yourself a lot of calculus.
Choose Professor Fefferman as your teacher!
Do all of the practice quizzes/tests/exams.
Do not take if you do not have a strong mathematics background, unless you have a lot of time to work with teachers/tutors.

Do not take it with Professor Sodin. The material is not that bad especially if you go to the McGraw Study Halls. But, it is very difficult to understand why you are doing the problems without the instruction from the teacher which simply does not happen in his class.
Do not take this class if you don't have to. If you simply enjoy Math, you probably won't like the course, and if you don't, you will find it way too hard.
Do not take unless you've taken some form of calculus before.
Do practice tests and quizzes and you'll be fine.
Do the homework and go to McGraw.
Do the homework and take notes! The past quizzes are really helpful as well.
Do the homework in little pieces at a time.
Do the problem sets! Study for quizzes and exams!
Do well on the quizzes! Problem sets don't count that much but they are crucial for understanding the material.
Do you homework and go to class and you'll be fine.
Don't be afraid. I got a 1 in AP Calculus AB in high school and got an A in the course. Just make sure you take the class with Fickenscher.
Don't do hw by yourself. Office hours are great, mcGraw tutor hours are great too, no reason you shouldnt do well on hw, just make sure you understand everything when you use these resources
Don't fall behind on the quizzes, keep studying for them! They get harder as the year goes on.
Don't take your high school AP background for granted. Be particular with your problem sets and always take notes in class even if you know them backwards.
Dude its Cal take the class
Either place out of another section or, especially if you have taken calculus before, go straight into MAT 104 and make sure you appropriately review the MAT 103 in the textbook.
Enroll in Jon's class.
FICKENSCHER IS THE BEST!

Find students to do the problem set with! Do it two nights before because it takes longer than you think! Also, the exams and quizzes are more similar to the past exams/quizzes than the homeworks (so prioritize those when reviewing).

GO TO OFFICE HOURS!!!!! There is no reason to get even one problem wrong on the homework if you go to office hours. And in the end looking back at the homework problems really helped me to prepare for the quiz problems.
Go to McGraw every week for help with problem sets. Other than that, it's a pretty good class.
Go to lecture. Missing that one hour of lecture means spending at least 4 hours reading through the chapters relevant to that week's homework assignment.
Go to office hours to ask about questions on homework. Check answers with multiple people. Take practice quizzes.
Go to office hours.
Go to office hours...or else! Calculus is a hard subject to grasp. If you still want to take the course, make sure you get Fickenscher. He will make your life a lot easier.

Go to study hall! I went to study hall for the first three quarters of the semester because I had some problems following what was happening in class. The tutors there helped me think about math in new ways and I did a lot better in this class than I thought I would.
Go to the lectures and do problems sets with other people in your class, and the course should not be too difficult at all.
Go to the lectures, take notes, and read them--they will help you tons as you study for your quizzes and tests
Good for people who have already taken the subject or are strong.  Needs an enormous amount of self-motivation for those who are struggling.
Good starting class to take for math at princeton.
Having taken calculus before this course is important

Having taking AB calculus in high school, this was a fairly easy class that did not demand too much time. But, if you have not taken calculus before you will need to teach yourself a lot of the topics.

I found that this course did not prepare you well for the quizzes and assignments. Jon did a good job trying to keep people engaged at most times but I think the course would definitely improve if more applicable examples were done in class. Also the office hours always conflicted with athletics. A decent course that most people are required to take but it is bearable and you learn some interesting things.

prereqs: MAT 100 or equivalent. Solid knowledge of precalculus (standard functions, algebra, trigonometry) is assumed..
descrip: First semester of calculus. Topics include limits, continuity, the derivative, basic differentiation formulas and applications (curve-sketching, optimization, related rates), definite and indefinite integrals, the fundamental theorem of calculus.

title: Problems in Post-Classical and Byzantine Greek Literature - Post-Classical and Byzantine Greek Historiography
descrip: This course will survey the diverse corpus of late antique and medieval historiography written in Greek from the 4th to the 9th centuries when an unprecedented number of registers enlarged the historiographic genre(s) of 'New Rome'. We will read texts in Greek (for accuracy and formal concerns) as well as in translation (for scope). Scholarship will buttress weekly discussion as post-classical historical texts are brought to bear on contemporary debates about the nature of (non-)narrative form and the epistemological underpinnings of historiography as a species of literature comprised of truth claims about the past.

title: Arts of Protest
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Happening: Performance & Spectacle In Russian Culture and Beyond
descrip: What is performance theory? Can it be applicable in fields other than performance studies? The course begins with a close reading of foundational theoretical texts, then zeros in on a number of uniquely Russian contributions. Special attention is given to visual material.

title: Seminar in Japanese Art and Archaeology - Appropriation and the Arts in Pre-Meiji Japan
descrip: Appropriation - of style, iconography, and actual objects - contributed substantially to shaping the arts of Japan. Japanese artists borrowed from China and Korea, from the West, and from within Japan itself. Whether the thing borrowed was a mode of depiction or an object, the appropriation was an active engagement with the source and a response to it that involved conceptual transformation. A range of examples will be studied, including ink painting, chanoyu (tea ceremony), and Floating World prints, exploring appropriation as impediment or stimulus to innovation, assertion of cultural dominance, and mediation of the past.

title: History of East Asia to 1800
reviews: Don't leave the essays to the last minute! Actually study for the midterm and final!
Go to lecture! Write your papers quickly -- they're not that big a deal. Just write them and cite sources.
I would advise it as a good department requirement.

I would highly recommend this course if you are looking for a solid general knowledge of Chinese and Japanese history. Although the course technically covers over 3,000 years of history, it presents the material in such a way that one can thoroughly understand the most significant events of each Chinese dynasty or Japanese period, the prevailing philosophies of each, and the political transitions between them. The workload is fair, and the readings are pretty interesting. The lectures can sometimes get a little dry, but they definitely help reinforce the material.
If a student has any interest in history or East Asian culture, he should definitely consider taking it.
If interested in East Asian history and learning ways to look at history in general, I would definitely take this course!
Lectures are very helpful.
Not very challenging, good course if you're interested in east asian history
Start readings as soon as possible, come up with some questions before precept.
Take the course if you're interested in East Asia. Attend lectures and look out for general themes and important figures throughout east asian history.
This course is very broad, but the material is interesting. There is a lot of reading and sometimes it is not incredibly interesting, but it is manageable. I enjoyed the course.
prereqs: P/D/F option is not available for History concentrators..
descrip: A general introduction to the history of the political cultures in China and Japan, with some heed to comparisons with developments in Korea and the Mediterranean worlds.

title: Design of Very Large-Scale Integrated (VLSI) Systems
reviews: Great class! You learn a lot, and Professor Verma is one of the best lecturers around! The class is a LOT of work, however, if you are interested in the general topic you will find it enjoyable. Again, Prof. Verma is very approachable and is a great resource. The course is front loaded, so the first half of the semester is more work than the second half.
I highly recommended this course, but this course is very time consuming.

Start everything early!  You are going to spend a lot of time on the assignments for this course, but they are worth it and aid in the understanding of the material and preparation for the exams.  Also, make sure to start the final project early, as it may take more time than you think.
This is a demanding, yet rewarding course. You need to put time and energy into it, but you will learn the basic concepts that you need as an electronic engineer in digital systems world.
This is an amazing class. A must take for those interested in electrical engineering and electronic devices.
too much time is needed for this course, ant way it is useful
descrip: Analysis and design of digital integrated circuits using deep sub-micron CMOS technologies. Emphasis on design, including synthesis, simulation, layout and post-layout verification. Analysis of energy, power, performance, area of logic-gates, interconnect and signaling structures.

title: Things Come to Life
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: General Plasma Physics I
reviews: Asking for clarification of the homework's intended goal may be helpful.
Do it. But do it pass/fail so you aren't pre-occupied by your grade.
descrip: An introductory course to plasma physics, with sample applications in fusion, space and astrophysics, semiconductor etching, microwave generation, plasma propulsion, high power laser propagation in plasma; characterization of the plasma state, Debye shielding, plasma and cyclotron frequencies, collision rates and mean-free paths, atomic processes, adiabatic invariance, orbit theory, magnetic confinement of single-charged particles, two-fluid description, magnetohydrodynamic waves and instabilities, heat flow, diffusion, kinetic description, and Landau damping. The course may be taken by undergraduates with permission of the instructor.

title: Intermediate Portuguese
reviews:
Do it!

TAKE IT.
Take it! It's a lot of work at first but its worth it! Don't approach it as an "easy class". It demands a lot of time and effort but its enjoyable and rewarding.
prereqs: POR 108 or instructor's permission.
descrip: Students will further develop their language skills, especially those of comprehension and oral proficiency, through grammar review, readings, film and other activities. The two-semester sequence POR 108-109 is designed to give in only one year of study a command of the Portuguese language sufficient for travel in Brazil, Portugal and beyond.

title: Junior Seminars
reviews: A really excellent junior seminar!
Absolutely take Professor Milam's seminar! She is a wonderful professor and I look forward to hopefully taking another one of her courses before graduation.
Absolutely. Prof. Milam is a great advisor and does a great job helping you get through your first JP.
Allows an interesting new lens for the study of history, allowing you to pursue your historical interests in a nuanced manner.
Appreciate the unique opportunity of having the primary sources! Appreciate Professor Grote's unparalleled attention to his students!
As far as Junior Seminars go, this seemed like one of the best
Definitely take it - Professor Karl is very supportive and knowledgable.
Definitely take it! Jack is such a helpful advisor, getting to know him is worth it on its own.

Definitely take this junior seminar! Professor Karl is demanding, but provides awesome feedback, is always willing to meet with his advisees, and is a great advisor to introduce you to independent work and what it means to be a historian.
Definitely take this!
Even if you're not interested in the material, Jack is a fantastic instructor who will keep you engaged.
Get started on JP early.

Great introduction to the History of Science as an upperclassmen who is committed to this field. Will teach you the necessary methods and techniques for writing a JP that revolves around the HOS discipline.

Having Tannous was quite a pleasure.

I know "Risk" makes it sound all finance-y, but it's totally not (unless you want to make it that way). I was surprised with how much the topic resonated with me, and Dr. Horan is the best adviser I've had yet at Princeton.

I would advise other students to keep up with the readings each week and participate in class discussion as much as possible. I would also advise other students to take advantage of how available Prof. Miles is to meet with you individually and help guide you along the JP process.

Take Professor Miles' Cold War seminar! He is extremely approachable, willing to meet with students, and eager to provide written feedback on JP chapters and drafts. The JP was a lot less scary because of Professor Miles. Should you take this class with him, take note: make sure to schedule your document analysis for a time you know you'll have time to work on it (i.e. not midterms week!). Take this course if you are interested in the political/social/economic processes that shape and are shaped by modern revolutions, and/or in how the relationship between the USA and the rest of Latin America has developed. prereqs: Compulsory course for departmental majors in the fall of their junior year..
descrip: The Junior Seminar serves to introduce departmental majors to the tools, methods, and interpretations employed in historical research and writing. This course is compulsory for departmental majors and is taken in the fall of the junior year. Students may choose from a range of topics. Seminar topics will tend to be cross-national and comparative.

title: Topics in Differential Equations
prereqs: TBA.
descrip: This course covers current topics in Differential Geometry. (More details provided the course is offered/scheduled.)

title: The Role of Law in American Society
descrip: This course offers an opportunity to explore the social and cultural meanings of legal texts. The focus is on methodology: on how to locate cases, statutes, treatises, trial records, and legal lives in their historical contexts, and on the differing ways historians have used legal texts as historical artifacts. In the course of this course, students will be exposed to a number of differing and contending perspectives on American legal history. It should offer students an opportunity to think broadly about the role of law in the wider culture and to try their hand at doing legal history.

title: Race and Ethnicity
reviews: A nice 5th class if you are interested in the course material at all.

Although the lecture notes definitely help you understand what's going on, do the readings. They're get more interesting in the middle and towards the end of the course. Also, you will have to go to every lecture because PFK notices everyone who is and isn't there.  She's pretty amazing.

I would definitely NOT take this course with Professor Fernandez Kelly.  She is incredibly unprofessional and stays off topic for about 80% of the lecture.  She picks favorites and jokes all class long, talking about whatever she wants but NOT talking about the topic at hand.

I would suggest taking the course if you'd like to know more about what "race" means. Coming from the sciences, I know that a lot of people think that intro-level soc classes are pretty fluffy, but this class really offers a lot of insight into the world around you. This is a very informative course and answered many questions that I have had on race and ethnicity in the world today and how it came to be. PFK is a great lecturer (witty and funny). Try to outline each reading. It will help you do better on the midterm. Make sure that you clarify any points that may have you somewhat confused with your preceptor
Very interesting class - I actually looked forward to going to lecture. And PFK is such a fun and entertaining professor!
doo it
grading is super arbitrary
interesting material
descrip: Our goal in this course is (a) to understand various definitions of race and ethnicity from a theoretical perspective and in a plurality of contexts and (b) to account for the rise of ethnicity and race as political and cultural forces in the age of globalization. Why are ethnic and racial delimitations expanding in areas of the world where such distinctions were formerly muted? Is race and racial discrimination all the same regardless of geographical region? What are the main theories and methodologies now available for the study of race and ethnicity from a comparative point of view? These are among the questions our course aims to answer.

title: Random Processes in Information Systems
reviews: A course worth taken
A worth taking course if the student want to gain some fundamental knowledge about probability theory as well as random process.
It is a good introduction to random processes. I would not take it if you are looking for mathematical rigor.
The coverage of the course is wide on random process. Will be helpful for reading papers in related areas.
The knowledge in this course is useful. So I recommend this course.

This course is more theoretical oriented. The math requirement is calculus, linear algebra, differential equations, undergraduate level probability theory and a little bit of real analysis. After taking this course you may gain a broad understanding about the research fields related to random processes. Since the textbook is newly written, the material is relatively new besides the classic theories.
This course require some basic knowledge
prereqs: Students taking this course should have a prior course in applied probability at the undergraduate level..
descrip: The course presents the fundamentals of probability theory and random processes needed by students in communications and information systems, computer engineering, signal processing, machine learning, bioinformatics, econometrics and mathematical finance. Topics include: History and overview; probability; random variables; functions of random variables; generating functions and transform methods; inequalities, Chernoff's bounds and large deviation theory; convergence and the limit theorems; random processes; spectral representation; Poisson and birth-death processes; Markov chains; random walk, Brownian motion, diffusion and Ito processes.

title: Intermediate Bosnian/Croatian/Serbian I
reviews: Great class; I would strongly recommend taking it.
If you want to learn Serbian (/Bosnian/Croatian/Montenegrin) then you don't really have any other options. That being said, I enjoyed this class!
You get as much out of this course as you put in it! If you want to get much better, you probably could, but the Professor isn't going to push you (it really has to be intrinsic).
descrip: Intermediate-level class with emphasis on communication and comprehension skills. Advanced grammar topics, speaking, and reading texts of interest to students; films.

title: Readings in Latin Literature - After Vergil: Transformation and Tradition in Latin Epic
reviews: Bouncing around between so many different authors can be difficult, but they are all interesting. Would highly recommend this course.
Definitely take it.
Don't leave all of the translation work for the last day.
Feldherr is a great professor. Whenever you have the opportunity, take it. Also, Latin epic is fun!

First off, Feldherr is a great professor. If you are willing to put the time in, this class will really pay off. It's on the intensive side, but if you're going to take a Latin class anyway, take this one!!!

I had a great time with Aaron Kachuck teaching this course, but I'm pretty sure that the main reason why I liked it so much was his passion and excitement for the subject, which was very contagious. He's a great teacher - I looked forward to every class.

The readings were definitely interesting and gave me a perspective on the scope Latin epic poetry beyond the well-known Vergil and Ovid.
I would expect a larger amount of translation than advertised (200 to 300 lines a week).

If you would like-- at once -- improve your Latin reading ability and be exposed to the major epic poems after Virgil, LAT 204 is it. Also, Professor Feldherr assigns the most lines out of any 200 or 300 level Latin class, which means you will be more than prepared to take a 300-level course after this. (you will probably find the amount of translation easy)
This is an excellent course and I very much enjoyed it.  But understand the amount of work you are getting yourself into.
This is definitely a course worth taking for anyone with an interest in Latin

This is the hardest 200-level Latin course.  Great for getting back in to Latin after AP Vergil or even after a year off from Latin.

LOTS of reading.  Feldherr requires an almost unreasonable amount of lines per class.  Find a partner and devote 2-3 hours of focused Latin homework for each class.
Use this opportunity to really think about the meaning of the text instead of just translating it.
prereqs: LAT 108 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course introduces students to the epic poems written under the reigns of Nero and the Flavian emperors, while further developing their skills and experience in reading Latin. We will explore how and why these poets allude to the works of their predecessors, especially the Aeneid. The syllabus focuses on "typical" scenes and elements in epic poetry like visits to the underworld or descriptions of works of art. In each case we will compare how different authors, including Ovid, Lucan, Statius, and the epic poets of the Renaissance adapt these aspects of the epic tradition.

title: Microprocessors for Measurement and Control
reviews: A large time commitment, but worth it.
Always talk to John or Chris for help. Learn how arduinos work. Follow directions in labs exactly. No need to do any work before class.
Be careful with the details, missing one wire or soldering something backwards can set you back hours in debugging time
Big time commitment but definitely worth it
I highly recommend this course to any MAE that needs a design requirement.
I would definitely take the course, it's a lot of time outside of class but very worth it.

If you are ME you are going to take this or Mechanical design.  I can't say which is better.  Both involve programming.  If you are interested in electronics, you will probably enjoy this class.  It seems that in this class, you get out what you put in.  If you can devise a cool final project that you can get excited about, you will probably enjoy the class.
It deserves the good reputation it has. Don't do a project that involves frequent decoupling, it's not worth it.
It's a great class. Just be prepared to work long hours at the end to get your final project done.
Take it if you can!
Take this course if you want to understand what goes on in all those chips and terminals on your laptop's motherboard. Think hard about what project you want to do
This course is a lot of work, but also fun and rewarding. Don't bite off more than you can chew for the final project though.

This course was fantastic. Professor Littman is a great lecturer and is great at explaining all the key concepts of this course. I learned so much about computers and electronics, even though I had very limited exposure to them beforehand.
This is a really fun class and you will learn a lot. I am a lot more confident now working with electronics and that came from the experience I got in this class.
This is one of the most interesting classes in the MAE department. Definitely the best MAE class I've taken. You will learn more in this one semester than in any other MAE class. Definitely take it.

You'll learn a lot about electronics. If you've taken a course in digital logic (like ELE 206), you'll have a good head start at the beginning with regards to the workings of microprocessors, logic design, and timing in chips.

You're going to have to work very hard towards the end of the class to get your project working. To make it easier, work hard all the way through. Everything that Littman is lecturing on, he selected for a reason. I.e., make sure you understand everything he tells you about transistors, even if it doesn't seem relevant, because when it turns out that you need to wire up a transistor circuit in the middle of the night in the final round of debugging your project, having that knowledge will help.
great class. takes quite a bit of time, but you learn about electronics, which is something you don't talk about in other MAE courses.
if you have a chance to take this class then do.
prereqs: MAE 221 and MAE 224, or introductory knowledge of analog and digital electronics.
descrip: Introduction to microcomputers for measurement and control. This is a hardware course in the area of electro mechanical systems. Students design and build microcomputer controllers and apply them to the automation of various aspects of a model railroad.

title: Russian Short Prose - Chekhov
descrip: An analysis of Chekhov's major works, including short stories and plays. Some attention will be given to Chekhov scholarship, both Russian and Western; to Chekhov on film and in performance; and to Chekhov in connection with later Russian and Western writers.

title: Genius
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Art of Adventure, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Image Processing
reviews: Good class to take.
If you're interested in this topic, you should probably take this course.  If you're not, then you probably shouldn't.
Interesting topic, consider the professor before taking it.
Worth taking for students who are interested in image processing.
Yes it can be a bit dull and seem disorganized and confusing, but if there's a few gems to be discovered in this course.
prereqs: ELE 301 or equivalent.
descrip: Introduction to the basic theory and techniques of image processing. Topics include image perception, acquisition, display, enhancement, restoration, compression, transformation, tomography, medical imaging, video coding and content analysis. Applications to HDTV, machine vision, medical imaging, etc.

title: Narratives of Identity in the Other Europe
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Advanced French
reviews: 108 isn't going to be a mindblowing experience in your French learning track, but it does a good job of covering all the main grammar points, lets you speak a lot (being engaged in the class discussions is key!!) and gives you a lot of practice in writing as well.
Be prepared to put in a significant amount of work, especially if you want an A.  Expect your classmates to speak very well, but know that written grammar is probably more important for grading.
Be ready to speak French, and do the readings before class to make participation easier.
Do all the readings and revise the grammar thoroughly. Although you tend to spend more time on the readings in class, the majority of the exam is on the grammar so do not neglect it!
Do the exercises and reading if you want to get the most out of it.  And study.
Do the homework, study vocabulary regularly, and do not be afraid to ask questions. The homework will take longer than you think it will take.

Every Monday we reviewed grammar; we looked over all the tenses (pass? compos?, imparfait, conditionnel, sobjonctif, futur, futur anterieur) and learned some more material about articles. On Wednesdays and Fridays we discussed readings, which were about French history and culture. Homeworks usually consisted of grammar exercises (which weren't handed in) and readings. There were also three 'papers', although they were creative compositions, not argumentative essays.

If this sounds like a class you would enjoy, then take it. Personally, I didn't think it was too challenging, but I had more experience with French than some of my classmates.
Focus on grammar because the readings hardly matter on exams.
I would recommend it, but be prepared to work.
I would strongly recommend taking this course with Florent! So many laughs.
If taking a French class for the purpose of reviewing grammar and vocabulary, I think it's an ideal course.
If you're interested in learning French or if you need to fulfill your language requirement, this is a good course to take.
It is challenging but not impossible.  The readings can be fun, but the long ones can be scary.  The class was really interesting and helpful in writing in French with the compositions.
Make sure to read and take notes, as well as  prepare questions for the professor for parts of reading or written assignments that you do not understand.
OK course. How much you put into the course will determine how much you get out of it.
Participate a lot.
Practice answering the reading questions of the lectures in full sentences -- this approach makes the exams easier when having to describe the readings.
Practice hard and don't be afraid to ask questions.
Professor Masse was a wonderful professor and anyone interested in French should take a class with him!
Read the passages, and do the grammar exercises as much as possible to reinforce the knowledge gained.

TAKE WITH FLORENT

Though it is basically a repeat of all you did in high school.
Take it
Take it if you have to. It wasn't a terrible class or too hard.
Take it! And make sure you get a great instructor, not necessarily just the head of course, because that really is what makes a language course.
Take it, not too hard and not too easy.
Take many notes when reading the texts, and devote significant time to the study of exceptions in the grammar part.
Take this course if you want to split your time between grammar and french culture.
The class goes pretty slowly, I did not feel my French speaking abilities and oral understanding improve at all though it improved my reading.
The course is challenging, even to former French students.
This is a difficult course to jump into after 102 but not impossible. Take it if you want to continue studying french.
Try to get Prof. Masse as your teacher, he is awesome.

When reading the passages, first read it with a dictionary and then reread it afterwards so that you understand the overall concept. Always do the grammar exercises, otherwise studying for exams is nearly impossible.

i enjoyed the class, the small group discussion, the wam and relatively relaxed atmosphere. good learning, good teaching style. and encouraged speaking in a non-intimidating way which i think is the best in learning a new language. fellow students also really encouraged me to improve. great class, definitely should consider taking it
prereqs: Placement through the University's Placement Test, completion of FRE 105, or permission of the Language Coordinator..
descrip: FRE 108 is an intermediate advanced course, with a brand new syllabus. It will take you on a journey through various periods of French history and culture and offer an opportunity to reflect on important questions at the center of controversial debates: national identity, immigration, relationships with the Francophone world and former colonies, the role of the State in the shaping of the nation, etc. Through a wide variety of authentic material, you will develop your ability to communicate in French and gain understanding of French and francophone cultures and societies. FRE 108 also helps prepare for applying to our study abroad programs.

title: Exploring Human Genomes and the Future of Human Beings
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Advanced Vector Calculus
reviews:
1. Try thinking about some of the tougher problem set problems before you go ask for help.
2. Don't expect to know how to do every problem on the exams. It's possible that you might study and still fail. Of course, you should still study, but keep the studying/tests in perspective.
All-around a good course, if somewhat difficult.
Be sure to prepare well for exams as they are much more difficult than any other problems in the class.

Consider how strongly you feel about knowing the theory of calculus--no matter how tempting 203 may seem (does not require 215 as a prerequisite!), if you are serious about formal mathematics, bite the bullet and actually take the 215-217-218 track, as while the proofs in lecture are fully rigorous, assignments and exams never really fully expect us to be able to match that level of rigor (and furthermore, many of the proofs for very important theorems are omitted entirely!).

203 is, despite what its description might say, distinctly weighted towards computation--I would recommend it only if you are more interested in being given challenging problems (albeit, sometimes certain problems were challenging solely because of unclear phrasing) and are not especially interested in formal mathematics.

DO NOT FALL BEHIND - especially not before Christmas break. If you think like "oh, I will catch up over break", let me tell you, you won't. 

Really (!) try and do the reading before lecture is happening, otherwise it is pretty much impossible to understand the material while it is taught. 

Also, while reading, make some sort of list of all the important theorems/equations, etc. It will be golden for reviewing.

Also, most importantly: find people in the class to do problem sets with. Do so soon. Don't be afraid to ask questions , more people than you think are just as confused as you are, they are just not brave enough to ask in lecture.

All in all, I loved the class, honestly (although I am not doing too well in it). I loved that nothing was left unproved, and there were explanations for everything. Problem sets are rough, and for me, office hours were vital - but I loved the beauty of the problems they gave us.
DON'T. You may be ambitious, your adviser may not no better, and then you're stuck drowning over your head with just a high school level of preparation.
Definitely start homework early. It's a good idea to preview and start things before they are actually taught, especially in this course.
Don't take this as your first exposure to multi. Understand the basic stuff, and that gives you a shot to do well on the exams. It's probably impossible to study directly for exams though.

Go to Professor Taylor's office hours for help on the weekly problem sets. She goes through the questions that students have trouble on and solves them for you. Some of the algebra gets a little tricky at the end though.

Go to Taylor's office hours or else you will die.  They're the only things that kept me from dropping.  If you think you're good at math, or even very good at math, seriously consider just how good you are.  Everyone here was the top one or two students in their high school, and the kinds of kids taking 203 were easily the best math students at their school as well.  Remember that grading is relative.
Go to Taylor's office hours.
Go to class everyday, even if it's a hassle! Most of the lecturers are great, and are willing to spend time during office hours to help you.
Good course to take, many of the concepts are used in courses like physics.
Good for math-savvy people who do not want to go for MAT215.
I feel like I didn't learn any more in 203 than I would have in 201, but I was more stressed about it at every step along the way.

I strongly, strongly urge you to look through the textbook first. And not just the beginning section, which is easy, but deeper into the textbook. See if you understand the way they present information, not just what they are saying but how they are saying it. This would be a good indicator of how you will understand the course.
I would definately reccomend this course for prospective physics majors or applied math track students.
I would take it--don't expect it to be your favorite class, but you'll learn multivariable calculus and it is challenging without being overwhelmingly so.
If Taylor's still teaching, it's going to be pretty tough exams, dunno how to prepare.  Good luck.  But you'll learn lots too.

If you are interested in pursuing Multivariable Calculus to a very proficient, mathematically rigorous level, this is the class for you. It is very tough and requires mathematical skill, much more so than 201 requires. However, if you are just trying to get the Math requirement out of the way, 201 would be a better fit
If you really like Maths and is choosing between 201 and 203, take 203!
It is a fast-paced course, but I feel like I defnitely learned a lot. It's important to pace yourself by reviewing every week not to fall behind.
It's a challenging course. Prof Singer wasn't helpful. Just know what you're getting yourself into.
It's a pretty hard multivariable class, but it's definitely possible. Don't take it if you have a tough schedule.

Keep up with the problem sets and go to office hours.  Be prepared to go above and beyond what is taught in class during the exams.  If you do not feel comfortable with the difficulty level, do not be afraid to drop into regular multivariable calculus.  I probably should have done that.
Make sure to study the material as you learn it, as you will not be able to study it all in the time before midterms and finals.
Make sure you can deal with more abstract concepts and use of new notations, it's not just numbers
Make sure you have time set aside for such a time consuming course.
Make sure you put in a lot of time and effort into this class. Go for office hours!
Make time for the problem sets.
My advice is to compare answers on the problem sets and to start the problem sets early.  If you go to class, you'll do fine.
Only take if you're really really good at math. Otherwise, you're better off with 201.
Only take this class if you have background in multivariable calculus already.  Make sure to attend office hours.

Overall, this has been a very useful and interesting course. The problem sets are helpful in better understanding the material, and the professors do a good job of explaining the topics. The only shortcoming of the course were the exams; I did not feel that we were given all the tools and strategies to solve difficult problems in a short period of time.
Prepare to be challenged.
Read before lecture, do the problem sets early, and go to Christine Taylor's Sunday night office hours.
Reread every chapter as often as you can.

Take it if you need to / want to, but make sure you're constantly on top of your work and have a good understanding of what's going on. Read the textbook, always, and really understand it because everything is cumulative.
Take it.
Take this class if you are really interested in math. A lot of the kids who take it have already taken multi, so you might feel a little behind at first.
Take this class if you like tricky problems.

Take this instead of 201 if you enjoy theoretical mathematics (to some degree) and have already taken some multivariable calculus. Beware of the exams though - most of the problems are nothing like those in the problem sets.
Take this with Prof. Christine Taylor if you can. She's wonderful.

The class emphasizes and promotes understanding on proofs. It involves a lot of critical thinking, and differs from 201 because it focuses less on computations. As the professor pointed out once, you really have to understand the materials and find the easiest way to work out problems.
The course is good, but really demanding and time-consuming. Not for everyone.

The course title and description are a bit misleading. If you become good at the course material, you become good at juggling many different variables and constants but not really good a proofs. If you want to take a truly rigorous multi class, 218 would be the better option.

There is absolutely no reason to take this class. STAY AWAY. If you are a math major, you're going to take the 215/217/218 track. If you're an engineer, take 201. There is, again, absolutely no reason to struggle through 203 and waste so much of your time just to get a B in a meaningless class.
This class is good for introducing you to difficult and formal math but the lectures and office hours don't always explain things very well
This class is very difficult and the lectures aren't that great, but it's definitely useful.

This course is challenging and the proofs add difficulty to the course material.  You will learn a lot in this course, but don't expect this course to be like high school math.  Even if you took multivariable in high school, this class will still be very difficult.
This course takes up a lot of your time. It is interesting, but don't take it unless you have to!
This is a good way to learn vector calculus, and the weekly workload isn't too bad, although the tests and quizzes are sometimes a bit stressful.

This is a great course, and you will learn much more in it than you will in 201.  Don't listen to the people telling you to take either 201 or 215/217; 203 is worth taking, but be prepared to work hard if you haven't had extensive experience with multi before.  Actually, even if you have, be prepared to work hard.
This is a pretty interesting course. Take it if you're considering it.

This is a very difficult course because many of the students have already taken multivariable/vector calculus.  They will set the curve, so be careful.  I learned a lot, especially from the second half of the course.
This will be a challenging course, especially for one who has not taken multivariable calculus before. Application is not emphasized, so consider the reasons for your interest in math.
prereqs: MAT 104 or MAT 215, or equivalent..
descrip: Vector spaces, limits, derivatives of vector-valued functions, Taylor's formula, Lagrange multipliers, double and triple integrals, change of coordinates, surface and line integrals, generalizations of the fundamental theorem of calculus to higher dimensions. More abstract than 201 but more concrete than 218. Recommended for prospective physics majors and others with a strong interest in applied mathematics.

title: Language and the Brain
descrip: Examines how language is processed in real-time in the human brain. The focus will be on the mental representations that characterize human language, and the cognitive operations that are necessary to construct them during comprehension and production. Students will be introduced to behavioral (reaction time), electrophysiological (EEG, MEG), and neuroimaging (fMRI, PET) results that identify the representations and processes of language processing, and the cortical architectures that support them.

title: PhD Gateway in Security Studies
descrip: The field fo Security Studies is distinguished by its focus on a clearly delineated set of intellectual and practical problems. This course will serve as the required gateway for all students entering the Woodrow Wilson School's new PhD cluster in Security Studies. Students will take this course during the fall semester of their first year.

title: Integrative Advanced Japanese I
reviews: I think the success of this class really depends on who's teaching it. Tokumasu Sensei is great. The course is a lot of work but your language skills will improve.
It takes a bit of time.
This course is so much better than the 3rd year. Do take it if you have any interest whatsoever in continuing to study Japanese.
To do well in this class, just stay on top of the work and participate.  It will help your Japanese.

nihongo ga jouzu ni naritainara,
totte kudasai.
descrip: Four skills approach to advanced Japanese with a focus on reading, listening and speaking. Reading materials include novels, essays, etc. Video materials are also used to enhance listening skills. The goal of this course is "advanced" level according to the ACTFL/ETS guidelines.

title: Seminar in Modern Spanish-American Literature - Avant Garde, Media and Modernity
reviews: A must if they want to learn more about one of the most interesting periods of history of literature and arts.
Enjoy the excellent syllabus and try to get the most out of the guest visitors. Also don?t hesitate to ask for Gallo?s comments and advice.
Excellent introductory course on the avant-garde and its afterlives. Strongly Recommended!

It is a great course. It deals at the same time with a large literary repertoire and an updated theoretical approach. It is also a course that only Professor Gallo could give, considering his finalized and ongoing researches.
While in the seminar, try to think in a topic for the oral presentation soon in the semester, in order to take advantage of the readings doing them in the particular perspective of your interest.
descrip: This course will explore various Latin American Avant-Garde movements in a comparative context: Mexican Estridentismo, Brazilian modernismo, Chilean creacionismo. We will examine these movements in the context of other international avant gardes, from Italian Futurism to Russian constructivism; discussions will be framed by various theories of the avant-garde, from Burger to Perloff.

title: Muscle/Memory: Dance
descrip: Students in DAN 300 will create dance works for unconventional spaces that will emphasize performance, theatricality, and props. Students in the associated VIS 300 will create sculptures that inform bodily movement in the form of garments, portable objects and props. The two classes will come together periodically to compare notes and pursue the question of how nearly identical movements and objects can be considered dance in some contexts and art in others. A lecture series of prominent choreographers and artists will accompany the courses. This studio course is open enrollment.

title: Religion and Culture Workshop
descrip: A weekly, year-long workshop devoted to the critical discussion of research in progress in the ethnographic, historical, and normative study of religion and culture. Designed for dissertation writers receiving fellowships from the Center for the Study of Religion and post-doctoral fellows.

title: Water: Keystone for Sustainable Development
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: When Adolescence Goes Wrong .... what they didn't tell you
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Advanced Topics in Genetic Analysis
prereqs: MOL342 is an absolute requirement..
descrip: The application of current tools of human genetics and genomic analysis including SNPs, copy number variants, HapMaps, high throughput DNA sequencing and DNA microarrays to perform genome-wide association studies of complex traits with an emphasis on neurological diseases including autism and schizophrenia. Recent evolution within the human species and genetic divergence of human populations in response to selective forces. Extensive use will be made of online genome databases as interactive tools for genome analysis.

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - Information Privacy Technologies
reviews: Don't be afraid as an undergraduate because it's a grad course.

I would definitely recommend this to any students who are interested in learning more about information privacy, from a variety of angles (technical, socio-economic, legal, etc...). The professor worked hard to ensure that the material was appropriate to students from both policy and technical fields.

If you are interested in learning about the technological aspect of privacy technologies this is probably not the course for you. If you are more interested in the policy/law/economics aspect of privacy technologies this is the course for you. This course is rather reading-intensive, such that it is hard to make extra time (with a full courseload) to work on the final project before winter break.
If you like having a diverse set of readings on a subject and think about a problem from various angles (interdisciplinary) you should take this class.

Prof. Narayanan is great at explaining things, especially when they are in fields unfamiliar to students. There are only a few technical topics in this course. I would recommend this to both CS students as well as students interested in policy.
Strongly consider taking this course, but make sure you have a solid understanding of computer science in order to make the most of it.

The topics for the material are really interesting but you might leave the class being paranoid about your digital privacy. This was the first year that the class was offered, hopefully in future years the discussion will be more student-led.
The topics were interesting, but after the first class I had high expectations for the course, which were not met.
This is a good course to take if you like reading about privacy in practice and in policy.

You'll definitely learn a lot about a huge variety of topics! Even though a lot of reading is involved, this course helps you become a well-rounded COS student because it focuses on the impact of technology in a non-cliche way.
descrip: Analyzes privacy technologies - both their power and limitations - and effectiveness of interdisciplinary approaches. Covers technical topics such as cryptography and anonymity (including Tor and Bitcoin) and thinks critically about their place in society. Reviews what law, economics, and policy have to say about privacy technologies. Students will choose a technical (programming-based) or policy (essay-based) project according to their background.

title: Prose Translation
reviews: Definitely take it, for the certificate or as a French course. The workload is quite light and you will learn a lot about French and English; actually it's worth taking for Prof. Bellos' digressions alone. He is so knowledgeable about so many things!
Definitely. I'd recommend it wholeheartedly.
Even if you aren't interested in translation, this course will really improve your writing skills and help you think differently about the nature of language.
If you don't care about your grade, you will learn a lot.
Take it! Spend a lot of time on the assignments.
Take it.

This class is great for learning to translate a wide variety of different types of texts- from recipes to excerpts from novels to newspaper articles. One note of advice- not too much feedback or written comments are provided on the translation handed back- meet with Prof. Bellos in order to learn where your weaknesses are!
This course improves your ability to translate if you put the time in and get to know the professor.
prereqs: FRE 307 or equivalent level of proficiency in French..
descrip: A practical investigation of the issues affecting translation between English and French. Weekly exercises will offer experience of literary, technical, journalistic and other registers of language. Discussion will focus on the linguistic, cultural and intellectual lessons of translation seen as a practical discipline in its own right.

title: Projects in Jazz Performance - Projects in Jazz Performance
reviews: I would recommend the class, provided the student is willing to practice fastidiously to keep up with the class.
The course is good?it totally depends on who is teaching it, I guess.
This course is a lot of fun and gives you experience playing in a jazz combo and writing parts. Jim Ridl was very friendly and shared his experience as a professional musician.
prereqs: Enrollment by application and audition..
descrip: A performance course that focuses on the development of style, concept, and repertoire in the jazz idiom. Students are coached by faculty in extended projects in performance.

title: Scientists Against Time
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Special Topics in Performance Practice - Casting: History, Theory, Practices
reviews: I would recommend that any student taking this course be comfortable and confident to voice their opinions in class and be open to classroom discussion. Also, feel free to bring in any information/experience with theater, film, or television. Every contribution helps further the conversation.

Prof. Herrera is a very engaging seminar leader who is clearly extremely well-versed in performance studies. Though the seminar seemed at times to be mostly a lecture, we tackled some pretty interesting topics that I hadn't analyzed in such depth before. Note that this course covers the criticism/history requirement for the THR certificate. I'd recommend it if you're a THR certificate student (every student in this seminar was).

The course did exactly what it set out to do? it explored casting as a history and practice and had lots of fun along the way. My main reservation with the course is that its subject sometimes felt narrow and trivial, but Professor Herrera's expertise and sparkling personality more than make up for that.
descrip: Casting - the process whereby actors are assigned to particular roles - has largely eluded scholarly investigation. This course is meant to enact just such an inquiry through a survey of the history, theory and practice of casting within U.S. entertainment industries over the last one hundred years. Course participants will trace the emergence of "casting" and "the audition" as discrete modes of performance making practice through review of dramatic literature, actor memoirs, how-to-guides, documentary films, and relevant scholarly literature.

title: Topics in Analysis - Equations arising from Physics
prereqs: Undergraduates require permission of the instructor..
descrip: This course will consist of several mini-courses, each lasting three weeks or so, covering diverse topics in analysis. The topics include quantum mechanics of graphene, evolution of oil and water in sand, interpolation of functions, and the Boltzmann equation.

title: Money, Work, and Social Life
reviews: Actually do ALL the readings carefully and be active but not obnoxious in precept. It's a great course

Be engaged in lecture, read the readings, and feel free to bring up any sort of sociological aspect within the economy that you see that may not be addressed within the course because Professor Zelizer is interested, and that is very cool to me.
Definitely participate and ask questions when you have them. Professor Zelizer and the preceptors are amazing fountains of knowledge and much more approachable than you think.
Definitely take this. It's one of the first classes I've taken that I haven't been required to take and I really enjoyed it. Very interesting stuff and Professor Zelizer is amazing.
Every Princeton class should be this good. Take this or you will regret it.
Good for non-sociology majors.
Good if you are interested in this topic. Not too hard.
I would definitely recommend this course to anyone!

I would definitely take this class. It has been one of my favorites I've taken at Princeton, giving a nice social spin on typical economic theories and models. Definitely a nice break from the typical problem set class.

I would highly recommend this course. While some analyses seemed slightly stretched, the majority of the topics were quite interesting and will make you think differently about all economic transactions.
Interesting sociology course that connects economics and sociology. Not much work, and great to PDF.
Keep up with the readings!
TAKE IT IT'S AMAZING
TAKE IT! This was one of the best courses I have taken at Princeton.
TAKE IT, it's very very very interesting and you don't need ANY econ background.
TAKE THIS COURSE!!!!! I wish I could take it again!

Take it. This helps you understand why traditional economic theories are simply not applicable to our systems. If you're an economics major, I don't think you can call yourself fully informed about your field until you've taken Professor Zelizer's class. If you're a sociology major, it helps you understand economic concepts that you probably slept through in ECO 100 or decided not to take.
Take it. Very good class.
Take this class!  It's amazing.
Take this course!
The topics the professor approaches are interesting, but she doesn't add anything other than what is present in the readings.

This course has a very reasonable workload with consistently digestible and interesting readings.  Though there is a final exam in addition to a Dean's Date assignment, there is constant support for the paper throughout the semester, and the exams are incredibly fair if you are keeping up with reading and attending most lectures/precepts.  Professor Zelizer is really one of the better instructors on campus, and also happens to be the leader in the field on this topic.  This course is not worth passing up, should you have the opportunity to take it at some point.
VERY interesting course. Coming from a more technical background, the chance to look at economics from a SOC perspective was really eye-opening. Don't underestimate the workload.
Very interesting class. Lectures fly by quickly as they are very interesting and the work for the class is not bad at all.
Yes, it opens your eyes to a new way of thinking.
have a study group.
interesting class
take it whenever it is offered! all majors.
descrip: The course offers a sociological account of production, consumption, distribution, and transfer of assets. Examining different sectors of the economy from corporations and finance to households, immigrants, welfare, and illegal markets, we explore how in all areas of economic life people are creating, maintaining, symbolizing, and transforming meaningful social relations. Economic life, from this perspective, is as social as religion, family, or education.

title: Metaphysics - A Systematic Overview of Ontology
descrip: The seminar will be part of a two-semester systematic overview of the central questions in metaphysics. Visitors will frequently be presenting their research work.

title: Advanced Persian Reading I
prereqs: Two years of Persian or permission of instructor.
descrip: This course is designed to improve the student's proficiency in the reading and comprehension of Persian texts. The emphasis is on reading and understanding and translating modern and classical prose. In the Advanced Persian course students are also expected to write essays in Persian during the course of the semester. Advanced Persian Reading class will be conducted in Persian.

title: Social Lives, Social Forces
reviews: Be prepared to read quite a bit!

Do all the readings before the night before or morning of so you can really do it thoroughly.  I think I could have gotten more out of them than I did because I rushed the reading assignments.  And there are only two readings for your one class period a week, so really give them your all.  And pay attention in class, even though sometimes its very easy to space out.
Do it!! You will definitely not regret taking this course.  Not too difficult, and you learn a ton!

Do take this course if you have a high tolerance for abstraction and theory.Don't take this course if you are expecting to learn concrete facts about Social Lives, Social Forces. Regardless of your opinion in these areas, Professor Greenhouse is a wonderful professor.
Do the reading, or you'll be lost during discussions.

Doing well in this course really isn't about how much effort you put into the readings or even on your assignments. It is about knowing how to write and speak in the style and manner that the professor does. It is very hard to predict how well you will do because it is very much contingent on how well the professor receives your ideas and explanations. However, Greenhouse is great to listen to and this course covers some important works and areas of thought for social science.

Good intro class to anthro while surveying some of the major works. Class discussions weren't as focused (possibly due to a larger than normal seminar size), but still the discussions were pretty solid overall. Prof. Greenhouse is awesome.

I'm not sure that my experience in this course will be representative of the course in the future. My seminar was way too large. But the material was interesting, and if the seminar is smaller I think it has the potential to be awesome.

If you are willing to do an often formidable amount of reading each week and read the text closely, this course is for you. But the discussions were very rewarding and I encourage you to be actively engaged as a listener and contributor.

If you like anthropology, you should definitely take this course, because Carol Greenhouse is an awesome professor and has a lot to share.  However, if you fancy yourself to be more suited to the natural sciences (like I am), then you should probably find a different anthropology course, assuming that you are interested in anthropology.  The nature of a seminar places a premium on participation, and if you are not confident in your observations from the readings and have not been immersed in an environment with more dedicated social sciences/humanities students, then you are likely to not participate much.  The readings seemed very sporadic at first; it was not until later in the course that earlier discussions began to make more sense and the course developed a more sensible focus.  

I think that the course would have been better had there only been 15 students or so, but 25-30 students in a seminar is not conducive to productive group discussion.  If you have reason to believe that the class size will be smaller, then the group discussions should be more focused and will allow you to understand the readings better.  

Overall, still a good course.
It is an okay class.
The discussions are often abstract and the three hours drags on forever, but the readings are interesting and Greenhouse is really nice.

The most important thing is to remember that the course is cumulative; to get the most out of it continue to search not only for meaning in each assignment but in the connections between the readings.

This course gave me an interesting insight into anthropology as a non-major. It almost functioned like a larger freshman seminar, focusing on topics that Professor Greenhouse was interested in, although I found them fascinating. If you like class discussions, I would recommend the course.
This course is more for students prepared to be personally invested in anthropology and discussing topics in social forces.  Personally, I had trouble finding aspects that interested me.

This course will force you to dive in completely to anthropological thinking, which, as an anthro major, I enjoyed, but I know some of my classmates found it tedious. It can be very difficult to follow along in class if you don't do the readings. If you do do the readings, though, you'll be doing yourself a favor because they can teach you so much about yourself and others.

This is a good course if you want a general understanding of what anthropology is about. Right now I basically understand the concepts, but none of my knowledge is specific.  Instead of going in depth on a topic or two, this survey course kind of skates the surface of anthro.

This was one of the best courses I have ever taken at Princeton. Prof. Greenhouse really impacted my Princeton experience in such an amazing way. I learned so much and I really feel like this course changed me for the better.
it is better to complete the written assignments earlier in the term.
descrip: This seminar takes up the connection between authority and obligation as a comparative cultural question. We draw on diverse sources (anthropological accounts, case studies, social theory, literature, public documents, art) to probe the conceptual and real-life gray zones between individual and community, liberty and constraint, love and law. We consider a variety of formal and informal institutions (e.g., states, workplaces, families) and a spectrum of formal and informal norms (from court opinions to common sense). Throughout, authority and obligation emerge as complex social relations that shape and are shaped by their cultural context.

title: Documentary Filmmaking
reviews:
MAKE SURE YOU ALREADY KNOW HOW TO MAKE FILMS. YOU WILL NOT GAIN ANY TECHNICAL SKILLS FROM THIS CLASS.
Also, make sure to make a BRILLIANT first impression because Emily grades ONLY on a subjective basis.
Take this course if you are interested in documentary filmmaking!

The guest speakers are one of the main saving graces of this course. I would only recommend this course if you have some previous film experience or you are a film certificate student. Even though in theory you don't need any film/editing experience, you do in this course because very little technical skills are taught.

This class is very good if you're willing to put in the time. It will help you network, understand the industry inner workings, and really get into the heart of making a documentary. But it takes a lot of time, commitment, and flexibility when working within teams.
This class was really bad. You don't learn how to make a film. You listen to a professor obsessed with her own career.
prereqs: none.
descrip: This course will give students an introduction to documentary film and video production, with a special emphasis on the practical challenges of producing films in the real world. Students will learn fundamental filmmaking techniques from a professor with thirteen years experience running her own film production company, as well as a handful of guest professionals in the fields of cinematography, casting, and editing. Production and critique of student work will be augmented by film screenings, readings, and discussion of the effects that practical realities can have on the creative process.

title: Fundamental Concepts in Ecology, Evolution, and Behavior II
reviews: Do not read so early as to forget what each paper was about by the time of the class. Allot sufficient time to read all of the papers, especially with longer sessions (Profs. Rubenstein, Horn, and Levin). Definitely focus on figures in papers.
Great course!

I would definitely advise other students to take this course because it gives students the opportunity to understand how the research of EEB professors have progressed throughout the years. This course helps students learn what research questions excite the EEB faculty and allows students to discuss papers with most of the professors throughout the semester. It also helps the professors better get to know the graduate students in the department. I would strongly recommend this course to other students.
They are the best!
descrip: An advanced foundation in ecology, focusing on the 50 fundamental papers, is given. Topics include dynamics and structure of populations, communities and ecosystems, and conservation biology. (This is a core course.)

title: Intermediate Latin: Catullus and His Age
reviews: Ask questions if you have any. Write vocabulary lists as you go along. And if you're going to memorize all the readings for the final, start more than a week in advance, and go over them over and over again.
Be prepared to put a lot of effort into this course, especially if you do not have a strong background in latin.

It is exactly what it says on the course description. There is quite a lot of text to prepare and translate throughout the semester. These preparations probably take around 7-8 hours a week. The tests are pretty straightforward but time-pressured. Learn the set texts well and you will do well in the course.
It's not a very hard class and you'll get better at Latin.
Make sure to do the translations before going to class, you'll get a lot more out of the participation
Take this course if you plan on completing LAT 108 in the Spring. Latin is taught very well at Princeton, and you will enjoy the material.

This course is really difficult if you don't have a natural gift for language acquisition.  If you're already good at Latin, great: you'll love this course.  If not, staying on top of the readings and making sure you're on track in understanding grammar/vocabulary takes a huge amount of personal discipline and organizational ability. That being said, the language is beautiful, and it can be a little bit uplifting, as you cry yourself to sleep at night, to remember that you're reading the real, unaltered words of Caesar and Catullus.  A little bit.
This course was great because we did not spend the entire semester on just one another.
prereqs: LAT 102 or departmental permission based on Latin Placement..
descrip: This course aims at increasing facility in reading Latin prose and poetry and introduces students to the literacy culture of Republican Rome. We shall read selections from two important authors of the late Roman Republic, Caesar and Catullus.

title: Entrepreneurial Leadership
reviews: A must take course even if you are not interested in being an entrepreneur. The class offers some great ways to think about what it means to be a leader in a group among other things. The time commitment is quite a bit though, so beware of that. However, the material is very approachable and requires no expertise in any area.

Good class with a lot of case studies and other things but It is a lot more work than anticipated as you are expected to meet regularly with teams. Prof. Lidow is a solid guy and understanding, which makes the course enjoyable. I definitely took out some ideas to help me outside of the class setting.
Great course.
I would definitely recommend this course. You gain a lot of experience, both from experience through the team assignments and from academic work.
I would definitely take it again if I could go back and do it all over again.
If you are anxious about future, come to the class. It is not only about entrepreneurship, and you can use what you learn from the class to anything in your life. The key is to understand yourself.
If you're interested in entrepreneurship take this class, but bear in mind that there are other classes which may better prepare students for assuming an entrepreneurial role.
My roommate dropped the course early because it looked too "soft" to him. He was right on that count. As it happens, I was looking for a softer course. If that's what you want, this fits the bill.
Take it -- but it's a lot of work.
Take it!
Take it! Be advised that there is a group assignment every week, so scheduling can be a hassle, but I enjoyed the class and felt it was manageable and often inspiring.
Take this class if you want to really think analytically about being a leader!  Requires you to spend a significant amount of time outside of class meeting with other students.
it starts off a little "soft" but the more you put into it, the more you get out of it
it's an easy class. but the team meetings were a bit annoying
prepare to do a lot of work
prereqs: Interest/passion in discovering how an idea can become a real company.This course is not open to students who took EGR 495 Special Topics in Entrepreneurship: Entrepreneurial Leadership..
descrip: The mission of the class is to enable students to successfully create and lead enterprises by teaching the basic skills required to be a successful entrepreneurial leader. This class compliments EGR 491 "High Tech Entrepreneurship" which focuses on 'giving birth to a company', by focusing instead on enterprise 'early child rearing'. The basic skills taught fall into three major categories: how to create and manage powerful relationships, how to know and manage yourself, in addition to understanding how organizations work as they evolve from the idea stage to become value producing, self-sustaining enterprises.

title: Introduction to Language and Linguistics
reviews: A good class if you're interested in Linguistics! Try to get Professor Fellbaum. If your professor isn't as engaged and helpful I doubt you will have as good an experience as I did in the course.

Attend lecture. Read the book when you can, it clarifies a lot and explains all the details that the professor cannot within the hour she has with us. If you like language and how it works, this course is for you.
Definitely go for it! The workload of this course is really light compared to other classes, but the content is very interesting.
