Definitely recommend this course if at all interested in linguistics, it's a great overview and the right difficulty for a course like this.

Despite what other students may tell you, DO ALL THE READINGS and ATTEND ALL LECTURES AND PRECEPTS. Although the material is presented very clearly in the textbook, the lectures delve much deeper into the topics and sharpen your linguistic analysis skills.
Do not take this course if you have any respect for either science or philosophy, since this subject, by straddling both of them, disrespects and disregards both.
Do the readings and attend lecture, and you'll do very well.
Don't. Very poorly run.
Enjoy the course and try to learn as much as possible.
Fairly easy conceptually, curve is annoying.
Go to the lectures! Do your assignments with much care because they will help you on your midterms and finals.
Good EC, little work and time involved. Don't need to go lecture, as it's pretty much just a repeat of the book. Professor Fellbaum is very nice and easily approachable.
Great class to take for an EC.
I think that this is a good course to take if you have curiosities about language overall.

I took the course from Fellbaum and really enjoyed it-- it's very interesting material, especially if you know another language, and not very much work. On the other hand, if you really want to be challenged, this may not be the course for you.
I would highly recommend this course, as it is not too easy and not too difficult.

I would recommend the class to people who know they have an interest in linguistics. For people who are unsure, it may be worth a shot. Some people may find it too easy, and others may find it too boring. Fellbaum is a good professor, but in some ways she seems too good for the course.

If Fellbaum is teaching this course, take it!  The material is very interesting.  It is NOT a grammar class.  It is a class that studies how language is formed, and I learned interesting features of so many different languages.  I also learned why people have accents and why it's so hard to get rid of them.  These things are really interesting!!!
If you are actually interested in linguistics, I guess go for it. Be prepared to go out of your mind with the problem sets. If you need an EC, there are others.
If you just need an EC, don't take this. Otherwise if you are interested in linguistics definitely do.
If you take this course, you will not learn anything. Just keep that in mind.
If you think you enjoy linguistics and you want to find out which areas in particular interest you, take this class. Otherwise, it's probably not worth it.
If you want a very easy distribution req (EC), take it.  If you want a challenge, I would stay away.
Interesting and engaging class!
Interesting and relatively easy EC, just be aware that one has to attend all of the precepts and many Monday lectures.
It is a great introduction to the fundamentals of linguistics.
It's really boring.
Not too difficult distribution requirement.
Pretty easy EC.  Grading is fair and simple.  Homework assignments are fun if you like logic
Really enjoyed it and not too much work. But a lot of the class was great because of Fellbaum. Take it only if you have a good professor. It'll make lectures great.
Redoing homework is the best way to study for the tests--the tests are just like long homeworks.
Study a lot for the midterm! Also, at least for my year, the final was an easy take home with no time limit, so don't PDF it unless you are really struggling.

TAKE IT. Professor Fellbaum is fantastic, the material is really interesting, and the precept for this class is so far (and will probably always be) my favorite one at Princeton (my preceptor was Anton).
Take a different linguistics course if you're interested in the subject.  If you're looking for an easy EC, take it and pdf.
Take a higher level linguistics course instead if you can.
Take it if Fellbaum is teaching.
Take it with Fellbaum. Go to the lectures, they're interesting. The problem sets aren't bad and the precepts are pretty interesting discussions usually.
Take it!
Take it! It's mostly interesting material, good to fulfill distribution requirement. You get out what you put in to the course.

Take it, especially if Professor Fellbaum is teaching it. I also especially recommend this course if you have an analytical mind and/or are interested in Computer Science. Analytical thinking helps you problem-solve on the problem sets and exams - they're basically just fun puzzles to solve. And computational linguistics is a fascinating field with many practical applications, and there's a good chance you'll find yourself leaning on your linguistic background someday for some program you work on. :)

Take the class with Fellbaum. She's a great presenter and a wonderful person. The problem sets are very doable, but the midterm was very tricky for most people. Overall, i learned A LOT and would definitely recommend it.
Take the course because it is fascinating.

Take this course! I loved it. I do know some people we sort of dreaded it, but know that you can find some really interesting things in the foreign languages provided and even about English. Take it particularly if you would like to understand how language works and like problem solving.

Take this course, especially if Professor Fellbaum is teaching it, and especially if Anton Koychev is precepting!
The topics are interesting, the slideshows and lectures informative, the precepts are good, and the problem-sets fun. It's not a very intense course, either. Overall, it's just a very good course!
Take this course, it is a good and interesting class.

Take this if Fellbaum teaches it! She's super nice, passionate, and a good lecturer. EXTREMELY light workload (maybe like 2 hours a week tops), reading isn't really necessary either. Great way to knock out the EC. Topics range from very boring to extremely interesting.
The disorganization of this class makes it difficult. The material itself isn't particularly hard.
The subject matter is pretty interesting but it does get really technical at some points.
This course is fairly painless. Take it if you need an easy filler / need to fill requirements.
This course is very interesting, and should be taken by anyone who has even the slightest interest in linguistics. It is excellent as an EC distribution requirement.
This is a good course; the workload is light and the material is interesting.
This is a great elective to take.  It's not too much work, and it's really interesting. If you can, get Anton as a preceptor, and just have fun!
This is a great survey of linguistics. Professor Fellbaum is an awesome professor, and it's a great course to balance out some of the heavy ones in your load.
This was an interesting class. Not too overwhelming. Grading etc. could be frustrating due to a lack of organization.
Try finding a better text!

Very interesting, especially if you like learning languages.

Great class for grammar nerds.
You're on your own in this class.
not super-interesting and the pseudo-scientific attitude of linguistics irritated me after a while, but it's a pretty easy class & distribution...
descrip: An introduction to the scientific analysis of the structure and uses of language. Core areas covered include phonetics and phonology, morphology, the lexicon, syntax, semantics and pragmatics, with data from a wide range of languages. Topics include the biological basis of language, language and cognition, the neurology of language and language disorders, and first and second language acquisition.

title: Senior Seminar in Translation and Intercultural Communication
reviews: Do the readings! They will help you decide what you want to write about.
Great diversity in topics, and the professor was very willing to tailor the syllabus towards students' interests.  It's rare that you get a class that can do that!
I would take this class even if I weren't pursuing the certificate. It's not too much work and you'll learn a ton.
If you have an interest in translation in context, it is a very enjoyable class to take, but TRA200 is already a decent class to get a good taste of this. Only take if you have further interests.

This is a requirement for the certificate, so take it only if you're really interested in translation. It's a class that's as good as you make it - engage with the material, participate a lot, ask follow-up questions and it will be much more worthwhile. The workload is reasonable.
prereqs: Prerequisite TRA 200..
descrip: A required course for students taking the certificate in Translation and Intercultural Communication but open to all who are interested in translation or any of its aspects, that is in movements between languages of any sort. Readings will focus on recent contributions to the emerging disciplines of translation studies across a wide spectrum of thematic fields (science, law, anthropology, literature, etc.). The seminar will incorporate the individual experiences of the students in their contact with different disciplines and idioms and, where relevant, in developing their senior theses. One three-hour seminar.

title: Commutative Algebra
reviews: Definitely take this with Kevin if you get the chance; even if you don't like algebraic geometry I think you'll begin to see why it's so useful for motivating commutative algebra. Also, commutative algebra in general is a beautiful subject; if you want to go into anything algebra-related definitely take this!
I would recommend this class very highly, with the caveat that the advisee be serious about putting in the requisite time to gain a deep understanding of the material

If you want to do number theory or algebraic geometry, this is stuff you need to know.  Problem sets are time consuming, but there aren't that many problems that you have no idea how to approach.  Kevin really cares about teaching, and combines the traditional Atiyah-Macdonald approach with Reid's more geometric viewpoint.
It's a hard course, but the material is interesting and important.
Recommend. You need it for algebraic number theory, algebraic geometry, algebraic topology, certain kinds of combinatorics and computer science (Grobner bases, for example), ...
Take the class if you want to learn commutative algebra. Also, with Prof. Tucker you will get a feeling of what algebraic geometry is about, so it might be a great orientative class.
Yes. Do it. Going through all of Atiyah-MacDonald in one semester is a hard experience but worth it.
descrip: This course will cover the standard material in a first course on commutative algebra. Topics include: ideals in and modules over commutative rings, localization, primary decomposition, integral dependence, Noetherian rings and chain conditions, discrete valuation rings and Dedekind domains, completion; and dimension theory.

title: International News - Foreign Correspondence Across Media
reviews: From day one, you need to be prepared to challenge yourself. It isn't easy, at first, to get into the mindset of a journalist. But with time and exposure to others' work, your writing will improve as will your ability to think critically. It's a fun course, just be ready to work.
JRN courses are wonderful. Take them.

Take this course if you're interested in journalism especially international news and correspondence. I took this same course two semesters in a row and although it might look strange on my transcript, the professors are different every semester so the course is entirely new every semester as well.
prereqs: Enrollment by application: http://humanities.princeton.edu..
descrip: Contemporary issues in reporting, including whether to break the law in search of truth and how to cover highly contested regions like the Middle East. We will discuss ethical and practical dilemmas: Do the media over-simplify and over-sanitize foreign news? Are foreign correspondents too dependent on their fixers? Can journalists have more impact on TV, radio, online or in newspapers? Students will learn to identify, write and deliver stories for different media.

title: Forgiveness
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS)
reviews: Definitely take this course if you have any interest in the applications of academics in the real world. Using your hands and collaborating with students of all different disciplines really allows for an amazing experience and learning environment.
EPiCS is a great, low time-commitment class that lets you learn about exciting and awesome engineering while providing community service.
Only take this class if you are passionate about the subject matter. You must be self directed and motivated.

do not take this course if you have it with catherine peters. she is unorganized, biased, and with her the entire class will be a bureaucratic mess to vie for her approval the most. anything that has to be done must pass through several layers of approval first, and there is no room for student ingenuity in the class that i would expect to have the most freedom. tasks assigned are menial and meant solely to appease teachers and prove that you are doing "sufficient" work, not to further the project. 
However I have taken the class with other EPICS projects and they are not bad at all. Truthfully this project is the most interesting to me, but the professors and TA Dena Feldman pretty much ruined it for me.
prereqs: EGR 250.
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of freshmen through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: Discovering Don Quixote de la Mancha: Then and Now
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Religion, Gender, and Sexuality in Early Latin America
descrip: This seminar explores scholarship on the history of religion, gender, and sexuality in Latin America, focusing primarily on the mainland colonial period (1492-1821), but including some pre-colonial and the nineteenth century material. Through historical studies, primary documents, and discussion, students will consider connections between religious beliefs, spiritual and sexual practices, gendered social relations, and the ways race, class, and gender intersected with ideas about moral and social order in the period under study. We will also think critically about how scholars have portrayed these subjects.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Game Theory & Strategy (Sess 1)
descrip: This course will present some basics about game theory (and perhaps debunk a few myths fostered by the movie "A Beautiful Mind"). While the course will be designed around the structure of game theoretic models, building from the simple ones to the more sophisticated, at each stage the emphasis will be on applications. These include models of oligopoly, bargaining, military conflict, legislative voting, and the design of the rules under which to negotiate, vote, or hold an auction.

title: Latin American Studies Seminar - Architecture as a Mechanism of Social Inclusion
reviews: Mazzanti seemed to want to recruit students of different disciplines to engage in a dialogue about uses for public space.  I would recommend that students from outside the field of architecture consider a course like this if they are interested in the issues it addresses.
Take it if you're interested in architecture and in general urban/social issues in Latin America.
Take it take it take it.
prereqs: Recommended that student has previous understanding of urban realities. The course will be taught in Spanish, therefore it is mandatory to understand and speak the language. The readings must be done in Spanish. Discussion can be conducted in Spanish, English or both..
descrip: Architecture as a mechanism of social inclusion investigates the processes that are transforming urban structures, in particular the public and common spaces. Latin America has become an urban laboratory of unique living experiences, becoming a scenario to look into new solutions for contemporary challenges. We will begin with a broader study that explores the characteristics behind the informality and urban plans, understanding the stories behind the new forms of city development, the related forms of democracy and governance in the Latin society; together with the power of architecture as a mean to transform social realities.

title: Engineering in the Modern World
reviews: A good distribution requirement - but the term paper could take some time.
Do it!
Do not hesitate to take this course for your HA requirement!
Harder than you would expect - but a great history credit for those who are interested in science, technology and engineering.
I great course that is very well put together.
I would recommend taking this course. It's not a lot of work on a weekly basis and the material is interesting to say the least
I would tell them to read the 2 books in advance to gain a good understanding of the course material early on.

If you are an engineer who needs an HA, I would indeed recommend this course.  If you have any interest in the history behind the biggest ideas of industrial age civil engineering, then this course is for you.  It is a cool blend of history and engineering.
If you are interested in learning more about simplified engineering, take this course!

If you need to fulfill an HA or STL requirement and are looking for an easy way to do it, this is it. The problem sets do involve a little bit of math-type thinking, but it's only algebra and some basic physics. Don't expect anything amazing that will greatly stimulate your mind though.

If you want to take this as a HA to PDF, consider other classes first. The professors take the class too seriously and push a ton of pointless assignments on you (final exam AND term paper AND presentation) that while might be done with minimal effort, still require a frustrating amount of time. Reading for precept is not necessary (maybe print it out and bring it, though)

If you're an upperclassman, beware that it will be more busywork than you're expecting.  If you're an engineer, the scientific aspect will be a piece of cake.  Definitely a good candidate for a PDF, although getting an A doesn't seem like it would be very difficult if you're willing to put time into the paper and into studying for the exams.

If you're interested in learning the history behind the greatest innovations of the United States (as well as some of the simplified scientific concepts behind them), take this course. It does a great job of placing the technology we take for granted today into a historical context.
If you're looking for an easy PDF, there are better options.
Its a nice class if you want a distribution requirement. There is a fair number of assignments and readings to keep up with however if you want to take the class for a grade and not PDF
Not a bad course but I would be careful regarding precepts still.
Participate well in precepts; make sure to review the materials after each lectures
Pay attention and take notes in lecture and enjoy the interesting material.
Pay attention during lectures
Read early, and WITH the course, not after it.  A.k.a. cramming is a terrible idea.
Realize that you will invest more time in this course than you think.
Recommended for Billington and Littman.

Start from the beginning of the year making a study guide for the exams, adding on during each lecture.  It is really hard to find the exact dates and names you need based off powerpoints later because they are not very well put together.  If you understand the exam format and take notes in that format, it it much easier to understand.
Study more than you think you need to for the exam. The material is very simple, but it's hit or miss.
Take it PDF.  Stay awake in lecture or do the readings.  Choose at least one.
Take it if you want to learn the history of American engineering
Take it, do the readings. They are actually interesting.
Take it.  Great subject material, some of which you will likely never forget because of its relevance to your daily life.
Take this class! You will get what you expect and more. The tests are reasonable and strictly based on what we learned in class and precept.
The course isn't too difficult, but don't blow it off. Readings pile up, even though its less than 100 pages a week.

The only advice I can give for this class is to "see what it can do for you." Whether one is majoring in a technical or humanities subject, the combination of engineering principles and social/symbolic analyses make it a great pick for anyone.
This course is interesting for engineers that need an HA requirement covered. It is a reasonable amount of work, however, especially when it comes to the term paper.

This course wasn't very hard.  I took it was a PDF.  It was harder this year then i think it was in years past. Classes were very boring and readings were not very interesting.  However with studying it wouldn't be hard to get an A.  Definitely and easy B /pass

This is a pretty easy course. The problem sets are very easy especially if you have any math/science background. The precept assignments can be a little annoying at times. The final paper is pretty much like the research paper for writing seminar in terms of the assignment. The work does pile up at the end of the course with the paper, presentation, and final so keep that in mind. The exams are pretty straight forward and pretty much require memorization of the facts and concepts of the course. The reading is pretty light and its contents are covered in the lectures.

This is an excellent course for the material. If one wishes to really learn a relevant piece of history, this course will give your the necessary background about the figures who shaped the United States and the world around us.
This is an fairly easy course that is also interesting as it covers the development of technology in America and the history behind each invention.
Way more work than you would think to prepare for exams

What I found out is that if you take this course as an HA (historical analysis distribution requirement) it will be like any other history class, unlike the common mentality that this course is an "easy A".  However, as an STL, this course, from what I've heard, is far easier than other STL's.  Anyways, I took this course as an HA and didn't think it was too interesting.  I fell asleep for almost every lecture.  The midterm was pretty much based on memorization.  Another thing to note is that I hate history classes.  This class wasn't the "easy A" I was expecting.  I haven't gotten my final grades yet but as of the midterm I had a B.
Yes! But it's not all about bridges. Be careful.
great course if you're looking for an interesting HA
descrip: Lectures and readings focus on bridges, railroads, power plants, highways, airports, harbors, automobiles, aircraft, computers, and the microchip. Historical analysis provides a basic for studying urban problems by focusing on scientific, political, ethical, and aesthetic aspects in the evolution of engineering over the past two centuries. The precepts and the papers will focus historically on engineering ideas including the social and political issues raised by these innovations and how they were shaped by society as well as how they helped shape culture.

title: Beginner's Spanish I
reviews: A definite course to take, especially with Prof. Zetterstrand: she makes the course fun and interesting while teaching the material extremely thoroughly.
Attend all classes and do all of the readings.
Be ready to have a class with students who already know a lot of spanish, but other wise it's a fine course. Hard to get a good grade in.
Be warned that the majority of your class will be freshmen, will have taken high school Spanish, and has no real interest in actually speaking Spanish.
Differently would recommend this course to someone with little to no experience in the language.
Do all the assignments on time and don't let work for the end of the course, because it will help you learn the language better if you study every day a little bit.
Do your work and you'll be fine!
Don't be afraid to go in for office hours and take a long time to study for tests. Be prepared to have kids in your class who have taken Spanish before. Work hard, and you will do well.
Don't take it if you never took spanish before.
Flashcards!
I loved this course, but mainly because I really enjoyed my professor.
I think students should definitely consider taking Spanish 101 order to fulfill their language requirement or if they have any interest in learning another language.
I would advise students to take Spanish with Profesora Olander.
I would say that if you can, take 103, because the classwork is similar but just a little more fast paced.
I would take this course if you are interested in becoming familiar with a very common language that will be useful in life. Study prior to going to class.
I'd say that you have to make sure you do all the homework every night because the workbooks get collected twice.
If YOU haven't taken spanish before you will be behind, I am still behind at the end of the semester but starting to catch up. Beware!
If you want to learn Spanish, go ahead.
If you want to learn Spanish, you have to start somewhere, namely here...not the best class ever, but necessary to get your Spanish-speaking career started!
It's college language course. Take it seriously.
Its a 101 language, its fun, not super hard, you learn a lot.

Loved this class, but effort = results for this one. You should be ready to put in about 30min-1h each day to review the work and do homework, which will more than adequately prepare you for any quizzes/exams. Also go to the Spanish table if you can, because it helps in listening and speaking.
Make sure to keep up on homework and listen in class.
Make sure to study any new concept you learned in class several times.
Make sure you block out a lot of time in your schedule to do all the endless little activities because the better you prepare the more you'll like it.
Make sure you keep up with all of the weekly assignments.
Make sure you pick Professor Bookhamer.
Make sure you stay on top of your work and do the homework daily. It is not fun trying to catch back on homework's.
One hour a day may not seem much, but to become fluent you really need to study a lot out of class. Especially vocabulary, it's so hard to memorize.
Participating is important because it makes oral presentations and tests that much easier.
Practice a little everyday, not just once a week.
Prof. Zetterstrand is great, so if you can get in her section!
Review consistently every night especially if you are an absolute beginner.
Review the vocab as much as possible and get used to speaking and listening.
Review the vocabulary often and practice the material during time off - this is a great course and if you work hard you will really enjoy it!!
Rewarding at the end of the course. Put in regular work for your own sake or tests can be a rush
Set aside some time to review each night.
Spanish is a cool language, and this introductory class is a good way to get started.  Azahara is great if you can get her.  Make sure you keep up with your work as close to daily as possible.
Stay at least a day ahead with the homework so you are prepared in class and then have extra time to study in case you have alot of other work!
Stay on top of work!
TAKE SPANISH!
Take it! Ana is great if she's teaching it again!
Take this course if you're new to Spanish or want a slow reintroduction to it. Specifically take it with Profesora B because she is great, super helpful, and really nice.
Take time to memorize the vocabulary every day, and make sure you do the homework.
This course was great for new Spanish students or anyone who has taken the class before but isn't quite comfortably reading or writing. Professor Olander was outstanding.
This is a decent introduction to Spanish for someone who has had absolutely no background in it before.
This is a very good class, but it can be tough to score well on all the assignments.
Try not to just go to class because you have to. Go with a desire to learn something!
Will be more difficult if you are a true beginner.
You have to be very careful-the exams and papers are very detail-oriented and it is easy to lose out points on assignments
study the vocabulary so that then you know what to say and so that you are not limited to basic responses.
take it
take it but keeping up with the work is essential
very fun class. a lot of work but definitely manageable
prereqs: Students with previous knowledge in Spanish MUST take the Department's Placement Test available online from July 15 - August 15 before taking this course. This also applies to Graduate students interested in taking the course. International Baccalaureate students must also take the Placement Test. Students with AP5 are not required to take this test..
descrip: SPA 101 presents the basic structures and vocabulary of the Spanish language. The four skills (listening, speaking, reading and writing) are practiced and developed by means of classroom activities and materials in which language appears in a cultural context. Classes are conducted in Spanish. No credit is given for SPA 101 unless followed by SPA 102.

title: Modern Japanese Prose
descrip: A study of selected major authors and literary trends in modern Japan, with an emphasis on the Meiji and Taisho periods.

title: Operating Systems
reviews: A really terrific course that's well worth the additional time spent doing assignments. Not particularly difficult if you keep up with everything.

Believe what people tell you about the difficulty of this course, but don't blow it up to something prohibitively intimidating. You want Compilers for that. This course was actually objectively interesting, and while the programming assignments are rather cryptic and impossible-looking, you always get through them anyway. And for it all, you come out a much better computer scientist.
Best class at Princeton. All COS majors need to take!
Covers important concepts for COS students, but has a lot of work.
Definitely take the course if you are a CS major and you are willing to put a good amount of work on it
Definitely worth taking. You will learn a lot if you put in the work to finish the assignments well (not too hard because they're almost entirely group projects).

Don't take it with Kai Li. Vivek Pai = way better. Aaron is a terrible TA; Yida is awesome; pick your partners wisely. You'll learn a LOT of necessary stuff, and the material is very important. OS kicks everyone's butts at every school, it seems. Expect to spend 15-20 hours per biweekly assignment. It's hard but kinda cool. I'd have liked it a lot more if it had been better run. And if Kai Li hadn't annoyed me in the beginning with his comments about women. That really turned me off for the rest of the class.
Don't take this class with Kai Li if you can avoid it.
For god's sake, take this in a less busy year, please.  You'll destroy yourself otherwise.

For most COS majors, this course is a necessary evil. And by "evil" I mean "say goodbye to your weekend." (I exaggerate somewhat, but not that much.) Review what you learned in 217, avoid taking other programming-intensive courses at the same time, and absolutely make use of the lab TAs' office hours. Also, the more friends you have taking this course with you, the better. If you don't have any, you will definitely make some.
Great content, but very poorly run.  It will turn into a headache very quickly, no matter how well you grasp the content.  I wouldn't take this unless I had to or had a strong interest in the area.

I would recommend you take Information Security or AI instead. Don't take this course. There was nothing here that worked out for me. A professor who didn't explain concepts, a dry book, incompetent TA's, and deprecated assignments. The TA's especially were the worst. They did not explain assignments, took multiple days to answer questions, and then answered with "maybe". They did not even know how to set up some of the tools we needed to use (bochsgdb for instance). Students who had taken this course previously called the tools "essential." The TA's would say, "Let us know if you figure out how to use them." This is unacceptable. I understand that some grad students did not want the job they were assigned, but maybe that means it should not be assigned to them in the first place. These clowns clearly were not interested in teaching us anything.

If you can, don't take this with Kai Li. From his guest lectures, Vivek Pai seems like a much better option. If you do decide to take it, start the projects early and be prepared to get caught on a lot of little bugs that are stupid but hard to find.
If you find operating systems interesting, take the course.

If you liked COS 217, you should definitely take this course.  If you didn't care for COS 217, you should still take it, but make sure you find a partner who enjoys programming assignments in C and Assembly.
It's a lot of work, and some professors are definitely better than others at presenting the material. That said it is a core class with material majors should know about.
It's a pretty good extension of COS 217, if you liked that you will like this. Lots of busy-work, but there's a good payoff.

OS is challenging but you learn an incredible amount so it's very useful; see if you can take it with Professor Pai ? we took it with Li, and he was decent, but Pai gave a couple guest lectures and he was way more interesting and really funny

Operating Systems is a subject that is important for a well-rounded computer science education.  That being said, this course is a nightmare.  Without exaggeration, COS 318 was more work than all my other courses combined.  Also, the averages are extremely high, making it devastating to receive a less-than-perfect score on an assignment.  The tools given for debugging the assembly code you'll have to write are atrocious.  I have never had a more frustrating experience.  Will it be worth it when you write your own virtual memory system?  Or when you have it on your transcript when you apply to grad school?  Maybe.  But definitely, definitely, definitely, think twice before taking this course.  I wish, so dearly, that I had picked another class.

Pay attention to the professor: having a lectures with more excitement and passion and less monotone stupor would make the class significantly better.
That said, you're probably taking this class for the assignments.  Yes they're long and complicated (be prepared to spend about 4 hrs in lab design review week and 16  implementation week) but you build an operating system!  It's kinda neat.
The exams may or may not have any bearing on the assignments.  Probably not.  Review old exams from previous years (especially for the midterm).
Read the textbook!
Start assignments early, and PLAN before you  code. Most of the assignments are pretty straightforward if you do it all (or most of it) on paper beforehand.
Start early on the projects, stay on top of the material.

Start projects early! Make sure you understand what to do before your design review - the median grade for the projects are like 14-15 out of 15 and the design review counts for 5 of it. There's a lot to read, don't underestimate the amount of time that takes too. This class is a lot of work.
Start projects early, plan to finish a week and advance.
TIme consuming, but worth taking.  I wouldn't call myself a real CS major without it.
Take it if you're interested in Operating Systems.
Take it in a semester taught by M. Martonosi, V. Pai, etc. Kai Li seems very detached and takes very little interest in the course.
Take it with Vivek Pai
Take it, but not necessarily with Kai Li. Quality of preceptors also varies.
Take the course, but be prepared to write a ton of code
Take this course if you're a COS major or have an interest in systems.
Take this course.

The MOS book is amazing!! The author has a sense of humor and explains concepts very well. The readings will get you through the class. Assignments are not easy, but working with partners helps. Always start early.

The material of this course is excellent. For anyone interested in the intersection of software and hardware, this course is a must. It goes hand in hand with computer architecture courses offered. But the course is very poorly organized, so prepare for frustration.
This class is a LOT of work. It can be extremely tedious and eat up entire weekends. You do learn a lot, but only take it if you're genuinely interested in systems.

This class is difficult.  You will bang your head on the wall many times over debugging and details but in the end the concepts are very useful and most of the building in the projects is actually worth it in the end.  If you want to be a serious computer science major or a decent programmer you should really take this class at some point.

This class really will teach you about operating systems, but it will make you work for it. Li is a bit of a dull lecturer, so most of my learning came from doing the assignments. Be prepared for a lot of debugging. The assignments don't actually involve writing very much code, but the code you write can be pretty tricky and sensitive

This class should be required for all COS majors, as it covers essential material such as concurrent and parallell programming that is not covered by the intro classes. That said, it is also a well taught and enjoyable (though very challenging) class.

This course is alright. It has a ton of work, literally. I mean it. The assignments take a long, long time, you have to do weekly reading/response questions (twice a week), they have a sign in sheet for lectures (so you can't even skip lectures), plus there's a midterm, a final project (which take like 20  hours easily), and a final exam. The lectures were relatively dry. That could be the result of kai li, or that could be the result of my lack of interest in operating systems. It's not hard to do well. I have around a 100 average heading into the final exam as of writing this review, but that's not to say it doesn't require significant work. As a cos major, you could probably do without taking this course, but you'll definitely learn a ton about operating systems if that's your thing.

This is a good class that teaches you a lot of concepts that are useful to know, but be warned that the assignments are not really explained to you and that you pretty much have to go about them yourself-every assignment feels like the "on your own" part of cos 217, except much harder.
This is a good course but take it only when Prof. Pai is teaching it.
Unless a requirement, just learn OS by yourself by doing the programming assignments and read the new OS book.
Well worth taking if you're interested in the fundamentals of how computers work.  Like all COS courses, just make sure you start the assignments early.
You should take this if you're a major.
prereqs: COS 217 and COS 226. Audit option only available with instructor's permission..
descrip: An introduction to operating systems. Emphasis is on the fundamentals of how to design and implement an operating system. Topics include operating system structure, processes, threads, synchronizations, concurrent programming, interprocess communications, virtual memory, I/O device management, and file systems.

title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Chemistry (Half-Term)
reviews: Requirement?
Should take it.
The more you speak up the more fun the lectures are.
descrip: Discussion and evaluation of the role professional researchers play in dealing with the reporting of research, responsible authorship, human and animal studies, misconduct and fraud in science, intellectual property, and professional conduct in scientific relationships. Participants are expected to read the materials and cases prior to each meeting. Successful completion is based on regular attendance and active participation in discussion. This half-term course is designed to satisfy federal funding agencies' requirements for training in the ethical practice of scientists. Required for chemistry graduate students & post-docs.

title: Advanced Economic Theory I
descrip: Topics vary from year to year reflecting, among other things, current developments and the instructor's interests. Topics covered in past years have included expected and nonexpected utility theory, intertemporal general equilibrium theory, evolutionary game theory, dynamic games, contract theory, theory of organizations, and bounded rationality.

title: Music Theory through Performance and Composition
reviews: Be willing to put in a vast amount of effort and time, especially if you have not done much theory before. This was the case with me and I found it very difficult to keep up.
Definitely take this class if you like music, but make sure you have some familiarity with musical notation and basic theory.
Even if you don't need this course for your major or for a certificate, any musician interested in learning the basics of music theory will benefit from it.
Expect a lot of work if you don't have any background in the subject. You can get through it but expect a lot of reading, ask questions, and you'll have to put the time in.
Finish all your homework, even if there is a lot.
Great for anyone with a interest in music, but be prepared for a lot of work.
I would advise other students to use a piano when completing voice leading assignments even if your piano playing is not very good.
I would definitely tell others to take it, especially if they play an instrument.
I would recommend this course for anyone interested in music. It is straightforward and a good foundation.
I wouldn't take it, unless you have to.  It is not very interesting.
If Barbara White is teaching - stay far, far away.
If Professor white continues to teach, the class will not be difficult, especially if one has any previous theory experience.

If you are a student with a rudimentary background in music theory, please take this course!  It not only helps you understand and identify so many of the musical phenomenon we hear, it helps you appreciate the complexity of what is going on.  It is a very well structured and effective course, and I highly recommend it.
If you don't have any prior music theory experience, this is a difficult course.
If you have an interest in music, might as well take it, since it's music theory.

If you want to feel like you have a decent understanding of basic music theory, you can take this course. Don't worry, at least this year with White, you don't have to do any performance unless you volunteer (this was one reason I hadn't taken it before). Overall a good class, though you will have a decent amount of weekly work that doesn't go away even if you PDF.

It is a beneficial course, but very, very difficult if you do not play piano or have little background in music theory, as I do. It seemed that everyone who was taking the course had either studied piano, taken music theory before, or was classically trained. Essentially, it seemed like they did not really need to take the course, which made it difficult for people like me to get the most out of it. Also, I had to spend about 5 hours a week on ear training, and had to give up on that after fall break just because I did not have enough time to incorporate that into my work, which was also disappointing.
It's interesting, not too much work and pretty fun. There's good music and it's stimulating. Take it.

Professor White's lectures were not very helpful in providing clarification and examples that were grounded solidly in the material we were reading about in the textbook.  Precept was at least a chance to get some questions answered on the technical elements that form the foundation of music theory.  That being said, I personally liked the textbook and thought it explained the concepts fairly clearly.  And I found the material itself fascinating.
Take it if you have a fairly strong performance background with little theory.  Don't be intimidated by all of the kids with perfect pitch.  There's a lot of them.
Take it with Dmitri.
Take the course.
Take this class if you are a music major or certificate student. I WOULD NOT recommend this for students who are simply looking for an "easy" music course.

Take this class if you need to to get to higher-level music classes. There's really no choice in that case. If you are considering taking this for fun, realize that it is relatively easy (which admittedly might be exactly what you're looking for), but not as interesting or involved as you might like.

Take this course if you are really interested in the rules of classical music.  Beware that you won't really be composing according to anything other than the principle rules of voice-leading and part-writing.

The class is not difficult and focuses a lot on music composition (four part writing). If you are interested in music (and especially composition), you will find the course relaxing and yet also enlightening.
have fun!
prereqs: The ability to read music in treble and bass clef, proficiency in singing or on an instrument. In the first lecture, students will complete a placement test to gauge preparation and appropriateness..
descrip: Music 105 is a comprehensive introduction to music theory. Our emphasis is on the theoretical principles of four-part harmony as exemplified in Western art music; areas of inquiry include rhythmic materials, melodic patterning, and formal design. Work includes theoretical exercises, analysis, composition, and ear training, all of which are intended to complement a student's everyday activity as a musician.

title: Applied Social Statistics
descrip: First in a two-course sequence for graduate students in Sociology. Two goals of the course are: (1) to provide a rigorous introduction to inferential statistics focusing on the probability theory required to understand the Central Limit Theorem, the basis for most classical statistical inference; and (2) to provide in-depth coverage of Stata, the most popular statistics package currently used in Sociology. Topics covered include: descriptive statistics and visualization of data, classical statistical inference, basic nonparametric tests, Analysis of Variance, correlation, and the basics of multiple regression.

title: Tragedy
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Main Street USA
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Contemporary American Prose
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Russian Drama
reviews: Take it even if you know nothing about Russian drama or drama in general.
Take it! It's going to be a fair amount of work, but it's definitely worth it.
Take this course!! You won't regret it. And don't hesitate just because you're worried about your language skills -- I guarantee that you know more Russian than you think you do.
This is an interesting and engaging course. The final drama project is especially rewarding.
prereqs: RUS 207 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: This course is devoted to the reading and discussion of masterpieces of 19th and 20th century Russian drama. It will also provide students with an opportunity to develop aural, oral, and written language skills. Classes are conducted entirely in Russian and all readings are to be done in the original. Students will participate in a performance project at the end of the term.

title: Philanthropy
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Experimental Chemistry
reviews: A good option for a required experimental laboratory course. Lab reports were time consuming and six hours of lab work per week, but the experience was overall enjoyable.
Chances are you're taking this because you have to.  Just try to avoid bad TAs.
Core lab requires a lot of work -- 4 lab reports, 2 exams, and an 6-week independent group project.
Design your schedule around this course, because it will be your main priority during the semester.

Go to Prof. Kelly's office hours!  He is so, so helpful and really clarifies the material.  Be prepared - this course has a huge amount of work, but the challenges are rewarding in the end.  You'll gain a solid chemistry foundation.

If you can, try to take MSE core lab, as I've heard that class is much better and it sounds like it has a greater focus on how to do lab work than on knowledge, which I feel should be the point of a core lab class.
Make friends and work with them, and start the lab reports early.
Prepare to work hard and long.
Relax

Start on the lab reports early!!! Read whatever material is cited inside the lab manual. Be sure to work with others and compare work. Remember, ferrocene and hcl/dcl are probably some of the most intensive labs. Also, if your answer is wrong, recheck the units and magnitude. Finally, USE EXCEL!!!

This course requires a lot of work and is quite a large time commitment. However, you will learn a lot over the course of the semester and it can be a rewarding experience. If you need to take it as a requirement, be sure to manage your time wisely and start the lab reports as soon as possible.

This is a course in which you will learn a great deal about a range of fields, from inorganic to physical to computational chemistry. Be aware that it is a large time commitment and select your other courses accordingly. Start lab reports early and meet with TAs if you run into issues. One valuable skill is getting comfortable going into the literature to find information: for the lab reports, and especially the independent project, doing this can really help you.
This is a good course to take. It is hard and time-consuming, but it's worth it.
Work hard. If you put in the effort, you're guaranteed the result.
dont take
useful for chem research/getting to know the field
you should take it, materials core lab is a joke
prereqs: CHM 202, 204 or 215 or equivalent. Concomitant enrollment in either CHM 305 or 407 is strongly advised..
descrip: The purpose of this laboratory course is to teach the principles and practice of modern experimental chemistry, including: data collection, analysis, and interpretation; experimental design; validity of data and meaning of statistical correlation; and theoretical and operational aspects of modern instrumentation. Applications of computers in data analysis and molecular modeling will also be covered.

title: Introduction to Indo-European
reviews: An awesome course, taught by an awesome professor. If you are at all interested in historical linguistics, or even have wondered about how languages connect, I'd recommend this course. Do keep up with the readings.
Do it! Never turn down a chance to learn from Professor Katz - especially not on a topic as interesting as this.
Fascinating, but a lot of work.
Great course, great professor. A bit of work, but it's worth it.
Great course. Take this course if you are at all interested in linguistics.
I highly recommend this course; Dr. Katz is great, and you'll learn a lot!

I took the HUM sequence freshman year, loved it and would defend it on any day as the best Princeton course. So I was completely sure no class could ever beat it. But I was wrong! "Introduction to Indo-European" was a pedagogical tour de force, which, among other things, meant that when I was doing the readings, I couldn't put the textbook down. This is almost unbelievable, because without Professor Katz's zeal, the plethora of technical details which make up a lot of Indo-European linguistics can very easily seem overwhelming. But, honestly, I always found it fun and never once thought of it as 'work'. How would you like to take a class in which you forget-- or never realize-- that you are doing work because you're having so much fun? Also, I came away from this class not only wanting to learn more languages and more cultures and more ideas, but also understanding that each new Indo-European language one learns is simply a different 'variation' or descendant of what was once, very many years ago, simply one 'language'.
Take it if you have the slightest interest in any Indo-European language! Or just take any class with Professor Katz.
Take it!  But be prepared to spend a lot of time on it to get as much out of it as you can...

This was an excellent course. It is very interesting and the professor and the other students in the class were very knowledgeable and receptive. I had no background in historical linguistics and not much in other Indo-European languages (except for English) and this was not a problem. Though it would certainly be beneficial to have this knowledge.
take it, obviously
prereqs: Knowledge of at least one older Indo-European language will be helpful but is not required. The same holds true for knowledge of basic linguistic methods..
descrip: This course provides an introduction to the study of the Indo-European language family from both a historical and a comparative perspective. The emphasis will be on the phonology, morphology, syntax, and vocabulary of the earliest representatives (Ancient Greek, Latin, Vedic Sanskrit, Hittite, Old Irish, Old English, etc.) and what they have to tell us about Proto-Indo-European and the culture of the speakers of this reconstructed "mother tongue."

title: Current Issues in Neuroscience and Behavior
descrip: Advanced seminar that reflects current research on brain and behavior.

title: Special Topics in the History of Science, Technology, and Medicine - Sensory Histories
reviews: I would recommend this class particularly to students who have a project in mind, which could benefit from a sensory history approach.
It's a very useful course to take for people in many fields.
Recommended also for the experimental streak in the course as much as the rigor.
This course would be good if you already have a strong background in sensory history.
descrip: This course will explore the historical recovery of the sensory dimensions of experience. How can historians recapture the sights, sounds, and scents of the past? What can these phenomena tell us more generally about the societies and cultures in which they were situated? How can textual sources be mined for sensory meaning, and how can modern media - such as photographs and phonograph recording - be deployed as primary sources for historical analysis?

title: Topology
reviews: 215 or an equivalent would probably be nice to know (to be comfortable with the real line, as well as manipulating sets) , as well as a bit of group theory, though the latter is not strictly necessary
An easy departmental with Szabo.
I would recommend this course if only to get a solid foundation in topology, which is critical for any future studies in math. Szab? is really great and will give you great intuition for the future.
It is a fun math course to take even for a not-math-majored student.

It is possible to take this class fairly early on in your undergraduate career, and it is probably a good idea to do so because the concepts involved can come in handy in other courses. Taking it earlier will also help you figure out which directions you want to go in in math. As long as you go to class and read the textbook you should do well in this class.

Take it! Topology is a really cool area of mathematics and Professor Szabo is a great lecturer - he's really good at providing the intuition behind concepts. Problem sets are not that time consuming in general.
Take it.
Take this course if Zoltan is teaching it.  He is great.
The class provides interesting material and is presented very well.
Theorem: You should take this class. Proof: (1) Szabo is amazing, (2) topology is cool, and (3) Szabo   topology = best combination. QED.
prereqs: MAT202 or 204 or 218 or equivalent..
descrip: Introduction to point-set topology, the fundamental group, covering spaces, methods of calculation and applications.

title: Roman Historians of the Empire
prereqs: 200 level Latin or permission of instructor..
descrip: We will read Tacitus' biography of his father-in-law, Agricola, and selections from the first two books if his Annals with a focus on the relationship between the emperor Tiberius and his nephew/adopted son Germanicus, a relationship that informs Tacitus' representation of that between Agricola and the emperor Domitian.

title: Friending, Following & Finding
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: The Environmental Engineering of Buildings, Part I
reviews: yep. not that it's a choice. but it's a good class.
prereqs: All undergraduate students must have permission of the instructor to enroll..
descrip: The first part of a sequence taught over two terms that provides a broad introduction to Building Systems, Environmental Control and Energy Conservation. Sustainable design themes and environmentally responsible practices are stressed throughout and form a backdrop to all the instructional material provided. The fall course focuses on fundamental concepts and provides an introduction to Mechanical, Electrical, Plumbing, Lighting, Acoustical and Life Safety systems. ARC 515, taught in the spring, considers the design process and the integration of these systems into buildings.

title: The Comparative Political Economy of Development
descrip: Analysis of political change and the operation of political institutions in the development process, with emphasis on the interaction of political and economic factors. Various definitions and theories of political development are examined and tested against different economic, ethnic, geographic, and social contexts.

title: Mechanics of Solids
reviews: If you need to take a mechanics of solids class, take this one instead of the MAE one.
If you really want to take it to learn about structures, go for it, but I'd only take it if I had to.
Put a lot of time and effort into the course.
Take this course. It is very interesting and very well taught.

Ted was the best TA I have ever had. This class is a great introduction into Civil Engineering. There are some required courses that make you think twice about your major. This class motivates you to continue on the Civil Track. A combination of the material, great professor, and great TA really make this an enjoyable class.
This is a great start to the Civil Engineering curriculum and a good mix of internal mechanics and design.
You're probably required to take this course, and there will be a consistent, yet not overbearing workload, but Prof. Adriaenssens and Ted will make the class very rewarding!
take it if you're a CEE
prereqs: PHY 103 and MAT 104.
descrip: This course teaches fundamental principles of solid mechanics. Equilibrium equations, reactims, internal forces, stress, strain, Mohr's circle, and Hooke's law. Analysis of the stress and deformation in simple structural members for safe and stable engineering design. Axial force in bars, torsion in shafts, bending and shearing in beams, stability of elastic columns, strain transformation, stress transformation, circle of Mohr, combined loadings, design project.

title: Art of Adventure, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Introduction to Ballet
reviews: Come in with an open mind, Tina often makes things up on the spot so you have to trust her. The class is extremely rewarding if you put in the time and effort to take it seriously. If you are a dancer who has never taken ballet, I strongly recommend that you take this class. It is very much an intro ballet class and will help you by teaching you basic theories of movement and mechanics.

DEFINITELY TAKE THIS CLASS. TINA IS A PHENOMENAL INSTRUCTOR!!!! Also, this is a great way to get in shape, but also for dancers and dance enthusiasts, this class is perfect for expanding your horizons and developing more as a dancer.
My favorite course!
Participate 100% in class! You learn a lot and really feel accomplished with what you've learned at the end of the course.
Take it!  It's lots of fun, you learn how to dance, and Tina's very nice!
This class is a wonderful exploration of the foundations of ballet! Not really intended for dancers with any ballet experience, but delightful nonetheless.
This is an excellent intro course for ballet.  You will learn the basics and have a lot of fun!  It's not too work-intensive; there is some reading and viewing, but mostly just dancing.

Tina is an approachable and accomplished professor. Even if you're not a dancer, Tina takes great lengths to make sure you learn the sequences and are comfortable. Because the class is PDF, it's about as much work as you want it to be. Also, note that this course has a heavy focus on performance. You'll become more proficient in ballet terminology, but don't expect to know too much about the history and the people. The readings try to give you a historical perspective, but, they are overwhelming for an intro class, and it's easy to skim through without knowing what's important to retain. But, this course is definitely one of Princeton's gems.
definitely take it!
descrip: From grand plie to grand jete, Introduction to Ballet is for students with a curiosity for the study of classical ballet. No prior dance experience necessary and beginners are welcome. In this studio course students will learn the fundamentals of ballet, gaining an understanding of its physicality, artistry, and principles of alignment. Students will examine the historical origins of ballet and its absorption of cultural influences. Live music will be featured in this class and key in exploring the inextricable link between music and dance.

title: 19th-Century Fiction
reviews:
1. Try to start thinking about your papers well before you write them.
2. In writing your essays, make sure you are analyzing the rhetoric/language of the novel and not just the overall plot. This will help you in constructing an arguable thesis.

Absolutely take this course. It has been one of my favorite courses so far at Princeton, because Jeff is an amazing lecturer. If you don't take a class with him during your time here, you're missing out. Even for someone not particularly interested in the subject (like me), Jeff brought this course and the novels to life.
Be prepared for fantastically intriguing and humorous lectures coupled with a heavy reading load that will be nearly impossible to keep up with. The lectures are worth it though.
Be ready to read a lot. You won't gain as much out of precepts and lectures if you haven't read them.
Be sure to attend the precepts as the lectures are not the most informative concerning how to write the papers.
Definitely take it if you can handle reading at least half of the novels.

Definitely take it, especially if you are looking for a good course to PDF. Lectures are fully worth attending just on Jeff Nunokawa's own merit. If he knows you by name, watch out - he may call on you to answer questions about the books at any random point in time, so you'd better have done the readings. Otherwise, sit closer to the back and enjoy. He tends to be forgiving with people who haven't done all the readings, but the books are so good that it's worth keeping up.

Definitely take this course to fulfill your LA. While you will probably do fine skipping most of the reading, you will get a lot out of the course if you do all the reading. Lecturers like Jeff Nunokawa are why Princeton is an amazing school.
Do not be intimidated by the amount of reading. Like Professor Nunokawa says, you will take whatever you can get from this course. Believe me, it is so worth it.

I didn't have writing sem before taking this nor experience with literary analysis, but I was able to write the papers and do well. I regret not finishing, or at least getting farther in, all the novels.
I would not recommend this course to any student except those interested in concentrating in English.

I would recommend this course because the workload isn't too bad.  You don't have to read all of the books and just have to write two big papers.  That said, make sure you'll have time to devote to the papers around midterms and finals

I would recommend this course with Jeff Nunokawa as he really keeps you going to lectures even when you don't feel like going to any other class. His enthusiasm regarding the novels and the class is contagious. Besides keeping up with the readings, the class itself isn't too much work.
I would say don't hesitate!  You must take this class, whoever you are because in any field, simply as a human being this class is relevant to you, and perhaps even life changing.
I've already been telling everyone to take it like people told me to take it. Because everyone should take it.
If you like 19th century fiction, there is no better professor than Jeff.

If you're even remotely interested in the novels being read, I'd take the course. Jeff is astonishing and it's a huge treat to hear him lecture. Whether you do the readings or not you'll get something out of the course (though obviously you'll get more if you actually do them).
It's great to learn insights from Jeff. Do the reading over the summer. Again, do the reading over the summer. You will have almost no work for the class and really enjoy it if you do that.
It's not a very difficult course but if you're looking to learn something from an LA course then this course will do that for you.
It's quite hard as a freshman, but very interesting.  I regret taking as a freshman, as I think it would have been better to take either sophomore or junior year. Still, I did enjoy it.

Jeff is hands down the best lecturer I've ever had. He's engaging, witty, eloquent, and soulful; full of heart and energy and love for the literature he's teaching. The class is only 2 essays (one after midterms and one due dean's date), so the majority of the work is doing the readings - and though it's easy to slack on them, do the readings and go to every single lecture and you won't regret it. You'll get so much out of the class. Anyone remotely interested in literature, or looking for a phenomenal (and not very work-intensive) LA, should take this class.
Keep up with the readings and start the papers early because Jeff gives really great feedback, but you need to ask him ahead of time.
Lectures are kind of crazy and kind of confusing at times. But reading list is great. Try to get Ariana for precept if she is teaching again!
Make sure to start on the material as early as possible because the books are fascinating but they're also quite long.
Make sure you like the books on the reading list.
Make sure you read a few books over the summer and the semester will be more manageable.
Prof. Nunokawa's lectures are awesome. The workload is also light (reading novels, a few Blackboard posts, and two essays).
Professor Nunokawa is great and you should take the course.
Read the books before the semester starts, then reread as you go along.
Read the books!
Read the books! I always ended up liking the novels in the end, even if they started slow. You'll get so much more out of lectures.

Read the novels! They are so interesting and relaxing once you get a hang of them.  At first, the readings may seem difficult, but they become much easier as you familiarize yourself with the language.
Read, read, read!! Keep up to date on the readings.
Read.
Stay on top of the reading! If you take it in the fall you can do 2 or 3 books over the summer which will give you a great advantage.
TAKE IT! READ EVERYTHING! GO TO LECTURES!
TAKE IT!!!! It is what you make of it. You can do a lot or do very little. Either way, if you write well and understand close reading, you'll be ok. Plus, Nunokawa is just great.
TAKE THIS CLASS BECAUSE JEFF IS AN AMAZING PERSON.
Take it
Take it, but beware the lengths of the novels
Take it, but understand that there is a lot of reading.
Take it. Just do it.
Take this course for Nunokawa! He's one of the most passionate, enthusiastic teachers I've ever had, and he really cares about his students. He's also really funny--you won't fall asleep in lecture.
The reading load can definitely be heavy, especially towards the end, but it is so worth taking the course and doing the readings.
The readings are great, I was a little disappointed in the quality of the lectures
This class is awesome. It's worth it for Jeff alone. Do the reading though if you want to get anything out of the class.
This class is fantastic.  Take it--you won't regret it.

This is a one of those classic Princeton courses that you do NOT want to miss out on.  Jeff is a fantastic lecturer: funny, engaging, and brilliant.  You'll learn things that apply not just to the texts, but to life in general.  TAKE THIS COURSE.

Try to read some of the novels over the summer, as there is a lot to read. However, it is well worth it, as these are truly inspiring books that become that much more eye opening when you hear the lectures and discussions in precept.
You should consider reading the novels before the start of the semester (if you have not read them before).
be prepared to do a lot of close readings!
definitely take it. i read all the books over the summer, so i didn't have to do any of the work during, it was awesome and made the papers much easier.
i would say dont take it cuz jeff is crazy, but theres almost no work so take it i guess
take if you are interested in the reading list
work hard on your papers! they are very important
descrip: This course will acquaint students with the distinctive features of the nineteenth century novel, from Austen to Hardy. Lectures will seek to illuminate relations between social and aesthetic dimensions of the texts we read. We will consider how these fictional imaginings of things like love, sex, money, class, and race help shape the ways we live now.

title: America and the Melting Pot
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Imperialism and Reform in the Middle East and the Balkans
reviews: A must for anyone interested in understanding some of the key internal events in the development of the modern Middle East.

Take it! Take it as long as you're interested in the time period. I am an engineer (the farthest thing from a history / NES major) and I loved it. The professor is intelligent, understanding, helpful, and un-condescending. Can't make it for class? Tell him! Want genuine feedback for your paper? Tell him! Want to talk about another topic in class? Tell him! Have random questions? Tell him! He will make time for you whatever your problems. Prof. Hanioglu's an angel.
Take this course!
You will learn a lot in this class, but you must come prepared to do the readings. Professor Hanioglu is extremely knowledgeable, but the class has a looser structure, which is not for everyone.
descrip: The major Near Eastern diplomatic crises and the main developments in internal Near Eastern history. The focus will be upon the possible connections between diplomatic crises and the process of modernization. Oral reports and a short paper.

title: Microeconomic Theory
reviews: Attend lecture
Definitely read the weekly chapters from the textbook.
Don't take it unless you have to for the economics departmental requirement. Even then, it might be worth looking at ECO 310 instead.
Don't take unless you need to, but it's not awful
For a clear, well-explained econ course that fulfills a lot of requirements, ECO 300 is a very good option.
Go to lecture and learn how to do the problem sets.
I enjoyed the content of the course. It is very useful knowledge to have.
I liked this class a lot and recommend it to anyone thinking about econ.

I would suggest reviewing econ materials before taking this class, since it moved fairly quickly; it was nice for me to have my footing at the beginning of the year, since I had background in AP Microeconomics and Macroeconomics.
If you just want an SA, don't take this. If you are considering Economics, take it.
If you thrive under an organized course, this is for you
It can be dry sometimes but it is generally very interesting, even if you're not thinking about majoring in economics.
It has material that is good to know, so I would recommend it even if you're not an econ major
Just do the work as you go - don't let it pile up and you'll be fine.
Keep up with all the readings and ask about any concepts that you do not understand.
Listen in lecture.
Only take this if you are not prepared for 310.  Because it lacks math, it relies heavily on subjective methods and intuition.
Pretty easy class. You learn a lot of good fundamentals. Swati really makes sure that calculus is minimally involved in your problem sets.
Pretty easy. You'll be tempted to not go to class and slack off.
Professor Bhatt is a great lecturer and very accessible outside of class.

Professor Bhatt is a great lecturer and very clearly lays out everything you need to know. Go to lectures, pay close attention to key diagrams from the book. The bi-weekly quizzes are more qualitative and not very difficult, but the problem sets can be vague sometimes, so go to your preceptor's office hours to ask for clarification.
Professor Bhatt is the most engaging lecturer that I have had so far in the economics department.
Study for quizzes.
Study for the Quizzes and dont fall behind
Take it if required, but it's not particularly inspiring otherwise.
Take it if you're an econ major
Take this, no calculus and pretty interesting.
The course is fair with no surprises.
The course presents a lot of relevant information.
Use online resources!

don't take this course. at least not with the current professor. anyway, microecon cannot be studied without math. so be smart and take 310, you'll love con if you do it in ECO 310 and you'd hate it if you take this course. 300 should not even be a 300-level course...it should rather be a ECO 200...
only take it if you have to for departmental
prereqs: Prerequisites: ECO 100 and MAT 103..
descrip: This is an intermediate microeconomics course. The general themes are: (1) choices made by individual consumers and firms, (2) equilibrium of the interaction of these choices in markets or similar institutions, and (3) the role of government policy in improving economic outcomes. Some new concepts and techniques are developed, especially for studying behavior under uncertainty, and strategic interactions (game theory). The theory of each topic is accompanied by evidence, illustrations, and applications.

title: Intermediate Russian I
reviews: Any student who wants to continue their Russian should take this course.
Russian 105 is a great course, more focused on grammar than 101 and 102. If that's your strong suit, then this class will possibly be more interesting or go more smoothly.
prereqs: SLA 102/RUS 102 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: Major emphasis on the development of vocabulary and oral expression with continuing work on difficult grammar topics.

title: Synthetic Organic Chemistry
reviews: Do not fall behind. Do all assigned readings during the weeks they are assigned, and learn all named reactions early. Have pristine handwriting and artistic/drawing skills.

Great class.  You learn a lot in lectures and Professor Knowles is always willing to work with you until you understand the material. It's definitely a manageable class for undergraduates and will provide you with a comprehensive library of some of the most important and influential papers in organic chemistry.
Learn some stereochemistry before taking it
Necessary for a practicing organic chemist.
Review the class notes each week and ask questions. Also be very on top of the named reactions and the homework sets.
STUDY HARD!
Very good class, but the 7-10pm time slot alone would make me tell a student to look elsewhere.
stay on top of named reactions and readings
descrip: A mechanism-based course on organic synthesis for advanced undergraduates and beginning graduate students who wish to learn chemical synthesis of organic compounds. Course deals with various classical and modern synthetic methodologies. Particular emphasis is placed on understanding scope, limitations, and selectivity based on the mechanism, with the goal to understand fundamental principles underlying each synthetic method. The knowledge and perspective acquired in this course is expected to provide sufficient foundation to understand and use the research literature in organic synthesis.

title: Numbers, Equations, and Proofs
reviews: Even though it is not in my major and does not fulfill any requirements, I am very glad that I took MAT 214.  As long as Dr. Kaletha is teaching it, you will not regret taking this course.
I would recommend it, especially if Professor Kaletha was teaching it.

Not sure about when others teach but if Tasho is teaching DEFINITELY TAKE IT. I was scared of enrolling, because I was taking this due to an interest in but a lack of knowledge in "real" math. Turned out to be my favorite class. I don't know what else to say but that I'm so glad I took it even though it didn't go toward my department or certificates and I was in 4 technical classes.
This is the best introduction to Mathematical proofs at Princeton.
descrip: An introduction to classical number theory, to prepare for higher-level courses in the department. Topics include Pythagorean triples and sums of squares, unique factorization, Chinese remainder theorem, arithmetic of Gaussian integers, finite fields and cryptography, arithmetic functions and quadratic reciprocity. There will be a topic, chosen by the instructor, from more advanced or more applied number theory: possibilities include p-adic numbers, cryptography, and Fermat's Last Theorem. This course is suitable both for students preparing to enter the Mathematics Department and for non-majors interested in exposure to higher mathematics.

title: Junior Independent Work (B.S.E. candidates only)
prereqs: Open to qualified sophomores as well as juniors, provided they are adequately prepared. B.S.E. candidates only..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a "state-of-the-art" project in computer science. Topics may be selected from suggestions by faculty members or proposed by the student. The final choice must be approved by the faculty advisor. Refer to course web page for additional details.

title: The Russian Empire: 1672-1917
descrip: This seminar covers major topics of Russian history from the late 17th century to 1917: political cultures and the institutions of autocracy; Russia in the age of Enlightenment; Nationalism and the policy toward non-Russian nationalities; Russian Empire in comparative perspective; Church and State in Imperial Russia; Russian village before and after the emancipation of peasants; social, legal, and cultural reforms; revolutionary movement and the development of Russian political thought.

title: Comparative Literature Graduate Pedagogy Seminar
descrip: Required weekly seminar for all departmental PhD students teaching for the first time at Princeton.
