A wide range of topics is discussed, including: creating lesson plans, facilitating discussions, delivering lectures, grading papers, designing course syllabi, teaching with translations, using technology in the classroom, developing a statement of teaching philosophy, and preparing a teaching portfolio. We will also examine recent discussions of teaching in the Humanities in current issues of Profession. Course leads to partial fulfillment of the McGraw Teaching Transcript.

title: Introduction to Formal Analysis
reviews: You have to take this class.
descrip: Introduction to the primary projective systems that form the foundations of architectural representation and serve as essential tools of formal analysis and design. Coursework will be derived from a structured examination of key primary sources by Gaspard Monge, Brook Taylor and Girard Desargues.

title: Prejudice: Its Causes, Consequences, and Cures
reviews: Make sure that you're interested in this topic and material. If not, you will dread going to class. The 3 hours will feel like forever. Some interesting stuff here. Really engage and press on thee issues to make it worthwhile. Not my favorite--opt for another if you can.
Take it!
Take it! Interesting class, great professor
Take it, you'll learn something without overtaxing your brain
Take it.
Take the course, but work hard on the written assignments.
Take the opportunity to really speak with your peers.

The class is meant to be a seminar, but was very large this year and was in an auditorium, which makes discussion feel a bit awkward. 
Topics are interesting but realize that it is almost 100% about race stereotyping and not other stereotypes, and almost all focus on black/white and no other ethnicities. 
The readings are good, but class feels a little boring. I thought we would spend more time discussing the findings and applicability than nitpicking methodology and things. 
The class is not difficult or stressful, a pretty fair amount of work - just weekly readings and postings; take-home midterm and final; final project.
Overall, I do like this class, it's just not quite what I expected when I signed up. I thought I would enjoy this class a lot. Mostly I just enjoy the readings, and am quite neutral on the seminar experience.

This is a must-take for all psych majors. Dr. Sinclair is GREAT and the subject matter never gets boring or repetitive. The workload is very manageable. For non-psych majors, it may take a little extra effort as all the reading is psych articles, but it's definitely worth it.
This is very applicable and important to everyday life, definitely take it.
Totally recommend taking anything from Prof Sinclair.  She will without doubt make the topic come alive for you!
Try to participate as much as you can because it will really help you understand what you are learning.  And don't be afraid to ask questions in this course.
You will learn a lot about prejudice.
definitely take this
take it! the professor is awesome!
understand that it is a lot of reading and that you can't fall behind.
prereqs: None (PSY 252 would be helpful)..
descrip: Prejudice is one of the most contentious topics in modern American society. There is debate regarding its causes, pervasiveness, and impact. This goal of this course is to familiarize students with the psychological research relevant to these questions. We will review theoretical perspectives on prejudice to develop an understanding of its cognitive, affective, and motivational underpinnings. We will also discuss how these psychological biases relate to evaluations of, and behavior toward, members of targeted groups. In addition, research-based strategies for reducing prejudice will be discussed.

title: Fluid Dynamics
reviews: Definitely read the text. It is excellent. The lectures can be a little bit dry (even though it's a fluids course), but are more helpful if you read ahead of time. Homework and exams are definitely fair and manageable.

From what I've heard, taking this course with Professor Nosenchuck is much better and much more organized than taking it with Gigi. This course more also interesting than MAE221, in my opinion. Lectures are helpful, problem sets aren't too difficult (mostly textbook problems that are fairly straightforward). Overall, I'd rank this as one of the better classes in the department.
Good course. I recommend it to MAEs, as I think it's definitely more interesting than heat transfer. Take it!
Interesting course. Material is relevant and relates to other classes nicely.
It is required so MAEs don't have a choice but definitely do not fear this class.
It's required...try keeping up with the textbook readings. Use the tables in the appendix...
Keep on top of the readings, and don't leave the problem sets to the last minute.
Nosenchuck actually gave decent lectures. Exams were poorly worded and ambiguous. Textbook a great resource for compressible flow. Incompressible flow done sloppily
Pretty good.
Read the book!

Really dive into the material. A lot of solutions involve making assumptions that you have to know inside and out, otherwise you will just spend the semester with a superficial understanding of the course.
Required; you have no choice.
Stay on top of the reading and go to precept.
Take if you have to or have some weird interest in more complicated fluid dynamics.

Take it, take it, take it.  Go to lecture and make sure you pay attention all the time--everything Nosenchuck says is deliberate, although it sometimes seems pointless at the time.  It's amazing how much useful information is given in lecture when people are skipping or not paying attention.  Often times one or two of the hw problems cannot be solved without having gone to lecture.
if you're not MAE, don't take this course. if you are MAE, better hope it's not with nosenchuck. if he's teaching it, you will lose all interest in fluids by the end of this course.
make sure you are thorough with the material and see how it all fits together
prereqs: MAE 221 and MAE 222 or Permission Of Instructor. MAT 202 is strongly recommended as background for enrollment..
descrip: The first half of the course deals with one-dimensional compressible flows, with special emphasis on jet propulsion applications. The second half of the course deals with aerodynamics of two and three-dimensional wings and bodies, concepts of thrust, lift and drag (frictional and lift-induced). Homework will include design problems and computational examples.

title: Topics in Algebraic Geometry - Arithmetic Algebraic Geometry
prereqs: Undergraduates must obtain permission of Instructor..
descrip: This course covers current topics in Algebraic Geometry. Specific topic details provided when course is offered.

title: Fusion Plasmas & Plasma Diagnostics
reviews: Don't take this course.
Take this class, but don't expect much.
descrip: Introduction to experimental plasma physics, with emphasis on high-temperature plasmas for fusion. Requirements for fusion plasmas: confinement, beta, power and particle exhaust. Discussion of tokamak fusion and alternative magnetic and inertial confinement systems. Status of experimental understanding: what we know and how we know it. Key plasma diagnostic techniques: magnetic measurements, Langmuir probes, microwave techniques, spectroscopic techniques, electron cyclotron emission, Thomson scattering.

title: Greek Prose Authors - Lysias and the Attic Oratory
prereqs: CLG105 or CLG108.
descrip: The course will introduce the students to Attic forensic oratory of the fourth century BCE, devoting attention to issues of style and argument. The speeches of Lysias and Demosthenes will also serve as starting points for discussions of Athenian politics and society.

title: Readings in Modern Japanese I
prereqs: JPN 306 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: This course is targeted to students whose Japanese proficiency is at an advanced or superior level. In this class students will (1) learn Japanese business manners and speak and write business Japanese, and (2) discuss various issues in international relations focusing on Asian nations, using dramas, short novels and editorials. Through these activities, students will develop critical thinking skills as well as Japanese language skills.

title: Atmospheric Radiative Transfer
reviews: Ask lots of questions.
Be sure to review the equations regularly. If you get behind it will be hard to figure out where you are at the next day.
If you want to have some basic knowledge on radiative transfer, this is for sure a very good course.

It's a fine course for getting a flavor of radiative transfer (a very important subject for climate science and modeling). I am coming away from it with not a very practiced understanding of radiative transfer, but enough knowledge such that I could reference and employ important concepts if I do come across it in my research. Make sure to fully understand corrections on problem sets in preparation for the midterm in final, which might require you to talk to the professors about what you did wrong.
descrip: Structure and composition of terrestrial atmospheres. Fundamental aspects of electromagnetic radiation. Absorption and emission by atmospheric gases. Optical extinction of particles. Roles of atmospheric species in Earth's radiative energy balance. Perturbation of climate due to natural and antropogenic causes. Satellite observations of climate system.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS)
prereqs: Completion of EGR 450.
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: The Political Economy of Health Systems
descrip: This course explores the professed and unspoken goals nations pursue with their health systems and the alternative economic and administrative structures different nations use to pursue those goals. The emphasis in the course will be on the industrialized world, although some time can be allocated later in the course to approaches used in the developing countries, if students in the course desire it.

title: The World of the Middle Ages
reviews: Don't just read the assignments; try to pull key concepts from the text and apply it to discussions. Otherwise, it'll be hard to stay on top of the large volume of information that the course covers.
If you don't like the Middle Ages, don't take the course.
Relatively easy course
descrip: An introduction to medieval culture in Western Europe from the end of the classical world to ca. 1400. The course focuses on themes such as the medieval concepts of self, humanity, and God; nation-building, conquest and crusade; relations among Christians, Jews, and Moslems; literacy, heresy, and the rise of vernacular literature; gender, chivalry, and the medieval court. Material approached through various cultural forms and media; some lectures by invited guest lecturers. Seminar discussion format with some lecturing.

title: Public Finance I
descrip: This course provides a microeconomic examination of the role of government in the economy. Topics will include the theory and measurement of excess burden, optimal tax theory, the analysis of tax incidence, and an examination of the effects of taxation on behavior.

title: City of Gold: Archeology & Exhibition
descrip: http://www.princeton.edu/pub/frs

title: Catalytic Chemistry
prereqs: CHM 303.
descrip: Concepts of heterogeneous catalysis applied to chemical processes. Major industrial processes based on heterogeneous catalysis, including ammonia synthesis, partial oxidation, petroleum refining, and environmental control. The major classes of heterogeneous catalysts, such as solid acids and transition metals, and the classes of chemical reactions catalyzed by these materials. Processing conditions and reactor design are considered. Fundamentals of surface reactivity will be explored.

title: Ordinary Differential Equations
reviews:
If you're looking for actually learning how to solve a lot of different ODEs, then take the MAE version of this course. If you're looking for a more theoretical treatment, then I would still not recommend this course because it doesn't do a good job of introducing ODE theory. 

Having said this, keep in mind that this was the first semester in which the course was taught, so the course content and/or the professor might change.
It was harder than expected.
Take an engineering differential equations course or the corresponding one in the math department instead if you're more interested in learning methods for solving ODEs.
This course is extremely easy; it makes a good fifth class.  Also good for knocking out the real analysis requirement.
prereqs: MAT 217 and 218, or equivalent..
descrip: Introduction to the study of ordinary differential equations; explicit solutions, general properties of solutions, and applications. Topics include explicit solutions of some non-linear equations in two variables by separation of variables and integrating factors, explicit solution of simultaneous linear equations with constant coefficients, explicit solution of some linear equations with variable forcing term by Laplace transform methods, geometric methods (description of the phase portrait), and the fundamental existence and uniqueness theorem.

title: Advanced Drawing: The Figure
reviews: Do it!
Take it if you want a serious figure drawing class
Take it if you want to learn how to figure draw.
Take it! Kauper gives a lot of artistic freedom, while you'd still advance a lot!
Take this class only if you want to improve you rfigure drawing skills. If this is exactly what you want then this class is perfect.

The Hours of the class can be a bit daunting at first but other than that the class is very chill.  There isn't a lot of time commitment outside of class time and the class time ends up being a very relaxing chance to just draw, which is really nice.

This class is hard work and requires stamina but because I the work is done in the class there is no way to procrastinate on assignments and when you are not in class you don't have to worry about the class.  It is a hard six hours but its the least stressful class I've taken at Princeton.  Take this class if you want to have a good art foundation and if you want to draw amazingly.  Also if you need some therapeutic drawing during the day.

This is a marvelous class. If you like drawing take it! I feel like I have improved on drawing the human figure so much. And what I learned here doesn't just apply to drawing humans; it also translates to other drawn objects.
prereqs: Introductory Drawing, or Introductory Painting, or Introductory Sculpture, or Introductory Photo, or Introductory Video..
descrip: Through careful observation, this class will focus exclusively on human figure and purse the development of a strong sense of bone structure, muscle contours and light. From this perceptual foundation, students will be encouraged to develop independent points of view. Assignments will loosely revolve around themes of narrative, abstraction, expression, and conceptual strategies. Primary source material will be live models in class, but photography, video and collage may also be utilized. Study of figurative issues in contemporary art will complement the course projects.

title: Topics in 19th- and Early 20th-Century Music - Music and Film
descrip: Music and Film

title: Elementary Turkish I
reviews: Definitely. I'm so glad I took it, and also so glad that I convinced Leyla to take it with me at a party last year.
IF YOU ARE ON THE FENCE, TAKE IT.
If you are interested in Turkish, it's a great course.
If you have any desire to learn Turkish, take it here.  Even if you don't particularly want to learn Turkish, you probably will by the end of the course.
If you like learning languages or need a language and don't want to stress over it, I can almost guarantee you'll enjoy this class.

Take it! It's a lot of fun, especially if your class is on the  small side, and no matter what your strong suit is in terms of language (e.g. writing, speaking), you will get good at all aspects of the language.
prereqs: No credit is given for TUR 101 unless it is followed by TUR 102..
descrip: A performance-oriented, multi-media introductory course in modern spoken and written Turkish. Based on authentic input, grammatical properties of the language are introduced. Cultural aspects are stressed throughout. Language skills are developed through communicative activities in class and individualized work with interactive digitized learning aids.

title: Industrial Organization and Public Policy
descrip: Methods for empirical and theoretical analysis of markets composed of productive enterprises and their customers are studied. Analyses are applied to modern market structures and practices, and public policy towards them. Topics include the roles of technology and information, the structure of firms, modes of interfirm competition, determination of price, quality, and R & D investment, and criteria for government intervention.

title: Projects in Instrumental Performance - Chamber Music
prereqs: Enrollment by application and audition. Auditions will be held on Tuesday, November 17, 2009, 6:00 - 9:00 p.m. in Room 105, Woolworth Center. (Sign up sheet is on the Bulletin Board near Room 101 Woolworth.) Contact Gregory D. Smith (609) 258-6078 or gsmith@princeton.edu for further details..
descrip: Instrumental chamber music class of the standard repertory of the 18th, 19th, and 20th centuries. Preparation for performance of ensembles. Each ensemble's repertoire will be determined in consultation with the instructors during the first week of classes.

title: Computing for the Physical and Social Sciences
reviews: An easier choice if you are pursuing the COS certificate.
Book not really necessary. Preceptors not at all helpful. Lecture slides all you need. Would not recommend.

Boring.  This class is really boring.  On the other hand, all the information is interesting, it just doesn't lend itself to exciting lectures.  You code in MATLAB (the horror!  the horror!) but you get the hang of it quickly.  The class is easy and the tests are mainly regurgitating material that was said in lecture.  Take it as a 5th class.
Decent course to take for COS certificate. I wouldn't recommend taking it for fun.

Don't do it, unless you have to. If you're a certificate student, do COS 226 and COS 217. Matlab is awfully tedious and painful. The number of people in the class drops dramatically after the midterm, which means either pdfs, or drops. Note, this review is someone who expects an A, minimum of B
Don't take it unless you need it.  It's not very fun.
Don't take it. If you're interested in data modeling, consider COS 424 instead.
Don't. Maybe they'll get their act together soon, but for now the class is an unpolished disaster.
Good departmental course and for those looking to gain experience in MATLAB.
I dunno.  Be sure you know what you're signing up for.  It may or may not appeal to you.
I liked the class a lot. It's a good class to improve Matlab skills and the techniques learned are also important/interesting.
I would recommend this course to a student looking for an class that doesnt involve much thinking
I would take this but be prepared to learn the stuff on your own. The assignments are a bit arbitrarily evaluated, so be tediously meticulous.

If you want to take this class, wait. It has been changing from lecturer to lecturer and needs to be given time to become more organized and established, but it definitely has potential to be a good class.
Interesting course, very useful for engineers (and very interesting for engineers). But make sure you really want to take it. If it doesn't seem like it's for you, don't
It is a bit dry and useful to the few who actually need to use the concepts in actual computations.

It is very heavy in math, so be prepared for that.  It is a good class, but you have to put in the effort to learn MatLab on your own.  Also, realize that expectations are not very clear, so you may have to spend some time at office hours.  Still, the material is interesting and a lot of the applications are fun.

It should be called "Computing for Physical and Biological Sciences" - not much social science going on here.

All the assignments are based on matlab
It's not an interesting course, and it's not an easy departmental as it once was rumored to be.
Keep up to date on the material.
Learn how to program beforehand.
Look to other departmentals.
No. Just don't do it. It's not worth it. Worst experience of my life.
Take good notes in class and go to review sessions.
Take it if you want to learn MATLAB and are interested in learning various coding applications.
Take it.

Take the course if you are interested in applying what you learn to other fields. Take a look at the previous year's syllabus to get an idea. Data modeling, simulation, least squares, PDEs, etc. are very important to data analysis and modeling.
Take this course if you are self-motivated and have a person who you know you can work well with on programming assignments in the class.
The lectures and lecture notes are important.

The material in the course was very good. The organization, however, was very poor. Neither the professor nor the preceptors took responsibility for getting our assignments returned to us in a timely fashion. Oftentimes expectations were not at all clear, and the preceptors did not know what we were being asked to do on assignments, so their input and the eventual grades would not match. The preceptors also did not attend lecture, and so could not help with the material. 

I thought the final exam was not very good: it tested derivations of algorithms rather than their qualities, uses, or applications. There were only 5 questions which did not cover most of the material on the course. I felt like I didn't get to demonstrate my understanding of the material, and my grade will be mostly based on luck. 

Finally, coordinating a group project over winter break made my "vacation" work-intensive and stressful.

The material taught in this course is very interesting, however, it is not as application-focused as one might think from the course description. I would still recommend taking it, if you want to learn computational techniques that could be useful in the sciences.

This course is an introduction to how numerical computing could be used in different academic areas (biology, physics etc).
The course is a bit disorganized, and we go over a lot of high level mathematics which you don't even need to understand/know for the course.
Unless you're interested in mathematical tools, this class is boring. However, it does teach you how to use these tools and how to program in Matlab.
Yes
You should take it.

dont take it.. seems easy at first, but gets hard and hits you with a lot of work at the worst times.  assignments are extremely vague and you can't understand what to do until everyone asks a million questions on piazza
get a good group for the final project and start the programming assignments early
it's pretty useful albeit a little boring. Szymon has dry humor which is nice.
take if you dig random math algorithms
this course is not as easy as you may have heard
prereqs: COS 126 or equivalent and MAT 104..
descrip: Principles of scientific computation, driven by current applications in biology, physics, economics, engineering, etc. Topics include: simulation, integration of ordinary and partial differential equations, iterative optimization algorithms, stability and accuracy issues. Students will pursue projects in a variety of fields, writing their own computer programs and also using higher-level tools such as Matlab.

title: Optics and Lasers
reviews: A strong background in optics quantum mechanics is very useful.
Buy one or two textbooks and read them parallel with the course.
If you would like to know the fundamentals of lasers and its application, this is the best choice.
Stay up with the material, because there is a lot of it every class. Take the time to
The course moves pretty fast but Prof. Miles seems really interested in helping you learn the material.
Try to ask questions in class to slow the professor down.
descrip: An introduction to principles of lasers. Topics include propagation theory, interaction of light and matter, Fourier optics, and a description of operational characteristics of lasers, light scattering, and nonlinear optics.

title: Portuguese Language and Culture through Cinema
prereqs: POR 208 or instructor's permission..
descrip: This course will examine a number of recurring cultural topics in Portuguese-language cinema from Africa, Brazil and Europe, such as personal transformations of characters against the backdrop of political turmoil, unusual representations of urban spaces and movement between centers and peripheries. We will situate works within their socio-historical context, explore linguistic regionalisms and registers and analyze cinematography and the process of literary adaptation. Discussions, readings, vocabulary exercises and papers will further increase students' fluency in written and spoken Portuguese.

title: Econometric Theory I
reviews: If you have note seen the material before, do your best to stay on top of the lectures and, if possible, read ahead.

Since this is a required course for graduate students, I have no recommendation to offer. Also, undergraduates who wish to demonstrate motivation to graduate schools will probably end up taking it anyway.
Take time to read a bit Bayesian Statistics before taking this subject. Also if you have time try also to read Hayashi's textbook .
This was a pretty accessible class. The first half is a lot of review of probability/undergrad metrics stuff. The second half can get into some more complicated matrix algebra at times.
descrip: A first-year course in the first-year econometrics sequence: it is divided into two parts. The first gives students the necessary background in probability theory and statistics. Topics include definitions and axioms of probability, moments, some univariate distributions, the multivariate normal distribution, sampling distributions, introduction to asymptotic theory, estimation and testing. The second part introduces the linear regression model and develops associated tools. Properties of the ordinary least squares estimator will be studied in detail and a number of tests developed.

title: Readings in Chinese Literature
descrip: Genre and Tradition in Early Medieval China: An analysis of the formation and canonization of the Chinese literary tradition from the perspective of the origin and development of genre classification. In addition to the major works of genre taxonomies (Wenxuan, Wenxin diaolong, lost anthologies, library catalogues), readings include early medieval essays, letters, poems, prefaces, etc. that implicitly or explicitly reveal the distinction of genres in the practice of literary writing, criticism, and history. Functional knowledge of classical and modern Chinese is required.

title: Policy Workshop - Implementation of the Affordable Care Act
descrip: President Obama signed health reform into law in March 2010. The Patient Protection & Affordable Care Act is an unprecedented joint federal-state initiative, with provisions to expand health insurance coverage, control costs, and improve the delivery system. This workshop will have as its client one of the states participating in the State Health Reform Assistance Network. We will study federal regulatory process, expansion of Medicaid, development of health insurance exchanges, legal challenges, & Congressional oversight efforts. We will examine implementation through a few states? unique political and operational environments.

title: Studies in Islamic Religion and Thought
descrip: This course focuses on reading texts that are illustrative of various issues in Muslim religious thought. The texts are selected according to students' needs.

title: Senior Independent Work (B.S.E. candidates only)
prereqs: Open to qualified juniors as well as seniors, provided they are adequately prepared. B.S.E. candidates only..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a "state-of-the-art" project in computer science. Topics may be selected from suggestions by faculty members or proposed by the student. The final choice must be approved by the faculty advisor.

title: Journeys in Portuguese: Studies in Language and Culture
reviews: Definitely take it. The writing assignments will really help you improve your language skills. The topics covered in the course are interesting enough to encourage real classroom discussion.

If you're looking to continue learning Portuguese and strengthen your writing as well as develop your analysis and speaking skills, then definitely take this class. While the workload isn't light, Nicola is very understanding if you ever need an extension, and the amount of work is worth it in terms of improving your understanding of the language. Class is always entertaining and you get to have thought-provoking discussions while learning a lot about the Lusophone world.
Pick your poison...if you do not have time to do all the work, maybe watch segments of the movie. Dont stress yourself out trying to do every little assignment for every class.
Take it!!
Take this course. Professor Cooney is truly an amazing professor.
Write about interesting things and you'll be fine.
You may well enjoy this course?but if you're looking to improve your Portuguese grammar specifically, it's not a great option.
prereqs: POR 109 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Designed as a journey through the Lusophone world this course seeks to present the Portuguese language in context by exploring historical, social, political and cultural aspects of Brasil, Portugal, and Lusophone Africa through the media, literature, film, music and other realia. Students will increase their fluency and accuracy in both written and spoken Portuguese, broadening their vocabulary and mastery of syntax through textual analysis, discussions, oral presentations and grammar review. An advanced language course and overview of the Lusophone world, POR 208 seeks to prepare students for further study of literature and culture.

title: German Intellectual History - Literature, the Sciences, & Philosophy: Leibniz to Goethe
reviews: Although a lot of great source material, lectures where often disoriented and confusing. It was difficult to know how to do the reading to prepare because of the disjointed nature of the lectures.

As someone with a very minimal background in philosophy, I felt I was missing a lot of knowledge in terms of historical contexts, which would have been helpful in gaining a deeper understanding of much of the course material.  However, the course served my purpose of fulfilling a distribution requirement,.
If you want an easy EC, this might be it. If you want an engaging EC, this might not be.

If you're really interested in the material, then you'd enjoy this course. You will especially got a lot out of it if you do independent study, and are really engaged. A lot of that engagement will have to come from your own initiative.
Professor Frey is an excellent teacher, and any class she teaches is worth taking!

Professor Frey is exceedingly helpful and the topic is rather interesting. That said, I would not recommend this class (yet) because I frequently found that expectations were unclear (and parts of it could be better organised).
Read the readings before the course starts. Look for essay ideas while you read -- don't wait until you need to write the paper.
Start your papers early and get feedback from your preceptor.  Concentrate on the texts that interest you, rather than trying to cram every bit of reading from each week in.
Take it if you're very interested in the subject matter and don't mind a slightly dull lecturing style (but interesting content!). Get into a good precept.
Take it!
Take it: you'll get an excellent overview of the history of ideas that are so important for us today that we might be taking them for granted without the familiarity with their development.
Take this course only if you're extremely interested in the subject matter and readings. Be prepared for disorganized lectures.
Take this course!

Take this course. Professor Frey is an excellent lecturer, the readings are fascinating, and the course offers an intriguing challenge to common historical narratives. If the subject sounds like something interesting to you, then you will definitely get a lot out of it.

This has the potential to completely change the way to think about the relationship between the Sciences and the Humanities. This is a distinction that is very much taken for granted today, but probably deserves a lot more critical attention that it is given. I would recommend science students especially to take this course so as to get a better grasp of the history of their disciplines.
This is a fun, engaging course with not too heavy of a work load.
This is a very good class to take if you're interested in early-modern European thought.
You need a strong interest to enjoy the course, but you will if you do.
prereqs: None..
descrip: How did the sciences, philosophy, and literature engage with one another on the way to becoming the discrete pursuits they are today? The course approaches this question by tracing a series of entanglements that challenge our sense of what knowledge is. We will explore why Bacon wrote a novel to promote his scientific method; how Leibniz's philosophy was shaped by the microscope and romances; how the modern novel aligns with statistics. We will retrace the birth of "aesthetics," investigate Goethe's scientific affinities, and discuss how the romantic concept of science questions our idea of the humanities and the sciences as "two cultures."

title: Roberto Bolano: Adventures in Culture Land
descrip: Forty years after the emergence of Gabriel Garcia Marquez, the narrative works of Roberto Bolano have once again put Latin American literature at the center of the world's cultural mainstream. Within epics of travel, adventure and youth culture, he combined literary traditions that until then seemed incompatible. This course will explore the fictional world, the poetics, and the artistic strategies of an author that made Jim Morrison dialogue with James Joyce, who resuscitated the myth of the Latin American avant-gardes, and who in less than ten years went from being an anonymous eccentric to a New York Times bestseller.

title: Climate: Past, Present, and Future
reviews: Do all the reading and pay attention from the start.
Don't do it. No if's, and's, or but's. Don't. Do it.
Interesting class, enthusiastic and engaged professors, perhaps more work than other 100-level courses.
It's a fun, relatively easy course but its extremely useful in understanding the news and the world around you.
Prepare for a lot more work than is typically expected from a 100 level class and keep up with all the material. Don't fall behind.
Review your notes at the end of the week and summarize salient points.
Take the lab, and try not to fall asleep in lecture!
The best outcome of me taking this class is that it made me realize I do not want to major in geosciences or take any more classes in the department.
prereqs: High School Calculus.
descrip: An introduction to the processes and conditions that control Earth's climate; an overview of past climate evolution from the time of Earth's origin to the period of human history; and an investigation of ongoing climate changes and those predicted for the future, including the capacity of human activities to alter climate and the impacts of climate change on environment and society. Intended primarily for students not concentrating in science or engineering.

title: Responsible Conduct in Research: A Course on Ethics in Engineering (Half-term)
prereqs: This course is required for graduate students in engineering who participate in federally funded research; the course is highly recommended and/or required for undergraduate students as well as post-doctoral researchers in engineering who participate in federally funded research. There are no prerequisites for attending the course..
descrip: This course educates the graduate student of engineering in the responsible conduct of research. The lectures provide theoretical background information as well as case studies about ethics in day-to-day research situations, in publishing and peer-review, in student-advisor relationships, in collaborative research, as well as in the big picture and considerations of long-term impact. The students are provided with resources to consult in ethical questions. In small-group discussions in research field-specific precepts, the theoretical concepts are made relevant to the individual students situations.

title: Music and Power
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Water, Savannas, and Society: Global Change and Sustainability in Africa's Hallmark Ecosystem
reviews: Familiarize yourself with GIS models and the R program before taking this class.
I liked this course a lot. It's an interesting view on a little-studied topic.
Really great guest lectures and if you have a strong interest in the region, you can really learn a lot!  The class is somewhat unorganized and it is sometimes unclear what is expected of you.
The material is very interesting
prereqs: Assignments will entail some analytical work involving geographic information systems and statistics..
descrip: Savannas have played an important role in shaping human societies, including our evolution as a species. That role will grow, as savannas must be increasingly harnessed to meet growing demands for food, fuel, and fiber. Starting with a primer on savanna ecology, this course will examine the ecological and societal issues surrounding our use of African savannas. A key focus will be to explore tradeoffs between agricultural development, ecosystem services (e.g. carbon storage), biodiversity, and existing livelihoods, how those tradeoffs can be optimized to achieve sustainability, and how climate change will complicate such efforts.

title: Energy Solutions for the Next Century
reviews:
A certain background in chemistry and maybe thermodynamics would be helpful. The course is not entirely recommendable for non-science majors and I would at least recommend to have taken a small number of other science courses before. Those who enter the course without prior knowledge will be able to follow - but it is a significant challenge to do very well (mainly when it comes to the midterm, and partly when it comes to the problem sets).
After all, however, it is worth keeping in mind that the course treats one of the future's most important questions - how are our societies going to deal with their energy demand?
A good intro to current and new forms of energy but the material is approached in a very straightforward and dry manner

Come prepared for precept if you want to get the most out of the class. Ask questions if you don't understand a major energy topic. Most people have a lot of preconceived notions about certain energy issues, so speak up if there is something new or confusing to you as it is probably the same for other people without a background in energy courses. This is a great class that should not scare you away if you are not an engineer.
Great overview of the energy industry - take it if you want to learn about the different fields of energy.
I would reccomend that the student have a basic engineering background before taking the course.
If you like the subject matter, it's definitely worth taking. Lectures can be a bit boring, but it's a fairly straightforward and easy class.

Take it, especially if you want to have a basic knowledge of the energy situation today. Stay on top of the material for the midterm, and prepare in advance for the final presentation. Take it with at least one or two friends.
this course is fairly easy and a good intro to various types of energy, problems, solutions, etc.
prereqs: This course is offered for both engineering and non-engineering students. (Calculus or Thermodynamics are NOT requirements)..
descrip: This course will deal with issues of regional and global energy demands, sources, carriers, storage, current and future technologies and costs for energy conversion, and their impact on climate and the environment. Students will learn to perform objective cost-efficiency and environmental impact analyses from source to end-user on both fossil fuels (oil, coal, and natural gas), and alternative energy sources (bio-fuels, solar energy, wind, batteries, and nuclear). We will also pay particular attention to energy sources, technologies, emissions, and regulations for transportation. The course will also include tours to energy research labs.

title: Fluid Mechanics
reviews: I would strongly recommend this course to anyone interested in reading about fluids.
Prepare yourself beyond what you think for the oral final. Practice with others.

Try and find some worked examples somewhere to assist with review.

Prepare carefully for the final oral exam.  This will require a lot of time.  Focus on getting the basics right.
descrip: An introduction to fluid mechanics. The course explores the development of basic conservation laws in integral and differential form; one-dimensional compressible flows, shocks and expansion waves; effects of energy addition and friction; unsteady and two-dimensional flows and method of characteristics. Reviews classical incompressible flow concepts, including vorticity, circulation, and potential flows. Introduces viscous and diffusive phenomena.

title: Polymer Rheology
descrip: A systematic development of the principles and applications of the science of rheology with an emphasis on the development of stress-velocity constitutive equations. Vector and tensor mathematics and Newtonian fluid dynamics are reviewed. Develops the physical and mathematical nature of stress and deformations in materials. Covers the use of theory and application of rheological equations of state. Advanced multiphysics software is used to model flows of non-Newtonian fluids. Open to undergraduates.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Behavioral Economics
prereqs: Prerequisites: WWS511c or d; WWS512c; WWS593c..
descrip: This course will explore how economics has recently incorporated a number of insights and findings from psychology and experiments, and examine some of the implications that follow for the workings of markets and policy. Topics will include: 1) Imperfect self-control, present bias; 2) Fairness and reciprocity; 3) Intrinsic/extrinsic motivation, signaling concerns; 4) Wishful thinking, overconfidence, anticipation; 5) Reference dependence, loss aversion, prospect theory, framing; 6) Malleable preferences, hedonic forecasting; 7) Bounded rationality, inattention.

title: Topics in Prose Fiction - Kafka
reviews: Make sure you leave enough time to do the readings. Since the course requires all student input, if you don't read the material the course will be very boring.
Take it!! Kafka is amazing, although totally bizarre.  Discussion is difficult if your German isn't great.
Take this course, and be sure to participate and read the material. It's fantastic writing, so reading it should be enjoyable albeit challenging.

This course is probably one of the harder courses in the German department in terms of its demands on self-preparation. Kafka can be especially hard to interpret, and even more so in German. I think if one wants to understand Kafka, make sure one gets the stories (either re-reading or parallel read), so that he can save the pain of trying to understand anything. But take this course anyway, because it is the only course on Kafka, and Kafka's one of the biggest name of 20th century literature.
prereqs: The course is taught in German..
descrip: An in-depth engagement with one of the canonical writers of modern literature. We will read our way slowly and carefully through a good part of Kafka's oeuvre, posing questions in the process about the relationship between literature and the life of the writer, the role of theology in modernity, the nature of law and judgment, and the affinity of architecture to text. Course will be taught in German.

title: Screenwriting I: Screenwriting as a Visual Medium
reviews: Don't be intimidated if you haven't written screenplay before. I applied to the course with a modified stage play, and I did not feel behind. Regardless of your background, don't miss the opportunity to take this wonderful course.
Recommend for students with a vested or passing interest.
Recommend unequivocally.
TAKE IT. SO fun, interesting, and Ms. Lazaridi's the greatest.
Take it, even if you've never done screenwriting. You will learn a lot about writing and plot.
Take it. ABSOLUTELY TAKE a course with Professor Lazaridi.
Take the course.  It is a great experience, and Professor Lazaridi is truly wonderful to work with.
Take this course.
prereqs: Interested students complete a creativing writing application (please visit the program website) by attaching a statement about why they would like to take the course. Please note this course cannot be audited..
descrip: The course will introduce students to basic screenwriting principals and techniques, using cross-cultural and cross-temporal examples. Course will examine the visual power of storytelling in film and other relative media, concentrating on the strategic use of visual elements to create a unified viewing experience and the use of visual moments/behavior in creating memorable characters. Students will complete the course with a strong working sense of the core elements used in visual storytelling as applied in film, tv, or new media. Final portfolio will include one silent short film and two narrative shorts.

title: Continuum Mechanics
descrip: Course covers 1) Introduction: the continuous medium; essential mathematics-scalars, vectors, tensors, indicial notations, transformations. 2) Basics: stress, strain and deformation; components, principal axes, tensors; 2D and 3D cases. 3) General principles: conservation of mass, continuity equation, momentum principal, motion and equilibrium, energy balance, constitutive equations: needs and axioms; ideal materials, elasticity, isotropy, plasticity, viscoelasticity and thermoelasticity. and 4) Applications: theory of elasticity, fluid mechanics.

title: Modern Control
reviews: Definitely take this course if you're interested in control theory. It compliments MAE433 well; for me, it was cool to see how learn the general solutions and theory behind what we saw in MAE433. Professor Leonard is a great professor, you'll love her.
Good course for getting an understanding of the mathematical foundation of control theory. However, this is also no math class.
If you liked 433, take this.

It's a great course to take if you've enjoyed prior course(s?) in control theory. It formalizes and re-emphasizes concepts you learned in 433 (especially the theory), and teaches you about different ways to evaluate a system. Workload isn't intense.
Professor is great but be prepared for some theory and proofs. Cemented by knowledge of control systems from 433.

The aim of this course as taught by Prof. Leonard is to expand on the subject matter of 433 by delving into mathematically rigorous justification for the techniques used.  You learn an additional design method or two, but you do gain a better understanding of methods from 433.  After the first week of class, I thought this would be my least favorite class of the semester based on the subject matter.  It turned out to be my favorite.  Take this course if you are interested in controls or like math.
This is an interesting, more rigorous look at the state space concepts covered in 433. I recommend it if you are interested in controls.
prereqs: MAE 206, MAE 305, and MAE 433.
descrip: This course provides an introduction to modern state-space methods for robust control system design and analysis. Applications include controlling the performance of a variety of dynamical systems. Topics include stability, controllability and observability, state feedback control, observers and output feedback control, linear matrix inequalities, and optimal and robust control design methods.

title: Research in Architecture
reviews: The proseminar format allows for an interesting form of collective research, with each session building upon the last. The flexibility and potential for following worthwhile leads in real time is a valuable opportunity.
descrip: This advanced pro-seminar explores architectural research techniques through collaborative investigation of a specific issue facing the field. Rather than study research methods in the abstract, students are asked to actively carry out detailed research in teams and reflect upon its limits and potentials. The research project of each semester is carried through to realization in the form of a book, a conference, or an exhibition organized by the students in subsequent semesters.

title: Domestic Politics
descrip: An introduction to the political analysis of policy making in the American setting. The course includes theoretical and empirical analyses of political institutions, including executives, legislatures, and bureaucracies. It also examines the political environment in which these institutions operate, with special attention given to the role of public opinion, interest groups, and elections.

title: Policy Workshop - Climate Change: Methane Mitigation Strategies
descrip: This workshop will identify cost-effective domestic and international methane emission reduction strategies, policies and funding mechanisms to inform current efforts to substantially reduce global methane emissions over the next ten years. Examples of mitigation strategies to be examined include: reduction of leakage from methane extraction via hydrofracking and leaking gas transmission lines, reductions of methane emissions from rice paddies and cows, recovery of methane from coal mining, landfills, etc.

title: Financial Investments
reviews: A very good course to build foundation in finance.
An excellent class. A fair amount of work, great support from the preceptors, and truly interesting material.
Choose the course if Hong is teaching it.
Concentrate on practice exams and less on lecture slides when preparing for the exams.
Definitely take this course! Important to get a glimpse into how the investment world works.
Do extra readings and practice more.
Do practice problems on your own. Study from old exams.
Do the practice exams before the exams. They help a lot.

Don't take this class unless you really have to.  If you're interested in the material, give the book a read-over.  ORF 335 does a really good job of teaching the portion on option pricing and Black Scholes.  The CAPM part wasn't really well taught anyways so better to self-study.
Don't unless you have to.
Easier than it sounds.

Exams are designed to break you (at least a little). Professor and preceptors are decent. More work than I would have wanted from a class I took purely out of interest (I took it for the finance certificate), but it covered a good deal of ground and was never unreasonable.
Go to lectures and learn the math.
Good as an intro finance course.
Good course, not too difficult (problem sets are short and gone over in precept). Tests can be tricky, but have a generous curve. Hong is a really smart guy. Take it!
Good intro to finance.
Helpful financial overview, and helpful course to take
Highly recommended for people out of finance who'd like to learn the basics.
I liked it.  Boring sometimes.  Worthwhile.  I just regret not keeping up with problem sets and not going to precept enough (precept is very useful in this class).
I recommend this course to any student slightly interested in finance.
I would advice students to really spend a lot of time completing problems on practice midterms and practice finals.
I would strongly recommend this course to anyone who has keen interest in derivatives and the basic understanding of the Financial Markets.
I wouldn't recommend this course for graduate students. For undergrads I think it is a good take
If you don't have to, don't take it.
If you're interested in finance and willing to put in some studying, this is a good class to take. Lectures and the book are stellar.
It is a difficult course but worthwhile and interesting
It's a good, useful course. Not super easy, but not too difficult if you can do some pretty simple math.
It's just not a very well taught class. Would only recommend taking if you have to for the Finance certificate.
It's not very rigorous, from a mathematical standpoint. But it's fairly accessible and definitely a course you should take if you're interested in finance.
Make sure you go to precepts and if you are having trouble, go to office hours. The preceptors are very open to helping you, which is a plus.
Material is very interesting if you're keen on finance, but the execution was much less impressive.
Not too hard of a class overall except for the exams.
Nothing in particular.
Only take if you have to.
Only take this course if you have to. A very poorly done intro to financial investments where little effort is put into educating the students who take it.
Problem sets and past finals are really important for review in this class, as the lectures contains many things not on the exam that could be quite hard to understand.

Professor Hong usually teaches this course every year; he is a rude (and almost immature) professor. The lead preceptor this year (Matt Baron) was very helpful and friendly though. The material was dry but easy. The exams were a bit tough but everyone does bad on them, so it doesn't matter. Overall, you probably *have to* take this course anyway since it's a core component of the finance certificate. Just study lots for the midterm & final, and you will be fine!
Take if you are interested.
Take if you're interested in finance!
Take it for sure! With Hong, this course is great because you learn fundamental theory and also learn the problems with it.

Take it if you are interested in finance or if you want the certificate badly. If you don't I would stay away, as Hong talks about things you won't understand without a lot of unguided studying outside of class. If you're really smart and good at math, it might not be too bad if you can memorize finance jargon.
Take it if you really want the finance certificate, otherwise stay away.
Take it only if you really like finance and are doing the certificate.  Otherwise don't, unless you like tedious math and need an A.
Take this class if you want, but realize that the lectures don't help with the exams and the exams are difficult with a very low average.
Take this class.   Very interesting material and well taught.
Take this course if you are interested in finance.
The class is interesting, but the exams are quite hard.
The course provides useful knowledge about stocks, bonds and other assets as well as their pricing.
This course is probably too elementary if you have previous finance exposure/experience. But if you don't, it's a good first course in finance.
This is a good course if you are interested in learning the basics about financial investments.
Try and understand each topic as you go along ... it helps to focus on being able to answer harder questions that come up in the final.
Well, you probably have to take it. But if you are interested in the material, it is definitely worth it.
Worth it. Though don't expect to be taught how to do the problems!

You sort of have to take it for the Finance certificate. Lecture is sort of useless. Half of the class has already seen this material before. It'll be an uphill climb if you are new to finance, but it's doable.

You're going to take it because you want the finance certificate, but it's going to be horrible - frustrating for all of the wrong reasons.  While Hong is a good lecturer and the material is interesting (although many even disagree on these points), problem sets that are unrelated to the material and unfair exams will leave you furious.  There is no where to go for help if you need it - the textbook is absolutely unrelated and impossibly long and dense, the preceptors (or at least mine) didn't speak English, and the lecture slides are illegible and disorganized.  As an econ major who got an A  in 310, this course is hard not because of  the material but because  it so horribly run and structured and that is extremely frustrating.
a very helpful class
boring, not a bad workload, but really boring
do practice exams over and over again.
do the homeworks as requested. they are useful in order to understand the concepts from the lectures. also refer to the book.
don't take it unless you have to
interesting intro to finance, definitely worth it
take it if you want to understand jargons.
take it if you're looking to go into a career in finance or just want a basic idea of how investing works
take this course if you're interested in finance, just be prepared for tough exams.
prereqs: MAT 200, ECO 202 and ECO 310. Course not required for concentrators..
descrip: This course surveys the field of investments with special emphasis on the valuation of financial assets. Issues studied include how portfolios of assets should be formed, how to measure and control risk, how to evaluate investment performance and how to test alternative investment strategies and asset pricing models.

title: Research Seminar
reviews: Mandatory element for graduation requirements.
N/A
it is a good choice to take it
descrip: A continuation of CEE 509. Each student carries out research, writes a report and presents the research results. Doctoral candidates must complete this course one semester prior to taking the general examination. Grading of the course will be 25% oral presentation and 75% submitted work.

title: Causes of War
reviews: Absolutely take it. Great introduction to international relations. It will teach you to look at the world and state relations that we hear about on a daily basis with a critical eye. In an age of terrorism, nuclear weapons and the decline of the U.S., this is stuff we should all be thinking about.
Absolutely take this class. Regardless of major.
Absolutely take this course. Do all the readings.

An incredible course. It's not easy -- tons of reading -- but Professor Bass is a world-class lecturer. Two notes: 1) Try splitting the readings with a (trusted) friend if (let's be honest, when) you find yourself unable to complete the readings 2) If you can, avoid Professor Bass as a preceptor. If Richard Jordan is still precepting, definitely make his precept your top choice.
Bass is a boss professor who owns every lecture. Get a study group to split up the huge amount of readings.
Definitely take it!
Do it!

Excellent course.  Not sure I learned a lot about war, particularly since I had learned lots about these theories in other classes, but the historical background and Bass's lectures were enough to make this class worth while.
Go to lecture, because Professor Bass is one of the best lecturers I've had yet.
Go to lectures. Gary Bass rocks.
Great class but be prepared to do a lot of reading, which is not optional since precept participation is a fourth of your grade.
I highly recommend this course for anyone with IR interests. Bass has pretty much changed the direction of my career from what was probably going to be finance to now considering a job in DC.
I wish I could take this course again. And again.

If you are looking for a fantastic and engaging course that will challenge your assumptions about wars and US foreign policy, this is the course. Don't fear the high number 388. I'm an engineer and an athlete and I was fine with never taking a course on politics before 388. All you have to do is be interested, which isn't hard with Prof. Bass.
If you have any interest in war or foreign relations, take the course. Or just take it because Prof. Bass is incredible.
Prepare to read a lot and have your mind blown on a weekly basis.
Shop precepts, it changes the entire experience of the course.
Super interesting and worthwhile. Great lecturer and pertinent material.
TAKE IT! The course is exciting and Prof. Bass is hilarious.
Take it
Take it no matter your major, can be tough but worth it... Bass's lectures alone make it worth it
Take it take it
Take it! Gary Bass is a stud, lecture quality is amazing, subject material is excellent and lectures are at a convenient afternoon hour.
Take it! You'll learn a lot and be very stimulated by the process.
Take it, attend lecture, do the readings, and you will do well.  Not a joke class, but not a constant stress.  Totally worth the work you need to put in.
Take it.
Take it.  Gary Bass is phenomenal.
Take this class. Very interesting, great professor and reasonable assignments.

Take this course instead of POL 240. Many of the same themes are covered, although this course moves at a faster pace and has a specific focus on war. That said, Bass is a great lecturer and a pretty funny guy.
Take this course. It's one you will remember. Bass is one of the best professors I've ever had and I wish I had had class with him before my senior year.

The course is a very effective introduction to the subject. The readings are a good mix of political science literature, some popular press, plus a few must-read classics (Thucydides, Kant), and Prof. Bass is a gifted lecturer who conveys facts and concepts particularly well.

This class is a lot of work and is very reading-heavy. I also felt like many of the other students in the course had a lot of background in the subject, so perhaps it's best to take this as an upperclassmen.
While difficult the course is extremely rewarding.
stay up to date on your readings and read the NY times!
descrip: Why do states and peoples go to war? Conversely, how can war be avoided? This course surveys some of the most important explanations--including human nature, the anarchic international system, domestic politics, economics, technology, nationalism and terrorism--and evaluates them in light of historical wars, and of crises resolved short of war. Cases include the Peloponnesian War, the Napoleonic Wars, World War I, World War II, the Cuban missile crisis, ex-Yugoslavia's wars, and September 11.

title: Violent Politics
reviews: A good course- be prepared for a lot of reading, but a really valuable experience for anyone in the social science.
A ton of readings, a good course, but prepared to split them with other people if you don't want to fall behind.
Be ready for heavy reading, but fascinating material

Definitely keep up with the readings, and if you understand logic well, then this is your course. If you have problems with logic, then don't, it can get very complicated very quickly, and isn't always explained in the best way.  It's a class entirely based on theories, and not case studies, so take that into consideration.
Definitely take this class if you're looking for an interesting politics course. You'll learn a lot and get pushed to perform your best.
Don't take if taught by Shapiro.
Find a reading group and leverage precept discussions in your papers.
Good departmental
Great course and awesome preceptor.

I thought this would be one of my favorite classes, but unfortunately it wasn't the case. Though not the worst course I've had at Princeton, there was much to be desired. If you are interested in the material, I would suggest taking the class, but know that what you are tested on may not accurately reflect your knowledge of the material.
It's an alright class, but it's not really about politics or violent politics; it is a methods course about experiments and counterfactuals.
It's an interesting topic, but poorly taught.
One of the best classes I have taken at Princeton.
Take it!!
Take it, but be prepared to put in if you expect to get anything out.

Take this class, especially if you're at all interested in the subject matter!  The material is super interesting and there's relatively not that much work compared to other Politics courses.  To do well, attend lecture, take notes of everything that Professor Shapiro says, and annotate all of the readings.  Do that and you'll be fine.
The course is a lot of work and not a lot of reward. The subject matter is interesting, just not presented in the best way.
The course is intimidating if you are shy because Professor Shapiro expects you to participate in lecture as part of your grade. While the material is interesting, beware the participation.
There is a lot of reading, but the course is worth it.

This class is very frustrating--the midterm and the final focus on research methods and counterfactuals rather than on violent politics.  If you like those things, you'll enjoy this class.  If not, I'd take something else.

This class should be called Research Methods in Political Science Through the Lense of Violent Politics.  The readings are all about violent politics, but the tests are all about the research methods used in those readings. There is lots of reading.  Good luck!

This class was relatively difficult. It focuses on the analytical approach to politics and really gets into experimental design. Without the help of my great preceptor this class would have been incredibly confusing and difficult.
Try to make an outline of the readings and what the author is arguing...what evidence he's citing...it's hard, but would have been helpful had i done this.

Unless the course is structured differently in the future, I'd only recommend taking it for Prof. Shapiro's lectures. Otherwise just get the syllabus from a friend and do the readings - it'll be interesting and help with other courses.
prereqs: Freshman and sophomores may enroll with permission of the instructor..
descrip: Governments have tremendous power over our lives and thus the competition over who controls them is always intense and often violent. This course will study various ways in which violence is used to political ends. The larger goal of the course is to understand the sources of violence in political competition and the conditions under which political disputes can be peacefully resolved. Specific forms of violence to be covered include assassination, civil war, ethnic conflict, insurgency, revolution, riots, terrorism, and war.

title: American Literary History
reviews: Be careful of Moby Dick. It's a lot of pages, and takes a while to read.
Be prepared to read and participate in class. This class is largely based on student discussion, so talking in class is necessary for a good experience.
Go to office hours for more stimulating discussion.
It was interesting. I would recommend it. I learned a lot about literature and American history.
Read Moby Dick before the semester starts.
Take it for an LA if you like writing; it's good.
Take it, but be careful, he's looking for very specific things.
prereqs: Open to all students. This course is
descrip: This course surveys American literature from the colonial period to the Civil War. We will read accounts of early contact, narratives of captivity and slavery, sermons, revolutionary tracts, autobiographies, novels, and poems. We will also examine modern representations of early America in fiction, poetry, and film. In lectures and precepts, we will discuss the influence of individual texts in relation to established accounts of American history to discover how American literature responded to and shaped debates about religion, race, gender, and liberty, and how these debates continue to impact contemporary life in the United States.

title: Introduction to Relativity
reviews: Generally this is a nice course. When taking it, be careful not to think this is an introduction to differential geometry. This is a physics course, and you are supposed to take a look at some interesting applications of GR rather than getting the inside beauty of theoretical structure.
Good course, good professor. As a physics major, one has to take GR. How can you count yourself one if not?!?
Great introduction to GR if you haven't already taken it; the parts about Cosmology (in the final weeks of the class) are also a great introduction for the Cosmology course.

It's not as difficult as you might imagine.  Be prepared to read the book and work on the problem sets, but the exams are always doable, and everything you need to know is presented in class at some point.
Pretty good class if you want to learn GR from (almost) scratch.

This may be my favorite class I've taken at Princeton, and I'm not even in physics. The class is really eye-opening if (like me) you have not thought about relativity before.  Pretorius is an excellent and accessible teacher, and Bantilan is a very competent and helpful TA.  I highly recommend the course.
good as an introduction to general relativity. Not mathematically challenging but rather develop basic notions and intuitions
descrip: This course gives an introduction to Einstein's theory of general relativity. No prior knowledge of general relativity will be assumed, and an overview of the differential geometry needed to understand the field equations and spacetime geometries will be given. Beyond this, topics covered will include black holes, gravitational waves, and cosmological spacetimes.

title: An Integrated, Quantitative Introduction to the Natural Sciences I
reviews: I think those that want to take Integrated and will benefit most from it will inevitably end up there. To someone thinking about pursuing research, to people who love science, to those who are genuinely fascinated by the mysteries and the triumphs of science spanning multiple disciplines, integrated is the answer. I would warn them of the long, very long, nights in Icahn, the very difficult problem sets, the on-average 40 hour labs, the times when I felt like I was in way over my head; but for those who will really benefit from integrated, this is not likely to deter them. It is, in fact, likely to encourage them, and I think that those people belong in the integrated program and will grow in understanding, in scientific ability, in strength, and in confidence by taking it. I think that I have been lucky in the group of people taking it this year - we have a fabulous atmosphere, strongly encouraging collaboration, and generally have become a tightly knit group of fellow science enthusiasts. I oscillate between being completely astounded by how brilliant these people are, thrilled that I get to work with them, and just plain amazed at the science we get to delve into. In short, I would recommend those meant for integrated to take it; it is, hands down, worth it. It will not be easy, but it will be rewarding.

If you are at all interested in science, this class is incredible and you should by all means take it, but do not take it out of the idea that it is easier or out of ego.  Be careful taking it with other hard classes.
If you're sure you're going into science, go for it. Otherwise, not for you.
Only take the course if you are willing to invest large amounts of time, especially initially.
See ISC 231.
See answer to ISC231
See evaluation for 231.
See evaul for 231
Take it! It's well worth your efforts and you learn so much that opens your eyes to the world around you.
Take the course. Of course, it is not for everyone, but the lectures precepts and labs are all amazing. Probably the best quality of teaching you will get all freshman year.
answered in ISC231
prereqs: Familiarity with the calculus at the level of MAT 103/4 or Advanced Placement Calculus BC, solid high school physics and chemistry courses..
descrip: An integrated, mathematically and computationally sophisticated introduction to physics and chemistry, drawing on examples from biological systems. This year long, four course sequence is a multi-disciplinary course taught across multiple departments with the following faculty: W. Bialek, T. Gregor, J. Shaevitz (PHY); P. Debenedetti (CBE); O. Troyanskaya (COS); H. Yang (CHM); C. Broedersz, T. Calhoun, A. Leifer, B. Machta (LSI Fellows). Additional lectures in fall term will be given by D. Botstein (MOL) and P. Andolfatto (EEB). Five hours of lecture, one three-hour lab, one three-hour precept, one required evening problem session.

title: A Social and Multi-Dimensional Exploration of Structures
reviews: Definitely take this course. Not only do you get to go on a field trip with your professors and classmates but you also learn a lot about extremely innovative structures. A great supplement to an engineering education.

If you want to do more research on a particular structure, this is the class that you should take. You would be best advised though to familiarize yourself with the use of some programs namely, SAP, Rhino, Illustrator.
It is an enjoyable and very didactic course at the same time.
Only take it if you wish to devote time for it. There were weeks when the workload outside of the 6 studio hours ended up over 10 hours.

TAKE THIS COURSE! It's better than the typical course where you read a book, attend lectures, and answer questions. This course allows you to apply the work that you have learned in the previous engineering courses.
Take this class if you are prepared to invest a lot of time into it.
Take this course! You won't regret it!
Take this course!!!

This course is a lot of work but is really enjoyable in the end. You get to showcase what you have learnt and produced in a display in Friend. The visit to the structures is really valuable and enjoyable.

This is one of the coolest classes offered by the CEE department.  It's not the type for people without initiative or self-motivation, but if you put work into it, you will be greatly rewarded.  The class gives a great appreciation for the creative-thinking and problem-solving skills that are necessary in engineering and gives a chance to exercise them in ways no other class I've taken with the department has.
You're better off taking another course - you waste a lot of time in this course and don't learn much.  Don't be attracted by the field trip, unless that is what you're after.
yes! you're going to SPAIN
prereqs: PreReqs CEE 205 and CEE 312.
descrip: The class has pedagogical objectives related to the spatial relations of dimensions and time (sustainability and society). It develops the students' skills in drawing, model making, writing, oral communication, and advanced engineering analysis. The course is focused on a study of one theme that changes every year. Within each theme engineering calculations of designs will be made through advanced analyses. The social context will be studied, a site visit will be made during break week, models of a few significant works will be created and placed on display as part of a small exhibition. Two three-hour studios per week with lectures included.

title: Introduction to German Literature after 1700
reviews: I can't really say. I never fully did the readings and always just made up pretty much everything I said/wrote, but that seemed to work for me, as I did somewhat well on most of the papers. Others I know tried the same tactic without as much luck.

If you're interested, shop this class and decide if you like discussing German and German literature (as well as the instructor's approach). It can be quite a step up from GER107, especially in terms of the difficulty of texts (you can't translate every word like you used to).
Take it, but only if you're fairly confident about your German ability beforehand.  It goes pretty fast...
prereqs: GER 107 or equivalent.
descrip: An introduction to major authors, periods, and genres of German literature from the eighteenth century to the present. The course provides a background for the further study of German literature while developing interpretive techniques and providing intensive writing practice. Conducted in German.

title: Science, Technology and Public Policy
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Responsible Conduct in Research: A Course on Ethics in Engineering (Half-term)
prereqs: This course is required for graduate students in engineering who participate in federally funded research; the course is highly recommended and/or required for undergraduate students as well as post-doctoral researchers in engineering who participate in federally funded research. There are no prerequisites for attending the course..
descrip: This course educates the graduate student of engineering in the responsible conduct of research. The lectures provide theoretical background information as well as case studies about ethics in day-to-day research situations, in publishing and peer-review, in student-advisor relationships, in collaborative research, as well as in the big picture and considerations of long-term impact. The students are provided with resources to consult in ethical questions. In small-group discussions in research field-specific precepts, the theoretical concepts are made relevant to the individual students situations.

title: Design and Interpretation of Social Psychological Research
prereqs: Psychology graduate students only, or Instructor's Permission..
descrip: An advanced seminar that considers current research in social psychology. Contemporary research conducted by the seminar participants is discussed.

title: Elementary Persian I
reviews: Great.
If you are even considering taking this course you absolutely should.  Even if you don't need it for a language requirement or a departmental, it was a wonderful way to start my day every morning.

Persian is a very interesting and very attainable language and classes with Amineh were great.  You might not speak Persian as well as you speak Spanish after SPA 101, but you learn an entire new alphabet and still are able to learn useful conversational skills.
Yes, take it!
prereqs: No credit is given for PER 101 unless it is followed by PER 102..
descrip: The focus of this elementary course is on sounds, letters and basic grammar of Persian language. The students will be exposed to the Persian culture through selected prose, daily news and class discussions.

title: Special Topics in Visual Arts - Painting Without Canvas
reviews: It starts off really slow....too slow.  But once it does pick up I promise its amazing!  So once you make it through the color walk assignment, the artist presentations, the get-to-know you class and the tech certification class then you are good and the class will be amazing.  Just be patient.
prereqs: Intro. Painting (VIS 203/204) and/or Intro. Drawing (VIS 201/202) and/or Intro. Sculpture (VIS 221/222) and/or Ceramic Sculpture (VIS 231) and/or Intro Photo and/or Intro Video/Film.
descrip: This interdisciplinary studio course encourages students to expand their definition of painting by investigating methods of painting other than the convention of stretched fabric over a wood support.
