Historical precedents for the class include fresco painting, polychrome sculpture, painted furniture, murals, and painted installations. Students will experiment with the effects of applied paint and color on paper, three dimensional forms, material fragments, and walls. A variety of application techniques will also be explored. The class will pay particular attention to the idea of paint and color as tangible objects with spatial properties.

title: Representing Illness
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Electronic Circuit Analysis, Design and Implementation
reviews: A pretty nice option to fulfill any requirements if you're willing to put in the time; and for concentrators, a course to look forward to.

A solid, hands-on introduction to circuits that will teach you a lot without necessarily eating all your time the way a lot of engineering classes do.  Prucnal is awesome.  The labs take a bit longer than the 3 hours they're allotted, and the course project can get a bit time consuming, but overall very manageable.
Be prepared for having to learn a lot on your own.
Definitely take this class. One of my favorites
Don't get too stressed out over the course work but instead focus on how much you are actually learning and be happy.
Enjoy:)
Get ready for bad TAs, but the class material is a lot of fun if you like circuits
Great course

I would highly recommend this class to people who are interested in circuits. While most of the class will be ELE majors, some non-ELE majors like myself thoroughly enjoyed the clear lectures, building things in lab, and seeing everything we learned come together in building the radio and the electrocardiogram. It is more work than the usual class near the end, it is worth it.
If you are into physics or electricity, this course is definitely very interesting. Otherwise, you might not have much fun.
If you have to take it, take it. It's more an introduction to hands-on work that you'll be doing later on in ELE than a theory class
If you love hardware, you'll love this class as the labs are very fun (great intro to how to use basic ELE equipment), and circuit analysis is fun.
If you're ELE, then you have to take it. Otherwise, take it if you have any interest in learning about the basics of circuits, although the lab can at times be time intensive.
It's a requirement, so take it. You'll definitely love Prucnal and the TAs, just don't underestimate lab.
Its a big time commitment, especially with the EKG project, but it's also really fun. I'd highly recommend it.
PRACTICE PROBLEMS!
Professor Prucnal is AMAZING! If you are even thinking about taking this course, TAKE IT! You'll enjoy it!

Professor Prucnal is a really soft-spoken teacher, but he's an absolute expert at what he does. He was always flying out to these conferences where Apple would consult him about their new chips.  The labs and lectures work really well together in this course, and the grading is very fair.
Start the homework early and be sure to read the labs ahead of time.
Stay on top of the material and you'll do great/ have fun.
Take it if you are ELE or interested in the subject. Grading is generous.
Take it if you are interested in the field, but know that is a ton of work.
Take it! You must be prepared to spend a lot of time in the lab, but it is worth it.  I loved this course! It was definitely my favorite course a Princeton so far.
Take the course! The ECG project was fun and taught a lot, although the general material could become a little dry.

The grading is generally fair, and I don't think the curve is too bad, but expect the ECG project to be time consuming and frustrating.  That said, I'm happy with the course as a whole, and I think it teaches a lot of useful skills.

The written assignments are fine but the lab stuff will take up your time like crazy. After the midterm you should expect to be spending 10  hours in the lab every week just building circuits (on top of problem sets, lab reports, and lab write-ups). If you're taking this with ELE 206 then don't expect to have too much free time in the semester.
This is a good course that will show you the elegance of analog circuits, and how to analyze and design them. Some of the labs can get a little lengthy, however.
if you like circuits you will love this class
take it slow and make sure you understand everthing
descrip: Introduction to electronic theory and practice. DC and AC circuit analysis theorems and passive and active components, from resistors/capacitors/inductors to operational amplifiers. Feedback, sinusoidal steady state analysis, frequency response, resonance, diodes, transistors. Labs and demos support and extend class material, culminating in a functioning radio. Creative circuit design using light and sound outputs is encouraged. A final project on bio-sensing, including design and testing of an electrocardiogram circuit to sense real heartbeats. SPICE circuit simulation is introduced and leveraged in the labs and project.

title: Nietzsche
prereqs: At least one Philosophy course-not elementary logic. Freshmen admitted only after interview. Please contact Prof. Nehamas for an appointment..
descrip: An examination of Nietzsche's central views, including the role of tragedy, the place of science, the eternal recurrence, the will to power, and the primacy of the individual. We will also examine Nietzsche's ambiguous attitude toward philosophy and his influence on literature and criticism.

title: Policy Workshop - Accountability and Service Delivery (India)
descrip: This workshop will analyze problems such as teacher and health worker absenteeism, the "leakage" of funds from legislatures to schools, clinics, roads, etc. Using surveys developed over the past decade as well as theoretical and empirical studies in the literature, the workshop will analyze the magnitude of the implementation and leakage problem in India, and propose potential solutions. Most likely the "client" will be "Accountability India", a non-profit based in Delhi, which has conducted surveys in various places across India.

title: Current Research in Law and Politics
descrip: This seminar examines current research in law and politics across a range of specific research questions, methods, and research traditions. The seminar combines background reading on selected topics with presentation of current research by scholars in the field of law and politics. Participants are expected to participate in both the regular seminar sessions and the public law colloquium, complete assigned readings, and complete assigned written work.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Impact Evaluation Tools
prereqs: Pre-requisite: 508c..
descrip: This course presents tools for designing, implementing, and analyzing impact evaluations from a practitioner's perspective. It explores real-world problems and practical limitations frequently encountered in conducting evaluations and methodological tools to address them. Topics include program operation rules and their implications for design choice, process and standards for assessing evidence, challenges to randomization, sample size determination, complex sample design, and construction of analytic and non response weights. Students will practice addressing these issues through a series of case studies and analytic exercises.

title: Senior Independent Work
descrip: A one semester study of an important problem or topic in chemical and biological engineering. Projects may be experimental, computational, or theoretical. Topics selected by the students from suggestions by the faculty. Written report required.

title: Religion, Poetry, and Memory in Ancient China
descrip: The seminar explores the interplay of religious and aesthetic -- especially poetic -- practice in ancient China and how the performance of texts and the use of images and objects in religious and social spaces contributed to the formation of Chinese cultural memory and identity. Combining anthropological, art historical, and literary analysis, the emphasis is on close analysis of original texts (in translation) and artifacts, including objects in the Princeton Art Museum.

title: The Ottoman Empire, 1300-1800
descrip: This course surveys the history of the world's most enduring Islamic state, the Ottoman Empire. With its beginnings in the fourteenth century, it lasted into the early years of the last century. At its height it ruled over much of the Mediterranean as well as Central Europe, the Balkans, the Middle East and today's Turkey.

title: Modern Genetics and Public Policy
reviews:
1. Definitely take the course; if you do not get in--stay on the waiting list. The waiting will be worthwhile. 
2. Do the readings (there will be a lot--so, do as much as you can); but, you discuss the readings during the 3 hr seminar. So, doing the readings is definitely necessary. 
3. Do not even think about missing class: a. it's a seminar b. you wouldn't want to--it's an amazing class with amazing professors on an amazingly interesting topic!
Definitely take it if it's offered again. Super interesting!
Definitely take this course.
Do the readings and write papers on what you are personally passionate about.
Highly recommend. Great discussion course with a lot of room to develop your own interest. One of the best interdisciplinary courses offered.
Lots of readings, great professors.
TAKE IT
Take it, you fool.
Take this!

This course is a rare opportunity to learn from two professors who are passionate about both the subject matter and about teaching. It is incredibly applicable and you will find yourself talking about the lessons of course in all sorts of contexts. If you have the chance to take this course, it would be ridiculous not to!

This is a great course. Take it if it is offered again and if you can get in! As a non-science person, I found the class really fascinating and important to take to understand a host of issues related to genetics and science in public policy.
This is a phenomenal course, I would absolutely recommend taking it. Professors are really good, readings are interesting, and you can't have a better group of people to have a discussion with.
Though thoroughly reading the assigned texts might not be necessary to do well in the course, try and complete all of them.
descrip: Examines modern genetics' implications for public policy focusing on health, law, consumer products, and criminal justice. Topics include: genetic testing and therapy; consumer regulations including FDA rules on at-home genetic testing; the law and genetic discrimination in insurance; and uses of forensic DNA in the courtroom. Explores social, political, and philosophical problems in these areas: changing conceptions of the self; relation of new genetics to the old, racially-charged, eugenics; impact of new theories of gene action and epigenetics on ideas about the "hardwiring" of health and behavior, and on "genetic blame" and future policy.

title: Intermediate Photography
reviews: Definitely take it. Be prepared to do some figuring things out on your own in the digital lab however. But Allan has so much insight into literally every aspect of photography that this class shouldn't be missed.
I have recommended many of my friends to take a film class at Princeton - particularly with Allan!

Intermediate is a great techniques based course - you'll work with medium and large format cameras and have a chance to do a lot of digital processing, as well. Allan definitely strives for quality over quantity in terms of images, which I think is a good thing for a course like this. Definitely take it if you're looking to expand your horizons in analog photography.
The work is difficult but the load is not heavy. Definitely a good class for those interested in a better understanding of photography than the beginning course provided.
This course is great. Allan is a very good teacher.
Use your time wisely.
prereqs: MUST have taken VIS 211 or 212 as a prerequisite for this class (Introductory Photo).
descrip: This studio course seeks to broaden students' skills through a wide range of photographic media. There will be an emphasis on the relationship between analog and digital photography and how visual artists negotiate the technological changes of today. A broad range of new tools will be introduced to the class including medium and large format cameras, scanners, Photoshop, color and BW pigment printing, studio lighting and the use of high-end digital backs. The class will consist of indepenent and collaborative assignments augmented by field trips, readings and discussion of contemporary issues. Prerequisite Course: Introductory Photo.

title: Introduction to Water Pollution Technology
reviews: If you're interested in the topic, go for it.  It's pretty specific material, so if it's outside your area, its probably not for you, but if not, I think it was entirely worthwhile.

If you're interested in water treatment, this course is a must.  Prof Jaffe is one of the best professors in the department and is very practical in what he expects out of his students.  The course is manageable and not too much work if you make it to every lecture (keep in mind they are at 8:30 am!).  However, if you're not a good test taker, your grade is completely based on the 2 tests and the final project.
Take if interested at all in water pollution.
Yes - as long as you are interested in the material.
prereqs: Student should have some background in chemistry and an interest in water pollution problems..
descrip: An introduction to the science of water quality management and pollution control in natural systems; fundamentals of biological and chemical transformations in natural waters; indentification of sources of pollution; water and wastewater treatment methods; fundamentals of water quality modeling.

title: Dostoevsky
reviews: Great course material.  Take the class with Chances if possible.  She does a great job of making everyone feel comfortable to share opinions and ideas.  Level of engagement was really high because we were all there out of interest rather than for distribution requirements.
TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT. Aaand do the reading. It's a lot, but Dostoevsky is so so good and it's worth every minute...and that way you can actually participate in precept.
Take it if you already have some background in Russian literature. Otherwise, you might miss out on some of the allusions that Dostoevsky weaves into his novels.
Take it if you want to curl up with a good book and read every night for homework.
Take it take it take it!
Take it. Do the readings as much as possible. Philosophical discussions with Professor Chances are fun.
Take this class -- readings are long, but well worth it.
This course is really fun if you want to read Dostoyevsky. Professor Chances is great.

Very engaging class, but the reading is heavy and there's a whole lot of it. Take if you have a specific interest in Dostoevsky--if you are looking to learn generally within the area of Russian literature, this is probably not the class for you.
descrip: The goal of the course is to acquaint students with the evolution of Dostoevsky's writings. A multi-faceted approach is used for coming to grips with the works. The focus is on stylistic, ethical, religious, philosophical and political dimensions of his art as well as on ways in which Dostoevsky fits into the cultural milieu of his time. Both non-Slavic Department and Departmental students are welcome.

title: Analytical Techniques in Differential Equations
reviews: I recommend taking this class, but I wouldn't say that it is required to pass Generals.
Keep an open mind and try to make connections between the various segments of the course.
descrip: Asymptotic methods, Dominant balance, ODEs: initial and Boundary value problems, Wronskian, Green's functions, Complex Variables: Cauchy's theorem, Taylor and Laurent expansions, Approximate Solution of Differential Equations, singularity type, Series expansions. Asymptotic Expansions. Stationary Phase, Saddle Points, Stokes phenomena. WKB Theory: Stokes constants, Airy function, Derivation of Heading's rules, bound states, barrier transmission. Asymptotic evaluation of integrals, Laplace's method, Stirling approximation, Integral representations, Gamma function, Riemann zeta function. Boundary Layer problems, Multiple Scale Analysis

title: Culture and Inequality
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Reading Literature: Drama
reviews: Be prepared for a little bit of close-mindedness from Professor Sandberg. Make sure you read the prompt for the exercises and answer every single part of it, even if it wasn't explicitly stated in the example. Enjoy the readings! They are really fun!
Don't save the plays for the weekend! Pace them out through the week.
Don't take this class unless you are interested in theater.  Also, be sure to read the plays-it's impossible to get into the class and participate well without knowing the material well.

Don't take this course if you are more interested in English than theater - it is very heavily geared toward students with acting experience, not students who have a general or literary interest in reading plays.
Good intro course to english.
I would tell the student to thoroughly form his own opinions and interpretations of each play before watching the productions.

If you don't enjoy plays, take some other English class. If you enjoy plays, the class might be somewhat interesting. Prof. Sandberg is really nice, but there are very few assignments in the class - 5 total, plus a final exam and class participation. The reading list can be very interesting, however.

If you enjoy reading plays and analyzing them, it's a good course. I don't think it is particularly easy, and if you don't love English, you might not enjoy it, but the plays are good and Professor Sandberg does a decent job lecturing.

If you enjoy theater and would like to spend time reading, watching, evaluating plays then this is a must-take. It really changes your way of viewing plays, movies and reading literature. Though be wary that you'll be taking this with quite a lot of English majors and actors who have better knowledge of the subject matter.
If you're interested in drama, this is definitely an enjoyable course. You can take opportunities to perform or not, depending on your personal inclination.

If you're interested in reading plays and learning how to better analyze them, this is a great course to take.  The work-load is very manageable.  You have the option to write a short play instead of a final paper, which is nice.
If you're not an English major, reconsider taking it because it can be tough on your grade. But at the same time, I think I learned a lot, and it was definitely a good class.
Keep up with the readings (it's not hard to do), take notes in class, engage in precept, and you should be fine. The gradings a bit hard, but reasonable.
Pretty good class- maybe not the best ever, but if you're interested in theater, take it!
Prof. Sandberg is a tough grader. I got lower grades on assignments than expected. Don't wait until the last second and don't be afraid to discuss the assignments with the professor/preceptor.
Recommend if you enjoy plays/english.

TAKE IT !!  Plays are quicker reads than novels, so one a week is very reasonable.  Sandberg is an interesting lecturer, and the points he makes add to your appreciation of the plays.  A great intro class.

TAKE THIS CLASS! If you like theatre this is the perfect class for you. Sandberg is an incredible teacher and understands the plays you read in a three-dimensional, theatrical way that a normal English professor can't. Generally, you just need to read one play per week and often they're plays that are being put up in Princeton so you get to watch the performances and analyze them in class. If you can, get into his precept as well.
Take the course. Professor is great. Readings are stimulating.

Take this class. The work load is not unmanageable by any stretch of the imagination, and Professor Sandberg is extremely wise and engaging. The plays that he chooses to study are also extremely varied and interesting reads.

The reading list was great, and I appreciated even the plays I didn't like. Precepts are a bit long. Since there are few graded assignments, don't be afraid to hone your ideas by talking to the professor/preceptor.
Work hard on the small assignments, they have the biggest impact on your grade.

Yes--if you like plays and theater and know you're good at English.  You have to be really into drama to truly love the course I think, and you have to be willing to pay to go see plays on your own time.
make sure you love theater
descrip: This course is designed to teach students how to read plays as literature written for performance. Key assumptions are that every act of reading is an act of interpretation, that a good reader of dramatic literature engages in an activity nearly identical to that of a good director or actor or designer, and that a reader might learn from theater practitioners how to make critical choices based on close reading and a knowledge of theatre history.

title: Beginning Polish I
descrip: This is the first part of a two-semester beginners' course in Polish. There are no prerequisites for enrollment. Previous exposure to other Slavic languages is advantageous, but is in no way required or expected. The course will develop all the essential areas of competence in Polish - speaking, grammatical knowledge, listening and reading comprehension - although the communicative aspect will be given high priority. Instruction will be carried out almost exclusively in the target language. English will be used only where absolutely necessary for conveying certain grammatical structures and course-related information.

title: Intermediate Urdu I
reviews: Fauzia is fun and engaging and pretty laid back. Take this course if you're interested in continuing your hindi/urdu instruction.

If you love India, Pakistan, or the Urdu language (or all of the above) take this class. Fauzia ji is an extraordinary professor and human being. You will not regret learning a beautiful, provocative, historical, political language with a really wonderful professor.
The same as with any language course: work hard and you will learn a lot.
Work hard and you will get the most out of it!
prereqs: HIN/URD 101 and 102 or equivalent proficiency in either language.
descrip: The course is a continuation of HIN/URD 102, concentrating on Urdu. Students beginning with intermediate proficiency in either Urdu or Hindi will be brought to an advanced level in Urdu in all four skills: reading, writing, speaking, and listening. Urdu script will be introduced and emphasis will be placed on strengthening literacy skills. Cultural aspects will be integrated with instruction. Activities will be conducted in Urdu and classes will be interactive.

title: Topics in Russian Philosophy - Religious Dilemmas in Three Major Writers
descrip: The seminar has a double goal: to explore religious topics in Gogol, Dostoevsky, and Tolstoy through Silver Age Russian thinkers who broadly commented on these writers, and to examine how various religious dilemmas raised in the works of Gogol, Dostoevsky, and Tolstoy prompted the Silver Age search for Unity (the concepts of Sobornost', Godmanhood, Theurgy, Intuitive Knowledge, and Sacred Corporeality).

title: International Monetary Theory and Policy I
reviews: Definitely take it.
For sure read all recommended papers in the list and if you have time read the others one too.
Take it.
descrip: This sequence (with ECO 554) develops core models of international finance and open-economy macroeconomics, and surveys selected current research topics in the field. Topics treated in the first semester include: the intertemporal approach to the current account; the determination of real exchange rates, and purchasing power parity; international CAPM and uncovered interest rate parity; sovereign debt crisis; speculative attacks and liquidity crises; international risk sharing and capital flows, home bias, and the stability of the international financial system.

title: Poetics - Eccentric Moderns
descrip: An examination of six 20th century poets (David Jones, Laura Riding, Hart Crane, Auden, Hill, and Anne Carson) in the light of ideas about Modernism. A pluralist model of Modernisms emerges. The course combines practical criticism with literary and cultural history, integrating formal analysis and historical context.

title: Life in the Universe
prereqs: One geosciences, chemistry, biology or astronomy class or AP Physics or Chemistry..
descrip: This course introduces students to the new field of Astrobiology where scientists trained in molecular biology, biology, chemistry, astrophysics and geosciences combine their skills to reveal life's origins and to explore for extraterrestrial life. Topics include: the astrophysical prerequisites for life, the origin of life on Earth, the RNA world, the evolution of metabolism and photosynthesis, life in extreme environments, and the search for life within our solar system and extra-solar planets that offer targets for NASA space telescopes searching for life.

title: Public Economics
reviews: Awesome course. Well organized, thoughtful. Lots of material and good conversation.
Best class at Princeton.  No one is better than Bogan.

Definitely take it!
Keep up with the readings, both because they're fun and because it'll help you come exam time.
Definitely take this course. Bogan knows what she is talking about and does a great job of making the lectures and readings interesting.
Do the reading

Every econ major should try to take this course before they graduate. Not only is the quality of the class incredible, but the material taught is some of the most useful stuff you can learn here. I feel so much more informed as a citizen than I did before taking this class, and understanding the economics of government is something that many people purport to do, while few actually do. Professor Bogan is one of the latter. And if you're lucky, David will be your preceptor, too. They are a dream team for teaching the class.
Great course. Very informative, but a lot of work.
Highly recommend, and frankly think it should be promoted more than it is, though I guess it's always oversubscribed anyway. Definitely the most practical econ course I've taken, by far.
If you enjoy Professor Bogan's classes this one is excellent. She uses current events to discuss the topics and this make the class even more interesting.
If you have any interest in economics, and politics, Bogan is an absolute treat.  She is one of the best lecturers in the entire department, and cares more than any other Professor I know.
If you like Bogan's teaching style and have an interest in public economics, then definitely take this class!
If you're considering it at all, take it.
If you're interested, definitely take the course! Very relevant to current issues and the material is up-to-date.  A good amount of reading, but it's interesting and manageable.
Interesting subjects and Bogan does a great job.
Spend time really absorbing the material covered in the readings. This isn't an easy course, but you will definitely learn alot.
TAKE IT! Take good notes on readings/ Economist articles
Take it - really interesting course!
Take it if you have any interest in economics or policy. You'll learn a lot and have a new context for thinking about policy.
Take it!
Take it.
Take it. One of my favorites.
Take this course if you want to actually know something about current public policy.
Take this course!!! Sooo relevant for living in today's world and understanding what's going on when you read or watch the news. Bogan is one of the best lecturers I've had here.

Take this course, it is potentially the best economics course at Princeton--it will give you a lot of depth and perspective on almost all of the key domestic policy  issues, such as health, education, crime, financial regulation, etc.
Take this course. The work load is a little more than a typical class, but is well worth it!! Bogan is an amazing professor you won't regret taking this course!
Take this course. You will be a smarter student because of it.

This course was fantastic!!! I took this course because it fulfilled a WWS distribution requirement and the topics of the course sounded really interesting. Also heard great things about Bogan.

Professor Bogan is amazing. She truly dedicates herself to her teaching, and it comes out. In lecture, she is animated and enthusiastic. She always makes a point to bring in relevant, related topics. She also has more open office hours than any other professor I've ever had. She is very open to student questions and really goes out of her way to explain things to you. Because of her, I was very engaged with the course. I found the materials fascinating. I loved the topics and feel confident in talking about many topics in public policy- including healthcare, education, welfare, taxes, pollution, and even finance. I think this class should be a requirement for all WWS majors. Learning about the costs and benefits of public policy is key for anyone who is going to be a decision maker for this country.

** TIPS FOR STUDENTS** Make sure you do the economist readings, form study groups with friends to summarize the packet readings, and review every problem set before your exams. Her exams are tough but fair and have a predictable format.
This is a really great Econ course, particularly for non-Econ majors who have some background in it. You'll learn a ton about various public policy issues.
This is an excellent class that is eye-opening in terms of how economically sound policies are. It is probably more challenging for people without economics backgrounds.
n/a
take it. just tailor precept reading to questions given out in advance
prereqs: ECO 100 and ECO 101..
descrip: The role of government in promoting efficiency and equity in the U.S. economy. Conditions when markets fail to be efficient. Problems with government allocation of resources. Economic analysis and public policies regarding health care, education, poverty, the environment, financial regulations and other important issues.

title: Critical Perspectives on Global Health and Health Policy
reviews:
1) Be prepared for a lot of reading
2) Do the readings! You'll get a lot more from the class. Maybe take a look at previous year's syllabuses and finish a book or two over summer
3) The professors and TAs really care about the class and (believe it or not) are on your side. Take advantage of that; talk to them after class about your issues, go to office hours, e-mail them, etc
A great class to gain perspective on global health, whether you are in the GHP certificate program or not.

A very interesting anthropological perspective on Global Health, taught by a team of anthropologists and one economics professor. Readings are really interesting and pertinent, and we talked about both international and domestic affairs involving multiple domains of global health.

An excellent course for anyone interested in health, development, medicine, technology, anthropology. Be prepared to read a lot, to question common-sense assumptions, and to grapple with the complexities of global health interventions. This was one of my favorite classes at Princeton--I definitely recommend!
Be sure to meet up with the professors individually and get a good sense of grading for the coursework.
Come prepared with something to say each lecture. Make yourself heard!
Dedicate a reasonable amount of time on reading responses!
Definitely worth taking - don't know what to expect grade wise - class is way too large.

Do the readings and engage with them; also get feedback on your final paper idea.  This is a good class that doesn't require tons of work, but there's a fair amount of reading.  Make sure you delegate work well for the group project.  You'll learn how to work with people from other disciplines, though at times it may be frustrating.
Do the readings if you want to get the most out of the lectures. Don't be afraid to raise your hand and speak in lecture
Do the readings, participate in class, and go to the professors' office hours - this is a class that is as interesting as you make it!
For anyone with an interest in global health, take this course!
Get to know your grader and what he/she expects in your writing.
Good course. I think they are adding precepts next year, in which case I would suggest that you definitely take this class!
Gotta take it if you're in GHP but it isn't bad.
Hopefully they cut the amount of reading for this class...

I think this is a really great course if you are looking for a medical anthropology course. The professors are fantastic, but it is not as interdisciplinary as advertised. I loved this course for the first couple weeks, but my enthusiasm faded some as we had more of the same week after week.

I think this provides a great overview of the field of global health. It exposes you to different ways of thinking and debates, opening up doors to questions and ideas. If you are GHP, this is why you wanted to do this certificate! If you are just interested in health, still take it! Though there is a lot of reading, it's all very interesting and will leave you with a good sense of the field and hopefully make you want to engage more.

If you have any interest in global health, I strongly recommend this course! If you don?t care about global health, I challenge you to take this course and not find at least one issue in the field that you?re extremely passionate about. This course might just change your life. Also, the teaching staff are wonderful and lots of great guest speakers are brought in. Be prepared for lots of readings and remember the art of selective skimming! Also, make sure to get a head start on your final paper?it?s really a chance to shine!

If you're taking this, it's probably because you're GHP and have to. It's a good enough course but they try to cover too large an area of study in a very strange format (70 person discussion based lectures...)
It's interesting, not a lot of work, but not an easy A
Lots of reading, but very interesting!!
Read as much as you can. Don't sweat the lack of direction - write about what interests you, just defend it well.

Take advantage of the availability of the teaching staff. I wish I did this more, but yeah - you have 2 professors and 3 "preceptors." They are all young and approachable, yet very accomplished and bright. They are more than willing to meet with you, speak with you, write to you, etc. so definitely do talk to them even if you don't have very specific questions. Try to do as many readings as you can, and stay engaged during discussions to get the most out of the class.
Take the course!
Take this class if you are interested in the anthropological side of global health.
Take this class, and go to it.

Take this course! If you have any interest in the sphere of global health, you will get a broad introduction to all the different facets of this truly multidisciplinary field. The professors are so nice and engaging, and really want to help you do your best.
The class is more or less an overview course of different issues in global health -- no specific topic is discussed in too much detail.
Try to understand the main ideas and patterns across readings rather than focusing on too much detail.
Work hard, do all the reading
You'll have to do it for GHP.
interesting, but not best structure.
descrip: Taking an interdisciplinary approach, the course identifies the main actors, institutions, knowledge and values at work in the field of global health, and explores the environmental, social, political, and economic factors that shape patterns and variations in disease and health across societies. Topics include: technology and public health; development and the governance of disease; human rights and social justice; the shifting role of states, civil society, and public-private partnerships in health care delivery. Students are encouraged to think creatively about health problems and to envision innovative and effective interventions.

title: Seminar in History of Photography - Abstraction and Photography
prereqs: Undergraduates must get permission from the instructor..
descrip: What does it mean for a photograph to be considered "abstract," if it is by definition a recording of light in the material world? Why and how have fine arts photographers such as Coburn, Bruguiere, Man Ray, Stieglitz, Moholy-Nagy, Roger Parry, Otto Steinert and the Subjective Fotographie movement and, more recently, Ruff, Welling, Tillmans, and Beshty self-consciously explored abstraction? This seminar will posit an alternative to the popular perception of the medium as documentary and "realistic." Connections with scientific imagery, the decorative, spiritualism, and parallel movements in the fine arts will be addressed.

title: Quantitative Analysis I
descrip: This is a first course in statistics for social scientists. Students will learn to explore data creatively and to conduct straightforward statistical analyses. Basic probability and statistical theory will also be taught. There is no prerequisite except high school mathematics and a willingness to learn elementary calculus.

title: Computational Physics Seminar
reviews: Do not take this course without some sort of programming knowledge. I had never programmed before, and since they teach very little coding, most of my time in lab was spent stumbling through code, not even getting to the actual, interesting physics. If you have coding experience, this  course is probably better.
I liked this class less than I expected. Take it if you're expecting to put a good amount of effort in to master Python, but not if you're hoping this is a fifth class without any stress.

PHY 209 gives a brief treatment of many different physics topics in the form of a lab each week. Frans is a good lecturer and the labs are neat. I would recommend taking this with another physics class, like PHY 205 or 207, effectively adding a few labs to the otherwise lab-less sophomore physics classes.
Think about python if you're not familiar with it (or whatever language is being used for the class), so that you can get more done in the labs.
This is a pretty chill course. Take it if you need a light course and are interested in learning Python/nonstandard physics.
prereqs: PHY 104 or PHY 106 or permission of instructor.
descrip: Introduction to the use of computers in physics research. The two main themes of the course are the difficulty of analyzing even simple physics problems with pen and paper, and the application of numerical programming to such problems. Methods include numerical integration, least-squares fitting, Fourier transforms, and Monte Carlo simulation. Students will engage in scientific programming, graphing, and some visualization. Examples are intentionally drawn from various fields of physics not normally explored by sophomores, including cosmology, condensed matter, and elementary particle physics.

title: Seminar on Selected Topics in International Security and Qualitative Methods
descrip: The seminar focuses on selected topics in international security that have not been sufficiently covered in other courses and seminars offered by the department. These include topics such as power, military effectiveness, signaling and interstate communication, beliefs and emotions, the role of reputation etc. Each session, the group will discuss the evolution in a particular body of literature in the field, while placing the emphasis on issues such as conceptualization and measurement of key variables, case selection criteria, research strategy and execution.

title: The Study of Comparative Politics
descrip: A general introduction to the field of comparative politics, with an emphasis on principal theoretical approaches and major problems and theories.

title: Thinking Translation: Language Transfer and Cultural Communication
reviews: A relatively easy class that gives a good overview on the struggles of translating. Only take it if you are interested in translation as the lectures can get repetitive.

Absolutely take it if you are interested in how people communicate across cultures. This course asks more questions than it answers, but it will definitely push you to think about the issue more critically. It also introduces you to the differences across different fields of translation, which are very thought-provoking.

Definitely take the course. You'll get a wonderful overview of what translation can do in a very wide variety of fields and situations. I particularly liked the units on linguistic anthropology and translation in law.

Depends on what you want - might be perfect for you, but as a freshman. It's not very hard, not very difficult to wrap your head around the concepts (a thorough Google search would have taught you enough about legal translation, the UN, machine translation, even translation theory..)
Enjoy! This class is a real joy to take. Read the readings.
Go to lecture and precept and do the majority of the readings.

It's a survey course - perfect for students with interest in Translation, easy distribution requirement, super awesome lectures, and not much work. That said, there are courses at Princeton that teach you more and are more practical.
It's great, take it.

It's not too much work and fascinating material (for the most part.) 
So if you are interested in translation and/or languages ... take it.

Seriously, take this class. It's one of the best I've taken here at Princeton. Even if you think you only have a passing interest in translation, this class will make you redefine what translation is - it looks at the topic from a wide variety of backgrounds, theories, and disciplines (from literature to the law to science and beyond) and makes you realize just how important (and prevalent) it is in the world. The class featured multiple guest lecturers, who were all fantastic, and our preceptor, Jill, was amazing. I was never bored and she was great at sustaining thoughtful discussion while at the same time always being helpful and open.
Stay on top of the readings and ask as many questions as possible.
Take it if you are in any way interested in translation!
Take this course if you find anything about language intriguing.  It's not just for people who are hoping to learn how to translate!

Take this course if you would like to understand more about translation in its various forms. Expect to be challenged by the different readings and discussions in class. Also, be prepared to analyze highly theoretical perspectives on translation.
The readings are generally very interesting. Amazing guest speakers, although some are not as good as others. Take it!

This course will make you think in a way that will apply to all aspects of your life. If you are at all interested in the concept of translation, or communication or the relationships between various components of society, take it.
Very good course, take if interested at all. Not too difficult, very good guest lecturers.
prereqs: Language requirement in at least one foreign language and completion of a 200-level course in a foreign language (may be taken simultaneously)..
descrip: What is translation? What is a language? So essential and widespread is translation today that it has become a central analytic term for the contact of cultures, and a paradigm for studying many different aspects of our multilingual world. This course will consider translation as it appeared in the past, but especially as it constructs everyday life in the contemporary world. It will look at issues of anthropology, artificial intelligence, diplomacy, film, law and literature that involve interlingual and intercultural communication. Students should acquire an understanding of the problems and practices of modern translation.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS): Non-credit
reviews: Be aware of the spontaneous time commitments. It's not just a class that meets solely at the assigned times. There are often days when you'll have to coordinate with other group members to meet for a while in the evenings. The course is largely student-led but with a unique role of the professor. Students devise the ideas that the professors can easily discount when they desire. Grading seems relative capricious but not due to any fault of the professor. By function of the course, it's difficult to prove measurable results.
Be serious if you want to work in a lab

EPICS is awesome. It's hands-on, and allows you and your classmates to be in control of the project. This is unlike any other class at Princeton and is great for developing handy skills that other classes cannot teach.
Learn up Labview quickly!
Make sure you are very interested in the subject matter before diving into it.
Take a different section of EPICS, not this one
This was a fun, interesting class. Working with the time team was a great way to get involved with a cool engineering project.
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: Landmarks of European Identity
reviews: Be forewarned that you have no idea what your grade is or will be throughout the semester - the only graded assignment was the final paper. Nonetheless, it was a great course.
Honestly, I wouldn't recommend taking it.
Interesting, but sometimes a lot of reading.  Take it only if you are pursuing the EPS or ECS certificate.
It's an easy course (as it is currently taught) with great general knowledge, some of the speakers were thrilling, but don't expect to learn anything about "What is Europe?"
It's hard to dislike great minds lecturing on their areas of expertise
Take advantage of the fact that you get to meet so many great professors.
Take for a fun and interesting, but low-work HA. Unclear if grading is lenient or not, however.
Take it if you're interested in the works, but also comfortable with having a class that might lack the structure found in others.

The course offers a good introduction to the canon of great European works. The reading load is heavy, and in trying to get to everything we don't spend as much time with each as we could. But if you put in the work you can get a lot out of it.
descrip: This course gives a broad and inter-disciplinary perspective on some of the very diverse cultural and historical roots of European identity. It examines contemporary debates over contested identity in the light of long historical trajectories in which identities were continually defined and reshaped. It is conceived as an introduction to many of the courses in Princeton dealing with European issues. The landmarks include, but are not restricted to, written texts. They include Machiavelli, Montesquieu, Marx and J.S. Mill, but also Fra Angelico, Beethoven and Thomas Mann. One three-hour seminar.

title: Plasma Waves and Instabilities
reviews: Listen to what Ilya says.  Ask other graduate students who have taken the course about the material, as often they can give a better insight to the material when one is first introduced.
You'll end up taking this class, even if it's bad.
descrip: Wave phenomena in a cold magnetized plasma, including resonances, cut-offs, mode conversion, drift waves, weak collisions, energy transport and finite temperature effects over a wide range of frequencies. Development of the full hot plasma model for waves in locally homogeneous plasmas, including collisionless damping mechanisms such as Landau, cyclotron and TTMP damping, velocity-space instabilities and Nyquist analysis, hot plasma mode conversion, and Bernstein waves. Applications to plasma diagnostics, radiofrequency plasma heating and noninductive current drive, and magnetospheric propagation.

title: Quantitative Analysis and Politics
reviews: An great course with Prof. Ratkovic.  He is incredibly accessible and effective at explaining statistics in a humorous manner.  It is a challenging course at times, but worthwhile.  I think this is better than most other stats courses because you actually apply what you are learning (we predicted the 2012 election using election polls)
Be certain to put enough time and effort into this course. It is very challenging and time consuming, especially if you have no experience coding.
Be ready for R, because it is not easy. The course is fair but make sure you know other students who are planning on taking the class as well because it will definitely help you.
Be ready to work if you are weak in math.
Be sure to keep up with the readings and take notes on the problems that you have with the quizzes and the problem sets. Go to office hours!
Definitely a useful class. Very good discipline to be familiar with.  Plus, Ratkovic is a boss and a veritable comedian.  Take it.

Definitely take it if you want a challenge. I learned a lot. But it could also be super frustrating. And definitely go to Marc or your preceptor with any questions. They are really receptive and helpful.
Don't Take this Course.
Don't do it if you don't have to.
Don't get too frustrated! The class is worth it. Go into office hours and ask questions about the coding and the concepts as needed.
Enjoy lectures and precepts, go to McGraw for problem set help, and try to figure out the ambiguous quizzes. You'll learn a lot of programming too, which was awesome.

Fine stats course.  If you have to take this one, it's enjoyable, though at times difficult.  IF you haven't taken a coding class before, this is an interesting introduction, though we definitely didn't do nearly as much actual statistics as I expected.
Get ready for some hard work, but you'll learn some good skills (R), or at least have the resources to do it with the handouts as aids.
Go to office hours! You'll need it!
Good knowledge to have, but be prepared to struggle

Good stats course. Of the three required for woody woo, I feel this is perhaps the best one to take since you learn the most but it isn't necessarily as hard as Econ stats. R is more useful than STATA (which is used in woody woo stats) also.

I had never taken a statistics class before. I came in with high hopes, but unfortunately this course didn't feel coherent to me.  The lecturer was decent and often funny, and the preceptors were extremely hard-working and helpful, but at the end, the two different textbooks, recycled lecture notes (from the former professor, Kosuke Imai), and R-coding emphasized in precept produced somewhat of a disjointed experience. In addition, the first two quizzes were pains because there was little practice material and feedback (the material on problem sets and quizzes were not always closely related). The material was not difficult, but I probably would have learned more, and more easily, had I taken the subject as an AP class in high school.  

For me, R-coding was the funnest and most useful aspect of the course, giving me a tool I may use in future projects. Overall, I recommend POL 345 lukewarmly; it may well be better than some of the other statistics classes available, but I would look at the one offered in ORF if you want a more quantitative approach.
I recommend that you take it only if you have some free time. The material is dry, but the faculty is terrific. Stay on top of things and you should be fine!
I would highly recommend this course to anyone wanting or needing to take a stats course. It will require a good amount of time though.
I would not recommend this course if you do not have an actual interest in it. If you need it to complete a requirement, you might want to consider looking for alternatives.

I would say that, if you have an interest in politics, this is a fantastic course to take. The real-world applicability of this course is wonderful, and even if you do not have a background in statistics, as I did not, it is still a stimulating and fun course to take.
I would strongly recommend taking this course to anyone interested in statistics, economics, or politics.

I wouldn't recommend taking this course. It's not a lot of work if you've ever done any programming before, and the statistical concepts are not that hard. Lectures are confusing, though, and the textbook is awful--I chose to use ORF 245's Open Intro Statistics instead of the one assigned. I did not walk out of this course knowing how to use R. It only taught me how to hack my way around in R and eventually come to a solution after long hours of Google searching. If you're serious about learning statistics, I would recommend taking ORF 245, even if you're in politics or Woody Woo.
I'd recommend it with prof. Ratkovic, but I don't know if it'd be as good with someone else.

I've heard horror stories about other stats courses, but this one was actually, believe it or not, quite fun! The coding problem sets were challenging but really cool--especially when we wrote a program that used polling data to predict who'd win the election! Prof. Ratkovic is amazing and I highly recommend the class to anyone with an interest (or requirement) in Stats.
If you are a woody woo major or pol major looking for an easy stat class should consider pol 345.

If you don't have a solid understanding of statistics (and want a real world application of it, rather than simply knowing distributions and formulas), take this class. Otherwise, there are probably other electives that will be more enjoyable.

If you're looking for a QR and/or are looking to satisfy a POL departmental or WWS prereq, seriously consider this course.  Professor Ratkovic is an excellent lecturer, and the entire course is focused around the needs of the students.  The grading is very fair.
Like Professor Ratkovic said, it's like eating your broccoli.  It may be tough at times and you may not want to do it, but in the end coding in R and understanding statistics pays off.
Make sure you know that it will be a ton of work but you will also get a lot out of it.
Not fun, but take it if you have to.
Not too difficult but not the best class if you don't think computer programming is your thing.

One of the more tolerable of the stats courses if you must take one and are not a math whiz. Warning, though: there WILL be crazy math formulas on the board, and you WILL be overwhelmed. You don't need to totally understand them to do well, though.
Only take it if you are willing to put in a lot of work.
Prepare for a few long nights, but overall, not too bad of a class.  Make sure you understand the material, you can fall behind.
Put the work in from the beginning, and if you don't understand a concept, make sure you ask before moving on.

R is very useful, and this course gives you a great introduction to it.

Do the FPP reading even if it seems too basic; you'll be surprised at how you can do problems at the end of a given chapter without even realizing you learned something doing the reading.

Read the textbook and make sure to put some time into the weekly handout assignments. They will help definitely help you to understand the course material better. Also, get an early start on all of your problem sets. If you are given a week to do it then you will need a week. In regards to the optional R Code handbook, I found that I never needed to use it, so I wouldn't suggest buying it unless you think you will need it for things beyond the course. Also, even though the class was difficult at times, it was defintely worth the time and effort that I put into it.
See above. Definitely recommend if you have any interest in stats.

TAKE THIS COURSE! From what I hear of other harder stat classes at Princeton I would say Pol. Stat is definitely the best. Professor Ratkovic and the preceptors of this class are phenomenal and they are there to help you get through any material you find challenging
Take it if you want to major in POL or WWS and if Ratkhovic is teaching it.
Take it seriously!
Take it to become a proper reader of statistics and surveys - will open your eyes to many inconsistencies in the world.
Take it, relatively easy. Make sure to get started on problem sets early.
Take this class if you want to know about stats and have enough time to invest in the problem sets!
Take this course - it is hard work but but outrageous, and you will learn very functional stuff.
Take this course but be willing to work really hard!
Take this course if you're interested in learning more about statistical analysis

Take this course with Professor Ratkovic. I think this was his first time teaching at Princeton--I'd say this was a pretty fantastic start! He really cares about his students, he implements their feedback constantly while still maintaining the rigor and organization of the course, he's approachable and even funny. They better hire him back, for the sake of all future stats students. It's definitely a tough class though--don't take it expecting a cakewalk. You really have to put in the effort. But it's really cool how you finish the course with real skills in R and a solid grasp of the concepts. And stats is such a useful thing to know.
Take this course, but be prepared to spend the entire weekend before a problem set is due working on it. And start early.
Take this course, especially if Prof. Ratkovic is teaching it!!!!!!!!!!!
The class is more code than you might expect from an intro Stats class. Otherwise, fun and you'll learn a lot.

The class may seem confusing as you're going through it, but it comes together at the end. Stay on top of your work, keep reviewing concepts if you're stuck, and don't give up! The professor and TAs are always available to help, so go to them whenever you need help-- I wish I had done that earlier. There is a lot of support in the course if you seek it out, so just be sure to do that if you are struggling.
This class is hard, but worth it. You get out what you put in - I definitely recommend it!

This course is intensive and requires regular work. However, the readings are short, and the preceptors and tutors at McGraw provide ample help if you are having any trouble. I actually think that I spent less work in this class than in any of my "reading" classes. I strongly recommend this course if you wish to complete the Statistics requirement for Woody Woo.
This course is pretty easy if you work at it. Once you've figured out R, it's a breeze.

This course requires consistent effort the whole semester, so be prepared to work. However, it is a very rewarding class because you WILL learn R coding language and stats. The teaching staff has high expectations but is also very understanding so the overall experience is a very positive one!

This course was very challenging and time consuming. But the professors and preceptors love the material and want you to love it as much. They take a lot of time to explain concepts to you and if you seek help they provide it. Don't take this for an easy grade. It's hard. But you'll learn a lot and the teaching quality is very high.
This is an interesting - and very useful! - QR.

Unless you're very interested in statistics, I would not recommend this class, even if you are a POL major. However, we did learn some stuff that proved useful to my independent work the last week of lecture.
Work like you've never worked before to gain good skills
Yes, but be ready to put in a lot of work. Read the book, and keep up to date on lecture slides, but skip a lot of lectures in the second half.
You will learn very important and practical things from this class. The coursework is quite time consuming and hard, but do not be discouraged. Give it a try.
definitely the best stats option for wws students--i thought it was hard, but prof. ratkovic and the preceptors were amazing and wanted us to do well. i recommend it for stats if you're in wws.
prereqs: High school algebra. Familiarity with elementary probability theory and computer programming is useful, but not required..
descrip: What accounts for who votes and their choice of candidate? Would universal health insurance improve the health of the poor? Researchers and policy makers use statistics to answer these questions. However, the validity of their conclusions depends upon underlying assumptions and correct application of statistical methods. The course will introduce basic principles of statistical inference and programming skills for data analysis. The goal is to provide students with the foundation necessary to analyze data in their independent research at Princeton and to become a critical consumer of news articles and academic studies that use statistics.

title: Modern Political Theory
reviews: A lot of work, but really interesting.
Be prepared to read a lot. But generally interesting and Ryan is certainly a character.

Be ready for some tedious lectures that may be hard to stay up in, but the thinkers discussed in this class are so amazing that you may find some of the most intellectually stimulating ideas in this class.
Definitely do the readings! You really won't understand what's going on otherwise and it's obvious in precept if you can't contribute.
Do all the readings.  Think about them- this is necessary for the exams and essays.
Do the readings.
Don't.
Good introduction to political theory, good as a general distribution requirement or to test the waters and how you feel about political theory.
I am a science major and I still think this class was extremely engaging an interesting. One of my best courses here!
I don't know, I personally did not find myself that interested in political theory.  But if you were I bet you would find this a serious, demanding, engaging, and stimulating course.
I strongly recommend this class to any political majors.
I would recommend this if you're looking for a broad overview of critical political thinkers. The teacher is great and the material is interesting.

It is a lot of reading, but this course is very enriching and gives you an excellent grasp on political theory if you do all of the reading.  I would recommend this class to anyone interested in political theory.

It's helpful to have background knowledge in political theory, since the content of the class is challenging. However, Professor Ryan is an excellent professor and it's certainly worth it for whoever's willing to take on the challenge. The workload is very manageable.
Make sure you stay on top of your readings
Only take if you're interested in theory and have some background in European history/politics.

POL 303 was a really engaging course...you have to let go of some modern presuppositions and really grapple with what philosophers of centuries past dealt, and if you can't just go to lecture and listen to the stories Professor Ryan will tell.
Sit close to Professor Ryan during lecture. It's a lot of work to do well, but reasonably light to PDF.
Take it.
Take this course if you have even a passing interest in politics or philosophy. It is worth your while and greatly enhances your thinking.
Take this course! It was very interesting and made you defend (and perhaps change) your views on the world.
Take this, especially if you're interested in the theoretical aspect of politics.
This is a good, solid course. The material is interesting and that sort of stuff that everybody should know. There is a lot of readings, but not a ridiculous amount.

This is a reading intensive course, so if you sign up for it make sure you have the time to read at least some of the material during the semester. It is possible to catch up on the reading during breaks, but staying on top of things will save you from headaches later on in the course.

This is a very solid--but not mind-blowing--introduction to modern political thought.  This is a course mostly about the works themselves, not their historical context (other than the American and French revolutions very generally).  If you're interested in political theory and are independently motivated to keep up with the readings and really think about the papers, you'll enjoy this course.  But if not--if you want something that will more actively engage you--consider another course.  Or take it with a friend or two--I got a lot out of informally discussing the material before class.
This was one of the best courses I've taken. Make sure to do the readings carefully and thoroughly.
read head the assigned readings - they are a lot!
descrip: This course discusses political order, law, revolution, freedom, democracy, and feminism in the writings of Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau, Tocqueville, Marx, and Mill.

title: Brainwaves in Language Research
descrip: This course provides a hands-on introduction to the use of electroencephalography (EEG) in language research. Students will be introduced to the fundamentals of EEG as a tool for cognitive neuroscience, as well as the specific goals and logic of EEG experiments in the study of language processing. Students will design, deploy, and analyze a novel EEG experiment during the course of the semester.

title: Mass, Momentum, and Energy Transport
reviews: Don't take it unless you have to. If you do, just...stay on top of the work and pray.
Go to lectures and read the notes. Don't try to do problem sets by yourself. It's doable but is simply a waste of time.
Good course.
Good luck! Make sure to go to office hours and just try to survive this class.
I probably wouldn't have taken the course if I wasnt CBE, but it still was a pretty interesting course.
I would just warn future students that this class will present you with things you've never before seen therefore succeeding requires attention and commitment.
If you are a CBE, grin and bare it.  Otherwise, run!
Interesting material, great class!
It's a departmental so you don't really have much of a choice.
Make sure you don't get behind! Everything builds on the previous topic.
Not as terrible as everyone makes it out to be. Certainly challenging but can remain doable if one is proactive in the course and stays on top of material throughout.
Only take this class if it is required.
Read the notes in depth before every lecture.  The reinforced material will help you learn it better and faster.
Study hard.
Take if necessary, otherwise it is unnecessary information
The material is challenging, but actually really interesting when you connect concepts across the three modules. Just remember that transport is not only about pipes. It's also about dinosaurs.
This is a great course on a lot of cool physics that you don't usually get in freshman physics. Don't be swayed by the "pipes" nickname.
Try to read the lecture notes before lecture.

When Brynildsen says to read the lecture notes before lecture, it's a very good idea, otherwise you tend to be overwhelmed by all the new material coming at you. This course is difficult for sure, but I also found it very rewarding after finally getting through it. Go to office hours, ask as many questions as you can, seriously. If you don't have one already, find a group to check problem sets with - it's very easy to get mixed up or make stupid errors.
You have to take it anyway, may as well enjoy it.
You have to, so yeah.
difficult course since you go through the material quickly-try to stay on top of things.  office hours are useful for help on psets or general questions.
prereqs: CBE 245, CBE 246, and MAE 305. MAE 305 or MAT 427 may be taken concurrently..
descrip: Course will survey modeling and solution methods for the transport of fluids, heat and chemical species in response to differences in pressure, temperature and concentration. Both steady state and transient behavior will be examined.Topics include fluid statics; conservation equations for mass, momentum and energy; dimensional analysis; viscous flow at high and low Reynolds number; thermal conduction; convective heat and mass transfer, correlations; diffusion and interphase mass transfer. Working knowledge of calculus, linear algebra and ordinary differential equations is assumed.

title: Engineering in the Modern World
reviews: Actually go to the lecture.
Be careful with lab partners, they will make or break your grade!
Definitely take it.
Don't take it as a dist. requirement if you absolutely don't find any interest in the material. Even studying to get that C- is a pain with how boring the readings are.
Find someone to be your lab partner that you know will be helpful.

Great PDF. Will need to put in time on labs but the PDF option gives you leeway if you want to submit late labs or if your lab report format is kind of shitty, which it could well be if you're not used to writing them. All the more reason to PDF and get that STL out of the way.
Great class, but do everything in your power not to get Michael Roussel as your preceptor.

Great class. Moderate to slightly intense work load. Taught in an interesting way. Go to lectures, they are really interesting (cool demonstrations) and explain basically everything you need to know in the course. Get a Friday lab so that if you turn it in late,  you have the whole weekend to work on it and it only counts as one day of grading penalty.
I mean, you know why you're here. Do it - there's only five labs and five homework assignments. Passing the midterm requires only the slightest bit of computational competence.
I would advice that student to take the course.

If you need a lab and are planning to P/D/F, it's a hard class to fail. If you enjoy the subject material and don't mind doing calculations, then you'll probably enjoy it. But don't expect to have you mind blown, or for independent thought to be encouraged or required.

If you put in a minimum amount of work, you'll get an A. Almost everyone P/D/Fs it, so the grade is wicked easy.

However, putting in that minimum amount of work will be torturous. The labs are pretty tedious, the lectures dry as anything, and the readings bore you to tears. I highly recommend taking a class you're interested in but that is slightly harder.

Of course, you could also P/D/F. If you do, you basically do no real work.
It's a lab and a fairly easy A. You really won't get anything out of it other than those two things.
It's easy, but not very interesting. Take this if you care more about learning about engineering in a historical context, or if you're bad at math.
It's the best of the worst.

Just take this class knowing that you shouldn't just think of it as a slack off distribution requirement course. Be ready to put in the amount of work that you should be ready to put in any other class.
Make sure your lab partners are PDF'ing or not in line with your grade decisions. Matt Streeter is awesome, too.
PDF. If you don't, study hard for the finals.
Perfect for a non-engineer looking to pass a distribution requirement
Take because it is a joke and also fairly interesting.
Take it if you want an easy and interesting STL course.

Take it if you want if you need a manageable 5th class. However, I suggest you take it as an HA as opposed to STL as the labs are rather tedious and not worth the trouble if you don't need to fulfill that distribution requirement.
Take this class. Not that bad for STL if you are a non-science major.
Take this course if you want to understand the fusion of science and history.
This is a good STL to take.
Understand the theories and who came up with each invention
You know what you're getting.
a course requirement that gets the job done.
take the lab section, there is a lot less work than the history section
descrip: Lectures and readings focus on bridges, railroads, power plants, highways, airports, harbors, automobiles, aircrafts, computers, and the microchip. The laboratory centers on the scientific analyses that are the bases for these major innovations. The experiments are modeled after those carried out by the innovators themselves, whose ideas are explored in the light of the social contexts within which they worked.

title: Studies in the American Novel - Henry James and William Faulkner
descrip: This course examines the careers of America's two most accomplished novelists. Manifest differences aside, both authors are obsessed with the ensnaring effects of plot, and imagine fictional realms that are as much "designs" on the reader as on their characters. Reading each author against the other, recurrent emphases become clear: on the language of perception and the relativism of perspective; on a Keatsian dialectic of chaotic vitality and lifeless aesthetic perfection; on the morality of art and the "ethics of readings"; on the costs of education; and preeminently, on the active role of the reader.

title: Popular Delusions and Wisdom of Crowds
descrip: http://www.princeton.edu/pub/frs

title: Human Adaptation
reviews: A decent ST; not an easy A though
A good option for a fulfilling a lab requirement. It is also interesting and you will learn a lot.

ANT 215 is a wonderful STL course for non-science majors. It is challenging without being overwhelming, and the focus is on understanding and analysis. It allows you to explore not just the scientific aspects of evolution (though these are fascinating and well worth knowing) but also what it means to be human on a broader level. As a student majoring in the humanities, I have found that this course has greatly enhanced my understanding of language, culture and the human condition.
As a no PDF, it is a relatively easy B, but a difficult A.

Be prepared to look at a lot of bones. If students think this is just an easy lab, it is not. The labs are hard to do well on. I would only recommend the class if you are genuinely interested in the subject matter.
Be sure to be extremely detailed in everything you turn in in order to ensure a fair grade.  Although the professor is very nice and helpful, the grading is harder than one would think.
Do NOT take it as a "general interest" class. You must already know that you like the evolutionary history of humans in order to have a chance at getting decent grades. Grading is very harsh.
Do the readings.
Grading is tough, but material and teaching are great. Take it if you have either a general interest or a distribution requirement to fulfil. You won't regret it!

I would tell other students taking this course to pay good attention in the lectures because the material presented there primarily is what you're held accountable for on exams. I sort of feel, however, that I can't give a true recommendation for this course because Professor Monge is not the regular professor so my experience in the course was likely different than it would have been if the normal teacher were leading it.

If Janet Monge is teaching this course, please do not take it. At one point, we were a month behind in lectures but on schedule with labs, which made it really difficult to stay on track with everything. From what most of us saw, Janet Monge seemed to think the class was a joke. She never gets back to students with emails, she gets very distracted in lectures, and she has horrible public speaking skills (she said "k" after every word for the entire semester), which makes it really hard to survive an 80 minute lecture. Also, if you think you'll learn about HUMAN adaptation, I'm sorry, because all you'll learn about is fish and apes. Please do not take this class.
If you are interested in anthropology and are willing to do the readings and prepare for the labs, I would definitely recommend taking this class.
If you want a good overview of human evolution, take this class. The lab was good too.
It's a great course to get a lab requirement and learn more about anthropology.
Only if they don't mind spending time in lab
Other students I spoke with seemed to agree with me that it is very easy to do fine but much more difficult to do well in this class.
Pay attention to/go to lecture!
Stay up to date with the lecutres and the readings, otherwise it will be difficult to do well on your labs.
Take it
Take it if you have to and if you're willing to put a lot of time into the labs before hand.
Take it!  The professor(s) who teach it are awesome.  I looked forward to lectures - tons of great, funny stuff
Take notes and ask for help on labs.
The class material is dry, the professor can be frustrating, but it's a relatively easy STL.
This is a great class to take if you want to fill your STL and have an interest in evolution. It is a fun class and does not require much work!

This is an AMAZING course, and I am so happy that I took it. I am sad that it is over. Although the 80 minute lectures are long, Professor Monge is great and makes them very entertaining, insightful, and interesting. She is a wonderful lecturer and a very funny person.  

The readings are interesting but are, for the most part, unnecessary. The labs are fun, you often get out early. The grading was somewhat particular, but not too harsh. Try and pay attention during the lecture, the midterm is based solely on that. Towards the end of the course, I found that it was better for me to take notes by hand and not on my laptop.
readings aren't that helpful/necessary, but go to the lectures because they are worth it and you get so much more out of it than just looking at the slides
take with Mann, and avoid it if Monge is instructing unless she uses her own ppt.
the professor is great, its probably a good lab course for non scientists
you dont have to do the readings, but definitely do the readings before lab sessions
descrip: Human adaptation focuses on human anatomy and behavior from an evolutionary perspective. Lectures and weekly laboratory sessions focus on the evolution of the human brain, dentition and skeleton to provide students with a practical understanding of the anatomy and function of the human body and its evolution, as well as some of its biological limitations. No science background is required on the part of the student.

title: Topics in Medieval Art, Architecture, and Theory: Concepts for the Depiction of God
descrip: Discusses the conditions of image making and theory in the Middle Ages. The course will focus on how to represent God in the visual arts, introducing iconographic concepts and their reception. Single image-types will be analyzed on the basis of sociological and intellectual history and from different historiographic view points. Discussions of selected readings will raise questions and suggest approaches to the iconographic material. Issues covered in this course are: institutionalizing Christianity in Late Antiquity, the idea of authenticity for various types of icons, iconoclasm, the image of God in Scholasticism, and allegory.

title: Heat Transfer
reviews: Final project was tough but very rewarding
Go to office hours- Professor Nosenchuck is very approachable and helpful!

Nosenchuck is a great person in a small class setting. He got to know him very well and always enjoyed coming to class. We had 5 problem sets which were all reasonable, and a final project which was a lot harder but nosenchuck offered us lots of help. The lecutures follow the required book almost exactly, so I would take notes in a book.
TAKE IT.
The problem sets aren't too time consuming and the class is interesting if you're interested in the subject.
