prereqs: MAE 221 and MAE 222, or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course will cover fundamentals of heat transfer and applications to practical problems in energy conversion and conservation, electronics, and biological systems. Emphasis will be on developing a physical and analytical understanding of conductive, convective, and radiative heat transfer, as well as design of heat exchangers and heat transfer systems involving phase change in process and energy applications. Students will develop an ability to apply governing principles and physical intuition to solve multi-mode heat transfer problems.

title: Microeconomic Policy
descrip: oh, dear

title: Design of Reinforced Concrete Structures
reviews: Be excited to take it (since you probably have to)!
DO IT
Great class! You will learn a ton.
If you are interested in designing a floor system or columns, take this course. Garlock is very helpful even if the material is not very exciting.
It's an alright class. The class could definitely use some refining though
Study!

Take notes during lecture and you will have a much easier time with homework assignments because you'll understand the concepts behind the problems much better. This is one of the few required courses in CEE that I have really enjoyed even though it is a tough class.
This is one of the first practical structural engineering classes I've taken. It reassured me that this is what I wanted to study.
You are probably only taking this as a requirement, but don't worry, you'll enjoy this.
prereqs: CEE 205.
descrip: Materials in reinforced concrete. Flexural analysis and design of beams. Shear and diagonal tension in beams. Short columns. Frames. Serviceability. Bond, anchorage and development length. Slabs. Special topics. Introduction to design of steel structures.

title: Topics in Knot Theory - Knot Floer homology
prereqs: Undergraduates must request permission of instructor..
descrip: Knot theory involves the study of smoothly embedded circles in three-dimensional manifolds. There are lots of different techniques to study knots: combinatorial invariants, algebraic topology, hyperbolic geometry, Khovanov homology and gauge theory. This course will cover some of the modern techniques and recent developments in the field.

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Engineering - Parallel Computation
reviews: If you want to have a deep understanding of computer architecture and parallel computing, you should definitely take the course
Make sure you participate in class discussions.  You will get much more out of the course if you participate than if you sit and listen to others discussing.
Take it if you're interested in parallel computing.
Take it.
descrip: Course covers advanced parallel computer architecture and parallel programming. Multicore, many core and large multi-machine architecture and programming will be covered. Discussion-oriented class focuses on in-depth analysis of research papers and primary sources. Final project/paper required. Juniors, seniors, and graduate students from ELE, COS, and related fields welcome.

title: Accounting for Taste
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Method and Logic in Quantitative Biology
reviews: A fantastic class if you're interested in quantitative biology. The professors are awesome and the discussions lively. Like a bonus semester of ISC.
An excellent course for getting a sense of quantitive biology!
Challenging material with a rockstar team of professors, definitely worth taking if you have an interest in quantitative biology.

I did not have much of math background. I was more comfortable with the papers in the class, compared to students with physics background, but I had to struggle a bit for the problem sets. Over all, I learned a lot from both parts.
I would advise students to brush up on their differential equations and to participate as much as possible.
I would recommend this course if you a physics student who thinks you want to do biophysics, or for any MOL concentrator.
If you are interested in quantitative biology and biophysics definitely take this awesome class. It is especially cool when Professor Botstein and Wingreen teach this class together.
If you are working in and is interested in knowing about classic work, this is a great class. And definitely even if you know about these things, this class will add to your knowledge
If you lack linear algebra, the course is still possible but will be more challenging, make sure to visit the TA often and start the problem sets early.
Only take if you have a strong math, quantitative biology background. This must include coding and linear algebra/statistics.

Overall an excellent class. It makes you think about a wide range of topics and provides a good foundation for future studies. Even if at times it was difficult, in the end a very worthwhile course, especially considering it also counts as a core.
Read the paper carefully, and be brave to say your ideas loudly.
Start the homeworks early, make friends that know math.
TAKE IT! Best class I have taken at Princeton, by far. The professors are so amazing and the material you learn is also fantastic.
Take it!!! get ready for a hellish couple of problem sets though... totally worth it.
Take it!!!! But watch out for the time: 3-6pm on Fridays.

The problem sets are difficult and require a good amount of work but the class is great.  If reading primary literature and learning how to design quantitative biology experiments sounds fun then take it.
This course is not easy, but definitely worth it.
prereqs: Prior knowledge of calculus (differential equations) and linear algebra..
descrip: Close reading of published papers illustrating the principles, achievements, and difficulties that lie at the interface of theory and experiment in biology. Two important papers, read in advance by all students, will be considered each week; the emphasis will be on discussion with students as opposed to formal lectures. Topics include: cooperativity, robust adaptation, kinetic proofreading, sequence analysis, clustering, phylogenetics, analysis of fluctuations, and maximum likelihood methods. A general tutorial on Matlab and specific tutorials for the four homework assignments will be available.

title: Contemporary Chinese Society and Culture
reviews: A lot of reading, but an interesting exposure to big events and trends in contemporary China.

Definitely take this course if you're interested in modern Chinese history (from founding of PRC to today) and want to talk about topics such as the Mao, the Cultural Revolution, or McDonald's in China.  The readings are a bit long but easy reads.  The midterm paper is pretty normal and the final project is a lot of fun.  There's a final exam but it's not very difficult, as long as you have been going to lecture.  Best class I've taken at Princeton so far and the Prof. is really engaging.
Great class, must take! Prof. Li makes the material interesting and is very engaging. One of the best classes I've taken here.
I would definitely recommend this course to other students.

Stay on top of your readings and go to office hours! Professor Li is very helpful and welcome to all sorts of suggestions. The writing isn't too difficult but Professor Li does expect a lot of your individual scholarship and has high standards for your ability to connect themes and write concisely and coherently.
Take this class if you have even an iota of interest in Contemporary China. You'll love it and Professor Li as well.

Take this course, but plan to work! It's a really interesting survey course if one wants to understand contemporary China and it's development since the Cultural Revolution, and Professor Li is an amazing lecturer.
This course is great for learning about modern Chinese history. The professor is challenging and also understanding. I learned a lot from her!
This is a great intro course for Chinese society and culture. I feel that I gained a lot of knowledge from this course, and topic interests for future research.

Would recommend: Prof. Li is a very engaging lecturer and she knows how to keep everything interesting and relevant. The use of films as well as informative readings created a strong foundation for lectures and precepts. One of the better classes I've taken.
descrip: This course surveys the history, culture, and society of the People's Republic of China from 1949 to the present. Using historical, literary, journalistic, ethnographic, and filmic texts, it seeks to provide understanding of people's lived experiences through recent historical turmoil and contemporary transformations. Apart from covering the impact of major events like the Great Leap Forward, the Cultural Revolution, and the 1989 Tiananmen protests, we will study topics such as memories of socialism, the rise of consumer culture and migrant labor, changes to Chinese families, cities, and popular culture, as well as the role of new media.

title: Religion and Critical Thought Workshop
descrip: A weekly, year-long workshop focused on current student and faculty research in religion and critical thought, designed primarily for graduate students working on dissertations and general examination essays on the philosophy of religion, religious ethics, and the role of religion in politics.

title: Quantitative Principles in Cell and Molecular Biology
reviews: A good introduction to biological sciences, suitable for students both in and out of MOL/EEB departments.

A very interesting Intro Bio class. Note that I would not recommend it to someone with a poor background in biology; the class seems to assume a lot of background knowledge. This class differs from a traditional intro class in that instead of giving a broad overview, the class delves into some specifics and intricacies of topics and experiments that one would cover in an only cursory manner in a traditional intro course.
DEFINITELY take if you like math and bio and just want to reach a better understanding of biological thinking.

Definitely take this course! The Professors are so amazing, so approachable, and so helpful. I also loved my TA, who was always willing to answer questions, and my classmates. There's something about MOL215 and its labs that just really bring people together :) Definitely made some really good friends in that course :) The exams are usually very long, so work fast and don't spend too much time pondering one question.
Definitely take this course. If your deciding between MOL 214 and MOL 215, take 215!
Don't be intimidated by the hard-sounding title. It's a great class.
Go to lecture - much of what is covered in lecture is NOT in the book.
Highly recommended.

I loved it. It was more work than I expected going into the course, but it was still very manageable. Plus, this is Princeton, what do you expect. There is a very strong focus on concepts rather than memorization, which played to my strengths. Because it is interdisciplinary, you will be seeing a lot more physics, chemistry, and math than you would expect in a biology course, but I feel that's also the direction the field is heading in anyway.
I would recommend if you enjoy biology
I would recommend taking this course to another student interested in potentially pursuing a major in Molecular Biology because it provides a good background in the subject and what biology is like.

If you like biology at all, it's a good class to take. Without being an overly large amount of effort, you learn about a lot of cool biological topics you would probably skip in MOL 214. The class emphasizes conceptual understanding over memorization which makes it a lot more enjoyable to learn. Don't be scared by the "quantitative" component if you're not mathematically inclined - most of the math is pretty gentle, and the professors don't expect you to be able to derive equations or anything on your own.
If you want to get a background to MOL, you will - just don't expect anything too rigorous.

If you're interested in biology but want to do more than just memorize, this is a great course. It would be best if you were still fairly familiar with AP chemistry and Calculus, as well as a bit of physics as there will be some math in the course, not all that much though. Major quantitative topics include looking at diffusion to analyze kinetics, free energy changes and binding, and Poisson statistics in relation to cancer. Also a big part of this class is understanding the classical experiments behind biology and how we know what we know, so expect to read some papers and understand how they arrived at their conclusions. Exams also have this emphasis, and might ask you to create an experiment similar to one looked at in class, or to predict the results if a given mistake had been made. The material was really interesting, and I would strongly recommend this course if you at all remember Math and Chemistry from high school and want to know some of the why and how behind biology. Workload is relatively light, with weekly problem set/lab report hybrids which are really short. Exams are not very difficult if you remember AP Biology, pay attention in lectures and at at least looked at the assigned readings.

If you're worried about the math, don't be. I came in with one of the weaker math backgrounds and came out solid. Professors can sometimes be brief and unclear about the underlying math concepts during lecture, but they are always very helpful and accessible either after class or during office hours. Do Sriram's lab if he's still TAing.
It's a pretty chill and interesting class.
Not a lot of memorization but there is a lot of mathematics
Only take it if you are mathematically inclined

Start lab problem sets ahead of time, so you can get help with difficult questions
Go to office hours frequently; all of the professors are really helpful
Stay on top of the lab reports and the readings and you'll be golden!
Take MOL 214 because this class is a little disorganized. I didn't like that we were learning seemingly random experiments. Also, there aren't many practice tests at all.
Take advantage of the readings! They're not required but they're very helpful, especially if you miss lecture that day.
Take it!
Take it. Why not?
Take this class! DO IT!
Take this if you enjoy combining mathematics and biology.
This course is a good option for premed biology if you are interested in the quantitative aspects of molecular biology. Overall, it was enjoyable.

This course is not much memorization but more of concepts. It is important to go to lectures because the exams are based on that. Keep up with the readings though! I did not keep up because there are no weekly precepts and had a hard time during exam periods.

This course is very interesting and does not involve a lot of work other than studying for the midterms and final.  Professor Nelson is an excellent lecturer.  Just be aware that the course seems a little disorganized which makes it easy to not put a lot of effort into the course.
Very interesting, work hard on labs and pay good attention in lecture.

While most students have to take this course the teaching of Prof. Nelson and Prof. Felton make this course bearable. Prof. Korrenykh struggled somewhat but since it was his first year one can see opportunity for improvement.
You should have calculus and some experience with statistics if you are lucky. Always do practice exams. Emphasis is on the concept even if you can't understand or memorize specific details.
have fun in lab!
make sure you have a strong mathamatical backgorund
yolo
prereqs: AP Biology, Physics, Calculus..
descrip: Central concepts and experiments in cellular, molecular, and developmental biology with an emphasis on underlying physical and engineering principles. Topics include important insights into the genetic code; energetics and cellular organization; communication, feeding, and signaling between cells; ideas about feedback loops and cellular organization; problems and solutions in development; and the organization of large cellular systems, such as the nervous and immune systems. Satisfies the requirement for entrance into the Department and the requirement for entrance into medical school.

title: International Economics
descrip: Survey course in international economics for non-specialists. The first half covers microeconomic topics such as trade theory and policy, multilateral trade negotiations and regional economic integration. The second half addresses macroeconomic topics such as current account imbalances, exchange rates, and international financial crises. The course stresses concepts and real-world applications rather than formal models. Prerequisite: 511b and 512b (concurrently).

title: Thermodynamics
reviews: Although the beginning of the course is rather tedious (and boring), it's really important to understand the concepts that crop up in the latter portion of the course when the more "exciting" concepts appear.

Be ready to put in the time required to produce a decent lab report, don't over-think them either.  It may feel like you're regurgitating the handout, but that is just because they want to make sure you understood the information inside of it.
Be sure to comb the textbook for examples, and attend the classes- they clarify the oftentimes broad lecture.
Do the problem sets.

Don't take it unless you're an MAE major (or have an already established interest in the topic). (As an aside, the *lab* portion of the course is AWESOME! Mike and Keith are absolutely spectacular at teaching concepts and engaging students. That being said...) The book is terrible (except for the chapter on cycles), the graphs are confusing, book keeping is so extensive that a four question problem set could easily take 10 hours, and while in some cases the concepts are pretty interesting, they're also frequently convoluted. If you do end up taking the course, make sure you read the notes posted on blackboard. If you have a take-home midterm exam when you take the class, start it as soon as humanly possible. No, seriously. It's LONG.
Fairly manageable, likely a distribution requirement
Focus on the homework. The homework counts for a freakish percentage of the grade. Also, prof Hultmark cares a lot about whether you are showing up to class.
Go to ever yoffice hour possible to try to understand how to do the homework. Do not do it the last night before it's due.
Go to office hours. Start the problem sets and lab reports early.
Go to the professor's office hours instead of the AI's for help on the problem sets.
However much time you think you're going to spend on thermo a week; add five more hours.

I know it's a requirement for MAE, so you're pretty much stuck with it, but if at all possible, avoid this class at all costs. The subject mater was extremely boring, and the professor and the way it was presented made it by far the worst class I've ever taken here. This class was so poor that it ultimately made me switch out of the MAE department. The good thing is the labs, which are separate from the actual class, and run by Mike, who is an awesome dude.

I've noticed that previous reviews have been somewhat negative in past years and I would like to assure other students that while the course starts out very slow, it gets much more interesting as the semester continues and the easy-to-follow lecture notes, problem sets, and laboratory sessions make it even better.  I would recommend this course, not only as required for those in MAE, but for others either interested in getting started with thermodynamics or even a college laboratory.

It's a departmental, so if you're MAE, you obviously have to take it. Professor Hultmark is very kind and helpful. However, the class unfortunately means pretty slowly. This seems to be a bit of a trend in MAE classes, and I'm learning a lot more in my other technical classes. If this is a worry for you, take this seriously... Think a lot about your major.

The labs are fun when you're actually in lab, but in the end the information is pretty boring and you don't learn much new. This makes the lab reports feel like way too much effort for not much learning (and they are a LOT of effort, even if you have a lot of experience). The grading is also an arbitrary rubric which you don't get to see, so it's a guessing game, and no extra points are rewarded for quality work.
Its an interesting course. Once you figure out the overarching method of solving thermo problems that class becomes alot simpler.  Hang in there.
Make sure to read the notes and do your best to find sections in the book corresponding to them.
Make sure you go the Professor Hultmark's office hours, they are very helpful in clearing up any questions you might have.

Not as hard as many people said! Hultmark is a really nice professor and he is super smart. Try to read more than his lecture notes- maybe the book or some online materials- and this would help clear the confusions out.
Only take it if it is a requirement.
Read Marcus' lecture notes. That is ALL you need to get a great grip of Thermodynamics.

Read Prof. Hultmark's notes! They are really helpful! 
As for the lab, I think it'll be better to have your lab later in the week. This way, you can ask TAs and Mike questions during the week before your lab is due since they don't respond to emails on weekend.

Read the lecture notes. They are very good. Go to office hours to find out how to do the problem sets. That will save a lot of time. Ask for what needs to be in the lab reports and technical reference sheets early and often so you don't get points off. The book isn't very useful for most of the course. Ask the TAs when you they think the book is useful to use. This is a very time consuming course so plan accordingly.
Start reading the textbook early along with Professor's notes. That would've helped a lot.

Take another department's thermo if they let you (i.e. CBE version), unless they changed this course a lot.  Hoped this course would be much harder and more enriching than it is; felt like I was wasting my time almost.
Take this if you are in MAE, otherwise I wouldn't suggest it.

The department reworks this class every year; it has not become as established or as polished as other courses. MAE Thermo has consistently bad reviews, every year, it seems. That said, it is very likely to change by the time you take it. The textbook by Moran and Shapiro is junk; I recommend reading a different one for intellectual enrichment.
The labs definitely make up for Hultmark's terrible lectures. Labs can be graded pretty harshly, don't worry about grades too much.

The material is much easier to understand than it seems. So read the notes carefully from day one and you'll learn the material well enough to score highly on exams. It's also cool to start learning how engines work. Hopefully Marcus is friendlier with the length of problem sets with future students...

The only reason I cannot in good faith strongly recommend against this class is because it is required for MAEs. It should be no means make or break a student's desire to be an MAE, but it is very difficult venture. Find upperclassmen who can help you and be sure to read the professor's notes. Collaborate on the problem sets and go to office hours. In short, get as much help as you can because it is nearly impossible to make it through alone.

The professor presented the material in the first few weeks in a lost, simplistic, and boring manner that attributed to most of my lack of engagement in the course. I was not prepared once the assignments started requiring a set of assumptions that were not well taught.

The subject matter should intrigue any true MAE. But as far as the work load is concerned, be aware that it's time consuming and difficult. It's important to do the textbook and notes reading BEFORE starting the problem sets. Otherwise you'll find yourself frustrated by the problems, as you have no conceptual basis or understanding of what's going on. Make sure not to fall behind in the material, as it keeps building on each other and you'll find yourself in the depths of confusion by thermo before you know it.

Thermodynamics = very interesting.
At least you'll have a better time then I did if you have to take it. If you think of taking it for fun, don't.
This is a great course if you have a genuine interest in the subject. The course load is quite high with both long problem sets and long lab write ups.

Unfortunately as an MAE you are forced to take this course. I'm very sorry. The labs are useful, but the lecture segment is horrific. Maybe there will be a different professor next year. If not, may the force be with you.
Use the lecture notes to go over the material and asked the lab technician exactly what he wants on the lab reports.
Well, it's an MAE requirement...has a lot of abstract concepts and difficult notation.  Really got interesting in the last couple weeks, but we had to learn the fundamentals first.
Work on problem sets with other people in your class.
prereqs: PHY 103 and MAT 201. MAT 201 may be taken concurrently..
descrip: Heat and work in physical systems. Concepts of energy conversion and entropy, primarily from a macroscopic viewpoint. Efficiency of different thermodynamic cycles, with applications to everyday life including both renewable and classical energy sources. In the laboratory, students will carry out experiments in the fields of analog electronics and thermodynamics.

title: Topics in Mathematical Modeling - Mathematical Neuroscience
reviews: A decent intro to theoretical/mathematical neuroscience, heavily biased towards dynamical systems approaches (so just realize the material is only a small subset of the whole field)

Be advised that the modeling done in this class is entirely reductionist. Models are proposed based on equations from physics, and their properties are evaluated regardless of whether they align with realistic data. Solid class for dynamical systems.
Everyone struggled with the math content.  Do not expect it to come easily despite success in other math courses.  Work with other students.

If you're interested in taking the course, know what you're getting into. It's a 300 level math class, and so if you're comfortable with that, I think you'll be alright. It has neuroscience in the title, but the emphasis is on the mathematics. If you think you might be interested in doing some sort of computational work for biological modeling, I think this course can help you decide if that's the field you want to work in.
It is a great class and you will learn a lot. Yet, unless you have a lot of time to devote to the class it will be difficult to keep up.
Study very hard. Only take this class if you're interested in computational/mathematical neuroscience or are a real applied math lover.

This course covers a huge variety of techniques while not going into a lot of depth for any of them. I'm certain the exposure will be useful down the road, but during the course it didn't feel like we really learned about anything. I recommend the course, with reservations.
prereqs: This interdisciplinary course in collaboration with Molecular Biology, Psychology and the Program in Neuroscience is directed toward upper class undergraduate students and first-year graduate students with knowledge of linear algebra and differential equations..
descrip: Draws problems from the sciences & engineering for which mathematical models have been developed and analyzed to describe, understand and predict natural and man-made phenomena. Emphasizes model building strategies, analytical and computational methods, and how scientific problems motivate new mathematics.

title: Neuroscience: from molecules to systems to behavior
reviews: If you are interested in learning about Neuroscience, meeting people who are into Neuroscience and getting great lectures from a lot of the faculty at Princeton, this is the class for you

Undergrads, this course's problem sets were sometimes a hell of a lot of work because of all the MATLAB you had to know. I spent up to 20 hours on one of them because of all the debugging I had to do to my program. I wouldn't take it as an undergrad. Undergrad courses are better-organized than this.
descrip: A survey of modern neuroscience in lecture format combining theoretical and computational/quantitative approaches. Topics include cellular neurophysiology, neuroanatomy, neural circuits and dynamics, neural development and plasticity, sensory systems, genetic model systems, and molecular neuroscience. This is one-half of a double-credit core course required of all Neuroscience Ph.D. students.

title: Modern Solid Mechanics
reviews: Any MAE has to take this. You'll spend time on it, but it should actually be a rewarding experience
Attend classes.

Definitely take this course if you're interested in any form of engineering. It's a good intro to engineering principles from a structural standpoint, and Haataja is a great resource of information. He genuinely cares that his students learn, and he encourages them to seek his help if they need. It's important to do the reading from the textbook before class; otherwise, it is difficult to follow the lecture and you'll find yourself frustrated and feeling like you're wasting time. So do the reading and pay attention - then you'll actually know what's going on and feel enriched after class. Bring the lecture notes to lecture so you can follow along, and take additional notes on them for the maximal effect.
Do problem sets well, and keep up with the course (especially toward the end)
Do the problem sets.

Do the reading. It is very light and helpful. Many of the problems in the problem sets correspond to the problems in the book. The lectures are very good and so are the office hours. The problem sets can be long and hard at times so plan accordingly.
Good course, though some problems require going to office hours/problem sessions so start on problem sets early, obviously.
I personally didn't go to the problem solving sessions, but I hear they help a lot, so go!
I'm not sure how interesting students would find this course if they didn't have a strong background in mechanics or found PHY103/105 to be interesting.
If you are a MAE student, you won't really have a choice about taking this class, but nonetheless Mikko is a great professor and Solid Mechanics is a good class.
If you are considering taking this course, you're the kind of person that would enjoy this course.

If you get interested then the course is great. Problem Sets take a bit of time when you do them for the first time but by the time the course is over youll be able to do the problem sets in under 30 mins each.
If you go to class and read the textbook you'll do fine.
If you need to take a Solids course, take it with Professor Haataja. He is incredibly engaging and clear and the course is perfectly reasonable in terms of time commitment necessary to do well.
Mikko is a great lecturer and his office hours are very helpful.
Mikko is a great lecturer and this has been my favorite class this fall.
My favorite class this semester
Only take it if it is a requirement.
Only take this course if it is a departmental, but know that you will enjoy it and learn a lot.

Read the Notes, Read the book, Go to lecture because Mikko tells awesome stories and is just agenerally an awesome person, spend a good deal of time preparing for the final it is much harder than the midterm.  Get to know the TA's as well they are great resources.
Somewhat interesting material, make sure to go to lecture and stay current on the concepts
Start the problem sets early, go to office hours. Review all of the completed problem sets that are returned to you.
Stay on top of things especially in the second half of the course which is significantly more difficult.
TAKE THIS COURSE!

Take it if you've taken PHY 103, whether or not you're not a Mechanical Engineer. From what I've heard about the CEE version, MAE 223 blows it out of the water. Professor Haataja is one of the best teachers at Princeton.
Take it, even if you're not MAE.  If you're CEE, consider Mikko's class if it fits into your schedule I don't think it's that easy to surpass his teaching skills in this subject.

Take this course.  Even if you're not an MAE student, if you have an interest (even a minor one) in the physics of solids, you won't be disappointed.  The lectures and readings are all very interesting and stimulating, but the course in no way drowns you with work as some other courses do.  The people working in this course seem to have a keen drive to make the experience of taking this course worthwhile, and it shows.  I strongly recommend it.

The lectures are really helpful and the slides explain stuff really well, but it also helps if you do the readings in the book. Prof. Haataja is a nice and very helpful guy, so do not hesitate to go to his office hours or just shoot him emails and ask questions. I like the course! Strongly recommend it!
This class is a good introduction to the sort of things useful for mechanical engineering, and you won't have to work too hard at it either
This class is hard. Really dedicate yourself to the material. It builds on itself and falling behind is deadly. Do problem sets with a group to make them take less time. The exams aren't terrible.

This is a challenging but rewarding course, and definitely well worth the time and effort. Professor Haataja is an awesome lecturer. However, be prepared for the problem sets and exams to be fairly challenging. Definitely find some friends to work with, because it helps immensely.
This is a great course if you are interested in the material and don't mind spending time on problem sets. The material is really interesting and the professor is absolutely amazing!
Very well taught class! Do the problem sets, go to precept, lecture, office hours and you're good for the class!
You'll probably take it because you have to, but it's not too painful if you work in groups and you pay close attention to the weekly readings - which aren't long at all and you'll learn a lot.
prereqs: MAT 104 and PHY 103.
descrip: Fundamental principles of solid mechanics: equilibrium equations, reactions, internal forces, stress, strain, Hooke's law, torsion, beam bending and deflection, and analysis of stress and deformation in simple structures. Integrates aspects of solid mechanics that have applications to mechanical and aerospace structures (engines and wings), as well as to microelectronic and biomedical devices (thin films and artificial hearts). Topics include stress concentration, fracture, plasticity, and thermal expansion. The course synthesizes descriptive observations, mathematical theories, and engineering consequences.

title: Extramural Research Project
descrip: A research project designed in conjunction with the student's adviser and an industrial, private or government sponsor that will provide practical experience relevant to the student's research area. Start no earlier than June 1. A final written report is required during the academic year.

title: Special Topics in Operations Research and Financial Engineering - Stochastic Methods for Quantitative Finance
reviews: A very good course with an excellent lecturer.

A very, very interesting course even if you only just like applied math and aren't even that interested in finance.  Van Handel is an amazing professor, and I loved how the topic was challenging but that it was presented in such an accessible way.

Do you want to learn Stochastic Calculus applied to Finance? TAKE THIS COURSE. It is fantastically taught and so clear that it seems easy. This was my best course this semester and I learnt a lot. It is not a theoretical course on Stochastic Calculus; It is really applied to finance and it is just marvellous
I learnt a lot. Take it. Ramon is a great professor.
If someone has a Mathematical inclination and  a strong interest in this field, I would strongly recommend this course to him/her.

If you're interested in stochastic calculus, this course gives you a good general understanding as it relates to finance. the professor does a good job of pacing the lectures to get the material across.
It's a really fun class and you actually learn intellectually interesting and practical stuff at the same time. (not many classes can be said to be like that). Also, van Handel is the boss.

Professor:
One word: AMAZING. Ramon is clearly EXTREMELY brilliant but what truly sets him apart from other smart professors is that, in spite of the fact that he operates at a much higher level than all of the students, he still has the ability to explain things at a level the students can understand. Going to lecture was an absolute pleasure and, speaking as someone who generally has terrible attendance, I couldn't help but attend every single one of Ramon's.

Lectures:
One word: AMAZING. Ramon is clearly EXTREMELY brilliant but what truly sets him apart from other smart professors is that, in spite of the fact that he operates at a much higher level than all of the students, he still has the ability to explain things at a level the students can understand. Going to lecture was an absolute pleasure and, speaking as someone who generally has terrible attendance, I couldn't help but attend every single one of Ramon's.

Tests and assignments:
The midterm was great, the homeworks were great, the final was too hard :/

Readings:
One word: WOW. Ramon's notes are so good they could explain stochastic calculus to a monkey. Seriously, I've never read anything like it. It goes back to his amazing ability to portray extremely complex concepts in such a way that anyone can understand them. After reading Ramon's notes, even someone who knew nothing about stochastic calculus before-hand would have a firm grasp of the subject.

Overall quality:
Everything comes back to Ramon and his awesomeness. He is an amazing lecturer and someone I truly respect and admire.
Take it, if only because Prof. van Handel is teaching it.
take take take TAKE this course if you're interested. you won't regret it.
very recommended for quant finance interested people
prereqs: ORF 309.
descrip: This course is an introduction to stochastic calculus at the undergraduate level with applications to financial models. The emphasis is on computational and practical techniques. Topics include: Brownian motion; Ito's formula; stochastic differential equations; partial differential equations; Girsanov's theorem; simulation and finite difference numerical methods; implementation in Matlab; applications in finance.

title: Japanese Society and Culture
reviews: Definitely take it!! If you have any sort of interest in Japan this course is critical in understanding the culture. Also Professor Borovoy's lectures are great, and the exams and one paper are totally reasonable.
Do it! A great class, and a fascinating look at another culture with a highly different and highly articulate(d) logical structure.
Have fun!

I would highly recommend taking this course. Again, Japan provides a particularly interesting case study, in its true exceptional nature that permeates so many facets of society and culture. It also serves to spark plenty of valuable discussion and critique of our own society, and so in this sense serves as a very valuable touchstone for our own lives in the Unites States/NA. This, coupled with a passionate professor, makes for a truly terrific course, that I am ever so glad I stumbled upon.
I would strongly recommend taking this course no matter what your amount of experience is with Japanese or EAS.

If you want to learn a lot about Japan, take this course. You'll learn a lot about their post WWII history, economics, their views on gender roles, views on mental illness, etc. and how all of these various things come together to structure their society today.

Professor Borovoy is an excellent professor with a genuine interest in her students.  Whether you have no previous exposure to Japanese studies or you are fairly well-versed, this class will expose you to aspects of Japanese society and culture that you otherwise would have never studied.  The class is engaging, and the work is stimulating but reasonable.
descrip: During the decades after World War II, Japan became the world's second largest economy and a highly educated, technologized society. While Americans once regarded Japan as a land of "corporate warriors," today Japan has become known for its popular cultural critiques of environmental destruction and for a gentler variety of capitalism that has weathered economic downturns while preserving a high quality of life for its people. We explore key social issues in Japan today: the contemporary "birth strike," gender and popular culture, civil society, medical ethics, difference and disability, adolescence and education.

title: Advanced Syntax
prereqs: LIN 302 or by application.
descrip: Explication and evaluation of recent approaches to the theory of syntactic representation, including the role of economy in a minimalist program. Topics will include the derivation of phrase structure and its interface with semantic interpretation.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - State and Local Finance
descrip: Examines budgeting and finance at the state and local level of government. Topics include: budget structure and process; decision makers within the political and economic environment; debt, capital planning and bond financing; revenue structures supporting expenditures. Tax policy and associated tradeoffs between tax equity and efficiency and spending and program needs are also examined. Two case studies are utilized---one related to state and local tax policy and one related to budgetary decision-making.

title: Ecosystems and Global Change
descrip: An introduction to the study of how humans are affecting complex ecological systems at local to global scales. Students will examine nutrient cycling, energy flow, and evolutionary processes, with emphasis on experimental approaches and comparisons between terrestrial, freshwater, and marine ecosystems. Particular attention will be on human influences-climate change, biofuels, biodiversity loss, eutrophication, and acid rain. Lectures cover theoretical elements and examples from the primary literature. The laboratory is organized around local ecosystems in which students conduct independent group research projects.

title: International Development
reviews: A non quantitative econ course for WWS students. You may not enjoy it much, but you'll basically have to take it.

Although the topic (international development) is interesting, be prepared to teach yourself or get help from the preceptor for a lot of the material in this class. Still, as a Wilson School concentrator trying to fulfill the 300-level ECO requirement, this class was a good option and not too math heavy.
Be sure to do the outside readings, because they provide the most critical look at traditional understandings of development.
Best way to fill the WWS ECO requirement if you're not an econ/math buff. Material is interesting and not too hard.

Decent course to take if looking for another ECO or WWS departmental: it's altogether interesting material, not too hard, and there's only a handful of problem sets, which, while a bit longer than usual problem sets (especially as an econ major, compared to other econ classes), aren't too hard.
Definitely a great course to consider if developing nations are something that interest them. Useful material to know in general, and not too difficult so not a class someone would regret taking.

Do not take this course if Professor Adsera is teaching it. Professor Adsera may be a smart researcher but she is not a good lecturer. I stopped attending lectures after Thanksgiving and found that I learned material much better by just reading the textbook without having Professor Adsera's lectures confuse the material. It is a shame that a class with such fascinating content is so poorly taught. Perhaps a different professor could teach it well.

Don't get Professor Adsera as a preceptor. She's very nice, but not very clear and talks incredibly fast. Also, this is not a great class if you don't have econ knowledge going in. I really struggled to keep up with lectures because I'm not an econ person but had to take this for my major. Problem sets are hard. You must go to office hours.
Easy class. The tests don't require much math.
I recommend the course, but make sure to attend all of the precepts and ask the preceptor for extra help if needed.

I would recommend this course. The reason why: the preceptor was really good. I've never had a preceptor in my whole time at Princeton as good as this preceptor, Chris. Other than that the field of economics the course focuses on overall is interesting since it deals with problems we are facing today.

I would take this if you are an ECO illiterate WWS major in need of an ECO credit, or if you have an interest in international development and are willing to put up with a professor who is less than ideal.

If you are not great at econ but need a requirement take this course. It is way better for the non-mathematically inclined than either of the intro classes, which are far harder and not necessary pre-reqs for this course. The readings will save you on the exam even if you do not really get the actual math part of the course.
If you're OK with being frustrated, you'll learn some interesting things. But I'd hold out for a different professor than Prof. Adsera.
It's a pretty easy, not very quantitative econ course. The multiple choice sections of the exams were a pain though.
Not really what I was expecting. Don't take this if Adsera is teaching. Her poor English is actually an issue when it comes to understanding lectures and certain info on problem sets.

Readings and problem sets are remarkably manageable (there aren't a lot to begin with, very rare at Princeton). Both Professor Adsera and Chris did an excellent job teaching this class and presenting the material in an interesting and relevant way. I loved this course and would highly recommend it!
Recommend this course - not too difficult, and you'll get a broad survey of various topics important to development
Take it if you want to learn more about the (very basic) economics behind international development.  If you're interested in general topics of international development, don't take this.
Take it only if you have to for the WWS requirement.

The course is not exciting or especially eye-opening, but it's a solid, easy course. It's not especially quantitative though, so even though the problem sets are numerical in nature, the exams test qualitative aspects of the material.
This is a really interesting class, unless you're looking for hard-core econ.
if Chris is a preceptor, take it
take it!
descrip: This course will focus on less developed countries and will consider topics such as economic growth and personal well-being; economic inequality and poverty; intra-household resource allocation and gender inequality; fertility and population change, credit markets and microfinance; labor markets and trade policy. The course will tackle these issues both theoretically and empirically.

title: Introduction to Genomics and Computational Molecular Biology
reviews: For a computer science student, this course contains too little meat.
Hard but worth it.
I would recommend attending office hours and precept, and definitely asking the TA or the professors for help or simply to clarify material.

I would recommend it to them if they have a good understanding of the basics of biology, especially genetics, and are interested in computer science or statistics. I would strongly recommend the course to anyone interested in computational biology or bioinformatics.
If they are interested in programming and biology then I would recommend the class.
Know or be familiar with some programming language before taking this course.
Take it, don't worry if you don't have programming experience. It will be hard, but very rewarding.

The TA, David Robinson, spent a lot of time helping students. Having TA'ed a similar-sized class at Princeton before, I understand the considerable amount of time that David put into the course. Definitely appreciated!
go to precept and office hours.
only take if you have coding experience. otherwise be prepared to spend a disproportionate amount of time in office hours, extra help, or just struggling through the homeworks.
descrip: Introduction to basic computational methods used for problems arising in molecular biology. Topics include computational approaches to: sequence similarity and alignment, phylogenic inference, gene recognition, gene expression analysis, structure prediction, and whole- and cross-genome analysis.

title: Chemical Reactor Engineering
reviews: Be prepared to be surprised on how different a grad course on Reaction Engineering is from undergrad. But a great learning experience and must be taken.
Be ready to participate and try to 'think' while taking the course.
Dr. Shvartsman asks a lot of questions to the class. Don't be afraid to try to answer them. Participation makes the class seem much more active.
Great course, I strong recommend this course to interested students. However, basic understanding of Matlab is required.
I would definitely recommend taking this course. It is taught very well and the material is presented in a clear and concise manner.

I would tell students to really keep up with the class (read over notes before and after class, make sure you can do all the derivations on your own, etc.) because Dr. Shvartsman will call you out on it if you don't!
Put in a LOT of time outside of class, and make sure you have a solid Matlab background.
Re-read your kinetics notes from undergraduate.
Read the posted lecture notes as soon as possible, and always refer to them first when you're not sure how to proceed on a homework problem (and when you think you are sure, also).
Review undergraduate material relevant to upcoming lectures.
Stay engaged in class and do not be afraid to ask questions.
Strongly recommended.

There probably aren't many people considering this class as it is required. Nevertheless, it was one of the most rewarding classes I have taken and one of the most engaging. Be prepared for lecture and think not just about the material as it is presented, but also potential applications and relevant extensions of the theory.
starthomework  early and schedule time to meet with the professor well in advance
descrip: Stoichiometry. Reaction kinetics and mechanisms. Types of chemical reactors. Steady-state and dynamic behavior of reactors. Mixing and non-ideal reactors. Porous catalysts. Stability and multiplicity. Multiphase reactors.

title: Microeconomic Theory: A Mathematical Approach
reviews: Avoid it if you can. If you can't, well, its not gonna be the highlight of your semester, sorry. Just get it out of the way. Its not particularly difficult, just very very dry and annoying.
Definitely take it, it's so much better than I imagine 300 would be, it's so interesting and it isn't even hard or a lot of work.  And Professor Abreu is wonderful!
Do not take this course unless it a requirement for your major or certificate program.
Don't
Don't take this, wait until the spring, and if you can avoid it, avoid it.
Go to class; use office hours; read the book
Go to office hours.

I was worried about the course because I didn't take ECO 100 beforehand, and I'm not a genius at math (I only did average in 201). Still, I found the class to be not nearly as challenging as people have made it out to be. Yes, you have to work, but if you can "think like an economist," you'll be fine.
If you are good at learning material on your own, take this course.

If you can do basic math (i.e. the simplest parts from MAT 201), are willing to suffer through a boatload of needlessly confusing crap from the instructors and don't mind doing endless algebraic simplifications, then this class won't be too bad for you.
If you like the material, you'll find a way to pull through. The last few problem sets can be ridiculously time-consuming; get smart collaborators and ask TAs for help.
It's an alright course. Take it if you're interested in the subject matter.
Keep trying on those problem sets! The experience of doing those is the best way to learn the material.
Make sure you have a solid understanding of multivariable calculus
Maybe take it in the spring, but it will be ok if you need to do it in the fall. Give Professor Abreu a chance.
Mentioned earlier.
Only if you need to.
Only take it if you have to; make a study group to do the problem sets with.
Only take this course if you are required to.

Precepts were very helpful. Lectures were very boring. Problem sets were rather hard.  Overall this class is required to get a finance certificate/ math track econ.  I would recommend only taking it if you are doing it for one of these reasons.  The material is rather interesting though.
Requires a lot of math. Some psets were really time-consuming and lectures can get heavy but some of the material is pretty interesting, esp in the later half
Study the slides before lecture and read the text book.  The lectures were terrible.
Take ECO 300.
Take it in the spring. You'll obviously need this class for several reasons but I guarantee you it is better to take in the spring. From what I've heard the spring class is a LOT more engaging.
Take it, but only if you like math and micro and need to.
Take it; really make sure you print out the lecture slides and bring them to class; be prepared to do math.
Take the class in the fall with Prof. Dilip Abreu. He is really good if you want to learn real econ.
Take the course in the spring when a different professor is teaching.
Take this course in the spring.

The class is manageable, but watch out for the second half of the course, as that's when the problem sets start to take more time. Definitely work in groups, you'll be spending a lot less time on problem sets than if you tried to tackle them on your own.
This is a difficult course, do not take it unless you must (ECO requirement, Finance certificate, etc.).
This is an excellent course if you have mathematical background.
This is an interesting intro to micro from a mathematical perspective. If you're not an econ major but want to take a micro class, take this instead of eco 100.
This is not a class to take if it is not required.

When doing problems, remember CORNER CASES. Also consider how answers change when ratios of prices, etc. change. Try and keep up with the readings, it will make the endless derivations in class more sensible. Some of the notation in the second half of the course seems unnecessarily dense, try and make sense of it. Try and think economically as opposed to just mathematically.
You're not taking it for fun, so these comments don't really matter. Dilip isn't as bad as people say, so don't rearrange your schedule just to avoid him.
don't take it
dont take 310 with abreu
n/a
take this class with a different professor
prereqs: ECO 100 and MAT 175 or MAT 201. Not required for concentrators..
descrip: This course presents the economic theory of individual and firm behavior using mathematical tools including calculus. The course will emphasize applications of microeconomic theory to consumer choices, output and production of firms, market interaction and equilibrium.

title: Techniques and Methods of Social Science
descrip: This course seeks to cover classic and contemporary approaches to social research with an emphasis on the logic of formulating questions to the empirical world and seeking reliable answers to them. Students will be asked to formulate and defend a research proposal on a topic of their choice. The elaboration of this research proposal is a central goal of the course. The core emphasis will be on the logic of theory formulation and hypothesis testing.

title: Fourth-Year Modern Chinese I
reviews: Eh.
I would definitely recommend this to other students.
If you're interested in Chinese and willing to put in the time and the work, take this class.
If you've survived to this point, this class should be no problem.
This course may seem redundant to those of you who just wish to learn conversational Mandarin, but the extra focus on expanding vocabulary is more helpful than you would think.
This is a good class to take to continue to improve your Chinese, but at this level the learning curve kind of slows down and it is not as rewarding. Starting to read literature is fun.
prereqs: CHI 303-304 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Reading and discussion of selections from Chinese scholarly journals and newspapers on contemporary Chinese political, economic, and social issues.

title: Special Topics in Social Entrepreneurship - Ventures to Address Global Challenges
reviews: Be prepared to do group work and listen to amazing/interesting people speak!
Definitely take this course.
Fantastic course, I would recommend it for someone of any interest or major.
Give it 100% and you will get a lot out of it. It wouldn't be a fun class if you weren't truly invested in the work.
Great class, and a terrific networking opportunity if you're interested in challenges such as international development, poverty reduction, climate change, etc.
I would recommend this course to any student interested in entrepreneurship. Great way to expand one's thinking on the topic

If you don't know anything about entrepreneurship or world issues, take the course; if you want more concrete advice on how to actually go about addressing these issues, just show up for a few lectures and sit in the back.
If you want general interest then this is for you, if you want deeper, I would say something else.

John Danner is an amazing professor. I have never encountered such an unconventional yet brilliant teacher. I never missed a class and enjoyed this course more than any other at Princeton. You will learn more than in any other class in your life
Take it if you'd like to know a bit what's going on in the field of social ventures, and if you would like an internship with one somewhere.

Take this class as an overview, or as a way to practice making a little bit of information seem like a lot. Much more about presentation skills than knowledge. If you have money to print all your projects at Princeton Printing or if you have graphic design skills, you'll do fine. Knowledge of the field is less important.

Take this class! It's fun and if you're not a business person it's easy enough to take but different enough that it'll push you out of your comfort zone. Danner's a really nice guy and you'll also get some interesting internship opportunities out of the class if you're interested. It teaches you things you didn't know about poverty and makes you a lot more socially aware. Put in effort in the assignments, and I wouldn't recommend PDFing because you won't get as much out of it.
Take this course.

This course is VERY time-consuming some weeks, and other weeks not at all. But if you find yourself passionate about social entrepreneurship, Prof. Danner is all about real-world application and you could easily get an internship or even start your own venture from this class and learn what you need to be good at it from the class as well.
Understand that you really have to put in a lot of work to get much out of it. Do this as a freshman or sophomore if you can, but do it anyway if you are already an upperclassman.
if you are interested in development or social problems definitely take this course
it was so practical. if you have an idea to take it.

take it. it's so important. more important than the other courses you're debating. I'm not just saying that. finally an opportunity to get out of the world of academic theory and reading about other people doing things and finally doing them yourself in a balanced student fashion.
prereqs: None, other than curiosity about the intersection between global challenges and entrepreneurship. This course is not open to students who took EGR 495 Special Topics in Entrepreneurship: Ventures to Address Global Challenges.
descrip: Focus: how entrepreneurial ventures - as compared with international aid programs, private philanthropy and corporate social responsibility initiatives - can potentially address major global challenges such as widespread poverty, intractable disease, slum housing and global warming that affect the lives and well-being of billions. Design: after overview of selected global challenges and the fundamentals of entrepreneurship, we will explore emerging and established ventures in each of these challenge arenas in more detail. Classes: combination of lectures and case discussions, interspersed with conversations with entrepreneurs.

title: Introductory Portuguese for Spanish Speakers
reviews: Absolutely take it if you are considering it
Absolutely take it, even if you don't speak Spanish. (I took it with a mediocre background in French) Megwen is phenomenal, and you learn an incredible amount very fast.

Definitely take this course! I've heard it is much less work than Spanish and it definitely is more fun and engaging! Both of the instructors were very friendly and kind and with either, you'll have fun in class!
I recommend supplementing this class with Portuguese TV and newspapers. Also, READ YOUR TEXTBOOK! I wish I had read the text book more, for the midterm and final were based heavily on the book!
I thought about taking the accelerated version, POR 110, but I was very satisfied with POR 108!

I would advise another student considering this course to take it, first of all! Then I would tell him/her to fully engage with the activities and assignments so that they can get the most out of it and gain in his/her language skills.
If you have background in Spanish, definitely take this class. It will set you up to move faster and reach higher level classes of Portuguese more quickly, and it is not an overly strenuous workload.
If you like languages and have already completed the requirement, take this class.
It is language you will love to learn because of how exciting and rich the Portuguese culture is.
It's pretty fun trying to pick up a language so fast. Definitely take it!
Keep up! Make sure you read the textbook before class so you know what is going on in class.

Overall, this course was very inconsistent and while some classes were fun and engaging, others were dull and repetitive. Feedback was also inconsistent. However, in one semester of learning Portuguese, I now feel like I could get by in a Portuguese-speaking country and have a good grasp of the language considering the short length of time I have been learning it.
Portuguese is a great language!! go for it.
Review the material at least once a week independently so that you can really learn everything.
Study outside of class and try to participate as much as possible early on.
Take it with Megwen!  She's awesome.
Take it!
Take this course!
This a great class to take if you have a general interest in Portuguese. Not only will you learn to speak the language but you will also learn about the Portuguese-speaking cultures around the world.
i <3 portuguese. good if you already know spanish.
take this class!!
prereqs: SPA 107 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Normally open to students already proficient in Spanish, this course uses that knowledge as a basis for the accelerated learning of Portuguese. Emphasis on the concurrent development of understanding, speaking, reading, and writing skills. The two-semester sequence POR 108-109 is designed to provide in only one year of study a command of the language sufficient for travel and research in Brazil and Portugal.

title: Modern Latin American Fiction in Translation
descrip: Latin "Camp." Susan Sontag defined camp as an aesthetic sensibility involving "travesty, impersonation, theatricality, seduction," and "flamboyant mannerisms." Camp has also been described as the style of choice for many gay writers - "a type of "coded" or "secret" language destined for those who are in the know. In this course we will explore manifestations of "camp" in some of the most exciting novels and films of the 20th Century, from Manuel Puig's "Kiss of the Spider Woman" to the Reinaldo Arenas' "Before Night Falls." Issues to be discussed include: gender and literary style, politics and aesthetics, and masquerade versus reality.

title: Egyptian Colloquial Arabic
reviews: If you're interested in speaking colloquial Arabic - learning the common expressions and language - then take this class! Tarek is an absolutely phenomenal teacher - energetic, fun, and very devoted to your learning and progress! Take this course!
TAKE THIS CLASS.
Take it. For Tarek, and if you have any interest in actually speaking the Arabic language.
Take this course! You'll learn a lot of practical conversational Arabic!

This is an AMAZING class. Tarek is wonderful in that he is super helpful and really knows how to make everything that he teaches stick in your head. Take advantage of the weekly office hours with him, as they will definitely prepare you for the final oral exam. As long as you put in enough work to learn a majority of the vocabulary, this is a great fifth class, and it's SO MUCH FUN.
prereqs: A minimum of two years study of Modern Standard Arabic (equivalent to completion of ARA 107) or NES permission..
descrip: An introduction to the spoken dialects of Egypt, particularly of Cairo. Students in this course are assumed to have a functional, working knowledge of classical Arabic, and the course will focus on developing the ability to use conversational language in common, everyday situations.

title: Rhetoric: Classical Theory, Modern Practice
prereqs: Completion of the Writing Seminar, or permission of instructor..
descrip: An introduction to the techniques of classical rhetoric both as a practical skill and as a philosophical approach to civic persuasion. Reading will consist of theoretical discussions of the proper means and ends of persuasion, along with exercises from Greek and Roman manuals of rhetoric. The goals of the course are: acquiring a historically informed understanding of the philosophical and ethical problems these techniques raised in their times; mastering the main classical techniques for persuasive reading, writing, speaking, and image-making; applying these principles to the analysis of a wide range of modern forms of persuasion.

title: American Literature: 1930-Present
reviews: Awesome course! Definitely take it. Professor Mitchell is a stud and if you are interested in English, this class is a must.
Definitely take it.
Go for it!

Great class to take for a distribution requirement or for general interest. The readings are great and represent a good overview of post modern American literature. Lectures are interesting, workload is fairly low, IMO.
I would advise students to participate in precept.
I would recommend people to take this course.
I'd take this course if you have any interest at all in modern lit, because the lectures are engaging, the precept discussions are stimulating, and most of all the readings are fantastic.
It's a fun class to PDF! The books are almost all really great--both fun to read and interesting to analyze.
Read all the books!
Read everything.
Readings were interesting and easy to get through for the most part.  Grading was kind of hard.
Solid survey of Modern American Literature. Worth taking if you want to read some of the most influential literary works of the past century
Take it it's wonderful
Take it whether or not you like literature or know the books being discussed.
Take it!
Take it! It can be intimidating because there are English majors taking this course but it's great and so interesting. Definitely a better response to American Literature as a whole.
Take it.
The books are great and the lectures are fascinating!
The reading list is one you won't want to miss. This class really lays out modernism and post-modernism in a way I'd never understood it before. Excellent.
This course is a must! Take it!!
descrip: A study of eleven modern American writers over eighty years that emphasizes the transition from modernism to postmodernism to retro-realism.

title: Fans and Consumer Culture
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Mathematics in Engineering I
reviews: A great course but the problem sets take a long time and it's best to join the large study groups that are likely to form for this class. Try to finish this problem set early because the other MAE departmentals likely have psets due in a row, and some of us ended up spending only a day on some psets because we spent too long on this pset, preventing us from utilizing office hours/precepts for those other classes. Precepts are definitely a must as they cover extra material needed on the psets.
Be prepared for a tough class, though Stone makes it worth it.
Be sure to do a bunch of practice problems before the test.  It's speed that counts.  And ask Prof. Stone questions...he's a friendly guy.
Definitely take this class. Professor Stone is amazing.
Differential equations is, without a doubt, one of the best taught quantitative courses at Princeton.
Difficult equations are difficult. But Prof Stone is incredible and if you are going to take diffeq, you should take it with Prof Stone!

Do not take if you don't need the class. People with no interest in engineering/math/physics will not enjoy it. Double the time you think you'll spend working on psets each week, and GO to Stone's office hours. They'll save your life
Don't bother with a book. Lecture notes are all you need. Challenging and fun :)
Don't buy a textbook.
Don't take expecting it to be easy. Expect to put a lot of time in studying the material, especially before the tests. Very interesting and applicable material though.
Don't take it if you don't have to.  A lot of work not much payoff

Everyone will tell you Professor Stone is great. The lectures are solid, the problem sets are fair, tons of practice problems, and amazing lecture notes. The only thing is, the class really doesn't move that quickly... I'm no math major, but in this case I think I could have learned more by taking a math major diff eq. You'll learn what you need in this course and enjoy it, but if you're the type of person who is really interested in learning everything you can here, consider do consider bumping up the difficulty a little!

Find the best TA and attend their office hours and precepts. The precepts give you problem-solving experience that you do not necessarily get from the lectures. This is crucial for success. Practice makes perfect!
Go to class and office hours and precepts
Go to lecture! On top of that, go to precept and you'll do fine.
Go to precepts! They are very helpful!
Go to the optional precepts if Stone still does them!  Almost no one goes so you can really ask your preceptor questions about whatever you want.  It helps you prepare for the psets, too.
Howard Stone is an amazing (and amusing) lecturer. I'd definately recommend taking this course in the fall. But, be warned: the problem sets can be intense at times!
I would not recommend taking this course unless you absolutely have to. Very challenging, but taught by a brilliant guy.
I would take this course if you're good at math, but otherwise, only take it if you have to. You may want to take it just to have a class with Professor Stone. He's awesome.

I'd recommend this course, mostly to be able to participate in Professor Stone's lectures.  He makes you want to study these concepts because he seems to like them so much, and it becomes a bit contagious.  The concepts covered do get very complicated and the problem sets do get very long (the last problem set took a whopping 12 hours to do), but if you attend and focus in lecture thoroughly enough, it actually isn't that big of a problem.  For any students who want a basic background in differential equations, I'd recommend this one, in a big part because of Professor Stone.
If it isn't a requirement, you might not want to take this course unless you really love math.

If you can take this course with Professor Stone, do it. He is the best lecturer I have ever had and couldn't be more enthusiastic or dedicated to the material or the course. He knows students by name and takes time to get to know people. If you are at all interested in Differential Equations, this is absolutely the course to take.
If you have any interest in math whatsoever, take this course! After some boring math classes at Princeton, this class really made me remember what I love about math.

If you have even the faintest interest in taking an upper level math course, take this course. You'll probably need some help and to collaborate on the problem sets, but it's worth it if even just for going to Howard's lectures (in the fall). It's challenging but rewarding, and the material is exceedingly useful.
Important subject matter, and Prof Stone does a great job of presenting it in a very interesting way.
It is a great course. If you fall behind in the lectures, just read the readings that he provides you on blackboard and you will be fine.
It is a lot of work. Interesting material though. I recommend it if you take it with friends.
It's a really hard class but totally worth it if you take it with professor stone
It's amazingly well run, and almost everyone in it is an engineer. It's really useful math, but the class is much easier than 203-4.
It's challenging and your grade may not be amazing in it. But you're going to learn a lot, and if you enjoy math, you're going to have fun!
It's pretty hard; if you don't need to take Differential Equations and aren't particularly motivated to work hard, don't bother.  However, if you need to take it, take it with Professor Stone!
Keep up with the material continuously!

OK class.  Pretty standard for math class, though he spends a lot of time going over the MAE applications which can get really slow/confusing sometimes if you're not MAE.  Not really a class I would take just for fun but useful material.
Professor Stone is a fun lecturer but the class is still very tough.
Professor Stone is a great lecture and makes the material as interesting as possible. Take it with him, go to lectures and precepts, and take advantage of the awesome notes he puts on Blackboard
Read the lecture notes before going to class and you should be ok.
Start the problem sets early and go to lecture.
Start your problem sets on time, go to office hours, and to review sessions!

Stone gives you his latex notes so you just have to look and listen during lecture jotting down stuff as needed.  He talks fast so don't even try to write down everything he says just take the golden nuggets of truth and flesh those out in office hours or precept.
Stone is awesome.  The material is interesting and well presented. Not an easy course, but doable.  You could do a lot worse as far as math classes at Princeton.
Stone is great. Not too difficult. Pretty straightforward.

Strongly recommend this course with Prof. Stone! Do go to lectures and do not miss any of them- they are super helpful. Precepts were okay, but I sometimes did not go to them and just download the handouts on Blackboard afterwards.

Take it with Stone. Not a particularly difficult class, but make sure you're comfortable with math. Otherwise it's easy to get intimidated by all the algebra.
Take it! Howard is the best!

Take this class with Professor Stone. He is amazing!
This class is difficult. That being said, it's very well taught, and it will help you to gain a very solid understanding of the material if you put in the effort
This course is hard but the professor is very good and the material is interesting,

This course, with Professor Stone, his awesome TA choices, his lecture notes, the class Piazza site, and the problem sets with lots of extra practice problems, is the best possible environment to learn math in.
