prereqs: MAT 201 or MAT 203 and MAT 202 or MAT 204. Open to freshmen with instructor's permission only..
descrip: A treatment of the theory and applications of ordinary differential equations with an introduction to partial differential equations. The objective is to provide the student with an ability to solve standard problems in this field.

title: Regimes of Value
descrip: In this course, we try to understand how people in different societies and in different historical periods link value and money in order to organize their exchanges and communities. We explore contexts in which concepts of the good and the desirable are first constructed and then associated with money. We examine the principles that different societies use to establish equivalence of values and things. Finally, we discuss how wealth (or lack of it) is represented through different social and artistic practices, and how it is transformed into an indicator of non-economic qualities and values.

title: History: An Introduction to the Discipline
reviews: DO IT / OR ANY CLASS WITH PROFESSOR / GRAFTON / FOR SO DOING / YOU WILL LEARN OF THINGS / HOW OTHERS / LEARNED OF THINGS / AND HOW TO LEARN OF OTHERS LEARNINGS OF THINGS .
Definitely take this course if it's offered, even if you're not a history major.
Grafton is a delight!

HIS 448 is fantastic-- a great professor leads weekly discussions about great ideas expressed in great books, and it is no surprise that the course draws a group of great students who are engaged and opinionated. A serious pursuit of historical truth, with plenty of laughs along the way.

If you are interested in thinking about history at somewhat of an abstract level and are willing to put in some work, this is really an unbelievable class (speaking as a philosophy major). Grafton is a master teacher and historian. Everyone in the class seemed invested in the material. Do it.

One of the best I've taken. Grafton is a gem and the discussions are interesting. I would totally recommend it for anyone. But BEWARE if you're not interested in history and the methodology of history, steer clear because that's exactly the focus of the class,
Take anything taught by Professor Grafton.  Prepare to work hard, but you will enjoy it.

This is probably the best class I've taken at Princeton. You should take it if you care about history or not. I learned more about how to read texts carefully and closely than in any literature class I've taken here.

You will learn a lot from the course and the papers are an opportunity to explore any area of history that really interests you. Regardless of what it is, Professor Grafton will have helpful comments for your paper.
descrip: This course, designed for seniors and juniors in the History Department but open to others, will offer an introduction to the discipline of history. Through a series of case studies, students will learn how historians frame problems, ranging in scale from the history of the world to the lives of individuals, and in time from millennia to single years; examine the kinds of evidence and argument that historians employ; study the intellectual and literary problems involved in constructing a substantial piece of historical writing; and investigate the relations between history and memory in the late twentieth century.

title: Image and Imagination
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

profs.name: Jorge Alejandro Mendez Seijas, Course Head

title: Spanish Language and Culture through Cinema
reviews: Definitely take this class if it's with Jorge! It's a great way to explore Latin American culture through cinema - it's very different from any films I've seen in the US! The discussion style of the class may seem daunting but you'll be thankful for it in the end!

Definitely take this course! It was one of my favorite at Princeton so far. The first few days are intimidating (I almost dropped out), but if you stick to it, you will be amazed at how much you improve throughout the semester. Plus, you watch about 15 incredible movies that I would have wanted to watch regardless of whether they were required! The structure of the course was excellent. Before each movie, we discussed the historical context, which taught us so much about the cultural aspect of the films. Then, we watched the movie and completed a written assignment, which forced us to analyze the themes and cinematography in the films, while also practicing our writing skills.  And then we presented our written work and discussed the responses as a class, which honed our speaking skills. The small class size allowed for a comfortable environment that demanded everyone's participation. I cannot say enough good things about this course -- I just wish they offered more film courses. I think they did much more for my speaking and writing skills (even grammar) than the beginner Spanish courses. Take it -- don't think twice!
If you like cinema and want to improve your Spanish - do not hesitate! This class is perfect.
Take It!!!
Take a few short notes as you watch the movies.
Take it with Jorge.

You should definitely take this course because it is amazing. It allows you to improve your Spanish while having a great time watching AMAZING movies. Please if you are considering taking this class...DO IT. Take it with Jorge. He is an amazing teacher.
if you want an interesting class, take it. if you want to get better, pick something else
prereqs: SPA 107 (with instructor's permission); or SPA 108; or SPA 207..
descrip: SPA 209 is an advanced Spanish course designed to improve oral and writing skills through the analysis and discussion of contemporary Spanish and Latin American films. A significant amount of classroom time is dedicated to intensive debate on a wide variety of topics and features presented in films. The grammar component aims to facilitate a more fluent communication in Spanish. Films are viewed in Spanish with subtitles.

title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Chemistry (Half-Term)
reviews: The course will make you think about many important issues which may appear in your future academic life.
descrip: Discussion and evaluation of the role professional researchers play in dealing wtih the reporting of research, responsible authorship, human and animal studies, misconduct and fraud in science, intellectual property, and professional conduct in scientific relationships. Participants are expected to read the materials and cases prior to each meeting. Successful completion is based on regular attendance and active participation in discussion. This half-term course is designed to satisfy federal funding agencies' requirements for training in the ethical practice of scientists. Required for chemistry graduate students/post-docs.

title: Introduction to Swahili Culture
descrip: This is an introductory course to Swahili culture. You will learn who the Swahili people were and who they have become, who they are not, and what the term 'Swahili' may refer to. This is a multidisciplinary course that will be sourced from different texts, newspapers, booklets, films, music videos, pictures, guest presentations, handouts, web sites, and a taste of Swahili cuisine. Through these you will get a bird's eye view of the East African people as well as some other Swahili speaking groups and their cultures.

title: The American Sermon
descrip: The sermon is one of the most unique contributions to the American literary and oral tradition. This course examines sermonic texts and recordings from the late 18th century to the present. We will explore written and recorded homilies, placing both sermons and sermonizers in historical context. In this way we want to discover not only the theological perspectives contained in the sermons but also the cultural, social, economic, and political situations in the U.S. that helped shape them. Rather than a concern for the "practice" of preaching, our course focuses on sermons as literature and historical narratives.

title: Directed Research II
descrip: This seminar is a continuation of ORF 509. Each student writes a report and presents research results. For doctoral students, the course must be completed one semester prior to taking the general examinations.

title: Urban Education Reform
descrip: This seminar focuses on issues involved in improving educational opportunities for children in urban schools. Students will analyze the historical and contemporary writings on concerns fundamental to student educational performance, with emphasis on understanding the barriers and pathways to reform and the political and policy dimensions of various reform initiatives. Seminar sessions will include issues analysis, student facilitated discussion, debates and guest speakers.

title: Artificial Intelligence
reviews: A course very worth taken.

A decent CS course. Note that more emphasis is placed on the write-ups than on code; it's a drastic shift compared to 226. Take if interested in the field. Not strictly required for the Princeton experience.
A great COS class.

A solid introduction to pretty much all the relevant topics in artificial intelligence. Programming assignments can take a decent amount of time, but shouldn't be a problem as long as you don't start it the day before it's due. Grading was generally fair.
AI is an interesting field, so I would recommend taking this course even if it isn't particularly enjoyable.
AI is an interesting field. Everyone passionate about mathematics or computer science should learn about it.
AI is massively useful. You *will* run into these algorithms and concepts if you ever end up doing COS in the real world. This is a pretty good class to take.
Be aware of the Udacity AI course. It's a great resource.
Be prepared for weekly problem sets. The course was taught well with an overview of a lot of material.

Definitely take it.  Assignments really aren't that bad, but be very careful to check over your code and psets.  I haven't seen another COS class with such a low median on the assignments (especially the first one.  It's easy, so don't lose those points!)
Do not take unless you are pdfing or want to do a considerable amount of work.

Do take it if you're at all interested in the subject matter. The lecturer really knows this area well, and the assignments are great (and not unreasonably difficult). Despite the 400 classification, it doesn't require any kind of prior knowledge or programming experience beyond 126-226, though some math or statistics background is helpful for following the probability stuff covered in lecture.
Don't take this course during a busy semester.
For the student who is really curious about AI but  remember be with solid math and logic background.
Give thorough answers on problem sets
Good times, pretty much like 226 in terms of workload
Great Course
I loved it, it's a great applications elective.
I would definitely encourage them to take the course.  Even if you are not a computer science major, the material will still be understandable and it applies to so many different fields.
I would highly recommend taking this course.
If AI sounds interesting, take this course. It's not too bad work-wise and the problem space is fun.
If Schapire's teaching, take it! I can't imagine a clearer presentation of the topics covered in this class.
If you are interested in AI and are looking for a class that covers both the applied and theoretical side, definitely take it.
If you enjoyed the material in COS226, then you'll like this class.
If you like the material, you should take it. Don't expect much from the lectures, but you will certainly learn a lot of useful and interesting information.
If you want to learn AI this is your best chance in life, don't miss it.

If you're interested in AI or an intro to machine learning, take this class! The class moves pretty quickly and covers lots of material, but you'll learn a lot of interesting stuff about this cool field.

It's a cool course that has a lot of information.  Some programs take longer than others (30 hours vs. 10 hours) so plan accordingly.  I'd recommend, take it with other COS classes because it doesn't take much time.
It's super interesting and the assignments are great.
Its a lot of work, but rewarding.
Must Take!
Okay course, a lot of work for basic algorithm concepts.
Start your problem sets early.
Student's of all backgrounds can fit in in this course

Take it! I really really liked this class. Even if you're not a COS major, it's really interesting. Schapire is a great lecturer and the TAs are really accessible and helpful as well. Does require a decent amount of work though, not necessarily easy (most people do quite well on the assignments) but it is so worth it!
Take it!!!!!!
Take it, its awesome.
Take it. Awesome course. The workload varies and it can really depend on how much you want to put into it, but overall, definitely worth taking.
Take the course! Number of interesting topics that are very relevant to modern computer development are covered.
The book is very good. Lectures aren't necessary, but provide a good introduction before reading the book.
The concepts of this class are interesting, but the course does come with a fair amount of work so be prepared to invest some time.
The course is like a continuation of 226. 402 is particularly interesting because the field of AI is still very young. Prof. Schapire definitely knows his stuff.
The programming assignments are fun and not to difficult. I found the problem sets to be kind of a pain. The biggest thing to know is that Schapire will put you to sleep.

The subject of AI is somewhat less exciting than it sounds, but this is still a good course. The lectures are good, and the assignments and final are well-written and organized. The written assignments take some time, but there is a pretty generous late day policy.

This class can take up a good bit of time but never gets very hard and covers a lot of interesting material. However, if you've taken algorithms and probability courses, you will have seen much of this material already.
This course is really interesting and taught well - you should take it!!
This course is well-run and covers a lot of pretty interesting material.

This course was a lot more challenging and mathy, especially in the first part of the semester, than I expected.  Take it if you're interested in AI, but be prepared for challenging problem-sets and time-consuming assignment reports.  Start things early: late days that disappear quickly will be regretted.

This is a very good applications course for COS majors and certificates.  The material is useful for independent work in a number of departments, and it doesn't require you to have taken COS 340 or other upper-level COS classes.
This is one of the good ones. Worth taking for its well-prepared curriculum, subject relevance, and quality of instruction.
This is probably a good course to take, but it is not super exciting. The programs are interesting, but the problem sets are less than fun. Grading is also a little bit arbitrary.
This should be a must-taking course if the student is thinking about pursuing further study in the area of machine learning and artificial intelligence.
This will take up time with weekly assignments, but the subject matter is pretty useful for any sort of AI based problem.

Though I was always very interested in AI, I  had been put off by the size of the course; I wasn't so interested in taking huge, standard-seeming departmentals.  However, I grew more interested in the course as I read the readings and attended the lectures and did the assignments - this course is definitely structured very well. The lectures are drier than they could be (Schapire is presents lectures like they're algorithms), but Schapire is still a great professor and the material is simply amazing. Definitely a worthwhile course to take and to not put off.
Unless you need to, or are fascinated by AI, don't take it

The grading is very harsh and can be really unfair at times. If you care a lot about your grades, this class will be really stressful.
prereqs: COS 226.
descrip: The fundamental principles, algorithms and techniques of modern artificial intelligence research and practice. Likely topics include: problem solving using search, game playing, logical inference, probabilistic reasoning in the presence of uncertainty, hidden Markov models, speech recognition, Markov decision processes, machine learning.

title: Taiko Drumming Workshop: Japanese and North American Perspectives
reviews: Absolutely take it! Fun and fulfilling class.
Be serious and have fun to get the most out of it.
Best class ever. Watanabe-sensei is the man. Take the class. OMG.
Definitely a fun class. The history/culture section can be a little redundant if you've done much Japanese studies, but the taiko workshop portion is worth it.
Definitely take if you're looking for a fun and interesting class. You won't regret it.

I think taking this class really depends on your interest in Japanese culture and music. That may sound obvious, but if you're just planning on taking it for the SA requirement and you have no interest in either of those fields you probably will regret it. Personally, I enjoyed the drumming enough for it to be worthwhile, but the readings were pretty dull. Watanabe is a really amazing instructor for the taiko section though!

If you get the chance to take this class, do it! The readings and class discussions are very interesting, both professors are very knowledgeable about the subject, and, so long as you are willing to put in the physical and mental effort for this class, it will be both fun and rewarding.
Stretch.
Take this coure if you have any interest in Japanese-American history of taiko drumming.  It is a great course and a great break from other lecture courses.

This definitely ranks amongst one of the most fun courses I've ever taken at Princeton!  Combining academic readings on Japanese drumming with the practice itself, it's a great way to learn about Japanese (and Asian American) culture and music, while getting the chance to learn how to play a new instrument and create original compositions.
You need to take this class.
nothing beats this course
take it.
descrip: This course explores the socio-cultural meanings of taiko (Japanese drum), from its uses in traditional Japanese music (gagaku, kabuki, festival music) through its development as a choreographic ensemble in postwar Japan and a site for Asian-American identity. Students participate in a hands-on workshop, learning techniques and three pieces of traditional modern styles, and in seminars on the history and cultural implications of taiko in the Japanese and Asian-American experience.

title: Workshop in Social Policy
descrip: A course required for and limited to students in the Joint Degree program in Social Policy. Papers drafted in the year-long course WWS 590a,b,c,d must be revised and submitted to the workshop leader by August 20. Papers will be provided to an expert reader outside of the Princeton faculty, who is invited to join the seminar for sessions devoted to each student paper. Each student will present his/her own paper and simultaneously contribute written critiques of one another's papers. By the end of the term, students will be required to submit their papers for publication to a leading journal.

title: Precalculus/Prestatistics
reviews: A good introductory course, especially if math is not your strength. It was decently interesting-- I thought  I'd never say this about a math class.
Always do your homework and ask questions! Go to office hours. Don't be discouraged if the quizzes are too hard. Spread out your studying for the midterm and final so that you're not blindsided!
Always reach out to Owen for help.
Check your homework with a classmate before turning it in or do homework in a group; small mistakes like forgetting a negative sign are easy to make and happen frequently!
Don't take this class unless you haven't already taken Precalculus.

I would strongly recommend this course because it is very useful and several fields and not hard to manage.  The material is presented in a way in which it is not too difficult to understand and that is it interesting.  The class starts off very basic so students shouldn't be worried if they lack a substantial math background.  I would recommend this to students who just need a QR requirement or of course those who need  it as a prerequisite.
If you need it, take it. Too bad Owen will have graduated! You'll miss the corny jokes that made class much more bearable.
It is a very nice introductory course.
It's a great class to take to get your math distribution requirement out of the way!
Study for the quizzes far in advance.

its more difficult than i thought it would be

descrip: An intensive and rigorous treatment of algebra and trigonometry as preparation for further courses in calculus or statistics. Topics include functions and their graphs, equations involving polynomial and rational functions, exponentials, logarithms and trigonometry.

title: Electronic Devices
reviews: Good background for experimental research in MOSFETs or PN junctions. Relied heavily on book, so it may be better to just read the textbook.
I think we need to know the knowledge in this course, but the knowledge in this course is not systematically taught.
It is a very good class to start
It's no problem to take this course. I recommend this course to those who have already know something about electronic devices.

This course will teach you a lot about electronic devices, but is very flawed. Exams are difficult and have no correlation to problem sets. Although you will still learn a lot from this course, I would recommend taking it from another professor.
Very good course.
descrip: Introduction to principles of electron behavior in semiconductors and applications to device physics. Band diagrams, Metal-semiconductor contacts, Schottky barriers, p-n junctions. MOS electronics, FET's, bipolar transistor, solar cell, detector, LED, microwave devices.

title: Special Studies in the Nineteenth Century - The Autobiographical Impulse
descrip: From DeQuincey's Opium Eater and Wordsworth's Prelude to Bronte's Jane Eyre and Gosse's Father and Son, the 19th Century was the age of autobiography. We will consider the reasons for this literary explosion, the relation between fictional and non-fictional examples, models of psychological development, and Victorian justifications for egotistical self-reflection.

title: Introduction to Macroeconomics
reviews: (For Prof. Bogan) If you can't get into her precept, make sure to go to her office hours at least occasionally! You can tell that Prof. Bogan clearly knows what she's talking about, even though she does often read off her slides during lecture.
Absolutely. Every student at Princeton should take this course.

BOGAN IS THE BEST. 
That is all. 
She is so incredible I can't describe it here.
Take this course or regret it for life.

Basic macroeconomic knowledge should be a requirement for everyone with a degree from Princeton, in my opinion.  So many aspects of this class are applicable to life, present and future, that anyone who does not take it is at a disadvantage.  Make sure Bogan is the professor, though.  She's phenomenal.
Be prepared to do a lot of reading! Also, be prepared for difficult exams.
Bogan is a great lecturer and good person. I didn't love the course, but for an introductory class, it was quite good.
Bogan is a great lecturer!
Bogan is a great professor! Keep up with packet readings, Economist Articles, and go to Office hours! Lecture notes should be detailed, study them a lot!
Bogan is an enthusiastic lecturer. The class is a good balance of concepts, current issues, and policy-making
Bogan's great. If you do the work, you'll be fine.
Class teaches you a lot about the financial collapse and the current recovery. Everyone should have to and want to take this to be informed citizens about the society and economy we live in.
Definitely an interesting course

Definitely really interesting and usual.
Definitely recommend taking this course, especially with Professor Bogan as a lecturer and preceptor.
Definitely take this course. It is good information to understand regardless of your career path.
Disorganized course. Bogan's lectures were disappointing given all her hype. Precepts are virtually useless, and problem sets are wonky.
Do all your readings on time and work on problem sets in McGraw.
Do not take this as a senior.
Do the Economists and pequod readings. Bogan is great; this is a really interesting course.
Do the economist readings and know the main argument. Focus on studying her lecture slides for exams.
Do the problem sets carefully!
Do the readings and problem sets and you'll be fine.
Do the readings each week.
Do the readings!

Do the readings, definitely, but know that nearly all the material for the problem sets comes from the lectures. Bogan is great--if you're going to take macro, which I recommend just as really solid basic knowledge for any college graduate, I'd take it with her.
Do the readings. Go to study sessions at Frist.
Do the work. Do the readings. Go to lecture. You'll get so much more out of class that way.
Dont take econ unless you plan to major in it.
Enjoy Professor Bogan's insights. Her personal 'rants' are not to be forgotten.
Everyone should have an elementary understanding of ECO 101 to be an educated member of society
Excellent for gaining a basic understanding of what's going on in modern economics. Let's you call BS on a lot of what you hear in the news.
Find a study group to complete the problem sets together with or go to McGraw. The material is difficult to digest alone.

First of all, if you have enough interest to have clicked through to read comments on it, you should definitely take this course.  Secondly, buy the pequod, but don't buy the textbook. Professor Bogan let us know about half way through the course that it was meant to be a supplement in case a student had trouble with the material -- I'm doubtful any students ever used theirs (and if you do struggle with a concept, borrow a friend's)
Get a good preceptor and go to mcgraw
Get a good preceptor.
Get a tutor
Go for it! Consider things like Econ sociology if you're looking for something more in a humanities-comfort zone, but otherwise, a strong class.
Go to McGraw at least once a week for problem sets. I don't think reading the textbook is all that necessary unless you need to figure something out last minute.
Go to class, don't worry too much about note taking, but pay close attention.
Go to lecture, it's more helpful than the book readings.
Go to lectures.
Great course, definitely take it with Professor Bogan.  Beware it is a hard curve and although it is an intro course it is still difficult.  Avoid Weicheng Lian at all costs, very hard to understand.
Great introduction to a great topic.
Harder than it sounds. Be prepared to work hard.
I recommend that students do the economist readings because they are interesting and important for the exams.

I think it was a good course to take, especially if you want to be an econ major. However, don't take the course just to get a requirement because if you don't like economics you will not enjoy this course at.
I think that every student should take this course to have some understanding of how the economy works.
I would definitely recommend it. Bogan is a great instructor and my precept worked out really well. Make sure to read the Economist!
I would recommend taking this course even if you are not directly interested in economics because it gives a good baseline for macroeconomics that I think people need to understand the current world.
I would say that lecture was great, and she was a really knowledgeable Professor and well worth listening to.

I would suggest taking this course to be able to read the news intelligently. Also, I would strongly urge students taking this course to speak up in precept about things you don't understand. Once you are over the embarrassment of asking something someone else may already know, precept (which many students say is boring) can become really fun!
I would take it because it has so many applications and helps you understand the overall economic situation.
I would take this course if you have very little knowledge of economics as it definitely helped me understand current events better. It's a useful course.
I would tell the students to keep up with the reading in the Macroeconomics book. While its contents won't be directly on the test, you'll understand the class much better.

If you do not need it as a pre-req, consider taking it because it will teach you a lot of important things about world events/how the economy works. Take it with Bogan in the Fall, or with Blinder if he ever teaches it again. If you have had no prior exposure to the subject, MAKE SURE YOU KEEP UP WITH THE TEXTBOOK READINGS. It will get very confusing if you don't understand some of the most important concepts well, especially those that show up right before the midterm. If you have a hard time, I promise it can be rewarding, but not if you just PDF and ignore the rest of the class.
If you have to, or want to take macro, Bogan is definitely a good call.
If you put in the time and effort to do the readings and attend lecture you won;t have any problems.

If you want a good understanding of general macroeconomic concepts, this course does a great job of that. Professor Bogan especially teaches the material clearly. Definitely make sure you read reviews for good lecturers (since those tend to make or break these courses), but going with Bogan would not be a mistake.

If you want to develop a good foundation in basic macroeconomics I would strongly recommend taking this course. Be prepared to complete both the Economist readings and the readings in the packet since  you will be tested on both.
If you want to learn about how the world works and about the global economy, take it. Don't take it unless you are very interested though. It would bore you.
If you're interested in Economics, take it!
If you're interested in econ this is a good course to begin with
If you're looking for a distribution, take Micro instead.

If you're looking to gain a basic yet in depth view into macroeconomics, this is a pretty good class. The graphs and equations might not be that interesting on their own, but if you know how they fit in the context of current politics and events, it becomes more interesting.
Interesting and relevant course. Take it for general interest! Not too difficult and pretty interesting. PowerPoints are very comprehensive, if you do choose to skip lecture.
Interesting. And it keeps you up to date with the ongoing economic changes.
It was a good entry level economics course

It's a solid class-- you get out what you put in.  Lectures are big, precepts are pretty uninspiring but Macro is good stuff to know, and if you are genuinely interested, you can get out a lot of the coursework
It's a thorough introduction to macroeconomics, but can be skipped without much loss.
It's pretty interesting material. Try to stay on top of things as you go along, because it's way better than cramming it in all at the end.

Keep up on the readings, and start the problem sets early.  Lectures are extremely important, because it's hard to understand the powerpoints without them.  If you keep up on the work, you will be fine!
Keep up with readings, and know how to do the short answer on the practice exam. The real exam was extremely similar for both the mid-term and the final.
Keep up with the material; if you fall behind, it is very hard to catch up since everything builds on the lecture before.
Keep up with the reading.

Keep up with the readings! And DO NOT wait last minute to do problem sets. If you rush your problem sets you will not understand it as well and you will do worse on the midterm and final. Many of the same problems appear on our tests.
Keep up with the readings, start problem sets early, and review the lecture slides after class to make sure you understand them.

Keeping up with the readings is crucial, because if not the lectures became confusing. However, I found it necessary to be a few chapters ahead because Bogan's lectures skipped around between each week's readings.
Make sure to attend classes so you don't fall behind and you understand the graphs.
Make sure you have friends in the class who you can discuss the problem sets with.
Make sure you stay on top of the material otherwise it becomes quite a hassle come finals time
Manage your time wisely
McGraw was super helpful

One of the best classes I've taken here. Professor Bogan is a fantastic lecturer, and her explanations are accessible to those of us that haven't taken Econ before. Try to get into one of Bogan's precepts: they are usually taught on Friday mornings, so just be prepared not to drink the night before! Beware of the grading scale: a lot of people have taken econ before, and the curve is pretty rigorous: less than 30 percent of the class gets A's. This is a great course to PDF, as the material is so applicable to everyday life and it is nice not to have to worry about all of the tools in the class. Overall, go for it! Bogan's ECO 101 is not to be missed, and you won't find a better professor to teach it.
Pay attention to the readings from the economist!
Read all the material and don't skip classes because they are all important.

Read the Economist articles for the midterm. It was difficult getting help understanding things because McGraw wasn't very helpful and her office hours were quite busy. Decent course, but just too overpopulated.
Regardless of major, if you have an interest in being economically literate, take this course.  It's one of the classes that will be very useful in the real world
Solid class, important material. Bogan focuses a lot on very practical things like the Euro crisis, fiscal cliff, and other relevant topics.
Stay on top of reading, take good notes and pay attention during class and you'll be set for problem sets and exams.
Stay up to date with the readings, get help with the problem sets either from the Student Center at Frist or from another student, don't get behind on your work.
Study the lecture slides, and stay on top of the class! If you do not understand the lecture, read the textbook. Prepare for precept with the discussion questions.
Take ECO101 with Bogan!
Take it
Take it - a necessary but interesting course.
Take it at least to be informed during presidential elections.
Take it for the sake of understanding economics

Take it if you're even thinking about being an ECO major and even if you're not, its a worthshile course for an citizen that wants to be informed and have a better understanding of the current events going on in our economy
Take it if your even minorly interested in how the world works. Go to lecture, office hours, Mcgraw, etc.

Take it with Bogan, try to get a Friday or Monday precept since there were sometimes problems on the homework not covered until Thursday morning lecture which then had to be handed in during the Thursday afternoon precept.
Take it with Professor Bogan!
Take it!
Take it! It's relevant to today and something that everyone should be at least vaguely familiar with. Professor Bogan is great too!
Take it, it's fun.
Take it.
Take it. Everyone should have a basic understanding of how the economy works. Just be prepared to do a lot of self-teaching.

Take macroeconomics with Bogan. Her lecturing style can take some time to get used to, but she is the only intro-level economics lecturer who cares about drawing real-world connections to the subject material. Attend lectures and keep up with problem sets.
Take the class with Bogan, she really keeps you interested.
Take the course if you are curious about how macroeconomies function or as a requirement. It'll give you the information, just not in a fascinating way.
Take this class (preferably with Bogan) because it's interesting and not difficult. Do problem sets with friends.
Take this class if you like economics, but be ready to work hard.

Take this class if you want to learn more about how the world works. The problem sets do not take more than a few hours, and the exams are definitely manageable. Professor Bogan's lectures are not particularly great, but they are decent. You learn about current events as well as economic theories.
Take this class when Prof. Bogan's teaching it.

Take this class! Bogan grades fairly and sensibly. She's also a great lecturer/preceptor who will change the way you evaluate the world. She also presents material in an effective manner, highlighting exactly what is important.

Take this course if you are interested in Economics and want to get some good baseline knowledge of the world of money (simply put). The professor often reads directly from the slides and rarely stops to explain a particularly tricky concept, at which point you should ask your preceptor. The textbook is almost never addressed by exams (but ALWAYS by problem sets). Be prepared to work hard.
Take this course if you want an introduction to macroeconomics.  However, if you are taking it for general interest, take it PDF--although there is still significant work for a PDF class.
Take this course only if you need to do so for your department or if you need economic literacy to understand events. It does not suffice as a general interest course; there are better options.
Take this course. I'd recommend Bogan even if her voice is slightly monotonous; her brain is worth it. DO IT.
Take this course. It's important to have a solid understanding of how the economy works. Bogan is pretty great.

Taking this class will greatly expand your knowledge of the national economy and how it works in context of current events. Just as current events move quickly, so must you. Stay on top of the readings and always attend lecture--this class covers a lot of interconnected material and you really only benefit if you are there for most of it.
The class isn't bad if you need to take it as an econ prereq. If you are taking it just to take it, make sure you have some prior econ knowledge, or else the info will go right over your head.
The essay topics are always on stuff covered in lecture!

The workload is rather heavy, so if you have a lot of other quantitative, work-intensive classes, this is not the best class to take alongside. At the same time, macro was able to keep me in the loop on current events, which I always appreciated.
There is a lot of material to cover and you cannot get in-depth knowledge of anything. This is expected of a 101 course though.
There is a lot of reading. Some of which is not necessary but most of which is really intriguing. I would recommend keeping up with the reading, for it can begin to pile up.
They should be prepared and stay on top of work

This class with Bogan is worth taking wether you are an Economics major or not. The textbook is never used, so it really is not worth buying unless you want a different take on everything Bogan is lecturing about. The class mainly relies on a pequod packet which contains the readings and problem sets. Bogan does a great job of incorporating historical examples along with modern political arguments over issues such as the national debt. Sure I learned about macroeconomic theory, but I'm much more excited about all of the economic political relevance that I now have a better grasp on. The course is worth taking for this value alone. Bogan does a very good job of remaining pretty neutral in her criticism of both democrats and republicans (although she feels the dems are closer in actually understanding how a cyclical economy works). Overall, I would definitely look to take another course with Bogan again in the future.
This course is definitely worth taking even for a student who has had some introduction to economics in high school. The quality of readings and lectures were very high.
This course is generally very basic and the grading on exams is somewhat maddening. However, it's not a bad course, and I wouldn't discourage people from taking it to learn something about macro.
This course is very useful in understanding the current events of economics, but it is deficient in theory and a big picture sense of macroeconomic principles.
This is a good class to take since you learn so much about the current economics situation.

This is a good course. If you're not already fairly passionate about economics and macroeconomic policy on the national, not to mention global, level, this probably isn't the course to make you say "A-ha! This is what I want to study." But if you have any interest at all in the topic, or just think it's relevant to understanding what goes on in the world (which it very much is), take this class. It's easy to approach the class casually, but the tests are no walk in the park. They're not painful, but they're no walk in the park.
This is a good overview of Macroeconomics.  Nothing less, nothing more.

This is a great intro to Macroeconomics.  It is hard.  The grading will screw you.  

Bogan's lectures are not good, almost not worth attending.  But her precepts are delightful.  She is a good professor.

Bogan's precepts are on Friday morning.  Try to get into them.

This is a hard course with a lot of work and a lot of people in this class have already taken AP Econ. For some people, the things that we learn come naturally and make sense; for others, not so much...

This is a macroeconomics course with very little math. Microeconomics would be a bit helpful to take first; however, it is definitely not a prerequisite. This class has a fairly standard work load and exams were not overly hard. This class will explain quite a bit about economics in modern political discussions specifically and you will learn a lot.

This is a worthwhile course to take if you'd like some understanding of how to think about economics and current events. However, it's not particularly well organized. You will need to spend some time figuring out Bogan's syllabus (actually there are two for the class), which is a hot mess
This is definitely a course everyone should take because it is filled with practical knowledge.

Took this class with Prof Bogan and really enjoyed it. Try to sit near the front because it can be very difficult to understand her at times. She highlights different countries for case studies of the concepts learned in class and seemed to emphasize these on the problem sets and exams, as well.

Wait to read the economist readings until before the test so that they are fresh in your mind otherwise, the info in the articles will most likely be forgotten. I would suggest also that you have already taken an econ class or that you have a strong political/economical interest.
Yeah

Yes, do take this class. Read the pequod articles for exams and pay attention during lectures for the midterm and final exams. Professor Bogan is a very good lecturer but covers a lot a material in a very short amount of time.
You should take this -- it will help you understand current events.  Go to lecture, read the Economist articles -- it makes problem sets easier.
buy a used book
dont stop to ask for help

if you are interested in getting a broad overview of a lot of the economic issues that keep being raised on the news and in the economist take this course. If you want to trump all your family at dinner table conversations take this course. If you want to feel like you really mastered a topic, developed as an individual, became a better scholar or learner, this isn't the course for you.
if you're taking this for a grade, make sure you really do all the readings and make an effort to understand the psets.
it is not your average highschool economics class. if youre not interested in learning policy or engaging yourself in current economic policy, you will not enjoy it.
pay attention in lecture and go to precept.
take it with blinder
take it. you need to know econ basics
take this class, even if it is just to be informed. PDF it if you want, but it is not terribly difficult to do well.
yeah its interesting just be careful-- it can get complicated w current events in economics (less conceptual)
descrip: The theory of the determination of the level of national income and economic activity, including an examination of the financial system. Emphasis on economic growth and such economic problems as inflation, unemployment and recession, and on appropriate policy responses. Some attention is also paid to international issues.

title: Architecture Design Studio
reviews: Choose the approach for each of the three issues relatively quickly to allow the most time for development.
If you want to learn a lot without doing much studio work, you should take this class. You will learn a lot from the professor.
My friend, this class will make you see the world in a new light.
descrip: Vertical Design Studio

title: Gender and Science
descrip: This course will explore two aspects of the gender and science literature: the historical participation of women (and men) in scientific work, and how feminists have used as well as critiqued science, technology and medicine. We will also explore how biologists, physicians, and other researchers have framed sexuality in scientific terms, and with what consequences.

title: Introduction to the Mechanics and Dynamics of Soft Living Matter
reviews: I would recommend this course.
Take this class and learn about soft living matter. Cliff encourages you to ask questions during class so do that-- ask lots of questions during class and you'll surely learn even more.
This course is a good introduction with good, simple explanations from the instructor and reading from journal articles.
descrip: This course introduces the concepts of soft condensed matter and their use in understanding the mechanical properties, dynamic behavior, and self-assembly of living biological materials. We will take an engineering approach that emphasizes the application of fundamental physical concepts to a diverse set of problems taken from the literature, including mechanical properties of biopolymers and the cytoskeleton, directed and random molecular motion within cells, aggregation and collective movement of cells, and phase transitions and critical behavior in the self-assembly of lipid membranes and intracellular structures.

title: The Greek World after 1453
descrip: An examination of selected topics in Greek history and civilization, broadly defined, between 1453 and the early twentieth century.

title: Research Seminar in American Political History
descrip: This course is an intensive research seminar on the political history of the United States from the Revolutionary era to the present. Students work closely with the instructor and with each other in defining and developing original research topics, and then in drafting and revising research papers. During open weeks, we cover readings that either discuss or exemplify changing trends in the writing of American political history. Emphasis falls on the history of formal politics and government, but topics may include matters such as political culture and the interplay of government and social movements.

title: Topics in Germanic Literatures - Kleist
reviews: Absolutely take this course! It seems like an obscure topic, but it's really engaging and the professor has totally unexpected things to say about all of the stories... and links them together in really useful and thought-provoking ways.
If you have a chance to take a class with Professor Vogl or about Kleist, go for it!
It's an excellent class and the professor is extremely nice.
This is a good course. I would recommend it to anyone interested in German literature.

Want to be blown away by the genius of German literature? Take this course, and take it with a genius of a professor. Hopefully he returns as a visiting professor soon. This course was a true pleasure, and an extremely rewarding intellectual experience.
prereqs: GER 107 or equivalent.
descrip: This seminar offers both a general introduction to the oeuvre of Heinrich von Kleist, one of Germany's most renowned authors of the period circa 1800, and an exercise in close reading of short German prose texts (novellas, anecdotes). We'll discuss specific narrative strategies, Kleist's poetics of the event, the relation of law and literature, and the codification of history. These issues will be related to other writings of Kleist (dramatic, aesthetic, autobiographical). Participants are encouraged to read a selection of Kleist's stories in preparation for the class.

title: The Politics of Modern Islam
reviews: Absolutely take it.  Great subject taught by exceptionally knowledgeable people.
Attend all the lectures, do all the readings, and you'll find yourself learning more than you expected.

Definitely take this course if you are interested in the subject. The lectures are packed with interesting information and Haykel is an expert in the field. However, be prepared to do a significant amount of reading each week.
Do all the reading yourself or split them up with another student. Try to summarize the readings as you go.
Do not do all the reading; much of it is unhelpful and strange. Rather, focus on topics covered and lecture, and read the selections that are related to those themes.

Don't take it unless you can avoid being graded by Mr. Sahner. He screwed me over with the grade. He gave my midterm a debilitatingly low grade simply for messing up one of the details of the instructions for the essays. He admitted the quality of my essays was far better than the grade he gave me indicated, but refused to reconsider on those grounds. Avoid him at all costs. He made this class, which is good based on its content and the professor, a living hell.
Go to every lecture and focus on the main points he gives every week
Great class to PDF
Great course, especially if you want to learn more about Islam/Middle East.
Great lectures and information. Will change your perspective of the world. I strongly suggest finding time each day to review/read, and please get Haykel as your preceptor.
Haykel is awesome.  Not a hard course, and you'll learn a lot.
Highly recommend it; Haykel is fantastic in presenting the material; do as much of the readings as possible; you probably won't finish

I absolutely recommend it to those in politics and history. I?d recommend that you make a study guide for the different Arabic words and names, and make your reading responses are thorough so that you can use them to review for the final exam.
I absolutely recommend this course- it's interesting, pertinent, and the professor is incredibly knowledgeable.

I strongly recommend this course; however, more so to those who are interested in the middle-east or enjoy historical and religious readings.  There is a lot of reading but it is interesting and all is most definitely not necessary to understand the concepts and key points that are reinforced in lecture.  Haykel is a great professor and committed to helping his students take away a lot of knowledge and understanding of the middle-east.  This class is very informative and relevant to today's world in understanding what is really happening in a big region of the globe.  It will be very useful.

I would strongly recommend putting in a lot of effort into each week's reading response. Being more specific as opposed to making generalizations is also an important approach to consider when writing them.

I wouldn't take it unless you're really interested in the specifics of Islamic history. Also, it's really tough to get a sense for what he's looking for in the essays which makes the grading somewhat arbitrary.

If you want to learn more about Islamic political theory to better understanding many of the current events of our generation, I would highly recommend this class if it's taught by Haykel. If you're not interested in the material, then I'm not sure you'd like it. Your interest in the material will make or break this class for you
It gives you a good general understanding of what's happening in the Middle East, but the beginning focuses more on religious theory. You need to put aside a lot of time to do the readings.
It's easy and interesting

Lots of reading, but you really only have to become an "expert" on two topics by the midterm and like 4 by the final and you can get a good grade in the course by the nature of it's grading structure. Take it if you're interested in the Middle East because Haykel is a boss.
Make sure that you attend every lecture because Professor Haykel gets through a lot of information in one session and the majority of it is important.
Must attend all lectures and be invested in getting the readings done.
Not all the readings are actually necessary. Try to appraise them beforehand. Also, don't think you can get by without reading at all. Then you just sound ignorant.
Pay attention in lecture, very helpful stuff.
Prepare to read alot. But you will learn a significant amount about Islamic politics, so it is definitely the class to take if you are interested in this subject.

Prof. Haykel moves quickly and his lectures do not have powerpoints nor correspond directly to certain readings. A lot of required reading, but a very intersting course and very important for all students, even those with little background on the Middle East, to take!
Stay on top of readings and take very good notes in lecture.
Take good notes, and think about the syllabus questions as you do the readings!
Take it if you have an interest in current affairs. You will learn a lot . Don't get behind on the reading.
Take it.
Take it. Become a knowledgable person in the world.

Take the course.  If you have any interest in the topic of Islamic and Middle Eastern politics, or just current world events, then the course is extremely useful.  The readings can be pretty lengthy, but if you go to lecture and take good notes then its pretty easy to work through the readings and pick out the main ideas quickly.  Professor Haykel is a great lecturer and I would definitely recommend this class.
Take this class, if only for Prof. Haykel! He is amazing.
Take this course - Professor Haykel is a brilliant, engaging lecturer and you will come away with such a better understanding of the affairs of the modern Middle East.
Take this course if you are at all interested in what's happening in the modern Middle East.
Take this course regardless of what major you are. It's totally doable and you WILL learn something
Take this course! It's a real winner: well-taught, interesting, and not too much work aside from readings.

Take this course! Professer Haykel was one of the best and most knowledgeable lecturers I have had at Princeton. You will learn so much about a topic that is especially relevant and important in this day and age. Join a reading group and split up the readings if they do not shorten the syllabus! Pay close attention in lecture, which should not be hard because Haykel is so clear and eloquent.
Take this for a basic knowledge of Middle Eastern political affairs.
This course is alright if you absolutely must take it to fulfill a departmental. Otherwise, I would not take it. It is fairly boring and not extremely interesting.

This is a good introduction to the subject matter, emphasizing the political theory and social history aspects. Prof. Haykel is a good lecturer with a wealth of experience in the field, so the course comes highly recommended.

This is a relevant course for anyone as it introduces the backstory behind the conflicts in the middle east today. It's also incredibly interesting, and Professor Haykel is great. Be prepared for a fair amount of reading, but it's not all totally necessary, and there isn't much work besides that, the midterm, and the final, which are both fair if you study and prepare for them.
Try to get Christian Sahner as your preceptor if you can
definitely take this course!!
take it! so relevant and so interesting
the precepts aren't great but lectures are worth it.
prereqs: Open to all and no pre-requisites for taking the course..
descrip: This course examines the political dimensions of Islam. This will involve a study of the nature of Islamic political theory, the relationship between the religious and political establishments, the characteristics of an Islamic state, the radicalization of Sunni and Shi'i thought, and the compatibility of Islam and the nation-state, democracy, and constitutionalism, among other topics. Students will be introduced to the complex and polemical phenomenon of political Islam. The examples will be drawn mainly, though not exclusively, from cases and writings from the Middle East.

title: From Jesus to Constantine: How Christianity Began
reviews: A great course. Professor Pagels is an excellent lecturer and the material is quite interesting. It's also not that much work, so it's a good PDF class if you need an HA.
Ask the professor questions. She is incredibly intelligent and knowledgeable.
Best HA there is. So cool, Pagels' lectures are phenom, and even if you do just half the readings a week you can keep up
Definitely recommend if you're interested in religion or Christianity!
Don't take it!
I recommend this course or any other course with Professor Pagels.

I took this class merely looking to fulfill an HA, but it's been my favorite Princeton course. Being raised a Christian, I now have a better understanding of some of the things I've taken for granted; don't feel like looking at things historically or critically will undermine your faith. (I know there were many non-Christians in the class too, and that made precepts more interesting.) We can see why Professor Pagels is top of her field--her enthusiasm really shines through during the lectures, which are fast-paced and interesting.  The primary readings are usually fairly diverse, and the assignments are definitely manageable.
I would recommend it if you want a good grade in a religion class, but making yourself go to lecture is challenging.
I would recommend taking the course definitely. I really enjoyed Elaine as a professor and would look into taking another one of her classes.
I'd say take it if you're interested in the subject.

If you're a Christian:  take it.  
If you're not a Christian:  take it.  
If you're into the humanities:  take it.
If you're more into the natural sciences and math:  take it.

Christianity is one of the most prominent world-wide movements not just in the last 2000 years, but in all of human history.  A better understanding of the origins of these movements (no, it was not one unified movement) helps to enlighten not just other disciplines, but everyday life experiences.  Plus, Professor Pagels is the best professor I have had at Princeton, and also one of the most approachable.
It is good if you have enough time to do the reading or know some things beforehand.
It'll change how you think about Christianity, and maybe even the world. An excellent, interesting class for anyone in any discipline.
It's much more focused on learning than grades - great way to structure a class.
Make sure to attend lecture even if you start to fall behind on readings. I found that even doing the reading after lecture can be helpful.
PAGELS IS THE BEST!! I want her to be my grandmother...she has so much enthusiasm for the material.  Definitely try to get her as a preceptor
Pagels is an amazing lecturer. Take this class especially if you are genuinely interested in Christianity and have some previous experience with religious studies.

Prof. Pagels is so engaged with the material and her excitement is infectious, the topic is super interesting but there is just so much to talk about that it is clear what Pagels chooses to focus on is only just skimming the surface.  Her lectures really made me think and the quality of the written assignments was great - I was excited to delve into the material. Highly recommend.
Select a good preceptor! And go the the lectures--Prof Pagels rocks!
Stay on top of the reading! It's a great class but can be a lot of reading sometimes.

Take it if you're interested, it's really relevant stuff.  I wish I had gone to more lectures -- Pagels is a great storyteller in lecture.  Workload is minimal so good course to either PDF or try to get an A in.
Take it!
Take it! And read as much as you can before lectures because they make the lectures even that much more interesting.

Take it! Professor Pagels is a dynamic lecturer, and precepts are pretty relaxed. If you do, though, just be conscious of possible biases in secondary sources.  For example, the four gospels are said to be written within a range of years, but some sources use the latest dates in order to claim that the Gnostic gospels were written around the same time period.

Take it, but be prepared for less history than the description suggests. Professor Pagels is fascinated with Christianity because she wonders how it succeeded - so she goes into detail on contradictions, peculiar happenings, and interesting topics, sometimes straying from the history of the movement. But overall, I found it interesting.
Take it, but be prepared to defend what you believe
Take it. So interesting

Take this course even if you have no religious background. I had no knowledge of the Bible and learned so much. Professor Pagels is very approachable and the most engaging and spirited lecture. I really admire her enthusiasm and dedication. Don't miss out on this course of a great opportunity to learn from one of the most distinguished scholars in the field!
Take this course with Pagels! Fantastic lectures. Absolutely no drawbacks to taking REL 252.
Take this course! But avoid having Prof. Pagels as your preceptor! While a great mind, she is terrible at running precept and generally bad at communicating with students.
Take this course! It's fascinating to critically analyze the bible and Christianity by seeing its formation and influences over the centuries.
Take this if you need an HA. Or if you will find the content interesting. I enjoyed this course.
This course can be spiritually challenging for Christians. Be sure to go in knowing that your faith may be shaken some.

This is a tough course to take if you are a Christian, but if you have a strong faith and can understand that Professor Pagel's perspective on the issues is NOT the only one out there (even if she presents it as so, you'll do alright.
You will learn about early Christianity, mostly because the readings are well-chosen. But the lectures are overrated.
don't buy all the books, its all online. only read articles if you need them for a paper.
go to lectures they're very good
pagels is great work is manageable would certainly recommend it
descrip: How did the movement that began with a few followers of Jesus of Nazareth become a world religion? We will investigate the earliest primary sources, gospels and historical accounts, Jewish and Roman, showing what was known about Jesus--including secret gospels; letters written to and from Roman emperors about whether to kill Christians to stop the movement; first hand accounts of trials, prison diaries, and martyrdoms; Paul's writings on sexual practices and gender; what converts wrote about why they chose Christianity, despite the dangers; how emperor Constantine--and, shortly after, Augustine--influenced what we know as Christianity today.

title: Matrix Structural Analysis and Introduction to Finite-Element Methods
reviews:
...Don't.

Unfortunately, if you're even considering the course, it's probably required anyway.  Go to precept, get through it, and learn what you can.
Always precompute the matrices you need for an exam. It would be very difficult to get through the entire exam if such time consuming tasks aren't taken care of beforehand.
Anyone who's taking it is probably required to take it. Give it your best shot, but don't be frustrated if you don't enjoy it.
DO NOT TAKE UNLESS YOU HAVE TO. IF YOU HAVE TO GO TO PRECEPT.
Do not take it.
Do not take this course if not required. You learn very little and the class is a wreck.
Don't take it unless you have to.
Don't take it unless you have to. This is not a 'for fun' class. If you have to, just ask lots of questions regardless of how the professor reacts to them.
Don't take this course unless it is required for your major. If you have to take it, GO TO PRCEPT, and be sure to ask the TA's lots of questions.
Don't unless you have to.
GO TO PRECEPT
GO TO PRECEPT. Make friends with the TAs. Find cool partners to work with.
Go to every precept!
Go to precept
Go to precept.

Go to precept. The preceptors are amazing and will tell you everything you need. If you put considerable effort into preparing for and listening during lecture, you MIGHT be able to get something out of lecture. Otherwise, you will not really understand the theory behind what's going on in the class. If you just want to pass, that's fine. You can even get a good grade that way. I'm kind of disappointed that the lectures were so bad though, because the class has potential. Also, BUDGET LIKE 50 HOURS FOR THE LAST PSET I'M SERIOUS.
HAHAHA just try hard. You can do it.
Hope they improve this course for you guys, but if they AIs are the same you'll manage to get through the class.
I'm sorry they make you do this . . .
If you can not take it. Don't.

If you're an engineer - take it. It's a class that provides you with a great understanding of finite elements - and this is crucial since it's used in a lot of computer analysis. Prevost is amazing - he's a genius - the precepts are helpful. But you sort of need to be patient - things make sense in time.
If you're taking it, you're being forced to by virtue of being MAE or CEE. Just grin and bear it, I guess.
It's ok...

It's really cool to see how differential equations and linear algebra are used in order to simplify structural analysis and plane stress problems and such, but unless that is your concentration, I probably wouldn't recommend taking the course. Learn Matlab!
Lectures are not helpful at all, but the precepts are great and teach you everything you need to homework and tests.
MAEs, I'm sorry you have to take this class. Everyone else, stay away as long as Prevost is teaching
NEVER TAKE THIS COURSE BECAUSE OF INTEREST!!! I wish so much that this course were dropped from the requirements for CEE. It is a horrible class. My worst at Princeton so far.

Obviously you will only take this if you have to. That being said, GO TO PRECEPT. Ask questions (to the preceptors, not Prevost). And make sure you try to understand the material you learn after the midterm, so you can actually do them by hand (your problem sets in the second half are all by Matlab).
Only take if you have to
People taking this are required to.
Precepts are the only way to survive.

Princeton is the only school where this course is taught at the undergraduate level. The skills and methods we learn in this class are going to be very useful for thesis work and will be helpful when/if I decide to go to grad school. I am glad this course is required for Princeton students because I feel like it puts us ahead.
Read Colorado State University FEM slides.
Required course for MAE/CEEs. Go to lecture, especially go to precept. Take good notes and find good partners for weekly psets.
Skip lecture, waste of time. Never skip precept. I would recommend against it, but it's kind of required for MAE.
Stay on top of the material any way you can.  I bombed this class, so I not really the one to ask for advice.
Take it if you have to

Take it to know more about what goes on in the engineering software you use. You compare the Matlab code with actual commercial software, which is cool. Examinations are more computational and require time efficiency.
The course covers material that can be very important for engineering studies, but the course is not taught well. You learn to do your homework during precept, not lecture.
There is no escape I guess. Just sit back and enjoy.

This is a course you just need to get through.  Choose your partners for assignments wisely as you will only be able to get help from them.  Even the preceptors do not give adequate help for most problems that you run into (unless you do the problem set before the precept so you can ask constructive questions..which is extremely difficult because they don't tell you how to do it until precept.)  Don't waste your time going to lecture.

This is a sink-or-swim sort of class. It taught me to rely on my own reasoning in order to solve any questions I had, since there is pretty much no extra help if you can't figure out the assignments or practice exams. You're not allowed to collaborate with other students except one partner, which makes this class competitive in the worst way, typical of Princeton. Don't take this class unless you absolutely have to. The main skill I developed in this class is how to code in MATLAB.

Use this website: http://www.colorado.edu/engineering/cas/courses.d/IFEM.d/
It will save your life in his class.

You're obviously only going to take this course if it's a requirement for your major. A couple tips:

1) No need to go to lecture. It's useless. you learn everything you need for the problem sets and exams in precept. 
2) Work five times faster than you think is possible on the first midterm, otherwise you'll never finish. 
3) In the second half of the semester when the assignments are MATlab code, try to solve a simpler type of problem by hand. You'll see it comes usual when preparing for the second midterm.
don't need to go to lecture at all- just attend precepts
interesting and useful material
prereqs: CEE 205/MAE 223 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: Basic concepts of matrix structural analysis. Direct stiffness method. Axial force member. Beam bending member. Formation of element stiffness matrix. Assembling of global stiffness matrix. Introduction of boundary conditions. Solution of linear algebraic equations. Special analysis procedures. The finite element method. Introduction and basic formulation. Heat diffusion, plane stress and plane strain elasticity problems. Plate bending problems. The use and implementation of structural analysis and finite element computer codes using MATLAB is emphasized throughout the course.

title: Introduction to Architectural Thinking
reviews: A great class. Lectures are hilarious and interesting. Workload is not too high. Material comes up in conversations every now and then, making you look smart, which is always great.
Always participate in the precepts and make sure you understand all the concepts. Work hard on the assignments and try to approach buildings and concepts from all directions.
Be aware that its not really an introduction to architecture.
Be prepared to think very creatively. Also, do not underestimate this class as an easy distribution requirement.

DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCES. This is the single worst class I've taken in all my time at Princeton. Even PDFing, it made me actively unhappy on a week to week basis. Grading on assignments is beyond harsh and homework design assignments are so frequent and time consuming and there's no way around them. I came out of the open note midterm crying because I didn't even understand what the questions were asking. Also, half of the preceptors are incredibly rude and take themselves way too seriously. 

P.S. Kipnis opens the class by saying you're all going to get A's. False...Half the people I know taking it ended up PDFing out of obligation (because their grades were so bad), not choice.
Develop a good relationship with your preceptor and stay engaged. Come to lecture because it is very interesting material and Kipnis makes it easy to pay attention.
Do not take for grade if you're not an artistic person and expect an A.You will be expected to draw and build models. That being said the workload was very light
Do not take it! Worst course on campus. Take any other class instead.
Do not take this class. Don't even think about it. You will not learn anything useful and will become extremely frustrated.
Don't take it unless it is restructured.

Fulfilling an LA requirement but don't have any idea of architecture? This may be interesting for some of you and I'd encourage you to try this course out to learn something. But, because I had no prior knowledge about architectural concepts, I found this to be a very hard course. It is more about theory than actually drawing plans for buildings. It all depends on you really, but because of my lack of interest, I really struggled.

I think the discussions in this course can be very interesting for anyone, whether they are an architecture major or not. This course will not only introduce you to discussions about buildings you never knew existed but also can increase your creativity, if you give time to the assignments. This course would take as much time as you want to allocate to it, but I recommend working on the assignments over the course of a couple of days and experimenting a lot; because I think they are both very fun to work on, help you understand the subject, and also you get a substantially higher grade on the assignments you work on more.
I would highly recommend it if you are flexible about doing work and want to push yourself to think creatively. Also makes a good pdf class, if you're looking for an LA.
If you like formal analyses, take it. If you want theory and history, don't.

Interesting introduction to architecture. Very theoretical with a few hands-on homework assignments, which may or may not be what you expect to learn from architecture. Professor is fun and engaging but also a little disorganized.
It's a very fun class, as professor Kipnis is hilarious, but don't take it unless you have some interest in architecture/art analysis.

Kipnis is a good professor but the preceptors were the problem- they seemed to all be working individually and standards were very different (some actually ensured students did readings, other not, easier grading, etc.)
Not to difficult
Only if really interested
Some of the reading is very difficult and is not used in class, so try to focus on the relevant material.
Take it

The lectures are extremely funny although a little bit unfocused. I think that the way in which Prof. Kipnis explains all the architectural concepts makes everything really easy and enjoyable to understand.

This class is a good introduction to architectural thinking. It will definitely leave you thinking about architecture differently, and the work load is very manageable. This is a fun class, for majors and non-majors alike.
This class is interesting, but be prepared to be a bit confused by the assignments. Ask questions for guidance.

This is a very interesting course and Jeff keeps it entertaining, though I had trouble taking the classwork seriously at times. Anyway, you learn a lot about the world of architecture and you start to see the built world differently.
This is much harder than the similar intro courses in art history, but if you are really interested in architecture and willing to work hard on the homeworks, take it. Kipnis is AWESOME.

When taking this course, realize that there is still a lot of theoretical information that you will be going over.  It is not as generic as just memorizing names of buildings, but more so the architectural idea that lies within them.  If you want a different LA or have a general interest in buildings around the world, I would recommend this class.
don't take it if kipnis is teaching again; if you need a light workload class, then take it.
the preceptors take it way more seriously than the professor, which kinda sucks because kipnis always jokes about it being an easy A, but he doesn't actually do much of the grading.
descrip: The objective of this course is to provide a broad overview of the discipline of architecture: its history, theories, methodologies; its manners of thinking and working. Rather than a chronological survey, the course will be organized thematically, with examples drawn from a range of historical periods as well as contemporary practice. Through lectures, readings, and discussions every student will acquire a working knowledge of key texts, buildings and architectural concepts.

title: Ceramic Sculpture
prereqs: Prerequisites: VIS 201/202, or VIS 203/204, or VIS 211/212, or VIS 221/222, or VIS 261/VIS 262..
descrip: This course is designed for students who are interested in learning the fundamentals of working with clay. A wide variety of hand-building will be taught, enabling students to make utilitarian vessels as well as sculptural forms. Students will learn about glazing and colored engobe application methods and how to operate electric and gas kilns. Studio work will be complemented by readings, field trips, and slide presentations.

title: Bodies in Cultural Landscapes
descrip: http://www.princeton.edu/pub/frs

title: The Medieval Romance: Writing Sex and Death
prereqs: No familiarity with Middle English or with medieval literature is assumed. Along with a course in Chaucer this course will give students a comprehensive idea of the most important literature of medieval and early Renaissance England. We will also examine descriptions of travel to imaginary, otherworldly, and devotional places; the role of the household in the writing and preservation of literature; and the function and nature of chivalry..
descrip: This course examines the most important form of imaginative literature in medieval England, covering at least as much terrain as the modern novel. We will focus on the romance's fascination with spectacle, luxury, love, myth, death, and rule, and consider the ways in which the recurrent subjects of identity, mourning, economics, and religious devotion subvert or reinforce structures of authority and belief.

title: Devising Theater with Youth
descrip: Devising Theater with Youth is a service learning course that will promote experiential learning for both Princeton University students and children from Community House, an on-campus afterschool program. This hands-on course will provide an opportunity for Princeton students to elicit the voices of children, interweave them into a theatrical play, and create a collaborative community event around the culminating performance. Students will learn and apply essential contemporary theories and foundational practices of community-based devising technique.

title: The Philosophy of Kant
reviews: Anyone interested in the history of philosophy should take this course, and anyone that wants to become interested in the history of philosophy should take this course, but it is not a course for someone that gives up when they are confused. You will be confused most of the time.
Difficult but worth it.

Find time to discuss the ideas in the CPR with other students.  It was hard to engage and discuss in class because it was really a lecture setup, but if you find time out of class you'll be able to engage more with the text.
Go to lectures. You are wasting your time if you don't.
I would recommend it, but keep in mind that as the course goes on it becomes increasingly difficult to keep up with the readings. Don't get behind, if you care about that.

If you have a serious interest in Philosophy, this is a must-take course. Not only because of the importance of Kant in the discipline today, but also because this is just a great course.
