Professor Hogan is a witty, humourous, dynamic and engaging lecturer (although at times his self-confidence borders on arrogance), and he is THE person to guide you through your first reading of the Critique of Pure Reason. You'll get a lot out of it whether you do the readings or not, but you will still get the most having done them.
Take it!

If you really like Kant, I would recommend taking this course. It is hard to slog through if you don't already have a love for his difficult style and ideas. It will, however, repay dividends if you engage seriously with the text.
It's an excellent course; be prepared for very difficult readings.
Only if you really want to work through Kant.
Take it if Hogan is teaching, but only if you're really interested in history of philosophy.
Take it if you're ready for the challenge..!
The material is difficult. If you really want to understand the material, it will take a lot of work outside of the class. That being said, it's very rewarding and interesting material.
This course requires serious work and mental gymnastics. I would only recommend it to Philosophy majors.
descrip: An examination of Kant's Critique of Pure Reason.

title: Jews, Muslims, and Christians in the Middle Ages
descrip: An introduction to the history and culture of the Jews in the Middle Ages (under Islam and Christendom) covering, comparatively, such topics as the relationship between Judaism and the other two religions, interreligious polemics, political (legal) status, economic role, communal self-government, and cultural developments.

title: Introduction to Biological Dynamics
prereqs: MAT 103 or equivalent.
descrip: Designed for students in the biological sciences, this course focuses on the application of mathematical methods to biological problems. Intended to provide a basic grounding in mathematical modeling and data analysis for students who might not have pursued further study in mathematics. Topics include differential equations, linear algebra, difference equations, and probability. Each topic will have a lecture component and computer laboratory component. Students will work extensively with the computing package Matlab. No previous computing experience necessary.

title: Financial Engineering Seminar - Topics in Financial Engineering
descrip: Discussion of recent topics and papers in financial mathematics

title: Architecture Design Studio
reviews: A sophisticated studio, interrogating architecture's role in social transformation and urban poverty, Not for the faint-hearted.
Be well prepared and try to challenge yourself.
I would advise other students to take time to make sure Giancarlo understood their project and that they understood his ideas.
If Mazzanti offers another course in Princeton, you should definitely take it.
Prepare for the intensity of the class.
Take it for sure. Do what you want and be clear with your arguments.
descrip: Explores architecture as a social art and the spatial organization of the human environment. Projects include a broad range of problem types, including individual buildings, groups of buildings, urban districts, and landscapes.

title: The Quantum World
reviews: Don't take this course unless you have to.

I would NOT recommend this class with Prof. Soos.  If Mark Watson is teaching, it may be better.  
Please, please do not take this.  It was poorly taught with tedious psets that do not help you understand the material... the worst class I've ever taken at Princeton.

If you're a chem major, go ahead and suffer through it.  If you're not a chem major, you better have a passion for learning quantum.  This course is a good way to obtain a basic understanding of quantum mechanics, and therefore, I would recommend it because I am an advocate of scientific literacy.
It isn't a fun class. I think this is the last time Soos is teaching it, so hopefully it will be better in the future. You probably feel obligated to take it...
Problem sets, lectures, and readings don't coincide well. You may have to spend a lot of time figuring out/looking for what you need to learn in addition to learning the material.
Read the book.
Take it if you have to because Soos is retiring and Mark Watson, who would have been an amazing main instructor, is taking over.
Take it if you have to satisfy the departmental and/or if you want to go to graduate school in Chemistry.
This is a good introductory course to quantum mechanics. If you're interested in the material, take the course.
do not take a class taught by zoltan
no
only take if you have to
prereqs: CHM 202 or CHM 204 or CHM 215; MAT 102 or MAT 104; PHY 101 or AP Physics in high school credit..
descrip: Introduction to quantum mechanics, surveying applications in chemistry, physics, and spectroscopy.

title: History of Palestine/Israel: Nationalism, Politics, Culture
descrip: Offers an introduction to major ideological, political, and cultural trends in Palestine before and in connection with the emergence of the State of Israel in 1948. Taking both a local and global perspective, we will analyze the evolution of Zionism and other forms of Jewish politics, the formation and negotiation of Arab and Palestinian nationalisms, and the complexities of interethnic and interreligious encounters in several spheres. We consider a range of historical interpretations and think about the multiple paths that scholars have taken in interpreting the history of Israel, Palestine, Zionism, and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

title: Introduction to Syriac
descrip: A systematic introduction to Syriac language. Close reading of selected passages of Syriac texts.

title: Syntax
reviews: Be prepared to draw a lot of trees.

I would definitely tell other students to stay on top of the reading and to not be afraid to ask questions. The material is challenging and abstract, so if you don't ask questions, then you could get lost.

If you can keep up with Freidin (he is brilliant, helpful, but a bit scatter-brained), and if you are at all interested in syntax, this is definitely not a bad course to take. Hopefully, if you do, there won't be other students in there determined to show-off and to get discussions off track every chance they get.

If you're serious about understanding linguistics, this is a must. Even if syntax isn't your favorite subfield, you can appreciate its elegance and analytic approach. If you're just looking to get a distribution requirement or just want to dip your toes into linguistics, I recommend taking a less analytic course.
prereqs: LIN 201 or 212, or by application..
descrip: An introduction to the syntax of human language, focusing on the mechanisms of sentence construction and the general principles that determine their operation. The focus is on the structure of English, with some side trips to other languages. Designed for students interested in a scientific approach to human language and a better understanding of its structure.

title: Screenwriting II: Adaptation
reviews: A great class if you are willing to engage with the material. It would be a disservice to other students to be enrolled in the class and not have an interest in active participation in the course material.
I would strongly recommend taking a course with Prof. Lazaridi. I am interested in her other screenwriting course
If you are interested and can get in, take it!
If you get in, take it!
If you have any interest in screenwriting- take this class!
Professor Lazaridi manages to teach creative writing in a way that not only helps you unleash your creativity, but also helps you with your nonfiction writing. Highly recommended.
Take this course if you have the chance!
prereqs: Interested students complete a creative writing application (please visit the program website) by attaching a statement about why they would like to take the course. Please note this course cannot be audited..
descrip: This course will introduce students to Screenwriting Adaptation techniques, focusing on adapting "true stories" pulled from historical sources or the news. Issues of documentary technique versus fiction, the ethics of adaptation, how to turn facts into dramatic structure and the questions surrounding the need to fictionalize truth for dramatic purposes will accompany the analysis of World Cinema examples of film adaptations through the 20th century. Students will be asked to write one short silent film and one 30 minute film, adapted from a story they find in the news.

title: PhD Seminar: Research Design
descrip: This is a research design course. We will discuss some issues in the philosophy of science, analyze questions of conceptualization, proceeding to problems of descriptive inference, objectivity, and causal inference, including role of causal mechanisms. The seminar will continue with analysis of how to avoid bias, tackle issues of historical change. Students will present their own research designs and critique their colleagues. Emphasis will be on qualitative research, but the argument underlying the seminar is that the same basic principles of inference apply to qualitative and quantitative research.

title: Bad A$$ Asians: Crime, Vice, and Morality in East Asia
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Language, Identity and Power
descrip: See Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Cultural Systems - Dream, Delusion and Reality in Literature Around 1850
descrip: In the post-Enlightenment period dreams and uncanny visions appear again in European literature. 19th c. novels, poems, plays feature dreams that border on delusion and madness. The line between reality and illusion forfeits its stability. This seminar inquires into how dreams relate to the political and social changes of the time. Also focuses on the link between dreamlike states of the mind and literature itself. Particular attention is given to different modes in which dream and delusion are represented in texts by writers of the period, from Hoffmann to Poe and Flaubert.

title: Music and Lyrics: Italy in the Eyes of its Pop Singers
reviews: A great class for exploring the history of Italy without focusing on literature. The songs were fun and I learned a lot about Italy and musical analysis in general.
Great new course, different change of pace from the literature and cinema courses commonly offered by the Italian department. Strongly recommend
I really hope that this course is offered again and strongly recommend it to those who just finished the 100-level sequence and even those who have taken 300-level courses.
I would definitely recommend this course to everyone that wants to improve their Italian while learning about Italian culture.
Take it! Do the listening and readings and participate, Marchesi is great.

This is an excellent course for someone who speaks a fair amount of Italian. It gives a great look into the history/culture/politics/etc. of Italy in the second half of the 20th century. I would highly recommend participating in class in order to get the most out of the songs and Marchesi.
do it! :)
fun and interesting!
prereqs: Prequisite: ITA 107 or permission of instructor. This course is taught in Italian. The course accomodates students who have just completed the language requirement sequence or come from the summer intensive course in Macerata..
descrip: This course is designed to introduce students to the rich tradition of Italian songwriters active between the 1960's and the present. Working at the crossroads of American influences and the tradition of Italian political songs, the cantautori merge popular appeal and literary sophistication. For at least three generations, their songs have provided an engaged soundtrack to Italy's turbulent social, political and cultural transformations in the post-WWII years. As lyrics on the page, as music to be listened to, and as performances recorded in video, Italian canzoni d'autore are part of the Italian identity today.

title: Materials World
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Shakespeare II
descrip: A study of Shakespeare's plays, covering the second half of his career. Emphasis will be on each play as a work of art and on Shakespeare's development as a poet and dramatist. Two lectures, one preceptorial.

title: Topics in 20th-Century Literature - Philosophy and the Poetics of Temporality: Heidegger and Celan
descrip: Our seminar will explore the relationship between philosophy and literature through the lens of Heidegger and Celan, towering figures who met in 1967 but had been reading one another's work from the 1950's on, and their profound meditations on the nature of temporality; we will confront the fundamental phenomenology and thinking of time in the early and later Heidegger with its radical reconfiguration developed by Celan in his poetry, prose, and poetics. Central themes: ontology and mysticism, now-time and the instant, datability and the date, the event and the revolution, the opposed visions of ethics and politics their projects suggest.

title: Philosophy of Mind
reviews: Boring, the least interesting type of philosophy. Generally asks lots of questions with a lot of incorrect assumptions underlying them, that are then assumed to be true in the proceeding discussions. Lectures boring. Good PDF class.
Excellent course for someone with interest in the topic. I would highly recommend.

Have taken at least 3 philosophy courses, understand what analytic philosophy is, how philosophical arguments are constructed, and be interested in reading academic philosophy papers. The material will not be dramatized or spoon fed.

I think people tended to love or hate this course, depending on how they reacted to the subject material. Figure out if you're actually interested-- it's awesome stuff and you'll get a ton out of it-- but don't take it if you're looking for a no-work ec credit. It ended up being a fair amount of work.

I think this was an okay course. Gilbert Harman is a brilliant philosopher and great guy, but some of the lectures just seemed lackluster. I found myself studying a lot of the material on my own (the reading is very dense by the way) and getting clarification on everything during precept. Overall, good course if you're interested in Philosophy of Mind. Wouldn't really recommend it if you have no idea what Philosophy of Mind is about.
Take this course if you are interested in the intersection of philosophy and neuroscience/computer science. It will broaden and sharpen your knowledge of both.
Unless you are a philosophy major, don't do it.
descrip: The course will discuss such issues as the relation between mind and body,what it is for mental states to have content, the computational theory of mind, neurophilosophy, folk psychology, mental causation, self-knowledge, consciousness, mental qualia, subjectivity, perceptual content, animal minds, and emotion.

title: Solar Energy Conversion
reviews: It is very confusing.  Not well organized.  He expects alot without telling you what he expects.
It's pretty fun. Difficult if you're a highly visual learner/thinker since the final exam is oral and you need to talk a lot in precept.
Take a lot of readings.

This course throws a lot of knowledge at you very quickly. I think it's almost impossible to take it all in at once - rather, take in as much as you can, and just spend some free time every now and then absorbing bits and pieces until the connections start happening in your brain.

This is a good class to give you an idea of the solar energy technologies that currently exist or are in the research phases. It also gives you some handy ways of thinking about and analyzing the viability of various technologies for replacing fossil fuels.

This is not just a course in solar energy.  Professor Wagner aims to teach you about life and prepare Princeton students for life after graduation.  The course is very much focused on critical thinking, high-level quantitative evaluation, and preparing students for engineering and management jobs.
This was a good course. Ask the professor to speak up, though.
prereqs: Completed freshman science or engineering courses (MAT 104, PHY 104, CHM 207). Open to others by permission of instructor..
descrip: Principles and design of solar energy conversion systems. Quantity and availability of solar energy. Physics and chemistry of solar energy conversion: solar optics, optical excitation, capture of excited energy, and transport of excitations or electronic charge. Conversion methods: thermal, photoelectric, photoelectrochemical, photosynthetic. Solar energy systems: low and high temperature conversion, photovoltaics. Storage of solar energy. Advanced conversion techniques. Conversion efficiency, systems cost, and lifecycle cost.

title: Contemporary Korean Language and Culture I
reviews: Definitely take this course. It's a lot of work, but it's worth it; you will come away from the class with a lot of knowledge and appreciation for the Korean language/culture.
Take it if you're really interested in learning Korean and the culture.
Take it, seoseonsaengnim is awesome! It's not a terribly heavy workload and as far as evening seminars go, it doesn't get more interesting and relaxing than this.

Take this course even if whether you've worked your way up from Kor 301-2 or whether you're already fluent. Language skills differed among students, but improvement was all scaled based on the individual, and you will definitely see yourself improve in reading, writing, and speaking.
prereqs: KOR 302 or Instructor's permission..
descrip: The 4th-year language course is designed to accelerate students' proficiency to the high-advanced level and to promote a deeper level of understanding of Korea and its people. A wide range of sociolinguistic and sociocultural issues are covered through the use of various media resources (e.g., dramas, films, songs, commercials, newspapers, websites) as well as short essays. Classroom discussion are conducted in Korean.

title: Probability and Stochastic Systems
reviews: A challenge, but if you like probability and are up for the work, it is a great course. Cinlar's lectures are fantastic.

A decent class, but tons of work. Really think about what your other classes look like before signing up for this course. It is valuable, but I feel that the amount of time you put into it is not worth the return.
Attend office hours regularly. Otherwise, the class can be almost prohibitively difficult.
Awesome course. Prof Cinlar is great.
Be prepared for a lot of work, and hard material.
Cinlar makes the topic very interesting. Be prepared to put a fair amount of work into the class though.
Difficult yet rewarding.
Do take this class, but take it seriously even though you are a Math major. If you practice enough, you will do wonderfully.
Don't schedule anything for right after this class because lectures tend to run over time.  Sit toward the front if you want to see the board and hear the professor.
Don't start your problem sets too late.
Find a study group at the beginning of the semester.

First off, this class is not as hard as some reviews claim it to be. Maybe if you're a humanities person who thinks probability is about fractions. But the excellent teaching could bring anyone up to par anyway. Cinlar is like a Yoda of probability. his lectures are stupendous. There's nothing more I can say. And, if he's still precepting, get Patrick! he's AMAZING and second to Cinlar really makes this course. I attended the other precepts at first and went away each time incredibly frustrated and actually depressed about how to face the week's homework set. Then I started going to Patrick's (i know this sounds like a medicine commercial now but honestly...) He clearly plans ahead of time, starts by looking at the big picture, is always sure to be consistent in notation and topic as Cinlar, even goes to lectures and records himself to get better. He's super helpful in office hours, will give you 200% of the explanation you asked for (even doing problems wrong to show you the error of your ways), and if he sees that you're still unsure offers to meet with you in person more. He really teaches you how to THINK when approaching a question. Yes, the class is a time suck but honestly is so worth it.
Fun course, requires some "mental gymnastics" and good intuition.
Fun, interesting course. Not nearly as terrible as some people would have you think. Also not exactly "life-changing" but definitely worth taking.
Go to precept.
Good class.  Take it.  If you're not good at math, it's hard, but it's still worth it.  I got a lot better at math towards the end, but I would have liked more time for learning and improving more.

Good course to learn about probability and stochastic systems. I feel that my view of the world has slightly changed for the better after taking this course, as I am able to analyze things in a more probabilistic manner.

Great course, I highly recommend it to anyone looking to get an introduction to probability. That said, while this course requires math and is listed as 300 level math, it is not on that level of rigor. People interested in the more rigorous treatment of the material are better off taking the math department versions.
Great course, you learn a lot, but you need to set aside serious, serious time to do well. If you're aware of that, take it. But don't take this course lightly.
Great course. Definitely go to all the precepts since its often key to doing the problem sets.
I strongly recommend the class if you are interested in the subject. The professor is great and the TA's are awesome.
I would advise students to take this course but be willing to put a lot of time into it.

I would definitely take this course, if you're into a real challenge. Make sure to go to Cinlar's office hours; he's an amazing person and very helpful.
Put in the work, it helps if you're gifted at math, and good luck!
I would take this course if you might be interested in the subject. Just be warned that it is very time-consuming.
If you like probability go for it.  If you like more concrete math, I wouldn't suggest it.

If you were good at math contests in high school chances are you are good a probability, but if you're not so inclined for probability you will definitely struggle a lot. The only thing you could do is go to office hours a lot. Also understand Cinlar's style for his exams.
It is great!  The material is really interesting, and Cinlar is the best lecturer.
It's all math but take it if you are interested because you will be engaged throughout.
Make sure that you understand how to do the problems fully. If you don't understand each step, you probably won't do very well on the tests. I speak from experience.
Office hours are super helpful! This a difficult but rewarding class!
Spend the time to learn the material in the beginning.
Start the problem sets early. Work with people. Go to office hours. Do practice problems. Even Cinlar will tell you that this stuff takes work, so be prepared to put in a good amount of work.
Take it and challenge yourself,
Take it if you can handle the work. It's definitely worth it.
Take it seriously. You'll get a lot out of it.
Take it! It is totally worth it.
Take it. It teaches you important concepts that will prove to be useful in the future.
Take it. Might take a while to understand the materials but it's worth it.
Take it. Take the course.
Take the course! You have to work though, its definitely not easy, especially if you slack
Take the exams seriously and do the readings, even if they seem redundant. Don't be intimidated by this course's reputation; if you take it seriously and don't slack off, it's not terrible at all.
Take the time to read over and understand the material. It is worth it.
Take this class
Take this class if you are interested in the subject. It is a lot to study, but it is rewarding at the same time. It is one of the best classes I took so far.
Take this course if you have to and Cinlar is teaching it. If you don't have to take it, still maybe consider it if you are interested in the subject matter since Cinlar is a great professor.
Take this course if you like math and understand calculus.

Take this course!  However, be prepared to invest a lot of time in order to fully grasp the deeper concepts (and the mathematical tricks); the material is fascinating, but developing a thorough understanding of the material is not an easy task.
Take this course. I'm WWS and I throughly enjoyed it.
Take this course. It will teach you to have an intuition for probability, which is so much more valuable than just having to plug and chug integrals.

Take this if you have a general interest in probability. It's useful and not very difficult. The course was definitely very interesting, and not too computationally heavy so the concepts were easy to understand.
Take. Cinlar is really cool and says funny things. Learn to understand problems conceptually.

This class is really hard. Cinlar is really good, but expect to struggle through the problem sets and study hours for the tests. Also, start your "Big Homework" pre-Exam assignment early, it literally took 5 days for me, that is, from getting up in the morning until 2-3am at night.
This class isn't for everybody, but the effort you put into it is well worth it (if you're interested in the subject matter).

This class will be harder than everything you take. Take it for PROF. CINLAR! If you do, go to Patrick Rebeschini's office hours, precept, review session, extra office hours, personal meetings...everything. You will learn simply by watching Prof. Cinlar, Patrick and Cagin (another cool TA) do some awesome and beautiful math. Ask for help if you need it.
This course was a lot of work and from my perspective, not much of it will be useful in my research, therefore I wouldn't recommand it.
This is a fantastic course: brilliant and immensely provocative! It's tough, but it's definitely worth the time and the effort!

This is a great introduction to probability theory. The problems in homeworks and on exams are very computation based. When you prove things, it is through computation. Professor Cinlar is awesome, and he is very knowledgeable about random things like history, etc.

This is a math class; but a math class that emphasizes thinking logically over intense calculations. That being said, the biggest reward from this class will be a new way to think of problems, which I imagine lasting far longer than the specific material covered in the course. If you don't enjoy thinking creatively about math, then this class will be very hard.

This is a very challenging course that is time consuming for a person who has not had exposure to probability and stochastic processes before. Be prepared to work for a long time on problem sets, especially the Big Homework at the end of the term! However, the material is very useful and applicable to a large number of different fields, so I urge you to take on this challenge even if you have to P/D/F it, as I have done myself.
Very beautiful math, interesting applications, and challenging problems. If you're at all interested, definitely take this class - you won't regret it.
difficult class, but worth taking
i found the material very difficult

it's a really good course; definitely take it if you're even slightly interested. the material's really useful for a lot of different fields. the course is definitely challenging though, so you'll have to be on top of your stuff from day one. do not fall behind! it'll be much more difficult to catch back up. as long as you keep up with cinlar, go to precept, and do the homework until you understand what's going on, it'll be a very nice experience. cinlar is also really good at teaching this
start the big homework early
take it if your research is about quantitative modeling
prereqs: MAT 201 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: An introduction to probability and its applications. Random variables, expectation, independence. Poisson processes, Markov chains, and Brownian motion. Stochastic models of queues, population dynamics, and reliability.

title: The Changing Brain
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Extramural Research Internship
descrip: One-term full time research internship at a host institution to perform scholarly research directly relevant to a student's dissertation work. Research objectives will be determined by the student's advisor in consultation with the outside host. Monthly progress reports and a final paper are required. Enrollment limited to post-generals students. Students will be permitted to enroll in this one-semester course at most twice. Participation will be considered exceptional.

title: An Integrated, Quantitative Introduction to the Natural Sciences I
reviews: Be careful. This course can be interesting and is definitely a unique opportunity, but it is not for everyone. The workload is exceptional and if you take this course, you absolutely should not be taking five courses your freshman fall.

Definitely try the course if you are interested but do not be afraid to drop.  It is an enormous amount of work (easily 40  hours some weeks for me) but worth it if you are interested.

However, be careful of taking on too hard a remaining schedule while taking this course.  For example, while it is possible to take MAT 215 and integrated together, the students who did so did not seem to get as much out of the course and had a needlessly difficult time.  Similar advice applies to other intensive courses.
Don't take this course unless you're sure you want to do a science major - in that case, it's great.

I think those that want to take Integrated and will benefit most from it will inevitably end up there. To someone thinking about pursuing research, to people who love science, to those who are genuinely fascinated by the mysteries and the triumphs of science spanning multiple disciplines, integrated is the answer. I would warn them of the long, very long, nights in Icahn, the very difficult problem sets, the on-average 40 hour labs, the times when I felt like I was in way over my head; but for those who will really benefit from integrated, this is not likely to deter them. It is, in fact, likely to encourage them, and I think that those people belong in the integrated program and will grow in understanding, in scientific ability, in strength, and in confidence by taking it. I think that I have been lucky in the group of people taking it this year - we have a fabulous atmosphere, strongly encouraging collaboration, and generally have become a tightly knit group of fellow science enthusiasts. I oscillate between being completely astounded by how brilliant these people are, thrilled that I get to work with them, and just plain amazed at the science we get to delve into. In short, I would recommend those meant for integrated to take it; it is, hands down, worth it. It will not be easy, but it will be rewarding.

I would definitely take this course, and I suggest some familiarity with physics and chemistry, and calculus in advance.  The course work, such as problem sets is reasonable, as long as you find people to ask questions and are not afraid to ask questions when confused.

I would recommend this course to those wishing to pursue an extremely (sometimes to the point of absurdity) rigorous course which will foster the kind of quantitative thinking necessary for all sciences in the 21st century. But it cannot be taken lightly.
If you are ready, and you want to challenge your self, then do it. This course is challenging, but if you are up to the challenge, you are going to love it!

If you're really interested in science and want to do research in the future, this class is perfect for you.  You also have to work really hard, but you get really close to your classmates.  The professors are awesome, too.
It's going to be extremely time-consuming and difficult, but you'll get a lot out of it.  Don't take if you don't want to major in one of the natural sceinces.
It's really tough, a lot of work, especially for a freshmen. But it's very intellectually satifiying with some of the best instructors.
Make sure you really are prepared for it before you enter. This course is incredibly hard but it is a very enriching course that forces you to think on a different level.
Only take the course if you are willing to invest huge amounts of time especially initially, or settle for a less than average grade.
Take people seriously when they tell you this class is a lot of work. Be prepared to stay at Icahn for several hours every night.

Take this class if you have a strong interest for the sciences and for the future of the sciences. The future is in computer science and the integration of the sciences, and this will prepare you very well for a research-oriented scientific career. Be warned, the workload is immense.
Take this course if you are truly willing to learn a new approach to science. Don't take this course if you want to have a lot of extra time.
Take this course if you're serious about science and are willing to put in close to 40 hours a week of work.

This is the most interesting course you can imagine. The lectures are interesting, even the problem sets are interesting. It's difficult, and takes a lot of time, but it's 100% worth it, especially since not only are the professors and grad students very available to help you, but the community is such that everybody helps one another. Definitely take this course.
You should take it.
prereqs: Familiarity with the calculus at the level of MAT 103/4 or Advanced Placement Calculus BC, solid high school physics and chemistry courses..
descrip: An integrated, mathematically and computationally sophisticated introduction to physics and chemistry, drawing on examples from biological systems. This year long, four course sequence is a multi-disciplinary course taught across multiple departments with the following faculty: W. Bialek, T. Gregor, J. Shaevitz (PHY); P. Debenedetti (CBE); O. Troyanskaya (COS); H. Yang (CHM); C. Broedersz, T. Calhoun, A. Leifer, B. Machta (LSI Fellows). Additional lectures in fall term will be given by D. Botstein (MOL) and P. Andolfatto (EEB). Five hours of lecture, one three-hour lab, one three-hour precept, one required evening problem session.

title: Circuits and Signal Processing
reviews: Be prepared to dedicate quite a bit of time to this class. The problem sets are usually pretty long and challenging, and the labs are either straightforward or seemingly impossible.
Do not take this course unless required to take it as an electrical engineer.
Don't take unless you have to. This course needs a lot of work.
Go to class, pay attention, and be sure to review your ELE 201 notes.
Good, interesting material. You'll need to be insistent if you don't understand something or if you magically lose points on exams.
I would recommend this course, especially as a starting point to understanding signals and systems and a precursor to other signals-related courses like Digital Signal Processing.
It is a difficult course.
There is no reason to take this class if you are not an electrical engineer.

This course was painful.  The material was interesting, and Professor Liu and the TA were kind and helpful, but the problem sets were extremely long and difficult, besides being graded harshly.  Take only if necessary.
prereqs: ELE 201.
descrip: This course focuses on analyzing signals (sound, voltage, communication transmissions, pressure, images, etc.) and the systems that act on them (circuits, physical echos, mechanical dynamics, modulation, etc.). We concentrate on the Fourier transform and linear-time invariant systems, providing a depth of tools for sampling, manipulating, preserving, and interpreting information signals. The course also has a weekly lab component which includes building a "Shazam" music identification system and controlling an inverted pendulum.

title: Systematic Ethics
descrip: This seminar will work through a range of problems in normative ethics, meta-ethics, moral psychology, and moral methodology.

title: Claims and Evidence in Sociology
reviews: If you put a good amount of effort into this course, then you will be in good shape for writing the rest of your JP in the spring.
If you're a SOC major, take it...though you don't really have a choice.

It's not the most interesting of courses, but it'll do. Sociology is one of those rare departments that really holds your hand through the entire research process. If you're not a SOC student, I don't know why you'd take it.
Read literature.  Start early.  Be honest with your preceptor.
The only reason to take this is because it is a requirement for SOC major.
Well, if you're a major, you're in the class.
You have to take it, so make the best out of it.  I encourage you to try methods you're not familiar with because this is one of few times you won't be penalized.
You have to take it. Prepare yourself, it sucks
prereqs: SOC 101 or another 200-level sociology course.
descrip: This is a course on the logic of social research. We discuss how sociologists apply a specific approach of inquiry we call "science" to analyze and explain social behavior. While surveying a wide range of methods, we will learn how research questions can be answered by using various combinations of theory, methods, and data. Three assumptions about society will be examined: 1) Durkheimian notion of "society as a thing"; 2) society as a composite of variables; 3) society as a meaning-producing process. Students will learn how to formulate a research question and how to marshal empirical data to make a sociological argument.

title: Central-European Literature of the 20th Century
descrip: This course is designed to introduce students to Central European literature, culture and history. We will focus on texts from Poland, ex-Czechoslovakia and Hungary, and the impact of Jewish culture on the region as a whole. The course will begin with the interwar period (1918-1939) and the immediate postwar part of the course is dominated by fictional and nonfictional accounts of World War II, the Holocaust and Communism. We will discuss literature as an opposition tool, the writer in exile, and the post-communist accounting for the past.

title: Modern Memory
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website

title: The Romantic Period - Xtreme Romanticism
descrip: A shattering of consensus during the French Revolution controversy had grave consequences for the notion of moral standards and norms. In the wake of such norms, many experiments--literary, political, or social--led to extreme destinations. Course explores the extremities toward which Romantic-era writers ventured and at which some arrived. Discussion, as it moves among poems, novels, dramas and non-fiction prose, is enriched by primary sources that report on scandals, conspiracies, spectacles, follies and fiascos of the era. Course also considers teaching strategies for texts and films.

title: Analysis II: Complex Analysis
reviews: Complex is beautiful.
Definitely take it with Professor Stein.
Do take this course, but depending on who you get for grading, you may need to be a lot more careful with your proofs.
If Professor Stein is teaching this course, then definitely take it!
It's hard to catch up if you start falling behind, so going to class forces you to stay in touch with the material.
No choice if you're a math major, but TAKE IT ANYWAY! Stein is really wonderful, and the class is just so well designed.

Stein is a living legend in this field and you have the opportunity in this course to hear him talk about a subject he literally wrote the book on. Bottom line, if you can do the math, take this course.
Stein knows his stuff very well, and you learn a great deal of complex. Four hours of class a week can get old, though.
Take it even if you are not a math major. The perspective it gives is really interesting.
Take it if you want to learn cool math.
Take it, take it, take it. It's very hard though, so be prepared.
Take it.
Take this class before Stein retires!
Take this class if you really want to get into complex analysis and alot of the number theory applications of it.

Take this course if you are willing to put in the work required for the problem sets. It is definitely a good class but if you only want to learn complex and are not really interested in the specific topics covered in Stein's book you can take MAT 330
The course is very useful and contains interesting material.
The material is very interesting, and Prof. Stein is quite a good lecturer.

This course feels a lot like 215 and 217, but at a higher level of difficulty.  The textbook is an excellent resource if you get lost in lecture.  The problem sets vary in difficulty, but are all manageable.

This course lives up to its reputation, as the best class the math department has. Stein's lectures have this paradox that everyone always wonders about: How does he proceed so slowly, and yet cover so much in the entire semester? Stein spends his time slowly going over each logical point (so that everyone can follow), yet by the end of the semester we cover all ten chapters of the book.
Tough graders...
prereqs: MAT215 or MAT 218 or equivalent..
descrip: Study of functions of a complex variable, with emphasis on interrelations with other parts of mathematics. Cauchy's theorems, singularities, contour integration, power series, infinite products. The gamma and zeta functions and the prime number theorem. Elliptic functions, theta functions, Jacobi's triple product and combinatorics. This course is the second semester of a four-semester sequence, but may be taken independently of the other semesters.

title: Evolutionary Biology
reviews: DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE UNLESS YOU HAVE TO OR FEEL YOU HAVE TO!
Don't take it unless you have too
Don't take it unless you're interested in genetics and evolution on the scale of the genome.  Landweber is much more of a MOL teacher than an EEB teacher.
Don't take it. The preceptors are wonderful but the class itself is not.
Don't, but if you're taking it, you probably have no choice.

Evolutionary Biology, as it was taught this semester, was one of the worst courses I have taken at Princeton. The material wasn't usually presented clearly, and many topics were basic evolutionary theories that I have explored in many of my previous EEB courses. I would recommend that if you can take any other course to fulfill the requirement, take that route.
Good primer for the unversed in evolution, and a good introduction to the deeper stuff for those who already know a thing or two.
I understand the course will be taught by a different professor next year, so it might be more interesting. As it was, I found it rather unexciting, and I don't think I learned very much.

I would recommend taking this course if you do not understand the basics of evolution yet. However, if you're like me, and this course only fit into your schedule senior year, you may find that you already know most of the material covered from other EEB courses and the course may seem redundant.
I would say to ask for the preceptors' help on the problem sets as they are very helpful and seem to understand the ambiguity that Landweber leaves.
I would strongly recommend taking this course.  I found it very interesting and enjoyable.
If given the choice to read either "The Origin of Species" or " Beak of the Finch", choose the latter. The former is too long and not worth the effort.

If something is over your head in the weekly readings don't worry too much about it. It's a good idea to make use of office hours in order  to understand the more difficult concepts that are covered in lecture.

If you have to take this as the evolutionary class then you have no choice, but if another class pops up, then take that one for sure.  The tests are very sloppily written which leads to unnecessary point loss.
If you're EEB, you have to take this course.  I suggest taking it with a different professor.
Landweber is not teaching the course next year so take it! It is a good course and you learn a lot.
Laura Landweber's lectures are absolutely horrible.  She doesn't talk loud enough and rambles in class so you have no idea what point she's trying to make.
Make sure you understand the quantitative methods!
Only take it if you really love evolution and all the math that goes with analyzing selection data or as a departmental.
Pay attention in lecture. Study in groups.

Professor Landweber likes delving more into molecular biology, which is okay for some people.  I think I didn't like the class as much because of that and, if I could have taken it earlier with a different professor, I would have.
Required class. Understand examples in lecture
Take this course if you are interested in an overview of both molecular level and organismal level evolution.
Take this course next year. The professor and lectures will be different, while the material should remain interesting.
The information can be interesting but sometimes can be presented rather dryly.

This course has a whole lot of fascinating material to offer but is delivered rather poorly because of the lectures. The subject matter is very important for understanding many aspects of biology, but the lectures can be very frustrating.
Work on the problem sets with other people. The textbook isn't that useful.
Work together, go to precept office hours
Wouldn't take it if I didn't have to
don't take unless it is a requirement
interesting but harder work than one would expect for "evolution." hint:it's not all darwin.
n/a
sucks. dont take unless you have to.
work in groups on the problem sets
you have to. it sucks.
prereqs: EEB 211 and any course in molecular biology or equivalent (e.g. 214 or 215).
descrip: All life on Earth has evolved and continues to evolve. This course will explore evolution at both the molecular and organismal level. We will examine the features that are universal to all life and that document its descent from a common ancestor that lived over 3 billion years ago. Topics include the origin of life, the evidence for natural selection, methods for reconstructing evolutionary history using DNA, population genetics, genome evolution, speciation, extinction, and human origins. This course will provide you with the basic tools to understand how evolution works and can produce the incredible diversity of life on our planet.

title: Modern South Asian Literature
descrip: Selected modern writers from the Indian subcontinent: India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, and more. This year's class focuses on South Asia since 1947. Topics covered include colonialism and nationalism, gender and sexuality, urban vs. rural imaginations, the impact of Gandhi upon politics and literature, violence and non-violence, Partition, ecology, diaspora and exile, literary representations of the contemporary "rise" of India as an economic power. All works in English translation or English original. Additional readings in literary criticism and history.

title: Introduction to PDE
prereqs: Introduction to Real Analysis (MAT320) or equivalent, or consent of instructor..
descrip: The course is a basic introductory graduate course in partial differential equations. Topics include: Laplacian, properties of harmonic functions, boundary value problems, wave equation, heat equation, Schrodinger equation, hyperbolic conservation laws, Hamilton-Jacobi equations, Fokker-Planck equations, basic function spaces and inequalities, regularity theory for second order elliptic linear PDE, De Giorgi method, basic harmonic analysis methods, linear evolution equations, existence, uniqueness and regularity results for classes of nonlinear PDE with applications to equations of nonlinear and statistical physics.

title: Language, Identity and Power
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Networks, Economics and Computing
reviews:
- Have a good idea of how to do FORMAL proofs. Even thought they teach you how, it would be better if you already knew.
- Informal proofs only get you partial credit.

An okay course, but not the best course that the COS department offers. Professor Braverman and the preceptors are fantastic, but the course/assignments felt disorganized at times. The course itself introduces a smattering of little topics, but did not go into depth into any of them. Therefore, at the end of the course, I felt as though I had not really learned anything. The course itself though was not a lot of work, but overall, I would not recommend it.

Chances are that this course will change a lot from now until the next time it's taught, because this was the first time. It's a good theory course, although I'm a little biased because I like theory courses. It felt about as hard or a bit less than 340.

Definitely interesting material, but be aware of the curve!  The median on everything was 100%, but there is not much work until the final project (independent research with a group).  Your grade pretty much comes down to this.  Braverman is awesome and definitely one of the most reasonable professors in understanding workload.
Do take this class if you are interested in theoretical computer science or discrete mathematics! The professor is amazing.
Don't take this course unless you have to or it's with another professor.
Easy for a COS theory course. Weirdly easy grading--not sure you can expect that next time. Interesting topic.
Good course if you are looking to satisfy the theory requirement for your CS degree.  Not that difficult if you have already taken CS340.
Good theory class for non-theory people. Interesting, acceptable workload and fun :)
Good way to fulfill theory
I can't speak from the non-COS perspective, but for COS majors: this is a good class to take to get your theory requirements out of the way.
I would wait to take this course until it is more established.  Everyone basically got 100s on all the assignments, so grade deflation may be  very bad.

I'd recommend against taking it if you really want to learn about the subject matter. Many people appreciated it as an easy theoretical computer science course, but I learned very little in this class. That said, Braverman is a great professor and if you're really passionate about the subject maybe you can pick up more by doing all the readings and getting guidance from him.
If you like game theory, you will enjoy this course.
Interesting stuff, not a bad way to fulfill the theory requirement
It's a very digestible CS theory course
It's probably the least time-consuming theory class you'll find. Braverman is a great lecturer!

It's unfortunately not as interesting as you would think, so only take it if you are looking to be largely bored with everyone else in a clustered set of identical grades with little differentiation until an ill-defined final project.
Not my favorite class but not the worst.
Not too difficult and interesting material. Lectures were boring and assignments were pretty chaotic. Good to fill the theory requirement, though

Overall this is a pretty good course, and probably one of the better (and easier) courses to take for your theory requirement.  It gets bogged down in notation a bit and some parts are needlessly complex, but overall it's not too difficult.  It focuses a lot on game theory and so in many ways feels like a more math-based and in-depth version of POL 250.
Perhaps wait a few years, although the information itself is interesting and good to know. But it's a course that requires a lot of management, and at the moment it's a bit scattered.
Take it for the COS certificate.
Take it!
Take it, but be prepared for a game theory intensive course.
Take it. Difficult, but not too difficult.
Take it. Manageable theory course, cool real-world applications.
Take this course, but be prepared for a near-perfect assignment median and a very important final project.
Take this course. It is interesting material and the programs are fun.
Take this especially if you need a theory course. It's not difficult and this is coming from a non-math/science/engineering/CS major.
The class is interesting and relatively light on the rigor of math this semester. Be warned, Professor Braverman claimed that future versions on this class will require COS340 as a prereq.
The course was ok, but it is tough to judge from a first-time offering.

The course was very disorganized, but it might have been just the first time it was taught. I didn't think the class was at all exciting, and if you've taken another course on game theory, it's kind of a waste of time. Also the assignments were too easy and the median was always around 98, so I expect a mean curve.

The material is interesting, but the curve is harsh. It's less work than COS 340, but your grade would be much less predictable (everything hinges on the final project). PDFing is a option if you want to save your grades.

The only reason to take it would be because it's the simplest COS theory departmental, falling right after COS 340. Apart from that, for everything in the course - Networks, Game Theory and Economics - there are much better courses to take at Princeton. Medians on assignments and exams will be in the 100's so be prepared for that.

The topic is great although some of the lectures were a little bit dull. I would suggest that Prof. Braverman make some slides for all of the lectures. 

Prof. Kintali is one of the best preceptors I've ever had. He gives interesting applications of the topics and he takes his time to answer any question. I loved that the precepts felt like a one-on-one session although most of the other precepts were probably different as they were a lot bigger.
There are better, more engaging options. Lots of them.
This is a good class to take if you're interested in economics, and is a great choice if you're doing the finance certificate.

This is a great class. At first, I was slightly intimidated because 60% of the kids in the class had already taken 340, and I hadn't. But Professor Braverman taught us everything we needed to know, and made lectures and assignments super interesting. That's not to say they were straight up easy. They were still challenging and required significant work, but they were very satisfying when completed. People generally ended up doing really well on the assignments, so grades may come down to our final projects, but we'll see. All in all, definitely a class worth taking. I would take it again in a heartbeat.
This should be your another theory class, if you don't like theory.
Unless you're so good at math that this would be boring, you should take this course. Nuff said.
Yesm take good lecture notes and start on assignments early
You should really take this class if you're a CS person. Even if you aren't, as long as you can code a little in java for the programming assignments, it's just really interesting.
You will be unbelievably bored.
recommended as a theory course.
prereqs: COS226, MAT 175 or MAT 202 or 204 or 217, or instructor's permission..
descrip: Computation and other aspects of our lives are becoming increasingly intertwined. In this course we will study a variety of topics on the cusp between economics and computation. Topics to be covered include: games on networks, auctions, mechanism and market design, reputation, computational social choice. The aim of the course is two-fold: (1) to understand the game-theoretic issues behind systems involving computation such as online networks, and (2) to learn how algorithms and algorithmic thinking can help with designing better decision and allocation mechanisms in the offline world.

title: Health Concerns in the 21st Century
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Representing Illness
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Policy Analysis: Selected Topics (Half-Term) - Public Private Partnerships
descrip: This seminar will explore the historical and current use of public-private partnerships (PPPs) globally. It will explore the technical, commercial, legal, policy and socio-political aspects of these critical transactions. The content begins with an overview of the typology of PPPs across the world. Diverse cases will highlight the key interests and recommended strategies of both the commercial party and the public agency in negotiation, introduce the critical considerations in an effective PPP policy, and draw out internal and external factors driving the success or failure of PPPs.

title: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Western Culture I: Literature and the Arts
reviews: An enormous workload- but it's possible and entirely worth it. That's all that matters. Don't take it if you're looking for an easy course with light reading.
Best class at Princeton, hands down. Cannot compare, am very lucky to have taken the course. Can't recommend it enough!
DO IT!!! (If you really like to read.)
Do it
Do it if you like reading and writing.  If you don't like reading and writing, don't take this course.
Do the readings ahead of time. Form relationships with the professors.
Don't take this course.

HUM is a class that you will either LOVE or HATE. Yes, they do have to be in all caps, because you will be passionate about your decision. It's not a class for everybody, but if it is a class for you, then it will be the best possible class for you.

HUM is an extremely rewarding class that takes an extraordinary amount of concentration and commitment.  Some people get by without reading some of the literature or don't prepare fully for class, but if you want to get the most out of the course, be prepared to organize your time well and spend hours immersed in amazing words. A must if you love all types of philosophy and literature or are eager to explore new realms of thought.

I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in the material, particularly if it is relevant to their future study. While you may get more insight into fewer texts by taking two other courses, this course is a particularly unique opportunity to interact with six different professors (two of whom will precept for you and grade your essays personally) and a community of peers that is uniquely interested in the subject matter. I am even more excited for the second semester than I was for the first.
If you are ready for a challenge, do it. The readings are daunting but entirely worthwhile. You do not take HUM for a grade; you take HUM to be enlightened.

If you would read the syllabus for fun take this class. If your expectation is to be able to say that you have read the great works of Western Literature, this is the class for you. However, if you are expecting to learn how these works fit into a larger theme, I suggest you look elsewhere.
If you're really interested in reading all the great classics and can keep up with the readings, I recommend it.

It will teach you to do hard work, but so will the other Princeton courses too. The only thing is you will probably laugh when others complain that they have 150 pages to read. As I like to read things in depth, this was probably not a good option for me. If you like to read things in detail, this might not be for you. However, you get general idea about the subject matters.

Only take it if you know you can cut out time to do a LOT of reading, probably the most amount out of any class at Princeton. That being said, it certainly guarantees breadth of knowledge regarding the foundations of western literature, while the precepts and the essays attempt to cover enough depth for each work (with fair success; it does not do justice for each of the canonical work covered, but this is a survey course).
Please show up to class and don't be afraid to have your own opinion in precept- it makes things interesting.
Read all the assigned reading.
Read, read, read
See previous evaluation
TAKE THIS CLASS.
Take it!
Take it.
Take it. You sign your life away to your reading, but it's worth it. If you want to know this stuff, there isn't a better time to do it.
Take this course!!! you will feel that you are so enriched after this

The class isn't really as hard as people say it is, it takes a bit to get used to the schedule, but once you get in the groove, it's fine. This is the case, at least if you really love the books that you are reading. I found myself looking forward to doing the HUM readings and drawing intertextual connections that just blew my mind. It was this that really motivated me.

You have to be really committed to reading everyday, all semester to take this course. Sometimes we read 3 whole books in one week (which is just not realistic) and it really stressful. If you are a masochist, take this course.

You will probably see a ton of other reviews that say "the most satisfying and fulfilling course at Princeton, wish every class were this amazing." Take this with a grin of salt because it only becomes that if you can manage the insane, yes insane, amount of reading. Otherwise you'll be lost and feel like you have a ton of philosophy being shoved down your throat. In small doses this course is quite interesting, but expect a ton of literature and philosophy, with dashes of history. I suppose I pose more of a warning than a negative recommendation. The professors are amazing and the classes are great so going to class is highly recommended, but again, if your a above average paced reader, expect 4am-ers, a lot. If your a slow reader, expect 4m-ers but witha ton more anger and frustration at the world. But hey if thats your thing, thats your thing. Carefully examine your abilities.
prereqs: This course is primarily directed to exceptional freshmen, but qualified students may apply at any point in their undergraduate careers..
descrip: This course, along with HUM 217, form the first part of an intensive yearlong exploration of the landmark achievements of the Western intellectual tradition. With an interdisciplinary team of faculty drawn from the humanities and social sciences, students examine pivotal texts, events, and artifacts of European civilization from antiquity to the middle ages as part of an ongoing cultural conversation. The course is enhanced by guest lectures and cultural excursions to museums, concerts, and plays. The two courses, taken together, total six hours a week and fulfill distribution requirements in both LA and HA.

title: African American Literature: Origins to 1910
reviews: Do the readings in advance!
I'd recommend to make sure to read each reading in depth, as it will help greatly in precept and lecture.
If you decide to take this course, make sure to practice writing some extra essays on your own time to learn good essay writing.
If you're genuinely interested in the subject, take it. If not, don't.
It's a lot of reading, but it's rewarding if you keep up with it.
Professor Brooks is great! Stay on top of the readings and you'll do fine (of course, that's standard Princeton logic but that's perhaps even more true here).
Strap in, y'all. Strap. In.
Take it! Great AAS intro course, and English course in general.
The readings were manageable, and the lectures and precepts are enjoyable. Even if you are not an English major, you'll still enjoy the class.
descrip: This introductory course focuses on texts from the mid-eighteenth century through the early 20th century; it will cover early texts such as poetry by Phillis Wheatley & Paul Laurence Dunbar; oratory by David Walker, Sojourner Truth; slave narratives by Frederick Douglass, Harriet Jacobs; spirituals; black theatre by Pauline Hopkins, Bert Williams; fiction by Charles Chesnutt, James Weldon Johnson; & non-fiction by W.E.B.DuBois, Anna Julia Cooper, Booker T. Washington. The course explores how black literature engages with the politics of cultural identity formation, notions of freedom, citizenship, and aesthetic forms.

title: Advanced Russian Grammar through Reading
reviews: If you're interested in languages, and if you really want to get good at Russian, you should take it. If you don't really like Russian that much, don't take it.
Take it if you want to learn more about Russian and translate better.
prereqs: RUS207 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: A practical approach to advanced Russian grammar through reading and translation of Russian prose texts with special focus on difficult grammatical constructions.

title: Topics In Complex Analysis - TBD
prereqs: Undergraduates must obtain permission of the instructor..
descrip: This course covers current topics in Complex Analysis. (More details are provided when course is offered/scheduled.)

title: Byzantine Art and Architecture
descrip: Art and Architecture of the Eastern Mediterranean and Eastern Europe, from ca. 600 to ca. 1500. The course will focus on the art of the Byzantine empire and its capital, Constantinople, but will also consider its broader sphere of cultural influence (Russia, Armenia, Georgia, Sicily, Venice, Serbia, Bulgaria, Rumania). The course will examine the major factors which shaped the artistic legacy of Eastern Christendom during the Middle Ages.

title: Advanced Hebrew Language and Style I
prereqs: HEB 107 or permission of instructor. Required course to receive NES Certificate in Language and Culture..
descrip: This course is one of four courses offered towards the certificate in NES Language and Culture. The course surveys different historical and contemporary aspects of Israeli culture and society integrated with current events, newspaper articles,T.V clips,etc. HEB 301 explores the history of the Israeli cinema, the evolution of the Israeli popular music and the reflection of socio-cultural-political events. Current events that are relevant are also integrated. All skills of the language are implemented.

title: Seminar in 19th- and 20th-Century French Literature - Readings in the 20th-Century Novel
descrip: A study of major French or Francophone novels of the twentieth century in conjunction with critical texts on narrative.

title: Quantitative Analysis (Advanced)
descrip: Statistical analysis with applications to public policy. The course begins with an introduction to probability theory followed by discussion of statistical methods for estimating the quantitative effects of changes in policy variables. Regression methods appropriate for the analysis of observational data and data from randomized controlled experiments are stressed. The basic level (507B) assumes a fluency in high school algebra and some familiarity with calculus, while the advanced level (507C) assumes a fluency in calculus.

title: Microeconomic Analysis: Basic
descrip: Course develops an understanding of basic microeconomic tools. Emphasis is placed on how these tools can be used for policy analysis. Students need not have taken any other economics courses, but should have a good command of algebra and be familiar with basic calculus concepts, although proficiency in calculus is not necessary.

title: From DNA to Human Complexity
reviews: A strong biology background isn't required, but will help a lot, especially in the beginning.

As far as STLs go, this is one of the best. It's relatively easy to get an A (especially if you've taken AP biology) and the labs are actually really cool. You use a lot of cool equipment and that's where Princeton's funding really shows. Lectures are somewhat optional. Just do the reading and try to remember high school biology; this isn't much different.
Be prepared to memorize before the exams, but it is all interesting stuff.
Definitely take it -- not much work, easy to get good grades, short labs, interesting material.

Definitely take it- it's a great way to get your requirement done, it gives you a good background in bio (which is incredibly interesting), it focuses on current issues in bio, it doesn't make things overly complicated or challenging, and best of all, the professors are wonderful and very enthusiastic about what they're teaching, which was great for me as a student.

Do all of the work, and there's no way you could do badly--the material is interesting and relevant enough that everyone can find a subject that interests him or her, even hard-core liberal arts majors.
Go to office hours for help prep for exams
Good for non science people
Great for an STL.
Great if looking for an ST and you're not much of a science person.
Highly recommend.
I great ST from non-science people. Very relevant to our modern world.
I learned so much from this class and highly recommend it (especially for someone looking for an ST).
I think some background on biology is a definite plus for this course because the first half of the semester goes into the technical details about biological processes.
I took AP Bio in HS, which might have helped me somewhat, but this really seemed like a fairly easy way to fulfill the science requirement for non-science majors. Strongly recommend.
I would advise other students to go to all the lectures as they help immensely for the exams.
I would advise students to go to office hours and seek out help because the information builds on itself so if you get confused at the beginning, alot of other topics will be confusing.
I would advise them to take the course.
I would definitely recommend - get Jaclyn as your preceptor and pay attention in lectures.
I would definitely recommend taking this class. There is not too much work and the material is presented in a really interesting way that relates to our day to day life.

I would definitely recommend taking this course if you are looking for an interesting way to satisfy your STL requirement. It is extremely interesting and I really felt that I learned something. That being said, it is relatively scientific and preparation for the exams is pretty difficult, so you shouldn't take it if you are just looking to fulfill your STL requirement without doing any work at all. It was still very manageable and provided nice variety to my courseload.

I would highly recommend this course to both people who love science and people who aren't so sure.  It is great because it covers a wide range of biological topics and examines them specifically and on a molecular level while also relating them to the broader scope of perhaps policy or history.  It is a very fascinating and informative class and will probably make you love science even more!  It isn't too much work and the professors are very helpful in explaining concepts.
I would recommend this course if you are interested in science
I would say that it is important to understand details as well as general concepts and that if you follow along in lecture then you will do well.

I would strongly reccommend this course to students looking for a serious, but not overly burdensome, STL. The class was very interesting and gave students a wide survey introduction to molecular biology. The professors even managed to give students a fair amount of depth on each topic. Furthermore, lectures engaged a lot of modern issues in genetics, such as cloning, that students should be educated about. The course itself explains the fundamental of genetics before moving on to discuss specific issues such as viruses and cloning, DNA replication, and altruism. Taking this course helped me better understand the human body. With good professors and ta's-this is a very good course. PDF if you need to, but you will still  learn a lot.

I would suggest taking this class as the material could be pretty interesting. This course is known to be for people who aren't very sciency, but I warn that sometimes it might get more sciency than you think.

I'd say this class is more difficult than I anticipated but is not impossible for someone who wants to PDF as long as they put in the effort of going to lecture. The lectures make the midterms much easier because some of the questions are addressed in lecture but not in the reading, which messed me up the first time. Labs are enjoyable, though, and usually don't last the entire 3 hours (generally around 2 hours or a little more).
If you need an STL, this course might work for you.

If you need to meet an STL requirement and are scared of labs: take this course!  You will survive, and maybe even excel.  Try to gain something personal from this course, as there are plenty of applications to go around.

If you would like to do engaging labs, with straightforward, short lab reports, or want a general understanding of many of today's biological controversies like stem cells and cloning, all while satisfying an STL and getting a chill class too-- then this is the class for you.

If you're looking for an STL, this is it.  If you're not PDF-ing, go to every lecture and pay attention.  For the exams, I found it most helpful to take my own notes during lecture but to study using the lecture slides, filling in confusing material with my notes.  Don't be afraid to use your lab TA as a resource.
It was a good class to take for an ST. The material is interesting and not too difficult. I think you could easily take this class even if you have a science background.
It's not necessarily difficult, but it will help a lot to actually go to lectures and pay attention instead of skip and then cram for the tests,

It's not the easy ST everyone is talking about, since they changed the format of the course. It's rather a lot more effort than it's worth, I think. The professors are great, but it's just not that great of a class to take. The textbook readings are awful.
It's really easy and not hard to PDF. I'd recommend it if you want an STL.
Just do the homework and the labs and you'll have a good time.
Keep up with the slides and go to every class!
Not very much work - lecture isn't mandatory but make sure you read the lecture slides each week.
TAKE IT

TAKE THIS CLASS. It is really fun and you'll learn a lot about the applications of science to the world around us. Labs may seem long but often we ended early and time passed really quickly because labs were fun. The professors' passion is very evident and that makes for a positive learning experience as well.
TAKE THIS COURSE. I have already recommended it to countless people.
THIS COURSE IS THE BEST.
Take it for an STL!
Take it if you want a doable STL.
Take it! This is the way to take a lab course and learn a lot.
Take it.

Take this class! Everyone needs and STL and it is one of the best there is. It's well taught and the material you learn will keep coming back to haunt you in the media, voting referendums, cocktail parties with people who think they know what GMOs are (they probably don't). Everything is way more relevant than you think, and everyone in charge of teaching the class loves what they do and wants you to do well.
Take this course!
Take this course!  If you need an STL or just are interested in bio, take it!

Take this if you want to complete a lab requirement. You will enjoy it more as freshman or sophomore rather than as someone already deeply engaged in his/her home department. This is the perfectly accessible "liberal arts" version of complex sciences
The instructors are delightful. Take it.
This class is a good option for satisfying the STL requirement.
This class is harder than I thought it would be.

This course is very interesting and is nice if you want a little bit of an intellectually engaging science class as a non-science student.  That said, if you're planning on squeezing this in as an after thought, you're going to have a rough time unless you PDF.  It's by no means a straight up breeze -- the tests are challenging.
This is a very good class to fulfill the distribution requirement. I'm not a fan of science at all, but the material is very manageable and the professors are amazing.
This is one of the most worthwhile ways to fulfill a distribution requirement. It's a great course for humanities majors.

This is the PERFECT lab course for non-science majors. Material is interesting, well-taught, and relevant to our lives. Professors are accomplished and engaging. Since the course has been taught for many years, and they improve it every year, it's veeery good by this point.
Very easy class for your science with lab requirement because so much of the class PDF's it. Don't PDF it because it is easy to get a good grade due to all the PDFers.
Would recommend for an ST.
You'll put in what you get out of it. It's helpful to go to lecture even if you only passively listen. Do the readings and look at the slides on your own time as well.
keep up! its not a lot so make sure you ask questions when you don't understand! good for st--perfect if you're pdf'ing.
take it.
yes.
descrip: This lecture and laboratory course will acquaint non-biology majors with the theory and practice of modern molecular biology, with a focus on biological topics of current public interest. Topics include: structure of DNA, RNA, proteins, genomes and an overview of state-of-the-art technologies including cloning, recombinant DNA and PCR. The course will address how recent scientific advances affect issues relevant to human biology including forensics, stem cells, molecular evolution and the genetic basis of human traits and behaviors such as obesity and aggression.

title: Studies in Modern Arab History - Readings in Islamic Revivalism, Islamist Politics and Law
descrip: This course aims to survey a variety of historical and religious texts in Arabic. Students must have mastery of advanced Arabic. Some of the texts that will be studied have been edited and published, others remain in manuscript form.

title: Advanced Spanish Language and Style
reviews: A little bit on the easy side. Only take if you want a little more practice with grammar and writing before you move on to a higher level Spanish class.
Don't take this class until they completely redo it. There are far better spanish classes and you'll learn a lot more without the frustrations of 307.

I was advised to take this course by the department head in order to improve my writing ability before moving onto other 300-level classes that required lengthier papers.  I was sorely disappointed by the syllabus--the emphasis turned out to be on aspects of grammar with which even many native speakers are not familiar, rather than on improving our writing and our grasp of useful grammatical concepts.  However, I hear that they're revamping the class next semester to fix some of these flaws, so it may be a good class to take in the future.

If Lorena is teaching this course, take it in a heartbeat!! The material is a bit dry, as you may expect, but she manages to make it interesting and relevant to improving your Spanish. Think about the course more as a semester-long opportunity to get better at the language (and also learn a couple of grammatical tricks).
If you like grammar, take it!  Coming from a complete grammar geek.
Only take this course if you have an interest in linguistics.

This class is not for non-native spanish speakers as it stands.  This class is both frustrating and discouraging, particularly if you are interested in improving your speaking skills.  I would recommend finding another class.

This course does not have a heavy work load. It is focused on grammar and weekly has a writing assignment or a grammar exercise. My spoken Spanish did not improve drastically, but my writing comes more fluidly.
This is a good class to take when transitioning from 200 to 300 level courses.
prereqs: SPA 207 and/or another 200-level Spanish course or instructor's permission..
descrip: SPA 307 is a course for advanced students of Spanish who want to expand their writing skills and improve their knowledge of grammatical structures which continue to pose challenges.
