Along with the study of grammar, this course aims at reaching higher levels of accuracy while expressing ideas and opinions in writing. Inspiration for written assignments to be drawn from literary works, journalistic writings and audiovisual materials. Combination of fairly intensive writing, reading and grammar based assignments.

title: Listening at the Museum
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Game Theory
reviews: Do it. Behavioral's the future.
If you are interested in behavioral ecnomics, you should take this course
descrip: This course will provide a broad treatment of game theory and its applications, particularly in economics. Coverage will include such topics as: common knowledge and rationality, refinements of Nash equilibrium, auctions, bargaining, mechanism design, dynamic games, and reputation. This follows up on the introduction to game theory provided in the microeconomic sequence.

title: Law and Economics
reviews: A decent class. Lectures were fine. However, the assignments were long, tedious, unenlightening, and sometimes arbitrarily graded.
A little tougher than other Leonard courses, but still well worth it.
Again, fantastic class. Can't say much more. Definitely recommend it!
All the work is take-home, which makes the readings optional until the assignments are given out. Assignments are extremely time-consuming. Going to lectures is absolutely imperative
Be sure to go to lectures, take notes, and go to office hours.
Definitely attend lectures! It is crucial to you passing the class.
Do not take it unless you like doing work completely alone and with no collaborations with others.
Go to lecture, take good notes, enjoy it!
Good class. A lot of information but it is very interesting. There isn't work very often, but when there is it a good amount. Not extremely difficult work, but a large quantity.
Great class that will especially be interesting for students who are interested in going on to law school. Very little in the way of technical economics is needed though a background is very helpful.
Great course to take.  Definitely time consuming, but the more time you spend discussing the material with other students, the more you will get out of the course.
Great course, delivers what it promises.
I would definitely recommend this class for econ majors.
If you're an Econ student, definitely take at least one Leonard class for your electives.
Make sure to give yourself enough time for the problem sets, take good notes in lecture, and do the readings!
Make sure to take good notes.  Collaboration is not allowed so be sure to ask questions after class and during office hours
Must take this course.
So interesting! Influenced me to change to being an econ major. take it if you like logical (though not necessarily mathematical) things
Start assignments early and go to preceptors for help. Go to lectures because all the important materials will be covered in lecture.
TAKE IT

TAKE IT. Even if you pdf or audit it because you don't have the time or space, take it before you graduate. It is by far one of the most rewarding courses ever in Princeton, and Professor Leonard is absolutely amazing. And go to the right office hours - Juha's if you are lucky enough to have him again.
Take diligent notes and look at the problem set before going to lecture.

Take great notes (they'll be tested extensively on the problem sets.) Be prepared for some great lectures -- this was one class where I was honestly NEVER bored during lecture. Also be prepared for some subjective grading on the problem sets.
Take it.
Take it.  It's hard and a fair amount of work, but it's really interesting
Take it. It's quite a bit of work, but it offers a great perspective into efficiency perspectives in relation to society and the law.
Take it. Professor Leonard is a great lecturer. It is challenging but not impossible, and you will learn a lot about the legal system.
Take it. You'll learn to think economically.
Take the course but start assignments as soon as they are posted on blackboard, and take very good notes (perhaps even audio record them to go back to later if you have questions).
Take this class if you are interesting in Law and Economics, and dont mind writing a bit on assignments.

Take this class! Professor Leonard is AMAZING and you will learn a lot about a very interesting subject matter.  Definitely take this if you're an econ major - it's one of the best departmentals.  It's not super quantitative, but there's definitely some numbers involved, but there's also a lot of qualitative econ.  So there's a nice balance of both qual and quant, and the topics are very relevant to everyday life! One of my favorite classes here, despite its challenging-ness.  I would set out a good amount of time every 2 weeks for problem sets.  Take GOOD lecture notes - they're essential for the psets and take-home exams.

Take this class, especially if you need to fill ECO distribution requirements. All assignments are take-home. You have to go to lectures in order to understand anything on the take-home assignments. But the lectures are fantastic so you should go anyways.
Take this course if you are interested in exploring the legal field. It is a good introductory course to law.
Take this course.
The course is pretty tough but definitely worthwhile

The material was fascinating - this sometimes feels more like a philosophy class about utilitarianism more than anything else - and Prof. Leonard was genuinely passionate about it, so it was great to go to class. But we really should have had precepts, as the assignments end up being opportunities to rehash exactly what Prof. Leonard said in class.
The problem sets are graded in an absolutely arbitrary manner. They are also long and sometimes difficult, but the course material and Leonard's lectures are sufficiently good to make up for it.

This class lots its lustre after 2-3 lectures: the material is interesting but really common sense, and the problem set/exams are insanely poorly worded, arbitrarily graded, and generally unclear. Also, no collaboration on problem sets really is a big downer in this class.

This course is not too challenging technically, but it certainly teaches you to think in a different way. Take advantage of office hours on problem sets and exams, especially with Professor Leonard. He is very helpful and understanding.

This is not a class where you read the textbook and do the assignments and work independently throughout. To do well you need to be willing to go to lecture (and take pretty good notes) because if you do go to lecture, the assignments become really easy. It is worth your time. You also need to go to office hours because the preceptors go over the assignments very well and I think whoever didn't come to these was at a very serious disadvantage. However, if you go to lecture and office hours - you almost have to do nothing else. The case studies take a maximum of half an hour to read and assignments are only due every two weeks - so if you take this class you'll have to work smart, but not very hard, except for the midterm and final assignment. These are not hard, but a bit more time consuming. Take this class though - it's fantastic and a great econ class to take if math is not your strong suit. There is no math in this class but it'll give you a nice and practical introduction into economics.
You need to go to lecture, he gives all the answers there. Take it if you don't mind no work most of the time, then a lot of the work some of the time.
go to every lecture and type as fast as you possibly can or record lectures so you don't miss anything leonard says.

take it, but be warned! psets are excessively long and graded very hard, at times almost arbitrary. but you learn a lot! and lectures are super interesting! one of the only lecture classes where i can actually sit through the 1.5 hour lecture
take this class.
prereqs: ECO 100. Course not required for concentrators..
descrip: An introduction to the economics of law. Application of price theory and welfare analysis to problems and actual cases in the common law - property, contracts, torts - and to criminal and constitutional law. Topics include the Coase Theorem, intellectual property, inalienable goods, product liability, crime and punishment, and social choice theory.

title: Studies in French Language and Style
reviews: 207 is a bit dull - I would recommend skipping it if you can.
A great course for beginning study of French beyond the introductory level.  Take it with Xavier Fontaine!  He's very engaged and passionate.
Be sure you are very familiar with the language before this class.
Do the readings, and make sure to do the grammar exercises, they really help.  Also preparing the questions beforehand can make for a better class discussion.
Don't hold back, talk as much as you can.
Don't take the class if you're not interested in speaking French.

Enjoyable and interesting.  The workload is very consistent -- though you will have readings for every class (which may take an hour each), there are never any huge projects/papers/tests that you will have to dedicate days to.
Follow the readings and be diligent.
Good readings, you have to teach yourself the grammar though.
I would definitely recommend this course for students who want more practice before taking literature courses. Note, however, that it does not count toward any majors or certificates.
I would not recommend you take this course unless it is a prerequisite for another one.
I would recommend starting papers early, and to do all the readings - they're worth it.

If you are genuinely interested in French and French literature/film, this would be a great class for you. However, be aware that if you want to improve technically there may be better options out there.
If you like science fiction/mystery/horror/fairy tales, take this class. Plus, if you need a grammar review, this class has it.
If you want to maintain your French ability without taking a really hard upper level class this is a good class to take.

It felt a lot like lower level classes in terms of the format (15 minutes of grammar and lecture). If you are still working to improve your grammar then take the class but if you are looking for a more conversational lecture based class I would look elsewhere.
It is quite a bit of work, but if you want to get your French from amateur to conversant in a semester this is the course for you.
It will improve your french especially reading and writing.
It's a good course with an appropriate amount of work. M. Fontaine was a great teacher and I really enjoyed this class.
Keep up with the grammar yourself. Do the reading. Even though you can hide in the back of the class sometimes, whether you do the reading or not will show in the end.
Keep up with the grammar. Always participate. Don't be afraid to contribute ideas to discussion. Pay attention to the works because they are central to class.
Le fantastique is a great topic to study. Take it with Fontaine if he still teaches it.
Make sure you work on grammar on your own because it won't be covered much in class.
Not a lot of work, and some of it was fun!
Plan to spend a lot of time studying.

Prof Gayle is all about consistency. Do not miss a class, hand in something late, or make excuses. If you make sure you're a consistent student and regularly participate in class, you won't have a problem in this course.
Take it if you have to or really really like French.  If you need a 200 level French course for a requirement consider other ones.
Take it! Xavier is da man.
Take this course if you are considering other French literature courses. It's a great intro.
Take this course if you want a sound basis in French.  The only way to prepare for the tests is by doing the grammar assignments before every class.
Take your time with the papers and study for the tests.
The topic is interesting but the class is not great
The workload is entirely manageable if you plan well.
This class ends up being what you make of it. For those who truly enjoy French language and culture, I would take a higher level class.

This course leads you into the world of French reading gently. Do the readings and do your classmates a favor by stimulating the conversations. The professor and your classmates will thank you for it. Silence in small classes suck! Also, the movies are very interesting.
This is a good course! It is slightly more challenging than FRE 108 (everyone in the class is better at French and assignments are graded a bit harder) but the workload is the same.
This is a really helpful class, and the material is an interesting way to improve your French.
good luck.
prereqs: FRE 107, FRE 108, or placement based on placement test..
descrip: A study of French contemporary culture and society. Intensive oral and written study of vocabulary, grammar, and idiomatic expressions prepares students for advanced courses in French literature and civilization and for working programs in French-speaking countries. Small class format. Strong emphasis on discussion. Film series. Intensive practical training in oral and written French.

title: Econometrics: A Mathematical Approach
reviews: All-in-all, pretty good class. A little tough during, but looking back you'll realize you learned a lot and you really understand the subject.
Definitely take this course, even if it's not a departmental! It's the most approachable proof-based class I've taken here.
Don't take this course without some background in linear algebra and proofs.
Don't underestimate it: this is a hard course. You do learn some pretty cool stuff though about regression methods.

Fair warning: this class starts to get dry and mathematically intense right around week 3 (which is past the SCORE add/exchange deadline). I think it's definitely possible to do well in it, only if you're able to stay awake in class.
Find the complete lecture notes online. Study those. Lecture is not too necessary.
I took 310 and 311.  312 is much harder.  It's all really mathy kids and the lecture is hard to follow.  It's like a real math class.

I would definitely recommend this course, but I'd also caution that a good amount of time needs to be dedicated to fully understanding the materials.  The problem sets are pretty forgiving, but studying for the midterm/final is extremely difficult if each of the building block steps is not completed comprehensive.

If you're interested in the mathematical justifications behind regressions and the techniques used to analyze economic date, this is a great course. If you don't care about the math and just want to learn the tools, this is not the course for you.
It is a very difficult and confusing class
Keep up with the readings and make sure to keep up with understanding concepts in lecture as you learn them.
Keep up. Do the derivations/proofs week by week or you will be overwhelmed at the time of the final.
Precepts are next to useless, lectures difficult to understand compared to the textbook.
Professor Norets is a very good professor and the TAs are very helpful. This was my most enjoyable class this semester.

Strongly recommend if you're an econ major and highly quantitative (or at least able to understand proofs). Otherwise, this class may be too difficult and you may actually take away less from it than 302.
Take it if you have to, otherwise don't.
Take it only if you have to. A lot of work, pain, are you really getting more than 302?

Take this course but don't do it with Norets, unless you already have a good foundation in econometrics. His writing is impossible to read and he has a thick accent. However, he is a genuinely nice and fair professor, and the problem sets and exams are more than fair.
The book gives great background and explanation to the more rigorous material covered in class.
This class gives a good understanding of econometrics that is essential if you do any kind of economic quantitive research in your independent work.
keep up with understanding the concepts
stay on top of the material, and only take it if you're an econ major.
take into account that it will require a lot of time commitment.
prereqs: ECO 202 (or ORF 245) and MAT 200 (or MAT 202).
descrip: This course is an introduction to econometrics. Econometrics is a sub-discipline of statistics that provides methods for inferring economic structure from data. This course has two goals. The first goal is to give you means to evaluate an econometric analysis critically and logically. Second, you should be able to analyze a data set methodically and comprehensively using the tools of econometrics.

title: Postwar Japanese Narrative: Modern to Postmodern
descrip: This course examines postwar Japanese experience through major literary, cinematic, and intellectual achievements. The objective is first to analyze a multitude of struggles in the aftermath of the Asia-Pacific War, and then to inquire into the nature of post-industrial prosperity in capitalist consumerism and the emergence of postmodernism. The course will cover representative postwar figures such as, Oe Kenzaburo, Dazai Osamu, Mishima Yukio, as well as contemporary writers such as Murakami Haruki. Topics include the rise of democratic ideas, unsolved issues of war memories, and the tension between serious and "popular" fiction writing.

title: Creative Writing (Poetry)
reviews: Absolutely take it if you have the slight bit of interest in poetry.  If you already enjoy
Absolutely take it, and take it with Michael Dickman, he's the greatest and this class is absolutely worth it.
Absolutely take it. The world will open up and speak to you, and you'll learn how to tell others about it. Poetry is life. Professor Dickman is awesome.
Come prepared to bleed on the page!
Definitely take it with Michael Dickman. He is nice, fun, loves and cares about poetry, and cares about your work. He teaches well and gave great feedback as well as instruction. Great semester!!
Definitely take this class with Professor Tracy Smith. I had absolutely no poetry experience, but I can't wait to get more after this.
Even though it's PDF, put in the time to really work on your poems because you'll be really glad you did when you come out of the class with a few you really like.

Great course.  The group atmosphere was great, Michael was great, and I definitely learned a lot as a poet and now write on my own sometimes.  The p/d/f only option works very well for creative writing, so you don't feel restrained into writing what you think the instructor will want.  This course was a great 5th class.

I definitely recommend this class if you write or have an interest in poetry or want to try something new. Do not take it just because you want to have a PDF class because you do have to work and put in time and effort. It is a very rewarding class that pays as you put in more effort.
I would say that volunteering your own work for in-class workshopping is one of the most productive creative experiences you can have.  It absolutely made me a better writer.
I would strongly recommend this course to any student who is interested in taking an extra class. The workload is light, and the class only meets once a week, but it's a truly amazing experience.
I would suggest that other students take it!  Definitely not as heavy a course load as most other classes, but if you put effort into it, you will get a valuable experience out of it!

I would take this course by all means. I would also advise anyone who does take this course to get more out of it by challenging him/herself and others to speak less about emotions inspired by the poems and more about the literary devices and aspects that led to those emotions.
If you are at all interested in poetry or creative writing this course is for you.
If you like poetry and/or need an LA it's a good class to take.  However if your goal is to take an LA that will require no work at all then there are better choices.
If you take this course seriously, you can really grow as a writer.
Only take it if you're willing to put in the time to write good poetry.
Really push yourself and take risks, because there are no consequences for that.
TAKE IT!

TAKE THIS COURSE. Paul Muldoon is not only a brilliant poet himself, he is a fantastic professor. He's thoughtful, gives good feedback, and is incredibly funny and kind. This class will greatly improve your poetic skills.
Take a creative writing class!
Take it! :)
Take it.  Don't be a slacker though.  Otherwise you're wasting everybody else's time as well as your own.
Take it. It will be your favorite course, and the course you do instead of all your other courses. Be warned: the poems you write won't leave you alone!

Take this class! And take it with James Richardson! I looked forward to my poetry class every week.  James is extremely funny and great at helping you improve your poetry.  And he gives awesome life advice as well.  It was very enjoyable to write a poem every week and discuss it with a small group.  I found it a nice addition to my other work.
Take this class! Make sure you read the assigned readings carefully, though they are not the focus of the class, the student work is
Take this course if you have any interest in poetry. It's low-stress and very interesting.
Take this course!  It provides a wonderful opportunity to explore different types of poetry in a supportive and engaging environment!
Very easy distribution requirement.
You get in what you put out. Cruise, and you'll have wasted a semester
You get out what you put in.

definitely take this class--it will make you love poetry
prepare to learn a lot
take it
prereqs: Interested students complete a Creative Writing Program application (please visit the program website) by attaching four pages of original poetry or (optionally) a paragraph explaining why they would like to take the course. Please note that this course cannot be audited..
descrip: Practice in the original composition of poetry supplemented by the reading and analysis of standard works. Criticism by practicing writers and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature. This class is open to beginning and intermediate students by application.

title: Theatre and Society
descrip: Theatre and Society investigates the ways in which theater and performance speak into their cultural and historical moments. We'll look at self-avowed political drama or performance in various historical moments in American theatre; at plays or performances that caused controversy in various communities in which they were performed; at street performance within protest movements; and at community-based performance produced for specific reasons within its locale. We'll also discuss the role of the artist in society. What is the artist's responsibility to his or her nation? To his or her local community or identity groups?

title: Survey of Population Problems
reviews: I great class to start off course sequence in demography or just to gain a broad understanding of the subject matters in demography.
It is a great course and provides an excellent introduction to the field of demography
descrip: Survey of past and current trends in the growth of the population of the world and of selected regions. Analysis of the components of growth and their determinants. The social and economic consequences of population change.

title: The Management of Organizations
descrip: This course will apply management concepts and approaches to nonprofit organizations. The course will emphasize the challenges faced by managers of nonprofit organizations in this period of resource scarcity. It also will examine the impact that the increasingly blurred boundaries between the nonprofit, public, and for-profit sectors are having on the management of nonprofits. Course materials will integrate both theoretical and applied research and writing on this topic with cases based on the real world experience of managers.

title: Graduate Seminar in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering
reviews: Bring coffee.
Yes, everyone should attend. It is a great way to learn about other parts of MAE research.
descrip: A seminar of graduate students and staff presenting the results of their research and recent advances in flight, space, and surface transportation; fluid mechanics; energy conversion; propulsion; combustion; environmental studies; applied physics; and materials sciences. There is one seminar per week and participation at presentations by distinguished outside speakers.

title: Hispanic Studies: Introduction to Cultural Analysis
reviews: Don't leave your essays for the night before! And don't feel free to think on your own.
Make sure you read carefully and proofread your essays for grammar mistakes.
Take it! The Professor is amazing, the size of the class wonderful, and the material fascinating. A win, win, win! And you will be challenged and learn a lot.
Take this course. The reading are interesting and he has so much knowledge on Spanish literature and culture that it will enrich your college experience.

This course is great.  The reading is interesting, and the work is very manageable.  Your written Spanish will probably improve, and you'll get to learn about many different mediums of art from Spain and Latin America: prose, poetry, film, and photography
This course will allow you to grow intellectually and view things differently. Highly Recommend it!
prereqs: Another SPA 200-level course or instructor's permission..
descrip: An introduction to the analysis of contemporary cultural texts (narrative, poetry, film, photography, painting, music) from Latin America and Spain, with the support of various theoretical ideas (metafiction, intertextuality, death of the author, the other, mourning and melancholia, the uncanny, orientalism).

title: Beginner's German I
reviews: A great course, I found it difficult, so stay on top of the readings and homework.
Definitely take this course. The department is wonderful!
Do not fall behind. Once you fall behind it is very hard to catch up. Also, speak up in class and ask questions when you are stuck. The moment you fall behind you stay behind.
Enjoy Frederic's comedy
Excellent course, especially if you get Prof Rankin

For any student wanting to do the language requirement especially, from my experience in GER 101 it would be the right language in which you can fulfill the requirement and get a lot of enjoyment out of it as well.
German instruction is great, take it if you want to learn the language.
German is a very interesting language and I would definitely recommend the course. Keep up with your vocabulary and learn your grammar.
Highly recommend for the manner in which the instructor engages in the course
Honestly, German department is great. And particularly if you have Prof. Rankin, that is really a blessing.

I would recommend studying whatever languages you took in high school, already speak, or that you have someone readily available to practice it with.

If you can get into one of Prof. Rankin's sections, you should take this course whether you're interested in German or not. I'm actually not exaggerating - Prof. Rankin is probably one of the best teachers you will have at Princeton - he's engaging, he has studied foreign language pedagogy extensively and therefore conveys the material in a surprisingly easy to comprehend format, and he genuinely cares about what you have to say and how your life is going.

If you're interested in German, of course, so much the better - even coming in without speaking a word of the language, as I did, you will leave with a solid grasp of the material and the ability to get your point across auf Deutsch without having to revert to English.

I can't speak for the sections of this course not taught by Prof. Rankin, but I give his section my enthusiastic recommendation.
If you have any interest in German, this is a very "cost-effective" course! It takes a fair chunk of time, but it is well worth it.

If you have even the slightest interest in learning German, I would highly recommend this course, especially if you can get into a section with Jamie Rankin. Compared to other language classes, there is less homework, but the rate of progress in the language does not suffer because of that.
If you want to learn German, take this course.
If you're looking to take German, might as well do it at Princeton!
If you've never been exposed to the language before, be sure to get a jump start before the beginning of the course, so that you don't lag behind.
It seems fast-paced, but it is manageable. The instructors were all helpful during various review sessions.
Make sure to keep up with the vocab.
Make sure you learn the grammar and be prepared to learn right away.
Pace yourselves on vocab. It adds up.

Spend a lot of time outside of class everyday and don't fall behind.
Stay on top of the vocab
Study a lot
Study.  Don't sit around because there's no homework.  Take the time to read and practice and your test grades will thank you.

TAKE THIS CLASS WITH PROFESSOR RANKIN!! This is one of the best language courses I've taken here, rivaled only by FRE 1027. Instruction is entirely in German from day one, so prepare yourself mentally for that. It's a bit difficult at first, but by the end of the first two weeks you'll be astonished by how much you can understand. Grading seemed fair overall, as the instructors stressed that the course would not be curved down if too many students did well. There are four exams in this class, and each one has a spoken and a written component. The tests are not difficult, but you need to use your time very efficiently and be on top of the material. For anyone who has not had a case language before this (i.e. Russian, Latin, Greek, etc.), make sure to spend a lot of time familiarizing yourself with the case system, as it is key to understanding the grammar from all later chapters in the book. A word on the textbook: I used the eighth edition and was perfectly fine in this course, but the page numbers are a little different. If you're willing to put up with that, then I'd recommend the eight edition over the ninth ($30 as opposed to $180). The workload was surprisingly light: homework is almost never obligatory, but doing a few exercises each night is advisable, just to reinforce the grammar topics. Overall, this class is not to be missed! (Just try your best to get Rankin as a professor. Some of the other instructors are good, but Rankin is the best.)
Take German!   You'll actually look forward to coming to class!
Take it if you want to become great in speaking German!
Take it if you want to learn German.

Take it with Rankin! 
A 9.00am German class is not as painful as you think it is.
Take it!
Take the course with Rankin, do the work.
The vocabulary builds up fast, so make sure you do a little reviewing each day!

This course assigns little to nothing, but nevertheless requires at least an hour (preferably two) of self-study a day.  Make flashcards, they will take up every inch of space in your dorm room, but are well worth the hassle.  I am amazed at how much I learned after entering the class knowing only about five German phrases.  I do think having the class at 9am was a hinderance to me, my class was very quite in the morning and I think I would have learned more with a more talkative group.

This course is the perfect language course. It only requires you to work for about 30 minutes every night and review the material regularly. If you pay attention in class, you will barely need to do any studying on your own.

This is an amazing opportunity to work with an incredible language teacher and learn a fun, interesting language.  If you've ever even considered German, go for it!

Try to take Hannah's section because she's an excellent teacher, be prepared to speak up in class, and work hard because it pays off over the course of the semester. I was very pleased with how much I learned in such a short time!
Whether you're particularly interested in German or just want to satisfy the language requirement, I can't imagine a language course getting any better than this.
Work on your German everyday! It will be easy to fall behind, especially because of the extent to which grammar takes importance in speaking.
certainly take it.
take it, take it, take it. You have nothing to lose and a whole lot of German to gain.
prereqs: Normally no credit given for GER 101 unless followed by GER 102. An afternoon section of GER 101 will focus on reading skills, in addition to oral communication, and is limited to graduate students. All participants, including graduate students, must be fully enrolled in the course..
descrip: The course lays a foundation for functional acquisition of German. Class time is devoted to language tasks that will foster communicative competence and will emphasize listening and reading strategies, vocabulary acquisition, authentic input, and oral production. Conducted in German.

title: Theories of Housing and Urbanism
reviews: If your are interested in urban planning or design, you should take this course.
It's a good course if you're interested in urban planning.

Professor Laing is wonderful, preparing you really well to tackle some of the most important readings in Urban theory. The paper is also a great way to delve into your interests in the field. If you are interested in urban  planning or urban studies at all, this is a wonderful course--my favorite course this semester for sure. Had a blast every Thursday. TAKE IT!
Take it!
Take this course if you are interested in the subject material. It's a lot of reading, but our discussions were always really thought-provoking and Professor Laing is great.
The best part of this class is the discussion, so make sure you are ready to be involved.

This is a class that fulfills a departmental credit. Otherwise I wouldn't take it, not because its too hard, but mostly because its not as inspiring as you'd expect from a 400 level seminar. I know many students in the class that just love architecture and were not arch majors, and I feel bad that they will not be encouraged to take more arch classes.
descrip: The seminar will explore theories of urbanism and housing by reading canonical writers who have created distinctive and influential ideas about urbanism and housing from the nineteenth century to the present. The writers are architects, planners, and social scientists. The theories are interdisciplinary. One or two major work will be discussed each week. We will critically evaluate their relevance and significance for architecture now. Topics include: modernism, functionalism and social change; technological futurism; social critiques of urban design, the New Urbanism; the networked city; and sustainable urbanism.

title: Mathematical Methods in Physics - Introduction to the Calculus of Variations and Spectral Theory
prereqs: Undergraduates must obtain permission of instructor..
descrip: This course covers current topics in mathematical physics. Specific topic information will be provided when the course is offered/scheduled.

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - Arithmetic Circuits
reviews: Obviously, the topic is very specific, since it's a seminar course. If you are interested, definitely take it. Otherwise may be a bit too esoteric.

Students (outside the core CS Theory group) might tend to assume that the course covers a niche area. However, I think it provides exposure to techniques which are generally useful in applied mathematics.

Take it. It is a lot of fun and there are many open questions that you could try to solve. Professor is also really excited about the subject, so it will be very rewarding to work on some open problem while taking the class.
prereqs: Undergraduates with permission of instructor.
descrip: Arithmetic circuits are a natural model for computing polynomials over an arbitrary field or ring. This course focuses on the computational complexity aspects of this model and in particular on the problem of proving circuit lower bounds. A tentative list of topics includes: Arithmetic circuits and formulas, Valiant's complexity classes VP and VNP, completeness of the Determinant and Permanent for these classes, lower bounds for restricted models, Polynomial Identity Testing.

title: Problems in French History - 19th Century France
descrip: Readings in the politcal, social, and cultural history of nineteenth-century France are the focus of this course. Topics include: the First and Second Empires, reaction and revolution, liberalism, France overseas, art and religion, the coming of the Third Republic.

title: Econometric Research Seminar
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Directed Research I
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out research and presents the results. Directed Research is normally taken during the first year of study.

title: Into the Wild
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - The Eurozone Crisis and Beyond
descrip: In the second half of 2011, the crisis in the eurozone threatened to run out of control. This course will discuss four themes: 1) the critiques of the concept of the eurozone prior to January 1999; 2) why the eurozone appeared a major success at its 10th anniversary, which coincided with the beginning of the global economic crisis; 3) the interconnected nature of the crisis?weak sovereigns, weak banks, and weak growth prospects; and 4) the domestic and multilateral measures to deal with the crisis. The course will also consider the future of the eurozone.

title: Calculus II
reviews: A great course even for those who are not required to take math -- there are no "surprise" questions on the test that have never been touched on in class.  Very fair coursework.
A necessary evil if you're not good at math but interested in the sciences. Could have been quite a lot worse considering I'm not a natural math student
A previous exposure to this calculus would be helpful (and seems fairly prevelant among other students).
ADRIAN BANNER VIDEOS.
Absolutely don't take this class unless you have too. It is very tough and no fun at all. Not interesting either.

Almost everyone in my class was there because they were required to for their intended major. It is an interesting course and most people like their preceptors, but be prepared to do a lot of learning on your own outside of class.
Attend the classes and do the problem sets. Otherwise, It's a pretty simple class and the concepts aren't too difficult. (from someone who is mathematically minded)

Be prepared for the difficulty of the midterm, it can sneak up on you, especially in the midst of all your normal classes. I would suggest this to anyone who took BC Calc but doesnt feel very confident of their knowledge of the material. Mark McConnell was a great professor, try to get into his class!
Be prepared to invest a lot of time if you haven't already covered the material.
Be prepared to self-teach a lot. It's a good a idea to go over the material thoroughly before its taught in class.

Be ready to study on your own and get ready for a fast paced course. Don't be afraid to ask questions. Because there's little interaction with the students in the classroom, it's easy to shy away from the professor, but don't do that! It is a good course, and you learn a lot as long as you engage yourself.

Definitely try going to different classes at first to find a lecturer that offers helpful information  in the daily class time. It is important and definitely manageable to get nearly perfect scores on the problem sets, especially with a study group or the McGraw center. The main exams are challenging but fair and the weekly quizzes will vary between preceptors.
Do a lot of independent studying.  Don't expect the problem sets to be enough practice.
Do a lot of practice.
Do all the homework problems and study before the test and you will do fine.
Do all the practice problems and exams online and take advantage of office hours.

Do all the problem sets and make sure you know the beginning topics because they are important later in the course.
Do all your psets, and extra.
Do as many extra problems as you can and make use of Professor's office hours because they are very helpful in clearing up material you may not completely understand.
Do lots of practice problems!

Do not let yourself fall behind, and ask questions.  Even if you think your question is totally dumb, just say you don't understand, and she will generally give a nice five-minute further explanation.
Do not take this course if you do not need to fulfill a distribution requirement for it.
Do the HW, go to class, review the materials before each quiz.
Do the problem sets and the optional problem sets. Practice makes perfect in a situation like this. Class isn't very useful, but the examples they use seem to come up disproportionally on tests.
Do the reading and psets, and you'll do great
Do your homework because just paying attention in class isn't enough.

Don't be fooled by the homework assignments, the test problems are 10 times harder and the final and midterm are 75% of the grade, so do well on those. Quizzes are 20% so don't blow those off either. Homework is 5%, but do it and so many more practice problems because their is a huge variety of stuff in this course and you want to be well prepared for all of it.
Don't take this class unless you have some background in BC calculus. Having taken only one year of calculus in high school, I felt a little helpless.

Go to McGraw study halls.  Go to office hours for extra help as needed.  Don't lag behind on work.

Go to class.  They may be basic and occasionally dismal (especially in the morning), but they help.  Take notes with the instructor's explanation on the side.  If you struggle, don't wait for the quiz to prove that you're struggling.  Get help.
He's a great teacher. If you're interested in the course or need it for a requirement, take it with him.
I mean, if you can avoid it, definitely don't take it.
I think everyone should take this course and know at least up to this level of math.

I would suggest taking this course! It has helped me develop new mathematical thinking habits. In the short time of one semester I feel I have a different grasp on mathematics.
I would take this class if you like Math, need a distribution requirement or it's in your department,

If you like math, take it. And be in Andy's precept!
If you're interested in math or need this class for your major, go for it. It's challenging but definitely doable.

However, Professor McConnell is an excellent professor and explains concepts very well and very clearly. I learned a lot from him. Also supplement the material with "The Calculus Life-Saver" and you've built yourself a great combination!
It is a good course.

It's decent. Most people taking this have to anyway, so you have no choice. But if you did, I'd still not say anything against it.

It's math-- if you like it, you'll like the class; if you hate it, the class won't be as much fun. Don't take the nine a.m. slot unless you're the type of person who is completely awake in the mornings, because otherwise falling asleep is a real danger. The calculus lifesaver, purchase it!!

The first few weeks will be quite easy, but you might feel the course becomes faster when the series start. Review the topics regularly, or just doing the homework can help with the review too.
The professor is very organized and provides lots of review sessions- Some of the quizzes are pretty challenging but the assignments are certainly manageable.
The review sessions are helpful.
This class is definitely manageable and a good basic math course to take.
This is a good course and required for BSE students.
This is a really straightforward course but also a really good one I think. I really learned a lot and I think this is the minimum math any student should take independent of its major.

This is a required class for most mathematical majors, but it also makes a great QR class, especially for anyone who's taken high school calculus. A good professor is definitely important though. It's not a ton of work. There's a weekly problem set that may take a few hours to complete depending on the chapter, and then a weekly quiz that only requires an hour or two of review if you've done the homework. The midterm and final are fairly in line with the harder p-set problems and the quiz problems, although each teacher makes their own quiz,

This is a rigorous and fast paced course.  Definitely go to McGraw and get started on problem sets early in the week.  Buy Adrian Banner's Calculus Lifesaver book, as it is very helpful and shows how to solve the hard problems that are almost always on the quizzes.  It makes the course manageable.

Tough call.  If you are an engineer, I think you have to take the class.  But, if you think you have some interest in math, it would be better to take 103 which is less complex and fulfills the QR requirement.
Use the textbook and do the readings (they are short!). Do the online practice problems to study for the quizzes and make a study sheet of all the material you have to memorize before the test.
Work Hard. Do the past exam questions for practice, not necessarily the problem sets.
Work on your homework early and with a friend. Also, you can never be too prepared for a quiz.
Work your butt off during the semester, and then it'll pay off in the midterms and finals. You can do it!

You most likely need to take this class as a prerequisite so just grin a bear it. It isn't too difficult, but make sure to take all of the practices that Fang Wang provides before taking an in class quiz, don't just rely on the problem types shown in class.

You'll learn a lot in this class if you don't know the material already, but it won't be a very pleasant experience. A lot of the students in your classes will be students who already know the material (if you're one of those students, please just go into 201) and the classes are quite dry. My lecturer had a tendency to get a little lost in his head, which made classes challenging, and As are very hard to come by even if you feel you know what you're doing.
You're going to need to study a lot throughout the entire semester to do well on the final.
do it if you need to
don't take this course unless you need it or have already taken BC. and if you do, dont take it with professor moeller.

read the chapter before doing the problems sets--it saves time in the long run. 
also I just discovered office hours = awesome.
yes
prereqs: MAT103 or equivalent..
descrip: Continuation of MAT103. Topics include techniques of integration, arclength, area, volume, convergence of series and improper integrals, L'Hopital's rule, power series and Taylor's theorem, introduction to differential equations and complex numbers.

title: Special Topics in Creative Writing - All the Moves: A Prosody Workshop
reviews: If you want a certificate or want to focus on your meter and rhythm, then take it! Also, even if you are just interested and want to have fun take it!
This is a good class. Of course be ready to share your work, but that's a skill everyone should learn. It is not particularly rigorous, so you must self-motivate to grow from taking it.
take it, loads of fun
prereqs: No prerequisites. Interested students complete a Creative Writing application (please visit the Program website) by attaching four pages of original poetry (not necessarily formal poetry) and (optionally) a paragraph explaining why they would like to take the course..
descrip: Prosody (Gr., tune) is the study of meter, rhythm, rhyme, stanzas, i.e. the aspects of poetry that ally it with dance and song. This workshop will focus on the major forms of English poetry and their adaptations by modern poets and also investigate the half dozen or so kinds of free verse. A flexible mix of assignments and exercises will have students trying out, parodying, humming, adapting and inventing forms and rhythms, learning how poetry works, and honing those qualities of "ear" and "style" by which poets recognize each other. This class would be an excellent first workshop and is open to poetry students at all levels by application.

title: Tokyo as a Literary Topos
descrip: In this course, we will examine the varying representations of Tokyo thematized in literary texts written since the alleged beginning of modern Japan. We will pay attention to the transforming metropolis, its repeated destruction and reconstruction, its changing roles in the lives of the people living within and without Tokyo. We will see how Tokyo at once becomes a site of nostalgia and suffering, desire and struggle. Our inquiries will also extend themselves to differing social status and gender roles in the city.

title: Topics in Literature and Philosophy - Rolls of the Dice
descrip: Chance was long thought to lie outside the realm of knowledge. Then there arose new means for measuring random and probable events of the most varied kinds. This seminar explores the conditions and consequences of that shift, as they are reflected in a few philosophical and literary works.

title: Topics in Biological Chemistry - Chemical Tools to Study Biological Systems
reviews: A strong bio background would be helpful, but I think the course was manageable, even without one.
Don't miss it if you are interested in Chemical Biology!
Great course if you are interested in the field.
If you are interested in this, take this
It is a great class. Take it if you're interested in chemical biology.
Read all the papers and study the notes during the semester.
Take the course if you are really interested in the intersection between chemistry and biology. It helps to have lab experience in molecular biology or chemistry.
descrip: This class emphasizes the use of chemical approaches to investigate and manipulate biological processes at the biochemical, the cellular, and the organismal level. The purpose is to provide chemical biologists with modern chemical methods. The class will then discuss how these methods can be applied to study different biological problems, highlighting important questions in biology. Typically a paper from the current literature will be presented and discussed by the students each class. Grades are based on problem sets, a midterm exam, a literature presentation, and a research proposal.

title: On the Persistence of Cultural Forms
descrip: Not so long ago critical theory thrilled to rupture: one looked for "epistemological breaks" and declared the end of narrative, art, ideology, indeed man. The worm has turned of late; today one sees a preoccupation with stories of "survival" and persistence across a wide range of discourses and disciplines. This seminar aims to explore this renewed interest in cultural transmission and tradition through an array of readings and test-cases. Among our topics will be "Revolution as Rupture and Continuity," "Cultural Memory and Generation," "Art as Mnemotechny," "Culture as Nachleben," "Deferred Action," and "Obstinacy and Obsolescence."

title: Advanced Questions in Photography
reviews: Be prepared to extract a lot of the value on your own.
If you really want to pursue photography beyond an introductory level, I highly recommend taking this course. It's thought-provoking and will push your work in ways that you could not have expected.

Sometimes famous artists are completely uninspiring professors. **Always ask for advice from students based on which professor is teaching a VIS class. I took this same class twice with different professors (!), one time it was pretty cool and one time it was a mess.
prereqs: VIS 211 or 212 and VIS 313 or 315 or by instructor's permission..
descrip: Student-initiated problems in photography will be explored in close working relationship with the instructor. Emphasis will be on integrating practice and critical thought.

title: Introduction to Classical Japanese
prereqs: Two years of modern Japanese..
descrip: Introduction to the fundamentals of classical Japanese grammar. This course trains students to read premodern Japanese historical and literary texts. Texts: Makura no Soshi, Taketori Monogatari, Ujishui Monogatari, Hyakunin Isshu, etc.

title: Ecology: Species interactions, biodiversity, and society
reviews: A good course to take - but lots of writing involved for various assignments.
Definitely take it.
Definitely take this class.

I absolutely loved this course. Pringle is a great professor. Lectures are interesting, fun, and thought-provoking. Exams are pretty fair. The lab could use work, but wasn't too bad, and I think it will improve with time.

I think this is a good class for everyone to take. The workload is manageable, and the concepts we talk about are very relevant to conservation and the interaction between humans and the environment, which I think everyone should have some basic knowledge of.
I would buy both the Mittelbach and the Molles book.  I found both to be particularly useful.

I would just say that they should spend more time reading/understanding the Mittelbach chapters as they were informative and proved pretty important for exams. Otherwise get engaged and excited for lectures!

I would recommend the course (especially if you're in need of a lab requirement) as a good mix of concept-based learning, and critical thinking. I really liked that it wasn't just about how species interactions work in theory, but in practice as well.

I would recommend this course with reservations. Prof. Pringle?s lectures were very well-designed and incorporated many examples from specific research studies. He also did a great job bringing in guest speakers and readings were generally interesting. However, labs were honestly kind of a joke and it was pretty evident they were poorly planned. There were initially a zillion presentations on the syllabus, but fortunately they realized how painful this was and cut a few out. If labs are improved, I strongly recommend this course to all EEB majors and recommend with reservations to non-EEB majors (as long as they?re willing to get through some pretty boring theoretical ecology).
I would recommend this course, especially if you're interested in the material.

If Prof. Pringle is teaching it, then take i! It's quite the experience you are in for! It is ecology in the most interdisciplinary way, giving importance to species interactions in nature, biodiversity (conserving and protecting it), and society's role in the field. Lectures are dynamic: be prepared for awesome guest speakers, ecological demonstrations, movies, youtube clips, treats of all sorts, and personal life anecdotes!
If this course is taught by Pringle take it in a heartbeat.  He's an amazing professor and this is by far the best class I've taken at Princeton so far
If you have to take an Ecology its a decent choice

Loved this course.  Pringle is an amazing lecturer and professor, and Caitlin (if you get her) is a great TA.  You will learn a lot about Ecology, especially about species interactions and how that impacts Ecology and biology overall.
Only take this if you are interested in conservation. Professor Pringle is great though!
Pringle is an awesome guy. The class is a good for those who want an advanced introduction to ecology.
Professor Pringle is really cool!
TAKE IT! Pringle is Great!
Take it! Pringle is absolutely incredible and engaging.  Definitely learned a lot.  Very different from the old (Henry Horn??) version of the course, but in a goodway

Take it! Prof. Pringle is a hoot and a half but also one of the most knowledgable, creative professors out there! The information is so well presented (and valuable!) that you will not regret taking this class at al!
Take the course: will catch your interest in conservation and you learn a lot. Need to study for the exams and the labs are slightly annoying but overall, not a bad class.
Take this course even if you're not an EEB major, and sign up for a friday lab.  You will not find another lab that is actually as much fun as this one.
Take this course with Prof. Pringle, he is great.
The professor is really interesting and committed. He has great experiences and perspectives to draw on and makes lecture an enjoyable experience.

This class gives you a good background in ecology and species interactions, but a rather one-sided one in conservation issues. It is, however, a rather painless (if boring) lab if you need to fulfill that requirement.

This is the best course I have taken.  Take it with Dr. Pringle??it will change your EEB experience and potentially alter your career choices after graduation.  He is an influential professor that will certainly change your perception of the world around you and your place in it.
Unless the lab syllabus is changed, I wouldn't recommend this class to others. It's really too bad, because Professor Pringle's lectures were great.
take it, its the best option for an eeb upper level lab
this class is awesome and Pringle is the bomb. Love him, love the class.
prereqs: EEB 211 or equivalent. Although the course is not heavily mathematical, it is quantitative; students should be prepared to learn and apply basic principles of probability and statistics..
descrip: How do wild organisms interact with each other, their physical environments, and human societies? Lectures will examine a series of fundamental topics in ecology--herbivory, predation, competition, mutualism, species invasions, biogeographic patterns, extinction, climate change, and conservation, among others--through the lens of case studies drawn from all over the world. Readings will provide background information necessary to contextualize these case studies and clarify the linkages between them. Precepts and fieldwork will explore the process of translating observations and data into an understanding of how the natural world works.

title: Analysis in a Single Variable
reviews: A very good starting point for students seriously interested in doing real math.
ABSOLUTELY TAKE THIS COURSE. you will learn how to think.
Be prepared for the most academically challenging course you've ever seen.
Be prepared to struggle!
Come prepared to apply pure logic in great quantities of time.
Course moves incredibly quickly...but you will learn so much. Problem sets can take a very long time, but they are very helpful in the learning process.
Do all the readings and study in advance about how to write a formal proof. Take it, it's really helpful afterwards.
Don't take it if you are not a math major and thus required to take this course.

Don't take notes in class; better focus on understanding the lectures and read the course notes. Also read other books and materials. Some of the problems are actually well-known theorems. Get more problems from other sources to practice. Learn to type problem sets in LaTeX if time allows. Email grader if have grading queries.
Go to office hours, go to McGraw, do the problem sets with other students.
Good introductory course to departmental math.

I felt like I was thrown into the ocean on my own without a floatation device. That being said, the student carries most of the responsibility in learning the material in this class, more so than other classes, and if you can't swim, then you're in trouble. I was told that this class is an intro to proofs and you do not need prior knowledge on the it, but this is wrong. I had no experience writing rigorous proofs before taking this class and felt lost most of the time. This course requires a lot of time and effort and although I did put a lot of time into it, I do not think it was enough since I started behind a lot of other students in the class who already had experience with proofs. I think that now, with the knowledge I got from this semester, would be a good point for me to take this class. Having background information would help me to learn a lot more and gain more from the class. That being said, I think I could have managed my time better by looking over notes (Rudin and pequod) before the lecture (so I had an idea of what was going to be taught), reviewing notes after each lecture, starting problem sets earlier, and going to more office hours, study halls, and tutoring sessions. So basically, students that do not have prior experience need to put a lot more effort into catching up and staying on top of the material.
I really enjoyed the course, and I learned a lot from it. I'm excited to take the continuation next semester.

If you have a strong interest in learning proof-based math and you are willing to put in time and substantial effort, this course can teach you more interesting mathematical knowledge that you believe can be squeezed into your head.
If you really like math and are ready to work hard, take this course - you will find it interesting and enjoyable.

It is a challenge, as you surely know. Be prepared to spend many hours a week with some friends arguing about whether a space has to be Hausdorff or not. Although the lectures make it feel unnecessary, definitely do the reading, even after you have covered the material it explains. If you like math and want to learn quite a lot of it, I advise you to give it a try. Don't give up when the problem sets seem frustrating.

It is definitely worth taking if you are interested in math! The workload may seem overwhelming at times, but how much you improve in your quantitative and logical abilities is astounding. Don't slack off on the work, don't skip class!

It would be really helpful to have learned a little about analysis before taking the class. Also, be prepared to spend a lot of time reading and doing problem sets. This is a really challenging and rewarding class.
It's a good class to take, probably much more interesting than any lower-level math classes. For a first math class, it is really good --- a little challenging but also forgiving.
Only take this course if you're interested in a math major and willing to challenge yourself and work very hard
Please take this class, you'll love it! And Damron is comedically amazing!
Realize that you will spend more time on this course than all your other classes combined, unless you are in a dual-credit class, in which case taking both is a bad idea.
Spend a lot of time reading the book because it helps a lot.
Take it if you have a penchant for abstraction and quantitative reasoning.
Take it if you really like math and are willing to devote a lot of time to it. Understand each new topic because the material is cumulative. The McGraw sessions are very helpful.
Take it if you're interested in math, and you like it.
Take this class if you're interested in learning math rigorously.

Take this course! Challenging as advertised, but definitely worth the pain. Even for the humanities majors, pdf it if you want to try a real math course--it's a guaranteed pass (at least using the curve for 2012 fall, the worst grade on the midterm was a C-).
Take this over MAT 214 if you want to be a math major. This course is actually great and not as hard as many rumors say.

This class certainly requires a huge time commitment, but don't be put off if you're entering without any proof-based math experience. I took BC Calculus senior year, and while the first few weeks of the course were something of a struggle in terms of the adjustment to the level of rigor, everything came together by the end of the course. I would recommend making thorough use of the McGraw tutoring center, as the tutors can teach you tricks and techniques useful for the problem sets, and can also help clarify questions on challenging concepts. In addition, take advantage of your professor's office hours, as asking questions and bouncing ideas off of an expert are often the best way to solidify knowledge of this tough subject.

This course is a good introduction to analysis though it can be a LOT of work.  I had a lot of experience with mathematical proofs beforehand, but found the sheer amount of homework to be overwhelming rather than the specific topics covered.  If you are comfortable with proofs it might be better to take the more advanced track, as it did not seem to be significantly more work but covered somewhat more interesting topics, in my personal opinion.  Be careful taking this course with other time intensive problem-set based courses, as you will most likely have to sacrifice one or the other in part.

This course is an amazing look into advanced mathematics, so it is absolutely vital for those majoring in mathematics (besides being a departmental prerequisite). While Prof. Gunning is somewhat notorious about making typos/errors (in the lecture, class notes, and problem sets), he is extremely helpful out of class. This advanced section is recommended to those who have had some background in mathematical proofing: coming in without a strong background could be a mistake. However, the class is totally worth it, regardless of the grade (note that this class has a very generous curve, so don't worry about GPA).
This course really gets you to think and work hard. It is time consuming, so make sure to balance your schedule well.

This is a very challenging course, but one that will develop your skills in mathematics and bring them to a whole new level. The problem sets are very challenging, but the tutors both at the help sessions that are held in Fine Hall and the McGraw tutoring center are very helpful in showing you the techniques required to prove the questions on your homework. The material this course covered was broad, which was good in that it exposes you to multiple fields of mathematics to see where your interests may lie. Expect to put a lot of work into this course, but you will gain much in return in terms of mathematical creativity and skill.
This is currently the hardest freshman math course, and it is a good course.
Very difficult, but very rewarding. Make sure you start problem sets early in the week and allow yourself enough time to chew over each problem.
Work hard!
Work on problem sets with a study group or at McGraw Center.
read the notes.
descrip: An introduction to the mathematicsal discipline of analysis, to prepare for higher-level course work in the department. Topics include rigorous epsilon-delta treatment of limits, convergence, and uniform convergence of sequences and series. Continuity, uniform continuity, and differentiability of functions. The Heine-Borel Theorem. The Rieman integral, conditions for integrability of functions and term by term differentiation and integration of series of functions, Taylor's Theorem.

title: Health and Human Rights in the World Community
descrip: This seminar will examine the relationship between health and human rights. It will provide an overview of human rights violations in the world today and an analysis of their health consequences. The course will consider how individual and community health can be improved by protecting and promoting human rights. The seminar will also evaluate the role of the health professionals in caring for victims of human rights abuses, documenting the health consequences of human rights violations, and participating in human rights advocacy and education.

title: Introduction to Chemical Instrumentation
reviews: Good class, learn a lot.
If you like NMR do it!
Take very good notes, and stay on top of looking up any techniques that you don't understand. Make sure to stop the instructor and ask questions if you are lost.
ask lots of questions.
descrip: The application of instrumentation (chiefly spectrometers) to modern chemical/biochemical research, including materials science and environmental and medicinal chemistry, will be covered. Primary emphasis will be on NMR methods (including data processing and spectrum analysis), along with portions addressing mass spectrometry , X-ray diffraction, IR, UV, and EPR spectroscopy, and chiroptical techniques. The integrated nature of using various instrumental methods for identification and characterization of molecular structure and dynamics will be emphasized. Recommended for graduate students, and junior and senior undergraduates.

title: Intermediate Polish
prereqs: First year Polish (PLS101 and 102 or equivalent)..
descrip: The course reviews, strengthens, and upgrades the knowledge from the first year of language acquisition (PLS101 and 102, or equivalent). While enhancing their familiarity with Polish grammatical structures, students will also develop a broader vocabulary and more idiomatic patterns of expression. All linguistic skills (speaking, reading, writing, listening comprehension) will be practiced, but the main emphasis will be on communicative competence, as well as on a closer acquaintance with Poland's culture and everyday life.

title: Topics in Latin American Cultural Studies - Contemporary Cuban Literature and Visual Culture
reviews: Good readings/watchings. Take if you are at all interested in Cuba as will provide much material with which few are familiar. Price knows her stuff.
I would just say to maybe talk to Price more. I didn't feel very connected, so maybe that's why I haven't been very successful or as interested as I should've been. Stay engaged!
If you're really interested in learning about the Cuban revolution, take it.
Professor Price is not particularly good at fostering discussion, and she looks down on you if your ideas don't match up with hers.
Rachel Price is a great professor who has good insight and is also really understanding and not intimidating which encourages participation.
Rachel Price is awesome!

This is a good course for a student who has never taken a class in Spanish because the reading and writing load is not overbearing. It will give you confidence that you can take other classes in a foreign language.
rachel price is a great teacher!
prereqs: A 200-level SPA course or instructor's permission..
descrip: In this course we will read literature and essays, examine artwork, performances and blogs, and watch films produced in Cuba or the diaspora from the 1990s through the present. Themes include the economic crisis, publishing and new media, post-cubanidad, the Raul Castro era, and others. Authors, filmmakers and artists include: Anton Arrufat, Tania Bruguera, Los Carpinteros, Victor Fowler, Abilio Estevez, Carlos Garaicoa, Pedro Juan Gutierrez, Fernandez Perez, Leonardo Padura Fuentes, Ena Lucia Portela, Antonio Jose Ponte, Reina Maria Rodriguez, Juan Carlos Tabio, Anna Lidia Vega Serova, Zoe Valdes.

title: Crime, Fiction, and Film
descrip: This course will explore representations of crime (mainly murder) in a range of American and European texts and films. We will look at amateur and professional detectives, theories of guilt, methods of investigation, organized crime, corruption, proliferating psychopaths, and much else. Why is there this persistent, international interest in wrongdoing on the page and on the screen? Even and especially on the part of people who have little or no interest in real-life crime. There may be just too many answers to this question, but that's a good reason for asking it.

title: Nation of Immigrants, A
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Literature and Environment
descrip: Deforestation, air pollution, urban sprawl, endangered species, watershed loss, animal rights, rampant consumerism, and similar issues have been appearing as controversial in Western literature for hundreds, and in some cases, thousands of years. Consequently, if we wish to better understand our contemporary attitude toward the environment and how it emerged (the goal of this course), its literary history is an excellent place to start. Starting with one of the West's earliest texts, iThe Epic of Gilgamesh and ending with Rachel Carson and Michael Pollan, this course explores the history of our relationship with our planet.

title: Elementary Modern Greek I
descrip: To set the foundations for acquiring a command of spoken and written Modern Greek. Equal emphasis will be given to speaking, reading, and writing.

title: Soccer and Latin America
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Enlightenment and its Discontents
descrip: Course examines the fictional and philosophical foundations of social theory, from its classical roots to its rise during the Enlightenment, and its legacy today. It asks, what notions of the individual do different models of community presuppose? How does fiction, in staging relations between persons, invite us to question such foundations? And, how do specific genres and rhetorical strategies articulate new ideas of the social contract, philosophy of history, and individual freedom? Topics include: ethics and the critique of natural law, the property of persons, Libertinage, scientism's triumph in modernity.

title: Research Seminar in Cognitive Psychology
descrip: Current research and issues in sensation, perception, and cognition. Ongoing research by seminar participants, research methodology, and current issues in the literature will be discussed.

title: Separations in Chemical Engineering and Biotechnology
reviews: Definitely go to the lectures because the book can be hard to read at times and parts of the exams are based off of the lectures, that you can't find in the book.

Go to lectures, and keep up with the weekly problem sets. As well, the concepts don't build on each other in the second half, so continue to revise each one (that's what I would have done, but now that it's final period I'm rushing to familiarize myself with each individual one)
If I wasn't a chemical engineer I don't know if I would have taken the course.
If you are in the department you have to take it, but don't worry, it's a good class.
It'll make your life easier if you work together with other people on psets.

One of the least painful CBE courses. It feels a lot like CBE 245 to me. I don't feel like I learned a whole lot from it, but you do get a good survey of the main separation techniques in the industry. The problem sets aren't really that work intensive, but definitely take advantage of office hours because the wording of the problems can get confusing.
Professor Link is a very good lecturer and makes this class easy to understand. He also does a good job answering questions and emails. Good TAs can be very helpful in this course.
Stay on top of assignments and you'll be fine.
Take general notes on the book readings in preparation for the final.
Take if you have to for CBE - not as much work as 341.
Take it if you have to, otherwise it is relatively unnecessary information
Take it if you have to. If Link is teaching it, definitely take it! He's a great guy, and a solid teacher. Do go to office hours, because the preceptors / TAs will save you and your pset grades.
Take it if you're a CBE.
This course is pretty good.  Office hours are helpful if you need them.
You have to, so yeah.
You'll probably enjoy it more than thermo or pipes!
well, you have to take it. But I liked sep. Link is pretty cool.But the psets defs take longer than he says they will.
prereqs: CBE 245 and CBE 246. MAE 305 may be taken concurrently..
descrip: This course covers the theory and practice of separations technologies used in the chemical and biochemical industry. Both equilibrium and rate-based separations will be discussed including distillation and chromatography as the primary examples. The first two-thirds of the course will focus on traditional chemical separations while the remainder of the course will be devoted to bioseparations.

title: Seminar in Comparative Politics - Europe and the World
reviews: A great introduction top modern Europe that covers a wide range of topics.
If you want to learn about Europe in new ways I would take this course.

It's a very interesting course that covers a lot of interesting material. You definitely have to put your work in though. And having your entire grade being based on a final paper kind of sucks, so consider that.

This is a great course for those who are somewhat familiar with European politics but would like to learn more about exactly how the EU functions and what its strengths and weaknesses are in various contexts.  Requires a lot of reading and active participation, but is very rewarding.

You should absolutely take this course! Prof. Suleiman gives guidance and you get to consider truly important questions throughout. There is a lot of reading, but Prof. Suleiman doesn?t require you to consistently refer to it throughout the seminar.
prereqs: None.
descrip: This course covers Europe's historical and contemporary role in world politics. Topics include the legacy of the two world wars, the Cold War, colonialism and decolonization, the genesis and subsequent development of the EC/EU, and the challenges confronting present-day Europe. These challenges include immigration, enlargement, democratization, and the EU's role in military affairs. By the end of the course, students should have an understanding of the evolution of Europe's role in world affairs, an ability to explain and evaluate contemporary European foreign policy, and a greater capacity to critically analyze history's repetitive nature.

title: Beginner's French I
reviews: 101 language classes require a lot of work to keep up, but grading is fair and there are no tricks so it's totally possible to get an A if you put in the effort

As there is no French for Reading course on offer except during the summer, this is the only option for graduate students seeking to learn French during the semester. The approach is context-oriented and communication-based. The graduate course also involves many interactive projects such as performing live skits and movie-making. While these activities certainly can be said to improve one's ear for French, they are also frustrating if you are primarily interested in learning to read historical literary texts. In short, the focus is less on mastery of grammar, on reading and writing, than on communicating smoothly.
Be sure to keep up with the vocab and study very hard for the sixth and seventh chapters.
Come to class everyday, do the homework, and practice daily.
DO THE HOMEWORK! GO TO CLASS! DON'T FALL BEHIND!
Do all the homework, no matter how simple it may appear.
Do the homework!
Do your homework.
Doing a little everyday is much more helpful than cramming all at once.

FRE101 with Vincent was great. He was always funny and engaging, and the material was covered at a good pace. I felt like most of the vocab/grammar we learned was pretty useful/applicable to real life. We also had a couple of classes on phonetics, which is important for an adult language learner. There wasn't too much homework, just be sure to keep up with it.
Go for it! French is a wonderful language, and the intro course has many enjoyable moments.
Go to class.
I loved this course and although the pace can be a little fast at times, it's nothing impossible.
I really do recommend this teacher if you want to take a french beginners course.
