I would recommend this course if you want practical communication skills and basic grammar in French. This is not an in-depth grammar or reading/literature-based course. However, this course will have you pronouncing words and forming sentences and comprehending others speaking the language very quickly.

I would strongly recommend other students to take a language course, whether it be French or another language at Princeton. This course was well structured and the pace (although at times might seem slow) is meant to give you the practice you need to assimilate the language.
If you are interested in learning French, I would highly recommend this course. It is a good intro-level course that is challenging, but not as difficult as many other beginning language courses.
If you can take a French class with Madame Perrier, take it!
If you want to take french, start with FRE 101! Joshua Rivas is a nice guy and a great teacher. Thanks Josh!

If you're considering taking up a new language (or you've taken Spanish before but need a 5th class), this is a great option. FRE 101 is well-structured, fun, and I learned a lot. Grading is fair/easy. Highly recommend!

It is a great course and a great language to take. It is fun and interesting. Languages are difficult and it involves a lot of work and time but if you really want to learn it you will have no trouble doing so.
It is a typical language course but I would strongly recommend taking this course with Joshua Rivas.
It's basic French. It's a lot more independent learning than you would expect, coming from a high school foreign language class. But that's college.
It's best of course if you have some prior knowledge of French. If you don't be sure to stay on top of the textbook readings!
It's not really that difficult if you pay attention and do all the homework, even though it might not be checked all the time. Also, if you miss anything in class, all the slides are on Blackboard.
It's worth it - take it.
Keep up with the assignments, and don't fall behind, but it's not a terribly difficult class. Macs is great.
Keep up with the vocabulary.
Listen to things outside of class like French news, etc. and go to every class because the practice is necessary
Make sure to do the assigned homework every night because it moves fast.
Make sure to do your homework.
NA
Practice makes perfect
Practice the language outside of class.
Princeton really knows how to structure introductory language courses.  The structure, practices,and pace of the course were all phenomenal.  If you are considering taking this course, do it
Review material daily and write less on compositions because content is not taken into consideration.
Take it with Professor Perrier.

Take it! If you've taken another language before, especially another Romance language, this class isn't too difficult. If you're an upperclassman and want to take a new language, it's totally doable. Just keep up with the grammar and vocab, even if you can't do the recommended 2 hours a day.
Take it! It's a lot of fun with Madame Perrier!
Take this, but be wary of the amount of work it is learning a completely new language. Do the work in the course packet when they assign it, and you'll probably be just fine.

The work is fast-paced due to the large amount of vocab given each week. Participating in class is very important to learning and understanding the information, as well as remembering all of the vocabulary long term.

This class was a great introduction to French. The class was fast-paced, but I was surprised with how quickly you can learn the language if you put in the work. Consider whether you see yourself wanting to study French language/culture in the future or whether you would like to travel to a French-speaking country.
This class was a long more demanding than I thought it would be, but it was fair and I enjoyed it.
This course is challenging but extremely rewarding.  Madame Perrier moves fast but guides you every step of the way and is willing to answer questions.  Be ready to work hard every day.
This course is just okay. Necessary if you want to learn French.
This is a great course to take and I would definitely recommend the course to anyone who is interested in learning French.
Try it!
USE THE COURSEPACK, the textbook is mildly informative but the cp is much easier to understand and work with.
Unimpressive teaching quality. Take if you like learning in conversation.
Work hard the entire time. Spend time on the vocab and study it early on. Exams are every ten days so take time to study every night.
You need to have a lot of motivation to do very well.
practise a little bit every day!
seems better than other languages
prereqs: Students having studied French previously must take the Princeton French Language placement test. No credit is given for FRE 101 unless it is followed by FRE 102. The afternoon section of FRE 101 (C05) will focus on reading skills, in addition to oral communication, and is limited to graduate students..
descrip: This class develops the basic structures and vocabulary for understanding, speaking, writing, and reading in French. Classroom activities foster communication and cultural competence through comprehension and grammar exercises, skits, conversation and the use of a variety of audio-visual materials.

title: Topics in Medieval Music - The Roman de Fauvel
descrip: The Roman de Fauvel (c.1315), an apocalyptic poem about an equine antichrist figure named Fauvel, survives with music and lyrical interpolations in BN fr. 146, the most lavish of several manuscripts to transmit the colorful tale. The course will use this and other sources as a window into generic, stylistic, and political vicissitudes which took place in French musical culture at the beginning of the fourteenth century.

title: High-Tech Entrepreneurship
reviews: Absolutely must take this course. Prof. Zschau is the best professor I have had at Princeton, and he has given me the tools I need to properly assess ideas and hopefully start my own business.
DO IT.
Definitely take this course, even if you don't think you are that interested in entrepreneurship.
If you are interested in entrepreneurship or looking to learn about new alternatives when looking for jobs and thinking about careers, this course is a great way to open your horizons senior year.
If you're into entrepreneurship or if you're just interested, take it.
Just do the readings and you will be fine!

Princeton needs more Entrepreneurship (and business) courses like this one!  Professor Zschau is an absolutely incredible man and is single handedly the most influential professor I've had at Princeton.  TAKE IT!  Extremely interesting case study readings, the work load is more than manageable, THIS CLASS IS ACTUALLY FUN!
TAKE THIS COURSE
Take it if you want to be involved in the real business world.
Take it if you're interested in the material. but grading is a bit arbitrary.
Take it.
Take it. Awesome class and Prof Zschau is a great person to get to know throughout a semester.
Take this class!  Do not graduate without taking this class it is a life changer.
Take this course no matter what.

This class is very practical if you are at all interested in how business are started or run and Prof. Zschau is inspiring. The workload is very manageable and you definitely don't need any technical experience, but be prepared to participate regularly in lectures of 50  students.
This course is as good as you make it.  Do the readings and participate.
This is an incredible class.  If you have the opportunity to take this class do it.  It's one of the more inspiring classes I have taken at Princeton.
This was by far the most interesting and best class I have taken at Princeton.
Too bad he is only teaching this one last time in Spring '13
Unless your senior schedule is absolutely filled with mandatory classes, this is a first priority.
great class if you ever are thinking of doing anything with business
prereqs: Enrollment is limited to seniors and is by written application only. Application forms are available in Room ACE-21of the E-Quad or http://commons.princeton.edu/kellercenter/courses/egr491.html. They must be completed and returned to ACE-21 by Thursday, April 19, 2012..
descrip: This "hands-on" practical course introduces students to the analysis and actions required to launch a successful high tech company. Using several conceptual frameworks and analytical techniques, it addresses the challenges of evaluating technologics for commercial feasibility, determining how best to launch a new venture, attracting the resources needed to start a company (e.g. people, corporate partners, and venture capital), preparing comprehensive business plans, structuring business relationships, and managing early stage companies toward "launch velocity" and sustainable growth.

title: Financial Risk Management
prereqs: ORF 245, ORF 335 or ECO 465 (concurrent enrollment okay) or instructor's permission required.
descrip: This course covers the basic concepts of modeling, measuring and managing financial risks. Topics include mean-variance portfolio theory, fixed Income securities, option pricing and hedging, Greeks, risk measures and utility functions.

title: Conflict in Africa
reviews: Great Material, lectures at time slow/boring

Professor Seegers is awesome, and the subject matter and readings are very interesting. However, the seminars can be a bit of a struggle if people don't participate--so do the readings and speak up!!! It makes everyone's lives better.
do the reading
descrip: Examines selected aspects on conflict in primarily sub-Saharan Africa. We focus on issues such as: theories of conflict; types of actors; behavior, especially civilian victimization; how conflicts end; and the moral evaluation of conflict. Cases and comparisons include: the 1998 Great Lakes Conflict; the child and corporate soldier in Sierra Leone and Uganda; causes and patterns of civilian victimization; the current conflict in Zimbabwe; and the problems of accountability as experienced by the International Criminal Court and the South African Truth and Reconciliation Commission.

title: China, 1850 to the Present
reviews: All in all, a very interesting and informative introduction to the history of modern China. Professor Chen is a talented lecturer, and her lectures are certainly worth going to. Though the course actually claims to start in 1850, Professor Chen actually goes back to the fall of the Ming dynasty in 1644 and goes right through the 2008 Olympics and the spat over islands between Japan and China. The workload in this course is not too excessive; there is a midterm paper, a final paper (10 pages), and a final exam. Do the readings carefully, as there is a quote section on the final exam! Try to get a preceptor who speaks English well, as some of the ones who grew up in China are a bit less than proficient. Not the best class to PDF, as you have to put a fair amount of work into the final exam in order to pass the course. If you want a better understanding of China's revolutionary century, though, this course is for you!
An excellent course in introductory Chinese history given the excellent professor!
Attend all the lectures. Go to office hours or meet with your preceptor. Stay on top of things during the semester, because so much is determined by your final grades.
DO IT. There is no other course I can recommend as highly as this one.
Definitely a very great class to PDF, would also recommend as a nice class to take to fulfill the HA distribution.
Doing the readings help for papers
Don't fall behind on readings and lectures.
Highly recommend! Really great course to learn about China's recent history, and how it got to where it is today. Very interesting material, and fantastic lectures.
I think more or less everyone should take this course. If you care about the modern world and want to be successful, I think it is a necessity.
I would totally recommend it, for anyone of any background. It was interesting and valuable information.

If you have any interest in China and need to fulfill an HA, this is a class worth considering. Although there a good amount of reading it is overall interesting. There are no weekly assignments besides the readings. There is a midterm paper which was doable. Although it was quite a lot to do both a final paper and exam, these were both also manageable.
If you want to learn about modern China, this course is great!
Knowing something about China and Chinese culture is extremely useful. This course only covers "Modern China," but the readings are often sprinkled with classical references.

Lecture is a little annoying because she doesn't post her slides or any sort of detailed notes, and you have to type fast and stay focused because Professor Chen talks fast, but maybe that's true of all history classes - I wouldn't know, this is my HA and my first history class. My preceptor took my precept absences really seriously, so that made it a little weird to PDF. But ultimately it's a fine class to PDF if you have any interest in Chinese culture, and doesn't seem too difficult to take for a grade either (two papers and an in-class final). Speaking Chinese may be a benefit to help keep up with names of people and places.
Prof. Janet Chen is awesome. You really learn a lot from this course.
Take it!
Take the course. It's really interesting and the workload is manageable. Make sure you get a good preceptor though.
Take this course if you want a great overview of the history of modern China. It is not too much work and you will learn so much. Definitely try to get into Professor Chen's precept.
Talk to your preceptor and Professor Chen. They're both awesome and really helpful!

The Professor and preceptors are really nice. I am a big fan of Professor Chen's lecturing style, and the material is very interesting if you have general interest in China. The amount of coursework is reasonable, and precept readings are always super interesting and good discussion materials. I would recommend taking this class if you are willing to work hard.
Think about the themes and topics in different contexts.
Very interesting course if you're interested in China. Even though this is a 300-level course with lots of history majors, it's still not bad as a P/D/F class.
Very well structured course which will give students a deep understanding of Chinese history if they are willing to do all the readings. This will pay them well.
if you are genuinely interested, take it! if you're just looking to fulfill a HIS req, it'll be a pain trying to remember everything

it was a great course. If you want to learn about Chinese history, take it and you will learn a lot about Chinese history. it is very interesting and I can have an intelligent conversation about China now and have some context for China's progress  in the international community.
prereqs: P/D/F option is not available for History concentrators..
descrip: This course is an introduction to the history of modern China, from imperial dynasty to Republic, from the Red Guards to Starbucks. We will explore, through primary sources in translation, political and social revolutions, transformations in intellectual life and culture, as well as competing explanations for events such as the rise of the Communist Party and the Cultural Revolution. Major themes include: the impact of imperialism and war, gender relations, tensions between governance and dissent, and the emergence of nationalism.

title: Economics of Labor
reviews: Take it if you're really committed to labor economics.
descrip: An examination of the economics of the labor market, especially the forces determining the supply of and demand for labor, the level of unemployment, labor mobility, the structure of relative wages, and the general level of wages.

title: Architecture Design Studio
reviews: N/A
You have to take this class.
descrip: Design Studio

title: French Literature: Approaches to the Language of Literary Texts
reviews: Don't take it unless you really like french literature/need it for a certificate. I found it extremely boring
If you don't like literature classes in english you probably won't like this one.
Take it!

This is definitely a good course to improve your French comprehension.  The fact that the classes are an hour and twenty minutes, instead of just 50 makes it easier to get into a French mindset, which helps with comprehension.  It's sort of like attending a French book club twice a week.
Very good course, not too hard, not phenomenal either.
prereqs: FRE 107 or FRE 108 or permission of instructor. Course conducted entirely in French..
descrip: This course is meant to introduce students to great works of French literature from a range of historical periods and to provide them with methods for literary interpretation through close reading of these texts. The course syllabus is organized around common themes and generic categories. This course is invaluable preparation for more advanced and specialized 300-level literature courses. Classroom discussion, free exchange encouraged.

title: Modern Dance: Beginning Technique and Choreography
reviews: Enjoy yourself! Take it only if you are genuinely interested in the dance artform.
I would advise another student taking this course not to be dissuaded by an approach to dance/movement that is a bit unfamiliar or intimidating. The initial discomfort is definitely worth it.

I would tell another student considering taking this course that this class is great for expanding your dancing abilities. Be open to new things, but also know that you do not have to change to fit these new ideas; know where you draw the line and feel free to share that with your teachers.

It is a really relaxed, fun class to get the LA requirement out of the way.  The only annoying thing is the time.  It is from 4:30pm to 6:30 pm, which is a time that no one else has class because of sports' practices.
It's a fun, low-stress class. Especially with the composition component, you get out what you put into it.
Yes, but only if you are prepared to spend  a lot of time on it
take it! especially if you need a relaxing LA. PDF only.
prereqs: DAN 209 or permission of instructor. Interview with faculty for placement in composition section from April 4th to April 20th, 2012. Interview times: Rebecca Lazier (rlazier@) T/TH 1pm-2pm, Tina Fehlandt (fehlandt@) M/W 1pm-2pm. To arrange interview, email Professor Lazier or Professor Fehlandt and send a list of any previous composition experience at Princeton..
descrip: Dance technique and choreography for beginning and intermediate levels. Technique class will emphasize placement and the increase of movement efficiency through proper alignment. Students will also explore dancing to different rhythms, tempos and styles of music while emphasizing weight of the body and its relationship to space and gravity. In choreography class students will develop their understanding of the ways in which structural elements and movement vocabularies contribute to a dance's overarching impact and content. Readings and viewings broaden students understanding of dance's position in the world of art and ideas.

title: Elementary Hebrew I
reviews: Hebrew rocks!
Just make sure you pay attention the first time.
Working on vocabulary at home is incredibly helpful.

You get as much of it as you put in. She doesn't require much of you, so you have to make sure you push yourself to keep up with vocab and assignments. Do work on your own and ask questions, that is what the teacher is good at.
prereqs: No credit is given for HEB 101 unless it is followed by HEB 102..
descrip: To develop the skills of reading, speaking, comprehending and writing. The main emphasis is on acquiring communicative proficiency and therefore, Hebrew is progressively employed as the classroom language. A solid grammatical basis and awareness of the idiomatic usage of the language will be emphasized. Classroom activities include conversation, grammar exercises and reading. Towards the middle of the semester, an Israeli movie is shown, discussed and critized through a written assignment.

title: Darwin and His Legacy
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: The Philosophy of Physics - How is fundamental physics fundamental?
descrip: Philosophers often allot a special role to fundamental physics. But whether it can play that role depends on its nature and aspirations. We will examine appeals to fundamental physics and attempts to say what makes some physics fundamental. Is quantum physics fundamental? After examining quantum theory to see why it may not be cut out to play the role some philosophers allot to fundamental physics, we will ask: "Should we try to (a) seek to reformulate or reinterpret quantum theory, (b) accept that quantum theory can make no contribution to fundamental physics, or (c) reject philosophers' demands on fundamental physics?"

title: The Japanese Print
reviews: I would tell them to take it, that this is one class they should not miss the opportunity to take.
If you are considering taking the course out of general interest, but lack a strong background in art history, don't be frightened off.
TAKE THIS COURSE. Professor Watsky is amazing, and the class is so much fun. The fact that you get to buy a print for the museum as a class is also really cool.
prereqs: At least one lower level course in art history or Japanese studies, or permission of instructor..
descrip: This seminar examines Japanese woodblock prints from the 17th through the 19th century. We will consider the formal and technical aspects of prints, the varied subject matter, including the "floating world" of prostitution and theatre, the Japanese landscape and urban centers, and the links between literature and prints, especially the re-working of classical literary themes in popular prints. The seminar will emphasize the study of prints in the Princeton University Art Museum; students will also research Japanese prints at an art gallery in New York and recommend one to be purchased and added to the collection of the Museum.

title: Topics in Cinema and Culture - Work and Love, Play and Politics in Spanish Cinema
reviews: Definitely take this class if you're interested in films,Spain,  anthropology, psychology, social sciences in general.
Take it if even remotely interested.
Take it!  The movies are great, although you really need to watch all of them to benefit from the class.  If you are developing your Spanish skills, this class will help you a lot.
Take it. Phenomenal class and teaching
This is one of the best classes I have taken at Princeton. Professor Loureiro is very invested in the discussions and the class.
prereqs: At least one Spanish course above SPA 207 or instructor's permission..
descrip: An exploration of some of the most distinctive themes in Spanish films of the last fifty years. Topics to be discussed, among others: political repression; the modernization of Spain since the 1960s; the perversions of love; the world as a stage; new sexualities; the redefinition of gender roles; uncanny worlds.

title: Topics in Social and Personality Psychology - From Collective Memory to Collective Action
reviews: I would definitely recommend this class if you're interested in political psychology and some of the more psychologically-based research behind international relations.

I'd take it again! Professor Coman brings together a really interesting set of readings and course topics to give students a wide perspective on collective memory, action, and violence. I learned a lot.

If a student is into the subject at least come to the firts class and see if you are interested in the way it is approached in this seminar. I definitely got a new perspective on conflicts from the class and acquired new tools to analyze them. If it's somthing taht you'd like to do then this class is for you.

If you're looking for a very interesting class on collective memory and collective action, that is extremely relevant in today's world, this is a great class for you. If you're just looking for an interesting class that has fun readings and won't punish you with work, this is also a great class.
Take a PSY 400 course and a course with Prof. Coman if his research interests you (it's not for everyone).

Take the class. Even if you are completely disinterested in psychological and social processes, it'll teach you something about the world - things that you probably hear often yet know close to nothing about.
Take this course even if you're not very well acquainted with collective movements. I learned a lot and really enjoyed it
definitely take it if you are a psych major or not
prereqs: PSY 252, or students may e-mail the instructor to explain why they would like to take the class, listing relevant coursework, including research methods and other social science courses..
descrip: Intergroup conflict and collective violence are central topics across the social sciences. Course provides a framework for integrating different approaches to intergroup conflict, from psychology (social-interactionism) to anthropology (epidemiology of beliefs) to political science (nationalism studies). Various intergroup conflicts are discussed (e.g. the Former Yugoslavian Republics, Israel-Palestine) with the goal of assessing the validity of the proposed interdisciplinary framework. No prior knowledge of social network analysis (SNA) or agent-based simulations (ABM) is required.

title: Beginning Bosnian-Croatian-Serbian I
prereqs: Knowledge of another Slavic language is not required..
descrip: An introduction to BCS, the primary language of the former Yugoslavia (also called Serbo-Croatian), this course develops the four major language skills: speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing. Class time is devoted to mastering conversational skills, grammar explanations, oral drilling, and reading a variety of texts--popular writing, fiction, poetry, and expository prose. Covers the fundamentals of BCS grammar (verbal conjugations, aspect, the primary verbal tenses, and all cases); high-frequency vocabulary will be progressively learned and reinforced. No credit is given for BCS 101 unless followed by BCS 102.

title: Introduction to Real Analysis
reviews: A good foundational course for math majors or people who work with probability. Not much materials covered, but proof and rigor are much emphasized in this class.
A good intro to real analysis. Professor Ionescu is a really clear instructor.
As a non-math major, this was very challenging as a first proof-based course. But overall, a pretty good class, material was presented pretty clearly in lecture.

Generally math majors and students from other majors which utilize some degree of measure theory take this course. If you want to do pure math for fun, take 215 instead; it connects a lot better with stuff you learned from calculus and (I think) is more fun as a result.
I would absolutely recomment it if you are interested in measure theory.
The most frustrating aspect of the course was realizing how good it could have been had it been better taught. If this were changed in the future, I would change my recommendation.
prereqs: MAT 201 and 202 or equivalent..
descrip: Introduction to real analysis, including the theory of Lebesgue measure and integration on the line and n-dimensional space, introduction to Fourier Series.

title: Thesis Studio
reviews: I strongly recommend Liz Diller, she is one of the reasons to recommend Princeton for the graduate program in architecture in my opinion
Mandatory
descrip: Thesis studio

title: Slavery in the Roman World
descrip: This course considers the problem of slavery in the Roman world, from the early Republic to the end of the Empire. There will be some coverage of the background developments in the slave system under the earlier age of the Greek city-states. A wide range of subjects concerning slavery in Roman society will be considered including the causes of the creation of the Roman slave system, the ways in which it was maintained, its main social and economic functions, and the problem of resistance to servitude.

title: Introduction to French Literary Theory
prereqs: 200-level French class or permission of Instructor.
descrip: Combines a general introduction to critical theory with in-depth study of a small number of representative original texts. Authors may include Sartre, Fanon, Deleuze, Foucault, Ranciere, Kristeva, and Badiou..

title: Recent Research in Population Biology
reviews: Follow your assigned journals, but do not feel obligated to pick from them. Present the papers you find interesting for personal research, so the course does not become a chore. Be considerate of others when considering how long your presentation will be. Be prepared.
I would advise a student to take this course because this course really helps broaden your knowledge in fields outside of your own research interests.
They are the best!
prereqs: Course is limited to graduate students only..
descrip: Systematic reviews of recent literature in areas of ecology, evolution, and animal behavior. The general survey of literature is supplemented with detailed discussion of selected research papers of unusual importance and significance. (This is a core course.)

title: Biochemistry
reviews: A lot of memorization and tricky questions.
A ton of work, so be very careful if, as a ChemE, you want to take this for fun and general interest. Otherwise, you're probably forced to take this for pre-med or MOL
Be ready to work hard - the curve can be nasty!
Best class ever. Take it if you want to understand what's happening in your body.
Biochem is tough. If you work hard though, it's a worthwhile course. Professor Hughson is great, he's probably the best part of the course. That and his lecture notes. Use them!

Biochemistry is tough, but it's not completely scary. The course is based on synthesizing information (lectures notes, precept problems, reading, problem sets, etc.) and then memorizing everything. Lectures and precepts are pretty good at making sure you have all the information you need. After that, make sure you have a deep understanding of how the different concepts are related to each other. Never stop connecting the dots! Also: try to space out your studying as much as possible; cramming doesn't work too well in this course.
Challenging class but you probably have to take it.
Do not take this course unless you have to.
Do the problem sets, go to lecture.
Don't fall behind on the reading.
Don't get behind! Memorize those details as they are presented to you.
Don't let the premeds scare you - Professor Hughson teaches a great course and you'll learn a ton. It's hard work but is rewarding.
Don't take it if you don't have to!!
Don't take this class unless you have to, or unless you enjoyed orgo.
Don't take unless you have to
Excellent course.  Lots of material.  Remember that just like with Orgo, memorization is not the solution.
Get a good preceptor! and do the reading! If you're engaged, the course is fun and intuitive.
Go to every lecture and read the book.
Go to lecture, keep up with the work.

Going to class is the best way to receive the material. Professor Hughson explains it very clearly and it will save you hours of trying to understand it yourself. Study off the lecture notes instead of the book, it will provide all the information you need for the exams.
Good class!
Great and well organized class. Really interesting.

Great course. Professor Hughson is a fantastic lecture and if you are interested in metabolism, definitely take it! It's a ridiculous amount of material and it takes ages to study for an exam, but I thought it was worth it!
Have an interest in the material.

Hughson manages to teach biochem in the best possible way. If you did well in MOL214 and orgo, then if you put in the time, you'll do fine here. Make sure to redo all precept problem sets and regular problem sets before each exam.
I would recommend against it unless absolutely necessary for graduating, just because it's a lot of work even for someone only moderately interested.

I would recommend taking this course if you have an interest in biochemistry and you have an easier semester - don't take this if you have more than one other hard course in your semester. Be aware of the sheer amount of memorization involved.
I would recommend this course if you need to take it for a major or if you're premed. If you're generally interested in biochemistry, I feel that it's not the best course to satisfy this interest.

I'm a CBE on the bio track and I loved loved loved this course. Hughson is a fantastic lecturer. As you might have expect, there's a lot of memorization that goes into this course, so start studying EARLIER for midterms and the final, just so you aren't overwhelmed with the sheer amount of stuff you have to learn.
If you are doing MOL or CHM, biochem will definitely be useful. Get lecture notes from previous years and study it before taking the course though.
If you are planning to pursue science after college, this course will prepare you well. However, it may leave pre-med students hoping for a little more clinical applications.
If you don't _love_ the material or have to take it, dont.  It's hard and frustrating and you feel stupid.
If you stay ahead, it will make this course far easier.
Interesting course and worthwhile to take.

It's a LOT of memorization. Come to class--you have to because you have clicker questions every class. Review your notes often: there are clicker questions and a TON of information. Do not save memorization for the night before (or even week before exam). 
Do the homework--it does come in handy when studying for the exams.
It's a whole ton of information, but taught very well by Professor Hughson. The curve is pretty intense on exams!
It's hard and hard to do well, so only take if you have to/are really interested. Don't lose sight of the big picture, and the material will be (relatively) interesting throughout.
It's hard. If you have to take it, know that you'll have to study hard.

Its' a lot of work so I would only take it if you need it but it's seriously a great class and I see myself using it outside of school (especially the metabolism part). I was dreading taking biochem so I put it off until my senior year but I could not have imagined a better experience.
Keep up with the reading, understand the material, and approach the preceptors and Prof Hughson with any questions. Understand all the clicker questions at the time.
Lot of memorization. Liked Orgo better.
Lots of work and memorization - be prepared! But it's a really great course. You learn a lot and the exams are fair, and if you just keep up, things should be good.

Many students will take this course to fulfill some sort of requirement, whether that be for med school or a departmental. Some of the topics covered are inherently difficult, tedious, and demanding, and there is no way around this. However, Professor Hughson has a well-thought-out approach to conveying the material in an effective manner that usually keeps things both interesting and fairly manageable. You will have to work hard in this class, and studying well in advance of all exams is a must. However, there is ample assistance and studying materials provided by the TAs and professor, and the material is rarely mind-boggling. Overall, the experience was quite good given the intrinsic constraints of the subject material.
Mmm... if you are interested in biochem then yes, do it. But be ready because it is a very time-consuming class and the curve is not forgiving.
None

Obviously, if you don't need Biochem as a requirement don't take it. Too time-consuming and it is difficult material. If you do have to take it, be prepared to work hard and spend a TON of time grappling with and MEMORIZING the material. It is quite the journey through the course, but when it is over, you will definitely feel like you have accomplished something (no matter what grade you end up with).
Pay attention in class and do the readings. I didn't find it that important to do the readings before class as recommended, but they should definitely be done before the exams.
Read and do the assignments! This is a course where falling behind is not advisable.
Read the book!

Read the textbook in advance of lectures, read the lecture notes after lecture, and stay on top of your shit.  If you don't understand a certain pathway or haven't memorized enzymes or reactions, you need to get on that before it all accumulates and you end up with 5 chapters of hazy material that you'll have to reteach yourself.  The class moves at a quick pace, so as long as you keep you keep up, you'll enjoy it.  If you don't, you won't.
Read the textbook. Start studying early.
Recommend this course if you are good at memorization
Start memorizing early.
Study for the clicker questions. If you can maintain a 90%-100% average on them, then you'll do fine on the exams.
Take if you have to or our good at MOL. Interesting at the end of the semester when everything is drawn together.
Take it if you are interested in learning more about the chemical reactions that are fundamental to life. Or if you just needed for
Take it!
Take it.
Take it. You probably have to, but even if you don't it's some pretty interesting stuff, especially once you get to see the big picture.

Take this class if you have a lot of time to dedicate--it is interesting, but you definitely have to earn any grade that you get.  I hated orgo and found biochem to be much more interesting, although still quite challenging.
Take this course! It gives a great intersection of organic chemical synthesis and tissue metabolism while retaining a solid grounding in fundamental concepts of physiology.
Take this if you are prepared to study
Take this only if you have to.  It is a good course, but very stressful - on the same level of orgo 2

The course covers a ton of material, but by the end you'll have a much greater appreciation for what your body can do. It was cool to learn everything in the course, but it definitely takes a lot of time. If you don't have to take the course, then only take it if you're sure you can devote the time needed to learn the material.
The curve sucks, and do not fall behind on readings
The final is extremely difficult and you will need at least 3 weeks of studying to memorize all the material.
The readings would have probably been helpful, and don't miss lectures (or clicker questions!) because they are very helpful.

This course is very well-taught and organized. Lectures are engaging (and interactive in that they feature "clicker" questions). However, biochemistry does involve learning an enormous amount of material and a fair amount of memorization.
Tough, so don't get discouraged
Tough, tough course. Material is very interesting. Memorization is painful at times, but when everything comes together for metabolism it can be gratifying.
Try to make time to study for the tests steadily. Cramming is not that fun.

Uh, well, if you're premed and/or MOL I guess you have to take this class. Too bad it's got one of the highest densities of hypercompetitive individuals. The only consolation is that Hughson is a great professor who really knows his stuff, and that the class is also really well structured.
Unless you need to take it for med school or a distribution requirement, don't.  Unless you like torturing yourself with work
Very well-taught. Professor Hughson and the preceptors are great. They explain concepts very well and are extremely helpful. Interesting course. It's quite tough to do well though.
You should know that this class is hard, but that probably won't affect your decision to take it - you know whether or not you want to take biochem already. And if you want to, then it's worth it.
You will learn biochemistry, and you will learn it well.
You're probably premed or MOL if you're taking this course, but at least you will be exposed to great lectures and interesting material, even if it is tough.
You're probably taking this because you have to.  Lucky for you, it's a really well-taught class.  You will love Hughson :)  Just stay on top of things as best you can, for the clicker questions.
hard
only if you HAVE to take the course
stay on top of the reading
super hard. Hopefully it comes back to help out in Med School. A lot of work
take it, even if not MOL major. pretty useful and applicable
you definitely learn a lot of interesting and relevant information for a MOL major or any science major
prereqs: MOL 214/215 and CHM 304/304B.
descrip: Fundamental concepts of biomolecular structure and function will be discussed, with an emphasis on principles of thermodynamics, binding and catalysis. A major portion of the course will focus on metabolism and its logic and regulation.

title: Princeton Atelier - Zoetrope: Creating Experimental Music-Theater
reviews: ATL courses are awesome...this one was a little tiny bit weak.

Don't expect to like all the work or know how approach it all. Just keep your mind open to new possibilities, When it comes to presentations, it helps to have as much of your work ready as possible each time so you can get the most complete feedback.

The course suffered from a lack of direction and unprofessional instruction, but worst of all was a lack of stakes. Because the course is P/D/F only and did not end in a public performance, and because all Princeton students have far more responsibilities jammed into their schedules than they actually have time for, work for this course (and presumably for other Atelier courses as well) sank to the bottom of each student's priority list, resulting in a seminar that nobody particularly cared about regardless of its content. I did not enjoy the class because it became a trivial responsibility rather than a serious engagement with a subject, and I would not take another Atelier course out of fear of repeating this experience.
prereqs: Students with backgrounds in music, design, poetry, architecture, dance, visual arts are encouraged to apply. The guest artists will be looking to build a team of collaborating student artists from various backgrounds. Application and interviews/auditions required. See the Princeton Atelier site at www.princeton.edu/arts/ for more information and applications or contact goellner@princeton..
descrip: Theater director Alec Duffy, playwright Dave Malloy and set designer Mimi Lien will lead students in creating collaborative works of experimental music-theater, inventing new ways of melding music and theater that challenge existing and prevalent forms. For inspiration we will look to works by Robert Ashley, Meredith Monk, Gertrude Stein/Virgil Thomson, and Robert Wilson/Philip Glass, exploring these artists' unconventional approaches to language, narrative, staging and composition.

title: Latin American Studies Seminar - The Politics of Ethnicity in Latin America
reviews: I would highly highly highly highly recommend this course. It is spectacular, well thought out, and you really develop as a scholar and academic with Prof Smith.
Professor Smith knows a ton so listening to him is a good thing to do.

Professor Smith was an amazing professor. He is incredibly engaged with his work, and his passion is clearly visible. I found this to be one of the most intellectually stimulating courses I've taken at Princeton, challenging my preconceived notions and broadening my understanding of indigenous movements. Professor Smith was also incredibly helpful as a mentor and was very generous in his discussions.
This has been my favorite course at Princeton so far and you have the chance to take any course with Professor Smith you should!
Unfortunately, the professor was only at Princeton for a semester. I would encourage taking a course that deals with topics such as this one. However, what made the course great was the professor.
prereqs: There are no prerequisites for this course, although a working knowledge of anthropological theories, the practice of ethnography, and some familiarity with Latin America (either through literature or field experience) will be useful..
descrip: In the late 20th century, an acknowledgment of ethnic and cultural diversity in Latin America influenced politicians to rethink their definition of citizenship in order to, at the very least, publicly demonstrate interest in fostering democratic forms of government. This opened up channels through which indigenous leaders organized their constituent communities by strategically using ethnicity as a platform for political participation. This seminar focuses upon Latin American indigenous movements with an eye towards anthropological concerns with representation, voice, and the precarious balance between solidarity and academic critique.

title: Complex Analysis with Applications
reviews: Don't take it.  The first few weeks are pointlessly easy, but then things get difficult and strange.  The professor doesn't seem to care about the students.

Don't take this class if you have too much going on and can't prioritize it, because the exams (at least when I took it) seemed much harder than the problem sets. It probably depends on the professor.

Good applications-based class on Complex Analysis. If you want to learn how to take contour integrals in the complex plane and other such things without learning it in all of the rigor of Stein's class, I think this is a good course for you.

If you're a physics major who needs complex analysis but doesn't want/have the background to take the math major course, then this course is for you. Professor Case was a great lecturer, but the problem sets were perhaps a bit too easy in comparison to the exams (which were each four hours long). Overall the course was good and I found the material interesting.
The midterms and final are a huge step up from the PSETs.  Study for them!  Otherwise, it's a similar math course in procedure and difficulty to 203 or 204.

The quality of the teaching was great. I liked Prof. Case's method of starting with the applications and continuing with a theoretical expansion, which was pretty challenging. 

The problem sets were quite easy and I would have appreciated if it were closer to the level of the exams. 

I think it's the best way to get an introduction into complex analysis.

This is a great math class! For me it was just the right level - I have taken math 203 and 204 and MAE 305 (differential equations). The professor is very clear & responsive to questions. Math is amazing, especially complex analysis! This is a good math course to take if you are curious about getting a window into a little bit of higher level / proof-y things but have not taken math 215 (and don't want to).
Very good course for a Physics major. Complex analysis is beautiful and this course is just at the right level for a science major.
prereqs: MAT 201 and 202 or equivalent..
descrip: The theory of functions of one complex variable, covering power series expansions, residues, contour integration, and conformal mapping. Although the theory will be given adequate treatment, the emphasis of this course is the use of complex analysis as a tool for solving problems.

title: Evaluation of Demographic Research
reviews: "Take it!"
Do it.
Start thinking about a dissertation idea early. Preferably during the summer before taking the class.
Take it.
This course is exceptionally helpful, and I would strongly recommend it to anyone.
descrip: Course is designed for doctoral students in their third year of a specialization in demography. One objective of the course is to examine critically how researchers tackle demographic research questions. A second related goal is to explore the construction of a dissertation and a research paper.

title: Seminar in International Politics
descrip: A general introduction to the field of international relations, with an emphasis on the principal theoretical approaches and major problems and theories in the field. Students emerge from the course with an ability to situate theories and empirical claims in the broader historical, conceptual and empirical context of debates and literatures.

title: Statistical Mechanics
descrip: The physical principles and mathematical formulation of statistical physics, with emphasis on applications in thermodynamics, condensed matter, physical chemistry and astrophysics. Topics that will be discussed include bose-einstein condensation, degenerate fermi systems, phase-transitions, and basics of kinetic theory. Students will be asked to participate in class discussion of challenging problems taken from past departmental generals exams (prelims).

title: Modern Islamic Political Thought
descrip: An examination of major facets of Islamic political thought from the late nineteenth century to the present in a broadly comparative framework and against the backdrop of medieval Islamic thought. Topics include: the "fragmentation" of religious authority and its consequences for Muslim politics; conceptions of the shari'a and of the Islamic state; and Islamist discourses on gender, violence, and relations with non-Muslims.

title: Advanced French Language and Style
reviews: A lot of it depends on who is in class with you.

Good class, moderate workload. Very practical: you will speak a ton, practice writing a lot, and get helpful feedback on your writing. One of the few upper level French courses that is not all about weird abstract artsy stuff. It's just about getting better at French. Also Professor Wampole is really, really cool.
I found that I did not get very much out of this class.  I do not think it was as much work, and hence learning, as I had hoped.
I would say definitely take this course as a certificate requirement or even just to improve your written and spoken French. A lot of writing, but worth it.

If you are looking for a super easy French class to take, this is it. Don't let the essay a week scare you off, they are painfully easy assignments and never more than 2pgs - oftentimes less. The weekly assignments take about 15min for the week and aren't necessary at all - most people stopped doing them about 2wks in.  However, if you're looking for a class that will improve your French, look elsewhere.  You won't speak a lot in class, and even if you force yourself to do the unnecessary assignments week after week like I did, you will leave with the same (or less) skill than you started with.

If you're looking for a very easy course and you're good at French grammar, this is a good course to take. The assignments (when I took the course with Gayle in fall 2012) were graded purely on grammatical correctness.

If you're serious about French, but haven't taken any "serious" French courses at Princeton, or are returning from a long hiatus, it might be worth your while to take this course. It might be hard or scary in the first couple of weeks, but with work it's possible to adjust and excel.

Loved it. Great discussions, wide scope of skills that you sharpen, and you come out of it knowing how to write everything (from a resume/CV to a book review to a creative piece etc) in French. Can be intimidating at first if you're a sophomore, considering the class is mostly comprised of juniors who have taken classes together at Princeton, but that intimidating feeling goes away really quickly.
This course is a great way to maintain your French abilities.
This course is useful to get practice writing and to advance your language skills somewhat, though (unless the curriculum is changed) I would not expect a mind-blowing or fascinating course.
This course, although somewhat dry, will greatly improve your French writing skills going into the upper level courses.
easy french class if you're engaged and willing to do little weekly assignments.
prereqs: A 200-level French course or permission of instructor..
descrip: To improve spoken and written French through comparative study of English and French grammatical and syntactic structures, literary translation, and reading of non-literary texts.

title: Rhetoric and Politics
descrip: http://www.princeton.edu/pub/frs

title: Sex, Sexuality, and Gender
descrip: Male/Female, Man/Woman, Masculine/Feminine, Straight/Gay. These "dueling dualisms" structure our lives, identities and social institutions. Most of us believe that we have a concrete biological sex, social gender and sexual orientation; yet, sociologists increasingly debate the very meanings of these categories and their relationships to one another. We will examine theoretical and empirical approaches to understanding sex, gender and sexuality, paying particular attention to the historical construction of categories, theories about human difference and efforts within sociology to make sex, gender and sexuality into proper objects of study.

title: Problems in Greek Literature - Hesiod and the Hesiodic tradition
descrip: This course begins from a study of Hesiod's Works and Days, an intriguing combination of cosmic myth, moral exhortation and agricultural advice, and moves to consider several important moments in the ancient reception and influence of that poem. In particular the course looks at the poem's reputation in the classical period (Plato and Xenophon), in Hellenistic poetry (Aratus and Callimachus) and in the Greek literature of the Roman empire (Plutarch and Lucian).

title: The United States Since 1974
reviews: Absolutely take this class, do the readings, and go to every lecture. I felt like I was going to watch a performance every week.
All the lectures are awesome, with Kruse and Zelizer using videos and songs. The readings are unnecessary, there are only 2 exams and the questions are given ahead of time.
Amazing professors, amazing material, amazing course.

An excellent course!  Do be prepared for it to be quite slanted to the left politically, however.  Other than that though, I would say take it!  The workload is very reasonable, and the class is quite interesting and applicable, as it covers such recent material.
Be careful of your precept selection.
Best class I took at Princeton
Best two courses I've taken.
Definitely a good course for anyone interested in the course work or someone looking for an HA with a lighter work load. Lectures are much more important than the readings.
Definitely a good history course.
Definitely attend every lecture, there is no reason not to.
Definitely take it!
Definitely take it.
Definitely take it. Doing the reading will really help you get more out of it, though the lectures alone are awesome and interesting. It's stuff we all should know.
Definitely take this - very interstin
Definitely take this course. Make sure to attend every lecture -- it will be worth it!

Definitely take this course. Professor Kruse and Professor Zelizer are fantastic lecturers and you will learn so much about why the US looks the way it does today on political, economic, and social/cultural levels.

Definitely take this course. This is knowledge that everyone living in America needs to know. My favorite class in HS was AP US History, but I was disappointed that it only covered up through the Vietnam war. This class is the perfect continuation. The class starts out a bit slow with Nixon, Ford, and Carter, but once we got to Reagan and onwards I was really interested in every lecture. The lectures by Kruse and Zelizer are very good, and they use a lot of media and video clips to demonstrate key events that they are talking about. I liked most of the readings, a few were a bit dry, but overall I would say they are worth doing. I'm so glad I have a much better understanding of the Reagan, Clinton, and Bush era's...all of which play a huge role in current American politics. This has been one of my favorite classes at Princeton.
Definitely take this course. You really can't ask for more. Make sure to read as much as possible, because the lectures are particularly interesting if you've absorbed the themes of each week's book.
Do all the readings, and look up any names/events/legislation you didn't quite get immediately after lecture. It will save you some time when you study for the exams.
Do the readings and try to avoid missing lectures. Also be prepared to take notes with pen and paper and write huge amounts in a very short period of time.
Don't worry about the details of the readings too much. Think throughout the course how events/people fit into the larger themes of the course.
Go to every lecture they are worth it
Good course. Lectures are very important. Grading is fair.
Great class about modern American history right up to the present.
Great course for anyone interested in the material or just looking for an HA.

I don't care who you are, what your major is, or what distribution requirements you need filled. Take this course. The instructors are amazing, the material is fascinating, and what you're learning about is directly relevant to you, whether you know it or not.

I highly recommend taking this course.  It's super interesting, and you'll learn a lot about our country in the past 30 years or so.  As long as you go to lecture and take good notes, you will probably do well on the exams.
I looked forward to coming to this class twice a week. If you like American history, I think you will too.
I loved this class.

I really liked the class. Even if you're not big on history, you will probably still find it interesting because it is so contemporary and covers a lot of politics and economics. Ending with how things are today, you can really gain a good understanding of how America today formed.

I think this is going to be the best class I will ever take here. Lectures, readings, and precepts were all great. Not a lot of work, and the exams aren't too hard. Also incredibly relevant and interesting. AMAZING Professors. DO the readings and go to lectures.
I would absolutely recommend this class even with no history background but you need to be prepared to do a lot of work and stay on top of it or it won't be fun or rewarding.
I would definitely recommend taking this course.
I would definitely recommend this to other students!
I would encourage future students of this course to make an effort to do all of the readings and attend every lecture.  Each reading and lecture is informative, interesting, and beneficial.
I would highly recommend the course.
I would recommend taking any course with Kruse. He is a phenomenal lecturer and the course is sure to be great.

I would take this class again in a heartbeat.  Professor Kruse is a must-have at Princeton.  He's wonderful.  It's an easy class to do well in.  There is no real need to do the readings, although they will help for the essays during the test and they are interesting.  Take this and be glad you did!

I'd recommend taking this course because the material is interesting, the lectures are thorough and there isn't a terrible amount of work to do.  It's definitely easy to do well as long as you attend lectures, review sessions, keep up with readings and engage in precepts.
If you're interested in modern US history or the USA in general this is a must take.
If you've ever wondered what happened in the US after your high school history class ended, this will tell you how the US came to be where it is.

It is an interesting course with good professors. Don't be scared about the amount of readings, you don't have to read everything word by word. Pay attention at lectures and precepts and you'll be prepared for and fine with the exams.
It is interesting and requires a medium amount of effort. Worth it.
Kruse and Zelizer are great and engaging lecturers. You have to go to lecture to understand everything -- the reading isn't enough.
Kruse and Zelizer are great and the preceptors are helpful, but the readings and precept aren't super interesting.
Make time to do the readings - you will be glad when you're watching the news!
Observe the one miss rule for history courses.
One of my favorite classes at Princeton.
Personal favorite course I've taken at Princeton so far. Fantastic lectures, readings, and precepts,
Realize that this is a survey course that will contain a lot of material. Also note that the course is very biased towards a liberal interpretation of political events.
Start the readings early in the week as they can be lengthy and take notes which will help for finals.
TAKE IT
TAKE THE COURSE!
TAKE THIS CLASS! SO SO GOOD AND VERY INTERESTING

TAKE THIS CLASS! So interesting and relevant.  Great readings and even better lectures.  Lots of great preceptors my semester too (DOV IS THE MAN. And Malkiel's precept was actually pretty good).  The exams are not difficult in terms of material but the grading is VERY difficult.  They consist of IDs and essays (you get the questions to the essays in advance).  Even with perfect answers, almost no one gets 10/10 on the IDs.
Take it
Take it - the past 40 years are already history, and you should learn how to analyze it.
Take it - you think you know stuff about Nixon/Ford/Carter/Reagan/Bush/Clinton/Bush years but you'll end up learning a lot of things that show us why the US is the way it is today.
Take it if you are at all interested in American History or are curious to learn more. Lectures are great and no work besides the exams.
Take it with these professors! Careful who you get as a preceptor.
Take it!
Take it!! Great lectures and interesting readings. Very important info to know too
Take it--you'll learn a ton, have some of the most interesting lectures at Princeton. But do know that it's a large class and grading isn't easy.
Take it.
Take it. Great lectures on very relevant material
Take it. It is a fun and very informative class, not much work, and great preceptors.
Take the course.
Take this class! It's fascinating and stuff everyone needs to know

Take this class! It's really interesting and really relevant; both Kruse and Zelizer are incredibly impressive lecturers and both are hilarious, as well. 

There's also very little effort required on your part, but that makes it a B  class unless you really write excellent essays on your exams. (The only assessments are the midterm and final, and precept participation; there are no papers the entire semester).

Take this class- Kruse and Zelizer are great! Lectures are engaging from start to finish. It covers a time that often gets overlooked in high school classes and so many themes and events are relevant in the current political climate. Work-wise there is reading every week but only a mid term and final so not bad at all.
Take this course and go to lectures!
Take this course and put effort into it.
Take this course, just know it entails a lot of work.
Take this course.  It is as close to perfect one can get.

Take this course. It's fantastic and far from demanding. Great for anyone who feels they have a gap in historical knowledge or wants a chance to examine recent trends. Also great for those who don't; it's that good.
Take this if you want to learn more about how America today is affected by its recent past. It's quite eye-opening, and I really learnt a lot!  (also, Dov is great!)
Take this take this take this. You will regret not
Take this!
There is a lot of reading every week! Stay on top of it, as your precept grade is important. The midterm and final are straightforward.
This class was absolutely fabulous and I couldn't recommend it any more. The lectures were engaging and presented a view on history that many today have yet to think about.
This course was generally very good. It is easy enough to get a good grade, but to get anything out of it you have to put in the work.
This is hands down my favorite course at Princeton.
Very interesting class, you appreciate it more if you take 1920-1974 first
Very politically slanted and opaquely graded. Kruse's lecturing is not as good as his reputation makes it seem. Not a terrible class, but there must be better ones out there.
probably not worth taking for general interest, but still interesting enough if looking for a history class
stay up on your reading!
take it!
prereqs: None.
descrip: The history of contemporary America, with particular attention to political, social and technological changes. Topics will include the rise of a new conservative movement and the reconstitution of liberalism, the end of the divisive Cold War era and the rise of an interconneted global economy, revolutionary technological innovation coupled with growing economic inequality, a massive influx of immigrants coupled with a revival of isolationism and nativism, a revolution in homosexual rights and gender equality coupled with the rise of a new ethos of "family values."

title: Introduction to Atmospheric Sciences
reviews: Fueglistaler is a very helpful professor and makes time to assist his students. Take his course, but make sure to reach out if you need help!
descrip: An introduction to atmospheric sciences. This course discusses aspects of weather and climate both from a phenomenological and analytical point of view. The course balances overview lectures (also covering topics that have high media coverage like the "Ozone Hole" and "Global Warming" ) with a few in-depth analyses of selected aspects. The lectures are complemented with homework based on real data, demonstrating basic data analysis techniques employed in atmospheric sciences.

title: Ethics of Persuasion, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Modern Brazilian Literature - Machado de Assis
descrip: This seminar will focus on the work of Machado de Assis (1839-1908). Through the analysis and discussion of recent criticism we will be able to perceive that some of the most interesting social issues of contemporary Brazil can be found in Machado's plots, thus raising questions about the relationship between literature and society, writing and politics, center and periphery.

title: Should the Mob Rule? Democracy, Crime and Punishment
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Projects in Vocal Performance - Baroque Solo Cantata
reviews: Definitely recommended. Final concert at the end makes the class worth it!
Request more feedback about baroque style if you're not as familiar with it. It is not really much of a master class since we are learning the pieces each week.
Take the course!
Take this course!
This course is very informative and fun.
prereqs: Enrollment by audition. Date TBA, late April. Please check Music Dept. website..
descrip: A master class format one 3-hour meeting per week. Student singers work with student keyboard players and selected student instrumentalists on Baroque solo cantata repertoire. Students rehearse outside of class and are coached by teachers in class. Final concert in January, 2013. Open to singers, keyboard players, string players and selected wind players.

title: Muscle/Memory: Sculpture
prereqs: This course is by open enrollment - no prerequisites needed.
descrip: Students in VIS 300 will create sculptures that relate directly to the body and compel performance, interaction, and movement. Students in the associated DAN 300 will create dances that are informed by garments, portable objects and props. The two classes will come together periodically to compare notes and consider how context informs perceptions of sculpture as performance and the body as object. A lecture series of prominent choreographers and artists will accompany the courses.

title: Readings in African American History
descrip: This course is designed to introduce graduate students to the literature of African-American History, from the colonial era up to more recent times. Major themes and debates will be highlighted. The course should help students to define interests within the field to pursue further study and research and also to aid preparation for examinations.

title: Honors Linear Algebra
reviews: If you're interesting in majoring in math, you should obviously take this course. I'd probably recommend MAT204 to physics majors, but I definitely think the general ideas presented in this course are more useful than the computational things learned in the other Linear Algebra courses. This was a good course -- take it if you think it will interest you.
Pretty good class.  Easier than MAT 215.  If using Lax, try to find another book like Hoffman and Kunze
descrip: A rigorous course in linear algebra with an emphasis on proof rather than applications. Topics include vector spaces, linear transformations, inner product spaces, determinants, eigenvalues, the Cayley-Hamilton theorem, Jordan form, linear systems of differential equations, the spectral theorem for normal transformations, bilinear and quadratic forms.

title: Intermediate Modern Greek
prereqs: HLS 102 or permission of instructor.
descrip: To improve the students' oral and written skills and introduce them to themes in the Hellenic tradition through readings in Modern Greek literature.

title: Creative Writing (Fiction)
reviews: A course that everyone should try out during his/ her Princeton career. Very enjoyable, not too much work but definitely intellectually stimulating and rewarding.

A very awesome class!  Take it if you enjoy creative writing in the classroom setting, can tolerate constructive criticism, and would like a PDF-only class.  The workload is very easy/appropriate if you are a fast writer.

As I've said, this was absolutely one of my favorite classes at Princeton. While the subject matter and the workshop format set up the makings of a great course, what really transformed this one was the professor's guidance. Take CWR 203 with Susan Choi if you can!
Being able to take one of these courses is a wonderful opportunity, no matter who your professor is. Don't waste it! Get to know your prof!
Choose Prof. White if you're taking creative writing, you wont regret it!
Come in with an open mind and a willingness to write!
Consider a different teacher. The quality of the course varies greatly from professor to professor.
Creative Writing - Fiction is fantastic for anyone interested in improving their writing technique. But your overall experience with the course will depend on which professor you take.

Definitely take this course if you're interested in writing fiction. Professor Choi is just amazing -- encouraging, witty, lively. Everyone generates a lot of great writing and the classroom atmosphere is laid-back.

Every workshop is different. JCO has been doing this for a long time and has a really well-designed progression of assignments to help you learn about writing.

Her feedback is at times spare but very smart and worthwhile. Discussion is for some reason always awkward. In part because JCO has such strong and confident opinions, kids feel like they don't want to contradict her. Towards the end, the amount we all had to read of each other became so much that not everybody had done it, which didn't help.
Give time to doing the readings, it definitely gives you a lot from the class.
Hope you can sign up for his section.
I highly recommend this course to all students, and especially to those who are looking for a fun PDF or won't pursue Creative Writing but who still enjoy it.
I would definitely recommend this course and Susan!
I would definitely take the opportunity to explore yourself as a writer and take this course. Edmund White is kinda and helpful. It was a great class
I would definitely take this class, or any creative writing class before graduating!
I would encourage anyone interested at all in creative writing to apply and take this course.
I would recommend this course to a student interested in working on short story writing.
If you are at all interested in creative writing, I would highly recommend this class.
If you're interested in creative writing, this is an amazing opportunity to study with an incredible writer - and, perhaps even more importantly, an incredible teacher.

Joyce Carol Oates is an amazing professor, and an inspiration to any aspiring writer. With one word she can change how you see yourself and your talents. For example,  She told me that I had the potential to write comedy. Taking her suggestion, I put my nose to the grindstone and studied comedic writing and wrote and wrote as much comedy as I could. My comedic voice improved. My confidence in my writing improved. In fact, I started publishing for the school's comedy magazine. When I published my first article, I felt the itch and soon became the most published freshman author in the magazine. I then set my sights on joining the Triangle Writer's workshop (the group of comedy writers who write Triangle's musical every year). I applied, worked hard on my pieces as I had learned from Creative Writing class, and was accepted. Because of a few words of encouragement Joyce Carol Oates gave me , I changed my entire identity on campus. And I've never been prouder.
Make sure you put in effort! It may be a PDF class, but don't take it just because you want an easy P--take it because you want to grow as a writer.
Must take! Especially from Professor Lee!
Prof. Gilmore is kind of crazy, and she's not afraid to be very blunt about what she thinks, but you will be a better writer at the end of the semester.

Professor Choi is very kind - if you're looking for more honest/hard-hitting feedback, I would suggest maybe another professor. She is however very nurturing, and allowed me to find my voice in a supportive environment.
She's a pretty nice person and pretty funny too. Just do your best on all the assignments - it's worth it to try, and not to BS the course just because it's PDF
Spend time writing your pieces! This is a class where procrastination truly is a detriment and you will be embarrassed having people read work that you know is bad.
Spread your work out.  Don't leave stories to the last minute.
TAKE IT!
TAKE IT!! YOU WILL ALWAYS REMEMBER IT AS THE BEST CLASS OF YOUR LIFE.

TAKE THIS COURSE. Colson Whitehead is funny, clever, and most importantly, honest in his criticisms. He's not afraid to give you his opinion, even if no one else agrees with him (which occasionally happens). He's definitely a student of the form, and he's got a lot of very important and valuable things to say about it, so pay attention!

Take at least one class in the creative writing department!  The pressure is low (P/D/F only) and it is a great way to rekindle an interest in writing as a hobby if you've had to set it down for schoolwork, demanding extracurriculars, etc.  The only caveat I would add is that there might be more work than expected: three 7 -page short stories over the course of the semester, weekly mini short stories based on a piece of assigned reading, and weekly response letters to the two or three students whose short stories are being critiqued in class (like freshman writing seminar).  But such homework is fun--just don't do it the night before class!
Take it
Take it if you are even remotely interested in writing.
Take it!
Take it! It is wonderful and reminds you over and over again why you love learning and creating.
Take it! Profesor Oates is an amazing teacher and her comments are very helpful.
Take it! Put in a lot of time to your stories, you will get a lot out of it.
Take it- Professor Whitehead is chill but gives honest criticism
Take it. Take it if you need an LA, take it if you don't, it's just a fantastic class, fifth or otherwise.
Take this class!
Take this class!!! The assignments are all extremely fun and you'll end up greatly improving your writing.

Take this class. Susan Choi is the most amazing professor ever. She gives you the freedom to write about whatever you would like while still giving you instruction on how to improve it. She facilitates great class discussion. Take it!

Take this course if you enjoy writing, but also if you don't mind writing under pressure (in my class we wrote a 1-2 page creative response every week, and submitted three manuscripts). After a while it became quite a slog for me, and I am not sure if I enjoyed that. Also doing the readings and responding critically to your peers' work takes time too, especially if you want to do it well. It is quite time-consuming even for a PDF class. But if you do, it's very well taught.
This class has no busy work, it's all learning, and I looked forward to class all week.

Whether you're a seasoned creative writer or a just looking to try it out, take it.  But don't be fooled by the PDF-only option--if you give this course the time and effort it deserves, it won't be an easy fifth class.
take it!
prereqs: Please visit the Lewis Center Creative Writing website for application information..
descrip: The curriculum allows the student to develop writing skills, provides an introduction to the possibilities of contemporary literature and offers a perspective on the place of literature among the liberal arts. Criticism by practicing writers and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature.

title: Structure of the Stars
reviews: Don't wait until the last day to do your homework, and you'll be fine with that. But watch out for the papers. 10-15 pages is a lot in emulateapj format, and you'll want to start on those several weeks in advance.
Necessary to take, and you know..
Start on the papers a few weeks before they are due.
Stellar physics is an important subject in astrophysics. Take this class if it's your departmental requirement.
descrip: Theoretical and numerical analysis of the structure of stars and their evolution. Topics include a survey of the physical process important for stellar interiors (equation of state, nuclear reactions, transport phenomena); macroscopic properties of stars and their stability; evolution of single and binary stars; mass loss and accretion of matter; and accretion disks. Emphasis is given to numerical modeling of various types of stars.

title: Introductory Sculpture
reviews: Everyone should take this course. It offers a completely different way of thinking and it can inform your academic work in ways you never could have imagined. It is more of a conceptual class than a handicrafts class, so come in with an open mind and ideas. If you participate you can get more out of this class than a class that is in your major.

I would definitely recommend this class to other students. The only downside to this course is that it demands extra time out of class to work on projects; if you don't have enough time/commitment, your projects (and grade) will suffer.
If you want to stretch your mind take this course
Take this class. Stop reading reviews and sign up now.
descrip: A studio introduction to sculpture, particularly the study of form, space, and the influence of a wide variety of materials and processes on the visual properties of sculpture leading to the development of an understanding of contemporary sculpture and a basic technical facility in wood working, mold making, coasting and metal working.

title: Introduction to Latin American Cultures
reviews: Go for it, but know that it's not going to be the Latin American classics.
I enjoyed this course because of the professor - he helped to make the material fun.
I would really recommend taking this course, though it is almost exclusively about literature rather than other forms of "culture"
Keep in mind that it is a literature class!
Meet with the professor before/while writing essays for this class.
Proofread all essays!
Take it! Prof. Guerrero is excellent and the readings are great and you can explore themes however you see fit, both in class and in your papers.
Work hard on the readings and participate in class.
prereqs: SPA 207 or higher, or instructor's permission..
