descrip: This course offers an introduction to modern Latin American literature and culture. It focuses on the complex ways in which cultural and intellectual production anticipates, participates in, and responds to political, social, and economic transformations in the 20th and 21st centuries. Through a wide spectrum of sources (essays, fiction, poetry, film, and art), students will study and discuss some of the most relevant issues in Latin American modern history, such as modernity, democracy, identity, gender, memory, and social justice.

title: Nonlinear Optics
reviews: The combination of fundamentals, current research, and open research questions along with Prof. Fleischer's background in physical analogy to other fields (including advanced financial modeling) make this course much more relevant than it would seem. Take it

Very mathematical course, but this course will teach you both about the fundamentals of nonlinear optics as well as some of the new research. Jason is a great lecturer and can paint wonderful analogies to help you understand. He clearly knows his stuff very well and takes the time to prepare lectures.
prereqs: ELE 351 or ELE 352 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: Introduction to nonlinear optics, second harmonic generation, parametric amplification and oscillation, the electro-optic effect, third order nonlinearities, phase-conjugate optics, photorefractive nonlinear optics, solitons.

title: Behavioral Finance
reviews: Audit.
Be aware of the master's project when choosing this class.

Be careful about taking this course. You will have to have a strong math background to do well because they (including the preceptor) will not teach you any of it. However, the struggle is worth it! The course is very rewarding intellectually, and will change worldview.
Don't take the course for a grade. Audit the lectures and you'll get 95% of the value without wasting your time on the useless problem sets.
Don't take this course on a full schedule.
Good class, but be prepared for a masters project that can eat up at least an entire month, leaving no time to study for exams.

I would recommend against taking this course. The material and lectures are good, so perhaps auditing it is the way to go. However, there was a lot of tedious HW, a long paper due during exams (for grad students), and the exams had very little partial credit so your score was a little arbitrary. Additionally, the preceptor was unresponsive, cancelled a majority of precepts, went missing during office hours, and didn't grade anything in a timely manner.
I would strongly recommend this course to other students.
If you don't mind annoying assignments, take it for the quality of the lectures.
Interesting but very self directed in terms of learning how to do assignments and study for exams.
Take ECO362 beforehand and then take this. This one cannot be missed.
Very good course but be prepared for the workload.
prereqs: ECO 562 recommended.
descrip: Traditional economics and finance typically use the simple "rational actor" model, where people perfectly maximize, and efficient financial markets. We will present models that are psychologically more realistic than this standard model. About 30% of the course will be devoted to economics, 70% to finance. Applications to economics will include decision theory, happiness, fairness, and neuroeconomics. Applications to finance will include theory and evidence on investor psychology, predictability of the stock market and other markets, limits to arbitrage, bubbles and crashes, experimental finance, and behavioral corporate finance

title: Passive Aggressive Diplomacy: US-Latin American Relations
descrip: This seminar surveys US-Latin American diplomatic relations. The focus will be on old or recurrent historical myths and disparate perspectives on the nature of hemispheric links. Key Cold War crises will be reviewed, specially as they affect the present. Topics covered: The Clinton, Bush, and Obama administrations' approaches to democracy, security, and economic policies; and new issues in relation to the larger emerging countries (Mexico and Brazil) and Andean governance in the context of the current crisis of globalization and evolving crosscurrents of power in the international system.

title: Viruses: Strategy and Tactics
reviews: Course material can pile up if you don't attend to it regularly, but if you do so, you will be well rewarded, since the course material is incredibly fascinating.
Definitely take it! It was my favorite MOL class and is really interesting because it is very applicable to every day life.
Do the "Did you get it?" questions each week if possible. You can get away with doing them all before the exam, but they are time-consuming and are more helpful if completed before hand.
Go to the lectures and watch the videos.

If you are interested in biology, this is a very solid course.  No infuriating course snafus, and the instructors are quite helpful and keep the slides updated.  I'm keeping my textbooks from this class for future reference - it's good stuff!  Even for cocktail parties.
One of many decent but unimpressive MOL lecture classes. Precepts are unusually bad.
One of the best courses I have taken at Princeton. Professor Enquist is a great lecturer. The material is interesting and manageable. You should take it.

Please take this course. Please read Prof. Enquist's course guide at the beginning of semester and follow it to the letter. It changed the way I study for biology and how I understand the field. And at the end, make sure to thank Prof. Enquist because he's a special Professor.
TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT
Take it!
Take it.

You should take this class because Prof. Enquist is an awesome lecturer, and it shows how devoted he is to virology. You should take this class if you are interested in viruses, immunology, or more broadly, any molecular biology. A strong background in molecular biology courses is definitely recommended. Prepare to memorize all the slides if you take this class.
prereqs: MOL 342 or MOL 348 or Permission of Instructor. No courses in the biological sciences or other departmental courses may be taken pass/D/fail by molecular biology concentrators..
descrip: Viruses are unique parasites of living cells and may be the most abundant, highest evolved life forms on the planet. The general strategies encoded by all known viral genomes are discussed using selected viruses as examples. The first half of the course covers the molecular biology (the tactics) inherent in these strategies. The second half introduces the biology of engagement of viruses with host defenses, what happens when viral infection leads to disease, vaccines and antiviral drugs, and the evolution of infectious agents and emergence of new viruses.

title: Microeconomics Theory Workshop
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Inverse Methods: Theory and Applications
reviews: Ask questions.
Take it!

This course is quite involved and specialized and is not an introductory level course. There are other courses which offer introduction to inversion techniques on a very basic level. But if the student is willing to delve into the details of these techniques then this is definitely a good course to take.
To ensure that they review the fundamentals of the methods as soon as they are introduced. It is too easy to get lost and fall behind if you dont understand.

You should definitely choose it. David is really a great lecture who conveys the mathematics so clearly that you don't need to spend large amount of time go over the formulas after the class. And the contents you learn from this course--MCMC, Kalman filter==are so helpful and advanced.
You should have a background in linear algebra and probability.
prereqs: Multivariable calculus, linear algebra..
descrip: Course treats inverse problems from both theoretical and applied perspectives. Students learn to develop the necessary theory to pose, interpret, and solve inverse problems, focusing on topics including error characterization, linear and non-linear methods, approximations, Kalman filters, use of prior constraints, and observing system design. Concepts are illustrated with examples from the current literature on the Earth's carbon cycle.

title: Junior Seminar in Critical Writing
reviews: Absolutely take this course!
Absolutely worth it for the context of being in London in conjunction with a hopefully well-crafted seminar topic by the advisor that works with the abroad context.
Bring a lot of your own discussion questions to class, and don't be afraid to email the professor for clarifications.
Definitely take it if you have a choice of junior seminars. Interesting material and Prof. Brooks is really knowledgeable and entertaining. Try to do as much reading as possible.
Don't worry if you know nothing about poetry and, instead, put that energy towards enjoying reading and thinking about the poems!
I probably wouldn't have taken this course if it wasn't required of an English major.
I would advise another student considering taking this course to go for it, but to keep in mind that a lot is expected of him/her and that he/she must take all the readings seriously.

I would recommend Professor Kotin as a junior advisor.  He is very good about meeting with students and offering guidance and feedback.  When choosing your junior seminar, try to pick a topic you are familiar with and would be interested in writing a JP on. Some Junior Seminars are more broad in topic and some are less broad.  For example, there was a seminar on death and one on new american poetry.  If you like neither topic, there are still many more possibilities for a JP to relate to death than to be about New American Poetry.

If you don't mind actually doing the work asked of you, taking a seminar with Professor Anderson is a great experience. While her standards are high, she is also kind and understanding and makes sure that the work, when done, pays off.
It's probably one of the best junior seminars in the English department. The night class element is annoying, but I would say worth it.
Professor Anderson is always ready to meet with you to help you on anything, or just for a great talk -- take advantage of it!
Recommend.
Sign up for this seminar!
Some weeks, you will have to make sure to start the readings immediately in order not to fall behind.
Take advantage of office hours.
Take it!
Take it, at least for the professor.
Take it.
Take it.  Even if you don't like jazz
The more engaged you are, the more you'll get out of it!
There is a lot of reading
This class is great, and more importantly, Prof. Anderson is great.  If you can't take this class, try to take another one of hers before you graduate.
Yes.
You should definitely take a course from Professor Chaudhary. He is a wonderful professor and will improve your writing and reading processes.
avoid
read ahead, have interest in the readings before committing to this course. Prof Kotin is a nice guy, he is very passionate about the class which makes the seminar better
descrip: Students learn to write clear and persuasive criticism in a workshop setting while becoming familiar with a variety of critical practices and research methods. The course culminates in the writing of a junior paper. Each section will pursue its own topic: students are assigned according to choices made during sophomore sign-ins. Required of all English majors.

title: Introduction to Condensed Matter Physics
reviews: I think that students from the chemistry department should take the undergrad level class.
I think this course is great, if you want to have an overview of whatever's happening in Condensed Matter Physics. You are taken all the way up to very recent discoveries.
If you have taken a solid state physics course before, this is not going to give you many new things.
It is better than the grad condensed matter physics class I took at MIT. More systematic, and covers more interesting topics.
It's an interesting class and if you want to do CM then it's a must. Not too hard for undergrads either!
N/A
Read Kittle first before this class
You can learn the basic techniques but don't expect too much on physical inspirations.
good as an introduction to condensed matter physics
descrip: Electronic structure of crystals, phonons, transport and magnetic properties, screening in metals, and superconductivity.

title: Fundamentals of the Geosciences I
reviews: You don't really have a choice in the matter, so take it.
You get out of this course what you put into it. It isn't a lot of work, but you can learn a lot if you are willing and able.
none
descrip: A year-long survey, in sequence, of fundamental papers in the geosciences. Topics in 505 (Fall) include the origin and interior of the Earth, plate tectonics, geodynamics, the history of life on Earth, the composition of the Earth, its oceans and atmospheres, past climate. Topics in 506 (Spring) include present and future climate, biogeochemical processes in the ocean, geochemical cycles, orogenies, thermochronology, rock fracture and seismicity. A core course for all beginning graduate students in the geosciences.

title: Practice Teaching
prereqs: Admission to the Teacher Preparation Program is usually required. Application for fieldwork placement must be made in advance. Completion of Pre-professional portfolio..
descrip: Supervised practice teaching (a minimum of 12 weeks) in a secondary school. Teaching is done under the supervision of an accomplished teacher and a program staff member who regularly observe and discuss the student's practice teaching. Students gain firsthand experience in developing teaching strategies, planning and implementing instruction, assessing student learning, and classroom management. Must be taken concurrently with TPP 401.

title: Topics in Logic and Foundations - Transfinite Numbers
prereqs: Undergraduates must obtain permission of instructor.
descrip: This course covers topics in Logic and Foundations. More specific topic details provided when the course is offered.

title: Topics in Music from 1600 to 1800 - Music and Theater Handel's London
descrip: The seminar will examine music and theater in London in the first half of the eighteenth century, with a special focus on the works of Handel. Topics to be considered include: Italian opera, ballad opera, and spoken theater; patronage and commerce; research resources and databases on 18th-century London; music and the visual arts; performance practice; manuscripts and print culture. Participants will also have the opportunity to prepare an exhibit on Handel for the Firestone Library in anticipation of the meeting of the American Handel Society (February, 2013) and present their work in a pre-conference symposium.

title: Master's Project I
descrip: Under the direction of a Bendheim affiliated faculty member, students carry out a master's project, write a report, and present the results in the form of a poster or an oral presentation in front of an examining committee.

title: Intensive Korean I
prereqs: KOR 103 and KOR 108 are designed as a year-long sequence. The credit for KOR 103 will not be given unless it is followed by KOR 108. Students who have completed both courses will be considered to have fulfilled the language requirement equivalent to completing 2-year study of a foreign language..
descrip: The first part of Intensive Korean is designed for heritage students who have already had considerable amount of exposure to the Korean language and culture but have not received any formal instruction before their arriving at Princeton. It covers the 1st Year Korean material focusing on vocabulary building, grammar, reading and writing. The students who have successfully completed KOR 103 and KOR 108 will be placed in the 3rd or 4th Year Korean if they wish to continue.

title: International Relations
reviews: A good survey of IR theory and literature. Carter's class leans on the more quantitative side of things so if that is how you think his IR is especially for you.

A pretty bland, too-simple survey course. It's easy to fall behind and stop caring because there are only 2 papers and 2 exams. Lecture slides matched up exactly to the textbook - which resembled my AP Human Geography or Comparative Government textbook, but was perhaps even more simple than that - and Prof. Carter just read off of them. The worst part, however, are the exams, which also match up exactly to the slides and are painfully simple, meaning that the curve will be killer, probably worse than the likes of PSY 101.
Carter says it's not important but read the textbook. You won't get the basics you need to understand the readings / papers just from lectures.
Don't take it unless you must.
Great course as an overview of international relations. Lectures could be better.
I hear the class is better with a different professor. Do NOT take this with Prof. Carter, it's awful.
I would choose a different POL/WWS class. The material wasn't really hard, but not worth learning about stuff that you learn about in other classes anyways.
I would recommend this, and push students to keep up with the readings.

If international relations are interesting to you, take this course - it really nails down the basic concepts. Don't expect to be super engaged, however, as Prof Carter is not the best lecturer. Make sure to know examples for concepts for exams.
If you are interested in international, this course offers a broad survey of various IR policy theories.
If you have a strong interest in international relations, I think this course will be very enjoyable. However, if you are simply looking to explore the field of IR, I would look elsewhere.
It is an okay course. It doesn't do much in terms of really preparing you for anything like an IR major but it sets the foundation for a little bit of elementary knowledge.
It's what you would expect.

Keep up with all of the reading. It is very easy to fall behind. Also, come up with the topics for your papers early. The preceptors are willing to give feedback and you will have more time to research.
Make sure you keep up with the articles/textbook reading assignments!
Maybe.
Only grades are papers and exams, focus on those.
Professor Carter is solid but sometimes rambles. Paper requirements are ridiculous.
Provides a broad background of IR, but nothing special.
Stay on top of the readings, especially the book. That was the most helpful in this course.
Take it if you are interested in IR, but avoid otherwise as lectures would be awful.

Take this class if you think you are interested in international relations. This class provides a good overview. I took this class with Professor Carter and the reading amount is a little less then my other classes, so I would say it was very manageable. Though the lectures can drag, do attend them seeing as Professor Carter does sometimes cover terms that do not appear in the readings but that are tested on exams. Papers and exams are also quite manageable.
Take this course if you are interested in the basics of international relations.
Take this course with David Carter, it is a breeze.
Try to get a basic idea of all the readings.  Even if you don't have enough time to do all of them, take 20 minutes before class and get the main ideas.
Yes.
do the readings
descrip: This course is an introduction to the causes and nature of international conflict and cooperation. We critically examine various theories of international politics by drawing on examples from various historical eras as well as across security and economic affairs. Topics include the causes of war, the pursuit of economic prosperity, the sources of international order and its breakdown, and the rise of challenges to national sovereignty.

title: Proseminar in Basic Problems in Psychology: Cognitive Psychology
descrip: Cognitive Proseminar: Introduction to graduate level cognitive psychology and cognitive neuroscience for first year graduate students in psychology. Course serves as the basis for more advanced graduate courses on specific topics in this area.

title: Politics of Inequality and Redistribution (Half-Term)
descrip: Study of policy preferences, differential rates of political participation, voting behavior, legislative process, political communication, urban politics and role of race in US political life are central to study of inequality in politics. Though the American case will feature prominently, we will approach issues from a comparative perspective. Thus the course provides introduction to comparative study of welfare states and political economy of advanced industrial countries, including regulation of labor markets and relationship between wage inequality, income distribution and policy preferences for redistribution and social protection.

title: Moral Conflicts in Public and Private Life
reviews: Absolutely take it if you have the opportunity. As with any seminar, the quality largely depends on the other students in the section. I was fortunate to have a really great group of people to talk with, and Macedo does a good job of facilitating.
If you're interested in the overlap of ethics and public policy, take this course.
It's a great course! Good readings, great professor, and if the group does the readings, great discussion!

This was a great class! Professor Macedo is great and so willing to help.  The weekly debates intimidated me at first, but once you get used to them are quite fun.  I took this class with no firm basis in the area and I did not take Ethics and Public Policy and was totally fine.  Take it if you want a relaxed seminar and a chance to discuss some of the ethical issues in the course description.
Work hard!
Worth taking to engage in debate with other Princeton students.
descrip: The distinction between public and private spheres of life is both foundational to modern liberal democratic politics and also fraught with controversy. This course examines such conflicts in the context of political theory, ethics, law, and public policy, including the tense interface between public values and religious conscience and practice, and the scope of freedom with respect to marriage, family, and sexual relations. How broad are the claims of private liberty and what is the nature and extent of legitimate public authority when it comes to activities claimed to be private? Can paternalist and perfectionist policies ever be justified?

title: Wittgenstein
prereqs: At least one previous philosophy course desirable; see instructor if you don't meet this requirement.
descrip: Ludwig Wittgenstein, often regarded as the most influential philosopher of the 20th century, left us two very different systems of philosophy, one in his early book Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus, and another in his posthumous Philosophical Investigations. The two works are among the most original, difficult and rewarding philosophical writings. They deal with highly theoretical questions about the nature of language and thought, the relationship between the mental and the physical, and other topics. This course will look at key passage from both books. Students should enjoy abstract thinking and the challenges of difficult texts.

title: Women in American Theater: Doing Gender, Race, Sexuality Onstage and Off
prereqs: Department Distribution: Modernity.
descrip: Addresses the history and theory, practices and polemics, of women working in American theatre and performance. We concentrate on contemporary examples, and theater's role in the struggle for women's visibility advanced by 1960s and 1970s American feminism. We'll study women playwrights, solo performers, collective theatre companies; delve into feminist, queer, critical race, and performance theory; and host guests currently practicing in the field. Our conversations will be polemical: What is the future of women's work in theatre?

title: American Revolutions
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Introduction to Moral Philosophy
reviews: A good course to PDF.
A very good introduction to moral problems in philosophy, and to the study as a whole. Compelling questions and complex ideas make this a good starting place.

Absolutely take it with Professor Smith, he is a funny and clear lecturer. If you are new to philosophy as I was, a good preceptor is invaluable to iron out the nuances and help out with the novelties of philosophy paper writing. Get Daniel Wodak if you can!
Absolutely take this course, even if it isn't your forte. It will help you learn to argue and it will improve how you think about morality.
An easy class to take, and with the PDF option it's completely stress-free.
An excellent liberal arts class that will change how you think without an inordinate amount of work. Be prepared to be challenged with high expectations on the papers, though.
An interesting topic. Your preceptor will make all the difference
Be prepared to read dense material. Learn how to write a philosophy paper...know the expectations beforehand.
Be prepared to spend the beginning of the semester learning about the definition of "morality" rather than commenting on it.

Complete all readings, and if you feel yourself slipping behind, get help quickly.  The course does not necessarily provide much of an intro for very first-timers, therefore, it is important to stay complete assignments and reading.
Definitely go to lecture; Prof. Smith is excellent at explaining the material in new and interesting ways, and it will definitely help come exam time.
Definitely take this course!! Perfect for an intro to philosophy
Definitely take this course. The topics that are covered surround our everyday lives. The course really exposes you to the historical discourse of philosophy and its a great way to fulfill an EM.
Do all of the readings!
Do all the readings as the lectures go.
Do the readings and attend lecture.
Do the readings.
Do the readings. Lecture is not necessary, but it is certainly worth attending.
Do the readings; you'll regret it if you dont.
Doing the readings is more important than going to the lectures. If you have to pick one, pick the readings.
Don't believe others when they say it's an easy course.
Don't take this course unless you really like philosophy
Don't take this course.
Go in to the course with a genuine interest and curiosity. Be ready to think deeply and go to the lectures!

Go to all of the lectures! They are great and probably the most important thing for the exam. Take weekly notes on the readings. The readings are very short, so do all of them even though they are dense! This is an excellent introductory course for anyone who is interested in ethics, especially current ethical dilemmas like abortion, euthanasia, etc. One of my favorite courses at Princeton -- don't think twice about taking it!
Go to class and precept.
Go to lecture and take notes!
Go to lecture. Professor Smith is really good at clarifying readings that seem difficult to tackle. Also, use the preceptors--they are there to help.
Good intro course. Not too much work and interesting material.
Great learning experience about a field of academia rarely understood.  Not difficult.
I recommend to anyone considering this class reading all of the assigned works.

I took this course out of interest and was not planning on PDFing it (it was not intially PDFable). But I did poorly in essays since I am not much of an essay writer and the course was not as interesting as I hoped it would be. It was sufficiently interesting and has a medium workload as a PDF class though.
I would advise them to take this course as a PDF, and if not then be prepared to work extremely hard.
I would definitely recommend this class.
I would encourage students to show up to lecture because they are extremely helpful in understanding the material
I would highly recommend this course. Do the readings! Although you can usually get by without, you'll get much more out of lecture and precept.
I would really recommend doing the readings for this class.
I would recommend this course, to anyone who is interested in philosophy or wants a relatively easy em
I would recommend to freshman who want to have practice in critical thinking
I would strongly recommend this course to anyone interested in taking an introductory philosophy course.
I would tell him to go through every reading thoroughly in order to clearly understand each lecture and precept.

If Michael Smith is teaching this course, I'd highly recommend it. His lectures make all the readings very clear, and the assignments are very fair and manageable as long as you devote some time to them. Excellent course for anyone with an interest in philosophy.
If you are interested in Philosophy, this would be a great intro.

If you have even the slightest interest in moral philosophy, this is the class to go for, although you need to be able to sit through hour-long lectures--which can be very passive. Take a higher level class if you want greater discussion time.

If you need an EM or you'd like to try out philosophy, this is a pretty good choice. Not very demanding in terms of work, and you get an introduction to the levels and branches of moral philosophy. Take it!
If you take this course, make sure you go to all the lectures and pay attention.
If you're legitimately interested in gaining knowledge from the course, be prepared to slog through a good bit of readings, but otherwise the course is a fairly interesting, easy B

If you're looking for an EM, I would definitely recommend this course. I have no real complaints about it. It may be difficult to get an A because there are so many students, but I'm not sure (as I haven't seen my grade yet).
Intro to Moral Philosophy is a very hard class. There is a tremendous amount of reading that lecture does not cover, and Professor Smith is not well organized.
Listen in lecture, ask your preceptor questions, and study for the final.
Look at the readings to determine if you want to read them.

Make sure you attend every lecture and precept, because they really help you in understanding the readings. Also, make sure you look up a few examples and guidelines on writing philosophy papers before you start to write your first paper.
Only take this if you are particularly interested in moral philosophy.
Professor Smith is great, the workload isn't bad, and the material is really interesting. Great course
Readings are important. Take notes, and ask questions, but it's really not too demanding
Readings aren't that important, but definitely work with your preceptor to make sure you understand concepts and how to form an argument.
Really great. Take it!
Spend a lot of time going to your preceptor as soon as you're given the essay prompt so you can figure out exactly what you need to do. Lecture notes are pretty much all you need from the lecture.
Start early on the papers.
Start essays as soon as they are given, Go to lectures if think its worth hearing Smith,  I though it was.  Sample all preceptors because they will be the key to succeeding in the class.
Take advantage of office hours/preceptors while writing papers.
Take it as a PDF unless you are a philosophy major.  The subject matter is very interesting but the papers are dry and it is extremely grade deflated.
Take it for an easy distribution that is taught well.
Take it for the distribution requirement. It's pretty good, and quite informative.
Take it if it's Professor Smith.
Take it if you want a PDF that you actually want to attend and learn something from. Great course
Take it just to experience something new, but don't expect an easy A.
Take it with Michael Smith-- he is an amazing professor and makes the subject matter much more manageable and interesting.
Take it with Smith! It opens up a whole new way to look at the world!
Take it! it's not too bad workload-wise and is interesting.
Take it, and at least go to the lectures.
Take the course if you want to.
Take the course if you're somewhat intrigued in philosophy or a major in philosophy. Even though I did not have the best experience, I would still recommend the class.
Take the papers seriously and talk to your preceptors about them.

Take this class if you want to learn about philosophy from the ground up. It is a good introduction to the subject, but I would recommend an additional PHI class (seminar, different material) to get a full grasp on the entire department.
Take this class only if you can get through dense long readings. But the subject matter is very mentally attractive.
Take this class, whether or not you have to.
Take this course if you're interested in ethics. You should be prepared to write complex papers. Keep in mind that the final is pretty straightforward.
Take this course only if you are extremely interested in philosophy.

Take this course! Professor Smith is a great lecturer, the precepts are helpful, and by the end of the course, you will have developed a good sense of understanding of the ideas of major moral philosophers as well as critical thinking skills.
Take this course, even if for a PDF. The lectures are truly amazing, and you get a framework for thinking about a lot of contemporary moral issues.

Take this course. It is hard to have a coherent moral view in this confusing world, but this course will lead you well on the road to clarity. However, do not adopt philosophical views just because they sound rational. I fell in love with Prof. Smith's genius and clarity (and his accent, oh my gosh! I want to run to Australia right now)

The beginning of the course might be frustrating because Professor Smith organizes it in such a way that the material of first lecture is material that you will understand only weeks later. Furthermore, given the breadth of the subject, most topics are covered superficially, but the information provided in class is more than sufficient for the essays and test. Finally, make sure to take precept with Michael Smith. He will really make the class shine.
The material can take a while to adjust to, especially if you are new to philosophy. Attending lectures is probably the most crucial component to doing well/getting something out of the course.
The readings are boring but Professor Smith is a great lecturer. The papers are not fun to write but the grading is fair.

This course is a good course for anyone looking to get a broad overview of moral philosophy. I would caution those not looking to major in philosophy, however, to think again about taking this course. It was not really set up in a way that gave students a good introduction to the discipline of philosophy itself. A lot will be on you to develop your own skills. This may hurt your grade at first, and later, if you do not "catch on."
This course is a good course to fill the distribution requirement.  Lectures are clear and the readings do leave you thinking.

This course is amazing. I'd recommend it to people who want to study philosophy or to those who are just curious about ethics. With any luck, it will change the way you think about things (which is very valuable!)
This course is awesome but only take it if the subject matter is interesting to you.
This course is full of interesting readings and topics of discussion, but be prepared for some dense and fairly lengthy readings.
This course provides good general coverage of a lot of controversial topics. The lectures are often very one-sided but the reading make up for what the lectures lack.

This course should be mandatory for every Princeton student.  Take this course freshman year--it will greatly improve your writing in terms of being more concise and persuasive. Excellent lecturer (M. Smith)
This course was well taught, but the subject mater made it hard to stay interested, and I eventually ended up just PDFing this class

This is a great course if you're sincerely interested in philosophy, but not a good one if you're not. It's more technical and less general than I thought it was going to be (which is good in some ways but also tedious in others).
This is a very interesting course, but a significant amount of work if you want to do well. Philosophy papers are also very different from any other kind of writing, something I was not prepared for.
Though it's always fun to hear Prof. Smith speak, this course is just too disorganized. I didn't really learn anything. If you want a easy d.r. then take it because it does not require much work.
Very interesting but not at all easy.

Very interesting topic - you go through some of the most relevant readings of moral philosophy, period. The reading list, while engaging, isn't all, though. Make sure you take this course with a good professor, and try to shop around for a good preceptor.  I was lucky with both and absolutely loved the course.
Well-taught class, although I found that philosophy was not really my cup of tea.
You don't have to take intense notes during lecture. Just know the main ideas.
You have to be ready to devote a big chunk of time to the class if you want to do well.
definitely take it, possible with Jack as a preceptor. Go to all the lectures, and actually do the readings.
dont get behind in the readings.
spend time on papers
prereqs: Course open to freshmen..
descrip: Can questions about what is right or wrong have real answers independent of any sort of divine authority? Are there moral principles that any rational person must recognize, or is morality essentially an expression of our feelings or a product of our culture? Are we morally required to do our part in making the world as good as it can be, or does morality give us permission to pursue our own peculiar enthusiasms and interests? What should we do about deception, unwanted pregnancies, and world hunger? This course will provide an overview of these and other issues in moral philosophy.

title: Colonization and Spaces of Urban Modernity: Readings
reviews: I would recommend this course to others.
Prepare to read a lot of theory.
Take it if you want some theory allied with wonderful narratives.
descrip: A seminar that examines theoretical and historical literature on urban modernity as a process of colonization of space - colonization both in the sense of territorial conquest and as an exercise of power to colonize and configure social space.

title: Tonal Syntax
prereqs: MUS 205 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: MUS 206 begins by making relevant connections between the modal counterpoint of the 16th century (studied in MUS 205) and tonality as it evolved in the 18th century. Fundamental tonal concepts will then be explored in later music including Chopin and Brahms.

title: Roman Art
reviews: Take it!
Try to keep up with the readings, but the key is just to pay attention in lecture. If you do, you're set; the course is interesting but not overly demanding.
descrip: The course provides a general introduction to Roman art. It discusses various artistic media--portraiture, historical relief, etc.--and highlights important works. The goal is an attempt to understand the significance of the imagery that the Romans produced, and which embellished all aspects of their world - that is, to understand the role of artworks in the Romans' lived experience.

title: Geochemistry
descrip: A review of the chemical composition of Earth's major realms, the governing processes, & their temporal evolution. This course will examine the origin & chemistry of the solar system; chemistry of the core, mantle, and oceanic crust, and continental crust; the origin and evolution of the oceans and atmosphere, the modern cycles of nutrients, carbon, and O2; and weathering. These topics will be reviewed through the prisms of the theory of the origin of the solar system, geodynamics, biogeochemistry, stable isotope geochemistry, and radiogenic isotope geochemistry.

title: Combustion Theory
descrip: Theoretical aspects of combustion: the conservation equations of chemically-reacting flows; activation energy asymptotics; chemical and dynamic structures of laminar premixed and nonpremixed flames; aerodynamics and stabilization of flames; pattern formation and geometry of flame surfaces; ignition, extinction, and flammability phenomena; turbulent combustion; boundary layer combustion; droplet, particle, and spray combustion; and detonation and flame stabilization in supersonic flows.

title: Japan Anthropology in Historical Perspective
descrip: The course considers Japan studies in the context of theories of capitalism, personhood, democracy, gender, and modernity. We will be discussing issues of fieldwork as method and "area" as a unit of analysis. We will also consider the place of Japan in American social thought.

title: Socialist Realism
descrip: The course will examine the historical formation and existence of Soviet socialist realism as a method of representation, theoretical platform, and cultural reality. Apart from prominent critical statements and secondary scholarly literature, it will consider a number of works from the fields of Soviet literature, art, and cinema. It will seek to understand socialist realism both in the broader context of European modernism and in the native Soviet context of social transformations, political prerogatives, and ideological sanctions. Lectures and discussions in English, readings in both English and Russian.

title: The Renaissance in England - Community, Communion, and the Commons
descrip: What was Communion, during the tumultuous era of Reformation? Course begins by tracing the striking changes in the sacrament of the altar during the first half of the sixteenth century as well as the related poetic and philosophical developments. It looks closely at the manifold connections between communion and community as well as to that which communities are supposed to hold in common. Beginning with the earliest Reformation writers in England course follows developments and experiments in communion, community and the commons through Herbert, Crashaw, and Winstanley to Hegel, Marx, Nancy, Negri, and Irigaray.

title: Race & Ethnicity (Half-Term)
descrip: An overview of important theories and theorists of race and ethnicity, that exposes students to fundamental concepts and equips them for subsequent independent study. The primary focus of the Race/Ethnicity Field is: 1) to understand the nature and persistence of race and ethnic identity as meaningful social groupings in contemporary society, and 2) to explain the social significance of these group identities - that is, how these groupings are related to social stratification, to socio-cultural relations, and to the political and economic dynamics in a society.

title: Behavioral Finance
reviews: A fantastic course that teaches a new way to think about finance.
Definitely a course to take to get ideas about independent work!

I think this course is more geared towards graduate students focusing on economics. This course is very research oriented, so take it if you want to do more with behavioral finance than just learning what it is.
I would recommend it for students who are interested in the topic.
Only take if you're deeply interested in finance.

Problem sets will take up most of your Thursday nights and Friday mornings. However, all of the problem sets are based on models derived either in the course readings of one of Hong's papers on his website. If you can find the relevant paper with a little Google-fu, you can save yourself hours of fumbling around in the dark.

The homework can be very tedious and the final exam was the hardest exam I've taken at Princeton. That being said, this was an absolutely amazing class taught by Hong which you probably could not experience anywhere else. Definitely my favorite econ course so far.
preceptor wasn't very helpful but professor is fantastic. Professor has great sense of fashion.
take to have a realistic understand of the financial markets.
prereqs: ECO 300 or ECO 310 required. ECO 310 and ECO 362 recommended..
descrip: Traditional finance typically considers that financial markets are efficient because investors are rational and maximize their expected utility from consumption. This course departs from this view and discusses how inefficiencies arise due to psychology and limits to arbitrage. The psychology of investors shapes their preferences and may impair their judgment. Whether these psychological factors have an impact on financial markets ultimately depends on arbitrageurs' ability to fight against mispricings. These issues will be covered through lectures and class games and will allow discussions about cognitive illusions and speculative bubbles.

title: Second Language Acquisition and Pedagogy
descrip: Readings and discussion in classroom application of SLA theory. Focus on quantitative as well as interpretive analysis. Primary audience is the current teaching staff of GER 101, but others are welcome. In English.

title: Topics in the History and Theory of Architecture
reviews: If it was an option to not take this class, I would say do not. Unfortunately, all architecture majors must. I only hope the department considers this evaluation, and the evaluations of my fellow classmates (most of whom share the same sentiment), and appoints a different professor to lead the course in the future.
Take your topic search and the weekly assignments very seriously from the very beginning! Attend writing workshops and set up office hours appointments.
This class is very fun and interesting. The only reminder I would give is that independent research needs to be going on the entire course, even when there are assigned class readings.
Use the assignments to your advantage... try to develop your thesis each week.
You get what you give.  Put your best foot forward because Lucia has this course organized for you to develop the best thesis that you can.
You have to be proactive in order to get the attention you need within this large seminar.
you have to take it. it's too late to turn back now.
descrip: We will consider that a successful thesis entails the meeting of a socio-cultural problematic with a specific disciplinary issue, that the confluence and exchange between these external and internal situations can instigate an original contribution to architectural knowledge and technique. The "newness" of this contribution comes through a particular kind of repetition, a wily swerve within the established canon. The seminar will introduce disciplinary methods and themes through close readings of architectural texts and objects and will provide a workshop for the testing and elaboration of architectural polemics through directed research.

title: Introduction to Movement and Dance
reviews: Aynsley's enthusiasm really made the class special and a space of free thought and movement removed from the stress of Princeton life.
Be prepared to try new things and don't be afraid to be yourself! That's really all this course asks of you.
Def Take it
Do it. No question. If you're even a little bit curious, just take the class. By far the best class I've taken here.

Even though this is a P/D/F I ended up putting in a lot of extra time for this course. Not because it was required, but because I loved it so much. It is absolutely wonderful. Most rewarding class I have taken at Princeton.
If you have any interest, take it.  Youll fall in love with dance.
TAKE THIS CLASS...by the end of the semester you will be so surprised by how much you have learned about yourself.
Take it! Love it! Enjoy it!
Take it! Very stimulating class, and a ton of fun.
Take it!! it was an awesome 5th class. I only wish I walked away with more sophisticated dance moves, but I did get more confidence in the way I currently dance which is always a good thing.

This is a great course! Don't be scared if you haven't had prior dancing experience- this class is structured so everyone will get a lot out of it. This is a very broadly applicable class. It will get you thinking about art and creativity in a new way. You will acquire a new appreciation for movement. Seeing how many different modes of motion there are will get you thinking about how you move in different situations. You will also be poised to get a lot out of dance performances which you see, because you will acquire a framework for interpreting them.
Try to attend every single class -- you won't regret it!
descrip: Designed for people with little or no previous training in dance, the class will be a mixture of movement techniques, improvisation, choreography, observing, writing and discussing. Students will investigate their own movement patterns and delve into many facets of dance and cultural questions surrounding it. We will explore the role of dancer, choreographer, audience member, and critic in relation to such topics as aesthetic questions, politics, identity, religion, and complex views of the human body.

title: Social Organization of Cities
descrip: A review of the historical emergence and social evolution of cities and urban life. Course presents current theories regarding the ecological and social structure of urban areas, and how urban social organization affects the behavior and well-being of human beings who live and work in cities.

title: International Trade
reviews: Find a friend in the course that you can study with if you want to get the most out of this, and take advantage of the preceptor because in a small course, they can do a lot to help individuals.

Good class. Go to precepts (obvious, but surprisingly few people thought to do so). Very few problem sets (3 total). First half very theoretical while the second half is much more grounded in real data (if that impacts your decisions).
prereqs: WWS 300 or ECO 300, or ECO 310.
descrip: This course analyzes the causes and consequences of international trade and investment. We investigate why nations trade, and who gains from trade. We then study the motives for countries and organizations to restrict and regulate international trade and study the effects of such policies on economic welfare. Topics covered will include the effects of trade on economic growth and wage inequality, multinationals and foreign direct investment, labor migration, international trade agreements and current trade policy disputes.

title: Psychology of Gender
reviews: Be prepared for questions derived solely from the textbook. Do not be easily offended. Consider the perspectives of all participants of a given interaction.
Do not take this unless you are really interested. Not particularly great.
Don't miss any of the psych studies you have to go to.
Easy and interesting psych class.
Especially good class for psych majors looking for departmentals.  The material overlaps some with other courses.
Fun class. Not too much work.
Good class. Take it. Keep up. Go to office hours.
Good for an easier departmental
Great course- highly recommended.
I would definitely recommend taking this course.

I would definitely recommend this as a class you should take if you're interested in learning more about how gender affects things we wouldn't necessarily expect, but it may be a difficult first psychology course.

If you are looking for a fun and interesting class, that will challenge your beliefs on the issues surrounding gender, this is a great class. If you are looking for a class to make you feel better and hopeful because "research shows things are getting better", this is not that class.
If you are open to it, this class will blow your mind.

If you want to be in a class where you feel like a third grader, take this class. You'll learn that people think women are weak, that people think men like sports. Duh. The material was just mindnumbingly boring. Maybe thats just psychology as a discipline though. It's so obvious. 

Thought this would be an easy but interesting class.  It turned out to be so easy I didn't care at ALL.

If you're really into gender, go for it (particularly if you are in to feminism). If you are a guy, I'm guessing you might feel a bit attacked, and if you are more interested in psychology than gender perse, try another course.
Interesting class, but a tad bit too much work if you are planning to PDF. Would definitely recommend to anyone interested in being a psychology major.
Interesting material - great class to PDF.
It was an interesting course, though there was a lot of overlap with other psychology classes I've taken.
It's a nice course to take if you have a heavy workload because it is interesting but not time-demanding

It's interesting, and Professor Brynildsen is very good about answering questions and clarifying the material in class as well as over email. It made me think about how these issues apply to my life. I'd definitely recommend it as a departmental, and also if you have an interest in gender differences.
Not a good class. Take it only if you really care about the subject matter.
Pay attention to the lecture slides and study the study guide. Go to precept and ask questions if you don't understand the material.
Pretty easy EC.

Really great course to take. It presents practical information that prevalent to everyday life. Professor B. is a really good lecturer and she is also really nice about helping students and answering questions. Good class to take if you have a heavy workload in your other classes. But do read your notes for exams, and the book is good as well. Good luck!
TAKE IT
Take if interested in gender.
Take it if you're interested in gender psychology.
Take it! Best course I've taken at Princeton. Or at least top 3.
Take it! Interesting material for an EC and not too demanding.
Take it! It's not a ton of work, but it's really interesting material, and Keiko is a great lecturer. Try to get in Andreana's precept if you can.
Take it--it's not demanding and it's fairly interesting.
Take it.  It's easy.  But it is painfully biased, stupid, and irrelevant.

Take this class if you need an easy EC or a science distribution for a GSS certificate.  I would try to get a different professor than Brynildsen though since she never seemed all that together and you don't get anything more out of lecture than what's in the textbook.
Take this course if you are interested in gender differences between men and women.  However, it gets very redundant and at times seemed like pure common sense.
Take this course.  It is a straight-forward and interesting EC and the professor is very nice and approachable.

The lectures are more important than the readings, so concentrate on them when you are studying, and the study guides were very helpful.  Make sure you take your time on tests because the question wording was very tricky.

The only reason why this class ended up being okay is because the topic is interesting.  But - you're better off just reading a text book by yourself.  Unless you're looking for any easy class to fit into a busy schedule, don't take this course.  It's a waste of an opportunity to actually feed your brain.
The textbook isn't necessary for the course. However, going to the lectures is. Also, taking notes must be by computer - it is a fast-paced course.
This class has fun material and is not too difficult, but it is not the most engaging.
Very interesting course that is extremely well planned and well-run.
great class
take it if you have any interest in gender studies. gives a great perspective of the issues we face today and the progress we have made
yes, it's a good introduction to the psychology of gender
descrip: Gender is a topic with which everybody feels intimately familiar. Indeed, people hold strong beliefs about how women and men are similar to and different from each other and about why gender differences exist. This course holds those beliefs up to scientific scrutiny, examining major theories and empirical findings in psychological research on gender. Topics include empirical comparisons of men and women, gender stereotypes and their perpetuation, and the role of gender and gendered beliefs in interpersonal relationships and physical and psychological well-being.

title: Image and Imagination
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Advanced Creative Writing (Literary Translation)
prereqs: This class is available for 300-level credit, by application only for any student who has previously taken two 200-level workshops in the Creative Writing Program. Students must have a fluency in a language in addition to English. Applications must include 3-4 pages of either original literary translation or original work from their previous workshops. See the Creative Writing website for application information. Please note this course cannot be audited and is not open to Freshmen..
descrip: Advanced practice in the translation of literary works from another language into English supplemented by the reading and analysis of standard works. Criticism by professionals and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature. Students MUST be fluent in their chosen language.

title: Graphic Design
reviews: Great course on typography if you're interested. No previous experience required, and David is very helpful and approachable.

If you are at all interested in graphic design (typography specifically) be sure to take this. Gives you an appreciation for the nuances in the world around you. Great experience learning to typeset using metal type.
If you're interested in typography and like doing hands-on projects, take it.
Take it if you're interested in typography--and don't mind spending 6-8 hours of your week setting type.
Take it! It's a lot of fun.

Take this! Even if you don't think of yourself as a design person or a studio person. As long as you're willing to put in the time, you will find it interesting, rewarding, and totally different than any other class you'll take at Princeton.
descrip: This studio course introduces students to graphic design with a particular emphasis on typography. Students engage typographic history through readings highlighting major shifts in print technologies. The readings provide the substance of studio assignments: students begin in the typography studio with letterpress printing and metal type, proceed to photo-typsetting and mechanical paste-up, finish in the computer lab using industry-standard typesetting and page-layout softwares. This course develops a synthesis of hands-on graphic design skills with a vocabulary and critical framework for speaking about them.

title: Introductory Photography
reviews: I would recommend taking this course if you don't mind spending money to buy a film camera. The class supplies the film and chemicals required to develop and make prints, but everything else must be bought.
Take it if you are interested in photography otherwise don't, you will be wasting the professors time.
Take it if you're looking to open your photographers' eye
descrip: An introduction to the processes of photography through a series of problems directed toward the handling of light-sensitive material, camera, and printing. Weekly laboratory sessions will explore the critical issues of the medium in relation to both student work and the work of guest photographers. One three-hour class and approximately three hours of independent laboratory.

title: Intermediate Studies in Acting: Scene Study II
reviews: Take this class! Especially if Mark is teaching. He is a very valuable resource and a great teacher.
This is one of the best classes you will take at Princeton, if you love theater and acting!
prereqs: THR 201 and Program Director's permission. Please contact Professor Tim Vasen (tvasen@princeton.edu) for enrollment permission..
descrip: A continuation of THR 201: Guide students in ways to develop a role and to explore important texts and characters in an imaginative and honest manner.

title: Intermediate Hindi
prereqs: Elementary Hindi 101 and 102 or the professor's permission..
descrip: Building on HIN 102, this course will focus on expanding Hindi vocabulary, mastering more complex grammatical structures and acquiring idiomatic expressions. There will be an equal emphasis on all skills (speaking, listening, reading, and writing). Aspects of the target language culture will be integrated with instruciton. Activities will be conducted in Hindi and classes will be intereactive.

title: Problems in Early Ottoman History
descrip: The seminar is a study of the origins and development of the Ottoman state. The emphasis is on the characteristic features of its cultural, economic, and social life, as they were developed in the eastern Balkans. By retracing the establishment of Ottoman rule in Northern Greece it will examine the nature of Ottoman Administrative practices in the 14th and 15th centuries.

title: Taste & Disgust
descrip: This course will examine constructions of the beautiful while also exploring its supposed opposite, the disgusting. Philosopher Immanuel Kant declared that the only objects impossible to enjoy aesthetically are those that incite feelings of disgust. What's so special about disgust? How does this ugly feeling work, and what are its political and aesthetic uses? Does disgust always say "no!" to its object, or might it sometimes say "yes"? Case studies drawn from 19th- and 20th-century literature, painting, and film; topics include the sociology of taste, beauty and the sublime, purity and taboo, stigma and abjection, and limit experiences.

title: Polymer Rheology
prereqs: Multivariable calculus, differential equations, some familiarity with polymers and fluid dynamics, problem-solving ability commensurate with junior-level engineering courses..
descrip: A systematic development of the principles and applications of the science of rheology with an emphasis on the development of stress-velocity constitutive equations. Vector and tensor mathematics and Newtonian fluid dynamics are reviewed. Develops the physical and mathematical nature of stress and deformations in materials. Covers the use of theory and application of rheological equations of state.

title: Economics and Politics
descrip: Focused on analytical models of political institutions, this course is organized around canonical models and their applications. These include: voting models, menu auctions, models of reputation and cheap talk games. These models are used to explain patterns of participation in elections, institutions of congress, lobbying, payments to special interest groups and other observed phenomena.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Economics and Ethics: Social Justice and Policy
descrip: The course presents the economic concepts involved in the evaluation of the socio-economic effects of public policies. It shows how concrete measures and indicators are grounded on ethical principles. It is organized around central ethical debates: Is there an efficiency-equity trade-off? Are there legitimate inequalities? How much priority should be given to the worse-off? Are interpersonal comparisons of well-being impossible? Why not maximize happiness? Should we discount future generations?

title: Religion in the Public Square
descrip: This course investigates the role of religion in a pluralistic modern democracy. The questions that we will consider include: Is it legitimate for government officials to act on the basis of religious convictions? Should citizens invoke God in political discourse? May religious organizations engage in political activism? The readings focus debates in contemporary political philosophy and political theology, including selections from John Rawls, Jurgen Habermas, and John Milbank, among others.

title: Planning Theory and Process
descrip: Introduction to the theory and practice of planning. Analysis and discussion are devoted to planning models, planning decisions, and alternative planning roles. Focused study of comprehensive and strategic planning, community participation, new urbanism concepts, equity concerns, and planning at local, regional, and state levels.

title: Memory, History and the African Diaspora
prereqs: Previous coursework in AAS recommended but not required..
descrip: This course uses historical scholarship, memoir, visual art, fiction and music to examine the relationship between "history" and "memory" and the different ways that race and social power have shaped that relationship in the U.S. and across the African diaspora. It considers the role played by acts of remembering in struggles for justice and self-determination, as well as the place of forgetting and erasure in processes of exclusion. We will link representations of the black past to debates on such issues as public memorials, legal justice, reparations, and affirmative action.

title: The Supreme Court and Constitutional Democracy
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Elementary Chinese I
reviews: As someone who began taking this course having taught myself Chinese for about a year, I would say that the majority of what I learned in this course was grammar. I already had a knowledge of around 700 characters, which made each week's new words much easier to commit to memory, as I often knew more than half of them. The homework for this course usually didn't take me more than around a couple of hours per week. For someone who is coming into this course having absolutely no knowledge of Chinese, I would say that it is definitely going to be time-consuming. If you are really motivated to learn, then you should find this course enjoyable and rewarding. For people who take the extra effort outside of class to engage in conversation with other students who know Chinese, or to attend Chinese tables, you will find that you will progress faster and find the course more manageable. The teachers are very accessible, approachable, and dedicated to tailoring their teaching method to each student. I would recommend that you take advantage of the opportunity to ask questions, attend individual sessions, and get to know your teacher. For a beginner, this course is very intensive, but certainly worth it for someone who aims to speak Chinese well.
Be prepared for the time commitment and intense workload.

Be prepared to work a lot, but if you are interested in Chinese, it's definitely worth it.  Don't let the characters get away from you, though, because trying to learn a week's characters in one night is extremely painful.
Be ready to work hard. Study a little Chinese everyday, this goes a long way in helping you be prepared for the weekly tests and recitations.
Chinese is a great language, really fun to learn, and the department is a blast. Only take it if you're willing to put in the work, but you'll be glad you did.
Expect to digest a significant amount of material every week. Even though you would be overwhelmed with the workload at first, it is surely worth it-!!
Get acquainted with the Pleco iPhone app to help with character drills. Don't let up on your study and review over reading period. The final is comprehensive and a killer.
Go to the language table as often as you can.
Good class
If interested in Chinese it is definitely a good course
If you are not a morning person, DO NOT sign up for the early morning sessions. Attendance COUNTS FOR YOUR GRADE.
It's a lot of work and you really need to spend a lot of time preparing and reviewing to keep up with the material. That being said, the program is really well taught and you learn a lot.
Just preview the next lecture the weekend before and constantly review!
Keep up with the work!
Make flashcards for all your characters.  That was how I learned best.  I'd also recommend writing out each dialogue in full to help memorize it before your recitations/dictations.
Make sure that you practice your speaking and do the readings. Learning the language and characters will take time, but it is worth it.
Make sure you learn the structures!
Many people say that Chinese has a lot of work load, but it is definitely manageable.
Nothing beats Princeton Chinese!
Only take the class if you're interested in learning the language.

Only take this class if you are genuinely interested in becoming fluent in Chinese, otherwise you will feel demotivated by the difficulty. If you want to become fluent quickly, this is the class for you.
Overall really well done and one of the best courses of its kind. Li laoshi is really enthusiastic, bright, and engaging!

STUDY EVERY DAY. If you don't, you'll wish you did. Otherwise, just relax in class, because the teachers are quite nice and understanding and you need to remember that they don't bite so there's nothing to be afraid of.
TAKE IT!!! It is a good amount of work but very rewarding. Classes are engaging and fun if you stay on top of your work.
Take it!  You really do learn how to speak Chinese.
Take it! Or be ready to regret over not choosing this course!
Take it! You will not regret it.
Take it!!! I have so much fun!

The course is relatively challenging, and for me, ate up a very significant chunk of my time, but then again i feel it was worth it. If you have no experience in the language or any oriental language, prepare to be challenged. Again, it was difficult, but worth it.

The course moves pretty fast, and you'll have to invest quite some time in it. But you'll have a lot of help along the way. Take readings, recordings, and one on ones seriously. Don't be afraid to speak up and imitate the sounds and tones of the language as best as you can. Speak up, be loud. You'll be corrected a lot, but trust me, it'll be worth it.

The small class size is definitely used to advantage, the learning for the most part personalized and made very fun and interesting. The class is not as hard as you'd think because the teachers are great, the quizzes (though plentiful) are very straightforward to study for, and the language is so fun to learn!
This class can be difficult, but one will never find a better language course, with more passionate teachers or a more well structured curriculum.
This class is a ton of work, but very rewarding.  Be prepared to work hard but learn a ton of Chinese!

This course has some truly wonderful people as teachers but requires a near ridiculous amount of work simply to survive. An average week may require about 3 to 4 hours per day in order to learn the material. It really is very difficult. The best thing about it though, is looking back and knowing how much work was put in and feeling good about yourself regardless of what the grade is because you know you worked extremely hard to receive that grade.

This course is very time consuming, in terms of amount of in class time, weekly quizzes and homework recordings, as well as regular written homework and memorization of passages for recitation. However, if you want a strong foundation in a language, all of the time you put in will pay off very well. There are also many resources on campus for additional help, and your instructors want you to succeed!

This is (one of) the hardest language course at Princeton. I know, because I took several. It is more time-consuming than a lab or a upper level course. Yet, it is very rewarding, because already after 1 semester I can hold basic conversations about a couple topics.
Write everything down in class. Everything.
You should take it.
You will learn a lot. Very satisfying course. It is an above average amount of work (lot of studying and memorizing) but I think it is worth it. Take it if you want to learn a language
You'll learn a lot of Chinese, and have fun doing it.
be prepared for A LOT of memorization and for really hard pronunciation. it will be a lot of work, but you'll get to know the language at a relatively fast pace.
it is a lot of work but really well taught.
take this class if you really want to learn Chinese because you can't half-ass it at all. but if you are interested, these are the best teachers i have ever had in my studies.
prereqs: No credit is given for CHI 101 unless it is followed by CHI 102..
descrip: An intensive introductory course in modern spoken and written Chinese, stressing oral-aural facility and the analysis of structure.

title: Satire: Mockery and Reform from Aristophanes to the Present
reviews: Be prepared to do or at least skim a ton of readings, although they're almost always enjoyable.
Give it a year or two to find its footing, maybe.
Give yourself a buffer on the longer readings.
Make sure to the main text that the class is going to focus on for the week - sometimes we didn't get to some of the more peripheral texts in much detail, so those might not be as important.
Pace yourself on the readings, break them up--it's a lot to do during one sitting. Meet with Prof. Ryzhik when she gives you the opportunity, because she's really helpful.
Take it, even if you're not really a humanities person. Satire is unique in that context matters very much, so it's more grounded in reality, in my humble opinion. It's a good class.
This course was good. If you're interested in the material and okay with reading a substantial amount of verse, you should take it. It's well-taught and interesting.

Very challenging and work intensive especially if you're background in English isn't very extensive, but also very rewarding and interesting if you like the subject material.  You'll definitely learn A LOT more than you're expecting!
descrip: The course traces the history of satire from Aristophanes to South Park, with a special focus on English satire in the Renaissance and 18th century. Narrowly defined, satire is a genre that ridicules human follies and vices in order to reform them. We will discuss the intent and efficacy of satire, the relation between satire and authority, and the role of the audience as target and participant. Required authors include Chaucer, Shakespeare, Donne, Jonson, Swift, Pope, and Byron. Materials for four open weeks may include American satirists (Twain, Bierce, Mencken), 20th century satirical novels, film, cartoons, stand-up, and academic satires.

title: Modern Brazilian Literature and Culture
reviews: I would recommend this class to anyone who wants to take a higher-level Portuguese class.
If you like modern literature you will love the class. Make sure you do the readings - they don't take that long - otherwise you won't be able to contribute or take much out of the class.
Pedro is a wonderful professor, and this class will give you a great introduction to the study of modern Brazilian literature.
Pedro is kind and wonderful. Take initiative to be really engaged and do all the readings, it will pay off.
Recommended - great for developing Portuguese and ideas about literary theory.
Take it only if very interested in literature and Brazilian literature in particular. Don't worry if your Portuguese is rusty - this course will help you work on it.
You should always take classes in the Portuguese department, they are the best on campus!
prereqs: POR 208 or POR 207B or instructor's permission..
descrip: A study of 20th- and 21st-century literature, this course aims at refining the students' command of the Portuguese language. It will focus on the blossoming of new narrative and poetic forms in Brazil. We will read authors such as Manuel Bandeira, Graciliano Ramos, Clarice Lispector, Luiz Ruffato, Adriana Lisboa and Ricardo Lisias. As part of the course activities, contemporary Brazilian writers will come to Princeton and give a workshop on their literary production.

title: Modern Latin America since 1810
descrip: Course examines interactions between states and citizens since Latin American independence with an additional consideration of the region's integration into global economic and political systems.

title: Comparative Ethnic Conflict
reviews: A great course to take if you are interested in the topic in general. No background in politics is necessary!
For POL majors: you might find this course a bit slow. The readings set a good base of knowledge in the area and lectures flesh that out a bit, but you probably won't be challenged much.
I really recommend this class. You ultimately have to do all of the readings but Professor Dancygier's lectures summarize every single one really well and help you understand them.
I would definitely recommend the course, but I would recommend keeping outlines of the readings throughout the semester.
I would say if you need a POL class, not a bad choice, however there are definitely better, more informative ones you could take.
I would strongly recommend this course, you learn so much and the material is really contemporary and interesting.
If you're interested in taking a politics course but are looking for something that's not your typical straight-up politics course, I recommend this class.
It's very reading-heavy and less concept-heavy, but I would definitely still recommend that anybody in comparative politics take this course!
Not an easy course, but interesting.
TAKE IT. Dancygier is a GREAT lecturer and the material throughout the course is fantastic. TAKE IT.
Take it if you really like the subject.
Take it, it's a great class, material is good.
Take this course!  It is incredibly fascinating.
Take this course! Not only does it give you a good understanding of ethnic conflict, it helps you see the different kinds of political theories that are used to make analyses.
This is a good course, not the most interesting, but a good comparative politics class.
Yes, certainly!
take it if you are interested in conflict
take it. doo the readings.
descrip: This course introduces students to the study of ethnic conflict. We will examine different theories of ethnically-based identification and mobilization; cover different types of ethnic conflict such as riots, genocide, hate crime and war; and study past and present cases of ethic conflict around the world.

title: Religion in the Americas Workshop
descrip: A weekly, year-long workshop focused on the current research of visiting presenters, current students, and faculty in American religious history. The workshop is designed primarily for Ph.D. students in the field, but is open as well to undergraduate concentrators with a strong background in the study of American religion and culture. Note: REL 523 (fall) and REL 524 (spring) constitute this year-long workshop. In order to receive credit and/or a grade, students must take the course both semesters.

title: History of Architectural Theory
reviews: Anyone who wishes to take any part in architectural practice/discourse must take this course.

Great course! If you are interested in architecture, this is a great overview of the more intellectual side of the discipline. It's a very "Princeton" architecture course. Don't worry if you aren't an ARC major, that will make it even more interesting.
I think this course is great if you're at all interested in architecture and would like to try it out.
If you are interested in architecture and want a detailed grasp on the history of the the disciplinary discourse. Take it.
Take it even if you already some theory background.
Take this course! but might be a bit out of range in difficulty for casual students that want to try out architecture.
