The readings will hurt your brain but understanding them will make you feel satisfied and enlightened in a sense. The ideas, albeit mostly architectural, could be applied to multiple fields.

This is a very challenging course but Professor Allais' lectures will be extremely helpful, so make sure to always go to lecture. What you get out of it will be be directly proportional to what you put in, so make sure to do the readings and pay a LOT of attention in lecture. If you've studied theory or literature before, take the class! Do not take this if you aren't interested in the inner workings of theory.
This is probably one of the best architectural history courses you can take at Princeton.
definitely take it
prereqs: Course open to undergraduate and graduate students. Of particular interest to art history, history, and architecture students. No prerequisites, but HIS 211, ART 333 and ART 322 are strongly recommended as background..
descrip: This course offers a history of architectural theory, criticism, and historiography from the Renaissance to the present, emphasizing the texts, media and institutions that have supported architecture's claim to modernity since the late 17th Century. Architectural thought is examined in its social and cultural context as it relates both to the Western philosophical tradition and to design method and practice.

title: Junior Seminar: Introduction to Comparative Literature
reviews: Be dedicated to the readings, and stick with them, even while frustrated! Your effort will be rewarded later. Also, do not wait until the final class to write papers. (I have to recommend this course for majors obviously, but if I could, I would probably recommend against it).
Do the reading twice.
Lot of secondary source readings.
Read the books carefully and take notes while reading.

Since this is the only specific course required for Comp Lit, it's a bit of a shame that it is also probably one of the Comp Lit courses that I've enjoyed least (given that I've normally been very happy with all the Comp Lit courses I've taken). I think the course's biggest problem is that it is difficult to create a course for all Comp Lit majors since we all study different languages and cultures. I think they've tried to make a course relevant to everyone, but in doing so, have made it relevant to almost no one.
Take it, you probably have to.
There isn't really a choice.

This course is as useful as you'll make it. Make sure to try to understand the readings as much as possible, and dedicating yourself to the task will be rewarding. It's also required if you're a concentrator.
You have no choice, it's required. Sucks to suck.
You have to take it if you're in the major (though debatable why), so...
descrip: This course will introduce concentrators to the discipline of Comparative Literature. It will draw upon both primary and secondary works to address four basic questions relevant to the field. How do dramas adapt to diverse cultural and historical contexts? What can an interdisciplinary approach reveal about lyric? How did the novel compete with other narrative forms? What does literature have to do with mass communication? The course will also focus on the preparation of junior papers and the eventual choice of a thesis topic.

title: 20th-Century Japanese History
reviews: Absolutely take this course if you have any interest in Japanese history.  Actually, take the course even if you don't--the course material is remarkably applicable even outside modern Japanese history.
I would recommend this class for students who aren't interested in it! The class is very student-friendly, informative and extremely useful.
I would strongly recommend especially for those who are studying Japan whether lit or history or religion etc.
descrip: Readings in Japanese political, social, and economic history. Topics include transwar continuity and change, political economy, labor, gender issues, culture and state, religion, Japanese expansion and colonialism, the Allied Occupation of Japan and "social management." Some readings in Japanese (optional for those who do not specialize in Japanese history).

title: Religion and Public Life
descrip: Presentation and critical discussion of research in progress by participants. Focuses on the use of social scientific methods in the study of religion and on applications of recently published work about religion and society. Includes an emphasis on religion and public policy in the U. S. and in comparative perspective.

title: A History of the World since 1300
reviews: Can increase lecture video speed. No need to read all readings in detail; can rely on precept introduction to know what's going on; then just think and talk. No need to go to global dialogues unless very interested in asking questions; can view videos online. Can ignore details and examples at first; can always look up when needed in writing papers. Only 1 week to write papers; better start immediately. Perhaps textbook is useful for revision.
Don't take it unless you are super internally motivated and will actually watch the lectures and not just walk away in the middle.
Great course, great teacher. Just the right amount of work and readings. And lectures are stimulating, although sometimes longer than the 50 min.
I am not pdfing it but it would be a great class to pdf. It's really not that much work.
I would say just try to make sure to keep up with the lectures if it's still in an online format next year -- it's easy to get behind.  I highly recommend it, though!
If it is online again, I would reccommend looking for another history course.

If this class remains as an online format, i would recommend to not take it. One of the main aspects of attending Princeton University is for the teachers, and i felt that i really had no interaction with Professor Adelman.
Keep up with the lectures and take notes on those. Focus mainly on the lectures, and use the textbook to back up your understanding of key concepts.
Make sure you watch all of the online lectures because it is easy to get behind.
Manage your time well, always start the papers a week in advance. Also, participate as much as you can in precept.

Obviously this class does not cover anything in depth, so don't take it if you looking to engage seriously with a historical moment/concept/etc.  However, Adelman is a great lecturer, and since all the lectures are online videos, you have a ton of flexibility.  The only problem is that Adelman doesn't give you the questions to the essays until a week before they are due.  The final take-home was 3500 words due on Dean's Date, and we got the questions a week before.  The grading was pretty easy though.  All in all an easy HA.
Take it!
Take this class! The lectures are informative and engaging. Precepts are interesting and helpful especially with Valeria as a preceptor.

Take this course. The format of the course next year will be changing from what it was this year, however, Professor Adelman is so excited about the material he teaches and it makes the world of a difference.

This course is fantastic and Professor Adelman is awesome. He is very engaging and very personable. He is a wonderful lecturer and really does a good job of promoting a global perspective of the world. The readings are not that long and they are very interesting as well. The textbook was by the best I have ever used, not just because of the information, but because it went in depth and provided arguments as well. The course material is very interesting and I would highly recommend this course.
prereqs: P/D/F option is not available for History concentrators..
descrip: An introduction to the history of the modern world, this course traces the global processes that connected regions with each other from the time of Genghis Khan to the present. The major themes of the course include the environmental impact of human development, the role of wars and empires in shaping world power, and the transformations of global trade, finance and migration.

title: Asset Pricing I: Pricing Models and Derivatives
reviews: Be active.
Be prepared to learn on your own, although asset pricing as a subject is worth pursuing.
Buy the textbooks to this course... it's much clearer than attending the lectures. A pity, because this course had the potential to be very interesting.
Do your own work.
Don't take it unless you have to (e.g. MFins), or unless it gets a decent textbook.
Get the recommended textbooks.
Good foundation course.
Good professor; interesting, foundational material; TA who didn't seem to care made understanding the material that much more difficult.
I recommend this course  for its content and the interesting insights provided by Pr. Brunnermeier.

I would recommend other students to keep track of the course slides as well as devote time to independent reading. Though the exams essentially focus on course slides, but given the high relevance of the Course concepts, its worthy to develop a very sound understanding of the concepts.
If you have previously taken a course in asset pricing, take the course. If not, good luck!
It is a core course !

Learn matrices before-hand.
Ask lots of questions. Especially when there are matrices on the lecture slides.  Prof. really does need to slow down and explain his methodology.  Don't worry, everyone else has the same blank look on their face as you.
No.
Print slides and correct all mistakes in class.
THE WORST I HAVE HAD IN YEARS. A TOTAL LACK OF RESPECT CONSIDERING THIS CLASS COSTS $4K.
This is a finance course with more of an economics flavor, rather than quantitative asset pricing course that deals with stochastic calculus and derivatives pricing.
This is a must to learn about asset pricing.
Try and negociate to avoid this course
Try to find some books to learn the material outside of lectures.
Yes helpful understanding of asset pricing techniques
good introduction at master level.
please read the book and learn by yourself
the homeworks are important since they highlight the relevant concepts of the class.
descrip: An introduction to the modern theory of asset pricing. Topics include: No arbitrage, Arrow-Debreu prices and equivalent martingale measure; security structure and market completeness; mean-variance analysis, Beta-Pricing, CAPM; and introduction to derivative pricing.

title: Contagion
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: The Russian Empire: From Peter the Great to Nicholas II
reviews: A phenomenal introduction to Russian Imperial history. Great course!

Especially if you have an interest in Russian history, this course could be very fascinating. The workload is not terrible, readings are interesting and lectures are very informative. Might be a little tedious if you are not too interested in Russian history. It was a small seminar and many of the participants were very much into Russian history and even spoke Russian - tended to dominate precept.
It says you don't need to speak Russia to take the course, but it's very hard to follow when you don't speak Russian.
Keep up with the readings- It's very, very obvious when you haven't done them.
Russia from the 17th-early 20th centuries was an exciting, intriguing place. Take this course if you'd like to begin to understand why Russia is what it is today.
This is a good course.  Not too tough.  I would recommend it with Kotkin, though, for I feel he'd be a more rousing lecturer.
This is a great introduction to Russian history.
This is an interesting and engaging class. I'd recommend pdf'ing it so you don't have to worry about doing well on the few graded assignments and can just enjoy the material presented.
Yes, I would recommend but only if you already find Russian history interesting.
prereqs: P/D/F option not available to History concentrators. No prior knowledge of Russian history or the Russian language required or necessary..
descrip: This course is a survey of Russian history from the late 1600s to the fall of the Romanov dynasty in 1917. During this period Russia emerged as one of the greatest powers in Europe and Asia. In 1917, it collapsed, and the first socialist state grew up on the debris of the former Empire. In this course we'll analyze the causes of Russia's enormous territorial growth and the reasons for its backwardness; explore why the Russian monarchy outlived other European monarchies and escaped the turmoil of the 19th century revolutions; and pay attention to the development of Russian art, culture, and intellectual life.

title: Topics in Greek Literature - Mothers and Daughters in Epic and Tragedy
reviews: A lot of work, but she really pushes you and your greek will get really good.

Excellent course to expand one's knowledge, both in regards to literature and  the general language. With two large quizzes, a final paper, and a prepared essay in conjunction with a final, it does demand a strong effort, however.
Take it, but expect to do a lot of independent work.
Take this course.

This is one of the best courses I have taken at Princeton, and I would strongly recommend taking it.  It is definitely challenging and requires a substantial amount of work to keep up with the texts, but this work is rewarded with fascinating and challenging class discussions.  Make sure you keep up with the text; I've also found it helpful to form small study groups to go over the texts before exams, as having a few people together makes it easier to clear up grammatical questions.  The secondary sources are really interesting, so make sure you take time to think about them and step back from the text.  This course is absolutely worth it.
prereqs: CLG108 or permission of instructor.
descrip: This course gives upper-level Greek students the chance for comparative, in-depth study of two canonical texts, each representing an important mythological mother-daughter relationship. The Homeric Hymn to Demeter examines the catastrophic consequences of disruption to the mother-daughter relationship and the possibilities for reconciliation. Sophocles' Electra is a study in the mother-daughter relationship gone wrong that culminates with the eternal virgin cheering on her mother's death. Together we will analyze how these works confront myth's family relationships, violence and social conflict, and narrative closure.

title: Arts of Protest
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Future Physics
reviews: Do not take this.
Don't take it. Or PDF it if you must. It's a good class to do so.
Great class for non-science majors. Highly recommended with Prof Meyers. Although some pointless assignments in the beginning, it gets very interesting!

I would not recommend taking this class if you aren't already familiar with the material or have a strong interest. Do not take it if you just want a distribution requirement! If you aren't very comfortable with quantitative concepts, ask yourself if you really want to spend an entire semester struggling with them (the course material is sadly very similar to the average high school physics course, although there are more interesting topics in the last part of the semester - like quantum mechanics and special relativity). 

Also, the instructors put a lot of time and energy into crafting a good course, so don't waste their time if you aren't going to care at all.
If you have any interest in physics but don't want to take 103, take this course.  That being said, I would still recommend 103, as it is more challenging by far.

If you need an ST, this is a great option. Meyers lectures were great. I thought it would be kind of a joke, but it was actually really interesting, fair, not too difficult, and a good use of my time.
Take it for an STL!

This class isn't for slackers. You still have to put in the work, and a lot at that. It's not such an easy course to PDF because there is weekly reading, pre-class assignments, post-class assignments, and full 3-hours labs (if you choose to do them). Some really cool and interesting material, but not as heavily non-science as it says it is. Calculations will be necessary. Get a good feel before you make your decision.
This class was so much more interesting than I initially expected.  We covered many interesting topics from a conceptual standpoint that made it accessible to anyone.
don't take it for a genuine interest in physics.
dont take it. too harsh of grader for a menial distribution requirement
if you are going to take this class, it is a ton of work so try not to waste a PDF
prereqs: Math skills at the level of high school algebra are assumed. No prior classes in physics or astronomy are necessary..
descrip: What do future leaders of our society need to know about physics and technology? The course is designed for non-scientists who will someday become our influential citizens and decision-makers. Whatever the field of endeavor, they will be faced with important decisions in which physics and technology play an important role. The purpose of this course is to present the key principles and the basic physical reasoning needed to interpret scientific and technical information and to make the best decisions. Topics include energy and power, atomic and subatomic matter, wave-like phenomena and light, and Einstein's theory of relativity.

title: Princeton Atelier - Movement Improvisation and the Choreographic Process
reviews: Even if you don't have dance experience, every student should take a class like this at some point.
Fantastic course - take it!
It's great! You should take it, especially if you haven't done much improv before or are interested in developing your choreographic skills.

Not sure if the exact same class will be offered again but definitely take a seminar or atelier with Susan! Also it's totally ok to take this course or a similar one even if you don't have a lot of dance background.

This course was very fulfilling and it allowed me to really push outside my comfort zones as both a dancer and a choreographer. I really enjoyed it and have learned so much about my dancing skills and abilities to solve choreographic issues.
prereqs: Students with strong/advanced dance backgrounds and an interest in working creatively and in collaboration are encouraged to apply. Students who have taken intermediate or advanced technique classes with the Dance Program may be qualified. Several spots will be available for actors with movement ability and strong interest. Application and interviews/auditions required. See the Princeton Atelier site at www.princeton.edu/arts/ for application and more information or contact Prof. Marshall..
descrip: Professor of Dance Susan Marshall and Toronto-based choreographer Sharon Moore will lead a course on movement improvisation and its uses in a choreographic process. Moore, a dance, film, circus, and theater choreographer/director is a master at leading artists through movement- and theater-based improvisation. Various improvisation approaches will be actively explored as choreographic tools and as ways to sharpen a dancer's performance and deepen the collaborative trust within a group. Students will work in small groups as Marshall's dancers and as collaborating choreographers of their own works.

title: Tragedy
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Elementary Korean I
reviews: Absolutely if you have any interest in Korean, take this class.
Do the homework no matter what. If you skip one day, you'll fall behind and not be able to participate in class.
GREAT class. Language isn't so difficult that it requires too much time. If you are interested in the language and/or culture I say go for it! Definitely recommended.
If you are interested in learning a language, I highly recommend Korean.

Korean is easier than you think--and it has a phonetic alphabet, so it definitely sucks up less of your time than Chinese does! So, if you want to learn Korean, don't let fear stop you from taking the course.
Take it if you are interested in Korean!
Take it!
Take it.
Take this class. Fun. Exciting. Informative. Easy as long as you do all the readings and hw.
Take this course if you're interested at all in Korean!! It's not too difficult and definitely worth it!
Take this course. It's probably the easiest East Asian language   it's very fun to learn.
This class is so much fun. It's a lot more low key than Japanese 101 was, but you still learn a lot. The teachers are so nice. If you're interested in Korean language or culture, take this!
This is an amazing language class with a lot of support.
Yun and Soh Seonsaengnim are great teachers and great people. It is a much easier class than Chinese, but you still learn a lot.
do all the homework assignments! participate a lot in class.
prereqs: No credit is given for KOR 101 unless it is followed by KOR 102. This is a 5 day a week course..
descrip: Elementary Korean is designed for beginning students who intend to build a solid foundation for further study in the Korean language. The course provides four balanced language skills - listening, speaking, reading, and writing - needed for basic communication. It emphasizes the ability to use Korean appropriately, and introduces students to useful information concerning culture and daily life in Korea.

title: Introduction to Materials
reviews: Don't be afraid by the large amount of material covered. Being confortable with thermodynamics is a plus.
Excellent class
Find a friend who knows mathematica if you've never used it before.

I started the course with the feeling it would be useless for me, a Structural Engineer, and I ended it glad I took it! It is a difficult class, but the material is very interesting and allows to view materials in general from a different perspective.
If you're in ELE and your research is relevant to materials (groups like Sturm, Wagner, Kahn, etc.), I highly recommend this course. You'll get a lot out of it.
If your research is related in any way to material science or nanotechnology, take this course! Professor Scherer is an amazing teacher and his lecture notes alone are worth taking the class for!
Know the thermo, because it won't go away.  Re-listen to the lectures ( I would recommend twice, once soon after class, and once before exams).
Listen to lecture recordings
Make a good use of the discussion board.
Read the notes before class so that you can keep up during lecture - Dr. Scherer blazes through the material!
Take this class
Very difficult but worth while.
be prepared to read a lot
pay close attention in lectures the first time around, and take the time to listen to the lectures again.
descrip: Emphasizes the connection between microstructural features of materials and their properties, and how processing conditions control structure. Topics include atomic bonding, crystal structure, thermodynamics, phase diagrams, defects, microstructure, diffusion, phase transformations, nucleation, coarsening, glasses, elastic and plastic deformation, fracture, sol-gel processing, sintering, and composites.

title: Advanced Microbial Genetics
prereqs: MOL 505 and 506.
descrip: An in-depth discussion of the genetic analysis of microbial systems, emphasizing examples from both prokaryotes and lower eukaryotes. The first part of the course features article-based discussions of the rationale, uses and limitations of advanced methods of genetic analysis, including suppression, synthetic lethality, and unlinked non-complementation. The remainder of the course consists of student led seminars on topics of current interest with the secondary aim of achieving proficiency in the public presentation of scientific seminars.

title: Junior Seminar - Violence in East Asia: Literature/ Film
reviews: It helps with writing your JP.

The junior seminar is required for EAS majors. The course is a good opportunity to meet your fellow majors, learn about their research, and gain some experience doing research in your language of specialization.
Well, it's a requirement, but the whole JP component really isn't too bad of a load.

You obviously have to take this if you are an EAS major. Be prepared to potentially zone out in lecture, and there's no way that you're going to manage all the extra course readings in addition to your other classes and your JP. The opportunity to discuss your JP with other students is great though.
You're taking this because you chose EAS. Good choice!
descrip: This seminar examines violence and its representations in the East Asian context. Students will explore the social and psychological needs for violence, and investigate various mechanisms of violence and their justification and perpetuation. Important literary and cinematic pieces, and their incarnations in the popular culture are to be studied diachronically and synchronically. The course also aims to trace the interplay between the East Asian traditions and outline how they draw and diverge from one another, from their history in the premodern period into their contemporary remixing.

title: Elementary Hindi and Urdu I
reviews: Fauzia is amazing. It's interesting, not too hard for a language, and super fun. If you're a senior especially--take it!
I would advise other students to definitely take this course. If you put in some time and effort, you will come out with a lot.
If Hindi interests you, then take it.
Study independently and learn the alphabets before you even start the class.
Take it, Fauzia is excellent and after just a semester, I feel comfortable conversing in basic Hindi.

This class is nothing short of amazing. Fauzia is a phenomenal professor, and she creates a great environment perfect for learning how to speak, read, and write hindi. I am a computer science major in the engineering department, so I was very hesitant to take a language. Apart from the fact that it meets so often, I was simply not required to take one. However, I am so glad I did, and I strongly recommend that you do too if you have any interest at all in south asian culture. If you don't have interest, I promise you that you will have great interest if you take it anyway :) This was by far my favorite class at princeton, and I looked forward to going to it every day. In fact, I never missed a single class. That was by far a first for me!

This was a great class. Fauzia is a wonderful teacher and the class is really fun as well as interesting. As a 101 class, you learn a lot but the work is very doable and also pretty easy. You will earn a good grade if you put in the time it requires.
Yes i would definitely recommend taking this course. The workload isn't that bad once you've mastered both scripts and it is a fun class.
descrip: This introductory proficiency-based course in Urdu-Hindi allows students to acquire linguistic skills in culturally authentic contexts. Hindi and Urdu share a basic grammar and core vocabulary but differ in their scripts and some cultural markers. Equal emphasis is placed on Hindi and Urdu, including writing systems, vocabulary, and culture. The course will focus on using language for genuine communication through a variety of activities. By the end of the course, students will be able to read and write both Hindi and Urdu scripts and communicate in a culturally appropriate manner. All classes will be interactive.

title: Computational Design
reviews: If you have the chance, take this course. It will make you a better architecture student and you will love the diversity of the computational design aspects that we touched on throughout the semester.
This is a fun class, you'll learn a lot, and you'll receive so much one-on-one attention. I'd take it even if it were not a requirement!
prereqs: Open to Architecture students based on seniority.
descrip: This course is an introduction to computational design using a range of techniques from NURBS modeling, simple programming and parametric modeling to basic digital fabrication. Through a series of computational exercises, presentations, and in-class discussions, we will investigate the evolving relationship between models of design and generative design issues of technology and culture in architecture.

title: Econometrics
reviews: A practical class to take for your JP, especially. The textbook is really good in helping you understand, while lectures can be dull and drawn-out.
Attend lecture
Definitely attend lectures and do the problem sets!
Definitely do all of the problem sets -- even though you can drop two, doing them helps with your understanding of course material.
I would only take it if you really like math or have to. Doesn't relate to anything in the real world much.
I would recommend this class even if you aren't an economics major.
If you are an ECO major... you don't have a choice.

If you are an econ major, then you have to take this. If you are not an econ major, I dont know exactly why you would want to take this, but if for some reason you do, this class isnt impossible. It will be work, and will be hard, but it isnt the absolute worst
If you must take it, don't dread it. It's not that bad!
If you're looking at this course, chances are you're an econ major and have to take it - that said, it is a good course and I would recommend it.

It is a challenging course (much more so than ECO 202) and the problem sets take up a lot of time. You don't have to buy STATA since it is on every cluster computer. I wouldn't take it unless you have to.
It's not unbearable. Quite easy so do problem sets!
Keep up with the lectures and work.
Lecture slides are very thorough, but the lectures themselves are hard to pay attention to.

Not a fun class, but you have to take it to major in econ.  If you're not in econ, there are more interesting classes out there.  If you are in econ, take this class and make sure to review lecture slides and read the textbook for things you don't understand.  I'm not doing the math track, nor am I very interested in stats, and I think I pulled a B without too many issues.
Not a great course
Not fun but not tragic.
Only take it if you are an econ major.
Only take it if you're an econ major
Read ahead and try to understand the lectures. I guarantee you you won't be able to pay attention for the full 80 minutes because its just too painful, but a worthwhile class if u need it.
Straightforward explanation. Fairly dry course, but definitely gets the job done on explaining econometrics.
Take it if you need it for ECO major.
Take it with Kirill! He will make what could be a boring and painful class much easier and more interesting.
Take only if an econ major
Take only if you have to.
Use the problem sets to study and understand lecture material, and office hours are very helpful for doing the problem sets.
Useful class- pay attention in lecture.
You have to take it if you're an econ major, so there isn't really any suggestion I can make. Study like mad for the exams and you'll be fine.
do the readings.
don't get behind on the material because it builds week to week.
keep up with the problem sets
only take it if you have to for departmental
pay attention
prereqs: ECO 202 (or ORF 245) and MAT 103.
descrip: Develop facility with basic econometric methods and the ability to apply them to actual problems and understand their application in other substantive course work in economics.

title: Classical Sociological Theory
descrip: The development of sociological theory through the early 20th Century with an emphasis on the problem of social order. Course begins with an introduction to the Enlightenment, followed by critical authors of the first half of the 19th Century (Hegel, Clausewitz, and Tocqueville). The central part of the course focuses on Marx and Weber with some attention to Mill, Durkheim, and Simmel. We conclude with consideration of some work in the early part of the past century (Freud, Elias, Frankfurt School).

title: Sociological Research Methods
reviews: A good course to take whether or not you are a sociology major since statistics are becoming more and more important in our world today.
Be sure to do the homework for the class and attend all the precepts.
Decently Easy QR
Definitely the easiest stats class on campus, and plus, it's a 300-level course while the others are 200. The homework load is pretty low too
Do not do homework the night before the test. Start earlier. And I think you will have a clue more if you don't skip lecture.
Don't  go to lecture.  Do the homework.  Study on your own time, and you'll be fine
Don't take it if you can avoid it.
Don't take it. Unless you have to take a QR or departmental stat. Then it's probably not so bad.
Go to precept and ask questions. read the textbook. do a lot of practice problems
Good - pay attention to the probability lectures, they are the most important!

I would think long and hard about taking this class if you don't have to.  There are better QRs out there with better professors.  It just seemed like a waste of time, especially if you PDF it.  You're not going to walk out with a conceptual understanding of stats, nor will you have had a great lecture experience.  Also, beware that the midterm is the hardest test of the semester.  Don't worry if you do badly on it, you'll bounce back.
If you are looking for a way to fulfill a stats requirement, definitely take this class.
If you dont have a good preceptor who explains the problems well, find someone else who can explain and teach you.

If you have an understanding of stats already, or can do basic algebra, or have written a lab report before, you will find this class to be quite boring. The book is well-written, but lectures and precepts just rehash the examples in the book.
If you need a stats course, this is a good one to take.
If you want an easy stats class and are willing to learn to use STATA on your own, take the class. But it's not a particularly worthwhile class.
If you want to learn simple statistics methods/math, this is the course for you. Easy peazy fresh and squeezy, no advice really needed.

If you're looking for an easy stats and not looking too get much out of it, this is the course for you. But make sure you stay on top of your work or else you could fall behind pretty easily (no curve).  I'd take it again but only for the stats credit, not to attain knowledge of statistics.

It does a good job covering the basics of statistics. If you are looking for anything with stata/computers, don't take this course. It's pretty easy overall, but if you do not intuitively understand the material you should really hope you get in Lynch's precept.
It's alright
It's easy but boring
Just read the textbook and do the homework.

Meet with your preceptor if you have any questions - they're really helpful, so take advantage! Do all the HW problems and make sure you understand both the ideas and the process behind each problem. Once you master basic processes you should be fine on the exams, since the questions all follow very similar patterns.
One of the easier stats courses available but do NOT underestimate the difficulty of the midterm.
Only take it if you have no other option, but it is the easiest Stats class if you're willing to teach yourself a little bit.
Pretty easy course; do the homework for the grade bump.

Previous knowledge of statistics is unnecessary, but make sure you have a good preceptor. Do the homework far in advance in order to do well on the tests, and try your best to do as well on the midterm as possible.
Read the book!  Lecture is not useful unless you read the book beforehand.  Do practice problems. Study hard for all the tests.
Stats can be interesting, but be prepared to put in a ton of your own work to actually develop a competency in the subject.
Take a different stats requirement if you can...psych stats or POL 350 are better options.
Take it--if you put in work you will do very well.
This course is easy for those who don't mind putting the time in to learn the material, read the book, and do the assignments.
This course is relatively easy if you are mathematically inclined, but some people struggle. The textbook and the lectures are almost identical.

This is a great course to take if you want to learn fundamental statistics skills. Most of lecture material is in the book, which is not hard at all. I recommend you to read the book beforehand and attend lecture to reinforce what have read. A manageable course load with Professor L., who is a good lecturer and at times, very funny. Good luck!
Try and get into scotts precept, he understands the material well.
Very easy QR, especially if you have any previous experience in stats.  The lectures tend to be repetitive.  I ended up teaching myself most concepts by doing the homework the night before the exams
Very easy course if you do the homework and attend lectures.  Prof. Lynch wants you to learn the concepts, not trick and aggravate you.

Very easy course if you have any statistics background.  SOmetimes this is a good thing (if you want an easier semester), sometimes it is not (if you plan to really use stats and programs for research)
You will study for the first exam and do well on it. But overstudy for the second exam because it is TOUGH
don't take unless you have to
don't unless needeed

it's a pretty easy and simple stats course, which will provide you with a basic knowledge of statistics. 
But, honestly, most lectures were not very informative or helpful (especially at the beginning). Also, precepts also weren't helpful at all...but you must go if you want to do well.
descrip: Most research in sociology is quantitative, and it is important for students at a minimum to be able to critically evaluate published quantitative research. Ideally, students should also be able to conduct empirical research involving statistical methods. This course provides the foundation for both goals. The course focuses specifically on how to determine, apply, and interpret statistical methods appropriate for answering a sociological research question given a particular set of data. Basic probability theory is introduced as a building block of statistical reasoning, and a variety of commonly-used statistical tests are developed.

title: History of the American West
reviews: Definitely a great course for history majors.  I took this class as a non-major and sometimes felt a little out of my league but I learned so much.
If you're interested in the West at all you should take the course. It is intriguing at times.

It's interesting material and Professor Sandweiss has very interesting things to say about it.  But outside of the academic realm, Professor Sandweiss is very harsh.  When she steps out from behind the podium, she makes it clear if she doesn't like you and it seems like there is no redemption after that.  She is a very tough grader and unapologetic about it.  You should do the readings so you can keep up in precept and meet with her before you hand in your papers.  Maybe that way you won't be surprised by the grades you get.
Take it, even if you don't know much abotu the American West!
take it. unique perspective on something we all think we know about, but digging deeper is the fun part
descrip: This course examines the history of the place we now call the American West, from pre-contact to the present. Our primary focus will be on the struggles between and among peoples to control resources and political power, and to shape the ways in western history is told. We will pay particular attention to the role of visual and popular culture in shaping the national imagination of the region.

title: Cultures of the Afro-Diaspora
descrip: This course analyzes key readings and studies on Afro-diasporic cultures across the Americas in the 20th century. From reggae's unrelenting rhythms to the dances that move carnival, the New World thrums with activity from populations that have persevered conditions of displacement to create new aesthetic forms. We will investigate expansive notions of blackness that move beyond national paradigms and the productive pressure that performance puts on ontologies of identity such as the Afro-Latino, African American, and West Indian in theory and literature. Artists include Bob Marley, Katherine Dunham, Jorge Ben, and Patato y Totico.

title: Fixed Income: Models and Applications
prereqs: ECO 362 or FIN 501, ECO 465 (concurrent enrollment is acceptable) Multivariate Calculus, Introduction Probability/Statistics.
descrip: This course will deal with no-arbitrage models of contracts based on interest rates including bonds, forward and future contracts, swaps, options and other derivatives. We will develop the theory of arbitrage-free pricing of financial assets in discrete and continuous time, as well as many special models that can be used to price and hedge fixed income securities.

title: Environmental Change, Poverty, and Conflict
reviews: Definitely take this course if you have the time.  But don't take it unless you intend to apply yourself.

Despite the challenges associated with the fact that the seminars are not organized, the expectations are not always clear, and there is always ambiguity as to how your performance is, this is a classic Prof. van der Vink course that should not be missed. It can be frustrating, but also a tremendous experience where what you get out has a lot to do with what you put in and the openness of your mind.
If you don't have a lot of time or aren't interested in the material, do not take this class because it requires deep involvement.
If you like research and working in teams, take this class.
It is a time suck, so be prepared to put a lot of work in, but it is rewarding.
Take this course if you actually want to feel like you accomplished anything coming out of Princeton. GvdV is by far the best professor I have ever had.
This could me the most valuable course you take at Princeton, especially if you have any interest in graduate school! Great preparation.

This is the best class I've taken at Princeton. It is how you envision every class will be when you decide to come here. Professor van der Vink actually treats students like adults, and the class addresses real-world issues. That said, he has no respect or regard for the value of your own time, and will act as though this is the only class you are taking. Plan on getting out of class at at 11:30 - if you are lucky.
descrip: We will evaluate the environmental, political, social, and economic impacts of climate change on development, poverty-reduction, civil violence, and conflict. Students work in teams integrating climate prediction models with environmental, social, and economic parameters to identify fragile populations that are becoming increasingly at risk due to climate change. Class results submitted for publication and presented to appropriate policy-makers and/or business leaders.

title: Social Psychology
reviews: Are you interested in Social Psychology? Then this is the course for you! It will teach you about social psychology!
Attend lectures and ask questions

Definitely take this course if you are interested in psychology! It is fascinating and reveals insights into your own social life. Just remember to read the chapters in the time suggested by the syllabus because it is a lot of material to remember.
Definitely take this course. It's very interesting and informative! Worth the time and effort.
Definitely take this course. The material is very interesting and there is not a huge workload.

Don't slack off - take the course seriously. Take advantage of your preceptor because they really want to help. This course is really interesting but if you take it seriously it is a great intro to social psych and is really interesting!
Even if you've never encountered psychology before, there is a big emphasis on understanding the basic tenets of research and scientific discipline.
Good class to PDF but still learn a lot. Very interesting.
Great course to PDF, but gets boring at some points.

I found the course really interesting.  If you're taking the course for a letter grade, MAKE SURE YOU READ THE BOOK.  The lectures may seem comprehensive, but you will be tested on much finer details.  If you're PDF-ing, you may only need to read a couple chapters.
I found the material kind of boring but that's because I'm just not into psychology.
I really like this class and think that is you are at all interested in sociology or psych you should take it

I suppose if you're looking for an easy class, this would be a good option. I put very minimal effort in and will probably get a B. Subject matter is interesting, but could read everything you learn all semester on your own if you're truly interested.

I would not recommend taking this course with Professor Cooper -- I would wait for it to open up with another professor and then take it.  The lectures are incredibly slow and you cover one tiny topic per lecture.
I would really recommend taking this course! It was really interesting!
I would recommend taking this course.  The material is very interesting, even if the lectures were sometimes less than spectacular.
If you are interested in analyzing your interactions with others and vice versa, this class is for you.
If you have a general interest in how people interact with each other, this course is worth it!
If you really love sociology or psychology, then this class is for you.
If you're looking for a kind of chill class to take on top of other problem-set or paper heavy classes, this one's great. It's interesting and it doesn't require a ton of work outside of class.
Interesting and easy.
Keep up with the readings and pay attention (though its very interesting, so don't worry it's not difficult).
Make sure to take good notes, especially from the reading.
READ THE BOOK. MEMORIZE ALL VOCAB
Read the textbook and attend lecture regularly
Read the textbook.
Read your textbook dutifully and don't fall behind.
Stay on top of the reading! Make flash cards to study, and make sure you know specific and general things about the studies covered. Overall it was very informative and interesting.
Super easy class. The lectures are not that important or useful, but the precept projects are fairly interesting. Be aware that there is a significant amount of group work/group projects.
Take it if you are interested in how social interactions work.
Take it if you are interested in studying the power of situational influence on people's minds. The workload is below average, and the professor is great. Easily recommended.
Take it if you need the distribution or the blow off.
Take it if you're interested in learning about the material. If not, consider your choice very carefully.

Take it! Whether or not you have previous experience in psychology, this course will be both engaging and informative. Cooper is laid-back and hilarious and the class is as much as work as you want it to be.
Take it, but don't expect to have too many new insights.
Take it.
Take it. Workload isn't bad and subject matter is interesting.

Take this class! It's a good intro to psychology, especially if you just want to see if it's the right subject for you. This course helped me realize that I enjoy the ideas of psychology but that I would never consider being a psych major, and that's what all intro classes should help you decide!
--Easy class: little homework or projects, straightforward readings and precept discussions.
--Lectures can get slow at times but Joel is adorable and also very knowledgable. 
--If you think you want to try a psychology course, take this!
Take this class! You will love it.

Take this course if you want an easy class that doesn't have a lot of outside reading. It's not very difficult, and some of it is kind of interesting. Don't take it if you are hoping to learn a lot about psychology.

This class moves nice and slowly for someone who has an interest in psych but hasn't done it before. The lecture and reading are slow paced and very intuitive, though you will be asked to recall it on the test. The professor is very nice and lectures well.
This course is fairly easy. There isn't a lot of reading. Just make sure you study the textbook AND the lectures for exams.
This course provides a lot of interesting, applicable, and important information.
This is a great course. I highly recommend it. Because of the content matter, it is probably one of the most fun psych courses. Take it.

This is a really interesting class.  Besides textbook reading, there is not a lot of work.   It is just difficult if you are one of those people who has a hard time figuring out what to study/what's important.
This is a very interesting class, even if you're not into psychology. The coursework isn't excessively hard and the readings are manageable.

This is a very interesting course to take if you ever wanted to know the reasoning behind people's actions. In particular, conventional logic is often wrong when it comes to group behavior. If you need a SA distribution, take this course.
Whether you've taken psych before or not, Social Psych with Prof. Cooper is a good course.  Prof. Cooper is a great lecturer and the projects/readings are relevant and not intimidating.

You can handle this as a fifth course. Interesting, but not too challenging. However, if you were to only take one psych class at Princeton, I would possibly encourage you to take another more stimulating one.
do the readings, and go to the lectures.
easy class, be prepared to read textbook for tests
read the textbook before exams. focus on key words and phrases
read the textbooks and go to lectures.
take it
descrip: The scientific study of social behavior, with an emphasis on social interaction and group influence. Topics covered will include social perception, the formation of attitudes and prejudice, attraction, conformity and obedience, altruism and aggression, and group dynamics.

title: Spenser
descrip: A study of the works of the poet's poet, Edmund Spenser, with an emphasis on his lurid, preacherly, confounding masterpiece, The Faerie Queene. Attention to his sources in the Bible, classical literature and philosophy, and the writing of his day.

title: Theory of Knowledge
reviews: A good EC to PDF. Two short papers and a midterm. Readings are short but dense. Precept is interesting. Students are either PHI majors who know everything about the topic or seniors who need an easy EC to PDF/ Be forewarned if you do not fall into either category.
An excellent P/D/F course if you're willing to attend all the lectures. Generally interesting, professor is an engaging lecturer, readings are very manageable.
Definitely an interesting subject--offers something that you won't find in other classes--take it
I think that students from a variety of different background could enjoy this class. However, I think that at least one or two previous philosophy classes could be helpful.

I think whether or not you will like this course depends on your interest in theory of knowledge.  I find the readings really interesting, and I like thinking about things like justification and knowledge.  I'd recommend trying to read something before-hand and gauging your interest.  There is a weekly precept to talk about the readings, and it is usually a good interesting discussion.

I would recommend this class to people interesting in taking a philosophy class for the first time. I would also warn them that they might need to PDF if they aren't satisfied with some B, as it seemed to be quite competitive to get an A in the class.

If the subject-matter sounds at all interesting to you, I would definitely recommend this course.  I found the material fascinating, and the lectures and precepts were engaging.  The work-load was very manageable, and I enjoyed writing the papers.
If you are interested in philosophy, this is a great course.

If you're interested in philosophy, then this is probably a great course because Kelly has a good lecture style and doesn't require much reading. However, if you're not interested, I advise against taking it. Even if just PDFing, it requires a lot of time just to read the texts. And if you don't go to lecture, you're in trouble on the final exam. A lot of final exam questions come strictly from what he says in class, and the info can't be found in the texts. So if you're willing to go to class and pay attention, this course will be fine for you. If not, be wary because you'll find yourself confused and frustrated by the topics if you don't put in the time. Though he says previous philosophy experience is unnecessary, I think it certainly would've helped me. I was very confused simply by the philosophical mode of thinking.
It was an interesting. If you need an EC I would recommend it.
It's a solid philosophy course, not earth-shattering. If that sounds good to you, take it.
Lectures are little hard to follow at times. Professor Kelley isn't the most interesting of lecturers though I definitely recommend talking to him personally.

Make sure to attend class and take great notes. Do not miss any of the readings, everything will appear on the final. It helps to participate, and do not be afraid to ask questions even during lecture.
Strongly recommended. Can take without philosophy course experience. Pay attention in class. Keep up with readings. Not hard.
Take this class whether or not you will be a philosophy major. It's awesome in every single aspect.
The course is alright. Ultimately not as interesting as the description makes it seem. But precept discussions are insightful and enjoyable.

This class is great for anyone who has taken an introduction to philosophy class and is considering concentrating in philosophy. The study of epistemology is fascinating, and I think that anyone would find the discussion of knowledge to be relatively accessible.
This is a good class.  It is more technical than most philosophy classes.  You will leave this class with a much better framework for how belief and knowledge is formed.
Unlike other philosophy classes, the material in this class is very contemporary and accessible. Solid EC.
Worth taking if you like philosophy
take it!!!!!!!!!
descrip: This course will examine central issues in contemporary epistemology. Topics covered will include the following: skeptical arguments that all we can really know about are our own private thoughts and experiences; the nature of testimony and our dependence upon others (including others far removed from us in space and time) for much of what we ordinarily take ourselves to know; questions about what makes an argument rationally compelling. Why (if at all) should we value knowing the truth?

title: Advanced Solid-State Electron Physics
descrip: This course deals with different aspects of electronic systems with disorder and/or strong electron-electron interactions/correlation (see Graduate School Announcement for range of topics). In 2012-13, the course will cover magnetism in disordered systems including classical and quantum spin glasses, random quantum antiferromagnets, ferromagnetism in diluted magnetic semiconductors and magnetism in the disordered Hubbard model. Reading material will consist of mostly research papers from journals.

title: Policy Research Seminar
reviews: Ashoka Mody is great.  Just make sure to understand the style of writing he expects, and work with him to develop a research question

I am happy to have done it, but I was not so happy while doing it. Expect a lot of readings from the substance portion. The people running both parts of the course are very helpful answering individual questions, so take advantage of that.

I would recommend against taking a policy research seminar, at least if they haven't fixed anything.  Professor Boix is excellent, but the format of the class meant that I didn't really learn anything about policy.
I would strongly recommend this course for those interested in learning about macroeconomics and doing a largely quantitative JP.
If you have a stats course already, I would recommend a solid commitment in the research seminar in your first semester rather than second!
Make sure you have a specific topic/interest for your JP before enrolling in this course.
Professors are great
Start your JP early; pick that topic and go with it.  You'll be able to utilize the resources and consult the professors of WWS much more effectively and learna  lot more.
Start your JP research early and seek out all the help you can get about empirical methods (i.e. using STATA or R) because the semester moves very quickly!
descrip: The junior policy research seminar serves to introduce departmental majors to the tools, methods, and interpretations employed in policy research and writing. Students may choose from a range of topics.

title: Electing the President: Voter Psychology and Candidate Strategy
descrip: This course will follow the 2012 presidential election and draw on political science research to understand it. We will examine the nature of modern election campaigns and their impact on people's political reasoning and voting behavior. How do citizens make voting decisions? How do they learn about candidates and issues? Can Obama win reelection despite poor economic performance? Do campaign ads manipulate voters? The goal of this class is to provide a comprehensive understanding of campaign conduct and effects. We will focus on the fall campaign for President, but will also briefly cover presidential primaries and congressional elections.

title: Abnormal Psychology
reviews: A good course for an SA requirement.
A great fifth class

Buy or download the book and read it, but more importantly take notes on what you read.  Take notes closely.  Perhaps it would be best to do the practice test to before you read to get a sense of what can/will be tested.
Choose your precepts wisely, it changes the entire experience.

Comer's lectures are kind of supplementary to the textbook readings: whatever he says in lecture is in the book, but he doesn't cover everything in the book.  Keep in mind that the exams are textbook-based and are surprisingly technical.  If you don't keep up with the textbook readings, though, I'd suggest attending lecture so you can understand the precept readings.  Overall, I thought the class gave me a good survey of mental illness and the challenges clinicians face with diagnosis/treatment.

Definitely read the textbook and keep up with assigned readings every week or it will come back to cripple your grade. Don't cram. And don't expect too much out of lecture, though make sure you do go.
Definitely take for an entertaining and interesting class.
Definitely take it - there are very interesting videos during lecture to supplement the material, and the exams are very fair.
Definitely take it!
Definitely take the class you will learn some cool stuff!
Definitely take this class, regardless of what your concentration is.
Definitely take this course- the material is extremely interesting and I looked forward to lecture. However, make sure to bring a laptop to take notes- Professor Comer talks very fast.
Do it.
Do the readings on time. It will save you a lot of time toward semester's end.
Do the readings.

Do the textbook readings! The exams only cover the textbook chapters, not the precept readings. All of the reading is interesting, but the precept readings are not sufficient for the exams. Take notes on the textbook chapters throughout the semester, so that you don't have to memorize so much right before the exam. Focus on the bolded words and the chapter summaries at the end of each chapter!
Don't take it unless you need it for something. I

Don't take this course. took a lot of time even for a PDF. Lectures repeated themselves every single time. Tests are designed to trick you rather than teach you. TOTAL WASTE OF TIME AND EFFORT. DO NOT TAKE
Dont bother making notecards for details because there are way too many of them.

That being said, your professors will assume you're coming in with pretty comprehensive knowledge of grammar and vocab - the focus is on constructing correct, nuanced sentences, not on memorizing conjugations/meanings. I've met three of the professors, and they all have different styles, but they're all nice and approachable. If you have questions, ask! I really enjoyed taking this course. I learned a lot both in terms of material and how to think critically in terms of ethical issues and the implications for public policy. If you're interested at all (or not, I wasn't at first) in ethics or politics at all, you should definitely take this course. Even though my background is in science and I had never taken a course like this before, I was able to keep up with what was going on with no problem.

I think the precept for this class is the best precept I've had at Princeton--Macedo designs it so that students are assigned to present different sides of whatever ethics debate we are engaging in that week, and are forced to speak about it as if defending that side. It means that everyone talks and has a really good discussion, without being nervous that people are judging them for what they're saying--but also that people are getting past the superficial "it's interesting that..." and instead actually engaging with the issues.

The lectures were great! Macedo is really animated and excited, and also provides a good overview of the readings, which is especially helpful when they're really dense and complicated. He's also great about incorporating student commentary into the lectures and often calls on students by name to allow them to contribute to the discussions--so impressive in a 150-person lecture!
I would definitely recommend taking this course, but would make sure to let people know that it does come with a sizable chunk of, at times, dense reading that might not be for everyone.
I would recommend taking this course.

descrip: The course examines major moral controversies in public life and differing conceptions of justice and the common good. It seeks to help students develop the skills required for thinking and writing about the ethical considerations that ought to shape public institutions, guide public authorities, and inform the public's judgments. The course will focus on issues that are particularly challenging for advanced, pluralist democracies such as the USA, including justice in war, terrorism and torture, paternalism, markets and distributive justice, abortion, the law of marriage and the place, if any, of religious arguments in politics.

title: Relativism
prereqs: One philosophy course or permission of instructor..
descrip: The course will explore various kinds of relativism: cultural relativism about beliefs concerning matters of fact; conceptual relativism, deriving from claims about the existence of distinct and, perhaps, incompatible conceptual schemes; something called "epistemic relativism"; and moral relativism of various kinds. We will look for the common structure of the various relativisms--if there is one--and explore whether relativism in any of these domains is plausible.

title: Arts of China, Prehistory to the 20th Century
descrip: This course introduces the history of art in China through focused studies of major media taken in roughly chronological order. First come the chief art forms of ancient China: bronze ritual vessels, jade, lacquer, and silk. A turning point in their slow eclipse by representational art is the famous Qin terracotta army (210 BC). A little later a foreign religion, Indian Buddhism, came to China, bringing new forms of devotional art; we look at sculpture and cave temples from the 6th to the 9th century. The rest of the semester will be devoted mainly to painting and calligraphy, but porcelain, architecture, and gardens will also be mentioned.

take it! It's interesting and fun
prereqs: Juniors only (except for sophomores who have completed EGR 251)..
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

profs.name: Esther Roseli da Costa Azevedo Meyer

title: Anxious Megalopolis: Shanghai's Urban Cultures (1842-2012)
reviews: Fantastic. Though I feel this class may be a one-time deal, I would strongly recommend classes with both professors.
I don't think this course will ever be offered again, so the question is kind of irrelevant.
I would highly recommend this course to anyone. However, it won't be offered again, I'm sure.  I hope a course similar to this one is offered so other students can have the amazing experience.
If it is offered again, TAKE IT
If there is an opportunity to take a course with Cary Liu or Esther da Costa Meyer, you simply must take it.
Make sure you give a good first impression and you volunteer early for a presentation.
Take any class with Esther, but obviously apply to try to get into this course!
descrip: From a small village and market town, Shanghai grew to become a bustling port, colonialist beachhead, hub of international commerce in the 30s, and a major testing ground for contemporary architecture today. As a crucial interface between East and West, this city was a place where national and transnational cultures fought and flourished, and stereotypes were forged and discarded. This seminar will cover the emergence of Shanghai's vibrant urban culture as it evolved into the complex megalopolis of today. There will be a trip to Shanghai over fall break funded by the department.

title: Topics in Development - Global Challenges of Infection, Burden & Control
descrip: An exploration of the biological, public health and global dimensions of infectious disease. The basic features of human-microbe interactions by examining several viral, bacterial and parasitic infections are analyzed.. Emphasis includes biology, burden of illness and domestic and global forces shaping the expanding threat. Control strategies, including chemotherapy, vaccines and environmental changes; and the role of international organizations such as WHO, UNICEF, and GAVI and the major philanthropies, are considered.

title: Linear and Convex Optimization
reviews: A good introductory level course on linear programming, with some interesting topics discussed at the end of the semester.
A mature methodology.
Be prepared to commit a lot of time and effort to the class.
Can gain a general idea of linear programming and some practical techniques.
I think that if the professor teaches the nonlinear prtograming part more rigorously, it will be more helpful

If you are interested in linear programming (definitely a very useful tool), I would recommend the course. Do not expect mathematical rigor or any convex analysis, it is really only linear programming.

If you want to learn more about linear programming, this course is really good. The professor is interesting and his book is extremely useful. The problem sets are sometimes long so it is a demanding course
It is a very useful course in optimization.
Programming knowledge in matlab assumed for some of the problem sets.
Take this course under Vanderbei.
The course will succeed in giving you an introduction to LP.

The focus is on algorithmic approaches for linear optimization and their applications. General convex optimization is barely discussed. In my opinion, the course covers the intended material quite effectively.

The math is not involved, and all it requires is basic linear algebra. By taking this course you may understand the theories related to linear optimization problems. Nonlinear convex optimization problem is also stressed as well. You may also learn to solve optimization problems with the well established solvers by writing AMPL code.
Try and read the chapters in the book before the lecture. Makes things a lot clearer.
Try to stay concentrated during the course.
descrip: Topics discussed include: the simplex method and its complexity, degeneracy, duality, the revised simplex method, convex analysis, game theory, network flows, primal-dual interior point methods, first order optimality conditions, Newton's method, KKT conditions, quadratic programming, and convex optimization. A broad spectrum of applications are presented.

title: The Philosophy of Kant - Kant's Ethical Thought
descrip: The seminar will examine Kant's main ethical writings, with particular attention to the controversy regarding constructivist and intuitionist interpretations.

title: Microeconomic Analysis (Advanced)
prereqs: A working knowledge of basic calculus and ease with algebraic manipulation are prerequisites of the course..
descrip: This course is an introduction to the use of microeconomics for the analysis of public policy on an advanced level. The emphasis is on both the intuitive and formal logic of economic principles, a deeper perspective on the impacts of typical policy measures, and an introduction to the use of professional microeconomic tools to assess and weigh these policy impacts. One goal is to move students towards the ability to read professional microeconomic literature with appreciation of both its contributions and foibles.

title: Roman Letters
prereqs: LAT108 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This class aims to improve students' ability to read good Latin prose for both comprehension and appreciation. We will observe three masters of Roman prose - Cicero, Seneca, Pliny - as they present themselves and their society in the most immediate of all prose forms, the letter.

title: Readings in Early Modern Japanese History
reviews: Take it. It's informative, comprehensive and fun.
descrip: A survey of major issues in the historiography of early modern Japan and Meiji Japan (1600-1890).

title: Facebook: The Social Impact of Social Networks
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Advanced Design and Behavior of Steel Structures
reviews: Definitely take this class! It is very useful in terms of knowledge it provides, and if you are interested in Structural Engineering it gives you the possibility to understand in detail aspects of the design that would rarely be covered in other courses, such as fire structural engineering.
Definitely take this course if you are interested in being a structural engineer. Professor Herning is extremely kind and helpful in office hours.
Do be shy in asking questions.
Get to know the manual inside and out
Good design class.
I encourage anyone interested in stew structures to take this course
Take take take
Take this class.
Undergrads: Take it if you are willing to spend quite a bit of time working through the problem sets.
yes! unless you're an undergrad and they make an undergrad steel class.
descrip: Advanced topics in the design and analysis of steel structures are covered. These topics include local and global stability, second-order effects of combined bending and axial loads, torsion, and structural design for fire.

title: Independent Study I
prereqs: Must fill out Independent Study form signed by Advisor & DGS. Bring signed form to Graduate Coordinator in E-211..
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out independent study. Prior to course registration, students must complete a departmental Graduate Independent Study form that describes the work being undertaken, and have the form approved by the supervising faculty member and the Director of Graduate Studies.

title: Mathematical Methods of Engineering Analysis I
reviews: Ask a lot questions in the lectures to force him to slow down. Be prepared to dedicate an inordinate amount of time to doing problem sets.
Be prepared to spend a lot of your time on this class.
Have a strong applied mathematics background
If you need to learn some broad mathematics that are used often in the natural sciences, I'd recommend this course.
It may help to have a background in linear algebra before considering this course.
Some of the materials might not be very useful if you do experimental work, but it's good to know the math.
Start homeworks early.
Work hard!
descrip: Methods of mathematical analysis for the solution of problems in physics and engineering. Topics include an introduction to functional analysis, linear analysis & eigenvalue problems for matrices & linear operators, Sturm-Liouville theory, Green's functions for the solution of linear ordinary differential equations and Poisson's equation, and the calculus of variations, and the inverse and implicit function theorems.

title: Transformations of the Self
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: The Language of the Qur'an
prereqs: Completion of ARA 302 or instructor's permission.
descrip: For students who have a working foundation in the Arabic language - a vocabulary set of around 1500 words and a firm grasp of Arabic syntax. The course is structured around passages in the Qur'an and will expose students to the traditional disciplines of the Arabic language of the Qur'an and its ancillary sciences, i.e., exegesis, recitation, orthography, etymology, philology, morphology, and grammar. Supplementary materials will also include scholarly articles in Arabic and in English regarding the recensions of the Qur'an, their collection and standardization, the seven recitations of the Qur'an, and other related topics.

title: Data, Models, and Uncertainty in the Natural Sciences
reviews: Definitely take this course, if you want to learn real, practical data analysis techniques. However, beware that the labs are quite time consuming and you will need to reach out for help on the labs. However, Frederik is an exceedingly good lecturer and you will learn and understand a lot of useful information through this class.
Expect to learn a lot about Matlab through individual trial and error.
Fun course if you want to learn matlab.
Great course.
I would recommend taking this course to understand statistics and how to use statistical tools to analyze scientific data. Tremendously useful for any scientific project, JP, thesis, and beyond.

If you are serious about going to graduate school or going into research in post-grad, you should DEFINITELY take this course.  Frederik will teach you rigorous statistical tools to test your data as well as MATLAB, if you haven't already learned that.
If you're a science major and looking into doing research at all, this class will be beneficial.
Take it if you actually are interested in the meaning of data. Otherwise it may be too niche/too much work.

This course will give you an understanding of the mathematical underpinnings to a lot of important statistical methods. If you plan to do serious science in the future and don't know how do to these things, then there's no better person to learn it from than Frederik, so take the course. Best thing to do for labs is set your own deadlines and get them done on your own time, because Frederik won't set them for you.
This is an excellent course for learning to conduct numerical analyses in Matlab.
have a command of matlab and linear algebra.
strongly recommend, very useful in the research about quantitative modeling
you should take it
prereqs: MAT 202 or MAT 204 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: No more being puzzled by dots on a graph! This course is for those who want to turn observations into models and subsequently evaluate their uniqueness and uncertainty. Three main topics are elementary statistics, heuristic time series analysis, and model parameter estimation via matrix inverse methods. While the instructor's & textbook examples will be derived mostly from the physical sciences, students are encouraged to bring their own data sets for classroom discussion and in-depth analysis as part of their term papers. Problem sets and Matlab computer programming exercises form integral parts of the course.

title: Introduction to Sociology
reviews: A good intro course. Duneier and Starr are great and readings are generally short and interesting. There's a little busy work, but not too much.
A great course for all majors.  If Duneier and Starr are the lecturers as they were for my semester, then you will be in for the treat of one of the most interesting courses at Princeton.
A great course to take if you are interested in the subject -- or even just to find out if you are!
Although sociology might not be your first idea of a major, it is definitely interesting enough to try it out.
Ask questions in precept about anything that you may not understand, but also just be ready to take in a broad span of information that covers many different aspects of sociology.
Attend the lectures, the concepts and format of the lectures are exactly what you are tested on.
Attending the lectures and watching videos is worth it, not so much for the sake of the class, but for the material itself.
Avoid this course at all cost. It's boring. Just, don't.

Bring pen and paper to lectures--or else you will be distracted and end up on Facebook. 
Also, readings and precepts are really important. I would even say that they might take precedence over the lectures.
Definitely an interesting course and a great distribution requirement.

Definitely take it! Our second to last lecture Prof. Duneier had a guy with a horse mask come in. It was crazy, but also really funny and interesting. The class is a great way to get rid of an SA requirement in a very non-intense way.
Definitely take this class. Take it with Professor Duneier and Starr.

Do most of the readings or at least skim them. Study for the midterm and final with other people; I did this and crushed both of them (B  on the midterm, which would have been an A anywhere else, such as at Harvard). Engagement in precept will help you get good notes from other prepared people.
Do not take this course. It is not very interesting, and I learned almost nothing.
Do the readings and everything will make sense. There are also so many cool guest speakers so take advantage of those opportunities.
Do the readings because they are very important
Do the readings!

Do your readings.
Stay on top of your readings.
Don't miss lecture.
Duneier is awesome and the course material is interesting and not difficult.
Easy-enough course; precepts boring, concepts interesting but not particularly stimulating.
Eh, if you're going to be a sociology major I guess you kind of have to take it. If you're looking for an SA to take, then you might want to look elsewhere for a smaller, more intimate class.

Even if you think you know what sociology is about and you don't think it is for you, take this course and you will change your mind.  It is an intro class so it is not that hard, but the value you get from it will be great.  Seriously take this course.
Fun intro class to take.
Go to lecture and keep up to date on readings.
Go to lecture because it is the best part of the course; especially Duneier's lectures. If you do the reading and go to lecture, it is not difficult to do well!
Go to lecture!!! They always cover the readings during lecture so they're really helpful.
Going to class was important because it gave us a good idea of what parts of the readings we needed to know.
Good class to take to see if you are in the subject matter.
Good overview of sociology. Not as fun as electives, but some of the weeks were really, really interesting.
Great class to take, just keep up with the readings.
Highly recommended if you want a new perspective on society in general.
