I don't recommend it. It's so simple that it's a waste of time.

I took this course only to fulfill a distro. Very quickly, this course became my favorite of the semester. I am highly biased towards maths/sciences, but I really loved this course. The class is very balanced and polished. The workload is not heavy, so take it as a 6th class if you need to.. just take it!
I was really excited to take this course, but I was disappointed. You don't learn very much, and it's not very rigorous. I'd only recommend it if you wanted an easy way to fulfill the SA requirement.

I would honestly never take another course with Duneier or Starr! Starr will put you to sleep and Duneier was supposed to be amazing, but he's incredibly boring too.  He also likes to play social experiments on the class- he did the lecture from some random place (not in the lecture hall) and tried to play God to us- I guess that's how he gets his kicks.

I would really recommend taking this course.  It's really interesting and not an overwhelming amount of work.  But I found all of the information to be really valuable, and I'm really glad I took this class.
I would recommend staying on top of the readings, and participating in precept.

I would recommend this class. The course load is reasonable and it was a great introduction into the field of sociology. I had never taken a sociology class before this one and felt comfortable and well prepared in this class.
I would recommend this course.  The workload is not too bad and the subject matter is interesting.  I'm not too interested in social science but I learned a lot and got a good overview of sociology
I would suggest doing the reading because it adds a lot to understanding the concepts.
I would tell other students to consider taking this course.
I would tell them that going to all lectures is very important as they were the place where I learned the most.
If you are at all interested in sociology, definitely take this course.  The more you put into it the more you get out.

If you think you might be interested in social science (or even if you just need a distribution requirement) take this class. Prof. Duneier is an awesome lecturer and the subject matter is really varied.
If you're interested in SOC at all, or just to open your mind, this is a good one to take.
If you're interested in sociology, you'll love the course.  Do the readings, and you'll do very well.  Don't do the readings, and you'll do passably well.

If you're taking this course to do a prereq for a different department, don't do it. I saw sociology and thought it would be easy. Hated the discipline. If you're legitimately interested in sociology, give it a shot.
It is worthwhile to do the readings.
It was a fun class and I feel like I learned a lot.  I recommend it.
It's an easy SA requirement. Make sure you're in the right precept. Switch to another if you have to. Do the readings and go to class, and it's an easy class.
Its an interesting course to see if you want to go further with sociology or just learn more about society in general.
Keep up on your readings.
Keep up with the readings, go to lecture and precept, and ask questions when you need to.
Know that the curve will be hard because there will be sociology major students in the class with you.
Lectures are not necessary, you can learn everything in precept.
Love it! Duneier and Starr are the perfect team. I found the material both inside and outside of the class interesting, applicable, and thought provoking. Really satisfying and not too difficult.
Mitch was great.  If Starr were the only one teaching the course, I would recommend against it.
Nice intro class. Take it to get a distribution requirement out of the way or as a more manageable 5th class.
Okay class. Not as absurdly easy as it is with PFK but do not need to put much effort into it either.

Professor Starr is eloquent and Professor Duneier is entertaining. Take it with these two professors! Very interesting material even if you don't plan on majoring in SOC. Helpful in understanding current social issues in the U.S.
Readings are most important part of class. Easy class to fulfill distribution requirement.
Since there is nothing else to be graded on besides the midterm and final, basically, do the readings.
Stay on pace with the readings.
Stay on track with the weekly reading and attend precept prepared to discuss anything and everything from the reading.
TAKE THIS CLASS
Take if you have a general interest, they will sway you into liking sociology.
Take it if interested. If you want to fulfill the requirment like I did, you might want to take it because there isn't much work, just a midterm and a final so it's very low-intense.
Take it if you need an SA i guess.  No strong feelings.
Take it if you need an interesting SA but beware of the gazillions of over eager freshmen.
Take it with Mitch and Paul. They are fantastic.
Take it!
Take it!  Great class, great lectures, interesting readings, and not a lot of writing involved!
Take it! It is very interesting!
Take it, do the readings and talk to the professors because they are really interesting and engaging academics who are quite distinguished and have a lot to say.
Take it. It's interesting and the lectures are good.
Take the class seriously.  Although it's a 101 and it's not that time consuming or hard, it's very interesting and could possibly be something you'd want to do.
Take the class. The professors are great.
Take the course. It's interesting and fun, you'll want to do the readings and you can use what you learn here throughout many different fields of study.
Take this class if you have a general interest in the topic or if you are looking to fulfill a requirement.
Take this class if you're at all interested - wonderful professors, excellent readings, and not too much work.
Take this course to receive a general perspective on Sociology.
Take this course!
Take this course... It is very interesting and not a very large work load.
Take this early on, even if you use a PDF, to get a better understanding for how society functions!
Take this if you want an easy, interesting course.
The class can be interesting if you are in the right precept. Danny Frost is a great preceptor; Karen Fraley is not.
The class introduces a lot of interesting concepts and helps you think about the world, yourself, and others differently.

This class does not require much work at all. Now that can be a good thing, but it can also be bad as it makes it very easy to stop caring about the class, which is a shame because the lectures were mostly very good

This class is an excellent overview to sociology. If you are in any class and curious about what sociology is, I think you should take it. Although no formal definition was made, I now have a sense of the field. Although I have no inclination to pursue the field much further, I do have an appreciation for the perspective it offers.
This class is very interesting. If you do not know much about sociology but are curious to see what it might be about, definitely take it.
This class was very interesting and addresses relevant issues and discussions in today's society. There is not a lot of work and Duneier and Starr are wonderful lecturers.

This course changed the way I think about people and the world in general. Definitely take it if you think you might have any interest in sociology! Duneier especially has interesting stories, and listening to him talk about his work researching homeless street vendors in NYC was amazing.

This course was interesting and manageable. Since the readings covered pretty much everything we talked about, you could easily have gotten through the course just by doing the readings, but I appreciated how the lectures and precepts gave us more insight by summarizing main ideas and picking up things that the readings did not elaborate enough on, or even by giving the points as sometimes the readings were just to give examples and not necessarily the actual concept we were to take away. There was not a lot of work and the readings were relatable so understandable. That being said, I think since this course was on the easy side, it was easy to lose interest. I kept up with the readings before the midterm, but after I was able to get away with skipping a lot of them because I had too much work for other classes. That made it so that I did not gain as much as I could from the lectures and precepts. It can be easy to fall behind. The main thing is to keep up with the readings. Go to lectures and precepts to get a deeper understanding of the concepts, but it is okay to miss some of the lectures.
This is a good intro class to the field of sociology, specifically from the United States/Western perspective.
This is an interesting course if you need a distribution requirement

This is such an interesting course. Lectures are very interesting and in precepts you always end up discussing very interesting and thought-provoking issues. Make sure you attend all lectures and take good notes. This will help you on the exams, which usually have very fair questions.
Try your hardest to pay attention in lecture, because it is hard.
Understand the key terms of sociology, as the student has to connect social theories often in the course and in the written work.

Very broad course - some info was interesting, some was not really, some you couldn't understand. If you want to take one course in sociology, do not take this one. More focused soc courses apply better to what you're interested in/the real world. This should just be taken by soc majors/potential ethnographers
You don't have to do all the readings word for word but attend precept, especially if you have Daniel Frost and read Sidewalk. Chug some Red Bull before Starr's lecture because they stink.
You must take this course with Professor Duneier and Professor Starr! It is outstanding--flexible, well rehearsed, interesting, straightforward, fair. I loved this course.
You're going to read a lot.
do all of the readings and participate in the precepts and things will go well
do the readings and engage in precept
not unless its required
pretty easy course that is interesting as well. not a lot of time needed to ace the course.
sit in the very front so that you can hear the speakers and read all the readings so that when you take the exams you won't fail.
study
take it!
very interesting, take it!
descrip: This course introduces sociology as a subject with a key role to play in modern intellectual culture and a central place within the social sciences. A range of topics such as race, class, gender, deviance, ethnocentrism, crime, families, urban life, social interaction, and social inequality will be covered. Lectures are intended to inspire students to draw on their sociological imagination to become more publicly involved and directly engaged in the real world.

title: Senior Thesis Seminar
reviews: It's definitely good to get started talking about your thesis early; put some effort into the class and you'll be happy you did.

Not the worst, good to stay on track senior year, best if people participate and keep things interesting so those 2 hours don't crawl by... we had a lot of visiting lectures right before class (6:30) which could be good but sort of made it seem too long.
This is a great course for senior VIS certificate students.  We each got a ton of feedback on our work, and it was helpful to critique others' work, too.
prereqs: Open to senior Program 2 students in Art and Archaeology and VIS certificate students in preparation for their senior thesis exhibition..
descrip: This seminar will give senior Program 2 concentrators in Art and Archaeology and certificate students in the Visual Arts a more structured and collegial environment for developing their thesis exhibitions. Over the course of the semester students will research and develop their art, their influences, and their aesthetic underpinnings to be presented as a formal proposal for their thesis project for group discussion. Material choices, exhibition design, and publicity strategies also will be addressed. Assigned readings will support and challenge received ideas of what art is and what the form and content of an art exhibition might entail.

title: Readings in Kanbun
descrip: This course focuses on various types of Japanese kanbun, including waka kanbun (Japanized kanbun) from Nara to Meiji era, such as Mayo-gana, okoto-ten, soro-bun, etc. Basic knowledge of classical Japanese grammar and kanbun kundoku reading system is required.

title: Cellular and Systems Neuroscience
reviews:
If you have no course in physics or a heavy science paper reading course, this would be tough to get enough understanding with any time. But it is doable if you can find a friend and seek help from the professors.

The material is really interesting and this is a solid class to get you well-versed in the chosen areas of systems neuroscience and elementary biophysics!
If you plan on pursuing neuroscience after Princeton, I can't recommend this class enough. It's tough, but you'll learn a lot.

If you understand differential equations, you're golden. Otherwise, this is going to be an uphill battle. Even though I definitely belonged to the second group, I think you learn so much that this class is worth it.
Take it - it's a great course and it would be sad to see it fade away now that it's not required for the certificate.
Take it. It's hard but totally worth it.
Very thorough and interesting course, covering topics ranging from biophysics to systems level cognitive functioning. Anyone who wants to do neuroscience should take this.
prereqs: MOL 214 or 215, PSY 258 and MAT 103, or instructor's permission. A basic familiarity with simple electrical circuits (as presented in PHY104 or ELE 203) is expected..
descrip: A survey of fundamental principles in neurobiology at the biophysical, cellular, and system levels. Lectures will address the basis of the action potential, synaptic transmission and plasticity, local circuit computation, sensory physiology, and motor control. A central theme will be the understanding of systems phenomena in terms of cellular mechanisms.

title: Readings in Modern Chinese Intellectual History
reviews: Be prepared to do lots of work!
It's a great class if you already speak Chinese well and want to learn more about modern history and practice your writing skills.
It's less work (especially memorizing) than the other Chinese courses, and I think you get a lot more out of it in terms of critical thinking.

Prof Chou is a remarkable teacher and this class is really great for any one interested in the contemporary history of China.  It is a lot of work but your Chinese will improve dramatically and you will definitely feel smarter at the end!

Take if you're prepared to put some effort in to the homework and readings in order to actually improve your Chinese. This class is definitely not an easy one, but it is very interesting and you will gain a very fresh perspective on China's modern political and intellectual history
Take it if only you have a genuine interest in China's intellectual history.

Take this course if you would like to apply your knowledge of the Chinese language to modern Chinese literature, as well as if you wish to increase your fluency in Chinese. Do expect to have your understanding of Chinese modern history and society tested at times, and be prepared to have to increase your working vocabulary.
Take this if you want to learn something about modern China
This is not really a language class. It's a history class.

While this course can be demanding in terms of the length of the reading, it is very rewarding - not only will you learn about the key debates in modern Chinese intellectual thought, but you will also gain broad knowledge about modern Chinese history.
You'll get as much out of the course as you're willing to put into it.
take this over 301 anyday
prereqs: CHI 403, 404, 405 and 406, or Instructor's permission.
descrip: Designed to give students who have had advanced training in both classical and modern Chinese an opportunity for directed readings in their own fields. The focus of readings is modern Chinese intellectual history. One class, two hours of discussion

title: Tales of Hospitality: France, North Africa, and the Mediterranean
prereqs: FRE 207, or permission of the instructor..
descrip: Since the Revolution, France has declared itself a haven for refugees from all countries. Yet, a series of laws and often fierce debates have recently marred this benevolence with sometimes dramatic limitations. Keeping in mind different models of hospitality in the Western, Mediterranean, and Arab traditions, we will examine the 'case study' of France and North Africa by comparing ethical and political, individual and collective models of hospitality. We will address issues such as immigration, nationality, and cultural identity and reflect on what it means to welcome a stranger.

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - From the Developing World to Data Centers
reviews: I wouldn't recommend any student to take any class of this professor. Almost all students of the class I asked in private hated the class. There was even one student who said it was the worst class he had in his whole academic career.

If you are interested in reading OS related papers, if you take interest in understanding how the computers systems are evolving, this course is for you. Of course it's a seminar course and you have to read papers thoroughly, don't take it if you can't read independent works in systems.

If you plan to work in networks/systems, take this course. You'll get to know the faculty (and students) in your area in a small setting. If you want to improve your technical presentation skills, take this course. There is a lot of emphasis on that, and some might say that this is the single best thing you'll learn from this course. If you want to learn how to read OS/systems papers, take this course. The course assumes little prior knowledge (incoming grad students or even seniors can easily take the course) and teaches you how to think about research, and how to get to the heart of technical issues (attention to detail). You'll get to read some of the most important works in Operating Systems in the past decade and the level of understanding you'll have of these works will be quite different from what you can achieve just by reading the papers yourself.
It's great if you are really interested in low level systems, especially storage.
The instructor is not so nice, but it's worth it.
descrip: Examines developments in computer systems, focused on scale, resource efficiency, and the new set of demands being placed on the operating system and networks. Primary interests will be the extreme ends of the resource spectrum, and the technical challenges in addressing them. Students will present papers and contribute to the critical analysis and discussion of existing work.

title: 19th-Century Poetry
descrip: How did we get from 1821, when poets were the "unacknowledged legislators of the world" (Shelley) to 1939, when Auden wrote "poetry makes nothing happen"? This survey of 19th-century British poetry explores poetry's engagement with political and social movements (from education to empire, sexual politics to steam engines). We will think about how and why poets were deeply invested in national movements at the same time that they were ambivalent about their role in society. We will also consider how the afterlife of 19th-century poetry haunts our conception of literary "modernism."

title: Introduction to Psychology
reviews: A fun and interactive course for people looking to fulfill their lab requirement!

A good STL if you are not interested in taking one in the standard subjects you took in high school. Attend all of the lectures because a lot of what the professor says is not on the slides and will be questioned on the exams.
A good way to fulfill your STL. Yarrow Dunham is a fantastic lecturer!
As any other science course in this field, this class requires a lot of reading in preparation for exams.
Attend Lecture, it really helps.

Attend all lectures, as they are basically the only thing covered on exams. Don't bother with the reading unless you're actually curious. It's the easiest course around, so if you need a fifth, here it is.
Be prepared to do more work in this class than you would in bridges.

DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE IF YOU'VE ALREADY TAKEN PSY 254. Dunham recycles like half of his lectures in this course. He is an interesting lecturer, but the content of his lectures is very pop-psychology oriented. Super frustrating if you've taken classes in the department; this course is a regurgitation of all that info. Took this course intending to concentration in PSY, changed mind, party as a result of this course. Hugely disappointed by the bureaucracy of this course.
Definitely take it. Easy lab, and fun intro to the field of psychology.
Definitely take this class, very interesting!

Definitely take this course! Although sometimes the information may seem very "intro," as many may describe it, Prof. Dunham is a great, enthusiastic lecturer and easy to follow! The labs are engaging and the subject matter is never boring. Simply put, a great class to take if you are interested in finding out more about psychology and have not taken a class in the subject before.
Do not miss a single one of Professor Dunham's lectures. They are really engaging, and pretty much cover everything you will be tested on.
Do the reading. It is not that much, especially for an intro course and it goes a long way toward clarifying difficult concepts and providing general understanding.
Do well on the exams, talk to preceptor for lab reports, and be smart about studying strategies in doing textbook readings. Go to the lectures.
Don't pay that much attention to every detail in the readings. The lectures are more important for the exams.
Don't take an early lab, do all the readings, pay attention and take good notes in lab.
Dunham is the best lecturer ever. And general psych is applicable to daily life. Take it.
Enjoy Prof. Dunham's crazy powerpoint presentations and his sense of humor! The material is interesting as long as you respond to the engaging professor.
For BAs - Probably one of the more challenging STLs in terms of grade deflation, but definitely worth taking.
For a 101 class, I was pretty pleased
Fun and interesting, take it!
Go to all lectures because that is what the tests cover and even though the slides are online it is hard to understand without attending
Go to class and take copious notes.
Go to class and take notes! Dunham's a great lecturer and takes content from class for exams.
Go to lecture and take good notes.  Lecture is actually interesting.  This course is not a lot of work.
Go to lecture.
Good STL course, necessary for Psych majors. For a general interest in taking a psych course (but not majoring), I'd considering something with a more specific focus.
Good STL, interesting.
Great way to fulfill your STL if you're not a science person!
Have fun!
I would advise to expect labs to be a greater part of the course than they would think.
I would definitely recommend other students to take the class because it is really interesting
I would recommend taking this.
I would recommend this course to someone looking to fulfill an STL, particularly those more humanities minded, or to someone possibly interested in psychology.

I would say to do the readings weekly, don't wait to do a few chapters at once. I also would stress how important lecture is for this class because it was a huge part of the exams and the information does not always overlap with the textbook.

I wouldn't take this unless you're looking for an STL (even so, grading is difficult because you're curved with all the psych majors   premeds). If you're strong at science and looking for an STL, avoid this class--not very rigorous at all.
If at all interested, take it! Only caveat: expect repetition if you have taken an upper level psych class already.
If you are just looking for an easy fifth class, this is not the best class in terms of exams but the weekly work is definitely manageable.
If you are looking for an ST that is manageable than I recommend it. However, the lab portion is not as engaging as some other STs.
If you are looking for an easy lab, this is it.
If you want to learn about the field of psychology, take this class. Simple as that.
If you've never taken psychology, take this course! The material is interesting and fun to learn about. Dunham is a good lecturer.
It's a great way to fulfill an STL and learn about people in general!

It's an interesting course. I'm an upperclassman and took it to fulfill my ST. It was clearly designed for younger students, so I felt like I was at an advantage over students who haven't been around Princeton as long.
It's interesting and you'll learn a lot that you can apply to life.
It's okay. You can take it for an easy P/D/F and STL course, but watch out for the rote memorization.
Keep in mind that the exposure to the material is somewhat superficial because it is a survey course, but with a good professor it can be very informative.
Keep up on chapter readings and attend every lecture.
Keep up with memorization, and the concepts will come from there.
Lectures were really interesting, but lab not so much. It dragged on for a long time and the experiments we didn't weren't always interesting or clearly explained.

Lectures were very interesting. Dunham comes prepared to every lecture and keeps your interest. Definitely take for an easy STL, but the material is really interesting, and you might find yourself wanting to be a psych major.
Make sure to do the readings and attend the lectures.

Make sure to read the psychology chapters on time, as they are long. In addition, feel free to reach out to your lab instructors if you have questions. They are more than willing to help and guide you. Also, definitely pay attention in lecture and take notes, as it will greatly help with the midterm and final.

Make sure to read the textbook. While some of the examples overlap between the book and the lectures, the textbook goes more indepth and presents the material in a way that make is easier to remember come test time. Also, make sure to get an early start on your lab reports, especially since this gives you time to take them to the Writing Center.
Pay attention in lectures and labs.
Pretty easy. You should take it.
Professor Dunham is a fantastic lecturer and the labs and lab reports are very manageable. Definitely take this class if you need to fulfill your STL requirement!

Professor Dunham is a great lecturer and you should attend all his lectures because you will not understand the slides without going. He also is funny and interesting so the 50 minutes goes by quickly. Do the lab reports exactly as the rubric says and it is impossible to do poorly. Midterm and final were not particularly difficult but definitely give yourself time to study as it a lot of information (primarily based on lecture)
Read the textbook and go to lecture, while taking strong notes. Lecture slides alone will not cut it.
Read the textbook. It might not all be on the test, but it will make the course much more worthwhile.
Review the lectures, start early on lab reports.
Spend time doing all the readings outside of class and go to all the lectures.
Study your friggin' heart out and don't expect to have anything come of it.
Take it PSY 101! I hope to take another psychology class during my time here.
Take it if you need a distribution - but remember you can't p/d/f
Take it if you want to learn tons of stuff about how we work. Excellent fun facts for parties.
Take it!
Take it! But keep in mind that it is an intro class so be prepared to cover a lot of material in a short period of time.
Take it! It gives you a great introduction to the topic. The labs are great! It is a very manageable STL.
Take it! It's Psych 101. It's a college right of passage. And Prof. Dunham rocks.
Take it, but don't underestimate the work load. You have to work pretty hard to get a good grade.
Take it, it's a good intro psych class for a broad knowledge of psychology.
Take it. Its a great way to fill your lab requirement as well as get an introduction to the field of psychology.
Take it. Psychology rocks.
Take this class if you need an STL.

Take this class if you're considering majoring in psych or are a non-science person in search of a lab class.  Be warned though, there is not much new material that hasn't already been covered in IB Standard Level Psych if you took that class.
Take this class! Dunham is an awesome professor, and it's an experience you don't want to miss!
Take this class! Especially good to take simultaneously with NEU 258 because they share content but with differing perspectives.

Take this class! Take this class! Take this class! It was a great way to fulfill the STL requirement, and was such a fun class beyond that. If the option of having Professor Dunham is on the table, take it. He's a brilliant lecturer and his slides alone make this class worth taking. Also, put in the proper effort in the lab sections - they mean more than you expect them to. Loved this class, and you will too! (I haven't heard any complaints from others in the lecture, so that must be a good sign)
Take this course!!! Lectures are fascinating, labs are easy, and textbook is interesting.

The lab assignments are not fun, but there are only two of them. This is a good class for the STL if you are not a science major/going to take another STL anyway. A very interesting class because of the material. Be warned that the size makes it difficult to grade well on the exams though.
The lab component of the class is tedious, but if you don't want a hard science lab, it's the way to go. Yarrow is a very enthusiastic lecturer and very interesting.

The lectures were interesting because Professor Dunham is such a great lecturer. However, some of the labs were a waste of time. The course also covers a lot without going into great detail in any single topic which is frustrating but expected from a 101 course.
The material and labs are fascinating and Dunham is the best professor I have had at college so far.
There are probably easier ways to get rid of your lab requirements than sitting through three grueling hours a week of incompetency.
This class is very interesting, fun, and very easy. There is minimal work. I strongly recommend. Yarrow Dunham is a great lecturer also.
This course is fairly interesting, but its different aspects (lecture, lab, readings) are not well connected.

This is an interesting class with a fairly low commitment level necessary to get a lot out of it. I would highly recommend this course for anyone looking for an STL or with any interest in an introduction to psychology.
Try to read the textbook chapters in the same week as the lectures; they might help reinforce information from lectures.

Unless you have a strong interest in Psychology and/ or a strong commitment to making this class a priority, I wouldn't take it. The course's NPDF designation rightly earns it the name of a "trap class"-- it seems straightforward, but requires much more effort than would be expected for a 101 class.
Very good class, read the book and take the lab reports seriously

Ya, I know Prof. Oppenheimer is gone, but give Prof. Dunham a chance. He has big shoes to fill, and he did well in his first semester of PSY 101. His slides are funny. This is the most practical course I have taken in Princeton so far.
You have to take this class

can't pdf so think wisely before you take it; lab report results come out after the pdf register date.. some people bombed their lab reports but couldnt pdf it; lectures are often interesting, but lab is very, very tedious; would recommend fulfilling STL with another class.
do all the textbook readings!
go to office hours
good intro course into psy 101. labs can be more interesting, but only 2 lab reports
take it
take it and pay attention in class! the midterms and finals essay sections will be difficult if you don't have a background in psychology
take it! broad but great course!
take it! go to lecture for sure if you have dunham and take good notes there.
take this course, its interesting and gives a great taste of psychology
descrip: The study of human nature from the viewpoint of psychological science. Topics range from the biological bases of human perception, thought and action to the social-psychological determinants of individual and group behavior. This course is a prerequisite for majoring in psychology and can also be used to satisfy the science and technology with laboratory general education requirement.

title: Spanish Islam, A.D. 711-A.D. 1492
descrip: Spanish Islam profoundly influenced medieval Judaism and Christendom alike - and through them, world civilization - from the Muslim conquest of most of Spain in A.D. 711 to the fall of the last Moorish stronghold in Granada in 1492 - on the eve of Columbus' voyage. Vital debate on modern Spanish identity centers on whether medieval Spain's Muslims and Jews were "foreign" or somehow "Spanish," too. A fruitful but uneasy 800-year coexistence ended in the expulsion of all Muslims and Jews, posing crucial questions regarding the roots of enduring cultural and religious strains in today's world.

title: Environmental Geochemistry: Chemistry of the Natural Systems
reviews: Go to class!  And go to office hours - Satish is EXTREMELY willing to help.
Good introductory course for environmental geochemistry

Prof. Myneni is a great lecturer! He's also very willing to meet with students in office hours to discuss anything they may not have understood initially. Given that the course had a pretty heavy chemistry focus, I would recommend previous chemistry knowledge (AP Chem or CHM 201/202).
Prof. Myneni is an engaging lecturer and is able to explain the material very clearly...not an intense science course
Take this course. It is literally one of my favorite chem courses ever! Satish is sooo nice, and non-judgmental
The lectures are somewhat dry, but the class isn't a ton of work and you get to go on field trips - take it if you're interested in the subject!
This is a good course that's not too difficult, especially for chemistry majors.  I recommend it!  Professor Myneni is a good lecturer and cares that his students learn the material!
This is a good course, and the material is very interesting. Take this course if you are interested in the connection between chemistry and natural environments.
yeah take it, a learned a lot about very fundamental stuff
you will learn alot about the environment if you take this class
prereqs: Introductory chemistry (CHM 201 or AP chemistry).
descrip: Covers topics including origin of elements; formation of the Earth; evolution of the atmosphere and oceans; atomic theory and chemical bonding; crystal chemistry and ionic substitution in crystals; reaction equilibria and kinetics in aqueous and biological systems; chemistry of high-temperature melts and crystallization process; and chemistry of the atmosphere, soil, marine and riverine environments. The biogeochemistry of contaminants and their influence on the environment will also be discussed.

title: Hegel's Phenomenology of Spirit
reviews: If you are interested in treating a very difficult text, this course is great. It's very hard, but if you like hard, also fun.
If you're willing to work hard and struggle with a classic philosophical text, this is an amazing class. You will learn loads.
Take it . . .

This is an amazing and challenging class for those who want to take a stab at Hegel. Just make sure that's really something you want to do because it can get frustrating and overwhelming. Never have I wished I could understand something so much, and found it so beyond my capabilities. At the same time, for me this was an exciting opportunity to be really challenged by a course, and Professor Stout is simply amazing.
Try to do the secondary readings. They prove to be really useful.
take it with Stout
prereqs: The course is intended for graduate students and undergraduates with at least some previous coursework in philosophy, political theory, or religious thought..
descrip: This seminar will focus on the conceptions of knowledge, recognition, ethical life, value conflict, freedom, morality, religion, and the Absolute developed in G.W.F. Hegel's most influential book, The Phenomenology of Spirit, which we will be reading in English translation.

title: Topics in Tonal Theory - String Quintets
descrip: A seminar devoted to such topics as theoretical models, analytical procedures, and the relationship of each to theories of composition and performance. Musical works will include string quintets by Mozart, Beethoven, Schubert, Mendelssohn, and Brahms.

title: The Roman Republic
reviews: A good course for general interest. It may be shocking at first to realize Flower doesn't use powerpoints or the blackboard, but her lectures (in the purest sense of the word) are very informative and can keep attention very well.
Anyone who is looking to learn more about the Roman Republic should take this course. For those who are interested in history, it is well worth the time.
Attend the lectures, because Professor Flower really gives you the need-to-know stuff out of Potter, because that reading was just dense and pretty tedious.
Break up the textbook reading or it will get really dry really fast!
Carpe canem!
Classics courses are the best!
Do the readings on time. Try to stay concentrated in lectures.

Don't feel the need to read 100% of assigned readings (meaning skim, but don't skip, some of the readings)- the midterm mostly covered the lectures, and most readings are never discussed in precept. That said, they could be useful for the end of term paper.
Don't take it unless you are internally motivated to learn about this on your own. If you're looking for great lectures to teach you about Rome, forget about it.

ENGINEERS OVER HERE!  So I took this course looking to PDF it.  After the midterm, I was considering taking the class for a grade because of how easy it was.  Then I got the grade back.  You know that thing AB majors complain about all the time, "grade deflation"?  Turns out it exists, and it sucks.  Luckily, professor Flower is incredibly nice and understands when people PDF the course.  If you do, as long as you finish the required work, you will not fail.  It's a great course, just don't be very surprised when your "easy" course starts giving you Cs for not already having a 3 year background in Roman History
Flower is a pretty good professor. It's not a very difficult class.
Fun course.

Go to lecture. Professor Flower is an excellent speaker. If you do any of the reading, read the text book because it clarifies the events very well. While the primary sources can be entertaining, some are very long and you don't need to read the whole thing to get what the author is trying to tell you.
Good class, very knowledgeable professor and interesting material. Do your readings regularly and try to make connections between the readings from one week to the next.
Good course, not bad for an HA if you need to get the requirement in; alot of reading though

I strongly recommend this course, no matter what reason you are considering taking it. There is a lot of reading each week, but if its broken up into smaller segments and you read some each day there is no reason you can't complete each week's readings. The lectures are interesting and discuss interesting controversial points of the readings. Professor Flower is extremely nice - and funny too! She is always available for questions and it probably one of the easiest people to ask for help if necessary.
I would advise taking it. Interesting material and good professor.
I would reccommend the course. It was very interesting.
I would strongly recommend this course
I would tell students to take this course and to do the readings, as they were very important to understanding the lecture.
I would tell them just to make sure they always do the precept reading.
If not for love of the Roman Republic, take this course because Professor Flower is just so great!
If you are interested in the history of the Roman Republic, this is the course for you. I suppose it's not for everyone, but if this is a topic that interests you, you will not be disappointed.
If you have any interest in Roman Republican history, take it.
If you take this, focus your energies on the moral outlooks of the classical authors.  That is much more valuable than the textbook.
If you want a background on the Roman Republic and need an HA, take this course. Professor Flower is engaging and precepts are informative and eye-opening. A good use of my time at Princeton.

If you're interested in Roman history/classics, definitely take this class because Professor Flower is just phenomenal. However, be prepared to read a lot of ancient texts and go into quite a lot of detail about historical figureheads.
If you're interested in the subject, than it's worth taking.
Interesting class but not easy.

It is pretty easy and pretty interesting, the professor and preceptors are great, so if you are looking for an HA or are just interested in Rome, I can't think of a reason to not recommend the course.
It's a good class if you are interested in the material already. If not, probably not the best choice.
Keep up with the reading!
Keeping up with the reading is essential
Nothing wrong with it, if you need an HA.
Overall a solid course! I would definitely recommend it to those interested in Roman history.
Read on time, and enjoy the lectures but don't stress about extreme note taking because the lectures are based on readings.
Stay on top of the readings and meet with your preceptor about your paper.
TAKE IT! Even if you aren't that interested in ancient history, it is very worthwhile and very easy to do well if you pay attention and are involved.

Take it if Prof. Flower is teaching. She is an engaging lecturer and really funny; she is what makes the class enjoyable. Careful: she lectures directly from her notes without a PowerPoint or any other visual aids except the occasional map.
Take the course if you need to get a requirement out of the way. Not a bad course and if you are interested in history, this class generally explores the broader topics regarding Rome and its fall.
Take this class!

Take this course - and, especially if you are interested in Classics, take it early.  I regret not taking this class earlier because it provided me with a new context for Latin literature.  Make sure you really spend time engaging with the primary sources, and try to see them as lively and fun (for instance, Polybius is very sassy about other historians' inadequacies).  The lectures are entertaining; Professor Flower seems at first to be quiet and almost monotone, but is in fact very clever and interesting.  Even if you are not interested in Classics, this is a great history class to take to understand some of the origins of Western Civilization.

Take this course if at all interested in history because the teachers are great and the readings have some fantastic stories. Just be sure that on the exams, you pay more attention not to the specifics that you learned during the readings but the general trends that are talked about in lecture, as the exams almost solely focus on lecture material.
Take this course if you are at all interested in the time period.

Take this course if you think there's something useful to be learned from history!  If you aren't terribly familiar with Roman history, don't worry.  And if you consider yourself fairly knowledgeable in Roman history, you can expect to deepen your understanding and be exposed to the details that really make for a complete picture of Republican Rome.
Take this course! It's really awesome. Do the readings, engage, and you'll get a good grade. Awesome material that's surprisingly quite relevant.
Take this freshman or sophomore year.
The course is great, but not sure if classics is my calling.

The readings are often long and a bit dull, but if you have a genuine interest in the subject matter this is a very enjoyable course. So long as you do most of the reading, it is not too difficult to do well in the class.

There is no reason to hesitate taking the class--it genuinely does not assume prior knowledge of Roman history, but even those who had already been exposed to early Roman history would be greatly informed by the depth of scholarship in the course.

This course is a good overview of the Roman Republic. If you have a solid foundation in this subject area, don't take this course! It can be tedious and not engaging if you know a lot of the history already. If you don't, i could see it being a great introductory course to Roman history.

This is a great course to fulfill a distribution requirement if that is what you are looking for. Some of the readings are boring, but the lectures are really interesting and the work is not difficult to keep on top of.

This is a very easy course, and had the highest curve of any class I've taken.  It does not take a lot of work outside of class.  At bare minimum either go to lecture or do the readings, both is not necessary.
To do the reading and broaden your ways of studying. I found some interesting YouTube videos that put an amusing spin on the Roman Republic which helped me study for my mid-term.
Would take for a relatively relaxing class.
Would've liked to see more general themes emphasized. I felt the course was very specific without enough overview.
good PDF, interesting material.
descrip: A study of the causes and consequences of one small city-state's rise to world empire, through analysis of primary sources in translation. Emphasis on the development of Roman society, and the growth and demise of republican government.

title: Explaining Values
reviews:
Fascinating class on moral responsibility, free will, and the criminal justice system. Loved every minute. Prof. McGeer is a really down to earth and cool professor as well. Things seemed to move quickly at first, but then it all started to come together.
Highly recommend.
I would strongly recommend this class to other students, especially students with a strong interest in philosophy.
If you're interested in free will, moral responsibility, or the interactions between philosophy and science, this is a great course.
It requires attention, hard work and passion but is rewarding and interesting.
Really 2 classes in 1. First half is an analytic philosophy class on moral responsibility. Second half is an applied ethics class about punishment and the criminal justice system.
Take it, and be prepared to think in new ways.

The course is a bit more focused on the meta-ethics component, so if you're looking for a more normatives-focused course, this could be frustrating. However, it is a good course overall, and one that lingers on in your thoughts outside of the classroom.
prereqs: One other course in Philosophy or permission of instructor.
descrip: This seminar will focus on the philosophy of responsibility, blame and punishment. It will examine how human interactions are permeated by evaluative understandings of agency and responsibility, and whether such evaluative understandings are well grounded. It will consider what implications this has for inter-personal relations, as well as for social institutions such as criminal justice. We will approach these issues from a multi-disciplinary perspective, examining how philosophical, scientific and institutional considerations can be brought into useful contact with one another.

title: Advanced Inorganic Chemistry
reviews: A good survey of inorganic.
Great lectures!
fun class.
descrip: A detailed examination of bonding and structure in transition metal complexes is undertaken. A variety of spectroscopic tools ranging from UV-visible spectroscopy and vibrational techniques to UHV electron spectroscopies is considered in this context. Charge transfer reactivity and photochemical processes is investigated based on electronic structure considerations. Examples are drawn from the literature.

title: Introduction to the Quantum Theory
reviews: Be sure to go to Professor Happer's office hours; he is absurdly helpful and welcoming.
Most of PHY 305 is just a review of PHY 208.
Requirement for PHY majors, may be of interest also to AST majors.  Otherwise not much appeal, especially opposed to PHY 208.
Shame you have to take it.
Study.

The quality of Prof. Happer's lectures was good although he focused too much on unnecessary mathematical details and not on the big mathematical picture. I think that a lot of topics from the beginning of the semester should be eliminated as they were already covered in PHY 208. I would suggest that we should cover a little bit more of the formalism.
This class is less work than thermal physics. It gives you a chance to go back an try to understand the stuff you missed in PHY 208.

Very little work; Happer is a great lecturer who (although slow on working out algebra) easily brings in examples from the real world and the lab to support the theory we learn. Definitely take if you want to learn how the stuff you learned in 208 relates to the outside world.

You have to take it as a physics major, otherwise don't. For me, it seemed like The first half was a bad rehash of quantum 1, the second half a cursory skim of other topics, which was just confusing. That being said, Happer's psets weren't very long or difficult, once he taught you the material in class.
You probably have to take it.

You take this course because you have to, but you do NOT have to use Griffiths. Do yourself a favour and buy yourself a real QM book, because Griffiths is not going to be an adequate reference, whereas Shankar or Sakurai will actually teach you all the basic QM you need to know.
make sure to have taken the earlier physics classes before this one
prereqs: PHY 208.
descrip: This course is a continuation of PHY 208. We will continue to develop the formalism of quantum mechanics and to explore its basis. We will apply our methods to phenomena from atomic, high energy, and condensed matter physics.

title: Contagion
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Britain and France in the Eighteenth Century
reviews: Consider reading general survey books of eighteenth-century Britain and France before taking the course. This will give you a good foundation.

I would definitely recommend the course to other students. I would recommend, though, that they aim to read some general histories of both Britain and France before starting the class, so that they could go in with a firm background upon which to build.
If you scan the reading on Dropbox (like we did) make sure people are responsible for scanning the introductions to the books, whether assigned or not, and the endnotes.
Take it because the professors are interesting.
Take it if you're interested. It's a unique and interesting course.
descrip: A survey of the main themes of British and French history in the eighteenth-century. Topics include nationalism, forms of government, social structure, women and gender, and the French Revolution.

title: Elementary Arabic I
reviews: Arabic 101 is an awesome class; you will learn a lot, have fun (especially with Eva), and work a lot. This is not an easy class to get an A in, but by the end of the semester even with a B you will feel very confident in your Arabic skills.
Arabic is a difficult language, which requires several hours of practice outside of the class; however with help from instructors it is possible to learn and enjoy the language.
Arabic requires a lot of work to master the basics of the language and you have to be committed to it, but it is really fun and a very rewarding language to learn.
Be dedicated to memorization early on! It took me too long to do that, I feel. And make sure that you do upkeep of what you've learned already.
Be patient, do all the homework, and be prepared to invest. It's worth it in the end.

Definitely take it, try to get Eva Slowinska...she is the best! So helpful, and always does so much for the students and makes sure they understand everything. We had so many office hour gatherings, and she would feed us and just practice with us for hours! I love this class!
Do it if you have a reason to lear the language.
Do take the time to study the vocab and grammar, even if it's just for 15 minutes a day. It will make it much easier when it comes time to take the final.
Don't fall behind. Never think about making up work because you simply won't. Just suck it up and finish the homework.

Don't hesitate to take the course if you are interested in the language.  The only part that is somewhat scary is that you have homework assignments every night.  The class is fun and interesting and you learn more than just the language
Go for it. It can be challenging at times, but it is well worth it.
If you have a general interest in Arabic, take this class!
If you have no prior experience with Arabic, as is the case with myself, know that most of the other students will have at least some familiarity with Arabic or other Semitic languages.
If you want to start a non-romance language, Arabic is a great option.
If you're in the class because you want to learn Arabic, it's going to be a great class. If not, then you'll hate it.

If you're like me and coming into this course with no knowledge of Arabic whatsoever, you may struggle at points. Don't give up; the instructors are extremely helpful, and the progress you make is certainly rewarding.
Just stay on top of your work. Study hard everyday.
Know what you're getting in to and be prepared to work.  If you're willing to do it, it's rewarding.
Make flashcards for vocabulary, don't get behind on homework, show up to class on time.
Obviously, it is difficult to learn a new language, but for Arabic it is worth it. Professor Laffan is a great teacher.
Put in the time you need to learn the material, and take advantage of Arabic related events and tables, if you can. I wish I did more of that.
Stay on top of the vocabulary and grammar, and practice speaking as much as possible!!
Take it with Nancy Coffin!
Take this course, but be honest with your passion for learning a new language. It will be a lot of work and you need to dedicate the time to it - there's no other option. Ustadha Eva is great!
The course moves very quickly, so it is important to stay on top of your work in order to do well.

This course is a lot of work- at least 10 hours of homework a week. I am happy that I took the class because I learned a lot. But it is a big commitment. Professor Slowinska is a really good professor. She really cares about her students, and will take the time to work with them to better their language abilities.
This course will introduce the basics of formal Arabic and some aspects of Arabic culture.  Make sure to keep up with the material and to practice vocab.

This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity! Take Arabic! Try to get Ustaadha Eva (Professor Slowinska) because she's very helpful and a great teacher. It's a ton of work but it will be worth it for how much you learn.
This is an excellent introduction to a challenging yet rewarding language.
Work hard, don't fall behind on homework.
take it if you have to i guess. i probably wouldn't take it for fun
prereqs: No credit is given for ARA 101 unless it is followed by ARA 102..
descrip: This class develops the basic structures and vocabulary for understanding, speaking, writing and reading Modern Standard Arabic, the shared formal variety of Arabic used throughout the Arab world. Students will also gain some familiarity with both Egyptian and Syrian colloquial dialects. Classroom activities are designed to foster communication and cultural competence through comprehension and grammar exercises, skits, conversation, and the use of a variety of audio-visual materials.

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Engineering - Trustworthy Computing
reviews: Choose a topic for the course project that has a narrow scope.  Do not try and do too much, after all it is just a course project.
You don't need a security background for the course.
descrip: Current topics in trustworthy computing, especially hardware-enabled trust and security. Topics include enabling hardware to thwart attacks (e.g., with randomization), measuring and characterizing normal software-hardware behavior, hardware that does not leak information, building cryptographic support into computers, dynamic information flow tracking, building resilient computers that operate under both faults and attacks, multicore security, secure virtual machines and secure cloud storage.

title: Responses of Freshwater Systems to Atmospheric Acid Deposition
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Introduction to the History of Art: Ancient to Medieval
reviews: A nice distribution requirement and not something you learn everyday.  Take it.
Attend lectures and take good notes.
Be prepared to have to understand art.
Be prepared to read, write, and talk a lot about art. There is a lot of memorization involved for the exams, as the course covers many civilizations/areas and centuries.
Come to class!
Constantly seek clarification from your preceptor regarding the assignments and exams.
Decent survey course of ancient to medieval art. Make sure you like this material, almost no paintings. Mostly sculpture.
Do it if you like art history.
Go to lectures and don't try to memorize everything the night before the exam.

I think this was a really good course. It was both interesting and had a manageable workload. Also, the multiple lecturers and hands-on approach to precepts made it engaging beyond a normal large lecture class setting. It made me want to take another art history class during my time at Princeton.

I would highly recommend other students to take this class. In high school we never really spent time on the artwork as we made our way through history. This class gives a great overview of art as it has progressed from ancient times to medieval with specific descriptions of key pieces of artwork.
I would recommend this course to anyone who doesn't have a background in art or art history, but wants to take a course in the department.
If you have ever been interested in art you should most certainly take this course!
If you want an entry-level art history course, this is a good start.
It is not so hard but also not that interesting.
Like most courses, you'll get out of it what you put in, but it's worth putting in time because you will come out of it with a better appreciation of art.
Pretty much what you'd expect.
Sure! Okay for a PDF.
Take it! They are a bit picky about the test some times, but overall the course is not a back breaker. Record lectures if possible.
Take it. Pay extra attention on the lectures because that is mainly what you need to know
Take this class for an easy PDF - it is interesting as well as simple to grasp.
Take this course if you want to learn more about art history or if you just need an easy humanities class. It's interesting and engaging and you can have some fun learning!
Take this course. It is very engaging and interesting
This course is a great introduction to art. Go to lectures, go to precepts, and you'll do well!
go to lecture. Take good notes. do the reading
descrip: An introduction to art and architecture from Antiquity to the late Middle Ages, including non-Western traditions. The course gives an overview of key monuments and works of art from diverse historical periods, regions, and cultures and introduces students to the basic interpretative tools of art historical research as well as to the history of the discipline.

title: Financial History
reviews: (fall 2012) Terrific material - it covers a range of topics that would usually require multiple classes to cover. The readings were overwhelming and the lectures (Professor James) were bad.

Avoid this class. It had so much potential to be an interesting class but fell terribly short. You are assigned in the high hundreds (and in one case a cool 1000) pages of dense, difficult, and ultimately unhelpful reading each week. Lectures are poorly structured and the exams tested a strange set of facts rather than cohesive themes.
Avoid this, there are so many better classes on the same subject here
Do not take this course unless you have a strong finance or economics background.
Don't take it with James.
Dont take this.
Harold James is a terrible lecturer, but if you're interested in the material, take this class and do the readings.
I would recommend the course if you are very interested in the material.
If you are really intent on learning a lot about financial history, mostly through readings, this would be the course for you.
Lots and lots of reading but interesting and well worth it.
The class is interesting, but prepare to be frustrated.

This class is not easy. Be prepared for a huge amount of reading and a lot of effort to follow along and integrate all the material for yourself, because it won't be done in lecture. You will definitely need a functional understanding of macroeconomics, monetary theory, finance and international political economy to do well.
Useful material, a bit dry lectures, unpredictable readings but overall recommended
descrip: The course examines the history of financial innovation and its consequences. It examines the evolution of trading practices, bills of exchange, government bonds, equities, banking activity, derivatives markets, and securitization. How do these evolve in particular state or national settings, how are the practices regulated, how do they relate to broader development? What happens as financial instruments are traded across state boundaries, and how does an international financial order evolve? What are the effects of international capital mobility? How is resulting conflict and instability managed, on both a national and international level?

title: Mathematical Methods of Engineering Analysis II
reviews: Basically a differential equations course.  If someone like differential equations, they should take it.
Be ready to participate and try to 'think' while taking the course.

Bring the book to lecture. Take notes with the book rather than copying everything down from the board as the material is straight out of it. Know that you will need to consult outside resources when the book doesn't explain something.

Bring the textbook to class, and use the lectures as an opportunity to clarify the material in the book. The class covers the material of the textbook very closely, but the professor's presentation of the material is clearer.
Having some knowledge from the Undergraduate about the concepts certainly helps a lot. Irrespective of that, I think this is a very important course whichever direction you chose your research to go.
I would definitely recommend this course. Professor Kevrekidis teaches it very well and the material is presented in a clear manner.
I would review your undergraduate linear algebra and differential equation notes.
I would tell student to follow along in the book, because it was followed pretty closely in the lectures.
Prof. Kevrekidis does a good job of actually using the textbook he made you buy, so try to read the chapters/sections before the corresponding lectures if possible.
Required course for CBE. Would be beneficial for students outside of CBE interested in computational research.
The material in lecture is straight from the book; read ahead or follow along in class to help.
This is an excellent course and it was taught very well. Anyone considering further studies in chemical engineering should take this course as it also used chemical engineering problems in teaching.
higly recomended.
descrip: Solutions of ordinary differential, partial differential and finite difference equations with emphasis on second order linear partial differential equations and their applications. Topics include special functions, eigenvalues and eigenfunctions, Sturm-Liouville analysis, Green's functions, explicit and implicit finite difference methods, stability analysis, transform methods, asymptotic analysis.

title: Design with Nanotechnologies
reviews: Apart from learning about nanotechnologies, this course will implicitly teach you how to read papers to find out main issues in technologies today. Then you will come up with ideas to fix the existing problems. Finally, you will start implementing your ideas while learning how to present your work in a well-written paper.
I highly recommended this course. Prof. Niraj Jha is very nice. The content of this course is very useful. This course also introduce a new sub-field in circuit design.
Professor Jha is extremely nice and receptive to feedback.
prereqs: ELE 206: Introduction to Logic Design.
descrip: Introduction to nanotechnologies; threshold logic/majority logic and their applications to RTDs, QCA and SETs; nanowire based crossbars and PLAs; carbon nanotube based circuits; double-gate CMOS-based circuits; reversible logic for quantum computing; non-volatile memory; nanopipelining; testing; and defect tolerance.

title: The Philosophy of Urban History
reviews: Careful, he'll call you out for skipping class!
Rarely but if you are really interested in philosophy, history (I mean real philosophy and history, not architectural ones) and architecture. This is the one.
descrip: The class introduces students to the branch of the philosophy of history that specializes in cities. Cities are social entities that exist at an intermediate scale between the micro-level of individuals and the macro-level of society as a whole. Social science has tended to focus at those two extremes, while the intermediate meso-level has been neglected. The philosophy of urban history aims at remedying this situation, stressing not only the role of cities as historical actors, but also the role of other meso-level social entities from local communities and institutional organizations to urban regions and provinces.

title: Electricity and Magnetism
descrip: A systematic treatment of the theory of electromagnetic phenomena from an advanced standpoint. Maxwell's equations are discussed with special attention to their physical meaning. Other topics include potential theory, macroscopic media, waves in simple media and in bounded structures, radiation, scattering and the limitations of the theory. Part of the time in class will be devoted to consideration of selected problems from the E&M section of previous preliminary exams.

title: American Politics
reviews: As with most 200 level POL courses it's not really much worth taking unless you have no background in American Politics or don't follow the news at all. If you feel you can keep up with it, I would recommend taking a 300 level one instead.
Did not enjoy the course while taking it but when I look back I learned a lot.
Do not take this course if you have no interest in politics and you are only taking it as a distribution requirement.
Do the reading.
Do the readings when they are assigned. They seem boring, but once you actually do them (or at least most of them), they aren't that bad.
Do the readings, participate in precept; if you have a good grasp of political issues, you should be fine!
Don't get behind on the reading
Don't let yourself fall behind on the readings.
Don't take it unless you are looking for a political theory course.
Form a group and combine notes on readings, it can be difficult to finish every reading on time alone.
Go to the lectures
Good course to PDF if you are moderately interested in the subject matter - especially if you took a politics class in high school.
Good intro course, but could have gotten all of this from high school AP Gov.

Grading is HARSH. Range of students from freshman athletes to senior WWS majors. A lot of work and reading for a 200 level class. There are better classes out there for Politics majors. Professor and Preceptor were nice, but not particularly engaging.

Great class, but it is not an easy A.  I took it thinking it would be a walk in the park after taking AP American Government in high school, but that was not the case.  The lecture material is easy to understand, but the readings are much more complex.  Tests and papers are only about readings, not class material.
Great overview of American Politics.
Great overview of the American political system. At times a bit simplistic as a senior in the department, but if you aren't familiar with the material of the course it is a must-take.

Hey guys. I really liked this class, but that is because I am a U.S. government nerd. I thought the topics were really interesting- the class gives you a broad theoretical overview of how the three branches work. If you've taken AP Government, this class will probably be pretty easy to you. 

Definitely take this class if you are trying to fill a WWS requirement and find domestic policy interesting. The class does not focus on policy as much as how the structures in government influence our country's leaders' decisions.
I recommend this course earlier in your Princeton career.
I suggest students keep up with the readings.

I was disappointed by this class, in part because I didn't realize McCarty's preference for assigning empirical studies over more theoretical writings and in part because the readings, lectures and precepts were dry and uninteresting. There are probably better classes to take than this one.
I would advice all students to take this course. Everyone should know how the U.S political system works.

I would definitely recommend it!  Great intro class to American Politics!  The readings are interesting and while you could definitely get away without doing most of them, they are worth reading simply for personal knowledge and interest!
I would tell other students to muscle through this class! It is necessary and a lot will come out of it, but only in the end does it become clear what was interesting and useful to learn.
I would tell the student to thoroughly read all of the material before each precept in order to be prepared for the discussions and debate.
I wouldn't recommend it, not particularly interesting
I wouldn't recommend this class.

If you genuinely want to understand the structure of the US gov, consider taking this class. But if you already feel like you have basic knowledge of the three branches of gov, the bureaucracy, media, etc, this class will be infuriating for you.
If you need the requirement, or are interested in the material, you'll be okay in this class. If you are not, it might get too boring at times to be enjoyable.
If you're a politics major, you have to take it. But if you want an SA, it's a good one, and very relevant for anyone who wants to understand American politics.

If you're interested in American politics, then this class might be good for you to explore the subject.  However, it wasn't taught very well, so I don't think you should take it if you want a sample of the politics department.
If you're interested in political theory like the constitutionality of the filibuster and whether judicial elections should be allowed, take the class. Otherwise, I would think twice.

If you're trying to decide whether or not to be a politics major, this might not help you make your decision (I'm still as uncertain as I was when I walked in!). It is a class that has good information, though. Lectures aren't EXCITING but aren't boring either.
It is a lot of reading, but it is a great class to take. You will learn a lot, not all positive things, mostly negative, about the American political system.
It's a fine 200 level course. Nothing to write home about.
Know the arguments of each reading. Participate in precept.
Maybe look for a more specific politics class; it might be more interesting and intellectually stimulating
McCarty is a clear, interesting lecturer. If Mike Barber is still a preceptor try to be in his class. Overall I'd definitely recommend this course to anyone interested in american politics.
Not a bad way to fulfill the WWS core requirement, but I wouldn't go out of my way to take it. There are more interesting classes out there.
Pay attention to the readings, and if you have trouble with them, seek help immediately.
Prepare for a lot of reading (they're all interesting).
Read!
Take a 300 level politics course instead.

Take if you've had high school background in American Government and are very interested in politics, as the readings are long/tedious if you're not interested in the subject. It goes further than AP Gov, so you still learn something.
Take it if you aren't an American Politics expert. If you are, you will probably get an A, but you won't enjoy it.
Take it whether your a politics major or not.
Take it! Professor McCarty is great, as a preceptor too
Take it, pretty straightforward. More reading than I thought.

Take it, though I feel like science kids just looking to get an SA out of the way might benefit more from it because it's kinda sciency and the non-sciency parts are common knowledge for WWS or POL majors.
Take it. It's very informative. from a study group and divide the readings.
The class hasn't been too hard so far, but take some caffeine pills for the lectures.
The course is great if you want to get a really complete knowledge of the US government.  I found it to be very stimulating
The course is very interesting and good way of getting into the basics of American politics. The lectures aren't always the most engaging but the concepts they cover were usually pretty interesting.

This class will give you a very basic introduction to the American political system; take it if you feel like you need a 101 course. McCarty?s lectures are a little monotonous so try eating or something to stay awake. The paper assignments and exams are all very fair.

This class with McCarty is pretty boring, but it is not very hard. I feel like a didnt learn a lot of facts about American politics ie how the systems actually work and was just overloaded with rather boring, nuanced scholarly arguments.

This course is very dull and unorganized. I felt lost during the course, unsure of the direction that the course was taking, with limited understanding about the "key" issues. Comments on papers were very limited and did not explain the generally-unfair grading. If you have to take this class, pace yourself during the readings, skip a lot of the empirical evidence, and pay closest attention to the "great debates" introduced in each week's readings.
This is a decent course

This is a very good course, but it has a lot of readings that are sometimes very in depth and hard to get through. The papers and midterm are not too difficult and the prompts are fairly straightforward. Like any other class, if you go to lecture and do the readings, the class is reasonable. Lastly, the textbook you are given can be crucial when writing some of the papers and the lectures are extremely important, but sometimes difficult to sit through.
Try to determine the most important readings and the most important sections of the readings because it is a lot.
Worth taking
Yes, take it if you want to learn more about American politics but don't really know much about the structure of things.
definitely take this class and stay on top of the reading.
do it
take it if you want to do lots of reading
descrip: A survey of the institutions of American democracy. Topics will include the Constitutional order, federalism, legislative deliberation, executive power, elections and representation, interest groups and social movements, the courts, and policymaking.

title: Readings in Kiswahili Literature and East African Culture
prereqs: SWA 101 through SWA 107, or permission of instructor.
descrip: This advanced Kiswahili course will help students gain a higher level of language proficiency by applying grammatical skills learned in Elementary and Intermediate Kiswahili to topics addressing the language and culture of the Swahili speakers in East Africa. Coursework will focus on readings, writings, and oral performance activities on selected issues related to the history, geography, politics, language, literature, and cultural practices of the people of Kenya, Tanzania, and other Swahili speaking regions of Eastern Africa.

title: Nature, Culture, Life
descrip: This course offers an ecocritical perspective on the nature-culture dualism that has patterned much of Western thought from the 17th to the 21th century, and asks to what extent vitalism presents an alternative to anthropocentric dualism. Setting philosophy (Descartes, Kant, Bergson) in dialogue with anthropology (Rousseau, Levi-Strauss, Descola), science (Darwin, Bichat, Saint-Hilaire), and literature (Michelet, Thoreau, Kafka), we will question both human exceptionalism and its vision of nature as inert matter.

title: Integrated Building Studios
reviews: Work on having a good final presentation and practice in a way that they can over come their stress in the final very stressful days.
You will probably have to take this course anyways, but it is certainly worth your time!
descrip: Explores architecture as a social art and the spatial organization of the human environment. Projects include a broad range of problem types, including individual buildings, groups of buildings, urban districts, and landscapes.

title: Junior Independent Work
prereqs: For each project, the requirements are set in consultation with the faculty advisor, and depend somewhat on the nature of the project. An oral presentation during Reading Period (as per departmental schedule) and a written final report is required. A copy of the report must be turned into the ELE Undergraduate Office Dean's Date. Details of requirements are available from the ELE Undergraduate Office. This course is open to qualified sophomores as well as juniors, provided they are adequately prepared..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a "state-of-the-art" project in electrical engineering. Topics may be selected from suggestions by faculty members or proposed by the students. The final choice must be approved by the faculty advisor. There is no formal reading list; however, a literature search is a normal part of most projects.

title: Implementations of Quantum Information
reviews: Approach the course bearing in mind that mastery of all topics is unlikely; stick to one or two subjects to devote time to and master, and treat all other subjects as overviews only.
Honestly, this is ONE class where I thought "wow, that was awesome" after EVERY SINGLE LECTURE! Definitely worthwhile, especially if you are interested in quantum computation.
I recommend this class to the one who wants know more about quantum computing. This class will give you a macro-scope of this field without ignoring important technique details.
Keep up on the readings and you'll be ok.

Reading the papers may seem a bit hard at first, but grind through them and read the relevant references until you're comfortable with the material. Also, ask Houck your questions -- he responds to email in minutes.
This was one of the best courses I've taken at  Princeton.  If you have an interest in quantum computing, take this course!
make sure to keep up with the paper reading.
descrip: An overview of several approaches to implementing quantum information and computation, touching briefly on quantum algorithms, but the main focus being physical systems.
