In particular, the course discusses what makes a good quantum system, the physics behind the leading implementations, and the limitations on each. Topics covered will include: superconducting qubits, electron and nuclear spin qubits, and ion trap qubits, as well as descriptions of gate-based, adiabatic, and topologically protected quantum architectures.

title: Introduction to Programming Systems
reviews: A must take for anyone interested in computers.

A very awesome class, if you are interested in computer science and systems.  The expectations are very clear, the lectures were interesting, the precepts were super helpful, and there was lots of help available if I got stuck.  Sure, it may take a bit of work, but it really is a great class!

Aardvark. If you are taking this class, you probably have no choice. Some people love it, some people hate it. Go to ACM coffee chats or PWiCS advising study breaks to discuss if this class is right for you. Make sure you get Dondero as your preceptor. Really. It's important.
Allow time for debugging and testing. Start programs early. If you have any questions, go to office hours.
Assignments take a lot of time, and can be frustrating. Be prepared!
Be prepared to debug, start early on projects. Very satisfying to complete.
Be ready to put a lot of hours into this course. However, there is always help for you in your peers and instructors.
Better than 226.

COS 217 is a rigorous introduction to low-level computer science that will take a lot of time and will not come intuitively. I would suggest that somebody looking to get a taste of computing on the side avoid this class like the plague. However, computer science majors and those who are really interested will find it extraordinarily rewarding. ALSO: take it in the fall, you need the extra time to get the assignments done.

COS 217 programs take ALOT of time to finish . There are quite of bit of nuances and quirks that don't appear in JAVA and it's very important to pay attention to details when doing the programming assignments. The course itself is rather boring and tedious for the first half of the semester (learning C isn't as easy as learning JAVA), but it gets much more interesting for the last half of the semseter.
Definitely take it.  The assignments are spaced out well so the workload is not too heavy, and the material is amazing.
Difficult, but rewarding class! Definitely start on the assignments early.
Don't wait until the last minute for your assignments. I did, and bad things happened.
Excellent course! Definitely take it if you enjoy coding and understanding systems programming.

FIrst of all, if at all possible you should get Bob Dondero as your preceptor.  He is extremely helpful, learning your name, responding to every single post on Piazza, and generally is very friendly and wants you to do well in the course.  Prof. Singh was fine.  Generally speaking if you don't like other COS you won't like this, but if you have any interest in the deeper workings of the computer, below what you learn in classes like 126 or 226, this is a really interesting class and I highly recommend it.  The assignments tended to be really time consuming and challenging so get a good head start.
Give yourself enough time to do the assignments. Also, doing the readings may or may not be helpful.
Go to office hours and ask questions early on if you get behind.
Great class. Lectures, assignments, and precepts were interesting and engaging. The midterm was frustrating.
I really enjoyed the class, though most people think it takes up quite a bit of time usually, so be prepared.
I thought I would like it despite everyone saying it was awful, but I was wrong.

I took this class already knowing C, but still learned a lot about how the compiler works, how memory is managed, what assembly code and machine code are like, etc. It's a great class! Start on assignments early, and then it won't be bad at all.
If you did 126 and then 226, 217 is more work than you're expecting.
If you have to take it, then take it. But COS 226 is more fun and the assignments are more interesting. 217 is low-level, lots of debugging, etc.
If you like COS and want to dedicate time to this class, it is great. However, if you are looking to just learn a bit more about COS casually, this is not the class for you.

If you like CS, coding, or computers in general, this is probably a worthwhile class for you. Be prepared to work a lot (J.P.'s exams are especially hard), but I'd say the effort is definitely worth it.

If you're at all interested in how computers work, take this course. You will understand the process of programming from the program design level all the way down to the code that the machine reads. To see how the machine reads that code, I highly recommend taking ELE206 (circuits and logic design) at the same time. They collide a few weeks after the midterm, and it is awesome.
It is a low of work so be prepared.
It is extremely time consuming but the material is great.
It is worth taking it you like programming, otherwise it might be a bit too dense.

It seems like the midterm and final are significantly easier during the spring. The difference seems so vast to me that I don't know if I could recommend that anybody take this class in the fall. I also think that there is no reason to take the class if you cannot get Dondero as a preceptor. I would recommend the class for the material, not for the current "balance" of the class on the whole.
It takes a lot of focus and hard work. If you are not looking for a challenging course, stay away from this class.
It will teach you how to code in C pretty well, which is something you should learn how to do, but it makes no attempt to make the process fun, like the 126 and 226 assignments do.
It's a big time commitment -- one assignment (number 4) took me about ~20 hours. Great course if you're willing to put in the time.
It's a tough course, and JP's exams are a bit of a wildcard. Still, it's helpful if you want to go farther in computer science.
It's hard tho.
It's pretty good. Great programming assignments. Good for COS people naturally, and anyone who wants to understand what goes on under the hood of your laptop. Pretty dense material though.

JP's lectures were okay, but occasionally long-winded and difficult to follow. He didn't structure the exams very well based on the material we'd learned, and overall seemed pretty haphazard about the class even though he's taught it a few times before. Regardless, the class is interesting and rigorous, and if you take it with JP be sure to take practice midterms and finals from the other years that he's taught this class. For preceptors, try to get Dondero or Sasha.
Keep up with the assignments!
Make sure to allot sufficient time to compete the assignments. Procrastination is an easy way to make your grade drop well below what you deserve in the class.
Make sure you have the time for this course in the second half of the semester. It picks up pace rather quickly.
Only buy the Bryant and O'Hallaron textbook, and use it well.

Probably worth taking because the material is very relevant, although you'd probably pick it up by taking other COS classes throughout your time here. However, the assignments are very tedious and the lectures are incredibly dull. Get a good preceptor because it can make a huge difference.

Professor Dondero, if you ever read course evaluations on SCORE... Thank you so much for your hardwork! You were there for us almost 24/7. We learned so much from your precepts this semester. You are the best instructor I've ever had in Princeton.
READ THE BOOK!
Reconsider.
Start assignments early!
Start assignments early, and try for Dondero as your preceptor.
Start early on the assignments.
Start every assignment very, very early. You are going to read this and be like "oh sure, yeah" but ACTUALLY. START. EARLY.
Start the assignments early and never be afraid to approach Professor Dondero, he is very helpful!
Start the assignments early because you will never know exactly how long you will have to spend debugging them. Also, always have a design plan before you write any code.
Start the assignments early. Always.
Start the programming assignments early so you can get help when necessary!  Definitely keep up with the material.

TAKE IT! You'll have to put more time into projects than COS 126 or 226, but they're so much more interesting. You actually build worthwhile programs and learn about the inner workings of computers at the same time

Take COS 226 first if you can, especially if you are skipping 126 like I was. The assignments in 217 are fun if you start early, but if you leave only 3 days or less for debugging, they can be a nightmare. Take it, but be careful that the time commitment is enormous.

Take it because you have to but also because it's interesting. The assignments are very well designed, and the material is essential. JP Singh is a decent lecturer. The real machine driving the course is Bob Dondero, who basically wrote every piece of code you use. He is a fantastic preceptor, but he without fail will keep you 7-8 minutes after his precept time is over every single class. Plan your schedule accordingly.
Take it before COS 226!

Take it if you are not taking many other courses at the same time. There're many readings and the programming assignments consume quite a lot of time- sometimes an entire weekend. So make sure you do not have several other problem sets due every week.
Take it if you have to, or if you're interested in computer science.
Take it only if it fulfills a requirement
Take it! It's so much better than 126, you learn a lot more, and you have a better understanding of cos beyond just C/Java.
Take it, but expect a lot of work.
Take it, it is easy and teaches you how to write more understandable code.
Take this class if you're interested in COS. Make sure you get Dondero though.
Technically worthwhile!

The assignments can take some time, so be prepared and start early. Think modular when you get to the later assignments, it will save you lots of time. The lectures on things like building and performance etc. matter and you will be tested on it. This course is on the guts of computers, and in some ways it reminds me of bio courses in that there are lots of diagrams with arrows pointing around with each change of state, and there is a lot to memorize for exams.

The class is a lot of work for a couple days before each assignment is due, which is every week and a half. It is very easy to get help on the assignments. The class will give you a much better understanding of how computer systems work and will make you a better programmer.
The course is a lot of work but you also learn a lot.
The course was a strong introduction to systems level programming.
The material is good, though the class organization is not.

This class will greatly improving your programming skills. Low-level programming is really interesting, and some of the assignments are a lot of fun. Beware of exams, since they cover very random topics. Sasha Koruga is a decent preceptor, but he moves through material quickly, so make sure you pay attention.

This course is not hard. They tell you exactly what to do for assignments (even in the "On your own" parts, they always cover a similar thing in lecture or precept). It could be time consuming if you program haphazardly and without thought, but with careful planning and attention to detail, debugging isn't hard at all. Exams are pretty pedantic, but curve decently. If you're a cos major or getting the certificate you need it, otherwise it's pretty easy and I guess you learn something.

This is a good course for learning more about programming, learning C, and learning about how languages work. The people that do the best already know a bunch about COS and work way ahead, but that's just kinda COS.

Take the help they offer you. If you put things off to times when you can't get help you will use your time much less efficiently.
This is a great computer science course. If you're looking to learn about programming systems and pick up some C along the way, this is the course for it.
This is a very hard but very rewarding course.

Very interesting material.  Be prepared to work, especially during the second half of the course, after you hit Assembly.  Not a course for the faint of heart, but you'll learn a ton, and it's all really cool stuff.
Very tough class, but worthwhile in the end. The assignments are very rewarding, but the exams are unnecessarily difficult.
a man crush on dondero - i got that.
suck it up.
use the resources given to you to your full advantage
prereqs: COS 126 (recommended), or ORF 201, or score of 5 on the AP Computer Science Exam..
descrip: Introduction to programming systems, including modular programming, advanced program design, programming style, test, debugging and performance tuning; machine languages and assembly language; and use of system call services.

title: General Physics I
reviews:
1. Do practice exams before taking the real one.
2. Don't take this class if you haven't taken physics before.
3. If you're an engineer and you have to take this class even if you haven't had physics before, be patient. You are at a disadvantage relative to others, so try your hardest and see what happens. Don't just give up.

A great class that serves to provide the major concepts in introductory mechanics to BSE students. Doesn't require a ridiculous amount of work and is graded pretty fairly. The demonstrations are pretty cool too.
Absolutely take this course!!! It's tough, but ten thousand times worth it.

As someone who actually had the option of choosing PHY 101 or 103, I'm happy I chose 103. The calculus involved isn't nearly as terrifying as what you would get in the Math Dept., so don't let that scare you away. Your enjoyment of the class depends heavily on who is teaching your precept and who is supervising your lab. Dr La Porta runs an awesome precept, but my lab was a weekly trial to be dreaded. If you don't like your preceptor/lab supervisor the first week, SWITCH SECTIONS! Make sure you go to lectures (the demonstrations are entertaining and informative), and read the textbook (lecture slides are good summaries but don't go deep enough for some problem sets and exams).
Avoid this class at all costs. Only take it if you have to.
Be prepared to do a lot of learning on your own, and definitely get a group together for problem sets, because it's going to be almost impossible by yourself.

Be prepared to think, rather than have equations spoon fed to you. Don't be afraid to try paths of thinking that could turn out to be wrong. Manipulate equations and *keep trying* until you get it right.
Be ready to work.
Class is fun and enjoyable.

DO NOT take this course unless you ABSOLUTELY have to. Quality is terrible. Anything you learn will be from the textbook or occasionally your preceptor. Labs are dreadful. Professors in other departments go out of their way to see students succeed, professors in Physics 103 couldn't care less how you do. If you don't have a strong High School AP Physics background (which I was lucky to) you will find this course extremely difficult. Even if you do, it will still be very challenging, totally boring and in all aspects miserable. Stay far, far away.
DO THE READINGS BEFORE LECTURES AND CLASS
DONT TAKE THIS CLASS UNLESS YOU NEED TO!!!!

Definitely try to get La Porta for your preceptor. He is extremely accessible through office hours and genuinely cares about the success of his students. He will work through as many problems as it takes for a student to understand the material. Labs, while interesting, are always pressed for time.

Despite what many others say, PHY103 is a great course, it's mostly about what you take from it. The labs can be dull at times, but that never takes away from the overall quality - you get from this course exactly what you prepare for.
Do lots of practice exams, and you should be fine.
Do not take the course unless you enjoy laboratory work. Also, read the textbook before the lectures.
Do supplemental problem sets
Do the readings BEFORE the lectures
Do the readings and do additional practice examples.
Do the supplemental problem sets even though they are optional!
Do the supplemental problem sets, because they will be closer to the level of the exam questions than WebAssign problems.

Don't be too complacent on coming in with prior physics knowledge from high school - I thought I needed to do minimal work since I had covered all the subject material before, but I was wrong. My grade took a hit for it. If you have Professor Haldane, go to office hours - precept alone isn't enough.
Don't fall behind.
Don't take it unless it's necessary.
Don't take it unless you have to! Very difficult, not fun, fast paced, lots of work, harsh grading
Don't take it unless you have to. It's very difficult to do extremely well in, and the lectures are not very useful. You'll have to rely heavily on textbook readings and outside study supplements.

Don't take it unless you need it. If you already know the material, please take 105 and don't mess up the grading curve for those less knowledgeable than you. And for those who do take 103, I hope you come in with a good understanding of AP Physics or something like that, because the learning curve is very steep if you just took "regular" Physics in high school.

If you're a humanities person looking to fulfill a distribution requirement, look somewhere else if you like your GPA and/or your free time.
Don't take this class if you don't have to.
Don't take this class unless you really like physics or you have to.
Don't take this course unless its a requirement for your major.
Don't take this if you don't have to. Even if you think you like physics - you don't.
Don't take unless you're BSE or future physics major!
Don't worry if the first three weeks aren't as good.
Dont take it unless you have to.
Even if your not an engineer or planning on studying a science I would recommend this course.
Feel free to take this course if you're interested (or if its required). Otherwise, I'm sure there are many physics related classes that would be better for you.
Find a study group; it helps to work on problems with others.
Focus on problem solving. Many other things are emphasized, but you tend to only be assessed on problem-solving/math skills.

For other students I would say to begin homework as early as possible, take advantage of office hours, and constantly study throughout the course. Do not wait til exam period to begin studying, else you would find it extremely difficult to do for a class like this.
For those of us having a hard time with this course, do not seek help until the eleventh hour. Struggling with the material is good because it forces us to think harder.
Get a good preceptor and be able to explain everything in words, not just math.
Go get help if you need it. If you have little to no background in physics, either get help from the start or take 101.
Go to all of Prof Olsen's lectures, suffer through the labs, and get a good preceptor. It's a solid, interesting class.
Go to all of the lectures!
Go to class, engage your preceptor; answer his/her questions and attempt to ask as many as possible yourself.

Go to lecture, precepts aren't totally necessary to go to but you should attend some since the lectures aren't enough. Keep up with the reading. If you put enough effort into the class, it can be rewarding even though it's challenging.
Go to office hours every week.
Go to the professor's office hours!
Going to precept is the most helpful thing.

I can see this class as being difficult for students with little or no physics background. That said I think the material is pretty well taught as long as you get a good preceptor, so definitely shop around for a preceptor that you like. Keep on top of the material and do lots of practice questions to develop your problem solving approach.
I don't suggest taking it for an STL unless you have previous experience in Physics C Mechanics or you're an engineer and you have to.
I guess most people are taking this because they have to - it's not too bad, but it's not that great either.

I had two years of physics in high school, including AP Physics B and C - Mechanics, and I still had trouble in the course. (Admittedly, I didn't study or attend precepts, and got a B. Take that as you will.) If you've never taken physics before, STUDY HARD. Also, always stay ahead of the class -- physics is extremely cumulative!
I really enjoyed this class, and you should take it if you want a basic background in physics.  It covers a lot of topics and moves relatively quickly, so try to keep on top of the work.
I recommend this course highly.  If you're not really a physics person then don't take it but if this stuff is interesting to you then they do a good job of teaching it.

I would advise other students to do their WebAssign homework early so that you only have several hard problems to do during the week.  I would also recommend using the old practice exams as your main tool to study for exams.  Also, I would recommend going to precepts and office hours.

I would definitely recommend this class. My experience with Professor Olsen was amazing. Definitely get him as your preceptor if you can! He is very approachable and will explain your questions with clarity. What could have been a very standard physics course turned out to be much more. In addition to the weekly homework, there were more challenging supplemental problem sets that really helped me to get a better grasp of the material. Work hard, ask questions, and you'll have a really good chance of doing well.
I would definitely recommend this course to engineers or anyone who wants to take physics.
I would not recommend the class unless you have to take it for engineering.

I would not take this course unless you absolutely have to. If you're not engineering or premed, don't take this course because it's just not going to be a highlight of Princeton, to put it nicely. If you have a genuine interest in physics, take 105/106 if you want the challenge. If you just need physics as a requirement, begrudgingly take this class.
I would recommend this course to another student, particularly if you are going into the sciences and have taken a calculus course in the past.
I would say do the web assign as early as possible so you are not up late Sunday night.
I would say that students must be very diligent in learning all of the topics because the problems and exams are extremely challenging.

I would suggest this class over PHY 101, but if you really want to understand the concepts, take PHY 105. That being said, I definitely learned a great deal from this class, and would likely take it (or 105) even if I was not an engineer.
I would take the course, but I highly recommend if you want a deeper understanding, to read Kleppner and Kolenkow in addition to the Feynman lectures.
I'd highly recommend PHY 103, it's really easy as long as you do the readings.
If I could place out of this class as a BSE, I definitely would. However if you need to take it, work hard.
If you are very, very confident in your physics skills, take 105. I started there but had to drop because it was unmanageable. 103 is much more manageable, and goes at a slower pace
If you can get through the labs, you will really like this course! Also, definitely take Dr. La Porta's precept.
If you don't feel good about physics, find a preceptor you like because this is the only time you will be presented the material at the complexity level it is on tests.
If you enjoy problem solving, it is a good choice for STL.

If you have to take it, I am sorry just power through it. It is physics concepts, but it is more in depth than high school physics. There is a lot of negative logistical qualities with the class that you will want to shake a fist to, but have to live with.

If you have to take it, I would take it; it is useful and there are some interesting problems to solve. However, it has been a rather stressful course, and I would keep that in mind. Most likely, it will not be easy to get the grade you want.
If you have to take it. It'll be ok it's just boring.

If you have to take this course, don't worry, you will get through it. If you find a good preceptor for yourself, and if you use all the practice problems and resources you are provided, you will be ready for exams. If you don't have to take this course, don't - it isn't that interesting, and the labs are particularly tedious and pointless.
If you know that you love physics and are really good at physics take it. If not, stay away.
If you need it for your major or you REALLY like physics, take it. Beware that it is challenging and will require you to teach yourself a lot.

If you took AP Physics in high school and did well, this class will be a lot of review and may lead to boredom. However, if this is your first physics class, the class will be a bit more challenging. The materials aren't too difficult, but the rate at which the class progresses is the more difficult part but the professor is fantastic. No prior physics and engineer: take it; or physics major: take it. Prior physics and engineer: I'd say go for this one; or physics major: be prepared for a lot of review, I can't say anything about 105.

If you took AP physics in high school, the class won't be too difficult, as it basically covers everything that is covered in that course (I took Physics B), but if you can place out or you don't need to take it, don't take this course. It's a lot of work and time consuming.

If you're a MOL major-- don't take it out of hubris. I know you might think that 101 is only for premeds and "you're better than that" but honestly, you have more important classes to spend your energy on (orgo, genetics...)

If you're an engineer and you have to take this class, just work on weekly problem sets with friends and don't leave them until the last day. The exams that aren't the midterm and final are very manageable, but the midterm and final can be pretty bad. Just keep up with the work and go to precept.
If you're an engineer you'll have to take this (unless you place out). If you're not an engineer, this is still worth taking!

If you're an engineer, it's a requirement.  For others with an interest in physics, this is a good course that will teach you all the fundamentals of mechanics, but just beware that there is a lot of material and the exams are definitely not easy, even if you took physics in high school.

If you're doing this for a departmental requirement, take 103 and NOT 105! Make sure you stay on top of material and review often. Take the webassigns seriously, they help so much with exam preparation.
If you're going to take it, just study on your own. It's not an easy class, but unless you know physics like the back of your hand don't take 105 over this.

If you're interested in Physics, this is a must take class to get basic knowledge before you can take courses on material you may actually be interested in learning about.  Other than that, there will be mostly engineering students in this class as it is a requirement, but definitely not a bad route for a pre-health student taking the class to fulfill a requirement.

If you're not an engineer or a physics major, this class might not be so useful for you.  I'm glad I took it, but it was frustrating to be one of the few people taking it "for fun," which made my time in the class a little less enjoyable.
If you're taking this for fun and not because you have to, be warned that it really does not present physics in a very interesting manner.
It is a very informative class and teaches you what it says it will.
It is way harder than high school AP physics. Be aware.

It's a difficult course, especially if you haven't taken physics before. If you're worried about the calc aspect, it's usually not too bad. I would recommend against taking the course, though, if you've never taken calc.

It's a good course. I had a great preceptor, and I've heard the preceptor definitely makes it or breaks it...get Andrei Bernevig if you can.  Do lot's of practice problems and try to understand everything as you go.

It's a hard class. Don't get Monday lab times because you won't know anything when you get to lab (do lab after the first lecture). La Porta is an entertaining preceptor and basically helps you through all the webassigns. Good luck!
It's good to keep up with the online homework since exam problems require similar thinking.
It's hard. Only take if you HAVE to, or if you really really like physics.
It's harder than you think
It's not too bad. Just keep up with the reading, make connections, and ask questions.
It's required, but it's not as bad as some of the reviews say it is.
Just don't fall behind. Do the readings and problem sets in a timely manner.
Just stay on top of your work and take practice tests, and you'll be fine.

Keep up with the readings, and don't just google the answers to the problem sets.  Actually make sure you fully understand and master each new topic as it comes, and devote at least a day or two before exams to going over all of the provided practice exams.  Take advantage of all review sessions and office hours.
Keep up with your Webassign.
Know integrals!!!! The lectures are great but my preceptor did not teach us very much in class so you basically had to learn on your own.

Labs were the worst part of the week, but lectures were interesting and homework was not too difficult. I definitely recommend using old tests as study guides, and reading the book is usually worth the time.

MAKE SURE YOU SHOP AROUND FOR PRECEPTORS. It is more important to find a good preceptor than it is to have consistant learning in the first couple of classes. Be Bold. Ask friends if they like their preceptor, try it out. I cannot imagine how much better I would have done if I had a good preceptor.

The class is hard for people with who have little to no experience with physics but if its a requirement, you will survive. Take notes on the textbook.
Make sure to solve all of the problems that are assigned and keep up with the readings.
Make sure you go to office hours or a smart friend when you need help. Do lots of past tests when preparing for exams.
Make sure you keep up on the topics and understand everything. Topics move quickly especially after the first weeks where some people can get away with minimal work.
Make sure you stay on top of your work.
Make sure you understand the math behind everything.
Make use of office hours, it makes the difference!
McGraw Review sessions are extremely helpful for the problem sets!

Most who will be taking this course are future science or engineering majors. So, for people in those fields it is an excellent course. A lot of the topics of mechanics were explained in more depth than in high school and I came out having learned where all of the formulae I simply accepted to be true in high school came from. I believe it is a great intro course to Physics for science/engineering majors.
Only take if you actually enjoy physics.
Only take if you are exceptionally good at physics.
Only take if you have to
Only take it if you have to or love physics.
Only take it if you have to.

Only take this course if you are considering being a physics major or if you are engineer.  It really seems unfair how hard they make the tests relative to the problem sets -- I was just very lucky that I got a preceptor who would go through difficult problems.  Lab is extremely frustrating.
Painful. Take only if you have to.
Pick your preceptors wisely! Makes all the difference....

Please stay on top of your work! Attend lectures (obviously, because of iClicker questions) and start your problem sets the day they are assigned. Do every practice exam available and you will succeed. Get Jim Olsen as your preceptor and you might actually fall in love with physics!
Practice a lot of problems and make sure to attend all precepts.
Practice exams, practice exams, practice exams. This course is unnecessarily difficult and challenging for those who just want to get the prereqs out of the way.
Practice past exams.
Practice, practice, practice and take advantage of all the many resources you're given.
Put in the time this class requires. While it is very difficult (especially for someone who hasn't really had physics exposure before), it is certainly survival (with a good grade).
Put in the time to understanding to concepts and you will do fine.
Read the book; lecture and precept are only supplements to solving problems on your own.
Read the textbook before going to class.
Read the textbook before lecture to make sense of it. Finish WebAssigns early. If you work hard you will get a solid foundation in mechanics and maybe even find that you love it.
Read the textbook even though it's annoying.
Read the textbook!!
Read the textbook, as it is the best way to learn the material.
Read the textbook.
Read the textbook. Go to office hours at least once a week. Prepare for the bonus clicker question to get extra points.
Really wish PHY103 would be more encouraging and interesting!
STUDY FOR THE EXAMS THEY"RE NOTHING LIKE THE REST OF THE COURSE
STUDY STUDY STUDY! It is harder than you think especially if you haven't taken AP physics.
STUDY.
Start doing practice tests early.
Stay on top of Problem Sets!
Stay on top of readings and make sure you understand concepts the first time through the material because the questions will get very difficult.
Stay on top of the problem sets and material. Ask questions often and regularly, be aggressive about finding help when you don't understand something.
Study for exams by doing past problems rather than just reading the textbook.
Study hard, well in time
Study physics 103 very hard because it is a very tough class. But if you study hard, it will be very rewarding.
Study the previous exams.
Study, and go to office hours from the very beginning of the semester.  They help a lot!
Switch classes until you find a preceptor you like.
Take AP Physics
Take advantage of office hours and do all the practice exams online.

Take class with Professor La Porta (or another preceptor that you find helpful and engaging). Problem sets alone aren't enough to make sure you understand the material, so make sure to do as many practice problems from the relevant chapters as possible.
Take it if you have to. Not a great course. Not a terrible course.
Take it if you like physics/math.  Its not that much work but the labs are a pain. Go to all precepts.
Take it if you must.
Take it if you need it for BSE or really like physics, but I wouldn't really recommend it for a fun course, particularly if you have no prior experience w/physics.  It's a very hard class.
Take it only if required or if genuinely interested in physics. Also, have some knowledge of physics coming in or get some.
Take it only if you have to
Take it only if you have to fill a requirement.
Take it!
Take it! A lot of work and a lot of knowledge gained.
Take this class if it is a requirement or if you are interested in pursuing a science major. I would not recommend taking this course just for fun, as it is very difficult.
Take this class, especially if you have to. It's a great introductory physics course.
Take this course only if you are very interested in physics.  This class can be time-consuming and difficult, especially if you never took AP physics.
Take this if you want to think critically.
Take this. I took this class after AP Physics C in high school, and it was about the same material, but more in depth.

The combination of lab, lectures, and precepts gives a very well-rounded understanding of physics. However, if you have never taken physics before, it may seem fast-paced, but of course there's nothing that hard work and office hours can't help.
The course is difficult.  Do the practice exams or else you're gonna get screwed like I was.

The course moves quickly, and the material builds on previous material, so stay on top of everything! Try to get into Dr. La Porta's section, because he's great, especially if you're not super into physics (like me).
The curve is hard and the midterm was killer
Think of everything fundamentally and geometrically.
This class is not too difficult, but labs are boring, and shop for different preceptors because most of the learning happens in class.
This course is very difficult if you don't have much of a physics background.  It takes a lot of time and effort.

This course overall was good, however the labs detract from the experience. Precept attendance is crucial, whereas lecture attendance is only helpful for clicker points. Much of the learning has to come from individual effort outside of the classroom, but success is not impossible.

This is a difficult course, but manageable if you study enough with friends and get help when you need it. Not the BEST course at Princeton, but if you're a BSE, power through and everything will be okay.
This is a good but hard class.  All the learning happens in precept, so go.  Lab is painful, brace yourself.

This is a great class, and the professors are great. Definitely attend office hours and review sessions when available as they are very helpful and especially precept. Trying to do the homework problems without getting assistance from the book will be great preparation for the tests as well as doing other exercises in the book at the end of each chapter.
This is a hard course and you're going to have to spend a long time studying for it. If you have a good preceptor though, it's much more fun to go to class.

This is an easy class. The labs are time-consuming. The lectures are awesome. 
And Philp LaPorta is the best preceptor you could ever have!
This is an important course to take for first year engineers. Even if you have taken physics in high school, it is a good idea to take this course in the first semester.
This is your basic physics course. The exams are harder than the homework, but the classes are really good.
Try out many different precepts to find one that is right for you.
Try to place out if you are a BSE. If you're an AB, don't even think about taking it "for fun". Physics (as presented in this course) is not fun; it is a chore.
Unless you need this for a departmental or you love physics. Don't take it (only based on level of difficulty and time required).
Very challenging and time-consuming, but you learn a lot.
Very, very difficult course.

While the labs are quite tedious at times, the lectures are very enjoyable and the precepts were very informative. I had Marlow as a preceptor; I think he did a very good job of presenting the material in an understandable way and responding to student questions. Not too difficult if you have a solid high school physics background.
Work hard getting the basics as you go through and never slacken. Material builds on itself so weak points will come back to haunt you.
Wouldn't recommend taking to anyone who isn't planning on being an engineer or isn't very interested in physics.
You had better be committed.
You probably have to take it, so just get on with it.  Use McGraw Study Halls as much as possible!
You will love the course but it is very challenging!
You will most likely regret taking this course. Avoid it if possible.
You'll be able to weather the course, you engineer. Not an engineer? Why are you even considering this course?
always stay up to date, work with classmates on the webassigns well before they are due, and go over your exams with your preceptor or professor after you get it back
be prepared to put the time in to understand concepts. without a conceptual understanding of the material, you will have a hard time
do psets carefully and especially supplementary psets.
great course
just do a lot of problems

literally don't ever take this class unless you have to. If you're BSE just stick it out and hope you pass, but otherwise I have no clue why anyone would ever want to take this. You think you enjoy physics until 103.
make sure to go to precept if you're not understanding something - but you don't ALWAYS have to go
work with smart friends, roll with the punches, stay ahead of the curve,  strive for fundemental understanding, stick with it, survive labs TAKE PRACTICE EXAMINATIONS BEST RESOURCE EVER CREATED
prereqs: Some prior preparation in physics and calculus is desirable..
descrip: To understand the basic physics needed for further study in science and engineering. Logical, quantitative approach to problem solving. Applying fundamental concepts to idealized, practical problems.

title: Advanced Organic Chemistry
reviews: Don't stress about the first half of the course - it ultimately doesn't matter that much and you can make it up in the second half. That said, learn, because it really is interesting stuff, and if you don't find it interesting, then maybe you shouldn't be taking the course.
It's a solid course, not the most interesting, but a light workload.
It's more chill than orgo 1 and 2.

TAKE IT. It is not a huge time commitment nor very heavy workload if you did pretty/very well in 304/304B. Both professors are chemists worth getting to know because they are at the forefront of their fields and there is so much to learn from them.
Take it if you had any positive feelings for orgo - it will increase them by so much.
Take it!
Take this class if you like synthesis or are interested in the biological side of organic chemistry. Take this class if you're taking biochemistry. Take this class!
This was such a good class I would really really recommend it.
read Clayden
prereqs: CHM 301 and CHM 302, or CHM 303 and CHM 304, or equivalent laboratory courses..
descrip: A selection of advanced topics in organic chemistry, including organic synthesis, organic reaction mechanisms, biosynthetic pathways, and elements of modern drug design.

title: Politics in Africa
reviews: Excellent course for anyone with an interest in Africa. Not too political-science oriented, with lots of good stories and history.
Go to the lectures because she doesn't post the slides and make a reading group and do summaries for each other.

I would strongly reccommend this course both to politics concentratior, Woodrow Wilson concentrators, and anyone looking for a good politics course. The course places issues in Africa within the greater context of major approaches to political science. It is well organized, and this allows students to really follow the course and connect what they are learning to many different courses. Further, the assignments we had were very interesting-even if the data assignments were not the fairest assignments and took up a lot of time.
If you want some exposure to African politics, this class may suit your desires.

If you would like to learn about Africa and you have no previous background, take this class and when possible, try to get to know Prof. Widner; she is a great Professor and an excellent person worth getting to know.
If you're at all interested in Africa or African Studies, politics major or not, take this course. It was tremendous.
It was actually worth having to go to a 9 a.m. class, which says a lot. I recommend it to anyone interested in politics in developing countries!

Make sure you go to lectures. Although they are early, Professor Widner is a great lecturer but she doesn't post the slides. The assignments are individually timed so you just have to budget your time well.
Only take this class if you have a sincere interest in African politics.
Professor Widner is an amazing lecturer! If you like or want to learn more about African politics and history or the politics of development in general, I strongly recommend this course!
Stay awake during lecture and don't get too far behind on the readings.  You don't need to do all of them, but at least do a little bit from every week.
Straight forward final. no suprises. Its decent.
Take it if you want to learn more about Africa.
Take it!
Take it!  A fun class, and a much more practical look at politics than the average.
Take this course given the great professor and the excellent introduction to politics in Africa.
Take this course if you are looking for a survey of some of the major issues on the continent. Professor Widner is engaging and fun, and the course has a lot to offer.
Take this course!
This would be a good course to take earlier in your career.
To keep up with the readings and take lots of notes during lecture. Ask questions to clarify the different problem solving methods, because they will be relevant to the essay questions and exam.

Try to keep up with the readings, and don't be afraid to meet with your preceptor or Professor Widner if you miss a class or have any confusions - they are all really willing to help you out! Also ask all questions related to written work.
Unless you need this for a politics requirement, I don't really recommend this course. It's fairly boring.

take it.  if you care about anything other than america, if you care about the developing world, if you want to understand our international arena, if you are a princeton student.  don't take it if you can't wake up for 9am class.
prereqs: No previous knowledge of Africa is required..
descrip: This course provides an introduction to the study of African politics. The lectures and readings briefly review the social and historical context of contemporary political life. They then profile the changes of the early post-Independence period, the authoritarian turn of the 1970s and 80s, the second liberation of the 1990s, and problems of war, state-building, and development. Although the lectures trace a narrative, each also introduces a major analytical debate and an important policy problem. Broadly comparative with some special attention to selected countries.

title: Problems in Late Antique and Byzantine Art and Architecture - Eastern Roman Empire
descrip: Problems in art and architecture of the Eastern Roman Empire and culturally related areas from 300 to 1453.

title: Design, Synthesis, and Optimization of Chemical Processes
reviews: Do not start the design project late. Several all-nighters could be needed if you leave everything to reading week.
Do not take this course if you can... way too hard
Good luck.

IF YOU STILL CAN, DROP THIS MAJOR!!!!!! Unfortunately, most of the people reading this review are probably rising seniors and therefore cannot switch majors, but if you are by any chance a freshman or sophomore, do not stay in CBE. Core Lab, while horrific, is nothing compared to this class. CBE442 single-handedly ruined my senior fall. I have never had to work so hard on something that I hate this much. I will always think back on my time at Princeton, and while positive, regret choosing this major.
If you're thinking about taking this course, you're already solidly locked into CBE. Start on the project early.
It's a required course, so there's no way to get out of it.
Learn Aspen and GAMS.
Learn how to use ASPEN and GAMS before taking this course.

Lectures and the project have preeettttyyy much nothing to do with each other. Just keep it in mind that you will have to know the stuff from lecture at the very end of the class. Don't stress about that; work on the project. But definitely don't miss class ever and take good notes.

Never in my life have I spent so long on a project only to learn almost nothing from it, except that I never want to design a process simulation ever again.... But unfortunately if you've made it this far, you have to take it. Don't fall behind. Start on your simulation early, because 90% of your time will be spent fixing errors. Make friends with the TAs.

No reason to take this unless you're CBE, in which case you have to. Stay on top of your work and don't fall behind on the project. The optimization side of things is where you can really get something out of this course; aside from that, the bulk of the course is just working through the simulation software, which isn't particularly good so get familiar with it quickly.
No. And don't do this major, either-- it's a big mistake.

Solely because of this course, if I was doing the past four years over again, I would have switched departments.  I have always been the biggest proponent of Chemical Engineering to underclassmen.  After this semester, no more!  (And I successfully got some of the younger students I had initially persuaded to be CBE to switch to another department).  If I had seen as a freshman how unhappy I would be this semester due to this course, I would have never majored in the department.

For the majority of students reading this feedback, it is probably too late for you, and you really have no choice about taking the course.  So here's my advice:
-bring a cell phone charger to the design lab, you will always be there longer than you think
-study primarily class notes for the final
-during class, whenever Floudas says something will be on the final, mark that in your notes: it will be!
-choose partners who work similarly to you over partners who you are good friends with.  friendship alone will not get you through this class if you inherently have different work styles
-befriend the TAs.  visit them early and often.  They will be more helpful if they like you, so be nice to them!  You CANNOT survive this class without the TAs.

Sorry :( Prof. Floudas is quite a good lecturer, but the lecture material and related assignments will be about 20% of your experience with this course. The other 80% is the project, which will test your patience, resolve, and perhaps your mental stability. You'll experience not-so-high highs but the lowest lows while working on it. The project this year is a bit harder than previous years' apparently, so maybe our experience isn't the best indicator, but this semester has been the most strenuous and stressful because of this single, semester-long project. Other assignments were put on the backburner, fun plans were cancelled, and sleep was lost because of that project. I'm taking only 3 courses with one of them being  a PDF, and I'm still just barely getting by. I'm probably not gonna look back on Design with fond memories. You'll be spending most of your time in the EQuad from now, so get comfortable. People also found the Design lab to be chilly all the time, so invest in a nice sweater and a nice pair of sweats as well. On a more positive note, the optimization portion of the class is fascinating, and it is quite satisfying when you get your Aspen and GAMS programs to do what you want. Prof. Floudas is a great lecturer and a very personable guy, and the TAs were fantastic and extremely patient. It's just unfortunate that the aspect of the course with which we spent the most time, Aspen, was undeniably the most painful. Make sure to work with people with whom you get along and can work productively. You're in for quite the experience ;)

Sorry CBEs, you have to take this course even if you never in your life plan to do anything related to this. This course is outdated and should be either tailored to the types of CBEs at Princeton now or removed entirely.
Sorry, kids. Just get through it and graduate.
Take it if you have to.
Try not to spend your whole life working on this class.
Unfortunately with these sorts of things I guess you don't have a choice.

Well, I hope you're happy. You were warned time and time again to change majors, yet you've persisted in your boundless ignorance. Sure, your earlier forays into the blight that is Chemical Engineering can be chalked up to freshman naivety. "Yes, Intro is dull, and Separations is useless, but beginners courses are always terrible. I bet the higher-level classes are intellectually stimulating and legitimately useful." But you're no longer a child, and you've run out of excuses. Yet here you stand. But fear not, dear Sisyphus?Christodoulos A. Floudas, Lord of Sorrows, is here to punish you for hubris. And rest assured, Floudas' torments are far crueler than merely consigning you to an eternity of pushing a boulder up a hill. "So," you ask, "you're saying that Design is an exercise in futility?" No. Attempting to broker a peace between Israel and Palestine would be an "exercise in futility." Design is no mere exercise; it is futility and wickedness given physical form. When Pandora, a fool much like yourself, opened her malignant box, the pestilence released into the world was termed "Aspen Plus." Don't believe me? Of course you don't?anyone capable of rational thought has long since abandoned this major. So allow me to provide a brief preview of your senior fall semester: you know how thesis advisers require a minimum of 20 hours in lab a week? You will fall far short of that goal as you spend those 20+ hours debugging your Design simulations and conducting process synthesis literature reviews. You have to write 40 pages for your senior thesis? That's cute. The average midterm Design PROPOSAL is 50+ pages. Your final paper will easily double that. As the semester progresses, your incessant Design whining will cause all your non-CBE friends to abandon you. And you deserve it, because you have no one to blame but yourself for your misfortune. In the last two weeks before Dean's Date, you will literally spend every waking hour in the Design lab. And when I say literally,

Well, you're a senior CBE so it's too late to make any decisions about "considering taking this course". Take good notes during lecture because you will need to memorize everything for the final, which is long, difficult, and impossible to finish. Project-wise, also be prepared for something long, difficult, and (nearly) impossible to finish - best advice would be to start early and work on it regularly (which is really hard fall semester senior year, especially if you plan on working on your thesis). Ask the TAs for help (and be grateful because they will help you a lot), even just to be clear about what your project objectives are, the general roadmap, and steps you should be taking for your project. Sleep will seem that much more beautiful after this class - relish it. Also, relish all the bonding experiences you'll have with your fellow CBE'ers. You'll make it to the end.
You have no choice.
You know who you are and you have to do it. Good luck.

You will hear this from others as well, just like we have all heard this from students in many of our classes in the past.  I have never listened myself, but I implore you: Do. NOT. Procrastinate. On. This. Project.  I didn?t realize until it was far too late that the lectures were not just conceptual supplements to the idea of process design ? they actually tell you how to do the analysis portion of the project, and the lectures are reeeeally good.  My group spent so long putting together the simulation that we had to cram in some version of the detailed analysis we had learned in class in the last few days.  The result of this was that we really know what we were doing on the analysis like we could have.  Also, we hadn?t learned the lectures the first time because we weren?t applying the material to the project, so that was two lost opportunities.  If you start researching ideas the MOMENT you get the project assignment (and, like, actually hardcore researching), the semester will go much better.  Semester beginnings are much more chill than middles and especially ends; you are just coming out of summer, the workload hasn?t piled up yet, and you?re still awake.  Use this time to research process ideas, and start simulating as soon as you learn aspen.  You?ll soon discover that not all papers have enough information to simulate, and you?ll start to see what will and what won?t be an option for use in the project.  You?ll gain a familiarity with aspen BEFORE the assignment is due, and you?ll freak out less when reactors don?t work for whatever reason (WATCH YOUR UNITS!!!! ASPEN IS PICKY!!!).  And then when Professor Floudas starts talking about how to size reactors and economics analysis in lecture (his lectures are really good!), it won?t just be this nebulous concept that you?ll write down but then forget until the final, it will be a tool you can immediately put to use because you already know what you?ll probably use for your process simulation, and you?ll learn
be prepared for what you are getting into
don't take other hard classes, because this course is ridiculous and unfortunately a departmental.
get ready for long hours, boring lectures, and confusing instruction
try to work on the project at a consistent pace and try not to get too frustrated with other group members, as that is usually counterproductive.
prereqs: CBE 341 and CBE 441..
descrip: Introduction to chemical process flow-sheeting; process simulation design, sizing and cost estimation of total processes; process economics; introduction to optimization, linear programming, integer programming, and nonlinear programming; heat integration methods, minimum utility cost, minimum number of units, network optimization.

title: Philosophical Logic
reviews: If you enjoy logic, I would highly recommend this class.  However, if you have never seen any proofs or done logic, I would take another class first, then try this one.
It can be very difficult material, but Professor Burgess knows his stuff and is very helpful if you approach him.
It's a nice, math-flavored EC which gives you interesting problems to think of, and rewarding proofs to write.

Take it if you're interested in nonclassical logic. Prof. Burgess is a very good teacher and you will leave the course with a better appreciation of classical logic (after you realize how messy some of these other logics are).
Take it. If you get stuck on a problem, talk to John Burgess in person or by email. He always responds within 24 hours (and usually sooner) and is extremely helpful.
This is a great class to take.  In the end I PDFed the class but I would have been fine had I not.  If you do take the class, make sure to go to officer hours, they are extremely helpful.
Try it, it will challenge your perceptions of what logic is and let you approach mathematical inference in new ways.
prereqs: PHI 201 or instructor's permission.
descrip: An introduction to non-classical formal logics: temporal, modal, conditional, relevantistic, intuitionistic.

title: Research Seminar in Empirical Investigation
descrip: Preparation of research papers based on field observation, laboratory experiments, survey procedures, and secondary analysis of existing data banks.

title: Selected Topics in High-Energy Physics
descrip: Quantization of Closed and Open strings. Two-dimensional conformal field theory. String perturbation theory and effective actions. NSR approach to superstrings. D-branes.

title: Contemporary Art: 1950 to the Present
descrip: A critical study of the major movements, paradigms, and documents of postwar art--abstract-expressionist, pop, minimalist, conceptual, process and performance, site-specific, etc. Special attention to crucial figures (e.g., Jackson Pollock, Andy Warhol, Robert Smithson) and problems (e.g., "the neo-avant-garde", popular culture, feminist theory, political controversies, "postmodernism").

title: Topics in Environmental Studies - Building American Style: Land-Use Policies and Rules
reviews: If you are at all interested in American land-use policy, take this course! The Poppers have extensive knowledge about the topic. Also, the written workload isn't too bad, though weekly readings are a bit long.
Take it. It's interesting and you'll learn a lot without dealing with the grunt work of other classes.

The professors are so knowledgeable in their field! You can ask them pretty much anything and they will either know the answer or get back to you with the answer within the week. They are very accessible, so don't be afraid to reach out to them if you need anything.
You'll learn from it.
descrip: Americans have built and preserved an astounding variety of environments. The course examines the evolving complex of incentives and regulations that drove the choices of where and how places developed. It focuses on the emergence of land-use and environmental planning as a way to encourage or discourage growth and to mitigate or intensify its environmental, social, and economic effects.We will examine the latest tools for building and protecting the American landscape. Case studies include Southern California, New Haven, the American Great Plains, and others. Analysis will be from historical, policy-oriented, and predictive perspectives.

title: Functional Analysis
prereqs: MAT 314/320, 332; MAT 317/330 or MAT331/335 helpful but not required; or permission by instructor..
descrip: Basic introductory course to modern methods of analysis. Specific applications of methods to problems in other fields, such as partial differential equations, probability, & number theory are presented. Topics include Lp spaces, tempered distribution, Fourier transform, Riesz interpolation theorem, Hardy-Littlewood maximal function, Calderon-Zygmund theory, the spaces H1 and BMO, oscillatory integrals, almost orthogonality, restriction theorems & applications to dispersive equations, law of large numbers & ergodic theory. Course also discusses applications of Fourier methods to discrete counting problems, using Poisson summation formula.

title: Greek Ethical Theory
reviews: Be forewarned: this is a class on ethics, which is not the most interesting aspect of philosophy. Having said that, this is a laid back class with fair paper topics. It is not much work at all and Lorenz is not only very intelligent, but also very understanding and helpful. I ended up PDFing the class, but even if you know nothing about philosophy, it is definitely possible to do well. If you want to do well, it is essential that you go to all lectures, because it is impossible to interpret Aristotle's writings without the help of Lorenz.
Can't speak for philosophy majors, but for people with not background in PHI looking to PDF, it's really easy and interesting.

Hendrik Lorenz is one of the most caring, thoughtful professors I've had.  He really cares about his students and their learning.  He is very reasonable, understanding, and is quite humorous.  He will go over something multiple times so everyone understands the concept.  He is a very calm, wonderful man.  Please take any and all of his courses.

Here's the deal ? this is a great class for philosophy students. I'm a philosophy student, so I loved it. If you're just looking to try out a philosophy class though, this isn't really the one to start with. It was pretty complex at times, and while I definitely recommend it and really liked Professor Lorenz, this needs to be your thing for you to love it like I did.
If you are interested in the subject matter, you should definitely take it (and try to take it with Prof. Lorenz).
If you're interested in Ancient Philosophy then this is a great class with which to start

Take it if you want to have a good understanding of the texts you're reading and especially of Lorenz's interpretations of them (which he will tell you are not all conventional). Papers are often exercises in showing you understand Lorenz's interpretation of an argument?and sometimes he will give you an assignment on something he has given you a 20 page paper about explicitly. Still, to get full points you need to show some outside critical analysis.

Take the class. It'll give your ethical thinking more clarity than any modern ethics class. I would recommend reading Anscombe's article Modern Moral Philosophy if you want to know why you should take this class.
This course is a bit slow. It is always helpful to know Greek ethical theory, though, which serves as a foundation for a long philosophical tradition.
To those who might be interested in just a bit of greek philosophy, this is quite interesting, definitely take it. very fair grading too.
prereqs: One previous philosophy course required..
descrip: We shall study the ethical theories and contributions to moral philosophy of Socrates, Plato, Aristotle and the Hellenistic philosophers.

title: Global Environmental Change: Science, Technology & Policy
descrip: http://www.princeton.edu/pub/frs

title: The Modern Period
descrip: In this course we will approach different literary and critical texts that problematize and configure the relations between space, architecture, and fiction in modern literature. We will explore the configuration of real and imaginary cities, architectural constructions, utopias and dystopias, and different philosophies of space. Writers to be discussed include Bolano, Borges, Calvino, Cortazar, Lispector, Garcia Lorca, Orwell. Theoretical readingsby Freud, Benjamin, Blanchot, Deleuze, and Heidegger.

title: Re-Enchanting the World: Religion and the Literature of Fantasy
descrip: Starting with the premise (articulated by Max Weber and many others) that the "modern" world has become disenchanted, this seminar will deal with the role of folktales, myths, children's stories, science fiction and other literary forms in attempting to re-enchant the world by force of imagination. The course will focus upon the traditional myths and religious themes which frequently are recast in contemporary fantasy literature.

title: Computing and Imaging in Architecture
reviews: A good introduction to scripting with python but I am not sure if the effort input necessary to really learning the material is proportionate to what I got out of it.
Build on assignments week to week instead of starting anew each week.
Expect a high amount of work every week which goes towards both familiarizing oneself with python scripting but also graphic representation.
I would only recommend this course if the format was expanded to include discussions/lectures  and a fabrication component of the class.
descrip: This course on digital media infrastructure will explore breaking technologies of fabrication, modeling and design based on production pipelines pioneered by the film and gaming industries--pipelines we will author in CATIA, McNeel's Rhino/Grasshopper, and Bentley's Generative Components. A series of formal experiments will be carried out each culminating in the fabrication of rapid prototypes using the CNC mill and the InVision 3D printer, explicitly challenging conventional modes of practice and seeking insight into new forms of organization, techniques and operative procedures.

title: Great Leadership in Historical Perspective
descrip: Course uses the lens of history to evaluate why some individuals are considered most effective as elected, bureaucratic, and appointed officials in American history. Course evaluates social scientific models of leadership, then delves into the historical record to discover any patterns. Careful consideration is given to the distinct challenges posed by different institutional settings. A wide range of influential leaders, including Gifford Pinchot at the Dept of Agriculture, Lyndon Johnson in the Senate, Wilbur Cohen at the Social Security Administration and George Schultz at State, will be examined.

title: Modern Classical Dynamics
descrip: Discussion of the most beautiful and important parts of classical dynamics: variational principles, ergodicity and chaos, fluid dynamics of vortices, shock waves and solitons as well as the theories of developed turbulence.

title: Operations and Information Engineering
reviews:
Absolutely do not take unless required.  Consider dropping the EMS certificate if you are currently in the program.

If you do make the mistake of taking this course:
The lectures for the second half of the course are worthless and the material will not influence your grade.  Since attendance is compulsory (sign in sheet), bring work from other classes to lecture. 

None of the modeling material in the first half of the course is useful for the OJ game.  The game has too many moving parts to be able to solve it analytically.  You will be better off building a simulator.  Surprisingly, knowing his definitions of a resource and other terms is not helpful in any way.

Course is not necessary unless you are an ORFE student, but you will learn how to quantitatively think about decision-making. The OJ game is a great aspect of the course, but it does require a lot of work.
DO NOT TAKE IT unless you ABSOLUTELY have to.
Don't. Unless you have to.
Enjoy the second half of the semester.  The first half is a real grind but you will get through it.
Good class to take but OJ game makes it tough to justify the time if not ORF major.

Good course, but a lot of work. If you're a senior and you don't have to take it... don't. Make your life easier.

But, if you do want to take it, do it. You'll have fun.
I think this is a good class no matter what field you are in, because every person can benefit by understanding how to model their decision making and optimize their use of information.
If you want to try your hand at a game where you manage an orange juice company with a lot of decisions to make, go ahead. I don't see much reason otherwise for non-ORFE majors to take this course.
Learn some VBA!
Make sure you stay on top of the lectures
Not your usual Princeton or ORFE course.  Not bad lectures.  Professor is nice and understanding!

OJ game isn't that bad. 
Take time in the beginning to REALLY know the game and what's going on.
Only class of its kind at Princeton. Great course.
PDF it if you are not an ORF major and are just taking it for the certificate program--it takes a lot of the stress off.

Take it for the EMS certificate program. The OJ game will take up a lot of your time if you have a good team who wants to do well. You don't get to choose your own teams, though. Hopefully, there will be no re-runs for specific mistakes that other teams made (and not the ones that your team makes) that might disadvantage your team. Also, class attendance for the second half of the semester is essentially mandatory.

Take this course obviously if you are required to, but also if you are interested in learning how to model various kinds of real-world problems. This knowledge can be very useful for future applications.

Take this if you want to learn how to put a mathematical framework behind decisions (business, technological, social, etc.).  Good course taught by great professor.  In the second half of the semester, lots of games are played and no out of class psets are assigned since OJ game will dominate your life.  OJ game is great if you can figure it out fast and your team is solid.  Luckily enough, my team did both.
The OJ Game is a fun experience, so if you're willing to deal with the negatives of the class, you should take it!
The course is somewhat time consuming, but the OJ Game was a great experience. You will learn a lot about how real life problems can be modeled and optimized.
This class is so poorly taught and executed so please don't take it unless you're an ORF major. Even if you're and ORF major, you aren't gonna learn anything new at all.

This is an interesting class and it covers a lot of materials (most of which would not be tested, though). It is important to know what to focus in this class: (1) know the theoretical stuff in the first half of the semester because midterm is VERY important (2) start early on OJ Game and make sure that you know how the game works because when you get into the real OJ Bowl it could be too late...
Understand the OJ game as EARLY as possible. The team that "got" it first won.
You likely don't have much choice of taking this course, but I highly recommend it.  You should also take ORF 418 with Professor Powell.
don't take it unless you need to

great class, really enjoyed the OJ game because it's so different from a typical exam that every other class does. Really makes you consider so many things, and the fun part was trying to understand the different parts so well that you could use that to do well in the game. really enjoyed the game, and the class!
prereqs: ORF 245/ECO 300, ORF 307/MAT 305, ORF 309.
descrip: The management of complex systems through the control of physical, financial and informational resources. The course focuses on developing mathematical models for resource allocation, with an emphasis on capturing the role of information in decisions. The course seeks to integrate skills in statistics, stochastics and optimization using applications drawn from problems in dynamic resource management which tests modeling skills and teamwork.

title: Advanced Russian through Film
reviews: Be aware that this professor often plays favorites.
Don't wait until the last minute to do your oral presentations -- you'll need time to practice. Trust me.
If you want to get good at Russian speaking and writing, this is a great course. Plus, you get to watch a lot of really good Russian movies, which teaches a lot about culture and history too.

Not too much work overall. There is a film, essay and oral presentation every two weeks, a midterm, and a final exam. Ksana is very sweet and willing to help. Just make sure to look at the vocabulary lists beforehand so you have something intelligent to say in class.
This is a good class. You will get out of it what you put into it, so really make an effort to learn the vocabulary (which is the most important piece of the course). The films are excellent!
prereqs: SLA207/RUS 207 or Permission Of Instructor.
descrip: A language course based on Russian films and designed to develop a more sophisticated level of spoken and written Russian. Discussions of life in Russia, weekly compositions.

title: Neurogenetics of Behavior
reviews: Definitely take if you're interested in neuroscience and how model organisms can be used to answer big questions regarding how the brain and nervous system work. Fantastic class, and not too much work. Just read a couple of papers a week and make a couple of presentations.
Difficult, but you will learn a lot.
Do the readings for the quizzed class, your presentations well and pay decent attention to your final paper and you should be fine!

I loved this course because there was very little work, but I still learned a lot. If you don't have time to do all the readings, make sure you understand the main points from them before every class, so you can have a little bit of background.
It's a good NEU class to take - interesting topics, but less of a focus on neuro than other neuro classes
Know much more molecular biology (in terms of the pros and cons of various assays and animal models) than that taught in MOL 214.
Take genetics.
Take this class. It's awesome. The professors are wonderful, the subjects covered are fascinating, and the workload is both  reasonable and enjoyable.
Take this course!
This class is very interesting, but very difficult, not in workload but in mastering the material.  Expect to have to figure out the class independently, and that you may not figure it out.

This course, for me, was mostly scientific training. It teaches you how to read and understand science papers, write grant proposal, make presentations, and work in groups. You learn a lot. I'm just more into humans, and this course is mostly Drosophila, bees, crickets, and other insects...

Try not to be the first presenter.  They grade you easier but it's a super hard to predict what they want.  Do the readings early and really in depth.  This class teaches you to pay attention to detail in papers.
prereqs: MOL 214 or 215 and NEU 258 or ISC 235/236 or written permission from the instructor. MOL 342 (Genetics) is recommended.
descrip: How do seemingly simple organisms generate complex behaviors? This course will explore our current understanding of the genetic and neural basis for animal behavior, with an emphasis on cutting-edge research and model systems that are amenable to genetic manipulation. Each week we will discuss a new behavior with a focus on the underlying mechanisms; students will also lead discussions of primary literature. The goal of this course is to provide required background, knowledge, and critical thinking skills to move beyond the published literature to proposing original experiments. This effort will culminate in a final paper from each student.

title: The Fantasy of the Middle Ages
descrip: http://www.princeton.edu/pub/frs

title: Life on Earth: Chaos and Clockwork of Biological Design
reviews: A much better improvement over the previous EEB 211, focusing on concepts and large-scale trends instead of minute details.  But incredibly unorganized and the lab reports are difficult to deal with because they aren't traditional lab reports and the grading sometimes seems arbitrary.
Attend lectures every day!

Be prepared to put in ALOT of effort for this course. The labs eat up a huge amount of time, and it is very difficult to know how to do well on them. Material is also sometimes confusingly represented, so that much time must be spent before exams trying to guess what various slides mean.
Be prepared to spend most of your time in this course on labs.  Pacala is a great lecturer and fun to listen to, but you need some interest in biology to enjoy the course and make it worth the work.
Be sure to go to lectures or else you will fail this course for sure.
Be thoughtful in your work, ask questions if you have them.
Both professors are great lecturers, at present the readings aren't valuable but lectures are essential. Have fun with it, it's an enjoyable class.
DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE.
Do not take UNLESS you REALLY REALLY REALLY love learning about animals.
Do not take this class if you dont have to. Poor organization of class. The hands on work was a bastardization of science and was quite nonsensical.
Don't miss lecture.
Don't stress about the readings. Study the notes from class. Go to every class, especially when Prof. Rubenstein is lecturing.

Don't take it unless you have to--it is a lot of man hours, and it is often unclear what tests and lab reports were looking for. I have heard that this is a better version of the class than the version that was previously offered, and hopefully the class improves with time.
Don't worry too much about doing every reading that is suggested - it is usually only supplementary. However, if you don't understand a concept, DEFINITELY go to the book - it usually has the answer.

EEB 211 has historically been a "worst class ever" course, but I think the changes made this semester made it palatable at worst and a great course at best. The information presented was interesting and easy to understand, and I didn't fall asleep in lectures, which is saying a lot. Be warned, however, that the labs take a lot of time if you want to get an A.

EEB 211 is an awesome into to bio course. Pacala and Rubenstein are enthusiastic about the subject matter and it positively influences your perspective of biology (and learning in general), your attentiveness in class, and your motivation to work hard. Loved these guys. Grading was very fair. Field trips / labs were fun.
Get started on labs early because they take a very long time to complete especially with Excel not being the most useful computer program to run.

Go to all the classes--you will not need to read the book if you go to class. Also, work hard in the lab reports--they may only be a couple of pages, but you need strong supported pages to get good grades. Good class, but a lot of work.
Go to the lectures and good luck with those labs.
Go. To. Lecture.  You will not pass or enjoy this course without lecture.
Have fun with it, and don't worry if you're confused.
I LOVED THIS COURSE!!! Take it, now. It was absolutely fascinating.
I don't know. Be prepared to spend time with your email account.
