I honestly loved this class.  The lectures were always interesting (though Rubenstein does tend to go over time a bit), the design classes were excellent, and the labs were based on fun, slightly off-the-wall ideas.  Yes it's an intro class and the material covered is therefore very broad, but so what?  It's all interesting and fairly easy to grasp, and Pacala and Rubenstein really know their stuff.  Take it if you're interested in anything bio or animal related.

I really enjoyed this class.  To be honest, I was not looking forward to it but I ended up learning so much more than I thought.  It does require work (weekly lab reports, keeping up with lecture notes, etc) but I think it's worth it.  Workload is definitely manageable and the TAs are great too.  I also enjoyed how laid back the professors and TAs seemed to be too.
I really enjoyed this course. The material answers a lot of life's questions.

I think most people take this class because it's a requirement, so I'm not going to tell anyone not to take it. Hopefully the structure of the class is improved in future semesters. I was given the impression that the reason the labs were so frustrating this semester was because the course was new this year and none of the labs had been done before.
I think this is a great class.  If you are able to put up with a little bit of the growing pains that go along with an entirely new course, I found it to be very intriguing.
I thought the class was a lot of fun, but it took up SO MUCH TIME!
I would advise the student to spend time each day going over a little material from lectures to help with the exams. Go in and talk to the teachers.

I would definitely take this course if you have a general interest in biology, are a prospect biology major, or before you take MOL 214. It discusses many important topics in today's science and is very intellectually stimulating.
I would only take this course if it's a requirement.

I would recommend doing all or most of the online reading, or at least skimming it before lecture. Attend all lectures and take decent notes. Start reviewing early on in the course, because I studied last minute for both the midterm and final and while thankfully this strategy worked out for the final, I did poorly on the midterm.

I would recommend this course if you are genuinely interested in biology and want to understand ecological processes. It is a large commitment if you are just looking to fulfill the lab distribution requirement. The amount of work and the format of the tests can be stressful.
I would say to not take this course unless you have to for premed/biology major.  There are a lot of other courses out there with a lot less work that address similar subjects.

If you are not pre-med or a potential MOL, EEB, or bioengineering major, beware that this class does require a great deal of time. Spend time on your labs (since labs are 40% of your final grade), and form study groups before exams so that you can fill in the many blanks your lecture notes may have. I would not recommend taking this class for general interest.
If you're a nonmajor taking it PDF, just go to lecture and you'll be fine.  I didn't study for the midterm more than 3 hours and spent 3 hours at most on each lab report.

If you're premed, you have to take it. If you're not, think hard about why you're taking this: if you want to understand evolution, you can read very well written books written for the public. While EEB 211 is a science course, it requires 'judgements' in answering questions or lab reports reminiscent of the humanities--- except in humanities its about your rhetoric and there is no "right" answer. In EEB, there *is* a right answer, so if your judgment is wrong, you're wrong. This makes the course doubly difficult, since it lacks the 'precision' entailed, say, in pure mathematics or physics or MOL, yet also lacks the rhetoric-based answers of humanities.

Interesting, but definitely not an easy STL for PDF since the labs and lab reports are very time-consuming. But I suppose most people in the class are there because it's required for pre-med or for your major
It is an interesting class if you are interested in biology.  I recommend taking the class but be prepared for a disorganized setup and a difficult midterm.
It's A LOT of work. Design class was really interesting but after being drained by all of the work that went into labs, it was more difficult to enjoy.
It's an alright course with a lot of memorization. Some of it is interesting, and some of it isn't. The labs are long and annoying and all feel like busy work, but it's doable.
Lecture is extremely important, go to every single one if you are striving to get a good grade.
Not as bad as you would initially think.
Only take it if you absolutely have to.
Only take it if you have to and if you're pdfing steer clear this class is a surprising amount of work.
Only take it if you have to.
Pacala makes the class, but I'm not sure if it is enough to overlook the horrible labs.
Pay attention in lectures and start the labs early!
Pre-meds.
Stay on top of the work, show up to lectures, and don't hesitate to ask questions.
Study hard, don't fall behind readings, and do the labs methodically and you'll do well and learn a lot
Take good notes in lecture!
Take it if you need to or if you have a genuine interest in trees. Fun course
Take it! Lectures are great, lab reports aren't fun, but overall, it's a really good and interesting course.
Take notes in lecture. Don't save write ups for the last night. And for all that is holy, don't try and memorize everything for the exams. Think concepts and examples, not rote memorization.
Take this class if you have an interest in evolution and the behavior of animals.
Take this course only if it is a departmental requirement or a pre-med requirement.
Take this course, if only for Pacala's lectures!!!
Take this course.  It is completely engaging and manageable for any kind of student (whether you want to major in EEB or fulfill a distribution requirement)
Talk to professors and lab assistants a lot; ask about every assignment because there are always things they don't tell you.

The change that Professors Pacala and Rubenstein made to this course were great! Usually biology classes focus a lot on memorizing an unmanageable amount of material, but these professors really just wanted students to be able to think critically and apply some basic, general ideas. Good course overall.
The labs are fun and the material is interesting, but this class is a lot of work. Sometimes you don't even know how to study...

The lecturers are awesome and they are reason enough to take the class.  Besides that fact, I think the topics are really interesting and you get to do some cool things in labs and design labs.  It's actually a pretty fun class.
The lectures are great and engaging, but there were some frustrating times when it came to applying the material learned because there is just so much information.

The material is interesting, and the professors and lab TAs are all really nice, supportive people. The textbook is not all that necessary, and the pace of the course is not too stressful. At the same time, I would only really take this course if you have to for EEB major because it is not that entertaining/engaging compared to other courses offered at Princeton.
This class definitely makes learning fun especially because of the labs and design classes. So if you are not really a science person I would recommend it.
This class is slightly all over the place but interesting
This class requires a lot of work but is worth it.
This course is not easy and is often confusing
This course is very interesting, i recommend it to anyone interested in taking biology with no reservations.
This is a great course and I would definitely recommend taking it. Just make sure you dedicate a good amount of time to lab each week because the reports are quite extensive.

This is a intro course that most people take because they have to, but I found it very interesting and cool, especially if you actually think about the material and engage. Its a good overview, and the themes are presented in a way that you get their significance. Also, Pacala is a fox.
Try and do the readings before lecture. Pay attention in lecture. Get started early on the labs.
Try to do labs earlier in the week.
Unless you're really interested in this kind of biology I think there are a bunch of other cool courses Princeton offers!!
Wait to take this course until they change it back to the way it's supposed to be
go to lecture, and have fun with the design classes! (and go to review sessions)
its a pretty good class. I had a pretty good time
pre-med kids need to take it so there is no way out, and i think it is a lot better than it was before, but take it with friends so at least you can vent to others about it.
descrip: An examination of how life evolved and how organisms function. Design--'intelligent' and otherwise--will provide a unifying theme. Why do some microbes produce slime and others do not? Why are males brightly colored in some species, but in others females are the showy sex? Why do humans have knees that fail whereas horses and zebras do not? These and other 'why is it so' questions related to the origin and history of life, genetic code, biochemistry, physiology, morphology and body plans, sex and reproduction, cooperation, and ecosystems will be explored. This course is required of all EEB majors and fulfills a requirement for medical school.

title: Research Projects in Molecular Biology (Laboratory Rotations)
reviews: Don't be disappointed if you aren't given your first choice, it just may work out for the best!

Dr. Troyanksaya is a great professor to rotate with irrespective of your level of computational background. Everyone in the labs was willing to help and answer any questions that would help bring you up to speed.
Get the most out of it.
Go to the all the lunch talks.  Free food, and you never know what might spark your interest.

I would advise any student rotating in a new lab to not be afraid to vocalize any questions or concerns they might have, and to be open-minded and willing to learn anything new from anyone willing to teach them in the lab.
N/A
Rotating is a good idea.

The class should really be called "Methods in Biochemistry," not "Cellular Biochemistry," as almost no topics of cellular biochemistry were actually covered. No reactions, no pathways, and few diseases were included in the course--the main topics were crystallization, mass spectrometry, and force transduction.
descrip: Students will perform research in the laboratories of two faculty advisers.

title: Culture and Inequality
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Chamber Dance: Repertory and Choreography
reviews: Amazing.
Go to the audition, see if you like the teachers as they are different every fall. Think about if you want a piece to be set on you vs generating a new work.
If you want to devote the time and participate in the Spring Dance Festival go for it, but do not accept lightly because it will take up a lot of your time.
Take this class if you want to learn to think in a different way from the way you do normally, and challenge your brain away from problem sets and papers.
take it
prereqs: DAN 419/409 or equivalent experience. Interview with faculty for placement in composition section from April 9th to April 20th, 2012. Interview times: Rebecca Lazier (rlazier@) T/Th 1pm-2pm; Tina Fehlandt (fehlandt@) M/W 1pm-2pm. To arrange interview, email Professor Lazier or Professor Fehlandt and send a list of any previous composition experience at Princeton. NOTE: Placement for Technique/Repertory component of class will be held Thursday, September 13th from 4:30-6:20 at Hagan Dance Studio at 185 Nassau..
descrip: In this course students will learn and perform a work by renowned choreographer Mark Morris, staged by professor Tina Fehlandt, founding company member of MMDG. This course will focus on mastering Morris' unique approach to choreography and specific musicality and use of rhythm. In choreography, students will work together on group objectives in movement-based laboratories focusing on collaboration and choreographic choice-making skills. Readings and viewings inform the studio work and place it in relationship to current artistic movements.

title: The Anthropology of Development
descrip: Why do development projects fail? This course examines why well-meaning development experts get it wrong. It looks closely at what anthropologists mean by culture and why most development experts fail to attend to the cultural forces that hold communities together. By examining development projects from South Asia to the United States, students learn the relevance of exchange relations, genealogies, power, religion, and indigenous law. This semester the class will focus on energy and water.

title: Readings in American History: Reconstruction to World War I
reviews: It was a tremendously heavy workload, so take care in choosing your other classes alongside it. But the work was mostly worth the effort.
Its a great course, good reading list. Professors Rix and Isenberg are both kind and challenging.
Please take a course with either/both Professor Isenberg and/or Professor Rix. It will definitely train you to be a better scholar!
Read a lot, and read quickly. Focus on articulating a single specific argument when writing papers...
Take it!
When it's your turn to lead class discussion, introducing/giving context for the readings is generally more helpful than a long history of the historiography on the topic.
descrip: A comprehensive introduction to the literature and problems of American History from the end of the Civil War through World War I.

title: The Media in America
reviews: Be ready to be critiqued, and take it in stride-- one of the biggest names in journalism is telling you how you could improve-- listen to him!

Before this semester, I had no intention of being a journalist, but now it's a job I am seriously considering. This course is wonderful because you create a relationship with one of today's most widely respected journalists - it's impossible not to, really, because of the weekly 30-minute meetings. Take this class. Evan Thomas might just change your life.
Do it if you're interested in a career in journalism and the media. Be prepared to write and be critiqued.

If you have the chance and have any interest in journalism as a career, you should take this class. At very least, it will convince you otherwise, but at its best, working with Evan Thomas is an opportunity that you should take advantage of.
If you want to be a better writer, take this course.

TAKE THIS COURSE.  This class did for me what Writing Seminar is supposed to do but doesn't really. Professor Thomas's criticism is always incisive-- he has an amazing knack for reading something once and immediately identifying places in which you tried to talk around a difficult issue.  This course has improved my writing and I think it has also made me a more effective person.  Lots of work but worth it.
Take it! Evan Thomas is not only a renowned journalist and former editor-in-chief of Newsweek/TIME, but also an insightful editor and a caring mentor. He will improve your writing and your thinking.
Take this class!
Take this! Evan Thomas is wonderful and it's a very informative and interesting course.
This is a great course! Professor Thomas is very interesting and wants to get to know his students.

This is a great introductory course to journalism. Take it if you have any interest at all in becoming a journalist because it will give a broad overview about the profession today and the assignments give you a chance to do your own reporting and some hands-on experience. You also get to learn from one of the best in Evan Thomas. Be prepared to write a lot however because you will have an assignment every week.
You will learn a lot about clear writing that will come in handy no matter what career you are interested in! And Evan Thomas is one of the best professors in Princeton!
be ready to work. and write.
prereqs: Enrollment by application: http://humanities.princeton.edu..
descrip: This seminar will discuss such topics as secrecy, national security, and a free press; reputation, privacy, and the public's right to know; muckraking and the "establishment" press; spin and manipulation; the rise of blogging; the economic impact of technological change on the news business.

title: Introduction to the Architecture Profession
reviews: Definitely take it, and try to get as much out of it as you can, as the information is very useful.
I would definitly recommend this course and my advice would be for them to have a practical perspective about what they are going to learn in this course as it is not a merely theory course.
It's a refreshingly different perspective from most of what you hear at the school.
My advice would be to take this course as well as the other one in the spring
They might want to suggest better way to do the assignment.
descrip: The carrying out of architectural services goes beyond design and involves an obligation to the public, to clients, to peers and employees. This course deals with the contracts, specifications, technical documentation, project management and construction administration phases of the architectural services.

title: Computers in Our World
reviews: Best QR course offered.

Do the readings before lecture: you will understand so much more of what you hear. Do problem sets and labs early enough to be able to go to Kernighan's office hours and the TAs' lab hours with questions, because you will have them. Above all, do not be fooled by the nickname "Emails for Females": this class involves tricky quantitative reasoning, and its workload is hefty. Labs and problem sets are a serious time commitment. Nonetheless, COS 109 is surely the most enjoyable way to do your QR if you are averse to math; you may even find yourself having fun playing with binary numbers, as I did.

Do the readings! You won't be as surprised by the materials if you keep up! 
Go to office hours, they are so helpful and it's really nice to just bond with Prof Kernighan 
Lab hours are super helpful!
Start the psets and labs a little earlier than you would that way you are not staying up at all hours of the night in frustration.

Don't be fooled by what others say about the class. There is a lot of busy work but it is an overall satisfying class and a much better alternative to a lot of the other QR classes that are offered. It would also be great to take a class with Professor Kernighan in a chilled out environment like this one.
Don't.
First, Professor Kernighan is brilliant and terrific in every way.  He makes up for the deficiencies in the interest of the material.  It's a good thing to know a little bit about.

Go to lecture and take detailed notes! You would think that since Brian is nice and posts the lecture PowerPoints online that you don't need to take notes, but huge wake up call on the midterm when little details such as people discussed in lecture that were not on the PowerPoints appeared on it. Also, take advantage of office hours!
Good QR. Lectures were interesting, and you end up learning a lot of material that is relevant to how you use the internet/your own computer.
Good class. Material is somewhat interesting, but professor kernighan is worth taking the course
Great, relatively easy QR with a great professor.
Highly recommend it. Take this course and don't be afraid. I hate math and math things but actually loved this course. It's a great QR!
I actually learned a good deal about computers in the class!

I took this course because I was afraid of 126, and I feel like I learned a lot of valuable information. Even my COS major friends learned things when I showed them my notes! Kernighan wants you to succeed and will help you as much as you need along the way. I just wanted to fulfill a DQ and get it over with, but this course has really sparked my interest and I plan on taking further COS classes.
I took this course purely for fun (I already got my QR out of the way) but now I think I may get a D. Generally, I regret taking this class.

I was prepared to put in some time and effort to get my PDF QR credit, but this took a great deal more out of me than I was expecting. I expect a little prior knowledge in the field would help and genuine interest in the subject matter is probably a necessity.
I would highly recommend this for anyone who needs to fulfill their QR or just wants to know more about computers. Professor Kernighan is an amazing lecturer
I would recommend this course to fulfill the QR requirement, although it was more difficult than I expected.  Be prepared to do a fair amount of work, even if you choose to P/D/F it.
I would say this is a great way to get a distribution requirement finished while at the same time learning something that you will use in your life beyond the final exam.

I would take it for sure, whether or not you have in interest in computers. You learn so much that is practical, and really interesting too. It'll be really worth your time. A great QR if you're looking for one.

If you are mildly interested in computers and want to enjoy a class, take COS 109. Be warned that this isnt a dont come to class dont do any work get an A type class, there is a problem set and a lab every week. They arent terribly difficult, but do require you to put effort in. If you dont mind doing relatively easy work for 3-5 hours a week (worth 40% of the grade) then go for it. Kernighan is a good dude.
If you have the slightest interest in computer science, then take it for sure, but if not, skip it.

If you suck at math because your high school math consisted of the teacher telling you that your calculator is your best buddy, you will most likely struggle with this course. It isn't as easy for those with little interest in quantitative applications of computer science. Since COS 109 is unique to Princeton, it's hard to get extra practice problems and alternative ways of explaining the concepts. If you need a QR, there are other QR's without a weekly lab and p-set. Good luck!
If you want to fill your QA and you are good at word problems, take this course. Professor Kernighan is wonderful.
It isn't as easy as you might think, but it is definitely worth taking
It's not as easy as you might think it is.

It's not as easy as you think. The lectures are great, but the problem sets can be really frustrating. Come to lab sessions with the lab already practically done or else you won't have enough time to get all the help you need from the one TA available during the lab session, but otherwise, the labs are definitely manageable.
Keep up on the readings, attend all the lectures, and don't fall asleep or use your laptop in class
Kernighan is the greatest guy. Take it.

Not bad for a QR, but I would warn that the exams seem arbitrarily preoccupied with trivia questions regarding notable computer scientists, tech geeks, and the like. I did enjoy learning some introductory level programming and ideas guiding cos from the labs. The psets were sort of silly but forgivable. Professor Kernighan is a really nice guy, and at the very least hit him up with an email sometime.
Pay attention in lectures and you don't have to do the assigned reading. Focus more on math problems when it comes to studying for exams.
Save your problem sets and labs.
TAKE IT. If you need a QR it's not much effort to PDF but you learn so much and Prof. Kernighan is the most awesome man on the planet
Take it and ask lots of questions. Visit Professor Kernighan.
Take it for a good QR.
Take it if you need a QR and are interested in computers. But know you will have to keep on top of work even if you P/D/F
Take it! I learned a lot about computers.
Take it-- you'll learn a lot of stuff that you should know but don't.  The math part is really easy.
Take it.

Take this course if you are that person who just takes your iphone and computer for granted because this will teach you so much about where technology came from and where it is going. People joke about how easy it is, but it is only easy if you stay on top of the problem sets, reading, and lecture notes. Professor Kernighan is approachable and a great resource for help throughout the course.
Take this for a goo but challenging QR.
This is not an easy class. Be prepared to work and study for the exam! The whole open book/open note policy is deceptive. the exam is hard!
This is the best class I have taken at Princeton.  Take it.  Brian Kernighan is the man.
You actually have to try. This has a reputation for being "really easy," but it's actually not. It was a lot more difficult than I thought.
take it.
prereqs: Not intended for science/engineering/mathematics students. May not be taken for credit after COS 126 or higher..
descrip: Computers are all around us. How does this affect the world we live in? This course is a broad introduction to computing technology for humanities and social sciences students. Topics will be drawn from current issues and events, and will include discussion of how computers work; what programming is and why it is hard; how the Internet and the Web work; security and privacy.

title: Polymers
reviews: Good class, great overview of polymer chemistry, and average workload.

I really enjoyed this course; the material was interesting, although the exams were difficult and the problem sets took time. I'd recommend taking this class with a friend or two so you can discuss any difficult concepts and work on the homework in a group.
I would recommend this course to other students interested in materials or polymers. I think its actually a useful area to have some knowledge in this field.

It's a good class to fill a departmental, especially if you're on the materials track. But if you just want to get your chemE breadth out  of the way, it's probably not the easiest class to choose. Problem sets won't be too time consuming.  Material is interesting
Nobody could possibly regret taking this course.
The material isn't appropriate for everybody, but if you think you might find polymers interesting then the course is a very good overview that provides reasonable breadth and depth on the topic.
prereqs: Prerequisite courses CHM 301 or 303, and MAT 104 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: Broad introduction to polymer science and technology, including polymer chemistry (major synthetic routes to polymers), polymer physics (solution and melt behavior, solid-state morphology and properties), and polymer engineering (overview of reaction engineering and melt processing methods).

title: Philosophy and the Study of Religion
descrip: The impact of twentieth-century philosophical ideas on the academic study of religion: naturalism, phenomenology, hermeneutics, structuralism, Nietzschean genealogy, and American pragmatism, among other philosophical movements.

title: Art for Everyone
reviews: Take this course if you're interested in learning about a lot of experimental forms of art. Be prepared for classmates who might not care as much about the course as you however, since it is PDF only and attracts mostly non-majors.
This is an interesting and low key class that allows you to explore a variety of types of art even if you have no artistic abilities
You are an idiot if you do not take this class.  One of the greats.
n/a
prereqs: Restriction: This course is not open to students who took VIS 472, Special Topics in Visual Arts - Art for Everyone.
descrip: This studio class will address the increasing social pressure on art to become more widely distributed, immediately accessible, and democratically produced. For the past fifty years, expanding definitions of what art might be fueled by a greater emphasis on active audience participation have encouraged an atmosphere in which anyone can claim to be an artist. Through studio work in a wide range of graphic and digital media, supported by readings and discussions, this class will take a hands-on approach to the question of whether art by everyone for everyone constitutes a dreamed-of utopia, a universal banality, or a cultural nightmare.

title: Constitutional Theory
descrip: The specific focus of the course varies from year to year, but the principal concerns revolve around questions of what a constitutional democracy is, why a people should want to live in such a polity, and how political actors can create, maintain, and change such systems.

title: Policy Workshop - Exploring Alternatives to the Two-State Solution
descrip: The search for Israeli-Palestinian peace historically has focused on the two-state solution, i.e., the partition of Palestine/Eretz Israel into two states. However, prospects for achieving this appear dim: peace talks have stalemated and Palestinian and Israeli views have hardened. This workshop will examine alternatives to the two-state paradigm, including prospects for diplomacy, political buy-in by the parties, and the impact on new realities on the ground. Following the fall 2012 U.S. presidential election, the workshop?s assessment and policy recommendations will be briefed to senior policy makers dealing with the Middle East.

title: Introduction to Comparative Literature
descrip: Comparative literature-always a fluid, contested discipline-may be more so now than ever. This introduction offers a forum for graduate students to become acquainted with our professors' varied approaches to the discipline. Students from other departments are welcome to join us. Our guests have selected readings and topics of general interest to students working in a variety of national literatures and time periods. The first and last sessions-as well as some in between-will include discussions of the present state and premises of the discipline, and some possibilities for its future. That's where you come in...

title: Topics in Ecology - Biodiversity: Origins and Maintenance
descrip: The causes of global patterns in plant and animal diversity remain a topic of debate just as when Wallace and Darwin defined the issue. This seminar seeks a new synthetic understanding of the topic via critical reviews of major papers on (1) macro-evolutionary patterns of species formation and loss as documented in the paleontological literature, (2) the causes and dynamics of speciation, (3) geographic (including latitudinal) patterns in species diversity, (4) allometric scaling of body size, abundance, productivity, etc. and diversity, and (5) analytical theories of interspecific interactions and species persistence/coexistence.

title: Reasoning about Computation
reviews: Be ready to think, and enjoy it.
Choose your homework partners well, and start your problem sets early.  I found this course to be very, very difficult.
DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE!  Oh wait, you're a COS major and you have to because it's a required departmental?  Sucks to be you!
Do not take this course lightly. It will eat you if you aren't careful. If you are careful, however, it will be greatly rewarding.
Great course (at least when taught by Moses - he's an excellent lecturer).  Homework can get a bit rough, start it early so you have time to look at the hard problems with fresh eyes on another day.
If you're truly interested in theory, this will whet your appetite. Even if you're not, this is an excellent introduction to proofs/mathematical thinking about CS.

It was hard for me because my brain isn't wired that way, but some people I know really liked the topics - and I even found some of them interesting. That being said, I wouldn't have taken this class if it weren't a departmental. Take if for the subject if you end up taking it - if you don't like the subject, you'll have a really hard time.
Also note that people come into the class from a wide variety of backgrounds so some of them just get this naturally. If you're not one of them, don't take it!
Only take this if you have to.  Not advisable as a fun class.  Expect to work non-stop from day one.
Prepare yourself to spend a lot of time on problem sets.  Go to lecture.  You don't need do the readings thoroughly, but they are useful for reference.

TAKE IT WHEN YOU HAVE A LIGHT COURSELOAD. But DO take it. You'll hear people say it's only for "math geniuses" but believe me, run-of-the-mill hard worker's who aren't gifted with the einstein gene can still do well. Go in with 2 friends and you'll have a blast. Also -- convince Moses to make the problem sets due at 12 am from the beginning of the semester, so you don't wind up pulling an all nighter every thursday night like I did.
Take it seriously. It's hard and it makes you better.
be sure about your mathematical expertise
very interesting class, but it is extremely hard.  make sure you have a good group of three to do the psets with. and get to work on them early!
descrip: An introduction to mathematical topics relevant to computer science. Combinatorics and probability will be covered in the context of computer science applications. The course will present a computer science approach to thinking and modeling through topics such as dealing with uncertainty in data and handling large data sets. Students will be introduced to fundamental concepts such as NP-completeness and cryptography that arise from the world view of efficient computation.

title: Chemical Kinetics
reviews: Be prepared to spend a lot of time reading journal articles.
Buy the text for the course.
Show up to class and read assignments to get the most bang for your buck!
Take it.
descrip: A survey of chemical kinetics. Kinetic measurements and experimental methods, reaction rate theory, molecular dynamics experiment and theory will be discussed. Both gas phase and condensed phase kinetic studies will be considered.

title: Secrecy, Accountability and the National Security State
descrip: National security secrecy presents a conflict of core values: self-government and self-defense. We need information to hold our leaders accountable, but if we know our enemies know too. This course explores that dilemma and the complex relationships that resolve it. We will apply competing legal and philosophical models to real-world cases of unauthorized disclosure. Class discussion will be enriched by visiting government officials, journalists and lawyers. Among the subjects: weapons of mass destruction, Pentagon Papers, domestic surveillance and Wikileaks.

title: Civitas Foundation Finance Seminar
reviews: NA.
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: East Asian Humanities I: The Classical Foundations
reviews: All you folks looking for an EM should take this class now. It's really chill, and honestly, a good way to get EM credit without dabbling into too much philosophy. This course is more literature than anything else, in fact. You watch cool movies, listen to cool music, try out Chinese calligraphy... Hell yeah, it's fun, and not a lot of work.
Be ready for a lot of reading.
Don't take this course unless you have to. It was probably my least favorite course I've ever taken (I'm a senior).
Don't take unless for EAS requirement
I would say that this course appeals to those interested in it but not if you don't already like thinking about East Asian thought.
Take this if you want an introduction course on history of China, Korea and Japan (with emphasis on the humanities side)
Unless you have to take this for a departmental, I wouldn't take it as an introduction to East Asian Studies.
don't take it
descrip: An introduction to the literature, art, religion, and philosophy of China, Japan, and Korea from antiquity to ca. 1400. Readings are focused on primary texts in translation and complemented by museum visits, films, and other materials from the visual arts. The lectures include faculty members from East Asian Studies, Comparative Literature, Art and Archaeology, and Religion. Students are encouraged to enroll in HUM/EAS/COM 234 in the spring, which will continue the course from ca. 1400 into the 20th century.

title: Educational Psychology
reviews: DO NOT FALL BEHIND. No, seriously, you may begin to drown. There is more work than you can comprehend in the course. It does not seem like it at forst, but it will pile up, so do everything in your power to stay current at all times!

Great course, but LOTS of work. The writing can be easily ~60 pages total, and more than half of the assignments give you the opportunity to revise, which is good in that you can do a better job, but also means that you basically do each assignment twice. There's lots of reading, but it is all informative, especially if you're planning on teaching, any subject at any level.

Great/good course.  I learned a lot.  This class was great for just sitting down to think about things--whether they were resolved or not and to let things ruminate in your mind for an earnest, hard discussion about it.  I think that psychology courses are basically for hanging out now, albeit a structured, official thoughtful hanging out with some readings.  I say this since this is my first psychology course ever, discounting intro to neuroscience which is really more of a biology class.  I think that I found my niche sorta, in it.  At the same time, I find psychology annoying with too many general inconclusions.  But it's good to thikn about them and think more about what to do about them.  More often, I wish that we made more headway as a group though on some things.  It was a bit frustrating for me.  I don't think that other people were as committed to pushing the boundaries of the topics as much as I was.  Even if they were, it was hard to feel/sense the presence/weight of their commitment.

I did not put down "Strongly Recommend" only because this class requires a lot of work, so a student must be highly interested and motivated to learn about the subject. Even though I think this topic should seem important to everyone, if this is not the case it would probably be better not to take it.

I would highly recommend this course for anyone interested in understanding the theories which support different ideas in education (including teaching techniques).  This is not a class on how to teach, but rather a class on how theories from psychology apply to the broad domain of education.  Students should be prepared to spend significant time each week on the reading assignments.
I would recommend this class to anybody who in interested in education, particularly teaching and education reform. Just be prepared because it does require a lot of work, but it is worth it.
If you are taking the course for TPP (or considering it in the future) spend time looking at those requirements so you can be strategic in how you use your time in PSY 307.
If you're interested in teaching at any point in your life - TAKE THIS COURSE. Professor Comer is absolutely phenomenal and the material is really engaging.
TAKE IT
Take it if Comer is teaching again. You will have fun and learn a lot.
Take it if you want to be a teacher.  Take it if you want to do edu policy stuff.

This class is not just for those in the Teacher Prep program. I took this class because I'm interested in teaching and education and really enjoyed it - it brought many of things I've learned as a psych major into a practical context and a discussion of how to implement in the real world. If you're thinking about teaching at all, take this class! It is so interesting and you will learn a lot - both from the material and your fellow classmates.
prereqs: This course is required for students enrolled in the Teacher Preparation Program (TPP). Priority is given to Juniors and Seniors in TPP. Other Juniors and Seniors may enroll only with permission of instructor..
descrip: Principles of psychology relevant to the theory and practice of education. Through selected readings, discussion, and classroom observations, students study theories of development, learning, cognition (including literacy), and motivation, as well as individual and group differences in these areas; assessment; and the social psychology of the classroom. The course focuses on how learning by children and adolescents at the elementary, middle, and secondary school levels is influenced by their own characteristics and experiences and the various contexts in which they learn: family, school, community and culture.

title: Elementary Swahili I
reviews: Attend lectures and keep up with memorizing vocabulary--it is very difficult to cram lots of material right before an exam!
I will encourage students who want to take this class that they will learn best with Prof. Mwita by being co-operative rather competitive with their classmates.
I would recommend that the student take this course if he or she has even the slightest interest in it.
If you want to learn Swahili, take it. And take it before senior year, so you can go to Dar!
Take it. It's easy, you learn a language, you get to really get to know the professor and classmates. :)
Take this course if you're even remotely interested in Swahili language or East African culture. Mahiri is great.
Take your journal seriously.
take it if you want to learn swahili
descrip: An introduction to Kiswahili language and culture for students who have no prior knowledge of the language. The course is taught in Kiswahili and focuses on acquiring novice-level skills to perform basic communication functions in the culture of Swahili speakers. Instruction is through performance of cultural themes and experiential activities that enhance the four components of speaking, writing, listening, and reading. At the end of the course, students are expected to acquire simple grammatical skills to perform day-to-day interactions in the language and gain some insight into the culture of East Africa.

title: Music & Animation from Ovid to Disney
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Frederick Douglass and the Long 19th Century
descrip: This seminar conjoins the work of Frederick Douglass - his speeches, essays, journalism, autobiographies, photographs, and fiction - with that of other contemporaneous figures as means to explore several of the philosophical, social, political, and cultural developments of nineteenth- and early twentieth century America. These include: the relationship between the public image and the private self, the politics of literary representation and a national literature, tensions among social movements, and the function of historical memory.

title: What Makes a Poem Endure
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Advanced Russian Reading and Conversation I
reviews: Be prepared to speak in class every day. Spend a couple of minutes before each class thinking about what you want to contribute orally in class about the material/reading covered. Ksana really emphasizes speaking participation in class.

If you like studying Russian, you'll like this class.  Ksana is a good teacher.  Keep in mind though, that this class is a good bit of work.  Ksana assigns a good bit of homework each night, and she expects you to participate in class.  Very little English is spoken.
If you want to continue with Russian, take this course.  It's a very good class with a wonderful professor.
It is your only option for third year. Yep.
Its a challenging course, but definitely rewarding and you will have fun while you are doing it.

Ksana is really nice, and although the class is alot of work, I'd still recommend it. You will go above and beyond the call for a normal class (like putting on a play in Russian for the slavic department, or singing at the holiday party), but you do improve your Russian.

This class is actually a lot of work and takes a lot of time almost every night, so be ready for that. Ksana has high expectations, but she also clearly cares a lot about the course and teaches it well. This is a solid continuation of Russian from PiP.
prereqs: RUS 107 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: A literature/language course designed to further develop speaking and reading proficiency, comprehension and writing skills through substantial expansion of vocabulary, work on sentence structure, review of selected grammar topics, discussion of the literary texts, and work with a movie.

title: Readings in Modern Korean History
descrip: A survey of major issues and debates in the historiography of modern Korea. Course introduces the major English language works on modern Korean history. Topics include: "opening" of Korea, Japanese colonialism, space of liberation, the Korean war, issues of gender and labor, and U.S.-Korean relations. No previous knowledge of Korean history or language is necessary, but basic knowledge of twentieth century East Asian history is expected.

title: Studies in German Language and Style: Society, Politics, and Culture in Germany, 1890-1945
reviews: Be prepared for a lot of in-class discussions and independent thinking - and reading that is not prolific but difficult for a new German-speaker.
If you're looking for a class that will maintain your language skills but is not terribly intensive, this one is a good choice.

Take it if Pourciau teaches it. She's very good at leading discussions and is very nice and approachable. Some readings are excellent, others are horrendous, but as long as you skim them or read a few pages, you'll be totally fine. Not too much work unless you agonize over the readings, which is definitely unnecessary. Just read enough to understand the main idea. Get initial feedback on essays.

This class is definitely worth taking. It's taught much like an English class, but in German. I took this class coming from AP German, and I found the level to be appropriate. Don't be afraid to speak up in class!
prereqs: GER 107 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: Discussion of exemplary texts from modern German society and culture, including essays, speeches, autobiographies, works of literature, art, and film. The course offers an introduction to important issues in modern Germany: Berlin as a modern metropolis, World War I, the rise of National Socialism, the postwar landscape, and the contemporary political situation. Intensive practice in spoken and written German with emphasis on vocabulary acquisition and complex syntactical forms.

title: Seminar in American Politics - Latino Politics in the U.S.
reviews: Ali really cares about the students and the subject matter.  It was great to have a professor who was so actively engaged with class topics (specifically conducting research on many of the issues).

If you are a freshman, sophomore, and even a junior, you can benefit greatly from this class. Professor Valenzuela structured his class in such a way that you leave thinking about different areas of research you can pursue. A lot of that work could be used as a head start for your JP or thesis. If you are a senior you will not benefit as much, but the class is still interesting.

If you're at all interested in Latino politics, or even just in political science more broadly, you should take this course.  This was a truly fantastic course.  I learned a lot about both areas, and I grew tremendously as a writer and thinker in both fields as a result of Professor Valenzuela's instruction. He's a great professor and the material itself is relevant and interesting by nature.

TAKE THIS CLASS. 
Go to Office Hours. 
Ali is the man. He's brilliant. I almost changed departments for him. He's so awesome.
The subject matter is very interesting, and you will have very enjoyable discussions during the class, but it was a little too focused on writing academic papers, and at times was dry and repetitive.
There's a lot of writing. You have to be willing to put in the work.
Think about how you can critique the findings of any and all scholars.

This class gave me real exposure to how research in political science is done, analyzing current research that tested hypotheses statistically. Would definitely recommend for someone who is considering doing quantitative research in politics for their independent work.
Though demanding and somewhat challenging at first, I highly recommend this course if you are ready to put in work because you will learn a lot.
prereqs: Open to sophomores, juniors and seniors from any concentration. Ideal for sophomore and junior social science concentrators interested in developing a research proposal on the course topic(s) that can later be used (after the course is finished) as the basis for a junior paper or senior thesis project. Students will have the option of a final paper in lieu of a research proposal. No prior knowledge of the topic is required, but familiarity with the basics of American politics and scientific inquiry will be very helpful..
descrip: What is the history and contemporary role of Latinos in U.S. politics? Will the growing Hispanic population reconfigure the presidential contest in 2012 or beyond? This seminar will use social science to examine these and other questions on how Latinos are shaping state and national politics. Topics include: immigration and its political impact; civil rights mobilization and political gains for Latinos; patterns of political participation and strategies for engaging Latino voters; public policy issues that concern them; and the importance of subgroup differences such as national origin and religious affiliation for Latino political behavior.

title: Public Finance
reviews: Attend all the lectures, it really makes a huge difference on how much you get out of the course. Only a fraction of the course is contained in Gruber's book -- all is exanded upon in lecture.
I would highly recommend this course to anyone who is interested.
Learn about some important issues in a reasonably sophisticated manner after enduring a boring introduction to economics.
Pretty good class for introduction to public finance.
prereqs: ECO 100. A working knowledge of calculus is required for this course..
descrip: The main goal is to learn to think analytically about government policy problems.

title: Problems in Political Theory - Moderation
descrip: This course examines Aristotle's Politics, Machiavelli's Discourses on Livy and Florentine Histories, Montesquieu's Persian Letters and Spirit of the Laws, Burke?s Reflections on the Revolution in France, and Tocqueville's Democracy in America. We will study the broader themes in these texts and we will also examine how far these texts shed light on the idea of moderation and the idea of a moderate regime in particular. Some of the questions we will address include: Is there such a thing as a moderate regime? Why is moderation valuable? Is a democratic regime more or less likely to be moderate?

title: Elementary Japanese I
reviews: Don't take it if you can't put in tons of time.
Go to class every day and do the homework, and you will learn the material quite well.  It is a lot of work but quite fun.
Great class. Go to lecture and do the assignments. Take sometime every day to review material from lecture. Do not fall behind.

I think if you want to learn Japanese you should totally go for it 
It requires a lot of effort in order to do well but it's worth it most of the time
If you are considering taking JPN101 but aren't sure, you should go for it.  It's a lot of work, but very fun.  It provides a good counterbalance to serious/depressing courses.
If you want to learn Japanese, take it. If you don't, you have no business here.
It takes dedication, but if you want to learn Japanese, this is the way to do it!

It you already have a little background in Japanese (you'll probably find that some of your classmates have already studied Japanese/lived in Japan), are a good foreign language student, and are committed to learning Japanese quickly and devoting a lot of time to it, this course is well suited to you.  Beware though that Japanese is arguably the hardest language for English-speakers to learn, and that the senseis (who are very approachable and helpful) are very hard working and will expect the same level of commitment from their students.  As a science-y student with no prior knowledge of Japanese and no particular inclination toward languages in general, I found myself frequently overwhelmed and wondering why on earth I had signed up for this course.
Japanese is a very interesting, fulfilling class to take. It is probably healthiest not to think too much about grades in this class though.

Learn the hiragana and katakana quickly, better if you learn it before class starts. Also, try to pick up as much vocabulary as possible before the class begins. Do your homework and go to all the classes.
One of the best courses I've taken at Princeton.  Go to the sensei's office hours for extra help/practice.  It really is a course where you get back how much effort you put into the course.
Study, and practice!  And blogging really helps.

TAKE IT. If you have any interest in Japanese culture or even if you just like manga/anime, you could not go wrong taking this course. Although Japanese does require a bit of a time commitment (it's supposed to be one of the hardest languages for English speakers to learn), the teachers are all excellent and willing to help. You really get to know the people in your class and you'd be surprised at how much you can learn.
TAKE THIS COURSE. IT IS AWESOME. THE SENSEI ARE AWESOME. JAPANESE IS AWESOME. TAKE IT!

This course is extremely fast paced, but if you're willing to put in the effort and don't have serious trouble learning languages, you will do well. Take this course if you are interested in an East Asian language.

This is a course with a singular vision for learning Japanese with which you may fall in love; it's also possible that you won't. You shouldn't take the course if you aren't completely serious about learning the language because it requires significant extra-classroom commitment and the language itself is ludicrously difficult. Also prepare to deal with a bunch of kids who love anim? a lot. Try and take it with a friend.
This is a fun course and you will learn a lot of Japanese. It's a big time commitment though. I am amazed how much Japanese I've learned in one semester.
This is a really fun, fast-paced course. I really enjoyed class; it's taught very well!
This was a fun course. Very difficult, but rewarding. I feel like I learned a lot.
if you want to learn, and are willing to take on the workload, go for it
take it if you want
prereqs: No credit is given for JPN 101 unless it is followed by JPN 102..
descrip: An intensive introduction to modern Japanese stressing oral-aural facility, but including an introduction to written Japanese.

title: Independent Study
descrip: Independent Study in the student's area of interest. The work must be conducted under the supervision of a faculty member and must result in a final paper. Permission of advisor and instructor are required. Open to sophomores and juniors. Must fill out Independent Study form.

title: Topics in the History and Theory of Architecture in Early-Modern Europe - The Rome of Giovanni Battista Piranesi
descrip: The focus of the seminar will be G.B. Piranesi (1720-1778), as architect, antiquarian, polemicist, dealer, and graphic artist. We will endeavor to see Piranesi in context, to understand his accomplishment against the background of his adopted city and the learned culture that flourished there. Piranesi's publications are well represented in Princeton collections, providing opportunities for those who wish to work closely with original sources.

title: Technology and Culture
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Policy Analysis: Selected Topics (Half-Term) - The Federal Budget
descrip: This course will cover how the Federal budget process is supposed to work and how it actually does work. Topics will include: (1) institutions, processes, and definitions; (2) history of budget outcomes; (3) the current state of the Federal budget process; (4) the role of uncertainty in budgeting; (4) the role of politics in budgeting; and (5) the budget's short- and long-term fiscal consequences.

title: History of Russian Literature before 1860
reviews: Amazing!  Great course with Emerson or Chances.  You'll be hooked on Russian Lit, I promise.
Grin and bear lecture, enjoy the books.
I recommend this class to any one who wants a great literature for someone who doesn't have a huge prior background in literature, Professor Chances is excellent.
If there is any interest in Russian literature, culture, history or even just a love of good literature, this course is worth a look.
Please take it!
Take it even if you don't know anything about Russian or literature.

There's a manageable amount of reading, which you really have to do to get the most out of precept and lecture. Prof. Chances is so passionate about Russian lit that it's really a pleasure to hear her speak about it.

This is really a great course if you are interested in the subject material. Professor Chances is so in love with her field that it is pure joy to listen to her lectures. (And she is wonderfully quirky). Read everything if you plan on taking the exam and want to do well, but I think it is also possible to take the course a bit easy because there is only reading.
prereqs: Knowledge of Russian not required..
descrip: A survey in English of major literary developments and fictional texts in Russian culture from the early nineteenth century to the mid-19th century. The course concentrates on these master prose writters: Pushkin, Gogol, Lermontov, the early Dostoevsky, and the early Tolstoy.

title: Public Opinion
reviews: A pretty typical mid-size Politics departmental
Don't take it unless it's a departmental. Mendelberg isn't a great lecturer and the material can be flat.

Don't take this unless it's majorly reworked. Professor Mendelberg is not a great lecturer or even course planner, though she does seem to attract invested preceptors. The course has potential, but it's not there yet.
I loved this class. Spend enough time on the papers, and you'll do well.
I probably wouldn't recommend this class to someone--unless they are very interested in public opinion

I would recommend this course to students who want to learn more about current events and the way that public opinion polls work but a lot of the scholarship we read was outdated so be prepared to read things from 50 years ago before anybody even had a computer.
If you are looking for a class that is not too time consuming but does accomplish the goals that it sets out to, take it!
If you're interested in public opinion or just politics in general, you should give this course a look. It's not great, but it's very little work and is often interesting.
Its a good departmental but not great if for just pure enjoyment
None. I would say not to take it.
One of the best politics courses I have taken at Princeton
Participate in any out of class activities.
Stay focused, participate, and take good notes in precepts, it will be very helpful later in the course.  Skim readings to get a general idea and compare to the studies that Tali has in her slides
Take it during an election year- it will be far more interesting. Take-home midterm and take-home final are the way to go!
Take notes on all relevant things to be used at the end because you will forget.

Take this class! Professor Mendelberg is great, the material is interesting, and the exams are challenging in the sense that they really make you think, but are also fair evaluations of the material provided.
Take this course!  Professor Mendelberg is extremely approachable and helpful!
This is a great department for Politics majors.
We only had two big papers and class participation so it was hard to determine whether or not to PDF
Without the experience of the polling project, this class is not the most exciting
definitely take this course but stay on top of the readings since you will get more out of it
it is not rivetting.
try to sign up for mendelberg's precept
would definitely recommend it
descrip: This course is an introduction to the study of American public opinion. We pay particular attention to the questions of where people get their opinions, to inequalities in public opinion, and to the public's competence to govern.

title: Introductory Playwriting
reviews: Do it. Go in with an open mind and a good sense of humor, and you will leave with an appreciation for a craft and the rudiments necessary to produce satisfactory pieces. There is nothing quite like learning how to create, creating, and then feeling proud of what has been created.
Do it. Take the course.

I strongly recommend this class to anyone interested in theater and perhaps anyone interested in just writing. This course gives you a new perspective on action, character and realism in writing, not just playwriting.
Strongly recommend if you have any interest in theater.
TAKE IT! (if Prof. Sandberg is teaching it; if not, I can't comment as accurately but you should probably still take it)
TAKE IT! Even if you are unsure of yourself as a writer, this class taught me so much, and it was so much fun.
Take this class if you've ever even considered playwriting.
prereqs: Enrollment by interview with the instructor, Professor Robert Sandberg (rsand@Princeton.edu). Please visit the Theater Program website for specific information..
descrip: This is a workshop in the fundamentals of writing plays. Emphasis will be on solving problems of structure, dramatic action, and character. Attention will also be given to innerlife, language, atmosphere on stage, creating living dialogue, and examining the sources to be used in writing, etc.

title: Intermediate Syriac
descrip: Study of selected passages from various genres of Syriac literature. Knowledge of Syriac is required.

title: Introduction to Geophysical Fluid Dynamics
reviews: Be prepared.

I went into this course driven to gain a "mastery" of GFD, only to realize that GFD is very hard to have intuition for (largely because of the non-intuitive nature of the Coriolis force). In order to be satisfied with this course, go into it looking to learn how to solve the problems, and maybe pick up bits of intuition as you go along. The problem sets are hard, but they are well thought out and it feels great to figure them out. If you don't understand the material or a problem, go talk to one of the professors, even if that means going to GFDL. This will help you a lot, and will also help the professors understand how much the students are understanding so they can lecture better.
It will take a lot of time, but it's worth it.

Read this before taking:  
John Marshal's Atmosphere, Ocean, and Climate Dynamics -- an introductory text
This is a tough class and it is better of you to have some background before you take it.
descrip: Physical principles fundamental to the theoretical, observational, and experimental study of the atmosphere and oceans. The equations of motion for rotating fluids. Hydrostatic and geostrophic balance. Conservation of potential vorticity. Introduction to quasi-geostrophic theory and baroclinic instability. Geophysical boundary layers. Rossby and gravity waves.

title: Evolution and Catastrophes
reviews: If you are able to take the field trip than go for it. If not then don't take it
It's a bit disorganized, but Professor Keller is really a lot of fun and let us decide on how our grading would break down.  You learn a lot from this class and really get to know each other.
Take this class!

This class if very very difficult. There is lots of information and lots of reading. The trip is lots of fun, though the field report with research component will put you in the library for a week. Professor Keller is excellent.
You really have to be interested in geology.  I am more of a biology person and was fooled by 'evolution' in the title of the course.  We talk about rocks most of the time.
prereqs: One 200-level GEO course..
descrip: This course introduces students to the evolution of life and mass extinction's based on a broad survey of major events in Earth history as revealed by the fossil record. Concepts and techniques of paleontology are applied to all aspects, including colonization of the oceans, invasion of land, mass extinction's and evolutionary radiations. The roles of major catastrophes in the history of life are evaluated, including meteorite impacts, volcanism, climate change, and oceanic anoxia.

title: Seminar in Comparative Politics - African Politics
descrip: One or more theoretical topics currently of major concern in comparative politics are treated.

title: Lighting Design
prereqs: This course is by Open Enrollment -- please enroll through SCORE directly..
descrip: An introduction to the art and craft of lighting design for the stage and an exploration of light as a medium for expression. Students will develop an ability to observe lighting in the world and on the stage; to learn to make lighting choices based on text, space, research, and their own responses; to practice being creative, responsive and communicative under pressure and in company; to prepare well to create under pressure using the designer's visual toolbox; and to play well with others-working creatively and communicating with directors, writers, performers, fellow designers, the crew and others.

title: Dance Performance Workshop: Intermediate Repertory and Choreography
reviews: Definitely recommend taking this class!
Never pass up the opportunity to take courses in the dance program!
Really listen to what Zvi and Ann say they have so much to give.
TAKE IT! Great way to get exercise while pursuing such a gorgeous art form
Take it.  Mark Morris is AWESOME!!!

Take this course! The guest professors are awesome and each bring a unique feel to the department. However, do not expect to be doing a lot of interesting or challenging readings, which I found myself craving.
prereqs: DAN 219/220, or equivalent. Interview with faculty for placement in composition section from April 9th to April 20th, 2012. Interview times: Rebecca Lazier (rlazier@) T/TH 1pm-2pm; Tina Fehlandt (fehlandt@) M/W 1pm-2pm. To arrange interview, e-mail Professor Lazier or Professor Fehlandt and send a list of any previous composition experience at Princeton. NOTE: Placement for Technique/Repertory component of class will be held Thursday, September 13th from 4:30-6:20 at Hagan Dance Studio at 185 Nassau..
descrip: Intermediate dance technique and choreography, with a focus on contemporary practices. In technique, students will be challenged to increase their body's strength, coordination and alignment, and to develop awareness and range of motion in multiple spatial planes. The repertory component of this course calls on students' collaborative abilities as they work with faculty in the development a new dance. In choreography, students will work in movement-based laboratories to develop their fluency with a wide range of contemporary choreographic approaches. Readings and viewings contextualize the work culturally and historically.

title: Tel Aviv: Urban History and Culture
descrip: Offers a multifaceted exploration of the urban history of the city of Tel Aviv, founded in 1909 to be a Jewish suburb of the multiethnic port city of Jaffa. Tel Aviv has become a symbol for the Zionist movement's development and a space in which the meaning of Zionism has been continually contested. Through inquiries into urban studies, city planning, architecture, identity, space, politics, language, culture, and conflict in Tel Aviv and Jaffa we will use the prism of one metropolitan area to explore the history of Palestine and Israel in the twentieth and early twenty-first century.

title: What is Ballet?
descrip: See Freshman Seminar booklet or www.princeton.edu/pr/pub/fs/

title: Essayism: Trajectory of a Genre
descrip: With exemplary essayistic texts by European writers, this course explores issues including: hybridity, open-endedness, contingency, voice, form, rhetorical devices and style, humility, intuition, self-portraiture, possibilitarianism, virtuality, digression, the peripatetic tradition (walking and thinking), playfulness, and political engagement. We will read essays from a range of sub-categories (the familiar essay, the critical essay, the politically engaged essay, etc.), and will consider examples of essayistic poetry, the essayistic novel, and the photo-essai.

title: Topics in Critical Theory - Comparative Literature Dissertation Seminar
descrip: This seminar welcomes prospectus and dissertation writers. At our first meeting, we'll establish a weekly schedule for pre-circulating work; at each subsequent meeting, we'll offer feedback on prospectuses, chapters, and articles.

title: Gossip: Autobiographical Fiction from Vargas Llosa to Bolano
prereqs: A 200-level Spanish course or equivalent..
descrip: Thirty-five years ago, Vargas Llosa's La tia Julia y el escribidor had a cold reception because of its autobiographical content. Today Bolano's Los detectives salvajes, an autobiographical novel, is the most influential book in Spanish. Globalization, democracy, the rise of Latin America's middle classes, produced a different idea of what literature should say. Personal matters became public, politics private, nationalities indistinct and allegories hollow. We will read a series of intimate fictions in search of the traditions that interweave them, developing a corpus of ideas that can explain the reason for the success of this hybrid genre.

title: Neuroscience of Being Human, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Biological Physics
prereqs: PHY 203 or PHY 205.
descrip: The boundaries between traditional scientific disciplines have become extremely blurred. Some of today's most interesting scientific questions can only be addressed using techniques and concepts from more than one of the traditional sciences. As such, Biological Physics (or Biophysics or Physical Biology or any number of combinations of the words biology, physics, chemistry etc.) is one of the fastest growing areas in Physics. In this course, we will examine one of the central topics in biological physics, namely, how energy, force, and mechanics are used by living organisms.

title: Modern Korean History
descrip: A survey of modern Korean history. The main emphasis will be placed on the transformation witnessed in the twentieth century, and will cover the following major themes: modernism, colonialism (1910-1945), war (1950-1953), industrialization, and the politics of gender and class. Course materials include literary works, historical writings, and other cultural forms, such as art and film.

title: Quantum Mechanics
descrip: The physical principles and mathematical formalism of nonrelativistic quantum mechanics. The principles will be illustrated via selected applications to topics in atomic physics, particle physics and condensed matter.

title: Genetics
reviews: Be prepared for a lot of work, but this class can be fun if you like the subject matter.

Do ALL the problem sets, and really try doing them on your own before getting as a group. The hours you spend on it will really really pay off in the midterm and final. Do super well on the midterm, because that will be your saving grace for the overall grade, because the stuff you learn after the midterm is going to make the final a sh*tshow.
Do not take genetics with this set of instructors if you can avoid it. The class methodology needs to be completely revamped.
Do not take this course with other hard sciences; it needs to be made a priority if you want to do really well.
Don't take it if you're not a MOL- it's a TON of work. If you are a MOL, keep up with it.

Don't take it this course unless you are required to. I'll never understand the people who take this class for "fun" and P/D/F it; it's not even worth the effort. The amount of work you have to put into this class is unbelievable. Work with other people on problem sets; it will be the only thing to save you. Go to office hours if you can.
Don't take unless you have to.
Dont take it unless you have to. And make sure you have people to do the problem sets with.

Extremely interesting course. Beware though...Professor Rose's lectures are often impossible to understand and problem sets can be quite the struggle. Find a group to work with immediately and make sure you reach out to the professors and/or find a good TA that can answer your questions.
Get a good preceptor.
I would recommend putting in all your effort in problem sets as they really help during exam time. Also, don't miss lectures because they are very helpful!
If you are a MOL major, this will be the bane of your existence. But like Batman, you will be stronger for going through this.
If you have to take this class, then you probably had no choice. Good class, but make time for the ultra hard problem sets.
If you love molecular biology, you should take this course!
If you're taking this, you're probably a MOL major and have no choice... the material is interesting, and the lectures are helpful (if not quite ideal).

It's not as bad as everyone says, I actually enjoyed it a lot. I would recommend it for students outside of MOL as well (in EEB/CHM) who might benefit from learning the quantitative and qualitative aspects of genetics.
Know the problem set questions very well, because they constitute the entire exam.

Look over the lecture notes when available. You might have missed somethings. I did better after studying the lecture notes after each lecture. But if you are mol, you have no choice but to take this, or 3 neuroscience classes. This is the better option.
Only take it if you have to.
Only take this class if you absolutely have to. It's sad how they made such an interesting topic so inaccessible.
Really make sure you understand the lectures, there's really a ton of knowledge in them.
Run from this class if you are at all able.
Take advantage of office hours and the opportunity for teamwork on the problem sets
The course was well taught and the grading was fair. The problem sets are a lot of work but  the tests are fair. I would recommend it to anyone interested in the subject.
This class is tough, but interesting.

This class will teach you just how hard and complicated genetics can get. It's not at all happy fractions and Punnett squares. Still, really interesting. Also get friends to take it with you -- no way you can pull off the problem sets on your own in the second half of the course. Really pay attention in lectures.
Try and keep up during the lectures - they may go too quickly and you won't understand it.
Very poorly organized course. Nothing is ever posted online. But what does it matter? You're taking it because you have to. On the bright side, Prof Rose is a very engaging lecturer. Have fun :)
Work hard.
Work together with others
don't take it unless you have to because it is very hard and a HUGE time commitment.
don't take it unless you're a MOL major
don't take unless MOL major.
hard
prereqs: MOL 214 or 215 or by permission of instructor.
descrip: Basic principles of genetics illustrated with examples from prokaryote and eukaryote organisms with emphasis on classic genetic techniques. The evolving conception of the gene and genome will be the primary focus of the course. Selected advanced topics will include Drosophila developmental genetics, yeast cell biology and human disease.

title: International Monetary Economics
reviews: A good class to take to satisfy the Finance Certificate distribution; it's not very quantitative compared to some other 300 level ECO classes
A very good 300- level class. Though be really careful with the exams.
Attend lecture
Be prepared to wrap your head around a lot of theory, but if that comes easily to you, this class should be a breeze.
Buy an old copy of the textbook on Amazon for $10 and save yourself some money.
Definitely not a terrible econ departmental, and if you've taken international trade there are some similarities between the two.
Easy departmental.
Good class for what it's supposed to teach you.  Not terribly hard either.
Good economics course that is challenging but not too difficult. Especially good class to take for fulfilling finance certificate requirements.
Good, light work - if you need a course for finance certificate program go for it

If you are interested in international monetary economics, than you should take this course. Pretty easy overall, but the material is useful and interesting and Aguiar's lectures are pretty clear and interesting.
It's an interesting and current events subject matter, just a bit scattered in its presentation.
Just make sure to understand the models as professor presents them, the readings will help you but aren't the same.
Light workload. Professor Aguiar is very nice and humorous, but sometimes goes through stuff fast in lecture. Precept helps a lot. Don't buy the textbook, you don't need it.
Make sure you attend your precepts. It really helps to clear up the issues with problem sets and then you won't feel awkward when you ask your preceptor for help on the final paper
Not much
Not recommended. I guess it's easy though, if that's all that you're looking for.

Not the most interesting class you'll ever take by far - the average lecture was painfully boring - but the workload is so small that it might almost be worth taking anyway.  We had a total of 4 puny problem sets that took about 20min each, a short 5 page essay that came right out of the lecture notes, no readings (that I did anyway), and exams that were a piece of cake.  So as an extra class to not devote much work to, it's pretty good - and to be fair there is some really interesting and relevant material mixed into the boredom.

Out of the 10  economics classes I have taken, I enjoyed this the least. The course was disorganized and the lectures unclear. The material was uninteresting to me, although it wasn't very hard, so don't expect an easy A. The workload was light, however, and if you are interested in international economics or want a class to meet a requirement for the finance certificate that doesn't actually cover much finance, then take this course.
Pay attention in lecture and precept, and make sure you can connect the material to real life events.
Pretty easy econ class with little math. Not terribly interesting however.
Professor is a great person but the course itself is a bit a bit lacking
Study with friends, and think of the course on a macro level. It makes it far easier to pass.
Take a intro macro class before taking it
Take it if you're even vaguely interested, some fundamental stuff
Take it with Prof Aguiar. Great lecturer and Cao is great preceptor
Take it! Professor Aguiar is wonderful, and the subject matter is very interesting and relevant.
Take this class! Easy departmental. Great professor, very nice.
The class is relatively easy and an interesting overview of international and monetary economics.  It's well taught and the workload is manageable.
