The course covers monetary economics very well, but also overlaps a lot with macroeconomics. If you don't mind macro, then by all means take the class.
The midterm is really, really long so go through practice problem sets. Not much work but really understand lecture material. Qualitative but uses basic algebra to create models. Aguiar is hilarious
There are a lot more interesting options if you're looking for an econ class

There is not a lot of work (only 4 problem sets and a 5-page paper) and it is not that math-heavy, but don't let this fool you! I ended up having to PDF it (even though it would have counted as a departmental) because the material is super tricky (exchange rate movements, interest rates, inflation, bond prices, and more). I don't feel like what I learned in class helped or prepared me at all for doing the problem sets or midterm.
This class is in the middle of quantitative and qualitative courses. For that reason I would not take it, I cannot say I learned very much

This course is frustrating. It's a fairly superficial coverage of material, and if you want to really understand the theory, this is not the right class. That said, it's not particularly difficult, but not very satisfying either.
Very interesting material and Aguiar is a great lecturer.
Very interesting topic and Professor Aguiar is AWESOME.
good class even if not needed.
good econ class to take
if you are interested in international economics this is a good course to learn the basics if you aren't looking into specific countries.
take it aguiar is a great lecturer
prereqs: ECO 100 and ECO 101. Course not required for concentrators..
descrip: This course studies topics in open-economy macroeconomics and international finance. Topics include Exchange Rates, Inflation, Sovereign Debt, and Growth. The course will include economic theory as well as several applications. Applications include the growth miracles of East Asia, India's recent transformation, emerging market crises of the 1990s, aid and development in Africa, and international aspects of recent financial crises.

title: State Formation and Political Regimes
descrip: Course surveys major topics and theoretical contributions in the construction of political order, the choice of constitutional regimes and the sources of citizens? compliance. Course examines: the formation and development of the modern state; democracy; authoritarianism; revolution and political stability; legitimacy and compliance; nationalism; and macro theories of political change. With the explicit goal of exploring how research in comparative politics should be pursued in the future, each session assigns readings from both traditional macrohistorical and qualitative research and more recent analytical models.

title: Contemporary Critical Theories - Novel Theories
descrip: Novel theories, theories of the novel: "The novel" has been defined since its establishment as a literary genre in tension with both "romance" and "history." This year's seminar will interrogate this definitive tension among narrative genres through readings in two related forms of historical romance that contributed to the development of the novel: chivalric and gothic. Contemporary critical theories-contemporary to the primary texts as well as to ourselves-will accompany our readings in narrative.

title: Introductory Drawing
reviews: A good class to take if you think you are interested in art. Outside of class, you may have to come in to finish projects.
An entertaining class to fulfill an LA requirement.
Definitely take an art class at Princeton, in general - but preferably in something you haven't done before. It's an eye opener.
Definitely take it. You will enjoy it and you don't need to be the best artist to excel.
Even if you don't think you have any business in a drawing course, take this one.  If you love to draw this course is also perfect for you.
Great class with Nathan.
I LOVE Eve! She is such a great Professor, but be prepared to spend a lot of time in and out of class for this course.
Sketch a lot.
TAKE IT!

Take advice with a grain of salt but put a lot of effort into your work. Don't start over in the middle of your piece or you'll have two meh pieces instead of one piece that you pushed through the hard parts to finish.
Take it with Nathan Carter!
Take it.
Take this course if you want a fun, laid back art class.
You should really enjoy drawing to be able to get something out of the course.
good course. but is not a course to take if youre taking it as a slack off class. lots of hours are required.
honestly though, TAKE IT
descrip: This course approaches drawing as a way of thinking and seeing. Students will be introduced to a range of drawing issues, as well as a variety of media, including charcoal, graphite, ink and oil stick. Subject matter includes still life, the figure, landscape and architecture. Representation, abstraction and working from imagination will be explored. A structured independent project will be given at the end of the semester.

title: Responsible Conduct in Research: A Course on Ethics in Engineering (Half-term)
prereqs: This course is required for graduate students in engineering who participate in federally funded research; the course is highly recommended and/or required for undergraduate students as well as post-doctoral researchers in engineering who participate in federally funded research. There are no prerequisites for attending the course..
descrip: This course educates the graduate student of engineering in the responsible conduct of research. The lectures provide theoretical background information as well as case studies about ethics in day-to-day research situations, in publishing and peer-review, in student-advisor relationships, in collaborative research, as well as in the big picture and considerations of long-term impact. The students are provided with resources to consult in ethical questions. In small-group discussions in research field-specific precepts, the theoretical concepts are made relevant to the individual students situations.

title: Sexuality and Religion in America
descrip: Sexuality has long been a contested and contentious issue within American religions, yet only recently have scholars and practitioners begun to forthrightly address it. This course will explore the emerging literature on sexuality and religion as a way to understand how approaches to sex and sexuality within "sacred spaces" have shaped private behavior and public opinion. We will give particular attention to American Evangelical and Catholic religious expressions for the way they have been especially influential in framing (and inhibiting) sexual discourse and practices in the US and throughout the world.

title: Population, Society and Public Policy
reviews: Don't take it, population is an important topic but this course is all over the place, and I don't really know what I learned. I wish I had time to form my own opinions regarding the information we were presented, but so much was thrown at us, you basically just have to regurgitate exactly what is presented...
Extremely interesting - if you want to learn more about population studies and demography, try it out! Even if you're not sure what demography is!
Great Class. Great Professor

I highly recommend this course to both Woodrow Wilson School majors and other fields.  It is extremely useful in for any major because it discusses global trends and the reality of what is happening in today's world.  The readings are super interesting and very informative and the professor is very passionate and helpful with teaching students about this subject.  She is available to assist students in understanding.  Even the research paper is rather fun, because you are allowed to focus on your own topic of interest.  The class is small and provides great discussion opportunities.

I recommend this class to everyone. It is amazing how your reference frame changes thanks to this class. Now I see everything through the perspective of population, something that I had never considered before. This is the kind of class I expected to find at Princeton.
I would definitely recommend this course to other students. Very interesting material and I learned a lot! Professor Tienda is a very engaging lecturer!
One of the most practical classes ever.
Take it
Take it. It's a ridiculously intuitive class, and it should be an easy A.
The professor is a little eccentric, but it's a really interesting course. I'd take it again!
There is a lot of reading, and problem sets might be a little confusing for students but it is a great course overall.
descrip: This course focuses on the causes and consequences of population change and the policy levers used to regulate demographic behavior and outcomes. In addition to basic demographic concepts, measures and data, we will address questions such as: What is the carrying capacity the planet? Why has fertility declined in some countries but not others? How does population growth influence the environment? What does population aging portend for social security solvency? Can countries regulate international migration? Why does China have so many male births? Is marriage obsolete? Is urban life good or bad for your health?

title: Merton & King
descrip: This seminar focuses on the issue of social justice in the lives and thought of Thomas Merton, contemplative monk and Martin Luther King, Jr., activist civil rights leader, who both mounted major critiques of U.S. public policy in the 1960s. Despite biographical and vocational differences, their arguments significantly converged on issues of racism, poverty, and war. Through close reading and discussion of their major work, we will critically examine their proposals for radical social change.

title: The Hispanic World, 1400-1800
reviews: Definitely take this class!!!! Professor Beaver is a wonderful professor, the material is interesting, and I guarantee you will look forward to lectures and even precepts.  One of the best history classes I've taken. I really wish I had the opportunity to take more classes by Professor Beaver!

Definitely take this course if you have any interest in Spanish history (or European history in general) during this time period.  I came in with almost no prior knowledge and fell in love with the subject.  Professor Beaver is great - really engaged, intelligent, and funny.

Definitely take this course. It's a great History class for people who are not history majors or have never taken history before. Adam Beaver is patient and extraordinarily helpful. If you are a history major, then this class should be required. It's a great opportunity to learn a lot and generates a lot of broad topics that are useful if you're looking for JP topics.
Do the reading. It will clarify the lectures so much!

I strongly recommend this class!! It is specific enough that the information is not overly generalized, but it does give you a comprehensive image of Spain and its place in early modern Europe. Professor Beaver's lectures are very interesting.
If you like Spanish or Latin American history, take this course.
If you're interested in the subject material, go for it.

Keep up with the readings and come to all of the lectures - the lectures are crucial in understanding the course! Also, go to office hours, because Professor Beaver is really helpful and happy to answer any questions, especially with regard to your papers - if you are stuck or need help finding sources he is happy to sit with you and work it out.
Pay attention in class and read the assigned readings because that is the only way to learn the material.
Take the class. Professor Beaver is one of the best you will have at Princeton.

This is a great course on Spanish history, even if you have little to no prior experience. I really enjoyed this course - the subject matter is really interesting and Adam Beaver is a very knowledgeable, fun, and helpful professor. Knowing Spanish is helpful for working with primary sources for the papers, but it's really not necessary and no Spanish is assumed. Take this class if you like history or even if you need an HA - this is one of the best HAs I've taken!
prereqs: There are no prerequisites, though a basic familiarity with European and/or Latin American history may prove useful. Students prepared to read Spanish or Portuguese may choose to use foreign language materials in their assignments, but this is not required..
descrip: Long before Victorian Britain became synonymous with world empire, there was Spain. In the 16th century, the kingdoms of medieval Iberia banded together to forge the first global monarchy, reaching from Latin America to the Philippines--only to watch it disintegrate in the 17th and 18th centuries. Understanding Spain?s Golden Age is essential for interpreting not only the histories of modern Spain and Latin America, but also the history of the early modern world. Topics include the creation of Spanish identity; Christian, Muslim, and Jewish relations; the Renaissance; the governance of Empire; imperial decline; and the Enlightenment.

title: Seminar on Student Learning and Methods for Teaching
reviews: Consider taking this post-graduation. The observations are a huge requirement, and unless you have an easy semester, this course will very much overwhelm you in terms of hours off campus required.

Do not take other demanding courses in addition to this one; meticulously keep track of assignments, requirements, and observations/field work that seem to be thrown at you at random. Be as professional as possible at all times. Own a car.

It was a great course.  A person generally has the right ideas about education and about how to become a teacher, but this class very much refines those ideas and gives details and instructions about how to carry out the basic functions of teaching effectively and well.

I really wish that they had an additional class about the history and philosophy of teaching/education.  It would be so fascinating.  I wish that even though I can't take it since the class won't be offered in time, I wish that I could still be in the loop with that.
It's a great course, but be prepared to do lots of observations in local classrooms.
Stay ahead of assignments. In particular, take time to understand details.
prereqs: The course is required for students in the Program in Teacher Preparation and is open to non-program students provided space is available. Interested non-program students should contact the Teacher Preparation Office for permission to take the course..
descrip: A study of essential methods of learning and teaching, including learner characteristics and needs, organization and structure of educational institutions, development of curriculum and instructional goals, preparation of evaluation and assessment, and design of subject/level specific methodologies and classroom management techniques. Required course work includes 18 hours of site-based field experience and evening laboratory sessions.

profs.name: Rodolfo Antonio Rios Zertuche Rios Zertuche

title: Multivariable Calculus
reviews: ...Don't take the course unless you have to or just looooooooove calculus. I also don't suggest taking the course if you've already taken it because the stress isn't worth it and you could probably spend your extra course somewhere more worthwhile.
201 is tough, do psets with friends, don't worry about scores around 50% on quizzes or exams as they will be curved up to a B.
A great course for those who love the subject.
A lot of reading and practice problems needed outside of class.  Tough problem sets and exams - form a study group.

A substantial number of students taking this have already learned multi in high school, so the curve for the class will be high. The homework assignments are quite simple and do not take up much time, but the exam problems require more insight. Take many practice exams to prepare.
A very computational class. Wouldn't recommend for those actually interested in math.
Absolutely do not take if you are not interested in the sciences or engineering. Unless you really love math, it's not worth the time commitment.
Attend class. Study past exams posted on blackboard. Ask your professor questions if you're confused because content is cumulative.
Be prepared to think in 3 dimensions, thats the hardest part of this course
Be prepared to work hard.
Be sure to spend a lot of time doing past exams as that is the best way to prepare for tests.
Because tests are so much harder than any other material, the only way to study for them is to use past exams. I also found I understood class about 10x better by reading the book beforehand.
Challenging course if you don't learn all the concepts.
Definitely have a solid grasp of Calculus if you try this class as a Freshman. Everything builds off of it.
Do all of your assignments! The problems will come up on exams!
Do homework early. Read chapter before lecture. Will help so much. (If you haven't done multivariable calculus before)

Do not take this course unless you plan on majoring in mathematics or are required to take it for your major.  The material covered is not too difficult to manage, but quizzes and exams are completely different and it is extremely hard to do well on them.
Do the weekly problem sets, and be prepared to do terribly on midterms and finals.
Do your problem sets ahead of time and don't slack off during the second half of the semester because it really does get harder.
Do your problem sets as you cover the material in classes, or beforehand.

Don't be afraid to shop around for a good preceptor (I'd recommend Luc Nguyen, although others are good as well), stay on top of the material, and study for tests and quizzes far in advance. The old tests and quizzes on Blackboard are really helpful!

Don't fall behind. Read the math book before going to class. Do the problem set. Do the practice quizzes/tests, and just hope that you're smart enough to get enough points on the tests to get a good grade.
Don't get discouraged by the exams and keep at it!

Don't take the course if you're not interested in math or if you're not a quantitative person.  The exams are really hard.  Sometimes the time you spend on studying is not proportional to the outcome.  It's definitely been an interesting class and I've learned a lot, but it's not for everyone.  If you want to take the class, try to get Luc Nguyen.

Don't take this course unless you absolutely need to. The preceptors are generally really bad at teaching, even though they're really good at math. Make sure you understand the material early on and review very often; watch Adrian Banner's videos. Also if you get stuck with a bad preceptor, switch! It really influences your understanding of the material.
Don't unless you have to
Either go to lectures or read the book. Solve a lot of problems.

Expect to have to learn the material by yourself because you probably won't be able to learn it during class. The lectures go by unreasonably fast and for someone who hasn't learned multi before, it was all just a blur.
Find a good class time with a good teacher (such as Rio)

For a math course, Multivariable Calculus is surprisingly interactive.  I would definitely recommend forming a study group, as checking your answers to the homework problems is very invaluable, but as long as you have a reasonable understanding of basic, single-variable calculus, you shouldn't run into many problems.

For those who feel like that they are going to get an A in this course no matter what because they are math wizards, please don't take this course and bombard the grades of those like me, who are even struggling to understand some of the equations. Please, I beg you. Go away, you smarties, to MAT 203.
Get a good instructor. Go to office hours. Do not fall behind because it will build up and be hard, if not impossible, to catch up.
Get ready for it to go very fast-paced. Try going over the topic in your textbook before lecture, especially if you have not taken a multivariable class before.
Go to class and keep up with the material - ask questions as they come up.
Good course, but be aware that to do really well on exams, additional practice and studying are required. Problem sets are much easier than quizzes and exams.
Good luck.

Google Adrian Banner Review Session Math 201 and watch the videos. I'm not someone who can read math out of a textbook very well, and this helped tremendously with understanding the material. Lectures were verbatim out of the book and therefore not much help.
Great basic math class.
Harder than I expected, but probably more rewarding too.

Having taken multivariable calculus through Johns Hopkins CTYOnline during my senior year of high school and having done very well, I felt that I would be more than prepared for this course. However, I found myself taking a lot of time to learn this material via the textbook and the McGraw center. The main reason for this was that the textbook often didn't do enough to explain more complex problems that showed up on tests and even some of the homework. I took this course because I wanted to get a solid background in math and also because it is a distribution requirement for engineers (I am considering an ORFE major). This is a pretty standard multivariable course with regard to the material that is taught. If you have not had multivariable before, it will probably be a fair learning curve. I would strongly recommend that you do as much as you can to get a solid grasp of the material early on as that will enable you to have a better chance at succeeding in this course.
I enjoyed the course and the material was interesting.
I had a great preceptor but don't take it unless you have to or you have an interest in higher level math.
I recommend that anyone who takes this class should read the lessons ahead of time in order to keep up with the lectures in class.

I would advise another student taking this course to be sure to do all of the homework assignments, including the ones that are not graded, and to do them well-before the due date so that you have time to go to office hours if you have any questions.  I would highly recommend Professor Shah's section, as well.  When studying for exams, it is best to look at the examples in the book, the homework problems, and the old exams from previous years.

I would advise to go over calculus notation, do the homework that corresponds to a lecture the day of the lecture and make sure they understand it. If they don't, use online resources and get help from peers. Don't get behind because quizzes and tests sneak up on you.
I would not suggest this course unless you have to take it; if you can, and you want to understand why you're doing what you're doing, take 203.
I would recommend it, but not strongly.

I would recommend taking this course only if you are required to.  Otherwise I would recommend finding an alternative way of learning basic multivariable.  It's not worth the stress surrounding the examinations unless you need it.
I would recommend this course strongly. I cannot comment on other teachers, but I can say with certainty that Rodolfo was very helpful.

I would take it if you need to or have an interest in multivariable calculus. It is an interesting and useful topic in many fields, but if you are positive you will not need it then it might be best to avoid it and focus on learning what you really want to learn.
I'm only taking the class as a distribution requirement it was not interesting in any way.
If you are highly interested in math, go for it. If you are taking it to fulfill a distribution requirement, you should reconsider that decision. It is not easy.

If you are not an engineer, I would think very hard about whether to take this course. I had an interest in math and did very well in 103/104, but if you can't visualize in 3-D, this course is going to be ROUGH. It's a class that you need to put a LOT of time and effort into, so only take it if you have the time to devote to it.
If you are not happy with your instructor within the first week or so, switch out.  Having a clear instructor is crucial to doing well in the course.
If you don't need to take it don't bother.
If you enjoyed earlier calculus classes, you will enjoy this class.

If you have a math requirement, take it. I would very highly recommend it over 203, though I realize that for some people, especially majors, 203 is better for them. As an engineer with practical, applications focused approach in mind, this course made more sense
If you have to take it, take it; if you don't, I wouldn't recommend taking it.

If you need to take it: take it. If not go for a theoretical math course or 215 and such. The course is not very well-taught. However, you have the textbook to take care of yourself !
Good luck

If you're going to take MAT201, really pay attention to which instructor you end up with. I originally was in a class with an instructor who I did not like. I ended up switching into Luc Nguyen's class, because I heard good things, and he did not disappoint. Math at Princeton is hard enough, so it was a real blessing to have an instructor who cares so much about his students both in and outside the classroom. As much as I dislike math and found this course difficult, I enjoyed going to his office hours, because he was always willing to help, remembers your name, and even remembers and talks to you about the extracurriculars you do.
If you've never done anything like multi-variable calculus before, be prepared to be challenged and mind blown, but keep pushing to understand, and things will work out.
In retrospect, I would not have taken this course if it were not a prerequisite.
It is a challenge, but if you put in the time outside of class and make sure you ask questions when you don't understand you should be able to do well.
It is a fair course.
It is a hard, poorly taught course.  A real first-semester ruiner.
It is a requirement and there's no way to place out of it, but try to approach your professor as much as you can one on one instead of in class.

It is difficult, but worthwhile. Devote study time to actually understanding the fundamentals and concepts of what the math is doing, not just memorizing formulas. This is the key to the tests (which are worth 75% of the grade).

It's a pretty standard math class. Required for BSE so expect a bit of competition. Other than that, the material is pretty interesting at face value but becomes a huge burden come exams. The problem sets are short and simple, but exams are much more difficult and competitive.
It's a requirement.
It's an interesting class that teaches the material. You don't learn everything as well as in 203, but if you're interested in math, I'd suggest this course, even if you're not an engineer.
It's extremely challenging but very stimulating!
It's fine. Not too difficult.
It's hard.
It's manageable if you're good at math. Not particularly fascinating otherwise
It's quite difficult math.
Keep up with the work, and make friends. Math is a lot easier to understand when you are working on it with other people.
Learn as much as you can - and practice theory - because tests will test your understanding of the material in really weird and creative ways.
Learn how to work quickly.
Make sure to take a lot of practice tests before midterms and finals.
Make sure to work hard if you want to take this course.
Make sure you do lots of practice problems and read the book.
Make sure you find a good preceptor. It will help you.
Make sure you give it time, especially if you aren't great at math. Don't fall behind because it's impossible to try and relearn it later.  Learn the concept, not the equation.
Make sure you understand everything thoroughly.
Make sure you understand the concepts as the course goes along, as they are cumulative. Additionally, it helped me a lot to watch the Adrian Banner videos.
Make sure you understand the homework

Many example problems are given in class, so lecture is helpful for learning the material. The majority of exam/quiz problems are harder than homework problems, though  exams sometimes include a problem that is similar to a hw question.
Many people in the class have already taken multi, so if you haven't, be prepared to work hard.

Most of the students taking this will be engineers who need to fulfill the requirement, but if you like math and would like to learn more math on a less rigorous level, this would be a good course to take.

Most of you will be taking this as a requirement.  It's a tough course.  Make sure to do all the homework (don't skip any problems b/c to me it happened that one of the problems I skipped on the homework ended up being on the midterm!!)  Also don't only study on the day before the final or midterm.  Oh and the midterm and final are really hard.  Have fun.
Most students have to take this class, but it is very useful and can be interesting.
Not too exciting, take it if you have to

Odds are you are probably required to take this course. Don't worry too much about it, it is definitely doable. I had taken multi in high school, but that course was badly structured. This course definitely gave me a much stronger grasp on many fundamental concepts. If you just want to take it for fun, this is probably the easiest multi course, but I don't know enough about 203 or 218 to compare how well they are taught.
Only take if you have to.
Only take it if you need to, otherwise, don't.
Only take this class if it's required.

Only take this class if necessary. If you can, get into Shrenik Shah's section - he is an amazing teacher and helped me pull up my grade for the class from a C  to a B  - after TWO DAYS of helping me review. If you don't have him, go to his office hours. Also, I hear the Adrian Banner videos are really helpful and great.

Only take this course if you are very interested in math.  The tests are more difficult than what the lectures and problem sets prepare you for.  You have to put a lot of time into this class if you have not taken multivariable calculus before in order to do well.
Only take this if you like math or have to take it as BSE.  Prepare to teach yourself almost everything.  McGraw tutors are really helpful too.
Pay attention during lecture.
Practice old exam questions.
Read before class.
Read every page of the textbook very closely.
Read the book and think of things geometrically.

Read the book before class and don't fall behind in the material. Also, make a study guide as you go along of all of the important theorems so that all of the course material is condensed into one place when you study for the midterm / final.
Read the book!
Read the chapter in the textbook the day before the teacher explains it to you, not the other way around.
Read the relevant chapters before lecture because occasionally I would sit there slightly lost.
Read the textbook and study before coming to class. It helps you learn better.
Read the textbook before coming to class.

Read the textbooks before going into lectures. The examples that they show in class are exactly from the textbook. Quizzes and exams are much harder than homework. So study well ahead of time for those in preparation.
Really try to understand the concepts as they come, read the textbook at home, and ask questions!
Review often and go to office hours!
Seriously consider MAT 203 if you have any desire for the material to be presented in a stimulating fashion. Be prepared to work very hard in 203 though.

Since there are 6 professors, which you get will completely change your view of the class. Make sure you shop as much as possible with professors so that you get an optimal situation, or else you get stuck teaching yourself.
Solid class, try to find a good teacher. Grading wise, the tests are hard, but the curve makes it not so bad. If you like math, take it, but if not, this might not be your best choice.
Stay on top of the homework - do it throughout the week instead of saving it for Sunday night!
Study a lot; the exams are much harder than the homework
Study from the books, get the distribution requirement out of the way
Study hard and keep up with your work or you'll suffer terribly.
Study hard!
Study harder and do more practice for the exams.
Study.
Study. Take this course with Rodolfo.
Take MAT 103 AND 104 at Princeton before taking this class.
Take as many practice exams as possible and go to office hours when you need help!
Take if you love math enough or if required. Also, pay attention in class!
Take it - make sure you get a good professor, READ THE BOOK, and be prepared for a challenging final exam!

Take it if you have to for a requirement. If you don't have to take this class, but are rather just interested in math from high school, then seriously reconsider going straight into 201. There's a lot of people who kill the curve.
Take it if you have to or if you like calculus, but study hard for the quizzes and exams. Take lots of practice ones.
Take it if you have to.  Don't if you dont.

Take it if you need it for a departmental. The class is not super interesting and if you can learn on your own time by reading textbooks then you might as well do that instead of attending class (though you should hand in homework every Monday). Know concepts but practice a LOT for the exams by doing as many practice tests as you can.
Take it if you need to, but not because you think it'll be interesting. Especially coming from high school, where I had really passionate and dedicated teachers, this was quite a disappointment.
Take it if you need to. If not, don't bother, unless you have Rodolfo, who is awesome.
Take it if you're an engineer because you have to. The pace of the course is fast, but if you get a good instructor and go to office hours you'll be fine.
Take multi beforehand. You won't regret it.
Take this class if you have some experience with multi. If you don't have any, it's a little harder but not impossible if you put the work in.
Take this class if you want to. Make sure you end up in a class with a good instructor review.

Take this class. Multivariable is a beautiful subject, because it comes together so beautifully. Especially if you're an engineer, you see all its possible applications, and it's always great to see how useful what you're learning is in real life.
Take this course as a requirement and find a great instructor just as I was able to luckily get.
Take this course if you have to and its fine.  However if you don't have to take it, I wouldn't recommend it.
Take this course if you must.
Take this course if you want to be challenged a little more than you need to be. This class isn't a requirement for anyone, so if you enroll, be prepared to be among very smart people.
Take this course only if it is a requirement for a major or certificate program you are interested in. It is a very time consuming and rigorous course.

Take this course only if you have to as a requirement. And make sure you allot a significant amount of time to study for exams by doing as many practice tests as possible; they are far more difficult than the homework.
Take this course!
Take this if you are good at 3-d stuff.
The class is very difficult, but necessary to take if you are a prospective engineer.
The course itself is pretty good but you really have to know what you are putting yourself into before you start. It is a tough trip.
The material is very important to learn especially if you are entering the sciences/engineering. But, don't underestimate the difficulty of the exams (much harder than the problem sets).

The quizzes and exams are much harder than the weekly homework assignments. If you've taken AP calc, you should be fine if you read the textbook and understand the material. Going to class is not necessary.
The rest of your courses must be fairly easy as a tremendous amount of time needs to be put into this course outside of the classroom in order to even understand what is happening.
The tests are much more difficult than the problems sets or anything presented in the book.
The weekly workload for the course is not too heavy but the most time is put in to study for the midterms and finals. But overall it's a nice class to take if you're interested in math.
They should do the reading before class.
This class is challenging.  If you are willing to put in work, you'll get a good grade
This class is definitely a challenge, but it is very well run and executed. I enjoyed it.

This class is fairly straightforward and manageable if you stay on top of your assignments.  The class starts out pretty easy and gets more and more complicated until it culminates in the mystifying and and somewhat counterintuitive chapter 16.  I never went to office hours, but that might've helped, especially Rudolfo's.
This class is not fun. Do not take it if you don't have to.
This class is very difficult. Prepare yourself.
This course will teach you the fundamentals. It is smart to study a bit beyond the assigned text problems to be more prepared for exams.

This is a challenging course. You need to look at past exams to prepare for exams because the problem sets are nowhere near enough. The concepts are pretty straightforward but you need to know them very well so you can apply them when the time comes.

This is a good course to take to fulfill your QR requirement. Many of my friends thought multi was a fairly pointless subject though in that it wasn't relevant to their careers. I didn't think it was too bad.

This is a great class and a lot will be learned. It is important to study from the beginning and understand what is taught in the beginning of the course very well because everything builds up and the end is much harder than the first couple of weeks. It is well taught and review sessions help for exams. Doing the homework will definitely help especially if it is done without looking to the book for assistance.

This is a great, challenging course. If you keep up with your work, you will never feel lost. And in the rare case that you do, there will be always be someone to guide you on your way. Go to office hours, seriously!
This is your standard Multivariable class.  The exams and exam curves can be quite brutal.  Take the class if you need it, otherwise there is no real reason.

This math class is probably harder than the level of classes you took in high school. The problem sets aren't adequate to prepare for the assessments; take advantage of office hours. The quizzes and exams are difficult but that gives you a generous curve. Most people end up earning around a B. Everyone should take calculus!

Try to get Fabio as your preceptor; he is one of the very best. Use the old exams and quizzes on Blackboard, and do as many of the problems in the textbook as you can in addition to the assigned problem sets. Use office hours if there is a concept that is hard to understand.
Understand everything before going to the next lesson.
Use all the practice tests online, especially for quizzes and tests, to further learn the material and become faster at doing questions.
Very useful material.
Visualization in 3D space is an integral part of this course. Be prepared to use your imagination and "see things in your head."
Watch Adrian Banner videos
Watch Adrian Banner's videos instead of going to class. Be prepared for the exams to be extremely difficult and perhaps not at all like the practice exams. Cry.
Watch the online videos by Adrian Banner - they're probably the most helpful tool for this class!
Well, this is a required course. Very poor teaching quality. Ended up teaching myself all of it.
Work hard. Don't fall behind.
Yes take it, but make sure to read the text.
Yes, I feel this would be better than MAT 203
You are expected to read the textbook before coming to class.
You need to put in a significant amount of time to do well in this course.
You should take it if you like calculus.
if you like the subject you should totally go for it
study your ass off
prereqs: MAT 104 or equivalent..
descrip: Vectors in the plane and in space, vector functions and motion, surfaces, coordinate systems, functions of two or three variables and their derivatives, maxima and minima and applications, double and triple integrals, vector fields and Stokes's theorem.

title: Los Angeles: Architecture, Mobility and Motion Pictures
reviews: A good historical overview.
I strongly recommend Jean-Louis Cohen to future students. He is a trully unique professor
descrip: The seminar will discuss both historical texts, designs and plans, and recent interpretations of Los Angeles as a global physical and cultural construct, studying the modes of construction of the main urban systems, from the wider features of the metropolitan landscape to the highways, the typical building programs and the architectural attitudes. The model represented by the city and its diffusion beyond the boundaries of Southern California will be analyzed, as well as the patterns according to which fiction, film, art and architecture have interacted to create specific Angeleno myths and cultures.

title: Shades of Passing
descrip: This course studies the trope of passing in 20th century American literary and cinematic narratives in an effort to re-examine the crisis of identity that both produces and confounds acts of passing. We will examine how American novelists and filmmakers have portrayed and responded to this social phenomenon, not as merely a social performance but as a profound intersubjective process embedded within history, law, and culture. We will focus on narratives of passing across axes of difference, invoking questions such as: To what extent does the act of passing reinforce or unhinge seemingly natural categories of race, gender, and sexuality?

title: Introduction to Chemical Engineering Principles
reviews: All potential CBE students have to take this class, so don't really sweat it. It's not great, but you have to take it so suck it up.

Although this is the intro to CBE class, the material you learn is really just a very basic aspect of CBE. It's boring for the most part, but when the guest lecturers came in to explain all the cool things you can do with CBE, it made me want to stick with the major. Don't let this class completely deter you from CBE, it will get more interesting.
Be prepared to work very hard.
Be ready for hard work and challenging problems but stay on top of the readings, get help, review well and look for extra problems and you will finish the course
Conceptually not a difficult class. The challenge is mainly in carrying out calculations correctly. Material isn't fascinating, but necessary for the major.
Don't judge CBE as a major based on this course.
Even though it's a pain walking to Friend, go to the precepts and get the majority of your homework finished then. The preceptors are very nice about answering questions.
Go to the optional precepts on Thursdays, they help with homework.

I would recommend always working with groups and making sure your work is pristine otherwise you will get hammered by the graders. Also, if you don't like chemistry, this course isn't for you. Its chemistry without biology.

I wouldn't take it... unless youre ready to hate engineering. This class would be much better with a new professor, which it DEFINITELY NEEDS. 

Otherwise, if its a distribution requirement, be prepared to deal with an entirely frustrating class.

I'd only suggest taking the course if you really want to do a LOT of balances (figuring out quantities and flow rates of substances in a system, as well as their energies). Also, the department may be CBE, but the course has nothing to do with biology. It doesn't really relate to gen chem/AP chemistry either, though. Lectures are dull, so I wouldn't suggest taking the course unless you are seriously considering being a chemical engineer.

If a student is interested in chemical and biological engineering, he or she should definitely take this class. Not only is specific material taught, but one also has the opportunity to learn about many different aspects of the major.
If you can, get a good group to do projects with. And go to the precepts: they are enormously helpful for solving the homework and project problems!
If you need to take the course or want to get a feel for CBE, take the course. It does teach you well. Otherwise, I'm sure there are other, more interesting courses out there.

If you take this course before deciding fully whether you want to do CBE, remember that this is not representative of the rest of the courses in the department.  This class sucks, a lot, but if you manage to follow along in lecture and put in the time to go over the readings and look at example problems, you will be fine.
It might not be the greatest representation of the actual major but it is a very engaging and enjoyable class.
It's not as easy as some may make it seem.
It's ok. make sure you work in groups from the very beginning!

Just read the book before and the notes after every lecture, understand all homework problems even if another group member did most of one. Do extra problems not assigned to help you have a more rounded understanding.
Keep up with the material!
Learn Mathematica. It saves countless hours on projects.
Lot of hard work--soooo many projects!!!
Not too challenging, just make sure you go to lecture and keep up.
Only take if you have to.
Only take the course if you are a prospective Chem-E major.
Only take this course if you are a CBE major.
Only take this course if you are definitely considering majoring in Chemical Engineering. Otherwise, it is not enjoyable.

Please take this course if you are interested in Chemical Engineering, but don't be discouraged if you find it dry. Many of us do, but we are looking forward to the classes we will take as upperclassmen.

READ THE BOOK before the corresponding lecture, it will immensely help with understanding. Find a group early to start working with because that will be essential to your problem sets, group projects, and studying for midterms and finals. However, ultimately it comes do wn to your individual understanding of the subject matter when finals rolls around.
Read the book before going to lectures. Then Priestley's notes will be really easy to understand. It helps you stay on top of the class too.
Read the textbook!! It helps a lot.
Stay on top of problem sets, read the textbook (it's quite helpful), and attend lectures and precepts.
Stay on top of the work and don't procrastinate
Take it because you are a CBE student and you have to, but otherwise, don't bother.
Take it if you are interested in majoring in CBE. Go to homework precepts and stay on top of the reading
Take it if you have to, but it does not give you a good picture of CBE.
Take it if you need to but don't use it to judge whether or not you like the department.
Take it only if you want to be a chemical engineer. Unfortunately, if you are taking it to gauge your interest in the subject, it will not be very interesting.
Take obviously if you're a CBE major only.

The course wasn't my favorite, but it was one of my easier courses and I didn't mind it too much.  I have heard this course isn't representative of the CBE major (including later courses and jobs later on) so don't let this course discourage you from pursuing a CBE major.
The exams can be rather time pressured so make sure you prepare for this.  Also, go to precepts.

The main thing you should understand before starting the course is that it utilizes very little actual chemistry (a fact i found disappointing).  In some regards it is more like a thermodynamics course; in the second half of the semester there is a large emphasis on energy and the behavior of gases and vapors.  Finding a good group to study with is essential for the class, especially because it tends to be rather results-oriented.  Partial credit is given, but the final value you get matters a lot when your work is being graded.  A lot of prospective majors, myself included, decided to switch out of chemical engineering after taking the class, but if you really think chemical engineering is for you, don't hesitate to enroll.
The material is not especially difficult but you should put time into learning it.
The work can be tedious, but it's important to make sure you understand the material.
This class rewards hard work.  If you put in the time and effort, you'll do well.
This course is not difficult but do not put it off just because it is! I had to work much harder in the second half of the semester to catch up sometimes.
This course is probably not the most exciting course, but the professor is very good and you will learn a lot about chemical engineering if you go to class and pay attention.

This is an excellent class to take first semester freshman year if you are interested in being a CBE major.  It will help you decide early in your college career if CBE is really the department for you.  It is also a relatively easier class with less work than most engineering/science classes, so it's a good class for your transition year.
Unless this course is required, don't take it
just tough it out.
prepare yourself for long problem sets and hard problems that are very involved
well it's only for CBE potential major students
you have to take it. I dont have any adice for you.
prereqs: CHM 201.
descrip: Introduction to chemical engineering analysis and computations. Course starts with unit conversions and conventions for representing processes and process variables in engineering calculations. Continues with methods for generating flow sheets and analyzing mass balances both with and without chemical reactions. Rules associated with energy conservation and energy balance calculations in non-reacting and reacting systems are also covered. Ultimately, full process calculations, including chemical reactions with energy changes and multiphase systems are covered.

title: Environmental Fluid Mechanics
reviews: Just stay on top of the material and use all the resources provided. If you're ever confused just email Eli because the rest of the class is probably pretty confused about that same point too.
Ok course. Great professor.
Professor Bou-Zeid presents the material in a very clear and engaging manner and makes the application of prior Fluid Mechanics knowledge interesting and enlightening.
This is a great course for CEE majors.
descrip: The course starts by introducing the conservation principles and related concepts used to describe fluids and their behavior. Mass conservation is addressed first, with a focus on its application to pollutant transport problems in environmental media. Momentum conservation, including the effects of buoyancy and earth's rotation, is then presented. Fundamentals of heat transfer are then combined with the first law of thermodynamics to understand the coupling between heat and momentum transport. We then proceed to apply these laws to study air and water flows in various environmental systems, with a focus on the atmospheric boundary layer.

title: The History of the Book in China
descrip: The course offers a comprehensive history of books in China, with reference to relevant developments in Korea and Japan and to parallels in the West, from the advent of actual books in East Asia during the first millennium BCE until the introduction of virtual books at the end of the 20th century. It covers the physical evolution of traditional Chinese books as well as their crucial role in the transmission of text and knowledge throughout China's long and complex history. Visual images and actual specimens will be used to reinforce presentations and stimulate discussion.

title: China in the Age of the Qianlong Emperor
descrip: This seminar will provide an immersion in the world of China in the 18th century through a concentration on the life and reign of Hongli, the Qianlong emperor (1711-1799). We will examine life in the Forbidden City, the tasks of being emperor, his family, the geographical expansion of the empire into the West, the production of court art, the emperor's journeys to central China, his summer palaces, how he controlled his officials and suppressed rebellion, his many portraits, and his belief in Tibetan Buddhism. We will read a variety of works, primary and secondary, Chinese and foreign, look at images, and make fieldtrips to museums.

title: Topics in American Statesmanship - The Founders in Comparative Context
reviews: Amazing material, fascinating topics and ways to think about them, but the discussions/papers didn't always entirely reflect those things.
Anyone interested in American history or political leadership would find this class enjoyable.

Do the reading and engage in class discussion. Also, I would have done better on the midterm if I had thought of a way of framing my ideas with a thesis and conclusion instead of reproducing all the information I could think of. For the final paper, write about something that you find exciting.
Read everything you can and really challenge yourself to understand the principles being taught.
Strongly recommend. All the best aspects of history and political theory rolled into one course.

Sugrue is the best professor at Princeton.  

Take this class.  You will learn so much about America and about the world.  The readings are amazing - do them all.
Take this course! Do all the readings!
With this professor, definitely do it.
descrip: This course will examine the Founders of the American political order and compare them with the more contemporary founders of other political traditions. We will study the political thought and political careers of George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, John Adams, Alexander Hamilton, and James Madison, and, among the non-Americans, Mohandas Gandhi, Che Guevara, Nelson Mandela, Vaclav Havel, and Lee Kwan Yew. Particular attention will be paid to the transition from the revolutionary turmoil of the late 18th century to legitimate government of the early 19th century, and then to the contemporary demands of political statesmanship.

title: Governance as Culture
descrip: This course examines debates about practices and discourses of governance. While focusing on China, Japan, and Korea, we will cover broader literatures on state-society relations, identity, and global institutions to consider the social and cultural implications of political change. We will also survey interpretive and ethnographic methods in comparative political inquiry.

title: Developmental Biology
descrip: Selected topics in the cell biology and development of multicellular organisms, with an emphasis on basic principles and underlying molecular mechanisms. Topics include gradients and pattern formation during embryogenesis, receptors and intracellular signaling, cell motility and cell movements, neuronal pathfinding and patterning in the vertebrate neural tube, redundancy and genomic redundancy. Classes center on critical reading of the primary literature.

title: Intermediate Arabic I
reviews: Arabic is a difficult yet rich language. Make sure you master the basics and constantly review them.

Arabic is a hard but very interesting language.  Because there are so many dialects in the real world, we have to study Standard Classical in the classroom, which can be frustrating because sometimes it feels like we're learning a language that nobody speaks, but in the end you have to look at it like hardcore background work for when we enter the real world and start speaking the dialects.
Arabic is awesome.  Professors are awesome.  Take it.
Be prepared to commit time to this class.  If you do, Arabic is a very rewarding language, and Tarek is a fantastic professor.

Be willing to study a lot. If students wish to become conversational by the end of this course, they need to do much more than simply the homework assignments and what's expected in the class. Outside of the classroom, students must constantly practice speaking and reviewing to retain the language.
Brush up on your Arabic from last semester during the first week of class. Will help a lot.
I love Tarek.
I would highly recommend it. I enjoyed coming to class every day. I learned a lot and had fun.

I would strongly recommend this course because it provided great instruction of the Arabic language and furthered our ability to speak, read, write, and listen to the language with good comprehension.  It is a really fun course and increases proficiency!  The work isn't too difficult to keep up with and the professors are always ready to help.
Make sure to attend all class sessions or otherwise, you will get quite behind.
Take his class! He is amazing. The best professor I have ever had.
Ustaadh Tarek is AMAZING. Take ARA 105 with him.
prereqs: ARA 102 or the equivalent..
descrip: This course builds on the skills developed in Elementary Arabic. Students in this course work to improve their proficiency in reading and writing as well as functional communication: vocabulary building, grammar acquisition, and discussion of general topics. We will focus primarily on Modern Standard Arabic in reading and writing, but dialectical forms will be used in informal speaking and listening exercises.

title: Mid-Infrared Technologies for Health and the Environment
reviews: If you are doing research in MIRTHE, you should really take this class. Make sure you work on the final paper early on! Otherwise the work can get overwhelming over break.
Take it.
descrip: This course is designed to give Juniors, Seniors, and interested graduate students a comprehensive and interdisciplinary introduction into mid-infrared sensing, its applications, and its technological foundations. Topics include: materials, light sources, lasers and detectors for the mid-infrared; spectroscopy and sensing; sensing systems and sensor networks. It addresses such important issues as global warming, policy making, engineering solutions to global challenges, environmental sensing, breath analysis and health applications, and sensing in homeland security.

title: Beginner's Italian I
reviews: An excellent course with a regular but easily manageable workload. The quizzes were regular and fair and going to class everyday was very fun. Definitely the best of all the languages to take.
As long as you do the homework and pay attention, the course is very easy and understandable.
Definitely take it!

Do not hesitate to take this course! Prof. Teardo is fantastic, incredibly helpful, and cares about every student. This class sparked in me a love of Italian language and culture, and I will definitely continue studying Italian in years to come.
Do the homework.
Go to class, and participate as much as possible while trying to have fun with it.
I enjoyed this class and I feel like I learned quite a lot in a short amount of time. There was a lot of homework, which is to be expected in a language course but is nevertheless annoying.
I would advise students to make sure to stay up on the grammar.
I would recommenced taking Italian. Although it is an easy class, doing well on the quizzes is essential, so be sure to keep up with concepts/assignments.
I would recommend practicing speaking outside of the classroom.

I would strongly recommend this course for any student interested in learning a new language.  If you put the work into it, this course is very rewarding in how much you will learn in a short amount of time.
I would tell the student to enjoy every moment! It was the most entertaining and interesting course I took my first semester.
If you are interested in the Italian language, do it! It is not very intensive for gaining a ton of knowledge.
If you're looking to start a new language, this class moves at a very manageable pace, but by the end of the semester you really will feel like you can speak basic Italian.
It's awesome! Take it Italian is a beautiful language and very fun to learn. The department is great and the class is not too difficult if you are looking to start a new language.
Italian 101 is a great course and Professor Spinazzi is a great teacher. I learned a lot taking this class and enjoyed it as well.
PHENOMENAL
TAKE THE COURSE!
Take Professor Spinazzi! I loved her and she was super helpful.
Take a chance.  Study something (like Italian) that you've never tried before.  It's a short time and you'll be glad you branched out in the long run.
Take it if you just want to get your language out of the way. Fun and the professors are all chill.
Take it! It's a beautiful language that Princeton makes easy and actually pretty fun to learn.
Take it! It's not very difficult, you'll learn a lot, and it's really fun--totally worth going to class every day.
Take it, this is a lot of fun
Take it. I've taken otehr intro language courses at Princeton, but this is definitely the best
Take this course!!
The Italian professors are incredibly friendly.  The classes are small, so you get to know the other students.  You will definitely learn some basic Italian.

The course requires quite a bit of time to be put into it, as it is a 100-level language course. Furthermore, in my experience, there seems to be some difficulty on the part of the professors in teaching around the barriers that non-native speakers have for languages, though they do make a great effort to do so.

This class was actually my absolute favorite of the semester and made me want to continue with the language. I even found myself procrastinating on my other homework with Italian work because I enjoyed it so much.
This course is amazing! I strongly recommend you to take this course, because the professors are very talented at teaching italian, and it is so much fun!
Try to study ahead so you can be prepared in-class because you will be called on against your will quite often so know your stuff.
take it with stoyanova if you can she's wonderful!!!!!!!!
take this, its awesome
prereqs: No credit given for ITA 101 unless followed by ITA 102..
descrip: To develop the skills of speaking, understanding, reading and writing Italian. The main emphasis is on oral drill and conversation in the classroom. Aspects of Italian culture and civilization will be touched upon.

title: Political Economy
reviews: Do not take it unless you must.
Dry, but requirement. Having Game Theory before this really helps.
Good for social science majors, due to bridging observable theories back to math.
I didn't love the class during, but am happy to have learnt the material
If you do take this class be prepared for some tedious algebra on the problem sets but professor Rohmer is great and lectures are interesting.

If you're interested in thinking about political science in a formal and structural way but lack a strong math background, this is the class to take. If you have a stronger background in math and game theory, the course will be very easy but still very interesting, a perfect 'easy 4th' or 'easy 5th'
Interesting, explains succinctly why we can't have nice things in politics.
Okay course, frustrating

Take this course if it's a requirement and/or if you enjoy game theory and mathematical modeling of politics. Not an easy class for someone if you have not taken previous courses in mathematical modeling and/or game theory.
Take this course if you need to. Otherwise, you can get the substantive points from other courses about game theory and inequality; taking them to their mathematical expression isn't worth it.
Take this course if you're looking for a chill, fifth class.

Take this course if you're not averse to doing some math & if you are interested in quantitative analysis of various political phenomena such as redistribution, central banking and economic development.
The class was very thorough and well taught. The midterm and final were very similar to the problem sets. If you're interested in political economy this is a good course.
The material is fantastic but not too difficult which makes the curve on the problem sets and tests quite challenging.
do it as junior or senior, when you have acquired the necessary skills to fully appreciate it
don't take it unless you really wanna be polecon.
prereqs: ECO 100, ECO 101, MAT 103.
descrip: Examines the role of political institutions in facilitating or hindering economic prosperity. We start with the basic tools of political economy - collective action, elections, and delegation. These tools are then applied to the problems of controlling rulers, and the persistence of inefficiency.

title: Topics in Spanish Civilization of the Golden Age - Gastronomy in Spanish Literature
reviews: Find the most relevant readings to do, find interesting topics for your essays.
If you have interest in food, take this class!
It is a great deal of reading but the classes are all centered on discussion of topics that are indicated as interesting by the students.
It is a very challenging course and you should have a very good grasp of speaking and reading spanish.
Never take this class unless you'd like your Spanish skills to worsen.
Take it if Surtz is teaching. Be prepared to carry around a giant, expensive Pequod
Take this course if you are looking for a 300 level Spanish course. It's not too bad. I enjoyed it! Though, Surtz grades a bit hard. But whatever -- that wasn't really a big deal.
Take this course!
Take this course, but be ready for the readings assigned because they are challenging.
This is a great class! Professor Surtz is funny and interesting and brings food to class on several occasions! Your Spanish might not improve, though.
prereqs: A 200-level Spanish course or equivalent..
descrip: Cuisine is always more than nutrition; it functions as an agent of identity at both the regional and the national level. Moreover, gastronomy intersects with other manifestations of culture such as painting, literature, medicine, and religion. Readings, in addition to cookbooks, handbooks of table manners, and medical treatises, will include literary texts ranging from medieval to Golden Age to modern.
